name: Martin SCHULZ
text: Ladies and gentlemen, at the beginning of our meeting today - in consultation with the President of the European Council, Donald Tusk, and the President of the European Commission, Jean-Claude Juncker, and because all three institutions are present this morning - to commemorate the 60th anniversary of the uprising of the Hungarian people against the Soviet dictatorship. On Monday of this week 60 years ago, an uprising began that lasted for weeks and cost an infinite number of victims. The Hungarian people rose up against foreign rule and a dictatorship that was unbeatable in brutality and ruthlessness. The heroic struggle of the Hungarians against the Soviet occupiers has not been forgotten. The example set by the Hungarians in 1956 was not without consequences. The heroic struggle of the Hungarians was an encouragement for many, many people - not only in Hungary but also in other Warsaw Pact countries - to stand up against the Soviet dictatorship. The Hungarian uprising was not the first, but it was one of the most important. In the end, the Hungarians' struggle for freedom was successful, albeit after decades of oppression. Without the courage of 1956, the courage of the late 1980s and the courage to open the border with Austria through Hungary in 1989 would have been inconceivable. What united the Hungarians in 1956 and 1989 was the desire to return to Europe as a people. When Gyula Horn cut the border fence in 1989, he was asked: You have now chosen between the West German and the East German state? His answer was: No, we chose Europe. In this sense, the struggle for liberation from oppression in all Eastern European countries - inspired by the courageous struggle of the Hungarians - has always been a struggle for Europe too. I had the opportunity this morning to talk to Donald Tusk, who himself was imprisoned in the 1980s as a resistance fighter against such a regime and therefore - out of personal concern - has a special solidarity with the Hungarian people.As the Parliament of the European Union, I believe that on this day we will send our greetings of solidarity to Hungary and remind you that many, many men and women who fought against the Soviet dictatorship had to flee and as Hungarians who fought for freedom,Were accepted as refugees in other countries.With this in mind, I hope that on your behalf I have expressed solidarity with Hungary.(Loud applause)

name: Martin SCHULZ
text: As announced on Monday, I referred the Advisory Committee on the Members' Code of Conduct about the dispute that had taken place between two Members of our House, Mr Steven Woolfe and Mr Mike Hookem. I have asked the committee to deal with this matter as a matter of urgency. The Advisory Committee sent me its recommendation. He has come to the conclusion that the facts are described very differently by the two members and that there seem to be no eyewitnesses to the incident. The Committee therefore stresses that, given the seriousness of the incident - it involves physical violence - and the possible criminal consequences, further investigations are needed to resolve the matter. I have therefore decided to follow the recommendation of the Advisory Committee and refer the incident to the relevant French authorities. I referred the matter to the prosecutor. On the basis of the results of the investigation, I will take a decision on any sanctions in accordance with Rule 166 of the Rules of Procedure. I will keep you informed of the progress of this unfortunate incident.

name: Martin SCHULZ
text: We now come to the first item on the agenda. Before I call on this, however, ladies and gentlemen, a message on administrative matters. On my left is the Deputy Secretary General of the European Parliament, Mrs Francesca Ratti, who will be attending a plenary session for the last time today as Deputy Secretary General. Ms. Ratti has worked in the European Parliament since 1979. Ms. Ratti started out in the European Parliament as personal assistant to Altiero Spinelli, after whom one of our most important buildings in Brussels is named today. In my opinion, Ms. Ratti, starting as Mr. Spinelli's assistant, personally accompanied the integration of the European Union very intensively. Today she is Deputy Secretary General of our House, for whom she did a great job, but not just administratively. As a personality, she has also contributed a great deal to the success of the European idea. I hope that, on behalf of all of you, I thank Mrs Ratti for her exceptional life's work and her great contribution to the European Parliament. Thank you very much, Ms. Ratti! (Loud and sustained applause)

name: Martin SCHULZ
text: The first item on the agenda is the debate on the statements by the European Council and the Commission on the conclusions of the European Council of 20/21 December.October 2016 (2016/2772 (RSP)).

name: Donald Tusk
text: President of the European Council. – Mr President, the European Council last week had three main topics: migration, trade and Russia, including Russia’s role in Syria. On migration: for the first time for more than a year the European Council was not a crisis meeting. The flows to the Greek islands are down by 98% compared to this time last year. However, irregular flows on the central Mediterranean route, that is to say from Africa to Italy, remain far too high and actually have not changed for the last two years. That is why we focused most of our discussion on cooperation with Africa.  Leaders heard a first assessment from the High Representative on efforts to control the flows in the central Mediterranean, in partnership with key countries. Good groundwork has been laid with Senegal, Mali, Niger, Nigeria and Ethiopia on the so-called Migration Compact. Leaders will assess first with us in December in terms of our goal, which is to prevent illegal migration to Italy and to the rest of Europe and to ensure effective returns of irregular migrants.  Leaders also discussed getting back to Schengen. The goal continues to be lifting temporary border controls over time. However, it has to be accompanied by further reinforcement of the external borders. The Commission will continue assessing the situation and come forward with its recommendations on this basis.  The question of a reform of the common European asylum system was also discussed, including how to apply the principles of solidarity and responsibility in the future. We agreed to consider concrete proposals by the Slovak Presidency on this sensitive issue in December.  We also had a discussion about Russia. Leaders shared individual experiences of several countries, ranging from disinformation campaigns, cyber attacks, interference in political processes in the EU and elsewhere, to airspace violations and the fanning of community conflict in Ukraine, the Balkans and further afield. Also, the developments in the MH17 investigation raise troubling questions.  Overall, we had a sober assessment of this reality, and no illusions. Increasing tensions with Russia is not our aim. We are simply reacting to steps taken by Russia, which is working with considerable energy and focus to weaken and divide the EU. Our long-term objective remains to find a modus vivendi. This means sticking to our values and interests, but also keeping the door open to dialogue. We all agree that European unity in approaching Russia is our greatest strength, and so we will stand united.  We also discussed Syria. We condemned attacks by the Syrian regime and its allies, notably Russia, on civilians in Aleppo. The EU is calling for an end to the atrocities and an immediate cessation of hostilities. We asked the High Representative to pursue further diplomatic and humanitarian efforts. If these atrocities continue, all available options will be considered. The Syrian people need an immediate and permanent ceasefire and a reopening of humanitarian aid corridors.  The last issue we discussed was trade. Our citizens are increasingly concerned about whether the trade deals we negotiate are in their best interests and I am afraid that we will not be able to continue to negotiate free trade agreements if we do not prove that we are very serious about protecting European consumers, workers and companies.  When we discussed this, we drew a big red line between protection and protectionism. In this spirit, leaders committed to reaching an urgent agreement on the modernisation of all the EU’s trade defence instruments. I know that this Parliament is ready to support this. We have now tasked our trade ministers with breaking the deadlock.  When it comes to CETA, the EU is still not ready to sign the agreement with Canada, but talks continue in Belgium this morning. I thank all those who have helped facilitate these talks, especially Martin Schultz and Jean-Claude Juncker. You have shown a genuine leadership and responsibility. Thank you very much for your help.  But at the end of the day, only the Belgians can decide on Belgium’s position. I am impressed by the determination and engagement they have shown during the last hours. I still hope that Belgium will prove that it is a consensus-building champion and that we will be able to finalise this agreement soon.  Here, I must also express my gratitude to the Canadian side for their cooperation and perseverance. If we cannot make the case for free trade with a country like Canada, the most European country outside Europe, and a close friend and ally, there are obvious consequences for Europe’s global position. But it is too early to go there yet. As we speak, the summit tomorrow is still possible.  On the Ukraine Association Agreement and DCFTA: the Dutch Prime Minister informed the European Council about the difficulties in ratifying the agreement. Prime Minister Rutte promised to use the next few days to try to work out a solution with the Dutch Parliament to address these difficulties. Whatever the outcome of the debate in the Netherlands is going to be, it is clear that we need to find a way ahead that is also agreeable to the other 27 Member States, and to Ukraine.  Let me also report that we were glad to welcome Prime Minister May at the European Council. She confirmed that the United Kingdom will invoke Article 50 of the Lisbon Treaty before the end of March next year. Consistent with our policy of no negotiations without notification, we did not discuss Brexit. However, given Prime Minister May’s confirmation that Article 50 will be triggered, let me recall the EU—27 position of 29 June. We want as close relations as possible with the UK. There must be a balance between rights and obligations and the UK can continue enjoying access to the single market, but it requires accepting all four freedoms.  To conclude, let me recall the meeting of the 27 EU leaders that was held in September in Bratislava. We met informally to discuss the future of Europe in light of the UK referendum on Brexit. As also reflected in the Bratislava roadmap, the Summit set out a number of actions to address the main concerns of Europeans: migration, security, both internal and external, and economic anxieties. It is now for Member States and the EU institutions to implement the roadmap and, as a matter of fact, we have already started to do so.  On 5 October, the EU ratified the Paris Agreement on climate change. Then next day, the European Border and Coast Guard was launched in record time. Here, I want to thank this Parliament for its excellent and swift cooperation. Last week, Bulgarian Prime Minister Borissov thanked his colleagues for their support in helping to protect the borders with Turkey, as decided in Bratislava.

name: Jean-Claude Juncker
text: President of the Commission. - Mr President, Ladies and Gentlemen, it seemed, from the outside, that the European Council which met last Thursday and Friday in Brussels focused exclusively on the free trade agreement with Canada . Such was not the case. Other topics were discussed. Progress has been made, particularly in the area of ​​migration, although there is still a long way to go and strewn with pitfalls. To strengthen the control of our common borders, we have created, with you and in record time, a European body of coast guards and border guards. It is now in place. It will have to quickly have all the personnel and all the necessary equipment so that it can, thanks to the rapid intervention reserve, act with all the speed required. December is the deadline to put in place all the planned systems. I am also counting on the speed of the co-legislators to adopt, by the end of the year, our proposal to create a system of entry into the territory of the European Union and of exit which will help to better control irregular migration. To combat irregular migration, dismantle smuggling networks, save human lives and provide refugees with legal routes of entry into Europe, we are also working with our neighbors, including Turkey. The first results are there. In the six months preceding the entry into force of the European Union-Turkey declaration, the total number of migrants arriving in Greece from Turkey was 739,000 people. In the six months following the implementation of this agreement, this figure rose to 18,000, a difference of 721,000 migrants. According to figures from the International Organization for Migration, between April and October 2015, 582 migrants were killed or went missing between Turkey and Greece. Between April and October 2016, this number is increased to 48 people. There are still 48 deaths or disappearances too many, but there is progress. These are only the first results, tangible but fragile, and we must consolidate them. To do this, we must continue to help Greece respond quickly to requests for additional staff from European agencies present there, in particular to ensure the protection of unaccompanied minors, speed up the relocation of refugees from Greece and continue resettlement from Greece. Turkey to Europe. We are also working with our African partners. As President Tusk has just said, we note progress in the implementation of migration pacts with countries of origin or transit, such as Niger, Nigeria, Senegal, Mali or Ethiopia. These are the programs that are underway. However, here again, this new cooperation should be consolidated, extended to other countries and the rapid launch of the external investment plan which is essential to fight against the causes of migration. Europeans need to invest in Europe and they will have to do it quickly. We also need to reform the European asylum system, including the Dublin mechanism, in order to have, as the Commission has proposed, a truly European and united system. Ich würde, sehr verehrter Herr President, gerne zu Ceta ein paar Worte sagen. Ich bin guter Hoffnung, dass es im Laufe des heutigen Tages zu einer Einigung zwischen der belgischen Regierung und der wallonischen Regierung und anderen Landesteileregierungen kommt. Ob dies es uns ermöglichen wird, den Vertrag mit Kanada morgen zu unterschreiben, ist mir noch nicht ersichtlich. Dem wäre auch nicht die große Wichtigkeit zuzumessen, die diesem Termin eigentlich zugemessen wird. Wichtig ist, dass es heute zu einer Einigung in Belgien kommt, damit das Königreich seine Bereitschaft bekunden kann, den Vertrag zu unterzeichnen. Wann dies passiert, ist weniger wichtig, als dass es passiert. Ceta ist ein wichtiges Handelsabkommen, wie alle Handelsabkommen wichtig sind. Aber in dem Zusammenhang - aber nicht nur in dem Zusammenhang - kommt es auch sehr darauf an, dass wir als Europäer nicht nur auf freien Handel, Sondern auch auf fairen Handel pochen. Wir sind für freien Handel, aber diesen freien Handel kann man nicht um jeden Preisherbeizwingen wollen. Wir als Europäische Union müssen uns darüber verständigen, dass unsere Handelsschutzinstrumentarien sich nach oben bewegen werden. Qualitativ hochwertige Handelsschutzinstrumentarien sind notwendig. Ich habe mir in Vorbereitung des Europäischen Rates die Zahlen angeschaut, was die Amerikaner machen, was die USA machen und was die Europäer und die Europäische Union machen. Und ich stelle fest, dass niemand die Vereinigten Staaten dafür kritisiert, dass sie auf bestimmte Stahlerzeugnisse, die aus China kommen, 265% an Antidumping-Zöllen verhängen. In der Produktsparte, um die es hier geht, bringen es die Europäer auf genau 20% Handelsschutzmaßnahmen. So kann man nicht gegen die Überkapazität, die es in China gibt, kämpfen. Die Stahlüberproduktion Chinas entspricht dem Doppelten der gesamten Stahlproduktion in der Europäischen Union. Und deshalb müssen wir dafür sorgen, dass wir uns nicht länger die Hände binden lassen, wenn es um die Regel des niedrigeren Zolls geht - lesser duty rule. Die Amerikaner verteidigen ihre Industrie und vornehmlich ihre Stahlindustrie. Wir müssen dies auch tun. (Beifall) Im Rat sehen das nicht alle so. Die Mitgliedstaaten teilen sich in zwei Gruppen auf: dreizehn dafür oder dagegen, zwölf dafür oder dagegen. Ich werde keine Ruhe geben, bis der Rat mit qualifizierter Mehrheit diesen Handelsschutzmaßnahmen, die wir qualitativ nach oben steigern müssen, zustimmt. Es geht um die Zukunft der europäischen Industrie und nicht nur der Stahlindustrie. Hinzu kommt, dass diese Debatte, die wir untereinander und mit unseren Partnern in der Welt führen müssen, einfacher wäre, wenn wir uns stärker darum bemühen würden, die europäische Wirtschaft wettbewerbsfähiger zu machen. Vieles wäre einfacher, wenn wir wettbewerbsfähiger wären. Aber diese Regeln des niedrigen Zolls müssen wir offensiv angehen. I had intended to describe the results of the European Investment Plan, but you have seen all the figures. Up to now we have mobilized EUR 138 billion of new instruments across 27 Member States and almost 300,000 small firms will have new loans. We are pursuing the aim of reaching EUR 315 billion from now to the year after next. We have proposed as a Commission to double the financial amount of the investments and we have proposed to the Council to double the duration of the plan. The European Council will come back to this issue in December and I really do hope that, on the basis of all the external and internal assessments that will be provided, that the European Council will take a decision along the lines of the Commission’s proposal. Herr President! Ich würde gerne ein letztes Wort zu den Schwierigkeiten sagen, die es in puncto Ratifizierung des Abkommens mit der Ukraine durch die Niederlande gibt. Ich würde von dieser Stelle aus gerne einen Appell an die niederländische Politik richten, genau des Umfangs dieses Problems sich sehr bewusst zu werden. Es wäre gut, wenn man in den Niederlanden auch eine innenpolitische Einigung in der Frageherbeiführen könnte. (Beifall)

name: Manfred WEBER
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. - Dear Presidents, my colleagues! I looked in the European Treaty to see what the task of the European Council is. The task of the European Council is to define the strategic direction of the European Union and to provide orientation for this continent. If I then look back at the articles and the headings of the last few days, it does not go together at all, because after this European Council we have more confusion, more confusion than orientation. This is disappointing. I'll go through the topics. First point - trade policy: what is the challenge? We have millions of people - especially young people - out of work on this continent. If we want to create jobs, then we need growth, and given the demographic development, we will not get growth internally, but only with more trade. The USA has already concluded an Asia agreement on trade issues, other regions of the world are overtaking us. That's the challenge. And what is the answer? The answer is that we have a mess at Ceta, that the Canadian Minister of Commerce, in exasperation, almost gives up and wants to leave and makes it clear that we are unable to deliver. And I have to make it clear where that comes from. That is not something for which we are responsible here in the European Parliament. The fact is that in the last European Council in July, the states said with an overwhelming majority - almost unanimously - that we have to make a mixed agreement and not a pure EU-only agreement. And that's why you have to say, dear colleagues: this is failure. What do we learn from it? For the future, it must be clear: European issues must be accounted for in the European Parliament and nowhere else. (Applause) We also learn from this that we must finally stand up for Ceta. I would also like to make an appeal to the socialists. Because if I see the appearance of the Austrian Chancellor at Ceta, for example, then I would like us all to stand up for Ceta now and argue and convince and not criticize ourselves and then agree in the end. And last but not least, at Ceta it is important to take your worries seriously. That is why, Mr President of the Commission, we expressly support the initiatives for more defense: we want fair and good world trade. The second is Russia. The challenge is clear there too: Putin uses the military and war as a legitimate political tool. Hundreds of thousands in Aleppo are suffering from it. The answer should actually be unity and strength here too. But it was a weak answer that the European Council gave. Options were even given away unnecessarily that were actually in hand. What do we learn from it? Putin is sitting at the table in Brussels. Its propaganda, its economic interests - gas deliveries, energy policy - also affect the highest levels of government in the European Union. I think that's a shame. The only language Putin would understand, given his behavior over the past months and years, is the position of strength. And that's why I would expect more strength from the European Council. The only positive thing I have to say was probably the statement from Theresa May. Why? Because she shows now to the European public what it means to leave the European Union. People see all over Europe how big the economic damage in Great Britain is already. The people see that Scotland is thinking about leaving Great Britain. The Scottish Prime Minister is rethinking a new referendum in Great Britain, and we have in the leading party - the Tory party - an ongoing battle between Hammond and Johnson, and nobody knows the outcome. The country is split, and Theresa May shows to the whole European Union that it is better to reform the European Union and not to destroy the European Union.People more and more recognize what populism means, ladies and gentlemen, because even here in the European Parliament we saw in the last Strasbourg week what populism means.UKIP showed us the true face - one UKIP member punching another UKIP member to hospital and still, ladies and gentlemen ... (loud protests from the floor)

name: Martin SCHULZ
text: Mr. Weber, wait a minute!Wait a minute, Mr. Weber!- If you now listen to Mr Weber for a moment, you may be able to put a point of order afterwards.(Interruptions from the plenary / unrest) But our Rules of Procedure do not provide that you have the right to shout down speakers here.So stick to the rules of this house!If you refer to a member of parliament as a “disgrace”, think about what your own behavior is like in this House.(Loud applause)

name: Manfred WEBER
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. - Mr President, I simply want to say that Nigel Farage is no longer the winner of the referendum. Nigel Farage is fleeing from responsibility and parts of his troop are behaving as ruffians. That is the reality in this house. I would like to conclude by unraveling the key points again. Ladies and gentlemen! Ceta: The commission presented a perfect result, a very, very good result. We in the European Parliament are in a position to get a majority in favor of Ceta straight away and put that into practice, and in the European Council, unfortunately, we have God's mess. The Commission has put forward very, very good proposals on the defense instruments, which are important for the citizens to defend ourselves in a globalized world. We in the European Parliament are in a position to implement these proposals tomorrow and give good answers for the citizens, and in the European Council, among the Member States, we have a split, a blockade. And the same picture with regard to migration: the Commission - Dimitris Avramopoulos is here - has put forward good proposals on how we should answer the migration questions for Europe. We in the European Parliament have clear majorities for this, and in the European Council the citizens have only seen arguments among themselves for months. Europe is not failing - that is important to me and my group - unfortunately the national egoism that is leading Europe into a block is failing these days. Europe needs unity, determination and leadership. That would be the EPP's wish. (Applause and boos) (The speaker agreed to answer a question about the blue card procedure under Rule 162 (8) of the Rules of Procedure.)

name: Nigel FARAGE
text: blue-card question. – Whilst it is regrettable that two of our MEPs fronted up to each other, there is absolutely no evidence that anybody was punched at all and I do want that put on the record. However, if you would like to come outside with me we could have a civilised conversation over a cup of coffee.

name: Manfred WEBER
text: Answer to a question about the “blue card” procedure.- Mr. Farage!To be honest, I am moved because I saw the pictures of my colleague lying on the ground outside.I don't know if you saw the pictures.I saw the pictures and I was shocked when I saw the pictures.The fact that something like this takes place in a democratic parliament is caused by the internal party dispute that you have.I would like to go one step further because we have more and more reports of where an EU citizen xenophobia is emerging in the UK, where hatred is sown, where distrust is sown.That comes from your politics, and that is why we will fight to the last what politics you practice.

name: Bill ETHERIDGE
text: – Mr President, I would like to say this in a calm and measured sense. There is an investigation going on into the events that Mr Weber has just made accusations about. Not only an internal UKIP one, but a parliamentary one where one of our colleagues is investigating this. What he has said has prejudiced that investigation, is absolutely outrageous, and I suggest to you, Sir, asking you as the guardian of the rules, please could you do something about this – this is unacceptable.

name: Martin SCHULZ
text: At the beginning of this sitting, Mr Etheridge, I do not know if you were already in the room, I said that after what had happened, I had referred the matter to our so-called Advisory Committee on the Code of Conduct.This advisory committee has examined the matter very carefully and has recommended that I consult the prosecution.The medical findings made after MP Woolfe was admitted to the hospital are that his fainting spell on the bridge here in the house resulted from a blow to the head.It's a medical finding.I questioned Mr Woolfe on this and the suspicion that violence was perpetrated against him is very likely.That is why the Strasbourg Public Prosecutor's Office will deal with the matter.Personally, I have no doubt about Mr Woolfe's account.

name: Gianni PITTELLA
text: on behalf of the S & amp; D Group. - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I greet the Presidents, I also greet Dr. Ratti with a strong hug. I am becoming convinced that some members of the European Council have not well memorized the joke of the cyclist President Romano Prodi who said: "to ride a bicycle you have to pedal, if you don't pedal you fall to the ground". This is Europe: to go forward you have to pedal. If the European Council does not pedal or pedal slowly, you will fall to the ground. And so it is happening. It also happened in the last Council. On Syria, our urgent request from Parliament for access to humanitarian aid has not yet been fulfilled. It is reasonable that sanctions have not been put in place, but we need to find a way, an instrument to stop that massacre. The efforts made by those countries that are defending the external border of the European Union and are welcoming thousands and thousands of refugees and migrants are well recognized. Well the institution of the Coast Guard to which President Juncker referred to which we, as Parliament, have given an important hand. However, the silence of the Council on economic issues should not be. In December, from Bratislava to Brussels, from Brussels to December the Council undertakes to discuss, to discuss the extension of the European investment plan, which I undertake to discuss. We want the commitment to approve the extension and strengthening of the European investment plan. It does not even go on the issue of relocations: this double standard of the right does not convince me, the Walloons are accused of stopping CETA and nothing is said to Orbán, who insists on no relocation. The position of the Walloons is a position of requesting clarification and I join the voices asking that in these hours we can reach those clarifications that can lead to the most progressive commercial treaty that we have been able to sign. There is no ideological position negative on CETA by the Walloons, there is a positive and constructive request for clarification, we are working in this direction, President Juncker, President Schulz worked on it and it is right to continue to work constantly so that we arrive at a positive solution . On immigration, I add, that we must put an end to "save whoever can", this story of the border, of border controls between Austria and Slovenia does not help Europe to find a common response to this challenge . And, I conclude, this Parliament must not be the Parliament of the brawl, it must raise its voice, but not among us on issues of goat wool, it must raise its voice to say "stop Aleppo, the Aleppo massacre", it must raise your voice to have fair trade, it must raise its voice to stop industrial crises, it must raise its voice to have a more expansive economic policy, it must raise its voice to give an answer to young people and women, it must raise its voice to give dignity to the European institutions and to the decision-making process, must raise their voices to give a smile to those children who hope for a better future! This is the Parliament that we must have and that we must build!

name: Syed KAMALL
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Mr President, if ever there was a theme for a summit meeting, then surely the theme of this one was ‘gridlock’. Powerless to move or commit to decisions on some of the key issues facing the West and the EU right now, at a time when voters in all EU countries are asking questions of their political leaders. The EU has been defined in the past week by weakness and indecision. Why? We should ask ourselves: why is it so difficult to unite on these key issues? Why does a trade agreement like CETA fail at the last hurdle? The ECR Group is asking if the EU cannot even reach an agreement with a country such as Canada – a country with similar environmental and labour standards – what hope do we have of telling the rest of the world that the EU is open for business? Why could the 28 leaders not make progress? Because there is a fundamental disconnect between EU leaders and the people they represent. With greater centralisation, individuals and communities feel weaker. Here we use the language of compromise, coalitions, and semesters, but people outside want to know: will they have more money in their pay packet? Will they be able to pay their bills? Will the business they work for grow and create jobs? All too often these simple questions go unanswered. If leaders fail to address these concerns, fail to listen to the warnings, fail to make the case for decisions taken, then do not be surprised if voters in many of our countries turn to extremist parties offering simplistic solutions.  I realise that our countries have different histories, and perhaps different interests, when dealing with Russia. But responding to Russia’s current actions is something which should unite us, rather than divide us. When we see continued violations by Russia in Ukraine and Georgia, when we see the bombing of Aleppo and its people, when we see Russia biting at the heels of the EU’s external border, then the whole West should be uniting together in wanting to use what power we have. The EU only has soft power. But surely soft power should be better than no power. Economic sanctions are beginning to have an effect on Russia – but not nearly enough. Yet even at this point, leaders could not agree to go further. Now we see one EU country, Spain, offering to refuel that same Russian fleet that is likely to inflict more atrocities on the civilians of Aleppo. What kind of signal does that send about our resolve? At this rate we are facing a future of the lowest common denominator politics. We needed a summit of action, a summit of clarity, we needed a summit of decisiveness. Yet again, this is not what we got. It is time to open our eyes and see what is happening around us. Just as each action has its consequences, inaction also has consequences. Prime Minister Trudeau walking away from a Canada-EU trade deal which would have helped create jobs and growth. Putin walking into other countries unchecked and uninhibited. If this is the result of our inaction, do not be surprised if our electorate eventually punishes us. To counter the simple message of extremism, to regain the confidence of the people who vote for us, we need solutions, we need action, and we need a new direction, to break the gridlock that we currently face. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Liisa JAAKONSAARI
text: blue card question.- Mr Kamall, you are a good speaker, but you give very few answers.You said that there has been a poor response to Russia.Should the Council have declared sanctions or what should the Council have done instead of condemning the Aleppo bombing very strongly?Please also provide answers.

name: Syed KAMALL
text: blue-card answer. – Thank you very much for the compliment; I will take any compliment I can get in this place. But, actually, it was quite clear: I think the answer was in your question. You asked, ‘should the Council impose sanctions?’ The answer is a clear ‘yes’; sanctions have not begun to bite properly yet, though they are starting to work. We should not let up; we should have imposed more sanctions, and we should be looking at whatever instruments we have.  Other speakers have said that this morning, and we know we are not alone. If we are to show true unity in the West, we have to use what instruments we have, and we can use sanctions.

name: Sophia IN 'T VELD
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Mr President, there seems to be a recurring theme in all the interventions, and that is the total inability of the Council to take any kind of decision up to now, but I will come back to that.  First, on CETA: the ALDE Group wants CETA to be salvaged, and if more time is needed then more time is needed. It is not the date, but the result, that matters. However, we cannot unpick the work that has been done, because trade is essential for our prosperity, and the credibility of the European Union – as has been said by others – has been severely damaged. The winners of this episode are not the Walloon farmers or the Walloon entrepreneurs; the winners are China, Russia and other countries, because they will get to set the standards, not Europe. Some parties in this House are actually welcoming the veto by Wallonia because they are against CETA, but that is a very dangerous kind of opportunism. Welcoming a veto when it suits your purpose will boomerang, because tomorrow a veto will be used against your priorities. The CETA episode exposes a much bigger problem, as I said: the weakness of the Council.  The EU cannot continue like this. If we look at the list of topics on the table, we have: sanctions against Russia – blocked; the Ukraine Agreement – jeopardised; CETA – blocked; refugee relocation – blown out of the water; the decision on Article 50 with the EU – kept dangling for nine months, and now one of the countries is threatening to veto the budget. We cannot continue like this. The EU is like a three-engine plane with one engine completely broken down. It is still flying, as the other two engines are still working, but it cannot stay on course until the Council engine is fixed.  Mr Tusk, please ensure that the European Union will not undergo the same fate as Poland in the 18th Century, when the Polish Parliament was completely paralysed by the ‘liberum veto’, allowing every single nobleman in the parliament to block a decision. As a result, Poland did not become greater; it became irrelevant. The Council has to take responsibility for the European Union as a whole and it has to do so soon, because not only will our own citizens tire of the inability of the EU to respond to the big challenges of today, but Europe is rapidly making itself irrelevant as a global actor. That has an impact and it has already been mentioned. The victims of the same inability to take decisions are the people in Syria. If the EU fails to decide on sanctions against Mr Putin, we lose any leverage we may have to force him to stop the bombing. We need a political transition urgently, and that means that we have to be able to put pressure on Mr Putin. Victims are equally the refugees, and I am actually a bit surprised to hear both the Council and the Commission be quite jubilant about the successful refugee policies, when the United Nations just yesterday said that 2016 is the deadliest year so far. More people have drowned in the Mediterranean than any year before. How can you say this is a success? How is it that the Council can still look at itself in the eye in the mirror and say this is a success? Mr Tusk, the Council – the Member State leaders – have a duty to end the paralysis, a duty towards the EU citizens and a duty towards the world.

name: Neoklis SYLIKIOTIS
text: on behalf of the GUE / NGL Group. - Mr President, we, the Group of the European United Left, as a matter of principle and based on our beliefs, are in favor of peace and against any war. The attacks and bombings of the Syrian regime and Russia in eastern Aleppo are rightly condemned. But there are no good and bad bombs. Equally barbaric and destructive are the bombs dropped by jihadists and insurgents in western Aleppo, which hit and even closed humanitarian corridors. Equally barbaric are the American bombs that kill civilians in Syria and Iraq. So stop turning a blind eye when your allies are waging war. How long will you keep silent when the Saudis kill innocent children and civilians in Yemen? gun violence and border forgery in the Middle East. Unfortunately, under the responsibility of the European Council, the European Union continues to hypocrisy, implementing the unacceptable agreement it made with Turkey, an agreement that violates international law and sets the conditions for the refugee trade. Instead of the Council and the Commission criticizing the Turkish government, which is constantly slipping into authoritarianism, for the daily violation of human rights and freedoms, for the invasion of Syria, for the intended Kurdish genocide, for the silencing of journalists and the war which he carries out against every minority, rewards it. It has recognized it as a safe country and promises rewards to keep refugees away from its borders. In fact, today, you want to release the visa, without Turkey fulfilling its obligations to all Member States. It is unacceptable Union to implement two measures and two weights. It is the result of these policies that has led to the worsening of the refugee crisis we are experiencing today. Unfortunately, the Commission and the European Council insist on increasing the border guards, strengthening Frontex, building new border fences, in the direction of a fortress Europe. It is with your own actions that the Balkan corridor was closed, but all you have achieved is to drown the refugees on the shores of Libya and off Lampedusa and not in the Aegean. These policies are not a response to the humanitarian crisis. They only succeed in reinforcing xenophobia and racism. What is needed is to develop a refugee policy based on solidarity and humanity, to create legal and safe routes for refugees and migrants, and a permanently binding and fair refugee relocation system. It is equally important to stop wars and foreign intervention in the wider Middle East and to really support the African states. And finally, as far as CETA is concerned: the people said "no" and with their struggles marginalized the TTIP agreement. What has been confirmed in recent days is that the Council and the Commission want to bring TTIP back through the back door through CETA. We, as the GUE / NGL, welcome the courageous stance of the Walloon Regional Government and Parliament, who said 'no' to the CETA blackmail ultimatums. They saved the dignity of Europe and thus expressed the real will of millions of citizens in the Union. (The speaker agreed to answer a question with a "blue card" (Rule 162 (8)).)

name: Udo VOIGT
text: Ask about the “blue card” procedure.- Honorable Member!I have heard that you, as the United Left, condemn all violence in the Syrian war, but I am missing a clear statement here.Why don't you condemn the illegal bombing and destruction of seven bridges by the United States Air Force, which are also illegal under international law in the airspace of Syria, because the Syrian government has never allowed them to do so?

name: Neoklis SYLIKIOTIS
text: GUE / NGL), answer to a blue card question.- I think I was clear - I do not know if you listened to the whole speech - I just referred to the American bombing.There are no good and bad bombs for us.All the bombings kill civilians, they kill children.And we must not condemn unilaterally, only the bombings in eastern Aleppo.We must also condemn the actions of the jihadists and the opposition, who are allies of the Union, but also the bombing of the United States.

name: Philippe LAMBERTS
text: on behalf of the Verts / ALE Group. - Mr President, indignation, protest, rejection, this is what the European project is increasingly arousing among too many of our fellow citizens. Some here would like to see only the sign of a withdrawal into identity. Yet this anger first resonates as a cry of alarm in the face of policies that are increasingly moving away from the general interest. It is quite a symbol when the epicenter of the dispute is located in Wallonia, a welcoming land and one of the most pro-European and most united regions of the Union. All this concerns a free trade agreement with Canada, which was the main course - the expression is not stolen - of the European Council last week. This is not a coincidence: it has been three years in French-speaking Belgium, free trade agreements have become the number one subject of unprecedented citizen mobilization. Under this pressure, the French-speaking elected representatives of Belgium seized the CETA and dissected it as few have done in Europe. All this led in May 2015, at the initiative of the Greens, to a well-argued resolution, expressing very serious reservations with regard to a CETA designed to assert the supremacy of a chimerical right to profit over all other rights. as well as the power of companies, their shareholders and their leaders over the power of democracy. Far from being Europe's spoilsport, Wallonia has today become the representative of all the citizens who reject a trade policy in the service of multinationals. No, contrary to what some would have us believe, Wallonia is not isolated, quite the contrary. It should be remembered that 1,500 European cities and towns declared themselves outside TTIP and CETA, that 3,400,000 petitioners reject the arbitration project between investors and states, that a majority of Austrians, Germans, French and Slovenes are against CETA? Faced with this, the response of the Commission and the European governments was a four-beat waltz. There was first the denial by the lack of response to the letter from the Minister-President of Wallonia, who expressed the reservations of his Parliament. Then there was the condescension on the theme: "If you do not agree with us, it is because you did not understand, we will explain it to you again". Then there was the intimidation: Wallonia has two days to decide, Mr Tusk. Finally, there was the tinkering with a jumble of statements of dubious legal value that added confusion to opacity. The pressure put to lift the blockade of CETA by the Walloons contrasts sharply with the silence of the same vis-à-vis the blocking of certain Member States, some of which are much less populated than Wallonia - allow me to tell you - on, for example, the fight against tax evasion or financial regulation. Even more disgusting is the stark contrast in the decisions of the European Council last week, Mr Tusk. Between the frenzied free-trade bias and a migration policy whose key words have become repression and keeping at a distance. Thus, for the Heads of State or Government of the European Union, goods, services and finances must be able to circulate freely, but especially not human beings. A few weeks ago, before the failed Bratislava summit, you said, Mr Tusk: "European citizens want to know whether the political elites are capable of regaining control of events and processes which overtake them, disorient them and, sometimes terrify them ". A few days later, in your State of the Union speech, Mr Juncker, you said you wanted a Europe that protects, preserves our European way of life and empowers our citizens. Gentlemen, therefore join actions with words; take this opportunity that Francophones in Belgium offer to the Commission and European governments; Remove from CETA all the mechanisms, foremost among them the arbitral tribunals, which aim to lock in the power of our democracies; assert their right to freely decide which activities will be entrusted to the public service and which will be entrusted to the market; finally, remove all doubts about the compatibility of this treaty with European law by referring to the Court of Justice of the European Union. Will it take time? Yes, it is the time of democracy. You know, for centuries we have traded with Canada without CETA. So do those few extra months matter? The Walloon surge must be the occasion, dear colleagues, not to put a stop to the trade policy of the Union, but to re-examine it, because most of our fellow citizens are not opposed to trade . In the 21st century, the objective of trade treaties cannot be the maximization of flows, because this is incompatible with environmental constraint. It cannot be profit maximization for a few, because that is not the role of politics. Their primary objective must be the dissemination of the strictest social, environmental, health, fiscal and democratic standards. It is these standards that set the binding framework within which trade can develop. Trade policy can no longer be decided in secret. On the contrary, mandates must be decided in full transparency and negotiations carried out under the permanent watch of elected officials. It is under these conditions, and I conclude, Mr President, that this trade policy will regain the confidence of our citizens. The Walloon no to CETA is a yes to a citizens' Europe. (The speaker agrees to answer a "blue card" question (Rule 162 (8) of the Rules of Procedure)

name: Hilde VAUTMANS
text: "blue card" question.- Colleague Lambert, you are actually trying to say that you are not alone in the resistance against CETA.But then explain to me why 27 other countries have given their agreement?You say: we already trade with Canada, so CETA is not necessary.Well, I would very much like to invite you to Haspengouw.Our fruit farmers long for CETA because this treaty removes trade barriers.You may not need that in Wallonia, but we in Flanders certainly want to open up those markets and build on what Commissioner De Gucht has set in motion.Colleague Lambert, at the end you said that "no" is an appeal to Europe.Then I challenge you;then you agree with me that it was actually a historic mistake by the Commission to label CETA as a mixed treaty.

name: Philippe LAMBERTS
text: answer "blue card".- Mr President, that obviously raises a lot of questions.I will focus on the first one: "Why is Wallonia the only institution - I am saying no - to say no while the 27 other Member States - and you would add Flanders - say yes?"I will give you the answer.It is very simple.In Europe, two parliaments, the Walloon Parliament and the French-speaking Parliament of Belgium, opened CETA and read it.All the others, either they did not do it, or they were prevented from doing it - I am thinking of the National Assembly in France.This is why governments decide to go above and beyond what their citizens want.(Uproar)

name: Martin SCHULZ
text: Let's see what the national parliaments - Mr Lamberts!Guys, can you calm down now?Colleagues, come to a rest.- Let's see what the national parliaments that have dealt with CETA will say about your statement, Mr Lamberts.

name: Nigel FARAGE
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. – Mr President, so Mrs Smith goes to Brussels and is given five minutes to speak at one o’clock in the morning. It is the same treatment that David Cameron got when he came to announce the referendum, although at least this time the French President did not leave the table to go to the bathroom. When Mr Juncker was asked by a British journalist how the negotiations were going, he said, ‘Pffft’ – well, I can’t really do Gallic shrugs very well – and the impression is that you are simply too busy to even discuss Brexit or to take it seriously.  Basically, you are hoping that we will change our minds – Mr Tusk alluded to that a couple of months ago. I know there has been a long tradition here, whether it’s with Denmark, France, Ireland or the Netherlands, that when there is a democratic referendum you try to either ignore it or overturn it. Today again, we heard Mr Juncker urging the Dutch Government to ignore the referendum result on the Ukraine. Frankly, the whole thing is a disgrace. It is even worse that it is supported by quislings in the British Parliament – people like Nick Clegg and Ed Miliband, who are desperate to keep Britain inside this awful single market. Well, I am sorry but it simply isn’t going to happen. There are 17.4 million people who could not have been clearer. We voted to say that we want our country back, and in the end that is what is going to happen.  I have to confess, though, that Mrs May’s position in her five minutes was somewhat curious. For her to be arguing that Britain must have a full vote and a full say in all EU affairs up until the time we leave is a very mixed message, and I have already seen this morning that some here take it as a sign of weakness. We need to get on with it. Every single day that goes by is a lost opportunity. The proposed trade agreement with Canada having been vetoed by Walloons after seven years of negotiations absolutely proves to you that, in a modern 21st century global economy, the European Union is simply not fit for purpose. I want us to get on with it, because this club is very expensive. We are paying in net GBP 30 million every day. Some will argue it’s a bit less, some will argue it’s a bit more. Either way, it is too much. We are helping to finance this monthly travelling circus to Strasbourg and, worst of all, I have now discovered that in your staff regulations up to 5% of employees every year are allowed to retire five years early and receive full pay and entitlements for five years for doing absolutely nothing. Nowhere else in the world would allow this sort of thing to go on. So I want us to get on with it. Interestingly, I met a large number of Scandinavian businesses the other day. They are worried. They are anxious. And why? Because they know that the United Kingdom is the eurozone’s biggest export market in the world, and they want to crack on. They know that the EU has trade deals with several countries in the world which involve no free movement of people, and their logic is: if we can do a deal like that with Mexico, why on earth wouldn’t we do it with our most important trading global partner? That is common sense coming from European businesses and common sense coming from most people in the United Kingdom. The only obstacle appears to be the high priests of Euro—federalism in this room today. If you think that by delaying or stopping Brexit you are going to help your own businesses and your own industries, you are wrong. It is in the mutual interest of all of us to get on with this and conclude a sensible, straightforward tariff—free deal.  (Applause)

name: Martin SCHULZ
text: Mr Farage, may I ask you a question?Did you refer to Messrs. Clegg and Miliband as "quislings"?Is that right?

name: Nigel FARAGE
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. – I certainly did, yes.

name: Martin SCHULZ
text: I just want to point out that Mr. Quisling was the leader of the Nazi collaborators in Norway.I think it is totally inappropriate for you to compare democratically elected politicians with it.(Applause)

name: Nigel FARAGE
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. – Mr President, he did it against the interests and will of his own people, and the point I am making about Messrs Clegg and Miliband is they are refusing to accept a democratic result, just as Mr Juncker is refusing to accept the Dutch referendum. There is something fundamentally wrong here.

name: Martin SCHULZ
text: At least these men didn't give their people fake election campaign numbers like you did.(Restlessness)

name: Marine LE PEN
text: on behalf of the ENF Group. - Mr President, I hope you will use your fourth blue card in this debate. Once again, my dear colleagues, you are quite confused by a principle which you had misled for your exclusive use: democracy. After the British Brexit, the Walloon Assembly decides to do what it was elected for, which also amazes you: defend the Walloons. Unbelievable! However, the treaty that you negotiated in great secrecy with Canada and which was supposed to come into force before it was even approved - which, you will admit, is quite scandalous - is not in the best interests Peoples. It would surely benefit a few wealthy multinationals but not the vast majority of citizens. An independent American study by Tufts University thus assesses its consequences: destruction of 45,000 jobs in France and 200,000 in Europe, fall in wages, reduction in the scope of public policies, fall in growth, rise in public deficits ... Don't say that the Walloons are blocking others. It's wrong! The reality is that they are just the only ones who could speak up. The rejection of CETA is largely in the majority, not because people are ill-informed, but because, on the contrary, they have opened their eyes to the disaster caused in Europe by ultraliberal free trade policies. You assured us that Europe was peace. It almost makes you smile. But in your rage, in the face of failure, you use force, the shameful pressures denounced by Mr. Magnette, unworthy maneuvers, authoritarian ultimatums. A democratic assembly has spoken. Forgive me, but you must submit or resign. Any other choice would reveal an authoritarian liberticidal regime. Finally, Mr Juncker, President Schulz will forgive me for nibbling a few seconds to highlight your start of conversion to protectionism, a concept however hated by the European institutions.I see for us, allow me to say it, a spectacular ideological victory which you know full well that it always precedes political victories.(The speaker accepts to answer a "blue card" question (Rule 162 (8) of the Rules of Procedure))

name: David COBURN
text: blue-card question. – Madam Le Pen, with the Wallonians halting the trade treaty with Canada, would you not agree with me that the British are better off leaving the European Union, when we will not have to have 27 other people and Wallonia agreeing to any future trade treaties? Would France not be better off joining Britain in a Frexit so that France can have the same privileges to make her own trade treaties with the world and get France out of the catastrophic economic mess that Mr Hollande has put it in?

name: Marine LE PEN
text: answer "blue card".- Mr Coburn, in reality I believe that the peoples of Europe overwhelmingly defend this position.It is only their elites who betray them on a daily basis and who continue to defend a system that is in the process of collapsing on itself.That is why I want a referendum not only for my own country but also, as I am not selfish, for all the countries of the European Union so that their peoples can express themselves on this subject.

name: Kostas PAPADAKIS
text: NI). - Mr Schultz, despite your anti-communist frenzy, history is not being rewritten for Hungary this morning. What did the overthrow of socialism and its conquests bring: unemployment, poverty, exploitation, wars, refugees, that is, capitalism. This is what history records today. That is why people pay dearly for the fierce competition of monopolies that is reflected in your European councils. That is why the European Union and the United States have set fire to a new war in Mosul over energy control, which is causing new waves of refugees trapped in miserable conditions, by your joint decision. The fight against the imperialist war and the immediate decongestion of the hotspots, the reception centers in the Greek islands, is urgent to allow the transfer of refugees and immigrants to their final destination countries. Concerning Walloon's involvement in CETA: this concerns who will have the upper hand in enforcing the standards that serve its profits to the detriment of its competitors. It is a controversy over the distribution of booty, which concerns new anti-labor measures, concessions of social services to monopolies, to act unhindered by crushing popular rights at work, health, education, protection of the environment. That is why CETA is approved by the SYRIZA-ANEL government. The people must fight to reject calls for a better or more transparent agreement and to fight for the withdrawal of CETA and TTIP and any other reactionary agreement, aiming to overthrow the real adversary - their monopolies, their unions and the very their exploitative system. (The speaker agreed to answer a question with a "blue card" (Rule 162 (8)))

name: Bill ETHERIDGE
text: blue-card question. – In the light of the debate that we have seen this morning, where we have had the whole of European trade seemingly held up by one area and where we have had the President of the European Union showing, in my view, absolutely unacceptable bias against one side, would you agree with me that now, in this madness that we have seen, the Walloons probably have taken over the asylum?

name: Kostas PAPADAKIS
text: NI), answer to a "blue card" question.- A fierce war is being waged between major interests to control the markets.Of course, there are also geopolitical interests in these developments.And the people have other interests that do not go hand in hand with such agreements and they must collectively organize their struggle without delay beyond these competitions.They must organize their own struggle against any such agreement that runs counter to their interests and fight for their own power.

name: Herbert REUL
text: - Madam President, gentlemen Presidents! Europe is at risk - everyone has said that now - and it is at risk because we are unable to prove that we are solving the problems. At the moment this is clearly due to the inability to act in the Council - that's right - because national egoisms are decisive there. This is because most heads of state in the Council allow themselves to be determined by populist sentiments. I have to say that I can no longer hear that people always talk about European values ​​and when it comes down to it, for example in Syria and Russia, the flag is not shown. The Europeans not only have to talk about the fact that this is bad and terrible, but you also have to prove action. Otherwise it is not credible. Or: You can't talk about solidarity all day, and with Ceta it fails because of a small regional parliament. We can't do it with refugees because some states only think of themselves, and with others the leaders are unwilling to comply with existing rules. If Europe is not in a position to enforce what has been agreed, to implement it and to ensure that everyone adheres to it, then the shop can be closed. Sorry, that annoys me more and more that we let it get away with the fact that one Member State is currently saying: “No, we are not taking refugees”, or another is saying: “No, I promised 1.8%, but I'm doing it now I'm happy 2.3% ”, and nobody acts! If this continues, Europe will no longer be taken seriously, to put it bluntly. That is partly up to us, at the moment more with the Council, but partly also up to us, that we don’t complain here, but try to get the parts that we can fix. I am grateful that the President of the Commission has shown today that we must also deal with the issue of industry, that industry must be protected. This also includes not only protecting, but also giving it the conditions so that it can develop.Competitiveness must be established.We also have something to do, but we are responsible for that!

name: Knut FLECKENSTEIN
text: - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen! President Tusk, you said that it was finally not a crisis summit. When I see the cover note where the result is written down, it doesn't surprise me either. When you talk about migration and read the bold headlines, you're talking about protection of external borders, preventing illegal migration. All important things. You only talk about the actual topic, which must also be of interest to us, under Miscellaneous: namely, how we cope with relocation and resettlement. If you hadn't talked about it at all, it might have been even more comfortable. All I want to say is: we agree, including with the points you have dealt with, and we believe it is necessary. But there has to be a balance to talk about the other problems as well. The footnotes that this is without prejudice for Hungary, Slovakia and others does not help us much. Let me make one point where I very much agree with the Council. The point is that we agree that what is happening in the city of Aleppo is a crime by the Syrian government against its own people. It is unacceptable that this is still supported by Russia or that it is actively accompanied and done. If, however, the European Council has decided to first concentrate all its attention on humanitarian measures that should bring urgent aid to the people in Aleppo and Syria, then I think that is right. The suffering of the Syrian civilian population must stop. This is what we want, and Russia should be about it too. But not only Russia, but also all other groups fighting there. Some members of the European Council would have preferred to see sanctions against Russia. I believe that by following Federica Mogherini and everyone, we are helping the Syrian civilian population more avail of diplomatic efforts.

name: Ryszard CZARNECKI
text: - Madam President! Mr. Chairman! I had a speech prepared, but I am throwing it out because I have to take a stance on what was said in this room. First of all, I would like to offer my private history tutoring for Ms in 't Velt: Poland in the 18th century did not disappear from the map of Europe because it had a bad Seym, just because it was divided by three partitioners: Russia, Prussia and Austria. I would be glad to give you this history lesson in the near future. We heard about the Juncker plan here. I would very much like the Juncker Plan to be finally something that will create an opportunity for investments and a chance for companies in the new Union, i.e. in the countries that joined the Union after 2004. For now, it seems that although it is clearly some chance, it's only for the fifteen countries. It can not be like that. Finally, I would like to say to Mr Weber that when it comes to CETA, it is also a matter for the Council and the Member States, and not just for the European Parliament.

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: – Madam President, Mr Tusk, I am afraid I have two or three critical remarks on the European Council conclusions. If I look at trade, it says that the EU is committed to a robust trade policy, etc., and then the first paragraphs of substance say that UK interests include fully defending and promoting the social environment, etc. In this context, the European Council believes that unfair trade practices... Now, don’t get me wrong. I want an improved defence mechanism, but I expected a certain leadership here, a certain kind of courage in saying what the agreement and what CETA really means, why it should be signed at the outset and as soon as possible. What Mr Lamberts has said here today is not true. We had a mandate, and neither Wallonia nor Belgium raised those issues of concern when the mandate was approved. Secondly, concerning Russia: if we look again at the European Council conclusions, what does it say? ‘The EU is considering all available options, should the current atrocities continue.’ You, as a Pole, know that the Russians will laugh at this text. This is a reality, and in the background there are people being killed and innocent people who humanitarian convoys are not able to reach. My final remark (I do apologise) is on migration. If we look at the European Council conclusions – skip the diplomacy, skip the diplomatic language – because if you look at it – measurable results – I do not see anything measurable here.

name: Anne-Marie MINEUR
text: - If CETA is the blueprint for how the European Union negotiates its free trade agreements, then we better stop today than tomorrow. Is it part of the blueprint that the President of Parliament takes over the negotiations without any mandate? Is it part of the blueprint that parliaments hardly have any more time to discuss the treaty in depth? Is it part of the blueprint that we do not sort out essential matters, such as the legal values ​​of the interpretative statement, the compatibility of the investment protection with the European legal system and the question of how exactly the powers are divided? Is it part of the blueprint that the negotiations take place behind closed doors with the business community at first rank and citizens and NGOs far behind? Is it part of the blueprint that we give away democratic control over our regulations to the business community through the arbitration system, by boiling our rules and now again - as Mr Verhofstadt and ALDE propose - by sidelining national parliaments when they do not do so what business is asking? If CETA is the blueprint for our future free trade agreements, then we should be ashamed to call ourselves a democratic body. Stop CETA!

name: Ska KELLER
text: – Madam President, the situation that we have right now with CETA was completely foreseeable and completely predictable. It was not something that came out of the blue, because the concerns that were raised by the Wallonian Government were also raised by the millions of citizens who went into the streets, signed petitions, and so on. It is nothing new. The problem is that those concerns were not addressed, or not sufficiently addressed, and together we need to learn the lessons from that. How do we go ahead now? What do we do with that, and what do we learn from that? One big problem is that Member States indeed did not say that they actually had problems at home. The Belgian Prime Minister should have said that there were going to be issues. The German Minister for Trade, for example, should say that he has a court case still running on that. The Austrian Prime Minister should at least mention that his parliament voted against ISDS. There are so many issues that the Member States never bring to the European area, which is causing problems. Also, the trade agreements are creating too many issues right now. It is no longer about trade; it is all about regulation. When Mr Weber says that the European Parliament needs to be more involved, I am all in favour of that, but then why did the Conservatives and the Social Democrats stop a proper discussion here in the European Parliament? That I do not understand.  (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Sophia IN 'T VELD
text: blue-card question. – There is something that bugs me about many of the statements that have been made on this side of the House. You are all welcoming the veto by the Wallonian Parliament and, in doing so, you actually disregard democratic decisions that have been taken in other countries. What kind of a democrat are you if you say that the Wallonian Parliament – which is indeed democratically elected, as Mrs Le Pen said – but so are the other parliaments? All the 28 Member States have democratic institutional arrangements that you seem to completely deny.

name: Ska KELLER
text: blue-card answer. – Not quite. I do not really understand the criticism here, because I would never deny the democratic legitimacy of the other parliaments. I think a big problem is that indeed many parliaments, including us, are only asked when the whole deal is done. They should have been asked before, and then they could raise it. No, they were not – not all of them. It was great if it was done differently in your parliament, but others were not, and the European Parliament (to stay with that) was not asked before. We can do resolutions which are completely disregarded, and if we are only asked afterwards, as well as national parliaments… (The President cut off the speaker)

name: Laura FERRARA
text: - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, President Juncker told us today that we need to reform Dublin to have a truly European and supportive system. Well, I completely agree with him. It is a pity that the Dublin reform proposal, which the Commission has presented, relegates solidarity and the fair sharing of responsibilities between Member States only to exceptional cases and it is a pity that the concept of flexible solidarity is beginning to be talked about in the Council, so I think we need to prepare for the worst. Then there was talk of African countries and greater collaboration with them, but even here we are faced with problems of coherence, because if they are not seen, they review those trade policies which, instead of giving development to those lands, cause migratory flows, even there we are faced with a beautiful dilemma. But it is not only the problems of Africa that fear the nature of certain agreements. The pressure of European citizens who oppose trade agreements such as CETA and TTIP is growing more and more, these treaties place the profits and particular interests of large companies, multinationals, before the interests and protection of the fundamental rights of citizens and States. Therefore, such agreements must be strongly opposed.

name: Marcel de GRAAFF
text: - As expected, the EU summit on 21 October was unsuccessful.This EU is a complete fiasco and I repeat, Frontex is a towing service for illegal invaders from Islamic countries.That has to stop.The open borders are a party for terrorists, for people and arms smugglers and that must stop.The economic dictate of Brussels plunges citizens into deep poverty.That must stop!I call on this Commission: restore the security of citizens, expel all intruders from the EU, stop foreign financing of mosques, close national borders.I call on this Commission: restore the prosperity of the citizens, stop with the euro, stop with CETA and TTIP, stop with visa liberalization for Turkey and Ukraine.I say to Mr Juncker: it is not the Netherlands that should ratify the Ukraine Treaty, but Mr Juncker must listen to the will of the people and leave.

name: Eleftherios SYNADINOS
text: NI). - Madam President, once again the leaders of the countries of the Union during the summit continued their wishes and findings. For the illegal immigration, a brave admission of the obvious would suffice, so that they would finally proceed with actions to combat it. There is no need for the European Border Guard, the revision of the Schengen Borders Code and the creation of a European information and travel authorization system for the protection of external borders. All that is needed is the application of international law. The illegal immigrant does not have the rights of a refugee. Preventing illegal immigration along the Eastern Mediterranean route requires sealing the external borders of Greece and Bulgaria, abolishing the agreement with Turkey and imposing sanctions on it, which continues to violate any notion of the rule of law, fundamental rights and democracy. Finally, on the issue of Syria, the policy of deadlock and poor strategic planning continues. Leaders condemn in a statement the attacks by the Syrian regime and Russia on civilians in Aleppo. Why do not any of the 27 top leaders condemn the Islamic State? I wonder.

name: Janusz LEWANDOWSKI
text: - If it is true that the European Union is developing through crises, then we can only envy Mr. Tusk and Mr. Juncker that they run the European Union at such interesting times. But I am not jealous, because I know that the battle for the credibility of European institutions, both internal and global, is taking place in fields where, unfortunately, fears and emotions prevail over reason and arguments. Since the feeling of insecurity of Europeans has been combined with migration and refugees, the future of the European Union is at stake here. If, in the imagination of Europeans, the nation-state is the haven of security, the future of the Community is deadly threatened. Fortunately, there is a growing awareness that there is no effective national response - there is only an effective European response to these challenges. On the other hand, the causative power and credibility of the European Union as a global player, unfortunately, are unfortunately shadowed by the CETA tragicomedy. We are hostages of one region. This is a culpable situation. I hope (there are still chances for that) that we will get out of this problem, but nevertheless the causative capacity and credibility of the European Union will be - even if we choose - strongly weakened. Indeed, the mission of the European summits is to build a sense of usefulness and credibility in the European institutions, and I hope that the next summits will contribute to this.

name: Victor BOŞTINARU
text: – Madam President, President of the European Council, President of the Commission, distinguished colleagues, while we are talking here about the bombing in Aleppo, the bombing only continues every day. Russia and Assad have no regard for international humanitarian law, distinction and proportionality. They are refusing any ceasefire which will allow humanitarian relief. Last Friday in Geneva – and I am convinced you are fully aware of this – the UN Commissioner for Human Rights, Zeid Ra'ad Al Hussein, described the bombardment and siege of Aleppo as ‘crimes of historic proportions’. He referred to the lifeless bodies of small children trapped under streets of rubble. He called on the UN to speak as one single voice. I would ask the Council to do the same and say that the collective failure of the international community to protect civilians and to halt this bloodshed should haunt every one of us. Yes colleagues, I also believe it is unforgivable today to witness such a horror and to do so little – probably only speaking. Yes, no one could contest the complexity of the Syrian War – the past errors and the current ones, the many actors who are to be blamed. No one could contest our strong commitment in fighting Daesh and other UN Security Council-recognised terrorist groups. But no one can contest either the deliberate bombing of civilians, hospitals and humanitarian professionals in Aleppo by Russia. And no, the fact that there are potential extremist groups infiltrated is not an excuse for any one of us. The fight against terrorism does not excuse the deliberate killing of innocents, and this is why in the end I say to the Council: it’s enough. Put an end to the divisions and the hesitations towards Russia and call for an investigation into war crimes for the perpetrators.

name: Joachim STARBATTY
text: - Madam President! President Juncker, you hope that by persuading the Walloons to give their consent after all. But when I now hear Mr Lamberts who said: 'A no in Wallonia is a yes to Europe', then that is fundamental and we can expect similar phenomena to occur in other countries as well. In this respect, nothing will be gained if we convince Wallonia to do something now - that is fundamental. And when I hear Ms. Le Pen again, who comes up with the figures, that Ceta is destroying jobs, reducing growth - that is complete nonsense. Such calculations are based on models, and if you look at the assumptions you can see that they are based on incorrect specifications. All positive and all negative calculations are superfluous, they are wrong. The only thing we know is: Ceta and TTIP lead to more competition, and more competition is more productivity, but also more unemployment, if you are not careful. As a politician, you have to take an offensive approach and say: This is an opportunity, but also a risk. We need to be prepared to face the world's risks. If we cut ourselves off, as Ms. Keller would like, then we really sink.

name: Maite PAGAZAURTUNDÚA
text: - Madam president. Look, the conclusions adopted by the Council in the last eighteen months are not even 100 pages long. Eighteen months ago, the Council deplored the continuing loss of life in the Mediterranean and spoke of the need for an effective asylum policy and said that it was waiting for Mr Juncker's plan. They spoke of the migrant and refugee crisis. A few months later those words disappeared and they began to speak only of the migration crisis: of immigrants and irregular migrants. For this Council we have gone much further. Now, we talk about attending to other elements of the global strategy. Those other elements are women and children; people who are cold; children out of school in Greece; a human plug: a situation that UNHCR says on Lesbos is unbearable. The Council is liable for negligence. And Mr. Juncker, unfortunately - and I am very sorry, I would not like it to be so - is also an accomplice. Today he has stolen all the people who are drowning in the central Mediterranean. It is not like you. And the criterion of "flexible solidarity" is the criterion of "à la carte non-solidarity."

name: Dimitrios PAPADIMOULIS
text: GUE / NGL). - Madam President, Mr Tusk and Mr Juncker, Greece and Italy need effective refugee solidarity, not flexible solidarity, not à la carte solidarity, not solidarity as Mr Orban allows. And I expect you, Mr Juncker, and you, Mr Tusk, to be stricter in Mr Orban's Ευρώπη la carte Europe and not to caress him because he belongs to the European People's Party. Europe will fall apart if you tolerate an μια la carte Europe, where Hungary, Poland and other countries want European funds, but do not accept a single refugee in their countries.
