And still, stop bullying against the Walloon authorities. The objections and concerns are well-founded and could lead to CETA changes in favor of a trade that is not only free but also fair. We are tired of hearing only words. We want practical solidarity and a Europe with a plan and cohesion.

name: Yannick JADOT
text: - Madam President, Mr Juncker, Mr Tusk, you speak of CETA on behalf of the employees; listen to the employees, they don't want it. You claim to speak on behalf of consumers; listen to them, they don't want CETA. You claim to speak on behalf of European citizens, but what will you say to them, Mr Juncker, when the Commission finally does its job on endocrine disruptors and Bayer and Monsanto condemn Europe for the measures taken? What will you say to European citizens, Mr Tusk, when Europe returns to its job as a climate leader and Canadian oil sands, shale oil and gas companies attack Europe? What will you say to European breeders when they are destroyed by intensive Canadian farming where animals are stuffed with antibiotics and abused? By wearing this European model of unrestricted movement of goods, goods, investments, but with barbed wire, walls and camps for people, you are rolling out the red carpet to the far right and all nationalism. Have the courage to go to the Court of Justice of the European Union on CETA! Be consistent with your words and go to the Court of Justice of the Union!

name: Peter LUNDGREN
text: - Madam President! The CETA agreement with Canada is now faltering after Wallonia and the Brussels region now say no to the agreement in its current form. One problem for my country is that our strong animal welfare is affected by the agreement in a negative direction. Dispute resolution is also a problem, where multinational companies are given too much power. Not least Canada itself has had problems with so-called mailbox companies that abuse this dispute clause. I believe in free trade agreements and I am convinced that it means great export opportunities for my country. However, the whole process has meant that it would have been much more transparent from the very beginning to avoid all the problems we see now. Finally, I just have to say to Mr Weber and others: the people of Europe are laughing at you and your constant pie-throwing. You behave like a bunch of uneducated puppies sitting in a sandbox with your bucket and shovel and are damned that you are not allowed to have your little sandbox in peace. Democracy is something you only like if it is your version of democracy.

name: Harald VILIMSKY
text: - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen! The Republic of Austria celebrates the national holiday today. I can inform you that the Austrians are a very proud people who value democracy, the rule of law and sovereignty and who commemorate these principles today. However, with current developments in the European Union - including the last summit here - we are facing major problems that are currently in the area of ​​sovereignty. Specifically, I am addressing the CETA trade agreement, which intervenes deeply in principles where the people of Europe have no direct say. The Austrian Federal Chancellor did a survey in our country: 92% of its members and 88% of the non-members spoke out against this trade pact. Nevertheless, he is whipped through. Against this background, I can only say in the direction of Wallonia: stay tough, don't give in to blackmail, don't give in to pressure! You are the last chance to prevent that accordingly. In the direction of Austria I would like to say: Long live the Republic of Austria! (The speaker agreed to answer a question on the blue card procedure under Rule 162 (8) of the Rules of Procedure.)

name: Paul RÜBIG
text: Ask about the “blue card” procedure.- Thank you, Mr Vilimsky.National holiday.I think it should also be mentioned that in Austria there were only 7% of the votes in the CETA vote that was made by the socialist party.15% of these 7% were for CETA.I have to thank Chancellor Kern for recognizing after the briefing in Strasbourg that this is the right way to create more jobs and prosperity.My question is: you are from the Freedom Party and you want free trade in the 28th Europe, then why are you against free trade with Canada?

name: Harald VILIMSKY
text: Answer to a question about the “blue card” procedure.- Mr Rübig!One after the other.Also, only 13% in Slovakia voted in the last election to the European Parliament.Take note that there are democratic votes that must be respected accordingly!And if people, because of disenchantment with politics, do not take part in democratic processes, the results are still to be noted.Our job must be to get these people on board and motivate them to participate in these decisions.Of course we are in favor of trade, there is no question at all.But there is also a need for appropriate regulation here and there.And here, too, I don't want Austria's sovereignty to be affected.(The President cut off the speaker.)

name: Zoltán BALCZÓ
text: - Ms. President!Migration is at the forefront of the EU summit's conclusions.They propose the introduction of a new Schengen border control code, increase the return rate in addition to stopping the flow of migrants, and state that migration should be dealt with primarily at the place of origin of the trigger.These are positive findings, the question is whether they will be put into practice.There is an issue in which the Council does not acknowledge its failure: this is a mandatory resettlement quota, which has practically failed, but which the Council still keeps on the agenda and would otherwise like to return to in December in terms of responsibility and solidarity.I believe that the responsibility lies primarily with those who have sent a political message as a responsible leader that is considered irresponsible and that has led to millions of economic migrants arriving in Europe instead of 10,000 refugees.

name: Franck PROUST
text: - Madam President, the migratory challenges at a time when the French government is struggling to cope with the relocation of migrants with the closure of the Calais jungle, the war in Syria or even CETA: we are all running behind news that is causing crises. Worse, we are provoking new ones on trade issues when we are in control. All member states have supported CETA, but Europe has been taken hostage by Wallonia. The false arguments, the untruths and the political posture will always remain stronger than all the guarantees, because we are in the irrational. With Paul Magnette's request for human rights guarantees in Canada, we reach the height of ridicule. Who can be the referent or who is credible to explain that our companies will access Canadian public markets, that our geographical indications will be defended, that investment arbitration has been revised as desired by certain Member States and citizens? Who is credible? Politicians, NGOs, the media or companies? The lack of education, communication and State involvement, whether in trade defense agreements or instruments, has made us all lose credibility. Mr Juncker, I agree with you. The red line between protection and protectionism must guide our decisions. Jobs must be saved or created if we firmly and pragmatically defend our interests. Tomorrow it will be the other way around if we let the rest of the world make the rules of the global economy for us. Those who stick to their positions without a proposal will inevitably bear this responsibility.

name: Enrique GUERRERO SALOM
text: - Madam President, after several years in this House, I have come to the conclusion that a semiologist, even if he is a simple amateur, is better able to interpret the results of the Council than a Member of Parliament. If that semiologist goes to the Spanish version of the Council's conclusions, he will find that the terms "controls" and the terms "returns" appear up to fourteen times, and the term "prevent" appears twice: a real win. And it is true that it is necessary to try to order and regulate the arrival but, above all, it is necessary to prevent the departure from the places of origin of the immigrants. And to prevent departure, the European Union has to strengthen its capacity as a global actor and its intervention through, of course, the global strategy, through the European Pact on Immigration and Asylum, through investments abroad and through the development of our security and defense capacity. Mr Juncker has pointed out, and also the President of the Council, that initial steps have been taken on this path: some agreements with African countries. That is the way, but you have to go much faster and you have to go in a more intense way. And the European Union has to play a role as a relevant actor to guarantee humanitarian access to the places where real atrocities are taking place: the emergency medical exit from Aleppo and care for its suffering citizens, who are subjected to continuous bombardments. A final question is that which refers to youth unemployment. It appears in paragraph 19 of the chapter 'Other economic and global issues', but it is a fundamental matter for the Union and we must not abandon or be content with this problem. We can't just wait until December or February of next year for results to start showing.

name: Sander LOONES
text: - There is a lot to do about the trade agreement that Europe wants to conclude with Canada. Everyone is ready to sign, except Wallonia, except Paul Magnette, except the PS, the Parti Socialiste. They say this deal will ensure that multinationals will write our laws. That is not in that agreement. They say we will have to overhaul our environmental legislation. That is not in that agreement. They say we will have to privatize our healthcare, that our labor market will diminish, and so on. That is not in that agreement. That's bullshit! What I hear now is that the PS would apparently be on the verge of turning its back today, perhaps to lift its veto today and perhaps give its approval. To save face, the party will hide behind an additional European statement, while there is nothing new in that statement; everything that is in it is already in the trade agreement itself. And when that happens, it will become clear to everyone what kind of party the PS is: a party that opts for party-political profiling, for its own political games, for its own selfish self and not for European cooperation.

name: Marielle DE SARNEZ
text: - Madam President, what is happening in Wallonia must not be obscured or brushed aside with the wave of the hand. On the contrary, it must be analyzed and understood to find new perspectives. First, it is the expression of an immense need for protection that must be heard. European employment and way of life cannot be variables for adjusting international trade, and free trade cannot be the only political horizon offered to the people. Second, the Union's trade policy must get rid of its naivety. We cannot continue to have the least effective anti-dumping duties and the most open government procurement in the world. Let us finally equip ourselves with worthy trade defense instruments. Finally, at the beginning of December, let us have a demanding position vis-à-vis China. Trade policy and the defense of our strategic interests are not mutually exclusive. The United States is a clear demonstration of this.

name: Martina ANDERSON
text: – Madam President, on Monday night, I spoke about Brexit and its impact on Ireland’s Good Friday Agreement. This morning, I will focus on desperate refugees who are dying at the border of the EU, yet the Council recommits itself to keeping them out rather than keeping them safe.  Rather than reassess the current obvious failings of Europe’s asylum policy, the Council seems content to continue with more of the same. Over 70 000 refugees remain stranded at Europe’s borders. Almost 40 000 men, women, little boys and little girls lie at the bottom of the Mediterranean Sea.  The EU-Turkey deal agreed six months ago has failed all tests in relation to humanity and effectiveness. Turkey has experienced a so-called coup and a criminal clampdown by the State. Turkey is not a safe country. Ask the Kurds, ask the journalists, ask political opponents of the regime, ask the Syrian child refugees being forced to work in Turkey’s factories for EUR 1 per hour. Europe and the EU needs to do much, much more about this humanitarian crisis.

name: Ulrike LUNACEK
text: - Madam President, representative of the Commission and the Council, ladies and gentlemen! Walling, blocking and sealing off - that is the sad summary of this summit and these summit resolutions when it comes to refugees and migration. Because here it is stipulated for the first time that humanitarian aid and development cooperation funds should not be used for poverty reduction, development, equality, rule of law, democratization, but are misused to operate European migration management because we as the European Union are unable to support the member states are not prepared to actually divide more refugees and distribute them fairly on this continent. A lot of development cooperation NGOs - you know some of them: Caritas, Care, etc., maybe you donate sometimes, Mr Tusk or other council members - have warned that migration management and deportation agreements are linked to development and trade policy measures. You know what? Regimes and dictatorships will be happy about it. Because corruption, clientelism etc. are promoted precisely by this, and these are exactly the causes for migration and flight. (The President cut off the speaker.)

name: Rolandas PAKSAS
text: - Mr Juncker, Mr Tusk, we are talking about free trade agreements, and at the same time the biggest trading companies are competing with each other, raising the prices of essential products. We are talking about trade agreements with the United States and Canada, which do not have enough safeguards, not only to create new jobs, but also to preserve existing ones in Europe. We are talking about peace in Syria, once again calling for a ceasefire, but apart from words, we are not finding the courage to take action that would eliminate the causes of the war. Apparently, on the eve of the Council meeting, no further negotiations on peace agreements in Ukraine have ended. It is true that no one talks too widely about these negotiations, which were led by the leaders of Germany, France and Russia and Ukraine. Maybe because there was no agreement on anything specific in them. Mr President, we are still trying to build a secure future for Europe in words. However, the future cannot be created by them, but by actions. An iceberg seems to be drifting towards Europe, as well as towards the famous Titanic, which also seemed unsinkable - a huge iceberg of languages, bureaucratic procedures and inability to function.

name: Mario BORGHEZIO
text: - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, the European Union did not defend the internal borders, Hungary defended them, putting up a wall, Spain defended them in Ceuta and Melilla with a four-meter high net; the citizens of Gorino, a small village, a small Italian fraction, successfully opposed their heroism and repelled the invasion. Like many, many citizens also in France, where illegal immigrants are distributed galore, would like to oppose. And then the promise in the Council document to relocate 160,000 migrants, but 4,000 a day arrive in Sicily alone, who can think, and if no other country, because there is only Italy that is obliged to welcome everyone. How can you expect 160,000 to be relocated! These are words in the wind and it is shameful that the Council has echoed them. And then as regards the agreements with Africa, it is said that the High Commissioner will give an answer in December, but in the meantime the invasion takes place. No to invasion!

name: Esteban GONZÁLEZ PONS
text: - Madam President, we are at our worst. Brexit can become a method and a model. Europe is showing that it is a project that can be reversible. And the refugee crisis has shown us that our solidarity is insufficient and, furthermore, it is waning. Furthermore, we have now blocked the Deal with decent Canada. If we are not able to sign an agreement even with Canada, we will not sign a free trade agreement with anyone. Free trade will continue, but we will stay out, and staying out of free trade means less prosperity, it means less employment, and it means less well-being. It makes no sense for the interests of a region of 2 million inhabitants to block the interests of a continent of 500 million inhabitants. Democracy works in the opposite direction: the interest and opinion of the majority always trump the opinion of the minority. Globalization is a fact; it is not an ideology. And those who oppose globalization and those who oppose free trade do so using mobile phones from companies whose workers are located in the United States, China, Mexico, Brazil, Singapore, Taiwan, Japan, France, Germany, Israel, Malta and Belgium. It is a true contradiction. As I was saying, globalization is a fact; it is not an ideology. To oppose globalization is to oppose the advance of time. Populism is a reaction; it's not an answer. Complex problems demand complex solutions and, of course, in an adult world, being in politics with childish attitudes constitutes a political pathology.

name: Patrizia TOIA
text: - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, pay attention to the numbers, and then I will talk to you above all about numbers: here, this year 153,450 people arrived in Italy, of which 20,000 minors. A record year is looming, as well as a record year for the dead, which have tripled. To understand, I also tell my French friends, the Italians face a Calais every week and when the weather is good we face a Calais every two days and we are proud to do so. (the President urges silence in the Chamber) This exceptional increase that I have spoken of, Mr Commission representative, Mr Vice-President, is enough to make you look at the Italian budget with due understanding. Saving costs, welcoming costs, integrating costs, children cost money. And then: either Europe sustains these expenses, if instead Italy supports them they must be recognized, it is our duty to acknowledge them. The choice is relentless: either you let people die or you pay the price, even economic, even budgetary, which is a choice of European civilization, of which, I repeat, I am proud to dissociate myself from other unworthy Italian words that I have heard in this House. So don't leave Italy alone, because a new anti-European demagogy of populism and social tensions is emerging. And then I ask you, Mr President Timmermans, if Italy, which does its part and is praised, is at the center of the crosshairs for the budget, what measures and sanctions will you adopt for the countries that refuse to accept refugees?

name: Richard SULÍK
text: - Madam President, dear Mr Timmermans!The European Central Bank has already bought public debt for more than EUR 1,400 billion.This is in clear contradiction to Article 123 of the EU Treaty, which forbids state financing.At the same time, the European Central Bank has lowered interest rates to zero, thus creating ideal conditions for ever new debts: unlimited money that costs nothing.So it's not surprising that big countries like France, Italy, Spain keep going into new debt, and you tolerate it!The Commission is doing almost nothing about this new debt.This combination of printing money, no interest and increasing debt leads straight to disaster.It may be another five or 20 years, but one day our common currency will crumble because of these devastating policies.

name: Izaskun BILBAO BARANDICA
text: - Madam President, the last European summit and the content of the declaration and the Bratislava road map could stir hope, but yesterday's debate on budget and priorities for 2016 portrays the difference between the big words of the States and his works - more timid - in the effort to build a true European sovereignty. We need leadership, and not a declaration of intent, because Syria is still on fire and there is no common position on the role of Russia or the solution to the refugee and immigration crisis. Because the unification of the energy or digital markets, the resurrection of our social model with special emphasis on the Youth Guarantee and the fight against poverty, is still pending. Because the States do not meet the priorities that give meaning to the European Fund for Strategic Investments or run aground our policy of trade agreements with the CETA crisis. Because we are slow in the face of foreign dumping. And leading a Europe that decisively overcomes these traffic jams is the best policy against the walls, which even the populists who defend them know are useless.

name: Luke Ming FLANAGAN
text: – Madam President, this is the week when people of Wallonia said no to tyranny by rejecting CETA. Also – and contrary to what Ms Vautmans said in relation to all countries supporting it – in the last week Ireland’s upper House, the Seanad, rejected this deal. Let’s be clear though: the EU hierarchy does not care what the general public thinks. I hear talk of breaking the deadlocks, but translated, that means: we will break your country unless you do what you’re told. I know the reality of that – I’m from Ireland. We were bullied for voting for Nice and then again with Lisbon. Their argument is that if you vote no, then you don’t understand; if you vote yes, then you’re enlightened. The reality is this: the EU and Canada already have judicial systems that offer rights and protections equally to all its citizens, companies and corporations, with appeals possible all the way to the Supreme Court or the European Court of Justice. Mr Pittella talks about peddling; here we have another type of peddling:  the peddling of lies. ISDS and ICS are one of the same; if you change the label on a tin of little cat food to one for caviar, it does not change its contents. It still has the same rubbish within.

name: Marcus PRETZELL
text: -  Madam President, ladies and gentlemen! Mr Juncker said today that the rejection of CETA is protectionism, whereas he is in favor of protectionism for European steel. That is only apparently a contradiction in terms. In fact, it's consistent. The consistent continuation of what has been the policy of this European Union for years. In truth, we practice protectionism for the benefit of large corporations and at the expense of small and medium-sized companies. That is also the policy of the European Union, not only in terms of trade agreements, but also in terms of internal market rules. On the Dublin Agreement: The Dublin Agreement is to be revised. However, states refuse in advance to participate in this to an extent that would be relevant. Finally, take note that this European Union will not work any better if it deepens! A return to the internal market and only to the internal market would be consistent.

name: Elisabetta GARDINI
text: - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, finally, I say finally, in this Chamber, today, I heard about the Central Mediterranean, on the Africa - Italy route, where the situation has not improved, indeed it has worsened, because we have this year, a record year of landings, we have not only surpassed last year, but also what had been the 2014 record and landings have only grown in Italy. So, well, that finally the Council has recognized that a concrete commitment is needed, with concrete measures to arrive quickly to combat illegal immigration and stabilize that area of ​​the Mediterranean, we will avoid many useless deaths, many useless deaths, they are a an impressive number, and we will restore security to our citizens. But look, in this way we will also have an advantage on the economic situation, because if there is no situation of stability, investors do not come, they do not come to invest in Europe, they will choose other areas of the world. And more and more will choose other areas of the world, while we need to grow again, we need to create new jobs, to give our young people a future. And this is why we as an Italian delegation have always said, for example, that we are against the recognition of China as a market economy, because it is not a market economy. This is why I say with force and passion: let's not abandon the target of 20% of the gross domestic product coming from manufacturing by 2020, let's defend the real economy, because without industry, without small and medium enterprises, we cannot get out of the crisis.

name: Dame Glenis WILLMOTT
text: – Madam President, last week’s Council meeting was attended by the UK Prime Minister, Theresa May, for the first time. If she was hoping for an easy ride then she was sadly mistaken. With a warning from François Hollande that a hard Brexit would mean hard negotiations, not the pick-and-mix many had hoped for or had alluded to during the referendum campaign. The reality is that Britain’s future prosperity depends on having sensible negotiations with other EU countries, not the chaos some would advocate. Membership of the single market, on which many jobs depend, is surely crucial for our economy. The resulting uncertainty has already seen the pound plummet, meaning higher food bills, inevitably affecting the most vulnerable in our society.  I have been dismayed so far at the tone taken by the British Government in regard to upcoming negotiations. We will not succeed in getting the best result for all by threatening, hectoring and lecturing. The Prime Minister needs a plan and it is clear the UK Government does not have one. So stop the talk of hard or soft Brexit because the next steps we take are huge. Let us at least try and take them together.

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: - Madam President, one of the main challenges facing the Commission is how to position the European Union as a global leader in trade and ensure a period of new rapid growth that Europe has witnessed since the Second World War. Developments around CETA show that a large number of our citizens feel threatened by one Canada, so I think it is illusory to expect that in the foreseeable future we will reach an agreement with global giants such as the USA, India, China or Russia. Nothing happens by accident. Citizens are losing confidence in political elites, and the Commission has contributed to this by doing too little to inform citizens and allowing a monopoly on populists in public communication around CETA and TTIP. The Commission has so far failed to convince anyone, not even me personally, that these agreements will not benefit exclusively multinational corporations, while SMEs will only get crumbs. This is an important issue and the Commission must clarify it for the citizens and for us who are their representatives.

name: Marietje SCHAAKE
text: – Madam President, President Tusk said that last week’s Council was not a crisis meeting. Well, I believe the lack of common positions, even in light of the worst crises – war and the migration it causes – is a crisis; a crisis of political leadership that does not escape our citizens. Trade may be the next victim and the EU’s ability and credibility to negotiate agreements at all is on the line. Regardless of whether the Socialists Walloon cliffhanger ends in a last-minute solution, a lot of damage has been done. The world is watching this stumbling and I wonder whether anyone is looking at this bigger picture and the longer term impact. What is clear is the need for more engagement with NGOs and citizens by those giving a unanimous mandate to the Commission and the Council, a mandate that is the logical consequence of leveraging the single market not only for global economic gains, but also to raise the bar of standards. It is the Council – Member States individually – that has to mitigate the negative consequences, but I hear very few leaders explain this. I think criticism has had too much space because of an absence of leadership. If you do not qualify that as a crisis now, please do not wait until it is, and do not let cooperation with Canada be the reason for it.

name: Ildikó GÁLL-PELCZ
text: - Ms. President! For two years now, there has been no European Union summit where the negotiating table has not stood up without the issue of migration remaining on the agenda. This problem has been around for two years and they are unable to find an answer to it. An answer that could be a common European answer. It has finally been stated that the protection of the Schengen borders is a priority. It has finally been said that European law must be respected. It has finally been said that the problem should not be imported into the European Union, but resolved on the ground. I could also say that progress has been made. What is missing is also to state that the mandatory quota response that has been devised is not a solution to anything. In Hungary, 98% of respondents said they could not accept this. I can only represent the opinions of 3.3 million people who have said no to this solution. You don’t have to force what doesn’t go. Instead, we should have talked much more emphatically about what our common policies are, how important investment policy is. That we will not have investors if we cannot provide an adequate response to the migration crisis. The shift in emphasis in the Council is as if we are not talking about converging the economic and social situations of the Member States or just talking about development. But at least such a big problem is not listening to the voices of national parliaments and citizens in the meantime.

name: Tibor SZANYI
text: - Ms. President! The previous speaker was also about Hungary, and I have a place here to continue this line of thought. If you were in Hungary now and looked at the Hungarian press as a simple Hungarian citizen, you could read that Prime Minister Viktor Orbán had knocked down the heads of government of the other member states, usually the participants in the European Council, and also he heroically prevented the European Commission, personally Mr. Jean-Claude Juncker, its president, from deploying a town in Hungary. Well, this is the Member State's interpretation of the European Council meeting, at least in Hungarian reading. I think that in order to counteract such loosened thoughts, much greater efforts are needed on the part of both the Council and the Commission, but even Parliament, to explain to European citizens what is happening, why it is happening, how does it happen.

name: Luděk NIEDERMAYER
text: – Madam President, I would like to make just a few remarks on the Council agenda. First of all on migration, I guess we must understand that the programme is not over. Just look at the data, and look at the pictures from Italy and Greece. The pressure is lower but I call on the Council not to underestimate the situation and not to repeat the mistakes that we made in recent months. We must act, and we must act together. That is the only way to solve the issue. Secondly, let me express surprise about the behaviour of the Commission and the Council in the case of creating the trade defence instruments for Europe. We have known for many years that in December this year there would be a change in our relation to China, and it was said not only by this House that we must react. I am surprised the debate is taking place only now.  Finally, on Russia, I guess even a few hours after the Council meeting we can see that we made a mistake, and that our policy does not work. It is costing lives and it is not getting us any closer to a solution. I do not want to remind you of the situation in Ukraine, which is tragic. So I call on the Council to act clearly, decisively and responsibly.  Last let me say that many speakers in this House talk about democracy and the voice of the people. If I understand correctly, 28 out of the 28 governments of the Member States support the CETA agreements. I don’t want to remind you, for example, of the history of my Communist country and what was ‘the voice of the people’ there, so please be responsible.

name: Simona BONAFÈ
text: - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, President Pittella, a little while ago, to describe the results of the European Council, recalled the words of Romano Prodi, President of the European Commission: "to go forward you have to pedal". To complete the picture, I want to recall the words of another great Italian, father of European socialism, Pietro Nenni, who in one of his last speeches said "we must either renew or perish". Here, I believe that this is the crossroads facing our Europe today. And enough of the timid and routine European Councils! Our continent is facing epochal emergencies from refugees begging for our welcome. It is therefore right to recognize the effort, also of a financial nature, made by states such as Italy at the forefront of immigration, but we also await concrete commitments on the division between Member States and on Africa, with partnership agreements for migrants from countries in transit and origin. But we must also give answers on the front of work, social security and the possibility for our citizens to lead a dignified life and for this we need the extension of the European investment plan, but also economic policies that are more attentive to the fight against unemployment.

name: Paulo RANGEL
text: - Madam President, I would like to start by referring to the CETA agreement and to say here that I do not understand how in this House there are so many people who are concerned, starting with the Greens, with the CETA agreement, because that is what Donald Trump wants , is what Marine Le Pen wants, is what Farage wants. They want to end freedom of trade. We are here at the service of this protectionist ideology, which is causing even parties that have an open view of the world to be held hostage to that protectionist ideology. They are next to Le Pen, they are next to Trump when they are against the CETA agreement. And it is necessary to make this very clear, because there was never a commercial agreement that had standards of social and environmental defense as good, as bold, as bold as CETA. I didn’t see anyone standing up here about the Vietnam agreement and in Vietnam there are problems with children and women and with working hours, there are problems with the environment, and nobody has any problems, but in Canada, where we we got an agreement that, at the moment, is a model for all the major trading partners in the world, we are here to undo that agreement. Therefore, I also draw attention to the agreement with Ukraine and our Dutch friends, because it is important to reinforce sanctions against Russia and there I am against the Portuguese Government, which now wants to end the sanctions against Russia, but what we what we can do to pressure Russia is to have a free trade agreement with Ukraine. That, yes, will be the great, shall we say, form of pressure on Putin and on his intentions.

name: Liisa JAAKONSAARI
text: - Mr President, the heart and soul of the European Union is peace and the key words are diplomacy and dialogue.This, for example, was demonstrated at best by this Iranian nuclear deal.It is difficult with Russia at the moment because there has been a paradigm shift in Russia.Russia does not want to get closer to Europe, but nonetheless, Europe must get closer to Russia and make every effort to gain a European interest in Russia as well.I think that a new Helsinki process should be launched - not forgetting Crimea, it is against international law, it is a crime.I am reallypleased that theCouncilstronglycondemnedAleppobarbarism, andit was considered thatifthe war continuesin Syria, thenthisisfrom the cradleof Christianitysooncoming tothe tomb ofhuman culture.We must not accept that.

name: Anna ZÁBORSKÁ
text: - Several of my colleagues have expressed their dissatisfaction with the last Council meeting, and I understand this feeling, which stems from unfulfilled expectations. As Manfred Weber said, the Commission has proposals, this Parliament is ready to approve them, but what is missing is the ability of the Member States to agree. And then to act with the determination that we expect from them, not only we, but especially the citizens of the European Union. But at the same time, I would like to mention one important thing: that an agreement between states rarely comes from one day to the next. As I listened to the reports of President Tusk and President Juncker, I perceived two messages. The first was that the Member States were not ready to agree on everything. This is undoubtedly a shame. But at the same time, it was clear from these reports that the Prime Ministers of the Member States met in a working meeting, that their deliberations reflected the current problems facing Europe; they will simply have to meet again, a few more times, until they reach an agreement. Ladies and gentlemen, good agreements need time. Let us take this time and give it to the Council as well. Because it is the hastily compromised compromises that have caused most of Europe's current problems.

name: Costas MAVRIDES
text: S & amp; D). - Madam President, I will focus on just one point and address the Commission. The evaluation report of the 72 criteria for granting visa liberalization to Turkey has been approved by the Commission and, based on this, only seven of the 72 criteria remain to be met. I therefore ask the Commission: the criteria met include serious issues, which are Turkey's obligations to the European Union and also concern the Republic of Cyprus, but which Erdogan refuses to implement. I will mention, in particular, only two: How does Turkey respect and cooperate in the management of the border with the Member States of the European Union, as long as it claims the seas of the Republic of Cyprus? Simple question. In closing, I would also like to ask the Commission: have you read and approved this report? Such a simple question.

name: Dubravka ŠUICA
text: - Madam President, Mr. Tusk, Mr. Timmermans, the fact is that at the beginning of this migrant crisis, we asked a question and said that we must be in solidarity and responsible. Today we may wonder if we have achieved that. The fact is that Europeans feel insecure. And because of CETA and because of migration and because of other relationships. We must do everything we can to make the decisions of both the Commission and the Council enforceable, and that is what we must all contribute together. We must make the Agreement with Turkey remain in force. He closed the Western Balkan route and today we have maybe a dozen migrants, unlike the thousands of migrants who passed through that route. We must do everything we can to ensure that the decisions of the Commission and the Council can be implemented. Many feel insecure because we cannot implement the decisions we have made, and that is what we must all insist on together. We need to find a way to refute the false arguments against CETA. Many do not understand that globalization exists today and that we have accepted globalization by the very fact that the European Union must become a factor on the scene. I am in favor of strengthening the role of the European Commission's foreign policy service and giving High Representative Mogherini greater powers. Europe must be a factor. When we talk about migration, we have to deal with it in the country of origin. How are we going to solve them in the country of origin if the European Union is not a factor at the table with big players. And so I ask you all to find a compromise in some way and allow the Council and the Commission to continue to act, of course in cooperation with Parliament.

name: Cécile Kashetu KYENGE
text: - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, another interlocutory European Council on immigration. The commitments made cannot remain on paper, there is no more time, words must be followed by deeds. It is clear to everyone, except populists, the way to go: to have a new European immigration policy, a global policy based on the principle of solidarity and fair sharing of responsibilities among all Member States. We must immediately turn words into deeds. Concrete facts, complying with the relocation of asylum seekers from Italy and Greece to all Member States, respecting the commitments undertaken. Concrete facts, implementing the European migration compact without securitarian criminalization of immigration, but aiming to affect the root causes of immigration. Concrete facts, towards the launch of the European investment plan of countries of origin, third countries of origin of migratory flows to favor development. No more referrals!

name: Elmar BROK
text: - Madam President, Mr President of the European Council, Mr Vice-President, colleagues! Two points in brief: the situation in Syria and the partial helplessness to react to it, which was expressed in the Council, as well as the fact that we are not even at the negotiating tables on certain points, leads me to believe that the Bratislava process must be successful. I encourage you to continue the Security and Defense Policy Summit in December and continue to Rome. If we don't want to overstrain our role as a global payer without being of benefit, we have to become a global player. And for that we need military capabilities. I ask you to create this possibility. The second point: the exit from Ceta. It's not about Ceta anymore. The point is that we in the European Union are increasingly only looking from our own lower level and not from above to see what effect this has on the whole. That is when the Canadian trade minister has to join the party council of the SPD in Germany when the Federal Constitutional Court comes up with a ruling that every country can withdraw from a treaty - with which union do you want to conclude treaties? - this is Wallonia. But I can give you just as many points on other subjects. We need more awareness and an attitude that the effect is viewed as a whole and not the effect of the individual. And for that we have to use the instruments. Majority decision-making is the instrument of democracy and efficiency, while unanimity is the instrument of stagnation and blackmail. For this reason, for example, we can no longer make a mixed contract, but make the European treaty! And the governments of the Member States are called upon to support the Commission in making such proposals. Otherwise they sin against each other their own interests.(The President cut off the speaker.)

name: Marlene MIZZI
text: - Consistency with the Member States, the Member States of which, in the case of a Member State, the Member States may, in the case of a Member State of the former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia, Uniti. As a result, it is possible to enter into the same agreement as in the case of the Kunsill, the Alleppo regime. Illum qiegħda nitkellem dwar Aleppo għax ma nistax ninjora; I have learned how much more is done. I nistax ninjora din it-traġedja umana li qiegħda tibdel lil Aleppo f'belt missi bi 300 000 persuna ivivili - maqbudin f'post u mċaħħdin minn ilma, minn ikel, minn provvisti u which medika u limitati f'qiegħ ta 'sptar. Agħar minn hekk, 100 000 maqbudin fil-belt huma tfal esposti għat-tbatija estrema u t-terrur ta 'bombi ta' kuljum. However, in the case of milled all-milled products, the following shall apply: - jitwaqqfu dawn l-atroċitajiet; - the immediate nature of the milled butter is reduced; - u humanitarian aid biex titwassal l-għajnuna umanitarja u jkunu evakwati l-pazjenti.

name: Ivo BELET
text: - Mr Vice-President already agrees with the previous speaker. Please, let's take a new initiative to stop the horror in Aleppo. Second, Mr Vice-President: CETA. Our European quality standards in social, environmental and consumer protection must be protected. These are high standards that must not be undermined. We all agree on that. Those guarantees are now in the text and have been clarified in the past hours and days, even today. That is why today is the time - I see you nod, Mr Timmermans - to reach an agreement. I think you can play an important role in that too, you have the confidence of the players. A warm appeal to our Walloon friends to come to an agreement here and to close ranks in Europe, and subsequently, dear colleagues, to learn lessons from this and to guarantee that we can move forward again. Mr Brok said it: we have to prove that we can make decisions in Europe and not play into the hands of our friends who sit here on the right, who often shout and scream and sometimes hit each other's brains. A crisis like the one around CETA is also an opportunity. Let us take into account the concerns of the people, national and regional parliaments and civil society, and reach an agreement that will be approved by the majority in this Parliament.

name: Kati PIRI
text: - Increasing vigilance, stricter controls at sea, hermetically closing borders and marking all migration as illegal; that is how the European Council approaches the refugee issue. Where peace and security, the protection of human rights and respect for the rule of law were central to our foreign policy, the focus increasingly seems to be becoming one-dimensional, namely preventing migrants. Last week, the further implementation of the refugee agreement between Turkey and the EU was discussed, but government leaders failed to emphasize its original purpose. The agreement was to exchange the illegal and dangerous routes for an airlift. This airlift for refugees has so far not been realized and EU leaders even fail to mention it in the conclusions. If we as the European Union want to show that we take our own values ​​seriously and are a reliable partner for third countries, it is high time to deliver on our own commitments.

name: Vladimír MAŇKA
text: - The role of the European Council is to steer Europe.Without helping Africa to create jobs, we cannot solve the reasons for migration.The UN expects the continent's population to grow from today's 1.2 billion to 4 billion by the end of the century.It would be a development catastrophe, a food shortage, a migration catastrophe.We will do Africa, but also Europe, with the greatest kindness, if children are protected from malaria, we will remove Ebola, we will stimulate investment and job creation, and we will enable girls to get a secondary education.Regarding trade agreements with Canada and the United States: National politicians are generally responsible for opposing these agreements.They cannot hide behind the European Commission, leaving public space to populists.Leaders need to show courage and clearly state why we need free trade, what makes free trade positive.

name: Ana GOMES
text: - Madam President, how can it be explained that the European Council meets on the migration crisis and the conclusions do not include a single reference to refugees, asylum, fundamental rights, legal and secure access to Europe, so that we do not continue to hand over crisis management to traffickers. What a denatured Europe is this, obsessed with border protection, who sees people asking for protection as a threat, who measures political success in terms of the number of forced returns, who defends the illegal and immoral EU-Turkey pact, which he praises as partner regimes repressive as the Ethiopian, from whose misery and repression flee immigrant refugees? There were times when I criticized the European Council for inaction, but today I am truly scared. This anti-European route by Bratislava from Fortaleza Europa is a direct attack on our current security and for generations to come. The Europe of defense is urgently needed, but dominated by the strategy and policy centered on the values ​​and objectives of the European Union, which has been lacking, even to show Russia that the continued aggression against Ukraine and the merciless bombings in Aleppo will not go unpunished .

name: Andrzej GRZYB
text: - Madam President!I think that the three topics highlighted by the President of the Council, Donald Tusk - migration, trade, Russia - were of course the most exciting in the part on CETA.However, in fact, the problem of migration seems to be in the forefront, because here is good news: the flow of people migrating to the Greek islands has decreased and there are positive effects of cooperation with African countries, where there is a source of migration.This is where we must counteract it.Another issue is border protection.We all have now recognized that border security and protection are both regulating the difficult problem of migration and ensuring the safety of these people.And trade issues - not only CETA, but also counteracting dumping practices.This seems to me to be of key importance for the stability and development of our industry, in particular the steel sector.

name: Juan Fernando LÓPEZ AGUILAR
text: - Madam President, I have paid special attention to the emigration chapter of this European Council and, of course, I am struck by the positive assessment that has been made of the infamous deal with Turkey. Has the Council given a thought to the extremely negative assessment it received from this Parliament? Has the Council devoted a reflection to the situation after the coup, with thousands of journalists and judges jailed? Has the Council devoted a serious reflection to the negative view that continues to perpetrate on immigration, on foreigners and, particularly, on the arrival on European soil of very vulnerable people: women, defenseless children who drown in the Mediterranean as a consequence? of the deviation towards the Mediterranean of the migratory pressure contained in numbers in Turkey? Has the Council made a commitment to strengthen solidarity with Italy and Greece - not just the European Border Guard? And above all, has the Council dedicated a word to that infamous and anti-European referendum that was perpetrated in Hungary on 2 October last?

name: Notis MARIAS
text: ECR). - Mr Tusk, I heard you mentioned Greece for only 10 seconds. Do you think that the issue has been resolved in relation to immigrants and refugees? Do you have an idea of ​​what is happening in the Aegean islands? Do you know that there are 14,000 people trapped? Do you know that there are only 7,000 places? Do you know that the European Union does not allow Greece Do you know that out of the 66,400 relocations that should have taken place a year ago, only 5,200 have taken place? Is this the situation? Are you allowed to devote even 10 seconds to your speech? on the refugee issue in Greece? And in addition, do you want the return from Germany of those refugees who passed and went there through Dublin III? Unacceptable situation! Your attitude is unacceptable!

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: - Madam President, the migrant crisis is definitely destroying the foundations of the European Union.Solving the problems with FRONTEX, solving the problems with Turkey are certainly ways that are welcome.However, the problem will not be solved if we do not become in solidarity between us.We cannot watch, as if we are blind, what is happening in Greece or what is happening in Italy.Without the mutual solidarity of the member states, a European project as conceived does not make sense because the migrant crisis may one day be a little smaller, a little bigger.The Western Balkan route is currently closed in some way, but migration will not stop.And I want to say, speaking of the Western Balkan route, that what we are experiencing is really a shame for the Government of the Republic of Slovenia, which is building walls and wires towards the member state, towards Croatia.

name: Josu JUARISTI ABAUNZ
text: -  Madam president;It is not just Wallonia, ladies and gentlemen;Ska Keller underlined that the Council has closed its eyes to opposition on the street and in some parliaments.I would like to provide another piece of information: more than 2 000 cities and territorial communities in Europe have already declared themselves as CETA and TTIP free zones, and this should also be taken into account.So no, it's not just Wallonia.A note on the arrival of migrants and refugees to Europe.The European Commission welcomes the fact that fewer arrive from Turkey and therefore less die in the Aegean Sea.But the Commission hides the B-side of all this: the unacceptable limbo in which they are living poorly at our external borders and at some points within the Union, and the 3 740 people who have already died since 1 January in the Mediterranean Sea.

name: Kristina WINBERG
text: - Madam President!We previously heard Mr Weber compare the EU to a bicycle that must be stepped on in order for it to move forward.Quite logical.But my recommendation to Mr Weber and the rest of you in here is to press the brake instead.Park the bike and think in which direction you are going to ride.I would rather equate the EU project with a punctured bicycle wheel that can no longer be repaired.It feels like everything you do is artificial respiration.We triple the funding for Frontex.We will have a new Frontex.We will reform Dublin, create new mechanisms, forcibly distribute migrants - yes, I do not know what else you can come up with.The only question is whether the people of the Member States know what you are doing.In any case, I will follow Britain's decision and bring my people to a referendum and leave this building.

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: NI). - Madam President, as expected, the Council has not taken any substantive decision to resolve the problems facing the European Union. On immigration, the presidents are celebrating because the flows of illegal immigrants from Turkey to Greece have decreased. They probably have not been informed that these have been repeated for a long time as before. So instead of threatening Turkey with severing accession relations, they are focusing on reviewing visa commitments. They are also celebrating the creation of the Coast Guard and the Border Guard. But how is it possible to deal with the problem with this bureaucratic organization, which does nothing more than accompany the illegal immigrants from Turkey to Greece and record them? The problem is not addressed by recording. It is treated with prevention. Finally, in foreign policy we have a unilateral condemnation of Russia and Syria and, paradoxically, we are not referring to the other forces involved, such as the jihadists, the United States and the other powers.

name: Maria GRAPINI
text: - I would like to draw your attention to the regulations.Today I started the debate 10 minutes later.10 people can't talk.I was the first person at 9.01, I signed up to speak.It does not seem fair and democratic to me, you should postpone the debate for 10 minutes, as long as you delayed the start of the debate.

name: Martin SCHULZ
text: Ms. Grapini, I can understand that.Otherwise you are a regular winner of the catch-the-eye procedure.But that has just been concluded.I had already given the floor to Mr Timmermans.

name: Frans TIMMERMANS
text: First Vice-President of the Commission. – Mr President, just a few reflections after the debate in the plenary. First of all, the migration issue: I share the concerns of all those who have raised their worries about what is happening in the southern Mediterranean. It is a tragedy that so many people are still drowning in spite of the tremendous efforts of the Italian authorities to save as many people as possible.  We need to have a comprehensive approach about this. Let me be very clear: better border protection is part of the answer, but it is not a panacea for the migration crisis. If we believe we can hide behind border and fences and rid ourselves of collective solidarity in this issue, we are being delusional. Delusional! Just imagine that in the next generation or two, the population of Africa will be anywhere between three and six billion people. How do you think the Mediterranean will ever be wide enough, or fences ever high enough to stop these people from coming to Europe if we do not have a policy that will offer them perspective in their own nations and their own continents, in their own cities and villages. So do not believe in the delusion of borders as the only solution to this problem and do not believe in the illusion that you can rid yourself of collective European solidarity in tackling this huge crisis. If you think you can rid yourself of the solidarity, others will rid themselves also of solidarity and that will be the end of the European Union. So I believe strongly in a collective approach and a comprehensive approach that addresses all the issues linked to the migration crisis.  On CETA let me just say one thing: if you believe, at the beginning of what I would call the 4th industrial revolution, that you can protect yourselves from not entering into agreements with parts of the world where they share our values, you are delusional.  Look at what is happening in the world’s economy, look how fast the world’s economy is changing. We need to have comprehensive agreements with those parts of the world which share our values, which want social protection like we do, which want environmental protection like we do. It is only together that we will face the forces of globalisation in a way that will guarantee the rights our citizens demand and I really call upon the Walloon Parliament to study carefully.  Mr Lambert said that it is the only parliament that has actually read the Treaty – well, I will leave that to his own judgment. I fear I do not agree with that assessment. But, if they read the explanations and the assurances that we have given, the clear indications on social protection, on environmental protection, on assurances that disputes will be dealt with by judges in a way that is in accordance with our legal criteria; if they have studied this perhaps they can come to a conclusion of this matter. It is clear to me – let me end on this point – that it is not an isolated matter that people worry about trade agreements. It is not an isolated matter that people sometimes think that building fences is an answer to our problem. It is an element in a world that is changing so fast that people fear that they have lost control of their destinies. Only by offering answers at a European level, so citizens feel that we can help them in a system in regaining control of our collective destiny, will we find solutions for global problems.

name: Donald Tusk
text: President of the European Council. – Mr President, thank you for what has been a good and lively debate. I have just a few comments. First, on CETA: many in this House have suggested that we should simply ignore the views of national parliaments on trade agreements and that the debate in Belgium and Wallonia’s resistance do not result from the belief that the competences of EU institutions regarding trade policy are too limited. Today people would prefer the state and national parliaments to have a bigger influence on the course of things – not smaller. Is it any easier to govern Europe thanks to this? No, of course it isn’t, but no one will change the fact that the EU is still the union of the states and not the institutions. When it comes to Russia, I have just one remark. The fears and concerns, for example on private arbitration, must be addressed, and they are being addressed and explained only now. I trust that after today’s talks in Belgium, the climate around CETA and maybe also around the next free trade agreements will change for the better. When it comes to Russia, I would like to say two things. First, we must keep unity in our relations with Russia. The building of EU unity is a difficult, not to say unaesthetic, process, but there is no alternative. If we want to be effective vis—à-vis Russia, we must stay united as the EU. (Applause) Second, at the European Council I backed those who were pushing for a stronger position on Russia’s role in Syria. The letter written by Verhofstadt, Harms and Weber was a real support for me. Thank you for your initiative. I want to say to those in this room who were the harshest critics of the European Council for not taking a sufficiently univocal position that they can help by doing the work both in their political families and in Member States. When it comes to migration, I have just one remark. I am absolutely aware that the situation in Greece remains critical. It is clear that it is too early to talk about success, but please just imagine what the situation on the Greek islands would look like if not for the decrease in the number of irregular migrants by 98% – not 9%, not 8%, but 98% – which we managed to achieve. This is the beginning of the process but this is the only way, also for the central Mediterranean route. This is why I am also starting to discuss the positive aspects of our activity. (Applause)

name: Martin SCHULZ
text: The debate is closed.

name: Mike HOOKEM
text: – Mr President, earlier today Mr Weber made a defamatory statement against me which you supported. Can I ask that both you gentlemen leave this building, where you do not have parliamentary immunity, and repeat those statements, so I can take legal action against you.

name: Martin SCHULZ
text: Honorable Hookem!I forwarded the dossier concerning you to the Strasbourg Public Prosecutor.All further investigations against you are in the hands of the public prosecutor.I can’t say more about that, and I’ve given the House no more than that.If you want to take civil action against me, I strongly encourage you to do so.You can do that here in Strasbourg, you can do that in the Federal Republic of Germany too.I look forward to a legal dispute with you.

name: Nigel FARAGE
text: – Mr President, I said in this Chamber that I felt the French Commissioner Jacques Barrot was unsuitable to be a European Commissioner because he had received a conviction for embezzlement and been suspended from public office. Despite the fact that what I said was true, it caused a huge outcry. I was told that because he had been amnestied by President Chirac under French law, it was an offence ever in public, in France, to refer to the incident. So there was a lot of speculation over whether the French police were going to come into this building and arrest me. But the President of Parliament at the time said: no, that is not the case because the European Parliament, rather like the United Nations in New York, is an organisation whose buildings are extraterritorial. So that ruling was perfectly clear.  How can it be, with that precedent having been set, that you can refer an alleged incident between two MEPs that took place in an official committee room, in this Parliament, to the French police? Can you please tell us: are these buildings extraterritorial or are we actually here, now, in France, under French law? (Applause)

name: Martin SCHULZ
text: Mr. Farage! First of all, matters involving Members of this House are governed by the House's Rules of Procedure. The rules of procedure of this House provide that Members of Parliament must adhere to minimum standards. According to our rules of procedure, one of the minimum standards is mutual respect. (Applause) The following incident has now occurred in the last plenary session here in this House: After leaving the Chamber, MEP Woolfe collapsed on one of the bridges in front of the Chamber and needed immediate medical assistance, including from Colleagues from this Chamber, who are doctors, was guaranteed; they helped him. Mr Woolfe was then hospitalized here in Strasbourg. The medical examination there revealed that the collapse was the result of an assault on his head. In plain language: the man was hit on the head. We then asked Mr Woolfe. Mr Woolfe described the matter to us from his point of view. I then passed the matter on to our so-called Advisory Committee on the Members' Code of Conduct. After hearing those involved, the Advisory Committee recommended that I refer the matter to the French Public Prosecutor's Office. I did this. Why? This is extra-territorial, but this extra-territorial area does not protect people from criminal prosecution when they commit crimes. That would be even better, and that also shows a strange understanding that you have. (Loud applause) Anyone who commits crimes in this House is also subject to prosecution, locally, and that is French territory. Now testimony stands against testimony. Mr. Woolfe made a statement and you, Mr. Hookem, made a statement. I have an obligation to inform the House of what I am President do.In such a case, if a testimony means that I was assaulted and suffered serious physical damage as a result, and another - the accused - says that I did not do that, then I am not the judge, but I am in chargethat - because it is an allegation of bodily harm - to the responsible public prosecutor.What I regret is that, as President of this House, I have to find out whether a Member has beaten another Member.This is the real scandal that we have to deal with!(Loud applause)

name: Philippe LAMBERTS
text: - Mr President, yesterday we voted for the report by our colleague Sophia in 't Veld on the creation of a mechanism for the rule of law in Europe.You know that two weeks ago, the main opposition daily was closed in Hungary.We learned yesterday, just after the debate on the in 't Veld report, that this daily has been bought by the oligarch who is probably closest to Viktor Orbán, Prime Minister of Hungary.I think this Parliament would do well, if it does not want to make a fool of itself, to show its opposition to this kind of procedure.Freedom of the press, in other words having a free press, including an opposition press, is an essential element of European values.(Applause from his group)

name: Martin SCHULZ
text: Mr Batten, then please explain the point of order on which you wish to speak.

name: Gerard BATTEN
text: – Mr President, on a point of clarification, you said, regarding the incident in the Parliament (if I heard you correctly) that you had referred this, or the Parliament had referred it, to the French authorities. I am not an expert on French law, but I have been informed that the only person that can make a complaint about a crime is the victim of the crime. Can you clarify: has the Parliament has referred this to the authorities or has Mr Woolfe referred it to the French police?

name: Eleonora FORENZA
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, two questions, the first: I would like this House to be informed that the two co-mayors of Diyarbakir were arrested by the Turkish authorities tonight.Turkey, we know to be a partner of the European Union, I believe that we cannot remain silent in the face of what the Erdogan government continues to do against the Kurdish people.Second question: I wanted to ask you, on the basis of what mandate, you have lobbied the authorities of Wallonia regarding their opposition to the signing of the CETA.

name: Richard HOWITT
text: –  Mr President, Martin, thank you. Thank you, on my last day in the European Parliament, to all of you in all of the Groups, Members and staff, for your friendship and for your cooperation. Thank you to the British Labour Party and to the Socialist and Democrat Group to whom I will remain for ever loyal, to my own family, sitting in the public gallery, to whom I will be always loyal too. I am proud to have represented my constituency, the East of England; it really is ‘bootiful’. I am proud, as a working-class boy who could never have expected to do so, to have represented my country and our continent. It has been a privilege and an honour to serve. I will always remember being here on the days of EU enlargement and of conflict resolution, of championing business responsibility on behalf of this Parliament, and my new career will be true to those values and principles.  I, my party, and many in my country, argued for Europe, and we will continue to do so. We must take our responsibility for the referendum defeat, and I am sorry, when I leave this building, I do not expect to return as an MEP. But if my country makes the historic mistake of leaving the European Union, I look forward to the day when it will return.   (Loud, sustained applause and standing ovation)

name: Clara AGUILERA
text: written. - In the latest conclusions of the European Council last week, the terms 'controls' and 'returns' appear up to fourteen times. Instead, "prevent" appears only twice. It is true that the arrival of immigrants must be ordered, but it is their departure that must be prevented. To this end, the Union must be able to exercise greater control in the areas of origin and represent the true global actor that it is through investments abroad, a global strategy and an effective capacity in terms of security and defense. Initial steps have been taken, reflected in some agreements with African countries. Yes, that's the way. But you have to go faster and more intensely. The Union must play a more important role in the territories where real atrocities are taking place; as for example, in Aleppo. As a last note, I would like to refer to the scourge of youth unemployment. We cannot forget it. We can not wait any longer.

name: Lorenzo CESA
text: in writing.- At the last European Council there was still talk of immigration.The heads of state and government addressed the discussion to define the European global approach to immigration.I stress the actions of the Council and the Commission which have seen the establishment of the European Border and Coast Guard as absolutely positive.Parliament and the Member States have done their part for the entry into force of the founding regulation.We now await the full capacity for action of this service and the tangible results by the end of the year.Among the results of the Council, the mandate given to the High Representative to present at the next meeting in December the progress achieved with the five major countries selected and the first results achieved in terms of arrivals and repatriations is certainly appreciable.These are two good decisions to finally give substance to our European action.

name: Nicola DANTI
text: in writing. - The Heads of State and Government who met on 20 and 21 October have faced a particularly complex agenda which, as is too often the case, does not receive concrete decisions. I refer in particular to the migration chapter, where the failure to apply the principle of solidarity and responsibility between states means that the burden of the emergency is still left on the shoulders of a few. The issues on the agenda also included that of trade policy and, in particular, the conclusion of the EU-Canada agreement. Regarding the latter, the veto of the Walloon region must lead to a deeper reflection. We are in fact in a historical context in which the failures resulting from the lack of regulation of globalization have created profound aversion and fear towards free trade agreements. If on the one hand, then, we must monitor the negotiations with ever greater attention and transparency, so that the necessary safeguards for citizens, workers and consumers are ensured; on the other hand, we cannot allow one of the few policies that have become a Community competence to be in fact guided by intergovernmental logic. National selfishness today risks leading to the slow failure of the European project, but we have the duty to find the tools to relaunch it.

name: João FERREIRA
text: in writing. - We value the position of the regional government and parliament of Wallonia, rejecting the CETA (Global Economic and Trade Agreement), even in the context of intolerable pressure from the EU, a position that prevents its signature by the Belgian federal government, thus blocking the process which aims to sign this free trade and services agreement between the EU and Canada. This position is an important contribution to fighting and defeating CETA, an agreement that the EU was preparing to sign and bring into force following opaque negotiations and through a process that constitutes disrespect for democracy and the sovereignty of States. If approved, this Agreement would represent an instrument to lower social, labor, environmental and public health rights, to place the interests of multinationals above the interests of peoples and the constitutions and sovereignty of States, and another step in the escalation of liberalization world trade - with serious consequences for countries like Portugal. This position demonstrates the importance and validity of the peoples' struggle to defend their interests and rights, providing an example and stimulus for the continuation and intensification of the fight against CETA and other free trade agreements, such as TTIP or TISA.

name: Lidia Joanna GERINGER DE OEDENBERG
text: in writing. - During its meeting on 20 and 21 October 2016, the European Council summarized the issues related to the comprehensive migration policy. An important step on the way to strengthening the Union's external borders was the entry into force of the Regulation on the European Border Guard. The newly appointed patrol will take care of, among others verifying the capacity of Member States to control borders and organizing joint operations against cross-border crime. Nevertheless, greater efforts are needed to contain irregular migrants, especially from Africa. In line with the position of the Council, a permanent stabilization of the situation on the Eastern Mediterranean route will require the full implementation of the EU-Turkey agreement and continued support for the countries along the Western Balkans route. It is also necessary to complete and implement the various single market strategies by 2018, including the digital single market, the capital markets union, the energy union and the single market agenda. In this context, work urgently needs to be undertaken on recent European Commission projects, including a proposal to reform the EU telecommunications and copyright law, as well as on completing the Capital Markets Union, in particular by swiftly reaching an agreement with the European Parliament on the prospectus rules to improve access companies to finance.

name: Maria GRAPINI
text: signed up. - Mr President, I will only talk about trade and agreements. Mr. Juncker informed us that the United States has a better trade defense policy than Europe. That is a reality. But who is to blame? Who stopped the Commission and the Council from proposing trade defense mechanisms? Why has Europe been deindustrialized? I am amazed at the attitude of the Council, which is blocking Parliament's initiatives and proposals. After CETA, TTIP, China and the United Kingdom, other agreements follow. We need trade agreements, but not in any form. Negotiations are not transparent. Citizens ask us and we do not know what to answer. We need unity, but it depends on us how we work. Why does the Commission not come up with concrete proposals for trade defense so that we no longer destroy jobs by entering counterfeit and subsidized products on the internal market? Why is the Council postponing important things and holding sterile debates without concrete decisions? You must respond to these things by deeds. I noticed that in the draft budget, the Council's position was to reduce the amount allocated to strengthening the financing capacity of SMEs and I do not understand why. Europe needs the development of SMEs and jobs.

name: Sergio GUTIÉRREZ PRIETO
text: written. - In the latest conclusions of the European Council last week, the terms 'controls' and 'returns' appear up to fourteen times. Instead, "prevent" appears only twice. It is true that the arrival of immigrants must be ordered, but it is their departure that must be prevented. To that end, the Union must be able to exercise greater control in the areas of origin and represent the true global actor that it is through investments abroad, a global strategy and an effective capacity in terms of security and defense. Initial steps have been taken, reflected in some agreements with African countries. Yes, that's the way. But you have to go faster and more intensely. The Union must play a more important role in the territories where real atrocities are taking place; as for example, in Aleppo. As a last note, I would like to refer to the scourge of youth unemployment. We cannot forget it. We can not wait any longer.

name: Agnieszka KOZŁOWSKA
text: in writing. - In today's debate on the conclusions of the European Council, both the right and left wing of the EP criticized the Council for its ineffectiveness on the CETA agreement blocked by one of the Belgian parliaments. There were also many voices to ignore the opinion of the Walloon parliament and to sign the agreement despite its opposition, as the remaining 27 countries consider it to be in favor. I disagree with either this criticism or the proposed solution. MEPs who demand a Europe of nations, "less Europe", need to understand that the consequence is perturbations in decision making, such as those under CETA. The direction of "Europe of nations" means the policy of the "lowest common denominator" criticized today and the need to equip the Council with instruments to facilitate negotiations. Secondly, I believe that the Council's decision to take into account the Walloon veto is right: this is the simple consequence of an earlier mixed-agreement decision. If other states or MPs consider the Walloons' decision harmful, they should persuade them to change their minds rather than pressure the President of the Council to ignore the rules of the game. The Council took the right decisions on the migration crisis, including on the conclusion of an agreement with Turkey and on increasing the protection of the EU's external borders. The implementation of these provisions reduced the influx of illegal immigrants by 98%. This is a great progress in an issue that has shaken the EU and continues to be one of its most difficult challenges.

name: Javi LÓPEZ
text: written. - In the latest conclusions of the European Council last week, the terms 'controls' and 'returns' appear up to fourteen times. Instead, "prevent" appears only twice. It is true that the arrival of immigrants must be ordered, but it is their departure that must be prevented. To this end, the Union must be able to exercise greater control in the areas of origin and represent the true global actor that it is through investments abroad, a global strategy and effective capacity in matters of security and defense. Initial steps have been taken, reflected in some agreements with African countries. Yes, that's the way. But you have to go faster and more intensely. The Union must play a more important role in the territories where real atrocities are taking place; as for example, in Aleppo. As a last note, I would like to refer to the scourge of youth unemployment. We cannot forget it. We can not wait any longer.

name: József NAGY
