text: in writing.- I believe that the lengthy negotiations on a trade agreement between the European Union and Canada have yielded results from which Europe will only benefit.Of course, only if everyone decides to accept it.I trust that our partners will still see us as a united and reliable negotiator.It is unfortunate that, after 7 years of negotiations, we are getting weaker because of a regional parliament.The most important thing now is to regain our credibility for our foreign policy as soon as possible, because a bad reputation can even deter future partners.I would like to emphasize once again that I am satisfied with the duration of the agreement and I was very pleased to hear today that Belgium has also succeeded in creating unity between its parliaments.

name: Urmas PAET
text: in writing.- The conclusion of a free trade agreement with Canada will benefit both the EU and Canada by opening up new opportunities and markets for businesses, eliminating most tax rates and giving EU businesses access to Canadian government procurement.The agreement simplifies and makes more transparent customs procedures, which is extremely beneficial, especially for small businesses.The agreement also provides guarantees for the protection of consumers, workers' rights, the environment and health, as well as cooperation to promote them in third countries.

name: Marijana PETIR
text: written. - This year, the European Union is facing great challenges that will directly affect the future of all of us. The United Kingdom's exit from the Union, European trade and defense instruments, migration challenges, EU-Russia relations, the EU-Canada economic and trade agreement are just some of the topics we were informed about at the last session of the European Parliament in Strasbourg. European Council President Donald Tusk and Commission President Jean-Claude Juncker. I agree with the position of European leaders that relations with the UK must remain extremely close, but also that the rights granted to Britain must be in line with the commitments it will make. The support given to the end of the conflict in Syria at the last summit is encouraging. I believe that stronger EU foreign policy action is needed, especially to protect Christians who are particularly vulnerable to persecution and killings. Of course, I am also pleased with the progress made on the issue of migration and the announcement of the strengthening of the agreement with Turkey, which should lead to a further decline in the number of migrants passing through the so-called "Balkan route". The debate that took place on Wednesday between Parliament and the Presidents of the Council and the Commission shows the strong desire of the main EU institutions to find quick and quality solutions, and I support the position on the importance of stopping unnecessary quarrels over Parliament's good proposals.

name: Maria Lidia SENRA RODRÍGUEZ
text: in writing.- Mr Tusk and Mr Juncker, what is happening with CETA shows that European citizenship is assuming the responsibilities that would correspond to you, that is, defending democracy and the sovereignty of peoples in the face of the interests and power of multinationals.And, although today they are able to unlock the signing of the agreement, as you just said, they should take into account that citizenship does not want this new generation agreement that converts the governments and parliaments that we choose into puppets of the multinationals.We do not want an agreement that mortgagees our future, that eliminates the precautionary principle, that converts rights inscribed in the Universal Declaration of Human Rights, such as health and education, into merchandise accessible only to those who can afford it.Do not prolong this unnecessarily.Listen to the population, stop pressuring governments, like the Walloon, who respond to the interests of the population.End the CETA negotiations.

name: Bogdan Andrzej ZDROJEWSKI
text: in writing. - The entry into force of the Regulation on the European Border and Coast Guard, cooperation with African countries, support for Lebanon and Jordan, as well as the implementation of the agreement with Turkey are further steps towards taking control of illegal immigration and the influx of refugees into the EU. According to the International Organization for Migration, 340,000 migrants arrived at the EU's borders in 2016. This is relatively much less than in previous years, but still, objectively, a lot! Therefore, one should be aware that there is still a long way to go for the systems agreed upon today to enter into force and fulfill their role. However, we are on the right track. I was concerned about the delay in adopting a trade agreement with Canada (CETA). The European Union is proof of the positive effect of a balanced, but above all, open trade policy. Consumers benefit from it. Therefore, we should not be overly simplified and half-truths uttered by opponents of this agreement. Its adoption is in our common interest. That is why I hope that the impasse on agreeing to the CETA will be overcome as soon as possible.

name: David Maria SASSOLI
text: The next item is voting time.(For the results of the votes and other details concerning them: see Minutes)

name: Jens GEIER
text: Rapporteur. - Mr President, ladies and gentlemen! I have to wait another two minutes before we get to the votes because, as rapporteur for the 2017 Commission budget, I would like to read out a brief statement for this House and I have to draw your attention to three technical changes. The Commission adopted a letter of amendment on October 17th this year. In addition to the traditional update of the budgeted needs for agricultural spending and fisheries, this letter of amendment includes essential elements of the mid-term revision of the multiannual financial framework 2014-2020. This letter of amendment testifies to the fundamental networking between the 2017 budget and the revision of the multiannual financial framework. The European Parliament expects the Council to be able to speak on this letter of amendment at the latest by the beginning of the council. The European Parliament is determined to adopt the procedure for the 2017 budget and the revision of the multiannual financial framework by the end of the year. This requires a uniform negotiation. The European Parliament expects the Council to be accommodating in this regard. Then I would like to draw your attention to three short technical changes which, due to the complexity of the process, are shown somewhat incorrectly in the reconciliation package. Line 15 04 77 12 "Preparatory Action - Europe for Festivals, Festivals for Europe (EFFE)" (AM 529): We need to adjust the payments to EUR 175,000. Line 09 05 77 10 "Pilot project - Framework for best practice in the fight sexual abuse of children on the Internet ”(AM 1573): The budget line must be corrected to 09 04 77 10. Line 33 02 77 19“ Pilot project - supervision and care for young people at risk of radicalization in the context of sports projects ”(AM 1611): The budget line must be corrected to 15 02 77 19.

name: Indrek TARAND
text: rapporteur. – Mr President, I know fist fights are more emotional than the dull numbers of a budget, but indeed we need more of the latter than the former. And I know I’m at terrible risk of sounding like Sir Humphrey Appleby from the ‘Yes, Minister’ series, but I have to make a technical amendment.  The text originally read ‘including one permanent AD 12 post’. Now we want to have ‘including one temporary AD 12 post’, for the Director of the Authority for European Political Parties and European Political Foundations. The Estonian wisdom goes that nothing can be more permanent than a temporary position.  I would also like to reach a compromise regarding changes to Parliament’s establishment plan to enable Members of this Chamber to vote really separately on the proposed increases in posts for political groups. I therefore propose to vote on Amendment 1556 in two parts, the first part to be the text as a whole without ‘plus 76 posts’ for political groups and the second part only the words ‘plus 76 posts’. I think if we can do that, Mr. President, we will send a good message to European citizens. (Laughter)

name: Janusz KORWIN-MIKKE
text: – Mr President, in the papers, the correction, the budget line is 15 02 77 19 but I have in the Polish translation 77 20 not 19. What is the correct number?

name: Jens GEIER
text: Rapporteur.-  Mister President!Of course, I would like nothing more than to help Mr Korwin-Mikke with his voting list.So of course I like to read it out again: Budget line 09 05 77 10 “Pilot project - framework for best practices in combating sexual abuse of children on the Internet” (AM 1573): The budget line must be corrected to 09 04 77 10. Budget line 3302 77 19 “Pilot project - supervision and support for young people at risk of radicalization in the context of sports projects” (AM 1611): The budget line must be corrected to 15 02 77 19. These are the documents I received from the secretariat.Unfortunately, I can no longer contribute anything else to the success of the vote.

name: David Maria SASSOLI
text: We have three technical changes proposed by Mr Geier, a technical proposal from Mr Tarand, who also proposed a split vote;but you, Mr Tarand, you are an expert, you know very well that this type of procedure has time for presentation, in this case you had to submit this request by 12.00 on Monday.And therefore of course this proposal cannot be accepted.However, I am putting to the vote the technical changes that were presented to the Chamber by our rapporteurs.(Parliament approved the proposed changes) - Before the vote on amendment 341:

name: Marc TARABELLA
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, we know that you are very polite, but we can, because the vote is very long today, say not by a show of hands, because we know and I promise you in exchange that we will raise our hands anyway.

name: Ivan Lesay
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Mr President, honourable Members of the European Parliament, the European Parliament has just adopted amendments to the Council’s position on the draft budget for the financial year 2017. I take note of the differences in the positions of our two institutions concerning the draft budget for 2017 presented by the Commission. Consequently, in my capacity of President of the Council, I agree that the President of the European Parliament convenes the Conciliation Committee as required in Article 314(4)(c) of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union.

name: David Maria SASSOLI
text: Of course we take note of his statements.

name: David Maria SASSOLI
text: This concludes the voting round.

name: Tim AKER
text: in writing. – This vote was a series of budgetary amendments to set the spending limits for the EU budget for 2017. The Commission had proposed an original budget of EUR 157 billion, the Council amended that to EUR 156 billion, and the Parliament was proposing to not only reverse the Council cuts, but to increase the budget significantly. UKIP and the EFDD Group submitted 33 cost-saving amendments to the EU budget, as well as voting in favour of cost-saving measures proposed by others. Our amendments, which would have saved in total over EUR 3 billion of taxpayers’ money, related to the cutting of bureaucracy. These proposals were for ‘victimless cuts’ which impact only upon the inner workings of the European Union and luxuries for officials. UKIP voted against any measures which would increase the EU budget, because it would be contrary to the decision of the British people on Brexit. In some cases the additions would have duplicated funding streams already in place in the UK. Exceptionally, we abstained rather than vote against where a new budget line was proposed to help Member States leave the euro. There was no actual funding proposed for this, and we support the principle of Member States leaving the euro.

name: Marina ALBIOL GUZMÁN
text: written.- The budget vote allows the plenary to express itself on only a few lines, leaving the definition and execution of most of the funds in the hands of the Commission and the Member States.With my vote, I have sought to ensure adequate income for European peasants, improve efficiency in the use of funds made by Parliament, reinforce the items for social and regional cohesion and environmental efficiency, oppose the planned cuts to financethe speculative programs of the Juncker Plan and blocking some aspects of the Union's aggressive foreign policy, especially towards Russia.

name: Eric ANDRIEU
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of this 2017 draft budget which already confirms the budget increases provided for in the revision, in particular on the program for youth employment, research or the dairy crisis.However, we will not vote on the budget without revising the multiannual financial framework (CPF).We ask that the negotiations also cover the next financial perspective in order to put an end to the structural shortage caused by the growing imbalance between the weakness of own resources and national contributions.Parliament is ready for negotiations with the Council, and determined to avoid the budgetary crisis which threatens the Union.We are waiting for the Council to quickly adopt a proposal on the revision of the MFF to start the discussion.The ball is with the Member States!

name: Marie-Christine ARNAUTU
text: in writing. - The main budgetary problems raised in the amendments to this project are multiple. However, they are mainly linked to the unprecedented migration crisis affecting the EU. If the payments crisis (linked to unpaid invoices and the remainder to be settled) which appeared at the start of the execution of the 2014-2020 multiannual financial framework seems to have subsided since the execution of the 2016 budget, the budget is now stretched by drawing on the new flexibility instruments to finance the influx of migrants, by exceeding the ceiling of heading 3 (security and citizenship) of the MFF, or as a last resort, the margin for unforeseen events (1.2 billion euros ) to redistribute the credits between the headings. This is in addition to the 200 million euros mobilized through the emergency aid fund voted this year. In total, the planned contribution from France should amount to 18.5 billion euros for 2017. Finally, note that the revision of the multiannual financial framework at mid-term will be an opportunity for Europeanists to push for a European tax . I therefore voted against most of the amendments put forward for a vote by Members.

name: Jonathan ARNOTT
text: in writing. ‒ We voted against the final resolution because we cannot support an increase in the budget of the European Union, especially considering that the British people have already voted to Leave and expect to stop paying money to the EU altogether. Our Group submitted 33 cost-saving amendments to the EU budget, and we voted in favour of these as well as in favour of cost-saving measures proposed by others. Most of our amendments, which would have saved in total over EUR 3 billion of taxpayers’ money, related to cutting of bureaucracy. These proposals were for ‘victimless cuts’ which impact only upon the inner workings of the European Union and luxuries for officials. We voted against any measures which would add to the European Union budget, because it would be completely contrary to the decision of the British people on Brexit. In some cases the additions would duplicate funding streams which already exist directly from the UK government to the British people. Exceptionally, we abstained rather than vote against where a new budget line was proposed to help Member States leave the euro. There was no actual funding proposed for this, and we support the principle of Member States leaving the euro.

name: Jean ARTHUIS
text: in writing.- The 2017 budget is the first tranche of a revised framework.In fact, the draft budget articulated by the Commission is unlikely to hold up unless the revision of the multiannual financial framework is completed.We must now turn to the Council which, unfortunately, is struggling to provide a comprehensive response to budgetary issues.In these times of crisis, it is therefore necessary to coordinate positions between the European Parliament and the Council.It is in this sense that I voted in favor of this text.

name: Zigmantas BALČYTIS
text: in writing.- 2017the budget needs to strike a balance between long-term priorities and new challenges.Therefore, I agree that in 2017.the budget must be in line with the objectives of the Europe 2020 strategy, which is its main focus and top priority, and, of course, provide additional funding for Youth Employment Guarantees.

name: Gerard BATTEN
text: in writing. ‒ This vote was a series of budgetary amendments to set the spending limits for the EU budget for 2017. The Commission had proposed an original budget of EUR 157 billion, the Council amended that to EUR 156 billion, and the Parliament was proposing to not only reverse the Council cuts, but to increase the budget significantly. UKIP and the EFDD Group submitted 33 cost-saving amendments to the EU budget, as well as voting in favour of cost-saving measures proposed by others. Our amendments, which would have saved in total over EUR 3 billion of taxpayers’ money, related to the cutting of bureaucracy. These proposals were for ‘victimless cuts’ which impact only upon the inner workings of the European Union and luxuries for officials. UKIP voted against any measures which would increase the EU budget, because it would be contrary to the decision of the British people on Brexit. In some cases the additions would have duplicated funding streams already in place in the UK. Exceptionally, we abstained rather than vote against where a new budget line was proposed to help Member States leave the euro. There was no actual funding proposed for this, and we support the principle of Member States leaving the euro.

name: Xabier BENITO ZILUAGA
text: written.- Parliament proposes its budget proposal for 2017 to negotiate in the trilogue process.His proposal, even cutting less than the Council or the Commission, still entails a reduction in the overall budget, around 5% compared to the previous year.The first voting list of figures and remarks includes numerous amendments without a final vote.

name: Izaskun BILBAO BARANDICA
text: written.- I voted in favor of the Union budget at this first reading by Parliament, which will serve as the basis for negotiation with the Council.I voted against the creation of 76 new posts in the political groups, as well as in favor of reducing the parliamentary allowance for travel of Members and reducing the allowance for assistants and the remuneration of Members.

name: Dominique BILDE
text: in writing. - I voted against most of the amendments tabled by parliamentarians on the draft general budget of the European Union for 2017, although I welcome some amendments tabled such as the reinstatement of the amounts of the European Agricultural Guarantee Fund, which will be beneficial in this period of endemic crisis for our agricultural sector. I would like to take this opportunity to express my opposition to the Council's plan which focuses all its increases (+ 7% for payment appropriations) on the management of the migration crisis, a humanitarian, social and economic disaster that the EU has largely contributed to worsen . It is scandalous that this project thus reduces the margin available under the ceiling of heading 2 (which concerns in particular the CAP) in order to finance expenditure in favor of migrants. In this regard, moreover, after two consecutive increases in 2015 and 2016, 5.2 billion euros will be allocated to the management of this "crisis" in 2017. Finally, how to support the increase in the budget for heading 3 " citizenship and security ”, even though the EU has for years pressured Member States to disintegrate their own defense budgets? An unacceptable federalist maneuver.

name: Mara BIZZOTTO
text: in writing.- Considering that little has been done to reduce the costs of the European institutions;whereas the EU is demanding more and more sacrifices from states, despite the severe economic crisis underway;that our local administrators struggle to guarantee citizens good services given the very limited resources available to them;I do not agree with the content of the draft general budget for 2017.

name: Malin BJÖRK
text: written. - I have voted against the budget. The budget is too large and extensive. Extensive cuts should be made. Agricultural policy is just one example. It results in overproduction and negative effects on the environment, climate and animal husbandry. Another example is the unmanageable regional and structural funds, which are the subject of extensive fraud, as the Commission itself has confirmed. I oppose the investments in the continued construction of Fortress Europe, which forces people fleeing war and oppression, to risk their lives to get to a sanctuary. This and the initiatives to increase the militarization of the EU are a completely wrong path for a Union that claims to defend human rights and is a peace project. In principle, as an anti-federalist, I also believe that the Member States that pay the EU budget should have full decision-making power over Union spending. It is the taxpayers in the member states who pay and therefore it is their direct elected representatives in each country who should have the power. These are some of the reasons why I choose to vote against the budget.

name: José BLANCO LÓPEZ
text: written. - We Spanish socialists have voted in favor of the proposal for the 2017 budget to be able to tackle unemployment and poverty. With this we reject all the cuts proposed by the 28 Member States and we demand more funds in the fight against youth unemployment and incentives for economic growth. Among other measures, we are proposing an additional € 1.5 billion for the Youth Employment Initiative, in order to help unemployed young people, and we are committed to increasing investment in infrastructure and research by € 1.24 billion. With our proposals, this budget reinforces solidarity within the Union (Youth Employment Initiative, child guarantee, support for farmers and ranchers) but also outside our borders. In this sense, we Socialists have obtained the support of the European Parliament for the increase of aid programs for refugees, humanitarian aid, development cooperation and support for neighboring countries.

name: Biljana BORZAN
text: written.- I support this Report on the Draft General Budget of the European Union for 2017.

name: Steeve BRIOIS
text: in writing. - This is to decide on the adoption of several amendments to the 2017 draft budget, submitted by the Council but rejected by the Budget Committee. The Council's proposals mainly aimed to increase commitment appropriations by 0.9% and payment appropriations by 7% compared to 2016. These additional funds are intended in particular to finance the reception of illegal migrants in the Member States of the 'Union. At a time when the peoples of Europe are suffering from mass unemployment and precariousness, it is astounding to see the European Union giving priority to the comfort of illegal migrants. This proposal reveals how much the Brussels technocrats are disconnected from the daily life of our fellow citizens. Regarding the aspect of economic growth, this project gives satisfaction to the Juncker investment plan, the ineffectiveness of which is however no longer to be demonstrated in view of the small amount of private capital that it has managed to attract. There was no final vote.

name: Matt CARTHY
text: in writing. ‒ This vote was regarding the mandate for the EP to negotiate with the Council. While I agreed with a number of aspects of the report, I disagreed with a number of the priorities outlined, which is why I abstained in the final vote. I supported the inclusion of certain elements into the mandate, especially Sinn Fein’s amendment, which was adopted into Paragraph 4, and which called for ensuring support for the North in the wake of Brexit. This encompasses retaining programs such as PEACE. While the EP position restores all the cuts made by the Council, it falls short on the cuts which had already been introduced by the Commission. The best reflection of this is reducing cohesion funding in favour of a militarised ‘fortress Europe’. The larger and wealthier Member States, who have been cheerleaders of neoliberal policies and champions of austerity, have played a significant role in the negative implications for social and regional programmes. This entails Member States, local authorities, institutions and civil society stakeholders being held hostage by ‘market logic’ and the systematic transfer of funds from existing EU programs and the erosion of public investment. I could not fully oppose the report as voting against consequently meant supporting the Council’s position, which is socially regressive, so I abstained.

name: James CARVER
text: in writing. ‒ This vote was a series of budgetary amendments to set the spending limits for the EU budget for 2017. The Commission had proposed an original budget of EUR 157 billion, the Council amended that to EUR 156 billion, and the Parliament was proposing to not only reverse the Council cuts, but to increase the budget significantly. UKIP and the EFDD Group submitted 33 cost-saving amendments to the EU budget, as well as voting in favour of cost-saving measures proposed by others. Our amendments, which would have saved in total over EUR 3 billion of taxpayers’ money, related to the cutting of bureaucracy. These proposals were for ‘victimless cuts’ which impact only upon the inner workings of the European Union and luxuries for officials. UKIP voted against any measures which would increase the EU budget, because it would be contrary to the decision of the British people on Brexit. In some cases the additions would have duplicated funding streams already in place in the UK. Exceptionally, we abstained rather than vote against where a new budget line was proposed to help Member States leave the euro. There was no actual funding proposed for this, and we support the principle of Member States leaving the euro.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: in writing.- We voted today on the 2017 draft budget. On all the proposed amendments, I emphasize that we voted in favor of the abolition of expenditure concerning the communication on the euro, the increase of funds for the early detection of harmful organisms for plantsand their eradication, as well as support for victims of natural disasters in Italy.

name: Lefteris CHRISTOFOROU
text: in writing. - We support the report and emphasize that we want a budget that responds to new jobs, to young people, to those actions that have to do with research, with innovation, that really bring Europe forward. We want a budget that corresponds to a more social and humane Europe. We also want a real campaign and a strong effort to abolish bureaucracy. The bureaucracy is currently affecting the European Union budget, but it is particularly affecting citizens, small and medium-sized enterprises and the system itself. Many millions are lost on the altar of bureaucracy, as are the hopes and dreams of many people. I also support the budget report, because it meets the hopes and dreams, especially of young people, because there has been an increase in youth employment, in youth action, in Erasmus +, and in everything that really pushes a budget. growth and employment, in a budget for social and human Europe.

name: Alberto CIRIO
text: in writing.- The vote on the budget was long and complex.I voted in favor of the draft, but getting through all the amendments was not easy.Although there is no more political act than this, the document represents the triumph of technicalities and Eurocracy: contrary to the budgets of individual Member States or companies, we are witnessing an expenditure that cannot go into deficit and income that does not dependnecessarily from the policies implemented (given that the bulk derives from the contributions of the Member States).However, I remain proud to see that the EU redistributes 95% of what it receives to the states, and that in any case the national contribution is around 1% of GDP - where taxation is between 45 and 55%.My challenge always remains the same: to ensure that Italy learns to cut its slice of the cake and take it, so that this contribution does not always and only benefit others.

name: Carlos COELHO
text: in writing. - The 2017 Budget must respond to the needs linked to the challenges of migration and the slowdown in growth following the economic crisis. It is therefore necessary to increase funding for research and infrastructure projects, as well as to combat youth unemployment. I support increasing the allocation for the Youth Employment Initiative by EUR 1 500 million in commitment appropriations. I welcome the Commission's proposal for an additional EUR 1.8 billion to meet the challenge of migration in the Union. I agree with the need to increase appropriations for Europol, Eu-lisa and Enisa. I approve of Parliament's decision to increase appropriations for the dairy sector by EUR 600 million in order to counter the effects of the crisis in the dairy sector and the Russian embargo on the milk sector. I subscribe to the replacement of all amounts cut in the Connecting Europe Facility (investments to improve European transport, energy and digital technology networks) and Horizon 2020 (EU program for research and innovation), for a total of EUR 1,240 million in commitments.

name: Lara COMI
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of the draft general budget of the European Union for the financial year 2017 and I believe that it must be framed in a broader context, which ensures a correct balance between long-term priorities and new challenges.The budget for 2017 must meet the needs posed by the migration crises and there is a need to strengthen the financing of projects in the fields of research, infrastructure, security, as well as projects to combat youth unemployment.

name: Javier COUSO PERMUY
text: written.- The budget vote allows the plenary to express itself on only a few lines, leaving the definition and execution of most of the funds in the hands of the Commission and the Member States.With my vote, I have sought to ensure adequate income for European peasants, improve efficiency in the use of funds made by Parliament, reinforce the items for social and regional cohesion and environmental efficiency, oppose the planned cuts to financethe speculative programs of the Juncker Plan and blocking some aspects of the Union's aggressive foreign policy, especially towards Russia.

name: Andi CRISTEA
text: signed up.- The budget allocated to 2017 must be in line with the objectives set out in the Europe 2020 Strategy, but also balanced between long-term and new priorities along the way.The European Union is facing a number of major emergencies, but also new challenges.Sustainable development goals must not be affected.Only by creating new jobs and supporting the development of enterprises and entrepreneurship can we have smart, sustainable growth.I voted to supplement the funds for research and infrastructure projects, as well as those aimed at combating the youth unemployment rate.

name: Edward CZESAK
text: in writing.- On the draft general budget of the European Union for 2017, I made the decision to vote against many of the amendments with which I disagree.My group, the ECR, has consistently taken the position of limiting the EU budget, in which the same budgetary discipline applied to national spending applies to EU spending.All the more so as the EU faces a number of new challenges since spending limits were agreed in 2013.In the current situation, I believe that budget efficiency should be increased without the need for increased contributions from the Member States.

name: Miriam DALLI
text: in writing. ‒ This draft amending budget refers to new security needs identified by the EU institutions following the recent terror attacks. It proposes to reinforce the budget for security among other things in a number of institutions. As far as the European Parliament is concerned it aims to create 35 additional permanent posts for the recruitment of security agents. I voted in favour of this draft budget since it refers to an allocation that is required for the next financial year.

name: William (The Earl of) DARTMOUTH
text: in writing. ‒ This vote was a series of budgetary amendments to set the spending limits for the EU budget for 2017. The Commission had proposed an original budget of EUR 157 billion, the Council amended that to EUR 156 billion, and the Parliament was proposing to not only reverse the Council cuts, but to increase the budget significantly. UKIP and the EFDD Group submitted 33 cost-saving amendments to the EU budget, as well as voting in favour of cost-saving measures proposed by others. Our amendments, which would have saved in total over EUR 3 billion of taxpayers’ money, related to the cutting of bureaucracy. These proposals were for ‘victimless cuts’ which impact only upon the inner workings of the European Union and luxuries for officials. UKIP voted against any measures which would increase the EU budget, because it would be contrary to the decision of the British people on Brexit. In some cases the additions would have duplicated funding streams already in place in the UK. Exceptionally, we abstained rather than vote against where a new budget line was proposed to help Member States leave the euro. There was no actual funding proposed for this, and we support the principle of Member States leaving the euro.

name: José Manuel FERNANDES
text: in writing. - The EP proposes € 161.8 billion in commitments to promote growth, jobs and investments in research or infrastructure as tools to create more jobs in Europe. At the same time, this budget will address the current migration and security challenges facing the EU. Regardless of the new challenges we face today in Europe, this budget is betting on jobs and growth. The new challenges must be addressed with more means, not through cuts such as the one proposed by the EU Council in the amount of € 1.32 billion. This 2017 EU budget should contribute to catching up with the huge delay in the implementation of the current MFF funds and programs. In 2016 alone, € 7.3 billion has not been implemented and will be returned to the Member States. The EU needs economic growth and to strengthen its competitiveness. For 2017, we need more flexibility and less bureaucracy, in order to quickly implement the commitments made to citizens.

name: João FERREIRA
text: in writing. - Again, the EU budget does not respond to the deep and persistent problems that the EU and its Member States are facing. The PCP presented more than 100 proposals for changes to the document. The vast majority was rejected, also with the vote of Portuguese deputies from other parties. We highlight some of the areas covered by the proposals that we have presented: increase in the lines for “refunds for pork”; defense and conservation of areas considered as special areas of conservation, proposing the creation of a new budget line to support the management of areas integrated in the Natura 2000 Network; support for fisheries; increased funding for officials of the EP language services; creation of support programs for countries intervened by the troika and for countries that voluntarily wanted to leave the euro (the latter must provide the appropriate compensation for entry and stay in the single currency). The nine proposed amendments to the PCP, which were included in the final proposal submitted to the vote, reinforced the rubrics in support of social cohesion and productive activities. As a whole, proposals of great relevance to Portugal, we emphasize that PS, PSD and CDS voted against the overwhelming majority, a fact that we deplore.

name: Lampros FOUNTOULIS
text: in writing. - This budget plans the implementation of failed policies, such as the Juncker plan, the forced relocation and assimilation of refugees from EU countries, the submission to Turkey's blackmail and its funding to drown human souls in the Aegean by promoting jihadists in Europe territory, the recognition of the occupying forces of Cyprus as a Turkish Cypriot community and the recruitment of staff for the benefit of the political groups here in this Parliament, while at the same time imposing a horizontal reduction of 5% on the remaining staff. The Union's budget must take into account current challenges and threats and address them. At the same time, to promote policies that lead to decent work, sustainable development and to ensure a balance between the financially sound and the corresponding weak economies of the Member States. Its main concern must be the well-being of the citizens of all the Member States. For the above reasons, I am voting against all parts of the draft general budget of the European Union for 2017.

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: in writing. ‒ The Budgets Committee reversed all Council’s cuts in commitment appropriations by restoring the Commission’s Draft Budget (EC- DB) for 2017. Furthermore considerable increases over the Commission’s Draft Budget on specific topics of political interest have been voted, mostly to fully compensate the cuts from the agreement on the European Fund for Strategic Investments (EFSI), as well as to ensure additional resources needed for the internal and external dimension of the refugee crisis, and for financing the Youth Employment Initiative. We must ask for a further use of the existing flexibility instruments under the current MFF and making reference to the revision of the MFF, in order to make the EP’s priorities clear. I welcome the fact that, in order to keep the political lead on the fight against youth unemployment, the Youth Employment Initiative will be increased by EUR 1.5 billion. Also the Fund for European Aid to the Most Deprived (FEAD) has been increased by EUR 4 million.

name: Ildikó GÁLL-PELCZ
text: in writing. - It is unfortunate that the EP's report on the EU budget for 2017 refers to the parliamentary report adopted in the July plenary vote, which gave an opinion in advance on the revision of the 2014-2020 financial framework. In this, despite the united protests of the People's Party MPs, the MEPs of the Hungarian left-wing parties voted against the interests of the country, attacking all Hungarian citizens with their decision on forced resettlement. MEPs from left-wing parties in Hungary supported the forced resettlement and the harsh financial sanctions of countries that rejected it by a firm and proud vote in the European Parliament. At the same time, the vast majority of Hungarian voters have a clear position: they said no to forced resettlement. Therefore, Fidesz MEPs will only adopt a revision of the financial framework and an EU budget in which these penalties are not even at the level of ideas. As the text of the report on the Council's position on the draft general budget of the European Union for the financial year 2017 refers to the EP report calling for a fine against Member States that did not adopt mandatory quotas in July, I abstained in the final vote on the report.

name: Enrico GASBARRA
text: in writing.- I thank my colleagues in the budget committee for the valuable work of synthesizing the various priorities expressed by the parliamentary committees for the 2017 financial year. I would like to emphasize one political point in particular that I would like to highlight:coinciding with the reopening of the negotiations on the multiannual financial framework until 2020. The position voted by the budget committee inserts some points (for example a stronger use of financial flexibility instruments) that will be a priority for Parliament in the interinstitutional discussion in the coming months, I supporttherefore strongly the position expressed by the Chamber today.

name: Arne GERICKE
text: written.- Out of responsibility before the taxpayers, I voted against the general budget of the European Union for 2017.It is far from exhausting all of the savings potential or simply setting the wrong accents.Europe must also become even better and more responsible when it comes to budgetary issues so that I can share my conscience.

name: Jens GIESEKE
text: written.- I agree to the European Union budget for 2017 in all of its sections.

name: Tania GONZÁLEZ PEÑAS
text: written.- Parliament proposes its budget proposal for 2017 to negotiate in the trilogue process.His proposal, even cutting less than the Council or the Commission, still entails a reduction in the overall budget, around 5% compared to the previous year.The first voting list of figures and remarks includes numerous amendments without a final vote.

name: Theresa GRIFFIN
text: in writing. ‒ Labour MEPs voted today to oppose an increase in the EU budget for 2017 - we believe the first resort should be finding money for EU priorities within existing budget lines. We remain committed to the principle of prioritising the jobs and economic growth agenda whether inside or outside of the European Union and hope to continue close cooperation with our neighbours as a means of protecting the UK economy.

name: Jytte GUTELAND
text: written. - We Swedish Social Democrats chose to abstain in the vote on the package agreements for headings 1-5 (blocks 1-6), and in the vote on the two reports on the EU budget 2017 (part 1 & part 2). Several items in Parliament's budget have a high priority. Here are well-functioning businesses with clear European added value. The investments in research within Horizon 2020 and infrastructure within the Fund for an interconnected Europe are among the best made in EU cooperation. The general focus should be on these programs being affected as little as possible as a result of the establishment of the EFSI investment fund. We would like to see significant investments in a number of programs advocated by the Committee on Budgets - and now the whole of Parliament. As a general rule, however, we believe that the investments made should be offset by appropriate savings in low-priority parts of the EU budget. As individual appropriations in the budgetary process have generally not been tested against each other for the purpose of reallocating funds to priority areas, this contributes to Parliament being far above the MFF ceilings for the budget as a whole. Consequently, we cannot support Parliament's draft budget.

name: Takis HADJIGEORGIOU
text: in writing. - The rejection of the budget remains for us a political act against the philosophy of the budget and austerity. Despite its positive elements, the increases that are being made are again moving in the direction of stimulating competitiveness and deepening militarization. The argument that we should support the budget because that is how we support Parliament does not find us in agreement, since even this does not oppose austerity. The funds it raises do not change the philosophy philosophy of austerity and memoranda.

name: Marian HARKIN
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the general budget for the financial year 2017. The budget succeeded in securing necessary financing in priority areas. EUR 600 million more was allocated for agriculture and in compensation for the embargo on Russia, while EUR 400 million more was given for Horizon 2020 for scientists and innovators as well as EUR 200 million more was allocated for COSME (EU programme for the Competitiveness of Enterprises and Small and Medium-sized Enterprises) in support of small and medium-sized businesses. I was particularly pleased that EUR 1.5 billion more was set aside for dealing with youth unemployment.

name: Hans-Olaf HENKEL
text: written.- This proposal for the 2017 EU budget contains a number of points which are not acceptable.Regardless of the tight budgetary situation in a number of EU Member States, all the proposals for cuts made by the Council in relation to the Commission's draft are to be withdrawn.In addition, the appropriations for commitments are to be increased by more than 4 billion and for payment appropriations by almost 2 billion euros.The planned distribution takes place primarily according to the watering can principle, regardless of compliance with subsidiarity requirements and without comprehensive monitoring of the success of measures.It is true that there are also positive approaches such as the fund we are proposing to support victims of terrorism or the increase in funds for Europol to strengthen internal security in Europe.Nevertheless, the negative aspects predominate, which is why I am rejecting this budget proposal.

name: Cătălin Sorin IVAN
text: signed up.- I voted in favor of this report on balancing long-term priorities with future challenges and also achieving the goals set under the Europe 2020 Strategy.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: written.- I voted in favor of the Draft General Budget of the European Union for 2017 - all parts, because I believe that the budget must be flexible, in line with the challenges currently facing the EU, and that the guidelines of the main EU policies should be followed.The European Union needs stronger growth and more jobs, and in order to achieve that, it is necessary to provide the necessary financial and other resources.On the other hand, cohesion policy is the EU's main investment policy and must therefore not be called into question.Security and civic challenges are a key problem that the EU is currently facing, and I accordingly support the additional resources that are earmarked for this.The Union certainly needs to strengthen its external action in order to be able to deal with and represent the interests of its citizens on a global scale.I believe that the budget for 2017 contains realistic aspects of the needs that lie ahead, and I therefore support it.

name: Jean-François JALKH
text: in writing.- The 2016 budget of the European Union, although having made it possible to reduce the effects of the payments crisis, today suffers from too much pressure to finance the massive influx of migrants.This leads France to have to spend the too large sum of 18.5 billion euros for the year 2017, as a contribution.We can feel the threat of the creation of a European tax looming on the horizon, a wish of the Europeanists.So I voted against it.

name: Eva KAILI
text: in writing.- We welcome the ratification of the EU general budget. However, we can in no way consider that the Union's budget is sufficient to meet the great challenges we face.The Union's financial capacity goes through its budget and an Organization like the EU cannot function as a political dwarf because of its disproportionately small budget.

name: Barbara KAPPEL
text: written.- Although the resolution on the draft general budget of the European Union for the financial year 2017 states that, in view of scarce resources, greater attention should be paid to compliance with budgetary discipline and funds should be used efficiently and effectively, it is clearly against possible cuts.Overall, the European Parliament wants to achieve a further increase in the EU budget.This is to be rejected not only for reasons of principle, but also in view of ever tighter budget budgets and deficits in the Member States.For these reasons I would have voted against this report.

name: Afzal KHAN
text: in writing. ‒ Labour MEPs voted today to oppose an increase in the EU budget for 2017 - we believe the first resort should be finding money for EU priorities within existing budget lines. We remain committed to the principle of prioritising the jobs and economic growth agenda whether inside or outside of the European Union and hope to continue close cooperation with our neighbours as a means of protecting the UK economy.

name: Jeppe KOFOD
text: in writing. Of course, when saving continues in Europe, the EU should not be exempted from this. Therefore, as in previous years, employees and administrative costs continue to be cut across a broad spectrum. We support this approach and maintain that the EU budget should not increase, but that better priority should be given. Therefore, we cannot vote in favor of the draft budget, which entails a significant increase in the EU budgetary framework and includes a number of unfunded measures. Likewise, we do not believe that there is a need for further support for either the foundations, the parties or the groups in the European Parliament, but we do support the close monitoring and review of these funds. We maintain our demand for more transparent rules for auditing the funds made available to members, and emphasize that equal, clear and effective rules must apply. Finally, we emphasize that members and staff should always travel in the overall cheapest way possible. For MEPs, these are typically the cheapest flex tickets for the sake of changing meeting calendars. We support the internalisation of the driving scheme because it will ensure orderly working conditions for the drivers involved, but maintain that it must be cost-neutral overall.

name: Bernd KÖLMEL
text: written.- This proposal for the 2017 EU budget contains a number of points which are unacceptable.Regardless of the tight budget situation in a number of EU Member States, all of the cuts made by the Council in relation to the Commission's draft are to be withdrawn.In addition, the commitments are to be increased by more than EUR 4 billion and the payment appropriations by almost EUR 2 billion.The planned distribution takes place primarily according to the watering can principle, regardless of compliance with subsidiarity requirements and without a comprehensive monitoring of the success of measures.It is true that there are also positive approaches such as the fund we are proposing to support victims of terrorism or the increase in funds for Europol to strengthen internal security in Europe.Nevertheless, the negative aspects predominate, which is why I reject the proposal.

name: Andrey KOVATCHEV
text: In written form.- I support the European Parliament's position on the draft general budget of the European Union for the financial year 2017.I believe that migration, weak economic growth after the economic crisis and youth unemployment are important aspects that must be reflected in it.The budget must be in line with the EU's political priorities in order to be able to respond effectively to emergencies and new challenges.

name: Constance LE GRIP
text: in writing. - Like a large majority of my colleagues, I approved this draft budget for the European Union for 2017. Our assembly has adopted a more ambitious and more voluntary vision than that initially put forward by the European Commission by increasing the funds for it. employment, youth and also those intended to help third countries to cope with the migration crisis (development aid in particular). For example, an additional 15 million euros have been allocated to Erasmus +. However, I strongly opposed the decision to internalize the Parliament's chauffeur service, as it is, no more and no less, the ousting of the current staff, who are very competent and professional. Indeed, beyond the additional cost that this will generate (50% more), there is also the question of current drivers: those in Strasbourg, for example, often did so in addition to their retirement. In addition, 80% of former drivers will not be taken on because of a competition deemed too hard.

name: Marine LE PEN
text: in writing. - I voted against the draft general budget of the European Union for 2017, for the obvious reason that I do not support the policies implemented by the European Union. This budget is resolutely focused on the crisis linked to the influx of migrants and the resulting security aspect. It also emphasizes the goal of growth, a way of appropriating the right role (in financing investments) while ordering states to tighten their belts. Regarding migrants, it follows the 2015 and 2016 amending budgets adopted: after 10.5 billion euros in 2015 and 2016, 5.2 billion for 2017 are allocated to the migrant crisis. Regarding the growth component, this project gives satisfaction to the implementation of the Juncker plan, which has brought nothing that will lead to the mobilization of the funds necessary in 2017 to achieve the objective set of 240 billion in private investments for the end of the year.

name: Philippe LOISEAU
text: in writing.- This vote concerns the adoption of several amendments to the 2017 draft budget submitted by the Council which were rejected by the BUDG committee on 28 and 29 September.This project is firmly focused on the migration crisis and the growth objective.On this last point, the EU is playing the right role, that of the investor, while at the same time suffocating national budgets.On the first point, the EU goes further and gives the possibility of redistributing appropriations between headings (made possible by the flexibility instruments) in favor of expenditure to help migrants.In total, France's planned contribution should amount to 18.5 billion euros for 2017. And a European tax is already under consideration.

name: Sander LOONES
text: written. - The MEPs of the N-VA are strong supporters of spending that provides an answer to the migration and security crisis, but note that there is insufficient emphasis on this in the 2017 budget. Less than 9% of the EU budget will be spent in 2017 on measures to strengthen security and asylum policy. That is why the N-VA delegation has also made proposals to increase resources for Europol and Frontex, the European Border and Coast Guard. Furthermore, the MEPs of the N-VA have a lot of reservations about the unnecessary and money-consuming issues that Europe does focus on, such as the new House of European History, its own limousine service and the refusal of the traditional political groups to cut costs. and travel allowances for MEPs. In times when serious efforts are required of European citizens and Member States, traditional political groups want to increase the EU budget by more than EUR 4 billion in 2017. Before proceeding to new expenditures, it should first be considered in which areas savings can be made. It is high time for the EU to focus on the policy areas where it has clear added value.

name: Paloma LÓPEZ BERMEJO
text: written.- The budget vote allows the plenary to express itself on only a few lines, leaving the definition and execution of most of the funds in the hands of the Commission and the Member States.With my vote, I have sought to ensure adequate income for European peasants, improve efficiency in the use of funds made by Parliament, reinforce the items for social and regional cohesion and environmental efficiency, oppose the planned cuts to financethe speculative programs of the Juncker Plan and blocking some aspects of the Union's aggressive foreign policy, especially towards Russia.

name: Bernd LUCKE
text: written.- This proposal for the 2017 EU budget contains a number of points which are not acceptable.Regardless of the tight budgetary situation in a number of EU Member States, all the proposals for cuts made by the Council in relation to the Commission's draft are to be withdrawn.In addition, the appropriations for commitments are to be increased by more than EUR 4 billion and for payment appropriations by almost EUR 2 billion.The planned distribution takes place primarily according to the watering can principle, regardless of compliance with subsidiarity requirements and without comprehensive monitoring of the success of measures.It is true that there are also positive approaches such as the fund we are proposing to support victims of terrorism or the increase in funds for Europol to strengthen internal security in Europe.Nevertheless, the negative aspects predominate, which is why I am rejecting this budget proposal.

name: Louis-Joseph MANSCOUR
text: in writing. - The Parliament wishes to negotiate the 2017 EU budget in close connection with the mid-term review of the multiannual financial framework (MFF) 2014-2020. As part of its strategy to revise the MFF ceilings upwards, it therefore proposes to provide a share of these additional funds as soon as the budget for next year is examined. Parliament is campaigning for an increase of € 4.1 billion in commitment appropriations and an extension of € 2 billion in payment appropriations, which would make it possible to strengthen budget lines in many areas: youth, growth and jobs; research, innovation and interconnection in Europe; support for key programs such as Erasmus +; security and migration; support for development cooperation programs; emergency support for the dairy sector. I vote in favor of this text, which constitutes an ambitious negotiating position for Parliament, both for the 2017 budget and for the review of the 2014-2020 MFF.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: in writing.- I do not support the draft general budget of the European Union for 2017 - all sections, because it is not complete and documented.

name: Dominique MARTIN
text: in writing.- The budget is geared towards managing the migration crisis and its corollary, the security aspect.The redeployment of funds in favor of the integration of migrants reinforces the programs for citizenship or against poverty which are now increasingly attributed to them, to the detriment of European citizens.At the same time, the plan continues to advocate austerity for member states' budgets and to promote the Juncker plan, which has yet to yield any tangible results.

name: Joëlle MÉLIN
text: in writing.- This vote concerns the adoption of several amendments to the 2017 draft budget submitted by the Council which were rejected by the BUDG committee on 28 and 29 September.This project is firmly focused on the migration crisis and the growth objective.On this last point, the EU is giving itself the right role, that of the investor, while at the same time the EU is suffocating national budgets.On the first point, the EU goes further and gives the possibility of redistributing appropriations between headings (made possible by the flexibility instruments) in favor of expenditure to help migrants.In total, France's planned contribution should amount to 18.5 billion euros for 2017. And a European tax is already under consideration.

name: Nuno MELO
text: in writing.- The 2017 budget must be seen in the broader context of the mid-term review of the multiannual financial framework (MFF);a balance needs to be struck between long-term priorities and new challenges.The 2017 budget must be in line with the objectives of the Europe 2020 strategy, which represents its main orientation and its overall priority.In a situation of scarcity of resources, greater importance must be attached to the need to respect budgetary discipline and to use financial resources efficiently and effectively.I think that is what this budget does, hence my vote in favor.

name: Roberta METSOLA
text: in writing. ‒ I supported the Parliament’s position on the Draft general budget for 2017 which calls for more support for the agencies dealing with the migration crisis as well as calling for greater support for the Union’s unemployed and its youth.

name: Marlene MIZZI
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted in favour of this draft budget, since it refers to an allocation that is required for the next financial year. This draft amending budget refers to new security needs identified by the EU institutions following the recent terror attacks and proposes to reinforce the budget for security among other things in a number of institutions. As far as the European Parliament is concerned it aims to create 35 additional permanent posts for the recruitment of security agents.

name: Csaba MOLNÁR
text: in writing. - According to the draft resolution of the Committee on Budgets, the 2017 budget fully reflects the political priorities. Notes that the Union is currently facing a number of major emergencies which could not have been foreseen at the time of the preparation of the Multiannual Financial Framework 2014-2020, and expresses its conviction that increased financial resources from the EU budget should be mobilized as a matter of urgency and priority in order to meet the political challenges and to enable the Union to respond and respond effectively to these crises. Takes the view that the 2017 budget must be able to meet the needs of the migration challenge and the slow economic growth caused by the economic crisis, and points out the need to increase funding for research and infrastructure projects and the fight against youth unemployment. It is convinced that the EU budget must find ways to fund new initiatives without putting existing EU programs and policies at a disadvantage. On this basis, it proposes to reinstate all the reductions proposed by the Council in the draft budget. I voted in favor of the draft.

name: Cláudia MONTEIRO DE AGUIAR
text: in writing. - In view of the scarcity of resources, it is essential to give greater importance to the need to respect budgetary discipline and to use financial resources efficiently and effectively. I endorse the rapporteur's position in the belief that the Union budget can contribute to an effective response to both the consequences and the root causes of the crises that the Union is currently facing. However, unforeseen events with a Union-wide dimension must be dealt with by concentrating efforts and making additional means available at Union level, without calling into question previous commitments or seeking refuge in purely national solutions. Flexibility provisions are in place to allow for this type of joint and rapid response and should be fully used to offset the strong restrictions imposed by the MFF ceilings. I also highlight that youth exchange programs are one of the most successful measures to increase skills and promote understanding and connectivity between populations. Thus, I believe that special attention should be paid to funds transferred annually to the Erasmus + program from the European Neighborhood Instrument, the IPA2 Instrument for Pre-Accession Assistance and the partnership instrument.

name: Sophie MONTEL
text: in writing.- This project is resolutely focused on the crisis linked to the influx of migrants and the resulting security aspect.It also emphasizes the goal of growth, a way of appropriating the right role (in financing the necessary investments) while ordering states to tighten their belts.Worse, it operates a redistribution of appropriations between headings (made possible by the flexibility instruments or the margins for unforeseen events) in favor of expenditure to help migrants.Thus, the margin available under the ceiling of heading 2 (which concerns the CAP, etc…) is reduced like a grain of salt to finance heading 3. I therefore vote against.

name: Nadine MORANO
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of the 2017 budget of the European Union.This budget will amount to 162.4 billion euros in commitment authorization and 138 billion euros in payment appropriations.I particularly welcome the amount allocated to youth employment, which is 1.5 billion euros, but also the 15 million increase in the ERASMUS budget.The additional package of 1.8 billion euros, in particular with the aim of increasing the budgets and staff allocated to Frontex, is also a considerable step forward in the current context of the need for external border control.However, it will be necessary to wait until the end of the conciliation phase with the council for the final budget to be adopted.

name: Victor NEGRESCU
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted in favour of the draft general budget of the European Union for 2017.

name: Demetris PAPADAKIS
text: in writing. - I voted in favor of the draft general budget of the EU for 2017 in view of the start of negotiations with the Council for its final vote. With this plan we are asking for more funds to help young people seeking work, to stimulate economic growth and to help third countries to alleviate the immigration crisis. To deal with the many new crises, the EU needs a comprehensive overhaul of the Multiannual Financial Framework (MFF) and a more ambitious European budget. Some of the additional funds will come from the new appropriations that will be created during the mid-term review of the EU MFF. However, we do not agree with the Council's proposal for cuts in the draft European budget for 2017. We are asking for an additional 1.5 billion. EUR in commitment appropriations for the Youth Employment Initiative to help young people looking for a job. We call for an increase in funding for the Connecting Europe mechanism, which funds infrastructure projects, as well as for the Horizon 2020 program, which supports research projects. We are also asking for more funds to support farmers and increase spending on culture.

name: Kostas PAPADAKIS
text: in writing. - Once again, the same mischievous farce is being repeated to disorient the peoples in relation to the size of the EU budget, with a certain conclusion, as always: the agreement on the redistribution of the wealth produced by the people into monopolies, through the Community budget. All the political groups are moving in the direction of supporting the groups with EU money from the budget. In the same vein, the Draft Budget calls for more money for the Juncker Fund and the "cohesion funds" funded by business groups, as well as for Horizon 2020 (Business Research - Innovation) and Connecting Europe »(Infrastructure networks), which are oriented towards new profitable projects for the capital. An increase is also foreseen in the funds for large agricultural holdings under the CAP. Additional funding is provided for the promotion of EU imperialist interventions, with additional funding for Europol, the creation of a "counter-terrorism unit", the "European Counterterrorism Center", defense research funds and the External Action Service. At the same time, increased funding is provided for the anti-communist Europe for Citizens program. In short: more money in monopolies, more funding for the complex imperialist aggression of EU monopolies at the expense of the people.

name: Margot PARKER
text: in writing. ‒ This vote was a series of budgetary amendments to set the spending limits for the EU budget for 2017. The Commission had proposed an original budget of EUR 157 billion, the Council amended that to EUR 156 billion, and the Parliament was proposing to not only reverse the Council cuts, but to increase the budget significantly. UKIP and the EFDD Group submitted 33 cost-saving amendments to the EU budget, as well as voting in favour of cost-saving measures proposed by others. Our amendments, which would have saved in total over EUR 3 billion of taxpayers’ money, related to the cutting of bureaucracy. These proposals were for ‘victimless cuts’ which impact only upon the inner workings of the European Union and luxuries for officials. UKIP voted against any measures which would increase the EU budget, because it would be contrary to the decision of the British people on Brexit. In some cases the additions would have duplicated funding streams already in place in the UK. Exceptionally, we abstained rather than vote against where a new budget line was proposed to help Member States leave the euro. There was no actual funding proposed for this, and we support the principle of Member States leaving the euro.

name: Marijana PETIR
text: written. - The resolution on the Council's position on the draft general budget of the European Union for the financial year 2017 reflects the political priorities adopted by Parliament by a large majority in its resolution on general guidelines of 9 March 2016 and in its resolution of 6 July 2016. the level of appropriations under Title 2 by EUR 179.5 million in commitments and EUR 198 million in payments. Unfortunately, this reduction has hit rural development hardest, and I am glad that Parliament is asking for the current level of funding for the CAP to be maintained. It is encouraging that the European Parliament is calling for an increase in appropriations of EUR 600 million above the level foreseen in the draft budget, in order to neutralize the effects of the crisis in the dairy sector and the consequences of the Russian embargo in the dairy sector. It is precisely this problem that I myself have pointed out countless times through the amendments tabled to previous resolutions and reports of the European Parliament. I believe that it is necessary to pay special attention to the position of primary producers. I also welcome Parliament's efforts to increase funding for research and innovation in agriculture under Horizon 2020, and reiterate Parliament's position, which I have advocated for years, that priority should be given to projects involving primary producers. Because of all of the above, I supported this Resolution.

name: Florian PHILIPPOT
text: in writing.- This vote concerns the adoption of several amendments to the 2017 draft budget submitted by the Council which were rejected by the Committee on Budgets on 28 and 29 September.He claims to have growth as his objective (through a satisfaction with the implementation of the Juncker plan, which has brought nothing and resulted in the mobilization of the funds necessary in 2017 to achieve the objective set of 240 billion in private investments forthe end of the year), but also on a resolutely immigrationist (“welcoming land”) and security (“safe continent”) aspect.At the same time, the Commission is promoting the financial consolidation of state budgets, and therefore austerity, the macroeconomic results of which are more than questionable.I am therefore generally opposed to it.

name: Tonino PICULA
text: written. - The budget for 2017 must be in line with the objectives of the Europe 2020 strategy, which is its main goal. We are facing a number of crisis situations and challenges that could not have been foreseen at the time when the previous MFF was being prepared. Additional financial resources are needed to find a solution. It is necessary to respond to the migration challenge and slow economic growth, and to increase funding for research and infrastructure projects. An agreement on the appropriate level of additional funding for the Youth Employment Initiative should be reached as part of the mid-term review of the MFF. Contingency events affecting the Union as a whole should be addressed by joint efforts and the allocation of additional resources at Union level, and not by calling into question commitments or seeking solutions exclusively at national level. Additional resources for Europol staff are also needed. We face an increased level of threats in several Member States, with comparative challenges posed by migration management, the fight against terrorism and organized crime. Guaranteeing further support for candidate and potential candidate countries in adopting and implementing reforms must continue. Adherence to our core values ​​is key to the enlargement process. We need to be up to the situation and be able to respond effectively to the challenges ahead.

name: João PIMENTA LOPES
text: in writing. - We are in the presence, once again, of a budget that is completely out of step with the reality and real needs of the European Union. In a European Union in deep crisis, increasingly unequal, where high rates of poverty and unemployment persist, we have a short budget, deeply shaken in its distributive strand and increasingly tied to the aggressive and militaristic course of the European Union's foreign policy. It is therefore important to reinforce this budget, but this is not enough. It is necessary to put this budget at the service of development and social and territorial cohesion and to reinforce the special instruments designed, it must be said, to remedy the errors of our foreign policy that are at the root of the Russian embargo or the refugee crisis. Unfortunately, this proposal does not point in this direction. Rather, it follows on from previous budgets, all conditioned by a short multiannual framework and at the service of the EU's neoliberal policies and their security drift.

name: Salvatore Domenico POGLIESE
text: in writing. - Parliament sets the overall level of appropriations for 2017 at € 162.4 billion in commitment appropriations and at € 138.0 billion in payment appropriations. The report focuses on the need for the 2017 budget to meet the needs linked to the migration challenge and the slow growth of the economy. In this regard, I would like to emphasize, first of all, that funding for the reception of asylum seekers needs to be increased in order to support, in particular, first landing states. Secondly, I would like to point out that the EU budget for 2017 will have to focus on infrastructure projects for less developed regions and the fight against youth unemployment. I fully agree with the reference in the text of the report which points out that the provisions on budgetary flexibility exist in order to allow Member States to approve rapid and effective responses to the economic crisis.

name: Jiří POSPÍŠIL
text: in writing.- When voting on the budget, I did not support increasing the appropriations for posts in the European Parliament, because I believe that there is no need to increase the number of staff in our institution.

name: Franck PROUST
text: in writing. - The vote on the budget for 2017 is an important moment for the European Parliament. We must remember the context: political priorities are growing (security, migration, employment, youth, investments), but the Council of the EU wanted to propose reductions in many areas. It is understandable that some Member States, which experience budgetary difficulties often due to weak national public policies, wish to reduce the EU budget. But at the same time, these states and their citizens are always asking for more efficiency at European level. So you have to be consistent, and that's why I voted for the EU's draft general budget for 2017, which has revised upwards, as far as possible, the proposals made by the Council. For example, we have decided to increase the initiative for youth employment to 1.5 billion euros in commitment credit, to release an additional 600 million euros in commitment credit for the agricultural sector in order to support farmers who are victims of the dairy sector crisis, or even counter the harmful effects linked to the Russian embargo. A Europe that acts and protects is also and above all a Europe that knows how to prioritize its spending.

name: Julia REID
text: in writing. ‒ This vote was a series of budgetary amendments to set the spending limits for the EU budget for 2017. The Commission had proposed an original budget of EUR 157 billion, the Council amended that to EUR 156 billion, and the Parliament was proposing to not only reverse the Council cuts, but to increase the budget significantly. UKIP and the EFDD Group submitted 33 cost-saving amendments to the EU budget, as well as voting in favour of cost-saving measures proposed by others. Our amendments, which would have saved in total over EUR 3 billion of taxpayers’ money, related to the cutting of bureaucracy. These proposals were for ‘victimless cuts’ which impact only upon the inner workings of the European Union and luxuries for officials. UKIP voted against any measures which would increase the EU budget, because it would be contrary to the decision of the British people on Brexit. In some cases the additions would have duplicated funding streams already in place in the UK. Exceptionally, we abstained rather than vote against where a new budget line was proposed to help Member States leave the euro. There was no actual funding proposed for this, and we support the principle of Member States leaving the euro.

name: Frédérique RIES
text: in writing. - This Wednesday, as every year at the same period, the European Parliament adopted a draft EU budget for 2017. It voted in favor of an ambitious budget, namely 161.8 billion euros, providing for increased appropriations in relation to the Council, of 4 billion for commitments and 2 billion for payments. A budget that has also increased compared to last year, as it is true that the two crises in Europe, migration and economic, are still very present. There is also the impact of Brexit and the artificial deficit created by the depreciation of the pound that will have to be balanced. This 2017 draft budget is accompanied by a resolution on the mid-term review of the multiannual financial framework (MFF) which calls on member states to the need to reform the EU's finances. This political link established between the annual budgetary exercise and the revision of the multiannual financial framework is favored by the ALDE group. It is important to support the Commission's approach in the context of the mid-term review of the multiannual financial framework. This would ultimately amount to removing this overly narrow budgetary corset that the EU wears to face new security and migration challenges.

name: Inma RODRÍGUEZ-PIÑERO
text: written.- I voted in favor of the draft general budget of the Union for the financial year 2017, as it is in line with the objectives of the Europe 2020 strategy, and sets a broader context for the revision of the Multiannual Financial Framework.The Union faces a series of new challenges, especially political ones, and serious emergencies that must be addressed, responding as a matter of priority and with the utmost urgency, which is possible only by providing the Union with greater financial resources.The three areas the budget will focus on are: migration and the refugee crisis;a Global Europe and competitiveness for growth and jobs.

name: Claude ROLIN
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of a large number of amendments to the 2017 budget despite the Council’s more than cautious stance on this budget.I cannot accept that the Council is so hostile to any increase in the budget when the European Union is in dire need of additional funds for its priorities of migration, growth or even employment.This is why I voted in favor of the amendment calling for EUR 1.5 billion for the youth employment initiative and the amendment calling for an increase in commitment appropriations for theagriculture of 600 million euros.It should be noted, however, that I was opposed to the plan to internationalize drivers or to increase the budgets to allow the various political groups to hire additional staff.

name: Fernando RUAS
text: in writing. - I took a favorable view of the adoption of this EU budget proposal for next year. It is a budget that must take economic growth, security, the management of migratory flows and initiatives such as employment for young people as priority areas for action and financing. I agreed with the proposal to increase the appropriations for these initiatives and to restore the amounts for the Connecting Europe Facility and for the Horizon 2020 Program, which have had such a positive impact (and should continue) on the economies of the different Member States and on promoting of the Union's economic, social and territorial cohesion. For 2017, the amount set is € 160.7 billion in commitment appropriations and € 136.7 billion in payment appropriations.
