In both cases, there was an increase in value compared to what was proposed in the Commission's initial project. I would like to point out as positive proposals: an increase in appropriations for the areas of youth, growth and employment by EUR 1.5 billion, in order to respond more effectively to the drama of youth unemployment, as well as in the areas of security, migration management and asylum, where the European response is absolutely vital.

name: Lola SÁNCHEZ CALDENTEY
text: written.- Parliament proposes its budget proposal for 2017 to negotiate in the trilogue process.His proposal, even cutting less than the Council or the Commission, still entails a reduction in the overall budget, around 5% compared to the previous year.The first voting list of figures and remarks includes numerous amendments without a final vote.

name: Sven SCHULZE
text: written.- I approved the general budget of the European Union for 2017.The Commission's draft budget has been increased by 4.8 million for commitment appropriations and 3.1 million for payment appropriations.1.7 million were called up to finance migration-related expenditure, which is partly financed by the flexibility instrument of the EU budget and partly by the trading margin for unforeseen expenses.In addition, 1.3 million of the total profit margin on commitments for jobs and growth (EFSI) was used.

name: Maria Lidia SENRA RODRÍGUEZ
text: written.- The budget vote allows the plenary to express itself on only a few lines, leaving the definition and execution of most of the funds in the hands of the Commission and the Member States.With my vote, I have sought to ensure adequate income for European peasants, improve efficiency in the use of funds made by Parliament, reinforce the items for social and regional cohesion and environmental efficiency, oppose the planned cuts to financethe speculative programs of the Juncker Plan and blocking some aspects of the Union's aggressive foreign policy, especially towards Russia.

name: Ivan ŠTEFANEC
text: in writing.- Financial resources from the Union budget for 2017 should ensure a more efficient channel of financial resources towards the European Union's main priorities, taking into account developments at European level, thus contributing to an effective response to European interests and potential unforeseen needs by aligning the budget with realneeds.

name: Beatrix von STORCH
text: written. - Unsurprisingly, I did not approve the “General Budget of the European Union for 2017”. A selection: The EU Parliament decided on a budget for preparatory measures with regard to a joint military budget of half a million euros, a propaganda budget for the benefits of the euro over 11 million euros, and 3 million euros for a project on fast lane integration through training for migrant women, one approved, 50 million euros extra for an excellence program for cooperation in the youth field and the participation of young people in European democratic life, 18 million euros for the social fund with gender mainstreaming, 1.5 billion euros for the European Youth work initiative, 5 million euros for a greener economy and the implementation of European environmental policy, 148 million euros and a further 750 million euros for bringing Turkey closer to the EU, another 137 million euros for supporting reforms in Turkey, 4.6 million euros for EU parliamentary television, 32 million euros for the European political parties, 19 million euros for the European party foundations, 98 million euros 10 euros for salaries, 166 million euros for its buildings as well as 16 new positions for the EU External Action Service and 17 million euros for travel expenses between the seats of the EU Parliament in Strasbourg, Brussels and Luxembourg.

name: Dubravka ŠUICA
text: written.- The political priorities of the European Union budget for 2017 are focused on maintaining peace and stability, the fight against terrorism, humanitarian aid and resolving the refugee and migrant crisis.However, the instruments for creating jobs and investing in the future of young people must not be neglected.The most important investments of the European Union should continue to be in the field of cohesion and development policy.The importance of implementing measures to achieve gender equality and investing in environmental policy is also emphasized, especially after the ratification of the Paris Agreement.Parliament therefore sets the overall level of appropriations for 2017 at € 161.8 billion in commitment appropriations and € 136.8 billion in payment appropriations.I support this report as the most important step in addressing the current challenges of the European Union, and with a view to greater development and a better future for European citizens.

name: Neoklis SYLIKIOTIS
text: in writing. - The rejection of the budget remains for us a political act against the philosophy of the budget and austerity. Despite its positive elements, the increases that are being made are again moving in the direction of stimulating competitiveness and deepening militarization. The argument that we should support the budget because that is how we support the institution does not find us in agreement, since even this institution does not oppose austerity. The funds it raises do not change the philosophy of austerity.

name: Eleftherios SYNADINOS
text: in writing.- The Union budget must take into account current challenges and threats and address them.At the same time, to promote policies that lead to decent work, sustainable development and to ensure a balance between the financially sound and the corresponding weak economies of the Member States.Its main concern must be the well-being of the citizens of all the Member States.

name: Marc TARABELLA
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of the draft general budget of the EU for 2017. We debated the text internally and felt that it met the objectives set and stated a priori.

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the budget as it restored the initial budgets under the Connecting Europe Facility and the Horizon 2020 programme. Both of these programmes suffered cuts to pay for the EU’s contribution to the European Fund for Strategic Investments (EFSI). It also reinforces budgetary lines on improving access to finance and innovation for SMEs and increase the funding and staffing for Europol in order to create a 24/7 counter-terrorism unit. Now negotiations will the Council will start, it will be a tough fight, but the budget team is going there with a strong mandate

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: written. - I voted against this draft budget, as it again exceeds the limits of its powers by trying again to increase the Union budget by a staggering EUR 4.13 billion at the expense of the budgets of individual Member States. In addition, this proposal in the budget leaves not the slightest room for maneuver for unforeseen events and needs in 2017. On this occasion, I would like to emphasize once again that the budget of the European Union should be subject to the same rigor as the budgets of individual Member States. I am aware of the many challenges that the changed circumstances have brought to the European Union since 2013, when the multiannual budgetary framework was adopted, however, I firmly believe that solutions to the new circumstances can be found in efficient and effective redistribution within the existing budget. "Traveling circus" in Strasbourg, with savings of 180 million euros per year.

name: Estefanía TORRES MARTÍNEZ
text: written.- Parliament proposes its budget proposal for 2017 to negotiate in the trilogue process.His proposal, even cutting less than the Council or the Commission, still entails a reduction in the overall budget, around 5% compared to the previous year.The first voting list of figures and remarks includes numerous amendments without a final vote.

name: Ulrike TREBESIUS
text: written.- This proposal for the 2017 EU budget contains a number of points which are unacceptable.Regardless of the tight budgetary situation in a number of EU Member States, all the proposals for cuts made by the Council in relation to the Commission's draft are to be withdrawn.In addition, the commitments are to be increased by more than EUR 4 billion and the payment appropriations by almost EUR 2 billion.The planned distribution takes place primarily according to the watering can principle, regardless of compliance with subsidiarity requirements and without a comprehensive monitoring of the success of measures.It is true that there are also positive approaches such as the fund we are proposing to support victims of terrorism or the increase in funds for Europol to strengthen internal security in Europe.Nevertheless, the negative aspects predominate, which is why I am rejecting this budget proposal.

name: Ramon TREMOSA i BALCELLS
text: in writing. ‒ I am voting in favour of the budget because we need the EU to begin work as soon as possible on its priorities in 2017, particularly on the refugee crisis and with higher ethical standards at internal level.

name: István UJHELYI
text: in writing.- The 2017 budget should be seen in the broader context of the mid-term review of the MFF.A balance needs to be struck between long-term priorities and new challenges, so the 2017 budget must be in line with the Europe 2020 strategy, which sets out the main lines of the budget and its overarching priorities.

name: Miguel URBÁN CRESPO
text: written.- Parliament proposes its budget proposal for 2017 to negotiate in the trilogue process.His proposal, even cutting less than the Council or the Commission, still entails a reduction in the overall budget, around 5% compared to the previous year.The first voting list of figures and remarks includes numerous amendments without a final vote.

name: Ernest URTASUN
text: written.- I voted in favor of Parliament's position on the budget, in addition to supporting all the amendments that sought to increase social spending.

name: Ivo VAJGL
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the draft general budget of the European Union for 2017. The draft stresses that the budget 2017 has to be considered in the wider context of the mid-term revision of the multiannual financial framework (MFF). It emphasises the importance of ensuring further support for candidate and potential candidate countries in adopting and implementing political, economic and social reforms; reminds that respect for human rights, fundamental freedoms and rule of law is essential for the enlargement process. Moreover, it calls for increasing investment in the visibility of EU external action in order to strengthen the impact of funding in that field. In addition, it underlines that youth exchange programmes are one of the most successful measures to increase intercultural skills and to foster understanding and connectivity between people and countries. I voted in favour because I believe that the European Instrument for Democracy and Human Rights, including its support of election observation, are key for stability and prosperity in the world.

name: Ángela VALLINA
text: written.- The budget vote allows the plenary to express itself on only a few lines, leaving the definition and execution of most of the funds in the hands of the Commission and the Member States.With my vote, I have sought to ensure adequate income for European peasants, improve efficiency in the use of funds made by Parliament, reinforce the items for social and regional cohesion and environmental efficiency, oppose the planned cuts to financethe speculative programs of the Juncker Plan and blocking some aspects of the Union's aggressive foreign policy, especially towards Russia.

name: Hilde VAUTMANS
text: written.- This report included several adjustments for the 2017 budget. I voted with my group against the request that the transport of MEPs be done by officials.The private sector is now doing this in a good and cheaper way.I also voted against raising the staff for the political groups.I think they have enough staff to do the job.On the other hand, Frontex and Europol must have enough resources to deal with the migration crisis properly.

name: Marie-Christine VERGIAT
text: in writing. - The examination of the budget is an important moment for judging European policies. That of 2017 is an opportunity to recall the Council’s promise to revise the multiannual financial framework and review funding in line with the challenges the Union must face. I am delighted that the European Parliament includes among them the reception of refugees and their integration and the ecological challenge. This report is positioned within the framework of the dialogue with the Council which, as usual, calls for arbitrary budget cuts in programs such as Erasmus + and COSME which are among those which are the most representative of what the European + should be. The same goes for cohesion policies which are supposed to restore regional balances and which are increasingly subject to austerity policies and I am thinking in particular of structural funds such as ESI or LIFE, which are seriously threatened by Council cuts. It is therefore not a question of approving the final budget overall, but of influencing the Council to stop distorting European policies in order to model them on what I will call national selfishness. It is for these reasons that I abstained on this report while waiting for the final result of the negotiations to give a final decision.

name: Miguel VIEGAS
text: in writing. - We are in the presence, once again, of a budget that is completely out of step with the reality and real needs of the European Union. In a European Union in deep crisis, increasingly unequal, where high rates of poverty and unemployment persist, we have a short budget, deeply shaken in its distributive strand and increasingly tied to the aggressive and militaristic course of the European Union's foreign policy. It is therefore important to reinforce this budget, but this is not enough. It is necessary to put this budget at the service of development and social and territorial cohesion and to reinforce the special instruments designed, it must be said, to remedy the errors of our foreign policy that are at the root of the Russian embargo or the refugee crisis. Unfortunately, this proposal does not point in this direction. Rather, it follows on from previous budgets, all conditioned by a short multiannual framework and at the service of the EU's neoliberal policies and their security drift.

name: Daniele VIOTTI
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of the report concerning the position on the draft general budget of the European Union for the financial year 2017. The report takes into account the recovery of funds for youth employment (€ 1.5 billion), for Horizon2020, therefore for our companies, for universities and research, for public bodies.Identify funds for culture (10.8 million for cultural programs and 13 million for creative Erasmus projects);it recovers funds for immigration, humanitarian aid and development cooperation (allocating 7.5 million to Europol, 3.3 million to Eurojust and 5 million to the European Asylum Office).We did our best with what we had and the risk - with the cuts proposed by the Council - is that of managing the newspaper, of not having perspective or vision.

name: Sotirios ZARIANOPOULOS
text: in writing. - Once again, the same mischievous farce is being repeated to disorient the peoples in relation to the size of the EU budget, with a certain conclusion, as always: the agreement on the redistribution of the wealth produced by the people into monopolies, through the Community budget. All the political groups are moving in the direction of supporting the groups with EU money from the budget. In the same vein, the Draft Budget calls for more money for the Juncker Fund and the "cohesion funds" funded by business groups, as well as for Horizon 2020 (Business Research - Innovation) and Connecting Europe »(Infrastructure networks), which are oriented towards new profitable projects for the capital. An increase is also foreseen in the funds for large agricultural holdings under the CAP. Additional funding is provided for the promotion of EU imperialist interventions, with additional funding for Europol, the creation of a "counter-terrorism unit", the "European Counterterrorism Center", defense research funds and the External Action Service. At the same time, increased funding is provided for the anti-communist Europe for Citizens program. In short: more money in monopolies, more funding for the complex imperialist aggression of EU monopolies at the expense of the people.

name: Auke ZIJLSTRA
text: written.- The PVV voted against the draft general budget of the European Union for 2017. The PVV aims to reduce the expenditure of the European Union.Any savings are returned to the Member States under the Treaty.This benefits the taxpayer more than any other EU expenditure.

name: Ricardo SERRÃO SANTOS
text: - Mr President, today we approved a negotiated package of pilot projects that allow the European Parliament to exercise what is almost a right of legislative initiative, deciding and allocating funding for new and innovative activities. For the outermost regions and overseas territories, we approved a pilot project with an allocation of 1 million euros, taking advantage of this prerogative of the European Parliament. It was possible thanks to the contribution of civil society in the field to the elaboration of this project and the support and commitment of MEPs from the other ORs, overseas territories and Continental Europe. The outermost regions are the largest repository of biodiversity in the European Union and this new project that will make available 1 million euros to involve policy makers, scientists and society in general in the development of methodologies to map and assess the state of ecosystems and their services. The main objective is to lay the foundations for the best strategy for the preservation of biodiversity in the outermost regions through their best knowledge.

name: Paloma LÓPEZ BERMEJO
text: - Mr President, I did not vote in favor of these budgets because I fundamentally disapprove of their general orientation. Little by little the power of the market over public spending is spreading, transforming a community development fund into one more instrument of financial globalization and its contradictions. How to defend that research and infrastructure funds are increasingly concentrated in the richest countries? That employment funds are wasted on grants to entrepreneurs? That agricultural funds favor landowners and large agro-exporters over local development? That with money for asylum and development to build open-air prisons in Turkey? Or that foreign funds are an appendage of NATO and of colonial powers like Israel or Morocco? In short, how to justify its use to reinforce the increase in inequalities and injustices of capitalism? Europe has no future if it renounces social cohesion, productive convergence and peace.

name: Monica MACOVEI
text: - I also debated the European Union budget for 2017 yesterday. Now I would like to address only two specific issues: the money for the President's parliamentary expenses, which must be blocked and unblocked only under certain conditions, if certain questions are answered, and I call for a clear separation of the roles of President of Parliament and candidate for candidate. Parliament staff should also not be involved in private campaigns. Unfortunately, this amendment fell to the vote today. I do not know why my colleagues do not want us to have this transparency and these answers. I also ask for information on the international missions of the President of Parliament, which appear to be linked to events in socialist organizations or events in the German government. And, secondly, I would like to plead once again for a single seat of the European Parliament. I repeat, it costs us 900 million euros a year to come to Strasbourg or Luxembourg. Unfortunately, this amendment also fell, but I will repeat it because it is a waste of European money.

name: Peter JAHR
text: -  Mister President! I would like to make three comments from the point of view of the agricultural budget. First, the Commission gave us the figures for 2017 very late. It has to get better. Because if the numbers come before the constituency week before the summer break, the time frame is very tight to carry out extensive consultation. Second: I would like to thank everyone who was involved, including Parliament. The agricultural budget has essentially been kept stable. That is a stability that our European agricultural policy needs. And the third remark: should or will or can or must or does society have additional requirements for agriculture? Then of course we have to talk about more money. We must not forget: European farmers are also part of the European internal market and are also part of the global world market. And of course, if we establish higher standards in Europe, there will be no compensation through the price. Agriculture must continue to be helped here.

name: Seán KELLY
text: - A Uachtaráin, ar dtús ba mhaith liom na feisirí go léir a oibríonn ar an mbuiséad a mholadh.Is obair dheacair, thuirsiúil é agus tá moladh tuillte acu as ucht é a dhéanamh ar ár son.Ba mhaith liom díriú ar alt amháin, is é sin alt 99, maidir leis an suíochán singil nó aonair, nó suíochán amháin a bheith againn.Bhí 501 feisire as 688 ina fhabhar seo inniu.Agus dar ndóigh tá sé in am deireadh a chur leis an dá shuíochán.Ní luíonn sé le réasún, ó thaobh athrú aeráide agus na hastaíochtaí a ghabhann leis, ní luíonn sé le réasún ó thaobh an geilleagar agus na costais mhóra, na milliúin a ghabhann leis agus ní luíonn sé le réasún ó thaobean an strusdhaoine a bheith ag teacht anseo seachtain amháin agus ansin ag dul go dtí an Bhruiséil seachtain eile.Go raibh míle maith agat, a Uachtaráin.

name: Lars ADAKTUSSON
text: written.- Today, the European Parliament voted on the Committee on Budgets' proposal for the EU budget for 2017. The Christian Democrats are clear that the long-term ambition is to gradually reduce EU spending on agricultural, labor market, regional and industrial policies.As the report wanted to go in the exact opposite direction, I chose to vote no.

name: Isabella ADINOLFI
text: in writing. - The report presents the draft budget of the European Union for the year 2017. Although the report takes into account the strengthening of Heading III, which is under a lot of pressure from migratory phenomena, there are many rather questionable aspects in it. Firstly, it is almost impossible for Member States to cope with a further reduction in the budget, especially while respecting the budgetary constraints imposed by the European Union itself. Secondly, expenditure items have been added, such as the fund for the agreement with Turkey, which do not represent a priority need for the Union; in addition, the section dedicated to expenditure on bureaucracy and the European administration continues to increase. I believe that the resources available must be concentrated on lines of priority importance and that this must be done primarily by the European Union. For the reasons expressed above, I decided to vote against.

name: Clara AGUILERA
text: written.- We Spanish socialists have voted in favor of the proposal for the 2017 budget to be able to tackle unemployment and poverty.With this, we reject all the cuts proposed by the 28 Member States and call for more funds in the fight against youth unemployment and incentives for economic growth.

name: Tim AKER
text: in writing. – UKIP voted against this non-legislative and non—binding motion for a resolution. The resolution called for the cuts proposed by the Council to be reversed and more resources be given to the EU budget. UKIP voted for amendments which called for cuts to the EU budget, opposed development of an EU military capability and also voted in favour of an amendment which said that no EU funding should go to bullfighting. The EFDD Group (which UKIP is part of) also tabled an amendment which, among other things, called for a reduction in the salaries, allowances and travel expenses of MEPs. However this part of the amendment was ruled ‘inadmissible’ by the President of the European Parliament.

name: Marina ALBIOL GUZMÁN
text: written.- The resolution of the European Parliament emphasizes the need to strengthen the European budget and provide it with greater content in the social and ecological sphere, without questioning its neoliberal drift.Although I agree with these reforms, I consider them insufficient and have finally decided to abstain.

name: Martina ANDERSON
text: in writing. – This vote was regarding the mandate for the EP to negotiate with the Council, whilst we agreed with a number of aspects within this report, there were issues surrounding the priorities of the European Parliament in this regard which is why we abstained in the final vote. We supported the inclusion of certain elements into the mandate, especially our amendment which was adopted into paragraph 4 which called for ensuring support for the North in the wake of Brexit, this would encompass retaining programmes such as PEACE. Whilst the EP position does restore all the cuts made by the Council, it falls short on the cuts which had already been introduced by the Commission itself. The best reflection of this is reducing cohesion funding in favour of a militarised ‘fortress Europe’. The larger and wealthier Member States who have been cheerleaders of neoliberal policies and austerity, have played a significant role in the negative implications for social and regional programmes. We could not fully oppose the report as voting against consequently meant voting in favour of the Council’s position which is socially regressive, so we abstained.

name: Pascal ARIMONT
text: written.- The report stresses the need to strike a balance between long-term priorities and new challenges.It is therefore underlined that the 2017 budget must be in line with the objectives of the Europe 2020 strategy, which are its main direction.The priorities of the budget are also to put in place measures to deal with the migration crisis, as well as to stimulate the European economy, to create jobs and to combat youth unemployment.I approve the EU budget for 2017.Sufficient resources must continue to be made available to the Union to meet today's political challenges and to ensure that the Union remains capable of action.

name: Marie-Christine ARNAUTU
text: in writing. - This report concerns the Council's position on the draft general budget of the EU for the financial year 2017. Commitment appropriations are set at EUR 161.8 billion and payment appropriations at EUR 136.8 billion. euros, against 156.4 and 133.8 billion euros respectively in the Council's draft budget. This report gives pride of place to what is qualified as "new challenges", including the migration crisis, faintly qualified as "the challenge of refugees". This goes hand in hand with a demand for respect for the “fundamental rights” of migrants and senseless budgeting for their integration in times of economic crisis. Finally, an ever more advanced Europeanization of the asylum system is proposed. This is therefore a very expansionary European budget aimed at financing the immigrationist whims of European MPs but also the forced federalization of the main features of sovereignty, namely defense or asylum. Their financing is ensured by a further increase in amounts and not by a redeployment of appropriations or an effort made on the administrative expenditure of certain institutions of more than doubtful utility. Therefore, I opposed this report.

name: Jonathan ARNOTT
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted against this non-legislative and non-binding motion for a resolution. The resolution called for the cuts proposed by the Council to be reversed and more resources be given to the EU budget. UKIP voted for amendments which called for cuts to the EU budget, opposed development of an EU military and also voted in favour of an amendment which said no EU funding should go to bullfighting. The EFDD Group (which UKIP is part of) also tabled an amendment which, among other things, called a reduction in the salaries, allowances and travel expenses of MEPs. However this part of the amendment was ruled ‘inadmissible’ by the President of the European Parliament.

name: Jean ARTHUIS
text: in writing.- The 2017 budget is the first tranche of a revised framework.In fact, the draft budget articulated by the Commission is unlikely to hold up unless the revision of the multiannual financial framework is completed.We must now turn to the Council which, unfortunately, is struggling to provide a comprehensive response to budgetary issues.In these times of crisis, it is therefore necessary to coordinate positions between the European Parliament and the Council.It is in this sense that I voted in favor of this text.

name: Zigmantas BALČYTIS
text: in writing.- 2017the budget needs to strike a balance between long-term priorities and new challenges.Therefore, I agree that in 2017.the budget must be in line with the objectives of the Europe 2020 strategy, which is its main focus and top priority, and, of course, provide additional funding for Youth Employment Guarantees.

name: Zoltán BALCZÓ
text: in writing.- The European Union's 2017 budget is determined by the pallet of the seven-year financial framework.The amount of this decreased by 4.5% in real terms compared to the previous cycle, within which the most important cohesion funds for us increased by 8.4%.As a result, the gap between the countries of the center and the periphery will continue to grow next year, and that is unacceptable.The EU's neoliberal economic policies are implemented by the Stability Pact, economic governance and the Euro Plus Pact, which are based on the adoption and maintenance of austerity measures for both the Union and the Member States and deepen the current economic and social crisis, especially in difficult situations.countries.Based on all this, I rejected the budget proposal.

name: Gerard BATTEN
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted against this non-legislative and non-binding motion for a resolution. The resolution called for the cuts proposed by the Council to be reversed and more resources be given to the EU budget. UKIP voted for amendments which called for cuts to the EU budget, opposed development of an EU military capability and also voted in favour of an amendment which said that no EU funding should go to bullfighting. The EFDD Group (which UKIP is part of) also tabled an amendment which, among other things, called for a reduction in the salaries, allowances and travel expenses of MEPs. However this part of the amendment was ruled ‘inadmissible’ by the President of the European Parliament.

name: Nicolas BAY
text: in writing.- I decided to vote against this text because it is a very expansionist European budget, aimed at financing the pro-immigration whims of Euro-globalist deputies but also the federalisation of important features of sovereignty such as defenseor the right of asylum.In addition, this financing would be provided by a further increase in amounts and not by a redeployment of credits or an effort made on the administrative expenses of certain institutions of more than doubtful utility, which would weigh on the finances of France and of France.its citizens.

name: Hugues BAYET
text: in writing.- I approved this report, which emphasizes that the Union is currently faced with pressing emergencies and that the necessary budgetary resources should be allocated to them.This is the case, for example, in dealing with the migratory situation and respecting the rights of hundreds of thousands of refugees while substantially strengthening development aid in the countries of origin.The fight against youth unemployment and for economic recovery are two other urgent matters that should be taken into account in any budgetary act given the situation of the European economy too long hit by austerity.

name: Brando BENIFEI
text: in writing. - Today I voted in favor of the motion for a resolution on the general budget of the Union for the financial year 2017. This year the EU is faced with a series of serious emergencies, unpredictable at the time of the elaboration of the 2014 MFF- 2020, which today however require a greater effort to be resolved. More financial resources must therefore be allocated to address those political challenges and allow the Union to act effectively in the new global context. A balance must first be ensured between long-term priorities and those new challenges involving issues such as the Union's internal and external security, migration management and the need to strengthen investment to foster growth and jobs. . It is a question of making these assessments bearing in mind the contextual mid-term review of the Multiannual Financial Framework. The text approved today respects this, adding 1.5 billion euros in appropriations for the Youth Employment Initiative and providing for the cancellation of all cuts made by the Council in the field of development policy and humanitarian aid .

name: Xabier BENITO ZILUAGA
text: written.- I voted against the Budget Resolution because, even though it is a less harsh position than the Commission or, needless to say, that the Council, it still assumes 5% cuts.Even though there are aspects that restore items of interest (youth employment initiative, although then it is barely applied by 7% by the Member States), it also does so with other security items, it continues to bet on the problematic Juncker Plan to promote investment, and I do not find a redistributive character in the proposed model.

name: Izaskun BILBAO BARANDICA
text: written.- I voted in favor of this report on the draft general EU budget for the financial year 2017. I voted against the creation of 76 new posts in the political groups, as well as in favor of reducing the parliamentary allocation forthe travel of the deputies and the reduction of the allowance for assistants and the remuneration of the deputies.Furthermore, I voted in favor of the amendment which referred to eliminating bottlenecks, improving railway interoperability, making the pending links and improving cross-border sections.

name: Dominique BILDE
text: in writing. - I voted against this report on Parliament's position in the context of its negotiations with the Council on the draft general budget of the European Union for the financial year 2017. It would be funny, if it were not scandalous , that Parliament seeks to increase the commitment appropriations it sets at EUR 161.8 billion and the payment appropriations it sets at EUR 136.8 billion, while at the same time Member States are called upon to tighten their belts. These increases have no other function than to manage the slump of crises that the European Union itself has created (youth unemployment, migrant crisis, progressive annihilation of our agricultural industries, etc.). The migration crisis, caused by the irresponsible policies of the EU, thus receives the fair share of the budget with an increase in appropriations for heading 3, guaranteed until the end of the programming period in 2020: let us remember that after 10 , 5 billion euros in 2015 and 2016, the 2017 draft budget plans to allocate an additional 5.2 billion euros. We are eagerly awaiting explanations from our respective governments justifying the drastic cuts in other priority sectors such as employment.

name: Mara BIZZOTTO
text: in writing.- I do not agree with what is said in the own-initiative report accompanying the budget of the European institutions for 2017. I believe that, apart from a few shared interventions such as those in favor of the CAP, there are still many completely unacceptable passages, for example the huge funding forTurkey.I firmly believe that this measure is far from responding to the real and concrete needs of our citizens.For all these reasons, I did not intend to support the text with my vote.

name: José BLANCO LÓPEZ
text: written. - We Spanish socialists have voted in favor of the proposal for the 2017 budget to be able to tackle unemployment and poverty. With this, we reject all the cuts proposed by the 28 Member States and demand more funds in the fight against youth unemployment and incentives for economic growth. Among other measures, we are proposing an additional € 1.5 billion for the Youth Employment Initiative, in order to help unemployed young people, and we are committed to increasing investment in infrastructure and research by € 1.24 billion. With our proposals, this budget reinforces solidarity within the Union (Youth Employment Initiative, child guarantee, support for farmers and ranchers) but also outside our borders. In this sense, we Socialists have obtained the support of the European Parliament for the increase of aid programs for refugees, humanitarian aid, development cooperation and support for neighboring countries.

name: Vilija BLINKEVIČIŪTĖ
text: in writing. - I voted in favor of this report, which deals with the Council's position on the draft general budget of the European Union for the financial year 2017. The European Parliament welcomes the integration of gender equality as an integrated policy objective of the EU budget into EU funds and programs. Recalls also that spending and income decisions have a different impact on women and men, and therefore emphasizes that gender budgeting is a key tool in combating gender inequality. Parliament emphasizes that the most important Job creation, growth and investment remain a priority for the EU budget; Draws attention to the gender-specific goals set out in the Europe 2020 strategy, namely to increase women's employment from the current level of only 63.5%; to ensure equal pay for men and women, equal numbers of men and women in national parliaments and equal numbers of men and women on the boards of large companies. Unfortunately, it is still a long way from achieving all these goals. Parliament therefore considers that the European Structural and Investment Funds should provide adequate funding for measures to promote and support quality education, employment opportunities and job creation for women and girls in order to improve their access to quality employment, further training, apprenticeships and apprenticeships. or training opportunities.

name: Andrea BOCSKOR
text: in writing.- It is unfortunate that the EP report on the 2017 EU budget refers to the parliamentary report adopted in the July plenary vote, which gave an advance opinion on the revision of the 2014-2020 financial framework.This provides for a penalty for Member States that reject the quota system.Fidesz MEPs will only adopt a revision of the financial framework and an EU budget in which these penalties are not even at the level of ideas.As the text of the report on the Council's position on the draft general budget of the European Union for the financial year 2017 refers to the EP report calling for a fine against Member States that did not adopt mandatory quotas in July, I abstained in the final vote on the report.

name: Franc BOGOVIČ
text: in writing.- I supported the draft general budget for 2017, as it accordingly provides for greater flexibility and an increase in funding for the needs of the migration challenge and slow economic growth following the economic crisis.Among other things, he strongly opposes cuts in the section that brings growth and jobs to citizens, especially young people.It supports the continued absorption of the ESI Funds and other funds and provides, inter alia, for specific measures to provide support to regions that may be harmed if the United Kingdom withdraws from the Union.

name: Marie-Christine BOUTONNET
text: in writing.- This report, which recommends a substantial increase in expenditure, due in particular to the reception of migrants, also proposes its financing by increasing the financial contributions of the Member States, already too high in my opinion, without examining at any timethe possibility of saving on operating costs.In addition, he mentions the strengthening of the role of the EU in matters of asylum and defense rights, which I consider to be the sovereign competence of the Member States.I therefore opposed this text.

name: Mercedes BRESSO
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the resolution on the draft general budget of the European Union for the financial year 2017 mainly because it points out the need to ensure the achievements of the EU 2020 targets and reprimands the Commission for its recent initiatives aimed at suspending the ESI funds. On the contrary, I believe that the Union shall deploy more financial resources in order to deliver political answers to the challenges we face nowadays, such as migration and the slow economic growth. In particular, I think additional funding is needed in order to address the current refugee crisis.

name: Renata BRIANO
text: in writing. - The EU budget represents around 1% of the EU's gross national income, therefore it is complementary to national budgets. The 2017 draft budget must take into account the expressed desire of the people of Great Britain to leave the European Union. The draft budget reflects and supports the political priorities set by Commission President Juncker and seeks to provide a European response to the challenges of managing migration, combating terrorism and organized crime, protecting the Union's external borders and collaboration with neighboring regions of the EU. One of the main priorities of the budget concerns employment, growth and investment as, even as the European economy continues its recovery, growth forecasts remain modest. The Fisheries Committee invites the Committee on Budgets to bear in mind that the EMFF has limited resources compared to other funds and that the network of agreements with third countries must be expanded. Furthermore, funding for the fisheries sector must not be reduced as this sector has an important economic, social and environmental dimension in the blue economy.

name: Steeve BRIOIS
text: in writing. - This draft budget calls for restoring the amounts that the Council recommended to reduce in order to preserve sufficient budgetary room for maneuver in the event of possible crises. With 161.8 billion euros in commitment appropriations and 136.8 billion euros in payment appropriations, this draft budget aims in particular to increase the funds intended for the Horizon 2020 program as well as for the initiative for youth employment. Of course, we approve of the 600 million euros in additional credits intended to come to the aid of the agricultural sector threatened by the fall in the price of raw materials and by the Russian embargo initiated by the European Union. On the other hand, we strongly oppose the increase in funds intended to finance the reception of irregular migrants in the Member States of the European Union. At a time when the peoples of Europe are suffering from mass unemployment and precariousness, it is astounding to see the European Union giving priority to the comfort of illegal migrants. This proposal reveals how much the technocrats in Brussels are disconnected from the daily life of our fellow citizens. I therefore voted against this text.

name: Soledad CABEZÓN RUIZ
text: written. - We Spanish socialists have voted in favor of the proposal for the 2017 budget to be able to tackle unemployment and poverty. With this, we reject all the cuts proposed by the 28 Member States and call for more funds in the fight against youth unemployment and incentives for economic growth. Among other measures, we are proposing an additional € 1.5 billion for the Youth Employment Initiative, in order to help unemployed young people and we are committed to increasing investment in infrastructure and research by € 1.24 billion. With our proposals, this budget reinforces solidarity within the Union (Youth Employment Initiative, child guarantee, support for farmers and ranchers) but also outside our borders. In this sense, we Socialists have obtained the support of the European Parliament for the increase of aid programs for refugees, humanitarian aid, development cooperation and support for neighboring countries.

name: Alain CADEC
text: in writing. - The European Parliament adopted its position on the general budget of the Union for the year 2017. We rejected all the cuts that the Member States had proposed. This draft budget represents 162.4 billion euros in commitment credits and 138 billion euros in payments. It is an ambitious budget that takes into account the many crises we are currently facing. The new European Border and Coast Guard Agency now has funding of 299.2 million euros, which is double the amount previously allocated to Frontex. An emergency support package of 600 million euros will be put in place to combat the effects of the crisis in the dairy sector and the effects of the Russian embargo. This is important support for our farmers. This report allowed me to remind that the seat of the European Parliament is in Strasbourg and must remain so. I also voted against the internalization of the chauffeur service which is a huge expense. Now we will enter into negotiations with the Council to have the 2017 budget formally adopted. I voted in favor of this report.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: in writing. - Today I voted in favor of the report on the draft general budget of the European Union for the financial year 2017. I believe that many of the political priorities, such as the effective management of the migration and refugee crisis, the promotion of competitiveness through the creation of jobs and the pursuit of sustainable development goals are supported with adequate allocations of financial resources. In particular, in the 2017 budget, Parliament focused its attention on new and serious challenges that could not be foreseen when drawing up the Multiannual Financial Framework 2014-2020. The 2017 budget, therefore, must be seen in the broader context of the MFF mid-term review and, as the report appropriately deduces, is in line with the objectives set by the Europe 2020 strategy. The EU, having ratified the COP21 agreement, it will allocate a large part of its financial resources to respect the international commitments undertaken. According to forecasts, for the 2017 financial year, the budget should allocate 19.2% of total expenditure to this end.

name: Matt CARTHY
text: in writing. ‒ Whilst I agreed with a number of aspects within this report, there were issues surrounding the priorities of the European Parliament in this regard, which is why I abstained in the final vote. I supported the inclusion of certain elements into the mandate, especially a Sinn Féin amendment in paragraph 4 ensuring support for the North in the wake of Brexit, which would encompass retaining programmes such as PEACE. Whilst the Parliament’s position does restore all the cuts made by the Council, it falls short on the cuts which had already been introduced by the Commission itself. The best reflection of this is a reduction of cohesion funding in favour of a militarized ‘fortress Europe’. The larger and wealthier Member States, who have been cheerleaders of neoliberal policies and champions of austerity, have played a significant role in the negative implications for social and regional programmes. This entails Member States, local authorities, institutions and civil society stakeholders being held hostage by ‘market logic’ and the systematic transfer of funds from existing EU programs and the erosion of public investment. I could not fully oppose the report as voting against consequently meant voting in favour of the Council’s position, which is socially regressive, so I abstained.

name: James CARVER
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted against this non-legislative and non-binding motion for a resolution. The resolution called for the cuts proposed by the Council to be reversed and more resources be given to the EU budget. UKIP voted for amendments which called for cuts to the EU budget, opposed development of an EU military capability and also voted in favour of an amendment which said that no EU funding should go to bullfighting. The EFDD Group (which UKIP is part of) also tabled an amendment which, among other things, called for a reduction in the salaries, allowances and travel expenses of MEPs. However this part of the amendment was ruled ‘inadmissible’ by the President of the European Parliament.

name: David CASA
text: in writing. ‒ The budget 2017 needs to be considered in the wider context of the mid-term revision of the multiannual financial framework (MFF). It has to be in line with the 2020 targets. The EU is currently facing a number of serious emergencies and new challenges, which could not be foreseen at the time that the MFF 2014-2020 was set-up. Therefore, increased financial resources need to be deployed from the Union budget, in order to meet these challenges, such as the migration challenge and slow economic growth, and allow the Union to respond effectively to those crises as a matter of utmost urgency and priority. The Council has overall reduced most headings of the budget, with 52% of the overall Council cuts in commitments falling within subheading 1a on competitiveness for growth and jobs. When faced with this situation, questions arise as to the Council’s political priority on jobs and growth, infrastructure projects as well as for fighting youth unemployment.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: in writing.- This is the resolution concerning the approval of the EU budget for 2017. We appreciated some political wishes and priorities, such as the strengthening of heading III, which is under severe pressure due to migratory phenomena;however, the European Parliament's vision lacks the necessary realism, since it is difficult, if not impossible, to ask for further budgetary efforts from Member States, whereas it is the EU itself which is responsible for a large part of the budgetary constraints to which States are subjectnationwide.Then the problem of the gap between commitments and payments persists, between vain promises and practical achievements: this year, two new heavy items of expenditure (EFSI guarantee and funds for the agreement with Turkey) have worsened the situation, whichresources that could be better used.In light of the above, together with the M5S delegation, I voted against.

name: Lefteris CHRISTOFOROU
text: in writing. - We support the report and emphasize that we want a budget that responds to new jobs, to young people, to those actions that have to do with research, with innovation, that really bring Europe forward. We want a budget that corresponds to a more social and humane Europe. We also want a real campaign and a strong effort to abolish bureaucracy. The bureaucracy is currently affecting the European Union budget, but it is particularly affecting citizens, small and medium-sized enterprises and the system itself. Many millions are lost on the altar of bureaucracy, as are the hopes and dreams of many people. I also support the budget report, because it meets the hopes and dreams, especially of young people, because there has been an increase in youth employment, in youth action, in Erasmus +, and in everything that really pushes a budget. growth and employment, in a budget for social and human Europe.

name: Angelo CIOCCA
text: in writing.- This measure is once again very far from meeting the real needs of citizens.In the context of the own-initiative report accompanied by the budget of the European institutions for 2017, some interventions in support of agriculture can be shared, but the huge funding in support of the EU-Turkey partnership is completely incomprehensible.I therefore confirm my negative vote.

name: Alberto CIRIO
text: in writing. - Effective and effective budgetary discipline can only be achieved through extensive and timely planning: in this way I intend to clarify my favorable vote. Moreover, in a moment of unfavorable macroeconomic conjuncture it is unthinkable to act differently if one yearns for a balance between long-term priorities and unpredictable challenges to be faced. The analysis offered by the project represents a source full of reflections and criticisms, as well as an opportunity to intervene on considerably heterogeneous issues. Among those that most aroused my attention I include the amendment to cut funds for breeders of bulls destined for bullfighting. Despite the opposition expressed by my group on the issue, I chose to vote according to conscience and thinking about the world in which I want my children and future generations to grow, I hope we no longer have to witness real slaughter that has little to do with it. what to do with the concept of lusus. Fortunately, the outcome of the vote reflected my thinking and therefore the funds for raising fighting bulls were cut from the 130 million annual funds for agriculture and breeding for Spain. I hope it will soon be possible to ban the bullfight itself: mere torture, neither art nor culture.

name: Deirdre CLUNE
text: in writing. ‒ I supported the report on the Council position on the draft general budget of the European Union for the financial year 2017.

name: Carlos COELHO
text: in writing. - The 2017 Budget must respond to the needs linked to the challenges of migration and the slowdown in growth following the economic crisis. It is therefore necessary to increase funding for research and infrastructure projects, as well as to combat youth unemployment. I support increasing the allocation for the Youth Employment Initiative by EUR 1 500 million in commitment appropriations. I welcome the Commission's proposal for an additional EUR 1.8 billion to meet the challenge of migration in the Union. I agree with the need to increase appropriations for Europol, Eu-lisa and Enisa. I approve Parliament's decision to increase appropriations for the dairy sector by EUR 600 million in order to counter the effects of the crisis in the dairy sector and the Russian embargo on the milk sector. I subscribe to the replacement of all amounts cut in the Connecting Europe Facility (investments to improve European transport, energy and digital technology networks) and Horizon 2020 (EU program for research and innovation), for a total of EUR 1,240 million in commitments. For this reason, I supported this report.

name: Lara COMI
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of the provision as it sets the overall level of appropriations for 2017 at € 162.4 billion in commitment appropriations and at € 138 billion in payment appropriations.The expenditure chapters represented in the text - and specifically those dedicated to competitiveness for growth and employment, social and territorial economic cohesion, sustainable growth, security, administration and the reserve for emergency aid - arein line with European policies.

name: Javier COUSO PERMUY
text: written.- The resolution of the European Parliament emphasizes the need to strengthen the European budget and provide it with more content in the social and ecological sphere, without questioning its neoliberal drift.Although I agree with these reforms, I consider them insufficient and have finally decided to abstain.

name: Edward CZESAK
text: in writing.- I voted for the general budget of the European Union for the financial year 2017 because I welcome its provisions.Given the global situation, I consider it important to create a new budget line for the 'fund for victims of terrorism'.The purpose of this fund is to provide both financial and mental support to victims of terrorism.The report mentions the need to increase the spending limits for taking specific measures to support the YEI and the dairy sector.The report describes very important issues, proposing concrete solutions.These are the reasons why I voted in favor.

name: Miriam DALLI
text: in writing. ‒ This report recognises the need for a higher budget allocation to be able to tackle new realities. The 3.8% addition in budget when compared to the 2016 allocation is required in order for the European Parliament to have the financial tools needed to keep working effectively. An example of realities which require further financing is the current refugee and migratory challenges while continuing with the support of sustainable development goals and the funding for victims of terrorism amongst others.

name: Daniel DALTON
text: in writing. ‒ I cannot support this report, which proposes increasing EU budget commitments by over EUR 4 billion, attempting to completely reverse the budgetary agreements made by national governments for 2017. At a time when national governments across Europe are facing significant fiscal challenges this makes no sense and is an attempt to reverse the historic agreement the UK secured in 2013 to bring the EU budget under control after decades of rising spending.

name: Michel DANTIN
text: in writing. - This report aims to establish the position of the European Parliament on the general budget of the European Union for the financial year 2017. Before entering into the budget conciliation phase with the Council of Ministers, the Parliament wished to vote in favor an ambitious budget of € 160.7 billion in commitment appropriations and € 136.8 billion in payment appropriations, constituting an increase of € 7.9 billion compared to the proposal from the European Commission, including an additional 600 million euros to stabilize agricultural markets, especially dairy. The main objectives of this political budget are agriculture, therefore, youth and employment, but also security and the management of the migration crisis. Considering that the European budget must meet the challenges and strong current expectations, I supported the position of the European Parliament on the general budget for the Union.

name: William (The Earl of) DARTMOUTH
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted against this non-legislative and non-binding motion for a resolution. The resolution called for the cuts proposed by the Council to be reversed and more resources be given to the EU budget. UKIP voted for amendments which called for cuts to the EU budget, opposed development of an EU military capability and also voted in favour of an amendment which said that no EU funding should go to bullfighting. The EFDD Group (which UKIP is part of) also tabled an amendment which, among other things, called for a reduction in the salaries, allowances and travel expenses of MEPs. However this part of the amendment was ruled ‘inadmissible’ by the President of the European Parliament.

name: Rachida DATI
text: in writing.- I approved the position of the European Parliament on the general budget of the European Union for the financial year 2017 which, in particular, increases spending in the fields of culture, communication, citizenship and youth.I also support the increase in the budget initially proposed by the European Commission which will strengthen the role of agencies with tasks related to security and home affairs such as Europol, Eurojust and the European Support Office forasylum.However, I reiterated my opposition to the internalization of the driver's service in Parliament which will cost an additional 3.7 million euros each year compared to the current system.

name: Angélique DELAHAYE
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of this report on the general budget of the EU for 2017. It proposes to renew the main existing funds and to increase the resources for several areas which are in particular need.He proposes in particular to increase the budget for the Erasmus and Marie Curie programs, to increase the credits in agriculture to alleviate the effects of the dairy crisis, and to increase the amounts to manage the migratory challenges in the Union.It is a very good thing.However, on the budget of the Parliament and the administration, I voted against the internalisation of the drivers, because for me it represents an unjustified additional cost for the budget of the European Union without real added value: this is unacceptable!

name: Marielle DE SARNEZ
text: in writing. - The 2017 EU budget responds to the challenges facing the European Union in terms of migration, access of young people to employment and foreign policy. It highlights growth, youth and innovation in line with previous budgets, the financial reinforcement of Horizon 2020, Erasmus + and the Connecting Europe Facility programs. The development projects carried out by the Union in third countries must also be supported more actively. It is a question of finding the necessary balance between investment and budgetary rigor. One of the challenges of this legislature is the implementation of the Investment Plan for Europe (EFSI).

name: Tamás DEUTSCH
text: in writing. - It is unfortunate that the EP's report on the EU budget for 2017 refers to the parliamentary report adopted in the July plenary vote, which gave an opinion in advance on the revision of the 2014-2020 financial framework. In this, despite the united protests of the People's Party MPs, the MEPs of the Hungarian left-wing parties voted against the interests of the country, attacking all Hungarian citizens with their decision on forced resettlement. MEPs from left-wing parties in Hungary supported the forced resettlement and the harsh financial sanctions of countries that rejected it by a firm and proud vote in the European Parliament. At the same time, the vast majority of Hungarian voters have a clear position: they said no to forced resettlement. Therefore, Fidesz MEPs will only adopt a revision of the financial framework and an EU budget in which these penalties are not even at the level of ideas. are included. As the text of the report on the Council's position on the draft general budget of the European Union for the financial year 2017 refers to the EP report calling for a fine against Member States that did not adopt mandatory quotas in July, I abstained in the final vote on the report.

name: Mireille D'ORNANO
text: in writing. - This report calls for restoring the amounts that the Council planned to reduce by several billion on the pretext that the margins left in the Council's draft budget would be insufficient to face crises or major issues such as the migration crisis, or the COP21. The text speaks of “new challenges” and qualifies the migration crisis as “refugee challenge” which calls for an increase in the related appropriations. He welcomes the agreement with Turkey on migrants. Likewise, an ever more advanced Europeanization of the asylum system is proposed, whereas this prerogative should be solely the responsibility of the Member States. It is therefore an expansionary budget aimed at financing immigration and federalism at a forced march. Their financing is ensured by a further increase in amounts and not by a redeployment of credits or an effort made on the administrative expenses of certain institutions of doubtful utility. Obviously, I voted against this budget.

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: in writing. - The Union budget must take into account current challenges and threats and address them. At the same time, to promote policies that lead to decent work, sustainable development and to ensure a balance between the financially sound and the corresponding weak economies of the Member States. Its main concern must be the well-being of the citizens of all the Member States.

name: Norbert ERDŐS
text: in writing. - It is unfortunate that the EP's report on the EU budget for 2017 refers to the parliamentary report adopted in the July plenary vote, which gave an opinion in advance on the revision of the 2014-2020 financial framework. In this, despite the united protests of the People's Party MPs, the MEPs of the Hungarian left-wing parties voted against the interests of the country, attacking all Hungarian citizens with their decision on forced resettlement. MEPs from left-wing parties in Hungary supported the forced resettlement and the harsh financial sanctions of countries that rejected it by a firm and proud vote in the European Parliament. At the same time, the vast majority of Hungarian voters have a clear position: they said no to forced resettlement. Therefore, Fidesz MEPs will only adopt a revision of the financial framework and an EU budget in which these penalties are not even at the level of ideas. are included. As the text of the report on the Council's position on the draft general budget of the European Union for the financial year 2017 refers to the EP report calling for a fine against Member States that did not adopt mandatory quotas in July, I abstained in the final vote on the report.

name: Jill EVANS
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against including Preparatory Action for Defence Research in the EU budget 2017. Since my election in 1999 I have strongly and actively opposed the militarisation of the EU. I have called instead for a civilian peace corps which could work directly with people in areas of tension to prevent conflict developing. I believe the EU could develop a new and positive global role in this respect. The defence proposal not only takes the EU in the opposite direction but it would actually divert money from other areas of the budget. Many of my constituents in Wales who contacted me on this issue will be disappointed that we did not achieve a majority in the vote to delete it.

name: Fredrick FEDERLEY
text: written. - The budget report contained many good elements such as restoring funding for the EFSI research fund and more resources to deal with the refugee crisis. However, the total budget was an increase both compared to the Commission's and the Council's proposal, and since I believe that the total EU budget should not be increased, I chose to abstain in the final vote.

name: Edouard FERRAND
text: in writing. - I voted against. It is indeed a very expansionist European budget aimed at financing the Euro-immigrationist whims of the European deputies but also the forced federalisation of the main features of sovereignty such as defense or asylum.

name: João FERREIRA
text: in writing. - This resolution is in line with the budget proposal itself. None of them respond to the deep and persistent problems that the EU and its Member States face, and in the face of these problems, they point out or guarantee the wrong paths. We voted against. As with the 2017 budget, we have also tabled several amendments to this resolution which, taken together, demonstrate the possibility and viability of another path. The overwhelming majority of our proposed amendments were, however, rejected, to which the votes of the PS, PSD and CDS also contributed. The PCP, which voted against the 2017 EU budget proposal, will continue to strive for a break with EU policies, presenting alternative proposals always in defense of the national interest, workers and the Portuguese people. Some positive aspects that the resolution contains do not erase globally negative content, either for what is said, or fundamentally for huge omissions. The EU's problem lies in its amount - it is very insufficient - but also in its priorities - they are wrong. They are at the service, not of objectives of cohesion, peace and development, but, on the contrary, of objectives of retrogression, aggression and interference.

name: Raffaele FITTO
text: in writing. - I voted against this measure as it does not address budgetary inefficiencies and increases the distance between citizens and EU institutions. In particular, the lack of clear rules on financing Turkey with regard to migrants and the maintenance of the status quo regarding the three seats of Parliament (Brussels, Strasbourg and Luxembourg) demonstrate the inadequacy of this EU to address the real priorities that need to be addressed. front: economy, immigration and security.

name: Lorenzo FONTANA
text: in writing. - I am voting against the report on the EU budget: net of some actions that can be shared, the measure is once again very far from responding to the real and concrete needs of citizens and continues to support the EU-Turkey partnership.

name: Ashley FOX
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against this budget put forward by the Parliament as it reintroduces cuts which were decided by Member States in the Council. The budget put forward an extra EUR 1.5 billion for the ‘Youth Employment Initiative’, something that has arguably done very little to change the percentage of youth unemployment in Member States. Instead of throwing more money at EU schemes we should seek to use the money already allocated more wisely.

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: in writing. ‒ The Budgets committee reversed all Council’s cuts in commitment appropriations by restoring the Commission’s Draft Budget (EC- DB) for 2017. Furthermore, considerable increases over the Commission’s Draft Budget on specific topics of political interest have been voted, mostly to fully compensate the cuts from the agreement on the European Fund for Strategic Investments (EFSI),as well as to ensure additional resources needed for the internal and external dimension of the refugee crisis, and for financing the Youth Employment Initiative. We must ask for a further use of the existing flexibility instruments under the current MFF and making reference to the revision of the MFF, in order to make the EP’s priorities clear. I welcome the fact that, in order to keep the political lead on the fight against youth unemployment, the Youth Employment Initiative will be increased by EUR 1.5 billion. Also the Fund for European Aid to the Most Deprived (FEAD) has been increased by EUR 4 million.

name: Kinga GÁL
text: in writing. - It is unfortunate that the EP's report on the EU budget for 2017 refers to the parliamentary report adopted in the July plenary vote, which gave an advance opinion on the revision of the 2014-2020 financial framework. In this, despite the united protest of the People's Party MPs, the MEPs of the Hungarian left parties voted against the interests of the country. MEPs from left-wing parties in Hungary supported the forced resettlement and the harsh financial sanctions of countries that rejected it by a firm and proud vote in the European Parliament. At the same time, the vast majority of Hungarian voters have a clear position: they said no to forced resettlement. Therefore, Fidesz MEPs will only adopt a revision of the financial framework and an EU budget in which these penalties are not even at the level of ideas. As the general budget of the European Union for the financial year 2017 In the text of the report on the Council's position on the draft

name: Francisco de Paula GAMBUS MILLET
text: written. - I voted in favor of the Union budget, convinced of the need for the necessary financial resources to be placed in the Union budget, to respond to political challenges and allow the Union to act and respond to crises as a matter of priority and with the utmost urgency. To increase investment in research and development by 25 million, to allocate 1.5 billion to combat youth unemployment, to help with 600 million to farmers hit by the crisis in the dairy sector, to mobilize 15 million euros more to funds Erasmus so that young Europeans can study around Europe with the help of the Union. To put an end to the waste of allocating resources from the common agrarian policy to raising bulls destined to die in bullfights, because our farmers are already sufficiently hit by the crisis in the sector, to lose resources in this way. For all this, I have voted in favor of the Union budget for 2017.

name: Iratxe GARCÍA PÉREZ
text: written. - We Spanish socialists have voted in favor of the proposal for the 2017 budget in order to tackle unemployment and poverty. With this, we reject all the cuts proposed by the 28 Member States and call for more funds in the fight against youth unemployment and incentives for economic growth. Among other measures, we are proposing an additional € 1.5 billion for the Youth Employment Initiative, in order to help unemployed young people, and we are committed to increasing investment in infrastructure and research by € 1.24 billion. With our proposals, this budget reinforces solidarity within the Union (Youth Employment Initiative, child guarantee, support for farmers and ranchers) but also outside our borders. In this sense, the Socialists have obtained the support of the European Parliament to increase the programs of aid to refugees, humanitarian aid, development cooperation and support to the countries around us.

name: Eider GARDIAZABAL RUBIAL
text: written. - We Spanish socialists have voted in favor of the proposal for the 2017 budget in order to tackle unemployment and poverty. With this, we reject all the cuts proposed by the 28 Member States and call for more funds in the fight against youth unemployment and incentives for economic growth. Among other measures, we are proposing an additional € 1.5 billion for the Youth Employment Initiative, in order to help unemployed young people, and we are committed to increasing investment in infrastructure and research by € 1.24 billion. With our proposals, this budget reinforces solidarity within the Union (Youth Employment Initiative, child guarantee, support for farmers and ranchers) but also outside our borders. In this sense, the Socialists have obtained the support of the European Parliament to increase the programs of aid to refugees, humanitarian aid, development cooperation and support to the countries around us.

name: Elena GENTILE
text: in writing. - I voted in favor of the EP resolution on the EU general budget for 2017, because the EU needs an adequate budget to face the major challenges ahead and especially as a result of the changed conditions compared to those of 2014, when the 2014-2020 multiannual financial framework was negotiated. I supported the EP's request for more funds for young people looking for quality employment, to stimulate economic growth, to help third countries to deal with the emergency of the migratory crisis, the crisis in the agricultural and dairy sectors. following respectively sanctions on Russia and the end of the quota system. However, the major problem remains the adjustment of the multiannual financial framework, therefore, I agree with the EC proposal in this regard, as it introduces greater flexibility and the creation of a reserve in case of crisis. The EU needs a more ambitious budget e adapted to the challenges facing the EU. Now is the time for conciliation to reach the final agreement with the Council. The two budgetary authorities will have less than a month to reach it, as the EU budget for 2017 will have to be finally approved in December.

name: Arne GERICKE
text: written. - I voted against the "Report on the Council's position on the draft general budget of the European Union for the financial year 2017" because I also had to vote against the budget as a whole: it does not and has to be sufficiently responsible for taxpayers' money get significantly better before I can agree with him.

name: Lidia Joanna GERINGER DE OEDENBERG
text: in writing. - Today we decided that the commitment appropriations in 2017 should amount to EUR 160.7 billion, i.e. EUR 4.1 billion more than in the European Commission proposal, while the amount for payment should be EUR 2.5 billion higher, which gives a total of EUR 136.7 billion. Additional funds of EUR 1.5 billion are required to help young people enter the labor market. In addition, funds are needed to support economic growth and to help third countries in connection with the ongoing migration crisis. In this context, we did not agree to any cuts introduced by the European Council. The addition of EUR 1.24 billion to the amount foreseen in the draft budget for the Connecting Europe Facility for infrastructure projects and for the Horizon 2020 program that supports research projects will also contribute to economic growth in the Union. Financing an agreement with Turkey and other ad hoc funds should not be established at cost anymore existing EU external policy. Additional funds will arise from new funds resulting from the ongoing revision of the 2014-2020 multiannual financial framework.

name: Bruno GOLLNISCH
text: in writing. - For years, I have voted against the budget of the European Union, which funds, badly, policies that I do not endorse. Added this year is the bad action against Strasbourg that is "the internalization of the driver service", allegedly for security reasons. I am opposed to this internalization. On the one hand, because, decided by the Bureau, it is done against the will of this Parliament, which had asked in a report of April 2016 that execution be suspended in the absence of additional information. Complement he never had. Then because in fact, it is not open to Strasbourg drivers, as their representatives informed us, even though they are in conflict with their employer without this in any way affecting the services that they give us back. You condemn them cynically to unemployment. Finally, this internalization will be very expensive with a result that is more than uncertain as to the results. We have benefited here for years from the competence of these people. Many are retired, often from the police and the gendarmerie. I am not sure that your new Brussels recruits will offer the same security guarantees. Especially if they come from Molenbeek.

name: Tania GONZÁLEZ PEÑAS
text: written. - I voted against the Budget Resolution because, even though it is a less harsh position than the Commission or, needless to say, that the Council, it still represents 5% cuts. Even though there are aspects that restore items of interest (youth employment initiative, although then it is barely applied by 7% by the Member States), it also does so with other security items, it continues to bet on the problematic Juncker Plan to promote investment , and I do not find a redistributive character in the proposed model.

name: Sylvie GUILLAUME
text: in writing. - The European Union has to face unprecedented challenges: in order to be able to take effective action, it needs a budget which is truly up to the task. Youth unemployment is now at unprecedented levels, so we need more resources so that the Youth Employment Initiative can truly reverse the trend. This 2017 budget must be put into perspective with the next revision of the 2014-2020 multiannual financial framework. This is why I supported this report and more specifically three priorities that the Socialists and Democrats wish to see reinforced: growth and employment (in particular by restoring the cuts made in the budgets of the interconnection mechanism in Europe and the program Horizon 2020), asylum and immigration (by increasing the budgets for Eurocop, Eurojust, EASO, and by restoring the cuts made in development cooperation programs), as well as agriculture (in particular with emergency support to the dairy sector).

name: Sergio GUTIÉRREZ PRIETO
text: written. - We Spanish socialists have voted in favor of the proposal for the 2017 budget in order to tackle unemployment and poverty. With this, we reject all the cuts proposed by the 28 Member States and call for more funds in the fight against youth unemployment and incentives for economic growth.
