Among other measures, we are proposing an additional € 1.5 billion for the Youth Employment Initiative, in order to help unemployed young people, and we are committed to increasing investment in infrastructure and research by € 1.24 billion. With our proposals, this budget reinforces solidarity within the Union (Youth Employment Initiative, child guarantee, support for farmers and ranchers) but also outside our borders. In this sense, the Socialists have obtained the support of the European Parliament to increase the programs of aid to refugees, humanitarian aid, development cooperation and support to the countries around us.

name: András GYÜRK
text: in writing. - It is unfortunate that the EP's report on the EU budget for 2017 refers to the parliamentary report adopted in the July plenary vote, which gave an advance opinion on the revision of the 2014-2020 financial framework. In this, despite the united protests of the People's Party MPs, the MEPs of the Hungarian left-wing parties voted against the interests of the country, attacking all Hungarian citizens with their decision on forced resettlement. MEPs from left-wing parties in Hungary supported the forced resettlement and the harsh financial sanctions of countries that rejected it by a firm and proud vote in the European Parliament. At the same time, the vast majority of Hungarian voters have a clear position: they said no to forced resettlement. Therefore, Fidesz MEPs will only adopt a revision of the financial framework and an EU budget in which these penalties are not even at the level of ideas. are included. As the text of the report on the Council's position on the draft general budget of the European Union for the financial year 2017 refers to the EP report calling for a fine against Member States that did not adopt mandatory quotas in July, I abstained in the final vote on the report.

name: Brian HAYES
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour since I have no objections.

name: Brice HORTEFEUX
text: in writing. - I think we have a proposal that goes in the right direction. In this particularly violent period marked by the succession of crises, it is imperative to have the financial means to respond to them. That is why I have decided to support the European Parliament's position in favor of a budget of 162.4 billion euros in commitment appropriations and 138 billion euros in payments. It is indeed important to take action in two areas: - agriculture for which Parliament has called for an increase of 600 million euros in order to counter the effects of the crisis in the dairy sector and the effects of the Russian embargo on the dairy industry; - security and migration where we approved the Commission proposal to release an envelope of 1.8 billion euros in addition to the amounts initially programmed in 2017. From now on, the level of financing of expenditure linked to migration phenomena reached 5.2 billion euros in total in 2017. Finally, I am delighted that MEPs have also increased the budgets of European agencies which have been particularly stressed since the start of the migration crisis, such as Europol, Eurojust and the European Asylum Support Office .

name: Cătălin Sorin IVAN
text: signed up. - I voted in favor of adopting the general budget of the European Union for the financial year 2017, all sections.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: written. - I voted in favor of the Motion for a European Parliament resolution on the Council position on the draft general budget of the European Union for the financial year 2017, because I believe that the draft budget is ultimately balanced and in line with the Union's main political priorities. I believe that a balance needs to be struck between long-term priorities and new challenges, and that the budget must be based on the principles of transparency, consistency and efficiency and in line with the goals of the Europe 2020 strategy. ensuring territorial and social cohesion, and therefore I think that their reduction is unacceptable. The European Union is facing unforeseen situations and problems, but key European development policies must be preserved. In this context, I support the additional resources earmarked for mitigating the migrant crisis and efforts to boost overall growth and employment.

name: Petr JEŽEK
text: in writing. ‒ I voted for the general budget of the European Union for the financial year 2017 because it states for an ambitious response to current challenges. I support boosting the economic and employment growth by supporting small and medium-sized enterprises and via recovery of funds for the interconnection of Europe and Horizon 2020, the biggest EU Research and Innovation programme. With regard to fight against terrorism, I am also in favour of increasing the support for Europol and the new agency of border guards and European coastguard, two key structures which I believe can make the EU a safer place.

name: Marc JOULAUD
text: in writing. - I voted in favor of the report on the general budget of the European Union for 2017. I particularly welcome the provisions stepping up expenditure in the field of culture. During the financial year for 2017, the budgets of the MEDIA and Culture sub-programs were indeed increased in order to support the promotion of cultural and creative works. On the other hand, I voted against the amendments leading to the internalization of the driver's service in the European Parliament, a measure that is unnecessary and costly for the taxpayer.

name: Philippe JUVIN
text: in writing. - I voted in favor of the draft budget. Members of the Committee on Budgets canceled all the cuts proposed by the Council to the draft budget of the European Union for 2017. The Parliament made this text, which looked more like an accounting tool after reading the Advice that a political act par excellence, a political text which takes into account the evolutions of our Union and the realities experienced by our fellow citizens. By canceling the proposed reductions and proposing commitments on security, employment and even agriculture, Parliament is demonstrating its ability to be in tune with the concerns of European citizens. I also voted against the “single seat” amendment in order to ensure that Parliament's seat in Strasbourg is retained.

name: Barbara KAPPEL
text: written. - Although the resolution on the draft general budget of the European Union for the financial year 2017 states that, in view of scarce resources, greater attention should be paid to compliance with budgetary discipline and funds should be used efficiently and effectively, it is clearly against possible cuts. Overall, the European Parliament wants to achieve a further increase in the EU budget. This is not only to be rejected for reasons of principle, but also in view of ever tighter budget budgets and deficits in the Member States. For these reasons I would have voted against this report.

name: Afzal KHAN
text: in writing. ‒ Labour MEPs voted to oppose an increase in the EU budget for 2017 - we believe the first resort should be finding money for EU priorities within existing budget lines. We remain committed to the principle of prioritising the jobs and economic growth agenda whether inside or outside of the European Union and hope to continue close cooperation with our neighbours as a means of protecting the UK economy.

name: Jeppe KOFOD
text: in writing. Of course, when saving continues in Europe, the EU should not be exempted from this. Therefore, as in previous years, employees and administrative costs continue to be cut across a broad spectrum. We support this approach and maintain that the EU budget should not increase, but that better priority should be given. Therefore, we cannot vote in favor of the draft budget, which entails a significant increase in the EU budgetary framework and includes a number of non-funded measures. Likewise, we do not believe that there is a need for further support for either the foundations, the parties or the groups in the European Parliament, but we do support the close monitoring and review of these funds. We maintain our demand for more transparent rules for auditing the funds made available to members, and emphasize that equal, clear and effective rules must apply. Finally, we emphasize that members and staff should always travel in the overall cheapest way possible. For MEPs, these are typically those cheapest flex tickets for the sake of changing meeting calendars. We support the internalisation of the driving scheme because it will ensure orderly working conditions for the drivers involved, but maintain that it must be cost-neutral overall.

name: Bernd KÖLMEL
text: written. - This resolution of the rapporteurs on the EU budget 2017 contains a number of statements which are not acceptable. Regardless of the tight budgetary situation in a number of EU Member States, all the proposals for cuts made by the Council in relation to the Commission's draft are to be withdrawn. In addition, the appropriations for the commitments are to be increased by more than 4 billion and for the payment appropriations by almost 2 billion euros. The planned distribution takes place primarily according to the watering can principle, regardless of compliance with subsidiarity requirements and without comprehensive monitoring of the success of measures. I also consider the link with the revision of the multiannual financial framework to be inadmissible. It is true that there are also positive approaches such as the fund we are proposing to support victims of terrorism or the increase in funds for Europol to strengthen internal security in Europe. Yet outweigh the negative aspects, which is why I am against this resolution.

name: Kateřina KONEČNÁ
text: in writing. - As every year, we have voted on a report on the Council's position on the draft general budget of the European Union for the new financial year. Even this year, I could not fully agree with the budget presented. This is despite several positive things that have emerged in the Council's position, such as avoiding part of the unconceptual cuts made by the European Commission, more resources for growth, increasing competitiveness and improving the social situation. From the outset, I do not agree with the Commission's attempt to budgetally support support for military research, as this is in gross violation of EU primary law. In my opinion, it is necessary to cut off from the budget all the unnecessary ballast and unnecessary initiatives, which only mean a waste of resources, and focus on issues such as migration and reducing social disparities between Member States, especially the convergence of living standards in western and eastern Member States. . Which, again, was not entirely true. Personally I also support further research activities in the fields of energy and space (ITER, CERN, the ESA budget, Galileo, Copernicus, etc.). From my point of view, a larger financial reserve for extraordinary affairs is also the right step. Given that the current budget is far from ideal, but I see some positive changes in it, I have only decided to abstain in the vote.

name: Béla KOVÁCS
text: in writing. - There are a number of budgetary concerns, on the one hand that the reduction in the original budget appropriations proposed by the Commission will make it difficult to carry out its tasks, and on the other hand that the Union is currently facing a number of major emergencies in 2014-2020. when the multiannual financial framework was drawn up. Nonetheless, the report is largely correct, factual. Incidentally, funding for research and infrastructure projects and the fight against youth unemployment should also be increased if we are to emerge from the negative spiral. Unfortunately, the entrenched neoliberal economic approach is ill-suited to offering real solutions to structural and social challenges.

name: Giovanni LA VIA
text: in writing. - The EU general budget for the year 2017 must be considered in the broad context of the mid-term review of the multiannual financial framework (MFF) and with it the need to ensure a fair balance between ordinary expenditure and the priorities necessary to address the new challenges, not foreseeable at the time of the budgeting. For 2017, we will continue to focus on growth and development, and therefore on job creation, by investing in the strategy objectives set out in Horizon 2020, including research, development and innovation. We will also focus on the competitiveness of our business fabric, on economic, social and territorial cohesion, on support for agriculture, protection of the environment and health, as well as on the safety of our citizens. Increases also seen for policies for managing the migration crisis. In fact, all the lines relating to the agencies that are engaged on the front line have been strengthened in the management of the migratory phenomenon. Our position, approved today, eliminates all the cuts made by the Council and will be the subject of negotiation in the forthcoming negotiations to reach agreement with the Member States on the common position.

name: Gilles LEBRETON
text: in writing. - I voted against this report, because it gives pride of place to the migrant crisis and calls for an increase in financial resources to deal with it.

name: Marine LE PEN
text: in writing. - I voted against the Geier-Tarand report on the general budget of the EU. This report calls for restoring the amounts that the Council planned to reduce on the pretext that the margins left in the council's draft budget would be insufficient to face crises or major challenges (migration crisis, COP21, etc.). Thus, commitment appropriations are set at 161.8 billion euros and payment appropriations at 136.8 billion euros, against 156.4 and 133.8 billion euros respectively in the draft budget of the advice. This report gives pride of place to what is qualified as "new challenges", including the migration crisis, faintly qualified as "the challenge of refugees". This goes hand in hand with a demand for “basic respects” from migrants, and senseless budgeting in times of economic crisis. Finally, an ever more advanced Europeanization of the asylum system is proposed while this prerogative should be solely to competence of the Member States

name: Philippe LOISEAU
text: in writing. - This report concerns the Council's position on the draft general budget of the European Union for the financial year 2017. After having voted the amendments to the draft budget 2017, the BUDG committee voted on the resolution establishing Parliament's position during the negotiations with the Council, which will start on 8 November. He will launch the 3-week conciliation period with the aim of reaching an agreement on the budget and its signature by December. It calls for restoring the amounts that the Council planned to reduce on the pretext that the margins left in the Council's draft budget would be insufficient to deal with crises (in particular migration) or major challenges (COP21 type). It is therefore a very expansionary European budget aimed at financing the reception and then the integration of migrants, but also the federalist whims of the Eurocratic “elites”. Their financing is obviously ensured by a further increase in amounts and not by a redeployment of funds or an effort made on the administrative expenditure of certain institutions or structures. I therefore voted against this report.

name: Sander LOONES
text: written. - The MEPs of the N-VA are strong supporters of spending that provides a response to the migration and security crisis, but note that there is insufficient emphasis on this in the 2017 budget. Less than 9% of the EU budget will be spent in 2017 on measures to strengthen security and asylum policy. That is why the N-VA delegation has also made proposals to increase resources for Europol and Frontex, the European Border and Coast Guard. Furthermore, the MEPs of the N-VA have a lot of reservations about the unnecessary and money-consuming matters that Europe does focus on, such as the new House of European History, its own limousine service and the refusal of the traditional groups to cut costs and travel allowances for MEPs. In times when serious efforts are required of European citizens and Member States, traditional political groups want to increase the EU budget by 2017 more than four billion euros. Before proceeding to new expenditures, it should first be considered in which areas savings can be made. It is high time for the EU to focus on the policy areas where it has clear added value.

name: Javi LÓPEZ
text: written. - We Spanish socialists have voted in favor of the proposal for the 2017 budget in order to tackle unemployment and poverty. With this, we reject all the cuts proposed by the 28 Member States and call for more funds in the fight against youth unemployment and incentives for economic growth. Among other measures, we are proposing an additional € 1.5 billion for the Youth Employment Initiative, in order to help unemployed young people, and we are committed to increasing investment in infrastructure and research by € 1.24 billion. With our proposals, this budget reinforces solidarity within the Union (Youth Employment Initiative, child guarantee, support for farmers and ranchers) but also outside our borders. In this sense, the Socialists have obtained the support of the European Parliament to increase the programs of aid to refugees, humanitarian aid, development cooperation and support to the countries around us.

name: Juan Fernando LÓPEZ AGUILAR
text: written. - We Spanish socialists have voted in favor of the proposal for the 2017 budget in order to tackle unemployment and poverty. With this, we reject all the cuts proposed by the 28 Member States and call for more funds in the fight against youth unemployment and incentives for economic growth. Among other measures, we are proposing an additional € 1.5 billion for the Youth Employment Initiative, in order to help unemployed young people, and we are committed to increasing investment in infrastructure and research by € 1.24 billion. With our proposals, this budget reinforces solidarity within the Union (Youth Employment Initiative, child guarantee, support for farmers and ranchers) but also outside our borders. In this sense, the Socialists have obtained the support of the European Parliament to increase the programs of aid to refugees, humanitarian aid, development cooperation and support to the countries around us.

name: Bernd LUCKE
text: written. - This resolution of the rapporteurs on the EU budget 2017 contains a number of statements which are not acceptable. Regardless of the tight budgetary situation in a number of EU Member States, all the proposals for cuts made by the Council in relation to the Commission's draft are to be withdrawn. In addition, the appropriations for the commitments are to be increased by more than 4 billion and for the payment appropriations by almost 2 billion euros. The planned distribution takes place primarily according to the watering can principle, regardless of compliance with subsidiarity requirements and without comprehensive monitoring of the success of measures. I also consider the link with the revision of the multiannual financial framework to be inadmissible. It is true that there are also positive approaches such as the fund we are proposing to support victims of terrorism or the increase in funds for Europol to strengthen internal security in Europe. Yet outweigh the negative aspects, which is why I am against this resolution.

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: in writing. ‒ I support the 2017 budget which sets outs the Parliament’s main priorities for the coming year. I did not support amendment 3 as there are no coupled payments for bulls in Spain.

name: Petr MACH
text: in writing. - I voted against. I voted first in favor of amendments that would reduce the salaries and allowances of MEPs, then those that would reduce the expenditure on EU self-promotion, etc. These amendments did not pass. On the contrary, I voted against the many additional expenditures that have been made. The spending program "Spreading EU values through music" amounting to 1.2 million has been introduced. EUR 6 million went to the Olympic Games in Austria. The staff of the Institute of Gender Equality was increased. Overall, I consider the vast majority of the EU budget of 160 billion to be wasted.

name: Ivana MALETIĆ
text: written. - The draft budget of the European Union for 2017 shows how the budget can and must be flexible. Although resources are limited and there is not much room for new initiatives, solutions have been found to significantly accelerate investment in preventing the causes of the migrant crisis, and payment limits have been increased by as much as 25.1 percent compared to 2016. Contracting amounts have also increased. payments for Erasmus +, COSME, the new European Fund for Strategic Investments and other competitiveness instruments to accelerate growth and increase youth employment. Because of all of the above, I supported this report.

name: Andrejs MAMIKINS
text: in writing. ‒ The EU needs to meet the needs of the migration and address the refugee challenge and slow economic growth as well as investment in research and fighting youth unemployment. For this purpose we must restore all cuts proposed by the Council to the draft budget.

name: Vladimír MAŇKA
text: in writing. - Due to a number of new crises in recent years, in particular the migration and refugee crisis, the crisis in agriculture - especially in the dairy sector, and the crisis due to the Russian embargo, European Fund for Strategic Investments (EFSI) and persistently high unemployment, especially among young people. people, the current budget is not enough to address and meet the EU's strategic objectives, which have been endorsed by all governments and the European Parliament. That is why I support compensating for all the cuts related to the European Fund for Strategic Investments (EFSI) under the Connecting Europe Facility (CEF) and Horizon 2020 for a total of EUR 1 240 million in commitments for 2017 through new appropriations to be obtained thanks to mid-term review of the multiannual financial framework. I also insist on the need to ensure an effective response to youth unemployment in the Union. Especially since the results of this project so far have been extremely successful. That is why we are increasing the funding for the Youth Employment Initiative by an additional EUR 1 500 million in commitment appropriations so that it can be continued.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: in writing. - I am voting against the report on the Council's position on the draft general budget of the European Union for the financial year 2017, for the reasons I set out in detail in my speech at the Plenary Session of the European Parliament in Strasbourg on 25 October 2016, and because the this report is not complete and substantiated.

name: Dominique MARTIN
text: in writing. - I voted against this text. The draft budget does indeed seem insufficient in view of the challenges facing the European Union. Expenditure is increasingly oriented towards increased commitments for areas that are not within the competence of the European Union, such as the right of asylum and common defense. In addition, the desire to promote migration and a forced march towards federalism is reaffirmed in this budget.

name: Marisa MATIAS
text: in writing. - This report refers to the Council's position on the draft general budget of the European Union for the financial year 2017, underlining that that draft fully reflects the political priorities adopted by an overwhelming majority. However, it expresses that "new priorities must not undermine existing priorities", in particular with regard to growth and job creation, which are in most cases precarious. The report also states that, in the current context, initiatives such as the suspension of the European Commission's ESI funds are not only unfair and disproportionate, but also politically unsustainable. However, the EP's position restores all the cuts made by the Council and, in some, very few points, exceeds the Commission's position, falling short of the cuts that had already been introduced by the Commission itself in its draft BUDG amendment. In fact, this report, despite presenting some positive aspects, focuses on in political options that do not contribute to the strengthening of cohesion and equality in the European space. On the contrary, it increases investment in areas that reinforce the security logic and Europe Fortaleza. Due to the contradictions present in the final proposal, I chose to abstain.

name: Gabriel MATO
text: written. - I vote in favor of the motion for a European Parliament resolution on the Council's position on the draft general budget of the Union for the financial year 2017, reiterating that the Union's accounts must find ways to finance new initiatives that do not harm the existing programs and policies, among other objectives. In addition, it is particularly relevant that cuts from the European Fund for Strategic Investments (EFSI) in the Connecting Europe Facility and Horizon 2020 are compensated for a total amount of € 1.24 billion. I hope that the Council shares the approach of the European Parliament's motion for a resolution.

name: Emmanuel MAUREL
text: in writing. - The Parliament is co-legislator, with the States, of the budget of the European Union. The position of the European Parliament is therefore a strategic moment in the preparation of major budgetary choices and in the action strategies of the European Commission. In this regard, the 2017 budget was drawn up in close connection with the resolution on the mid-term review of the Multiannual Financial Framework, on which it is dependent. The European Parliament retains its realistic ambition in the budgetary field. He also recalls that the Union's missions cannot do without a concrete commitment in terms of appropriations and, in this perspective, the budget lines have been reinforced for three priorities, which I share: youth, growth and employment: for the youth employment initiative; to compensate for cuts made in research and transport programs which had been transferred to the Juncker Plan; and for key programs such as COSME, Progress, Erasmus +; migration, asylum and security: increased budgets for EU agencies; compensation for cuts in cooperation and development budgets; agriculture: with 600 million in emergency support for the dairy sector. I voted in favor of this balanced report.

name: Georg MAYER
text: written. - I firmly reject any further increase in the EU budget. The resources made available by the Member States must be used more efficiently. That is why I have rejected this general budget.

name: Valentinas MAZURONIS
text: in writing. - I supported the European Parliament's position on next year's EU budget. This heading provides for increased funding for youth employment and economic stimulus, as well as support for third countries facing migration challenges. The European Parliament also calls on the Council to provide additional support for farmers, culture and migration. Following the adoption of the resolution, the 21st interinstitutional negotiations on 2017 will begin. Approval of the EU budget.

name: Jean-Luc MÉLENCHON
text: in writing. - This report on the draft EU budget for 2017 essentially aligns with the proposal made by the European Commission and criticizes the additional cuts proposed by the Council. I regret that Parliament has no ambition of its own to pull the EU out of the slump of budgetary austerity, because the Commission's proposal is notoriously insufficient in view of the social and ecological emergencies facing the EU; it does not even make it possible to honor the commitments already made by the EU, in particular under structural funds but also financing against climate change. Payment appropriations would thus be down by 7% in 2017. Yet the EU has still not finished paying the bills for the 2007-2013 programming of the structural funds! These unpaid debts will still not be cleared at the end of 2016. And as the payment appropriations continue to be under calibrated, further delays are encountered in the implementation of the programs. 2014-2020 to the detriment of all sectors affected by European funding. I am voting against this resolution, which confirms Parliament's distance from the needs of the people.

name: Joëlle MÉLIN
text: in writing. - This report concerns the Council's position on the draft general budget of the European Union for the financial year 2017. After having voted for the amendments to the draft budget 2017, the BUDG committee voted on the resolution establishing the position of the parliament during the negotiations with the Council, which will start on 8 November. It will launch the three-week conciliation period with the aim of reaching an agreement on the budget and its signature by December. He calls for restoring the amounts that the Council was planning to reduce on the pretext that the margins left in the Council's draft budget would be insufficient to cope with crises (especially migration) or major challenges (COP21 type). It is therefore a very expansionary European budget aimed at financing the reception and then the integration of migrants, but also the federalist whims of the Eurocratic “elites”. Their financing is obviously ensured by a further increase in amounts and not by a redeployment of funds or an effort made on the administrative expenditure of certain institutions or structures. I therefore voted against this report.

name: Nuno MELO
text: in writing. - The 2017 budget must be in line with the objectives of the Europe 2020 strategy, which represents its main orientation and its overall priority. In a situation of scarcity of resources, greater importance must be attached to the need to respect budgetary discipline and to use financial resources efficiently and effectively. I think that is what this budget does, hence my vote in favor.

name: Roberta METSOLA
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report on the Draft general budget for 2017 as more funds are needed to tackle the migration crisis and to support the Union’s youth that are often over-represented in the number of unemployed.

name: Louis MICHEL
text: in writing. - I voted for a significant increase in the appropriations of the 2017 budget in order to face the challenges and priorities of the EU, in particular in terms of migration (the migrant crisis and its root causes), economic growth, investments, employment (of young people) and the fight against terrorism by giving Europol more financial resources, etc. This means that the 2017 EU budget would amount to € 160.7 billion in commitments, an increase of € 4.1 billion compared to the Commission's draft budget and to € 136.7 billion euros in authorization / payments, or an increase of 2.5 billion euros compared to the Commission budget. This budget, which reflects the Union's needs to face up to its responsibilities and take credible action, will have to be agreed during the conciliation procedure with the Council for November 17, 2016.

name: Miroslav MIKOLÁŠIK
text: in writing. - The EU budget for 2017 needs to be seen in the context of the revision of the Multiannual Financial Framework, which was created for the period 2014-2020, and is currently in the middle of this period. It must be agreed in line with the objectives of the 2020 strategy, which is its central priority, and it will need to strike a balance between long-term goals and new challenges. The total appropriations for 2017 amount to EUR 161.8 billion in commitment appropriations and EUR 136.8 billion in payment appropriations. The main areas are competitiveness for growth and employment, economic, social and territorial cohesion, sustainable growth and natural resources, security and citizenship, global Europe and administration. However, the Union is currently facing a number of new challenges and threats that were not foreseen at the time of the establishment of the financial framework until 2020, so more financial resources need to be allocated from the Union budget to address policy challenges with to enable the Union to act and respond effectively to these crises. We are talking about the challenges of migration, the slow growth of the economy, which is recovering from the financial crisis, but also other facts. By ratifying COP 21, the Union has made certain international commitments, compliance with which requires a certain financial envelope.

name: Marlene MIZZI
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted in favour of the report, which recognises the need for a higher budget allocation to be able to tackle new realities. An example of realities which require further financing are the current refugee and migratory challenges while continuing with the support of sustainable development goals and the funding for victims of terrorism amongst others.

name: Sophie MONTEL
text: in writing. - This text aims at an unreasonable increase in the European budget. All the criticisms which could be made vis-à-vis the draft budget remain moreover entirely valid. I therefore vote against this text.

name: Claude MORAES
text: in writing. ‒ Labour MEPs voted today to oppose an increase in the EU budget for 2017 – we believe the first resort should be finding money for EU priorities within existing budget lines. We remain committed to the principle of prioritising the jobs and economic growth agenda whether inside or outside of the European Union and hope to continue close cooperation with our neighbours as a means of protecting the UK economy. The UK’s contribution to the EU budget may be set to increase as a result of the fall in the value of sterling, down nearly a fifth since the referendum, due to the uncertainty caused by Brexit and the chaotic handling of the aftermath by the UK Government, particularly on the question of whether we will remain a member of the Single Market. Labour MEPs will continue to fight to protect our constituents and the UK from any unfavourable deal and work with Labour MPs to ensure crucial areas of EU investment are replaced when we become ineligible for European Union funding post-Brexit.’

name: Nadine MORANO
text: in writing. - I voted in favor of the 2017 budget of the European Union. This budget will amount to 162.4 billion euros in commitment authorizations and 138 billion euros in payment appropriations. I particularly welcome the amount allocated to youth employment, which is 1.5 billion euros, but also the 15 million increase in the ERASMUS budget. The additional envelope of 1.8 billion euros, in particular with the aim of increasing the budgets and staff allocated to Frontex, is also a considerable step forward in the current context of the need for external border control. However, it will be necessary to wait until the end of the conciliation phase with the council for the final budget to be adopted.

name: Luigi MORGANO
text: in writing. - Europe today faces many challenges. Given the difficulties, it becomes more important to maintain continuous and substantial investments in the fields of education, vocational training and youth. Therefore I am very satisfied with the text passed today by Parliament, obviously also for the amendments proposed by me and adopted by the Committee on Culture and Education which increase funds for Erasmus +, Creative Europe and Europe for Citizens. Funds essential to support European policies on employment, youth, culture and creativity, social inclusion and democratic participation. If we want to pursue an awakening of the true European spirit, especially among young people, we must choose appropriate policies for all citizens of all Member States. The budget is an integral part of EU policies: if we want to regain the trust of citizens, Europe must go back to making Europe, not being confined to small national selfishness. This applies to common policies, to national contributions to the EU budget and to program implementation.

name: József NAGY
text: in writing. - The European Union's budget for 2017 is closely linked to the multiannual financial framework. After a thorough examination of the objectives and priorities, we have mapped out the financial means needed to meet them, which will be available to us next year. The report mentions one by one the areas where more important programs are being implemented. I am satisfied with the budget and I am confident that as many EU citizens as possible will take advantage of the opportunities it offers.

name: Victor NEGRESCU
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted in favor of the Draft general budget of the European Union for 2017 that will ensure balance between long-term priorities and new challenges while in line with the EU2020 targets which represents the main priority of the budget.

name: Norica NICOLAI
text: signed up. - I voted in favor of this report, as it emphasizes both the importance of building a budget for 2017 in line with the revision of the 2014-2020 multiannual financial framework and the need for funds allocated to new challenges not to undermine the EU's initial commitments and objectives. I believe that it is essential that investments and allocations continue for projects that support the economic development of the Member States and the creation of quality jobs and that encourage young people to develop new successful businesses. The European Union has set important goals through the Europe 2020 Strategy, and they must remain a priority in terms of funding in the years to come, despite all the challenges we face.

name: Franz OBERMAYR
text: written. - I spoke out against this report, as a further increase in the EU budget is called for. In view of the increasingly tight budgets and deficits in the Member States, I believe that this report should be rejected.

name: Urmas PAET
text: in writing. - I supported. The general budget for next year has been worked out by the parliamentary committees. The resolution points out that the EU's budget must take into account both the Union's long-term priorities and be prepared to finance unforeseen problems. The budget covers economic and social affairs, security and citizenship sub-themes, pilot projects and preparatory actions, as well as the budgets of the EU institutions.

name: Kostas PAPADAKIS
text: in writing. - Once again, the same mischievous farce is being repeated to disorient the peoples in relation to the size of the EU budget, with a certain conclusion, as always: the agreement on the redistribution of the wealth produced by the people into monopolies, through the Community budget. All the political groups are moving in the direction of supporting the groups with EU money from the budget. In the same vein, the Draft Budget calls for more money for the Juncker Fund and the "cohesion funds" funded by business groups, as well as for Horizon 2020 (Business Research - Innovation) and Connecting Europe »(Infrastructure networks), which are oriented towards new profitable projects for the capital. Increase additional funds for Europol, the creation of a "counter-terrorism unit", the "European Counter-Terrorism Center", defense research funds and the EU External Action Service. At the same time, increased funding is provided for the anti-communist program "Europe for citizens". In short: more money in monopolies, more funding for the complex imperialist aggression of EU monopolies at the expense of the people.

name: Margot PARKER
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted against this non-legislative and non-binding motion for a resolution. The resolution called for the cuts proposed by the Council to be reversed and more resources be given to the EU budget. UKIP voted for amendments which called for cuts to the EU budget, opposed development of an EU military capability and also voted in favour of an amendment which said that no EU funding should go to bullfighting. The EFDD Group (which UKIP is part of) also tabled an amendment which, among other things, called for a reduction in the salaries, allowances and travel expenses of MEPs. However this part of the amendment was ruled ‘inadmissible’ by the President of the European Parliament.

name: Aldo PATRICIELLO
text: in writing. - I believe that the 2017 budget fully reflects the political priorities approved by the majority and that it is consistent with the objectives that the European institutions intend to pursue. Therefore, I voted in favor.

name: Marijana PETIR
text: written. - I support this Resolution and commend the support of as much as EUR 500 million to the European dairy sector and funds of EUR 100 million intended for those farmers affected by the Russian embargo. Since I come from Croatia, a country where unemployment is a big problem, I can also say that I am especially glad that according to this draft, the Youth Employment Initiative continues at the same level as it was planned, because young people in Croatia with praise talk about this initiative. I am glad that all cuts related to Horizon 2020 have been returned to the basic guidelines of the Budget, and I am especially pleased with the agreed increase for some programs such as Erasmus or COSME, which should be very important for our small and medium enterprises.

name: Florian PHILIPPOT
text: in writing. - This is a very expansionist European budget aiming to finance the Euro-immigrationist whims of the European deputies but also the forced federalization of the main features of sovereignty such as defense or asylum. Their financing is ensured by a further increase in amounts and not by a redeployment of appropriations or an effort made on the administrative expenses of certain institutions of more than doubtful utility. Once again, we are therefore going to make the French pay more on the grounds of making more Europe when they want less and wish to regain democratic control of their destiny. I am obviously voting against this budget.

name: Pina PICIERNO
text: in writing. - The budget for 2017, as reiterated several times in our discussions, will have to be linked to the revision of the multiannual financial framework. It is a condition that Parliament does not want to give up for the simple reason that the challenges of the EU continue to increase but we insist on addressing them with current inadequate funding. Migration flows, youth employment and the development of the neighboring countries are issues to be addressed with the highest priority, priority which must be translated into substantial allocations because these problems can only be solved at European level. The reading of the budget that we approved today goes in this direction and we are confident that the Council too will be able to follow up with concrete facts, that is, by making sufficient resources available. As we repeat every year, cutting the European budget does not mean cutting bureaucracy, on which, however, we could certainly save, but it does say cut investments. Real investments that benefit businesses, local administrations, universities, students, farmers, NGOs. I therefore naturally voted in favor of the budget and this resolution and I hope that the conciliation will lead to confirmation of these right choices in favor of European citizens.

name: João PIMENTA LOPES
text: in writing. - We are in the presence, once again, of a budget that is completely out of step with the reality and real needs of the European Union. In a European Union in deep crisis, increasingly unequal, where high levels of poverty and unemployment persist, we have a short budget, deeply shaken in its distributive strand and increasingly tied to the aggressive and militaristic course of European Union foreign policy. It is therefore important to reinforce this budget, but this is not enough. It is necessary to put this budget at the service of development and social and territorial cohesion and to reinforce the special instruments designed, it must be said, to remedy the errors of our foreign policy that are at the root of the Russian embargo or the refugee crisis. Unfortunately, this proposal does not point in this direction. Rather, it follows on from previous budgets, all of which are conditioned by a short multiannual framework and at the service of EU neoliberal policies. and its insurance drift.

name: Tomasz Piotr PORĘBA
text: in writing. - On September 28, the Committee on Budgets voted on 2,221 amendments to the Council's position on the EU budget for 2017. As a result of the vote, the net increase compared to the Commission proposal will be 4.07 billion euro. The proposal includes EUR 160.6 billion in commitment appropriations and EUR 136.7 billion in payments. The 2017 draft resolution on the EU budget is the political position of the European Parliament ahead of the annual budgetary negotiations with the Commission and the Council. In addition to undoing all Council cuts, in the Commission's estimate, the most significant changes include EUR 1.5 billion for the Youth Employment Initiative, EUR 600 million to support the dairy sector and an additional EUR 1.24 billion to compensate ESIF through cuts in Horizon 2020. and in the Connecting Europe Facility. However, these changes leave no room for maneuver in the event of unforeseen events in 2017, and your rapporteur therefore proposes to increase the spending limits by providing "new resources" in the context of the review of the multiannual financial framework. I voted in favor of the report.

name: Jiří POSPÍŠIL
text: in writing. - I cannot vote in favor of this report, for several reasons. I have no reservations about most of the proposed budgetary measures, but I do not support the passage that proposes the creation of a new separate EU revenue. I see the possibility of introducing a new European tax behind this proposal, and that does not have my support. It would not be economically beneficial and would reduce the support of the citizens of the European Union. We already have enough taxes in the Member States.

name: Paulo RANGEL
text: in writing. - The 2017 budget must respond to the needs linked to the current challenges of the European Union, while respecting the forecasts and responsibilities assumed in previous years. I support the increase in appropriations in the area of migration, security and sustainable growth, as well as I strongly support the financing of programs such as the youth employment initiative, in which the previously registered values remain. I consider it important to increase the amount allocated to agencies that improve efficiency in the field of justice and home affairs, in particular those dealing with migration and security; I stress that these agencies must have sufficient resources (including for investment in new technologies) and personnel. The values attributed to cohesion policy seem to me to be adequate since economic, social and territorial cohesion is essential to reduce disparities between the different regions of the EU, as is important for the implementation of the Europe 2020 strategy for smart, sustainable and inclusive growth. For the above, I support this report.

name: Julia REID
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted against this non-legislative and non-binding motion for a resolution. The resolution called for the cuts proposed by the Council to be reversed and more resources be given to the EU budget. UKIP voted for amendments which called for cuts to the EU budget, opposed development of an EU military capability and also voted in favour of an amendment which said that no EU funding should go to bullfighting. The EFDD Group (which UKIP is part of) also tabled an amendment which, among other things, called for a reduction in the salaries, allowances and travel expenses of MEPs. However this part of the amendment was ruled ‘inadmissible’ by the President of the European Parliament.

name: Christine REVAULT D'ALLONNES BONNEFOY
text: in writing. - At the sitting of October 26, 2016, I voted in favor of the European Parliament's proposal on the 2017 budget of the European Union. In its proposal, Parliament calls for a budget that responds to the many challenges facing the Union, in particular to deal with the refugee crisis, strengthen the means to boost employment and investment and support young people. With this in mind, I voted to reject the cuts proposed by the Council and increase the budget ceilings thanks to the revision of the European Union's multiannual financial framework (MFF). Parliament is therefore in favor of a budget in 2017 which amounts to 160.7 billion euros. In this context, I would like to raise funds to strengthen the youth guarantee and the Union's support for young people. Finally, I voted for the restoration of the budgets of the mechanism for interconnection in Europe (which finances infrastructure projects in transport) and Horizon 2020 (which supports research projects) which have been cut to finance the Juncker Plan. Parliament must now find an agreement with the Council and with the S&D Group; we will have to be vigilant in order to adopt a budget that meets the challenges of the Union.

name: Sofia RIBEIRO
text: in writing. - I voted in favor, recognizing that the Union is currently facing a series of serious emergencies and new challenges that could not be foreseen at the time of drawing up the 2014-2020 Multiannual Financial Framework. More financial resources must be mobilized in the Union budget to rise to the political challenges and allow the Union to deliver results and respond effectively to these crises, with priority and high urgency. The 2017 budget must respond to the needs associated with the challenge of migration and the slowdown in growth following the economic crisis, the fight against the crisis in agriculture, and there is also a need to strengthen funding for research and infrastructure projects, as well as for the combating youth unemployment. I recall that around one third of the Union's annual budget is destined for economic, social and territorial cohesion and that cohesion policy is the Union's main investment policy and the main instrument for reducing disparities between all regions of the EU, playing an important role in implementing the Europe 2020 strategy for smart, sustainable and inclusive growth.

name: Inma RODRÍGUEZ-PIÑERO
text: written. - We Spanish socialists have voted in favor of the proposal for the 2017 budget in order to tackle unemployment and poverty. With this, we reject all the cuts proposed by the 28 Member States and call for more funds in the fight against youth unemployment and incentives for economic growth. Among other measures, we are proposing an additional € 1.5 billion for the Youth Employment Initiative, in order to help unemployed young people, and we are committed to increasing investment in infrastructure and research by € 1.24 billion. With our proposals, this budget reinforces solidarity within the Union (Youth Employment Initiative, child guarantee, support for farmers and ranchers) but also outside our borders. In this sense, the Socialists have obtained the support of the European Parliament to increase the programs of aid to refugees, humanitarian aid, development cooperation and support to the countries around us.

name: Fernando RUAS
text: in writing. - As Jean-Claude Juncker recently said in his State of the Union address, the 2017 EU draft general budget should be living proof of financial solidarity, focusing on those that are its main priorities - growth, employment, security and migration - and also ensuring greater flexibility and less bureaucracy. The OE 2017 thus has an additional task, which is to restore confidence, by recovering the enormous delay in payments, that is, in the execution of the multiannual financial framework. The mid-term review should therefore be reflected in this Community budget, so as not to waste time or money. Unfortunately, the Council intends to cut the Commission's proposed figures by EUR 1.28 billion in commitments and EUR 1.1 billion in payments, thereby weakening the EU's instruments for responding to the economic and refugee crisis. I therefore hope that the process of The following conciliation serves to reach an understanding, since we are facing a budget that favors the resolution of the current challenges, without compromising the future of the EU.

name: Tokia SAÏFI
text: in writing. - I voted in favor of this report on the 2017 budget which rejects all the budget cuts proposed by the Council, gives more leeway to respond to current challenges and maintains the priorities to be pursued. I supported this text because it provides for an adequate level of funding for dealing with the refugee crisis, both internally and externally. The Union will have the means to stem the root causes of this crisis by canceling the cuts planned by the Council for the neighborhood, development cooperation and humanitarian aid. It is important to underline that this 2017 budget foresees an increase in the amounts allocated for agencies with security-related tasks such as Europol and Eurojust. This budget allows the Union to pursue its efforts to promote employment and competitiveness with the increase in funding allocated to Horizon 2020 programs, to the investment fund, to the COSME for SMEs, Erasmus + or the youth employment initiative. This budget does not forget to respond to the agricultural crisis and thus proposes to mobilize an additional 600 million euros in favor of farmers, in particular those affected by the Russian embargo.

name: Lola SÁNCHEZ CALDENTEY
text: written. - I voted against the Budget Resolution because, even though it is a less harsh position than the Commission or, needless to say, that the Council, it still represents 5% cuts. Even though there are aspects that restore items of interest (youth employment initiative, although then it is barely applied by 7% by the Member States), it also does so with other security items, it continues to bet on the problematic Juncker Plan to promote investment , and I do not find a redistributive character in the proposed model.

name: Maria Lidia SENRA RODRÍGUEZ
text: written. - The resolution of the European Parliament emphasizes the need to reinforce the European budget and provide it with greater content in the social and ecological sphere, without questioning its neoliberal drift. Although I agree with these reforms, I consider them insufficient and have finally decided to abstain.

name: Siôn SIMON
text: in writing. ‒ Today I voted to oppose an increase in the EU budget for 2017 as I believe that the first resort should be finding money for EU priorities within existing budget lines.

name: Branislav ŠKRIPEK
text: in writing. - In the case of the legislative resolution on all sections of the EU budget for 2017, I voted against this resolution in line with the EQF's position. First of all, I do not agree with the use of budgets to support the financing of LGBTI activities. Also, in line with my colleagues in the group, I argue that instead of increasing the budget by increasing Member States' contributions and revising the MFF, we should respond to the new budgetary needs by increasing efficiency in the use of initially available funds.

name: Monika SMOLKOVÁ
text: in writing. - We see the 2017 budget in the context of the mid-term review of the Multiannual Financial Framework 2014-2020, as the EU faces new challenges related to the migration and refugee crisis, but also to agricultural problems, youth unemployment and the EU's internal and external security. . The budget sets the total appropriations for 2017 at EUR 161.8 billion in commitment appropriations and EUR 136.8 billion in payment appropriations. Roughly one third of the EU budget is focused on economic, social and territorial cohesion, with cohesion policy being the main investment policy and EU instrument for reducing disparities between all EU regions. Therefore, the EP disagreed with the reductions proposed by the Council of EUR 3 million in commitments and EUR 199 million in payments. As an EP, we have also expressed our concern at the significant delays in implementing the cycle of European structural and investment funds, which will have an adverse effect on the achievement of results in practice and will lead to the re-creation of a significant new number of outstanding invoices in the second half of the MFF. In the tripartite negotiations, we expect both the Council and the Commission to take positive action. I supported the draft budget in the final vote, even though many of the amendments were not passed, but the budget will still be adjusted in the next tripartite negotiations.

name: Michaela ŠOJDROVÁ
text: in writing. - I voted in favor of the draft budget of the European Union for 2017. According to our proposal, the total budget of the European Parliament for 2017 will be approximately 1.2% of the EU budget. It could be even less if Parliament did not have to move to Strasbourg for a week every month, which I have been fighting for for a long time. I have a positive view of the call for an increase in the Erasmus plus budget, which I am addressing as Vice-Chair of the CULT Committee. I firmly believe that further support for the Erasmus plus program will result in increased mobility for pupils and teachers between EU Member States. This program should continue to improve opportunities for foreign language teaching, for sharing examples of good practice and for building partnerships between schools. Its extension should also give more scope for the use of activities prepared by youth organizations and the European Voluntary Service. Given the current security situation, I also very much welcome the fact that the EU budget for 2017 devotes a significantly larger share of funds to security, to support security institutions such as EUROPOL, which not only help to address the migration and refugee crisis, but also fight terrorism.

name: Igor ŠOLTES
text: in writing. - The priorities of the 2017 budget include employment, growth and investment, a European response to the challenges of migration, and the management of the fight against terrorism and organized crime. In line with the European Roadmap for Security and Migration, the EU budget will continue to support Member States in their management of migratory flows, the protection of the EU's external borders and the integrity of the Schengen area, while coordinating in partnership with border regions and third countries. In addition to these priorities, the budget contains items that represent progress for an integrated digital single market, a flexible energy union, a deeper and fairer internal market, and the further development of economic and monetary union. The budget provides funding for a reasonable and balanced free trade agreement with the US and more funding for the EU in the field of external relations. The European Parliament should increase the budget, especially in the field of environmental policies and to combat climate change. Important shifts should also take place in the area of European economic recovery and the creation of sustainable jobs. This year's budget also takes into account the already mentioned environmental aspect, so I decided to support it.

name: Jaromír ŠTĚTINA
text: in writing. - I supported the EP resolution on the draft EU budget for 2017. I am pleased that the text has succeeded in pushing for a significant increase in funding for the European agencies Europol, Eurojust, EASO and others. Among other things, these agencies are working hard to improve the EU-wide security situation and are making a significant contribution to resolving and managing the current migration crisis. For example, this year Europol launched a new counter-terrorism center, made a significant contribution to improving the exchange of information between Member States and continues to form the Union's basis for much-needed cooperation between Member States. I also support an increase in funding for the Erasmus plus program. The program, which contributes to deepening European integration and creating a common European culture and identity, is one of the most beneficial initiatives in today's Europe full of populism and xenophobia. I was also very happy to express my support for the new initiative of the European People's Group 'Interrail'. It is a project in which EU citizens would receive their 18th birthday monthly rail ticket throughout the EU. I would also like to recall my support for the idea of a single EP seat. I therefore supported this point in the resolution, but at the same time I am aware that it is not up to the EP to provide assistance in this matter. The agreement of the Member States is needed to change this established practice. Members may express their disagreement with the two seats only in the form of a non-binding initiative.

name: Beatrix von STORCH
text: written. - I did not agree to the resolution of the EU Parliament on the “Council position on the draft general budget of the European Union for the financial year 2017”. The budget is guided by the idea that the 2017 budget needs to be seen in the larger context, particularly in the context of the current new challenges (migration) and the objectives of the Europe 2020 strategy. These goals serve to soften, which alone justifies the rejection. A large number of specific projects ensure that the budget is to be rejected: the costs internalized in the budget for allegedly man-made climate change, the EFSI, youth unemployment programs at EU level or a facility for refugees in Turkey are just particularly striking examples.

name: Dubravka ŠUICA
text: written. - The political priorities of the European Union budget for 2017 are focused on maintaining peace and stability, the fight against terrorism, humanitarian aid and resolving the refugee and migrant crisis. However, the instruments for creating jobs and investing in the future of young people must not be neglected. The most important investments of the European Union should continue to be in the field of cohesion and development policy. The importance of implementing measures to achieve gender equality and investing in environmental policy is also emphasized, especially after the ratification of the Paris Agreement. Parliament therefore sets the overall level of appropriations for 2017 at EUR 161.8 billion for commitment appropriations and EUR 136.8 billion for payment appropriations. I support this report as the most important step in addressing the current challenges of the European Union and with a view to greater development and a better future for European citizens.

name: Patricija ŠULIN
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of the report on the Council position on the draft general budget of the European Union for the financial year 2017. We have a draft budget which, despite limited resources, covers all political priorities in a balanced way and ensures synergies between different areas.The first priority is to invest in jobs through the EFSI, and the second is to tackle the migrant crisis and ensure security, such as € 7.5 million in additional funding for Europol and a € 25 million pilot project to improve defense research capabilities and cooperation between members..And thirdly, more knowledge resources in Horizon 2020 to make the EU innovative and competitive in the long run.We therefore have a draft budget for the challenges of the present and the future.

name: Eleftherios SYNADINOS
text: in writing.- The Union budget must take into account current challenges and threats and address them.At the same time, to promote policies that lead to decent work, sustainable development and to ensure a balance between the financially sound and the corresponding weak economies of the Member States.Its main concern must be the well-being of the citizens of all the Member States.

name: Tibor SZANYI
text: in writing. - I voted in favor of the report on the draft general budget of the European Union for the financial year 2017, as I find it doubtful that the ceiling of heading 4 (Global Europe) would be sufficient to adequately fund the external dimension of asylum and migration challenges. I agree with the report's view that EU-wide contingencies should be addressed by pooling resources and providing additional resources, rather than questioning past commitments or returning to purely national solutions. I also welcome the fact that the 2017 budget is in line with the Europe 2020 strategy, and I also urge that additional funding for the fight against youth unemployment be secured in any case. However, like the rapporteur, I regret that the Council has in many cases reduced the budget line for a key issue: the proposed cuts in the areas of culture, media, citizenship, fundamental rights and public health are particularly damaging in the current circumstances. I therefore support restoring the level of these appropriations in the draft budget.

name: Marc TARABELLA
text: in writing.- I voted for the proposal of my colleague Indrek Tarand.Of course, I voted on several amendments and do not agree on every point.I voted for the single seat.The review of the 2017 budget should also be placed in the broader context of the mid-term review of the multiannual financial framework.We stress the need to ensure a balance between long-term priorities and new challenges, and therefore stress that the 2017 budget must be in line with the objectives of the Europe 2020 strategy, which represents its main orientation and general priority.

name: Isabelle THOMAS
text: in writing. - Combating youth unemployment, welcoming migrants, supporting research, helping to deal with the dairy crisis, these are the European priorities in 2017. Europe must therefore devote sufficient resources to respond to them. The European Parliament's plan for the 2017 EU budget is coherent in precisely providing for an increase in the programs that address these challenges. It is also ambitious since it plans to provide 1.5 billion euros to the program to fight youth unemployment to respond to the social emergency. Lastly, it is responsible because, through the accompanying resolution, it establishes a conditional link between the revision of the European Union's multiannual financial framework 2014-2020 and the 2017 budget. The framework adopted in 2013 is no longer in tune with current realities and challenges. There is an urgent need to revise it so that the 2017 budget and the following ones allow Europe to act. The message is therefore clear: this budget cannot be adopted without revising the MFF. The Council must quickly adopt a proposal on the revision of the MFF to start the discussion. The ball is on the side of the Member States.

name: Valdemar TOMAŠEVSKI
text: in writing.- I did not support the 2017 draft budget because it imposes excessive costs on the EU administration and does not contain the financial proposals necessary for ordinary citizens.It is about, among other things, too little support for the development of so-called small businesses and small family businesses.In addition, which is very important from the point of view of the interests of agricultural countries, for example, Lithuania, despite reports, has not developed new financial instruments to intervene urgently in the agricultural sector in the event of a crisis, without compromising annual direct payments.It is a pity that the word was not kept in this case.

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: written. - I voted against this draft budget, as it again exceeds the limits of its powers by trying again to increase the Union budget by a staggering EUR 4.13 billion at the expense of the budgets of individual Member States. In addition, this proposal in the budget leaves not the slightest room for maneuver for unforeseen events and needs in 2017. On this occasion, I would like to emphasize once again that the budget of the European Union should be subject to the same rigor as the budgets of individual Member States. I am aware of the many challenges that the changed circumstances have brought to the European Union since 2013, when the multiannual budgetary framework was adopted. "Traveling circus" in Strasbourg, with savings of 180 million euros per year.

name: Romana TOMC
text: in writing. - I supported the motion for a resolution on the Council position on the draft general budget of the European Union for the financial year 2017. The 2017 budget needs to be seen in the broader context of the mid-term review of the MFF and to ensure a balance between long-term priorities and new challenges. The 2017 budget should be in line with the EU's 2020 targets, which offer a central focus and key priorities. In considering the 2017 budget, Parliament took full account of the political priorities adopted by a large majority in its resolution of 9 March 2016 on the general guidelines and the resolution of 6 July 2016 on preparations for the post-election revision of the 2014-2020 multiannual financial framework. The 2017 budget must meet the needs of the migration challenge and the slow economic growth following the economic crisis. Funding for research and infrastructure projects, as well as projects to tackle youth unemployment, needs to be strengthened. It is fully recovering the Connecting Europe Facility and Horizon 2020. The total level of appropriations for 2017 is EUR 161.8 billion in commitments and EUR 136.8 billion in payments.

name: Estefanía TORRES MARTÍNEZ
text: written.- I voted against the Budget Resolution because, even though it is a less harsh position than the Commission or, needless to say, that the Council, it still assumes 5% cuts.Even though there are aspects that restore items of interest (youth employment initiative, although then it is barely applied by 7% by the Member States), it also does so with other security items, it continues to bet on the problematic Juncker Plan to promote investment, and I do not find a redistributive character in the proposed model.

name: Evžen TOŠENOVSKÝ
text: in writing.- I could not support the EU budget for next year as a whole because it contains a number of redundant items.On the contrary, I support investment in research and development and other areas for future growth, such as private-public capital projects under Horizon 2020.

name: Ulrike TREBESIUS
text: written. - This resolution of the rapporteurs on the EU budget 2017 contains a number of statements which are not acceptable. Regardless of the tight budget situation in a number of EU Member States, all of the cuts made by the Council in relation to the Commission's draft are to be withdrawn. In addition, the commitments are to be increased by more than EUR 4 billion and the payment appropriations by almost EUR 2 billion. The planned distribution takes place primarily according to the watering can principle, regardless of compliance with subsidiarity requirements and without a comprehensive monitoring of the success of measures. I also consider the link with the revision of the multiannual financial framework to be inadmissible. It is true that there are also positive approaches such as the fund we are proposing to support victims of terrorism or the increase in funds for Europol to strengthen internal security in Europe. Nevertheless, the negative aspects predominate, which is why I am against this resolution.

name: Ramon TREMOSA i BALCELLS
text: in writing. ‒ I am voting in favour of the budget because we need the EU to begin work as soon as possible on its priorities in 2017, particularly on the refugee crisis and with higher ethical standards at internal level.

name: Mylène TROSZCZYNSKI
text: in writing.- This report recommends a substantial increase in expenditure, due in particular to the reception of migrants, and also proposes its financing by increasing the financial contributions of the Member States, already too high in my view, without examining the possibility ofsave on operating costs.In addition, he mentions the strengthening of the role of the EU in matters of asylum and defense rights, which I consider to be the sovereign competence of the Member States.I voted against.

name: István UJHELYI
text: in writing.- The 2017 budget should be seen in the broader context of the mid-term review of the MFF.A balance needs to be struck between long-term priorities and new challenges, so the 2017 budget must be in line with the Europe 2020 strategy, which sets out the main lines of the budget and its overarching priorities.By my vote, I followed the position of S&D;

name: Miguel URBÁN CRESPO
text: written.- I voted against the Budget Resolution because, even though it is a less harsh position than the Commission or, needless to say, that the Council, it still assumes 5% cuts.Even though there are aspects that restore items of interest (youth employment initiative, although then it is barely applied by 7% by the Member States), it also does so with other security items, it continues to bet on the problematic Juncker Plan to promote investment, and I do not find a redistributive character in the proposed model.

name: Inese VAIDERE
text: in writing. - I have always been in favor of increasing funding for agriculture and the protection of external borders, but not for cohesion, science and research. I am therefore particularly pleased that the 2017 budget supports the proposal to allocate an additional EUR 600 million to the dairy sector to help farmers overcome the current difficulties in the market. It is essential to maintain the balance between the long-term priorities of competitiveness, growth, employment and new challenges, such as migration and security, which require additional funding both in next year's budget and in the coming years. But the search for additional funds in the EU budget and the financing of extraordinary expenditure must not be at the expense of cohesion and agriculture. There is a need to increase funding for the Youth Employment Initiative, which is already operating successfully in Latvia, helping young people to improve their qualifications and integrate into the labor market, as well as research and infrastructure projects. It is therefore particularly important to restore funding under the Connecting Europe Facility (CEF) and Horizon 2020. At the same time, the European Fund for Strategic Investments (EFSI) should be improved so that funds reach Eastern Europe, including the Baltic States.

name: Ivo VAJGL
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report on the Council position on the draft general budget of the European Union for the financial year 2017. The report stresses that budget 2017 has to be considered in the wider context of the mid-term revision of the multiannual financial framework (MFF). It underlines the need to ensure a balance between long-term priorities and new challenges and emphasises therefore that budget 2017 has to be in line with the EU2020 targets, which represent its main orientation and overarching priority. I voted in favour because I believe that the report fully reflects the political priorities adopted by an overwhelming majority in its resolution of 9 March 2016 on general guidelines and its resolution of 6 July 2016 on the ‘Preparation of the post-electoral revision of the MFF 2014-2020: Parliament’s input ahead of the Commission’s proposal’.

name: Marco VALLI
text: in writing. - I voted against the resolution approving the EU budget for 2017 because, although some political will and priorities such as the strengthening of funds for the migration emergency are sustainable, a distorted use of European funds remains. Despite the reduction in the amount of payments compared to 2016, Member States are clearly experiencing difficulties in financing the European budget and absorbing the funds, as the governance structure and the absence of public investment block the economy. Furthermore, two new heavy items of expenditure (the EFSI guarantee and the funds for the agreement with Turkey) take away huge resources that could be better used. Finally, the level of expenditure for the administrative and bureaucratic functioning of the European machine continues to increase. However, the 5 Star Movement had tried to improve the text through several amendments, including one - unfortunately rejected - regarding the TEN-T program, which asked not to use the appropriations to finance projects without real added value, such as the new Turin-Lyon high-speed line.

name: Ángela VALLINA
text: written.- The resolution of the European Parliament emphasizes the need to reinforce the European budget and provide it with greater content in the social and ecological sphere, without questioning its neoliberal drift.Although I agree with these reforms, I consider them insufficient and have finally decided to abstain.

name: Hilde VAUTMANS
text: written.- Although I approved the Council's position on the 2017 budget, there were a number of amendments that I did not agree with, such as institutionalizing driver services and increasing the EP's security staff.I fully supported the call for budgetary discipline, one seat for the EP (abolition of travel to Strasbourg every month) and a fund for the victims of terrorism.

name: Lieve WIERINCK
text: in writing. – I voted in favour of this resolution since I believe that this budgetary line sets the right priorities, consistent with my party’s view. The budget also takes into account the Russian ban and prioritises a real greening of the economy. I agree with the funding for the victims of terrorism since we have always been very sensible concerning this issue. I am in favour of budgetary discipline and I also believe that driver service internalisation will generate additional expenses.

name: Marco ZANNI
text: in writing. - I voted negative today on the resolution on the EU budget for 2017. The Commission, in its July proposal, set commitments of 157.7 billion and 134.9 billion in payments. In its September reading, the Council proposed several reductions, bringing the final figure to 156.4 billion in commitments and 133.8 billion in payments. The Parliament's Committee on Budgets has completely rejected the Council's cuts and has relaunched, especially on the commitment front, coming to propose the record figure of 161.8 billion, and bringing the level of payments to 136.8 billion. I appreciated some political will and priorities, such as the strengthening of Heading III, heavily under pressure due to migratory phenomena, the vision of the Parliament however lacks the necessary realism, since it is difficult, if not impossible, to ask for further budgetary efforts from the States. . The problem of the gap between commitments and payments also persists: this year two new heavy items of expenditure have intervened to worsen the situation, stealing huge resources that could be better used. As regards the "other sections", the level of expenditure for the functioning of the European administrative and bureaucratic machinery continues to increase without end, which is totally unacceptable.

name: Sotirios ZARIANOPOULOS
text: in writing. - Once again, the same mischievous farce is being repeated to disorient the peoples in relation to the size of the EU budget, with a certain conclusion, as always: the agreement on the redistribution of the wealth produced by the people into monopolies, through the Community budget. All the political groups are moving in the direction of supporting the groups with EU money from the budget.
