In the same vein, the Draft Budget calls for more money for the Juncker Fund and the "cohesion funds" funded by business groups, as well as for Horizon 2020 (Business Research - Innovation) and Connecting Europe »(Infrastructure networks), which are oriented towards new profitable projects for the capital. An increase is also foreseen in the funds for large agricultural holdings under the CAP. Additional funding is provided for the promotion of EU imperialist interventions, with additional funding for Europol, the establishment of a "counter-terrorism unit", the "European Counterterrorism Center", defense research funds and the External Action Service. At the same time, increased funding is provided for the anti-communist Europe for Citizens program. In short: more money in monopolies, more funding for the complex imperialist aggression of EU monopolies at the expense of the people.

name: Auke ZIJLSTRA
text: written.- The PVV has voted against.The EP has decided in committee that no budget item can be reduced.Apparently everything has been spent perfectly.The PVV considers this a sign of mental laziness, and is of the opinion that this demonstrates the conviction that everything the EU does is well done and that tax money is free.The PVV cannot support this waste of tax money.

name: Jana ŽITŇANSKÁ
text: in writing. - I did not support the report on the European Union budget for 2017. In voting on this report, as well as on the budget as such, I have followed my long-standing view on the budgetary area, by making efficient use of existing resources and not by increasing the volume of funding every year. I think that the budget cuts that have been proposed have been justified and that unpredictable crises can be covered, for example, by shifting resources from other budget lines without having to increase the budget. I strongly disagree with the approach taken by the rapporteurs, namely to abolish all the proposed cuts and increase the funding required, without the requirements proposed by them having a clear concept or being potentially effective. However, from the changes in the budget, I welcomed the establishment of the Fund for Assistance to Victims of Terrorism and I was also happy to support the supplement to the budget in support of the Special Olympic Games.

name: Carlos ZORRINHO
text: in writing.- (PT) I voted in favor of the Geier and Tarand report because, although I believe that it is not the budget that the Union needs, I still agree with the European Parliament's proposal to increase budget allocations in key areas such as youth employment, economic growthand migration and security policies.I stress that Parliament's position rejects the cuts made by the Council to the Commission's draft budget and restores all the amounts that have been cut in the Connecting Europe Facility and in the Horizon 2020 innovation program to a total of EUR 1,240 million in commitments.I believe that, in the particular context in which we live, initiatives such as the suspension of funds provided for in the Juncker Plan by the European Commission are not only unfair and disproportionate, but are unsustainable at the political level.

name: Marco ZULLO
text: in writing. - As every year we are at the moment of the approval of the EU budget for the year to come and as every year I see a further increase in expenses for the functioning of the administrative and bureaucratic machinery. An endless process that can only see me disappointed and that I expressed with my vote against the report. However, I am pleased that the Plenary has approved the amendment, presented together with my colleagues from the M5S, to put an end to the funding of over 100 million a year for bullfighting farms. These funds are taken from the CAP, the common agricultural policy and therefore are subtracted from all other agricultural activities. Since we have been seated in the European Parliament, the 5 Star Movement is the only Italian political group to vote unanimously not to take money away from farmers, fostering a barbaric and senseless practice like bullfighting. We have promised to fight against these shows and we are fighting. We have loudly asked the states and the executive to change pace and to listen to the citizens and the only European body they have elected, the EU Parliament: stop financing bullfights!

name: Milan ZVER
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of the report on the Council's position on the draft general budget of the European Union for the financial year 2017. According to the report, the 2017 budget must meet the needs of the migration challenge and slow economic growth following the economic crisis.I also agree on the need to increase funding for research and infrastructure projects, as well as projects to tackle youth unemployment.As the 2017 budget includes employment, growth and investment, a European response to the challenges of migration and the management of the fight against terrorism and organized crime, I have decided to support it.

name: Monica MACOVEI
text: - Mr President, we need more budgetary flexibility, because we are facing acute crises in terms of internal security and migration. We have unprecedented problems related to youth unemployment, to the collapse, in a way, of the agricultural sector. People have prompt and justified reactions to these realities. The Treaty states that the Union shall provide itself with the means necessary to attain its objectives and carry through its policies. This means that both the European institutions and the Member States must adequately and realistically reflect the budgetary situation. But the problem is: do we have these goals clearly set? And, in my opinion, they are not clearly established. We seem to forget the main reason we are here, which is to represent people's interests. Second, what are our key priorities? Do we know them very clearly? With all these European institutions - the Council, the Commission, the Parliament - I don't think we know them clearly. This is the only way we can regain people's trust: if we know what we want, we have our priorities and our vision.

name: Peter JAHR
text: - Mister President! On my part, two or three comments on medium-term financial planning. The first: I think it's good that medium-term financial planning is being made, because dealing with the budget over a seven-year period also brings security and stability for those affected. Secondly, and this criticism is clearly directed at our Council: if, of course, new problems arise, new ideas emerge, new demands are made on the European Union, on the European Parliament, then we really have to accept the principle going out: whoever orders, also has to pay. Indeed, in recent years we have seen the viciousness that the Member States are placing new demands on our European budget. But when it comes to financing, the imagination is simply lacking. This has to be stopped. And thirdly, I simply ask that if funds are not used up and we temporarily reimburse contributions to the Member States, then at the end of the seven-year period we do not forget and pay back these arrears.

name: Momchil NEKOV
text: S & amp; D). - I supported the resolution because I believe that the mid-term review of the Multiannual Financial Framework is an opportunity to ensure a sustainable budget for the European Union, both for long-term priorities and for emerging challenges. In his speech on the state of the Union, Jean-Claude Juncker said that the fight against youth unemployment remains the number one priority. In this regard, I welcome the Commission's commitment to increase Erasmus + funding by EUR 200 million and the Youth Employment Initiative by EUR 1 billion. However, I believe that the proposed increase is not enough. If young people are really a priority for Juncker, his words should be solidly backed financially. Funds from the Youth Employment Initiative must be increased by at least EUR 3 billion a year as targeted funding, plus EUR 3 billion from the European Social Fund. As Juncker himself said, if we do not act now, the current generation of young people will be the first to have a lower standard of living than their parents.

name: Seán KELLY
text: – Mr President, this is a very important review and I welcome it, but first of all I want to say that we have to put more pressure on Council Member States to give a bigger budget to the European Union overall, especially in the next MFF. 1% of GDP is very small when you are asked to do almost everything because every time there is a crisis people look to Europe for funding. The first thing we should look at is having a far bigger emergency fund: look at what has happened since we discussed the last MFF –the way migration has taken off and the funding required for that: nobody anticipated it a number of years ago. The same is true in agriculture: it is crisis after crisis, so we need a bigger emergency fund for that. I also support measures in relation to structural funds, cohesion funds, employment funds, TEN-T, Connecting Europe – all those things are very important for our citizens. But unless we have a good, strong budget, we will not be able to do it. The MFF is very important from that point of view.

name: Jasenko SELIMOVIC
text: – Mr President, globalisation has created cross-border problems that need to be addressed in a flexible manner. The priorities of yesterday are not the priorities of today. Therefore I welcome the Commission presenting a mid-term review. The new proposal is, however, in the words of Georgi Gotev, an unusual budget. The envelope dedicated to security and migration could be increased by 25%, while money spent on inclusive growth could be decreased by 15%. Like my liberal colleagues, I am convinced that revision is highly needed. The European Union is currently facing a wide range of crises, notably the immigration crisis, internal emergencies, security issues, agriculture crises, the lack of funding in research and development and a persistent high level of unemployment, especially among young people and third-country nationals. Let us therefore redesign our priorities.

name: Isabella ADINOLFI
text: in writing.- In this report, which focuses on the post-electoral review of the MFF (Multiannual Financial Framework) 2014-2020, greater flexibility is first of all called for and significant additional resources are also requested to address the new challenges and problems of the Union.Although I agree with the increase in flexibility and the search for new funds, in my opinion increasing the ceilings is not the correct method of achieving these objectives, being instead preferable to try to find new resources from other already existing budget lines, trying toreview future priorities.For these reasons, I voted against.

name: Tim AKER
text: in writing. – The Multi-Annual Financial Framework is the long-term budget planning for the EU, which sets the maximum the EU can spend. The current period is for 2014-2020, set at EUR 960 billion. When the current MFF was agreed, David Cameron came back from Brussels claiming that he had achieved a cut in the European Union budget. Fast-forward three years, and we see the use of a ‘Flexibility Instrument’ and an Emergency Aid Reserve which operate outside these MFF spending limits. Money collected from fines is no longer returned to the Member States, but used to increase the EU budget through the back door. In practice, this has led to an EU budget of over EUR 1 trillion in today’s prices over the seven-year term of the MFF. This MFF ‘review’ adds to the flexibility; unspent money in any area will be used to increase the budget in others. This resolution calls for the MFF ceilings to be amended and for more resources to be given to the EU budget. Anything which costs British taxpayers even more money in EU spending is inappropriate in the light of the mandate received from the British people on the Brexit vote.

name: Marina ALBIOL GUZMÁN
text: written.- The resolution reiterates Parliament's priorities for the revision of the MFF, endorsing the financialisation of investments, the austerity conditionality of cohesion and development funds, the privatization of research, the commercialization of agricultural policies and the use of fundsexternal forces to reinforce strong Europe and the geopolitical adventurism of European elites.I voted against to express my criticism of the current use of European funds, which have become one more instrument of neoliberal policies.

name: Martina ANDERSON
text: in writing. – We supported the inclusion of certain elements into the European Parliament’s resolution on the MFF revision, especially our amendment which was adopted into Paragraph 4 which called for ensuring support for the North in the wake of Brexit, this would encompass retaining programs such as PEACE. There were negative elements in this report especially in paragraph 10 where the term populism is associated with misinformation, the wording is problematic as it used in a general sense. Whilst there are many examples of the far-right using misinformation to manipulate more impressionable individuals to participate in discrimination against refugees and ethnic and religious minorities, there are also far more examples in places such as Ireland where left-wing parties like Sinn Féin who consistently challenge the establishment parties with regards to corruption and austerity and how people have suffered, are accused of populism in a negative manner and spreading misinformation, aka the ‘sinister fringe’, to invalidate the reality of the situation. With the MFF we abstained on the final vote as we could not fully oppose the report as voting against consequently meant endorsing the Council’s position which was regressive.

name: Eric ANDRIEU
text: in writing.- I welcome the adoption of this resolution, voted by 446 votes to 181, which once again shows Parliament's determination to match the Union's political objectives with its resources.After noting the under-dimensioning of the budgetary framework, the resolution gives Parliament a mandate to obtain from the Council the flexibility proposed by the European Commission, the increase in ceilings and additional resources on a number of priority programs.Chronic investment deficit, youth unemployment, agricultural crisis, reception of migrants, climate change, establishment of European borders: European priorities must address these challenges.

name: Pascal ARIMONT
text: written.- This report emphasizes that the current multiannual financial framework is constantly suffering from resource scarcity and the new crises and priorities that have arisen in recent years, such as the migration and refugee crisis, the agricultural crisis, external emergencies, internal security measures, unemployment (especiallyamong young people), the ratification of the climate agreement, is not given due consideration.The assessment of the multiannual financial framework shows that more funding and resources will be required to respond adequately to the challenges.The revision of the framework is therefore a good opportunity to respond to the budgetary difficulties.However, new political initiatives should not be financed at the expense of existing programs and measures, but through new resources.Finally, the EU budget should become more transparent and accessible to EU citizens.

name: Marie-Christine ARNAUTU
text: in writing.- This report concerns the mid-term review of the multiannual financial framework (MFF) 2014-2020.The text calls for giving more financial means to the EU by increasing the ceilings of the MFF, in particular to face the "challenges" of migration and terrorism and therefore by increasing the contributions of States.It emphasizes the mobility of young people through the free train ticket for 18-year-old Europeans, an age category regularly targeted by Europeanist propaganda.The report also declares itself in favor of an increase in the EU’s own resources and therefore a European tax.Therefore I voted against this report.

name: Jonathan ARNOTT
text: in writing. ‒ When the Multi-Annual Financial Framework (MFF) was first agreed, David Cameron came back from Brussels claiming that he had achieved a cut in the European Union budget. Fast-forward three years, and we see the use of a ‘Flexibility Instrument’ and an Emergency Aid Reserve. Money collected from fines is no longer returned to the Member States, but used to increase the EU budget by the back door. In practice, this has led to an EU budget of over EUR 1 trillion in today’s money over the seven-year term of the MFF. This review adds to the flexibility; unspent money in any area will be used to increase the budget in others. Anything which costs British taxpayers even more money in EU spending is inappropriate in the light of the mandate received from the British people on the Brexit vote. We therefore felt that we had no choice but to vote against.

name: Jean ARTHUIS
text: in writing.- The revision of the multiannual financial framework marks the end of a cycle and must be the occasion to put an end to two forms of hypocrisy.The first concerns special instruments and the differences in perception between Parliament and the Council, which runs the risk of widening the gap between commitments and payment appropriations.The second concerns the various budget satellites which violate the principle of budgetary unity and at the same time create a blind spot for parliamentary control.I therefore voted in favor of this resolution, which represents the opportunity to restore legibility as well as sincerity to the budget.

name: Zigmantas BALČYTIS
text: in writing.- The European Parliament is constantly concerned about the insufficient resources available under the current Multiannual Financial Framework (MFF).Notes also that many new crises and priorities have emerged in recent years, in particular the migrant and refugee crisis, external emergencies, internal security problems, the agricultural crisis and the European Fund for Strategic Investments (EFSI);), high levels of unemployment, especially youth unemployment, persist.I therefore agree with the need to ensure a realistic, credible and sustainable EU budget for the rest of the current program in order to meet the European Union's political commitments and strategic objectives.

name: Zoltán BALCZÓ
text: in writing. - The motion for a resolution on the mid-term review of the Multiannual Financial Framework 2014-2020. It emphasizes the European Parliament's constant concern that the resources available under the current multiannual financial framework are insufficient. He points to a number of new crises and priorities that have emerged in recent years, namely the migration and refugee crisis, external emergencies, internal security issues, the agricultural crisis, the financing of the European Fund for Strategic Investments and the persistently high level of unemployment. He believes that the revision of the multiannual financial framework offers a unique opportunity to overcome the budgetary difficulties currently threatening the credibility of the European Union. It therefore calls on the Council to assume its responsibilities, follow its deeds and ensure a realistic, credible, comprehensive and sustainable EU budget for the remaining years of the current financial framework. I also agree with the arguments listed and thus with the motion for a resolution.

name: Gerard BATTEN
text: in writing. ‒ The Multi-Annual Financial Framework is the long-term budget planning for the EU, which sets the maximum the EU can spend. The current period is for 2014-2020, set at EUR 960 billion. When the current MFF was agreed, David Cameron came back from Brussels claiming that he had achieved a cut in the European Union budget. Fast-forward three years, and we see the use of a ‘Flexibility Instrument’ and an Emergency Aid Reserve which operate outside these MFF spending limits. Money collected from fines is no longer returned to the Member States, but used to increase the EU budget through the back door. In practice, this has led to an EU budget of over EUR 1 trillion in today’s prices over the seven-year term of the MFF. This MFF ‘review’ adds to the flexibility; unspent money in any area will be used to increase the budget in others. This resolution calls for the MFF ceilings to be amended and for more resources to be given to the EU budget. Anything which costs British taxpayers even more money in EU spending is inappropriate in the light of the mandate received from the British people on the Brexit vote.

name: Hugues BAYET
text: in writing.- I approved this report, which underlines from the outset that the insufficiency of the financial resources available in the multiannual financial framework (MFF) is a constant source of concern for Parliament.He recalls that adequate resources must be made available to deal with new emergencies such as the migration situation and the refugee crisis, internal security or the financing of the EFSI, not to mention the persistence of far too high unemployment, especially among young people.Europe must absolutely concentrate its resources on a recovery policy that abandons austerity, on the fight against unemployment and on taking into account both internally and externally the migration situation and respect for migrants' rights..

name: Brando BENIFEI
text: in writing. - The many challenges that the European Union is facing, primarily migration and economic crisis, make the chronic insufficiency of resources available within the current multiannual financial framework increasingly evident. In this context, its review may represent a unique opportunity to address the budgetary difficulties that are undermining the overall credibility of the EU. The resolution passed today by Parliament, and supported by me, strongly calls on the Council to ensure a credible, coherent and sustainable budget for the remaining years of the current programming period. The budget must be made more flexible and able to respond promptly to the challenges of our time: migration, refugees, agricultural crisis, terrorism, international security and unemployment. The new resources must also be linked to an evaluation on the post-2020 MFF because the way to recover citizens' trust in the European project also passes through the definition of a more transparent, effective and accessible budget.

name: Xabier BENITO ZILUAGA
text: written. - The European Parliament does not have powers to define the Multiannual Financial Framework, which is the scheme that structures and limits the evolution of the budget over 7 years. It is the Council who decides. However, the pressure of the Union's crisis circumstances has generated a parliamentary consensus on the need to strengthen European budgets to face existing challenges (refugees, investment crisis, security, employment, etc…). The Resolution points out many positive aspects. Urges to increase resources, reform the system of own resources, assess the new flexibility conditions of the new MFF, criticize the Council, ask to withdraw the "rebates" (discounts on contributions from more than 10 Member States to the European budget), give the possibility of reusing non-used resources and unity of the Union budget against intergovernmental funds. However, the resolution seems like a good-looking facelift to legitimize itself, because a negotiation in which Parliament decides is not really at stake. In fact, the budget proposal for 2017 goes in the opposite direction, thereby reducing the credibility of this resolution. That is why I have abstained.

name: Izaskun BILBAO BARANDICA
text: written.- I would like to thank the authors of this resolution for their work on the mid-term review of the multiannual financial framework, which underlines Parliament's constant concern about the insufficient resources available in the current multiannual financial framework.We must take into account the new crises and priorities that have emerged in recent years, specifically the migration and refugee crisis, emergency situations abroad, internal security issues, the agricultural crisis, the financing of theEFSI and the persistent high level of unemployment, especially among young people.

name: Dominique BILDE
text: in writing. - If money is the sinews of war, the EU has understood this well since it seeks through this mid-term review of the multiannual financial framework to acquire more financial resources, which obviously aim to '' always increase its political prerogatives. I therefore voted against this resolution, which also opens the door to a European tax. For the Europeanists, the logic is supported by the ideology since it is in particular a question of increasing the ceilings of the MFF to face the "challenges" of migration and terrorism, these problems that the EU has greatly contributed to aggravate, when it did not create them. Rather than continually asking for additional contributions, it is time for the European institutions to start by redeploying unnecessary funds; they are not afraid to demand this from the Member States by imposing ever more austerity on them while demanding that they contribute ever more to the EU budget.

name: Mara BIZZOTTO
text: in writing. - On 6 July the European Parliament approved a report on the preparation of the revision of the multiannual financial framework 2014-2020. The resolution voted today, presented by the Committee on Budgets, takes note of this proposal and reaffirms the priorities of the European Parliament, along the lines of the July resolution. The proposal does not differ much from the report approved before the summer: more flexibility is required and additional resources are required to allow the EU to face new challenges. Especially on this last point, I have very strong reservations, I do not see how the Member States, in the current crisis situation, can engage in new economic efforts also and above all, in the light of the budgetary constraints imposed by Brussels and the disastrous results of its policies. . Instead, I think it would make more sense to move towards a review of existing priorities, making real cuts in EU spending and unnecessary costs to start serving the interests of our citizens.

name: José BLANCO LÓPEZ
text: written. - I voted in favor of the resolution on the mid-term review of the 2014-2020 Multiannual Financial Framework, to give a clear political response to the presentation of the review of the MFF package presented by the Commission on 14 September. While I broadly welcome the Commission's decision to propose a review of the MFF, I emphasize the limited resources available under the current framework to meet the Union's political commitments and strategic objectives, and in this regard We emphasize, once again, the responsibility of the Member States to match the promises with the necessary means to ensure a response in line with the emerging challenges. I welcome the proposal on flexibility, although I regret that an upward revision of the ceilings of the current MFF is not being proposed, which is necessary if we are to face present and future challenges and meet our objectives. Finally, I call on the Council to start negotiating the financial framework urgently as we will not be able to negotiate the 2017 budget without having a framework under which to negotiate.

name: Vilija BLINKEVIČIŪTĖ
text: in writing. - I voted in favor of this resolution, which covers the period 2014-2020. mid-term review of the multiannual financial framework (MFF). The European Parliament welcomes the Commission's intention to simplify the financial rules and considers this to be an important part of the mid-term review of the MFF. Takes note, therefore, of the Commission's proposal to revise the Financial Regulation as a whole and to amend 15 sectoral regulations. Parliament emphasizes that the aim of simplification is to improve and streamline implementation conditions for beneficiaries and is committed to achieving a successful outcome in line with this provision in due course. The European Parliament emphasizes that the effective implementation of the EU budget is a top priority for Parliament and therefore welcomes the Commission's proposal to reinstate in the EU budget commitment appropriations canceled due to unimplemented actions for which they were originally intended, and emphasizes that this was one of Parliament's main demands; expressed in 2016 July 6 resolution on the multiannual financial framework.

name: Andrea BOCSKOR
text: in writing. - The EP motion insists on the Parliament's report adopted at the July plenary session, which gives an opinion in advance on the revision of the 2014-2020 financial framework. In this, despite the united protest of the Hungarian People's Party representatives, they supported the forced resettlement and the harsh financial sanctions of the countries that refused it. At the same time, Fidesz MEPs will only adopt a revision of the financial framework and an EU budget in which these penalties are not even at the level of ideas. In the review, the European Commission proposes an increase of € 12.8 billion. At the same time, we must avoid a liquidity crisis during the previous seven-year framework, when the Commission was unable to pay the invoices submitted to the Member States for the projects implemented. All proposals can only be supported if we receive the right guarantee: there will be sufficient resources in the annual budgets for the catching-up programs and agricultural subsidies that are already under way. As the text of the motion for a resolution confirms the EP report calling for a fine against Member States that did not adopt mandatory quotas in July, I did not support the adoption of the motion.

name: Franc BOGOVIČ
text: in writing.- I agreed with the resolution on the mid-term review of the multiannual financial framework and also supported it at this plenary session, as it envisages many good changes or additions to the existing policy in the multiannual financial framework.The audit supports, inter alia, the Commission's proposal to establish an EU crisis reserve as an instrument for rapid response to crises and events with serious humanitarian or security consequences.It encourages further investment in European youth through the EU budget, such as the recently proposed 'Interrail' program.It proposes reforms to the own resources system, including the introduction of new own resources, which will significantly reduce the share of contributions to the EU budget.

name: Mercedes BRESSO
text: in writing. ‒ I endorsed the resolution on the mid-term revision of the mutual financial framework (MFF) 2014-2020 because it underlines our concern with regard to the insufficient resources that are available at the moment. We are facing new challenges today such as the refugee crisis and I believe the revision of the MFF shall have the aim of ensuring a fair balance between the long-term priorities and the new emerging challenges. In this regard, I welcome the proposal of the establishment of an EU Crisis Reserve by the Commission as instrument to tackle rapidly the crises.

name: Steeve BRIOIS
text: in writing.- This mid-term review of the multiannual financial framework (MFF) calls for an increase in the financial resources of the European Union, in particular in order to finance the reception of illegal migrants in the Member States.At a time when the peoples of Europe are suffering mass unemployment and the decline in their purchasing power, it is truly scandalous to see the European Union give priority to the reception of these illegal migrants rather than to the fate ofour fellow citizens.Furthermore, we strongly oppose the creation of a European tax which will help finance the functioning of the Brussels bureaucracy.This is the reason why I voted against this text.

name: Soledad CABEZÓN RUIZ
text: written. - I voted in favor of the resolution on the mid-term review of the 2014-2020 Multiannual Financial Framework, to give a clear political response to the presentation of the review of the MFF package presented by the Commission on 14 September. While I broadly welcome the Commission's decision to propose a review of the MFF, I emphasize the limited resources available under the current framework to meet the Union's political commitments and strategic objectives, and in this regard We emphasize, once again, the responsibility of the Member States to match the promises with the necessary means to ensure a response in line with the emerging challenges. I welcome the proposal on flexibility, although I regret that an upward revision of the ceilings of the current MFF is not being proposed, which is necessary if we are to face present and future challenges and meet our objectives. Finally, I call on the Council to start negotiating the financial framework urgently as we will not be able to negotiate the 2017 budget without having a framework under which to negotiate.

name: Alain CADEC
text: in writing.- I voted for this resolution on the mid-term review of the multiannual financial framework.This mid-term review was a Board commitment;I therefore call on the Member States to honor this commitment.I support the broad lines of the Commission's proposal, which provides flexibility and additional resources made necessary by the new challenges facing the European Union.I stress the importance of the additional 6.3 billion euros proposed until 2020, which will cover growth and jobs, security and control of external borders, as well as the European Development Fundsustainable.These are fundamental areas for European citizens, on which the Union must act.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: in writing. - Today I voted in favor of the resolution because I share the recommendations it addresses to the European Council for the mid-term review of the multiannual financial framework. Parliament requests that the budgets be increased so that the EU has a budget corresponding to the political commitments and strategic objectives it intends to pursue. The problems of migration, internal security, the crisis in the agricultural sector and the persistent high unemployment rate, especially among young people, require the adoption of adequate measures and additional funds which, unfortunately, in the first years of the current multiannual financial framework (MFF) were not foreseen due to scarce resources available. The mid-term review of the MFF should also be the start of a consensus-seeking process for the post-2020 MFF. In this context, the report recommends making strong commitments, including the creation of new own resources capable of significantly reducing the quota. contributions to the EU budget on the basis of GNI, as well as the phasing out of all forms of correction, as well as to align the duration of the MFF with the political cycles of the institutions.

name: Matt CARTHY
text: in writing. ‒ I abstained on this report. I supported the inclusion of certain elements into the European Parliament’s resolution on the MFF revision, especially Sinn Fein’s amendment, which was adopted in paragraph 4, and which called for ensuring support for the North in the wake of Brexit. This encompasses retaining programs such as PEACE. There were negative elements in this report, especially in paragraph 10 where the term ‘populism’ is associated with misinformation, and it conflates both right-wing and left-wing parties. With the MFF I abstained on the final vote, as I could not fully oppose the report as voting against consequently meant endorsing the Council’s position, which was regressive.

name: James CARVER
text: in writing. ‒ The Multi-Annual Financial Framework is the long-term budget planning for the EU, which sets the maximum the EU can spend. The current period is for 2014-2020, set at EUR 960 billion. When the current MFF was agreed, David Cameron came back from Brussels claiming that he had achieved a cut in the European Union budget. Fast-forward three years, and we see the use of a ‘Flexibility Instrument’ and an Emergency Aid Reserve which operate outside these MFF spending limits. Money collected from fines is no longer returned to the Member States, but used to increase the EU budget through the back door. In practice, this has led to an EU budget of over EUR 1 trillion in today’s prices over the seven-year term of the MFF. This MFF ‘review’ adds to the flexibility; unspent money in any area will be used to increase the budget in others. This resolution calls for the MFF ceilings to be amended and for more resources to be given to the EU budget. Anything which costs British taxpayers even more money in EU spending is inappropriate in the light of the mandate received from the British people on the Brexit vote.

name: David CASA
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report to secure the appropriate funds for the remaining four years of the multi financial framework (MFF) in order to promote growth, jobs and competitiveness, address youth unemployment and the migration and refugee crisis, ensure internal security in the EU and fight terrorism. It should also prevent a future payment crisis in the EU Budget. The MFF mid-term revision should also represent an excellent opportunity to secure the appropriate funding for newly-proposed programmes like the ‘18th birthday InterRail pass for Europe’, as the mobility of young people is essential in increasing a sense of European identity. This is all about not just the economy, but the review of the EU’s credibility. It is important that funds start pouring through to the regions and young people in our Member States in order for the EU to be visible also at local level.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: in writing.- On 6 July, the European Parliament approved a report on the preparation of the post-election review of the MFF (Multiannual Financial Framework) 2014-2020.This resolution relates to the Commission proposal and was strongly supported by the rapporteurs to strengthen Parliament's position in view of the negotiations with the Council.The Parliament's previous statement is therefore substantially reiterated: greater flexibility and significant additional resources are required to meet new challenges and problems.While the first aspect is in complete agreement, with reference to the second it is clear that states do not want or can engage in new economic endeavors.It would therefore be more sensible to proceed with a review of priorities, also identifying budget lines on which to intervene in order to find the necessary resources.For this reason, I voted negative.

name: Lefteris CHRISTOFOROU
text: in writing.- We support the mid-term review of the Multiannual Financial Framework and believe that its review provides a unique opportunity to address the budgetary difficulties that currently undermine the credibility of the European Union.

name: Alberto CIRIO
text: in writing. - I agree with the revision proposal because of the constant concern about the insufficiency of the resources available under the current multiannual financial framework (MFF) in the face of the multiple crises and emergencies that have emerged in recent years. Indeed, substantial volumes of additional funds are needed to the EU budget, and a mid-term review is a nerve center for optimal weighting on the post-2020 side. Among the measures present, the one that has generated the most confidence in me is the Commission's proposal to create an EU crisis reserve as a means of rapid reaction to events with serious humanitarian or security implications. In fact, in the light of what happened recently in Central Italy following the earthquakes in September and October, it is a duty to provide assistance and aid to those who suddenly find themselves losing everything. Therefore, I invite the Commission to implement the measures in question as soon as possible, integrate them without delay into the 2017 EU budget and to enter into substantial negotiations with the Council on the MFF mid-term review in the context of the conciliation procedure on the 2017 budget. Together with the above, I urge the Commission to provide clarification on the financial implications of the UK's withdrawal from the EU, subject to future negotiations.

name: Deirdre CLUNE
text: in writing. ‒ I supported the motion for a resolution on the mid-term revision of the MMF 2014-2020 and noted no objections.

name: Carlos COELHO
text: in writing. - The revision of the Multiannual Financial Framework is a unique opportunity to respond to budgetary difficulties that jeopardize the European Union's credibility. The Council must therefore assume its responsibilities by ensuring a realistic, credible, consistent and sustainable budget for the remaining years. With this review we must seek to ensure a balance between meeting the EU's long-term political priorities and responding to new emerging challenges. This review should also be the beginning of a consensus building process for the post-2020 MFF, and firm commitments must be made in this context, in particular to address the reform of the own resources system, including the introduction of new own resources, as well as align the duration of the MFF with the political cycles of the institutions. I agree with the creation of a crisis reserve as an instrument for rapid reaction to crises, as well as events with serious humanitarian or security implications. In view of the above, I support this motion for a resolution on the revision of the Multiannual Financial Framework for 2014-2020.

name: Lara COMI
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of the measure as the text presented on the one hand positively incorporates some proposals for amendments that Parliament had previously expressed in particular on the subject of flexibility.Some corrective needs and specific needs still persist, such as that relating to the mobility of young people, an essential element for strengthening European awareness and identity.The creation of an EU reserve as a rapid reaction tool to crises, as well as to events with serious humanitarian or security implications, is welcome.

name: Javier COUSO PERMUY
text: written.- The resolution reiterates Parliament's priorities for the revision of the MFF, endorsing the financialisation of investments, the austerity conditionality of cohesion and development funds, the privatization of research, the commercialization of agricultural policies and the use of fundsexternal forces to reinforce strong Europe and the geopolitical adventurism of European elites.I have voted against to express my criticism of the current use of European funds, which have become one more instrument of neoliberal policies.

name: Edward CZESAK
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of the motion for a resolution on the mid-term review of the MFF, which aims to increase the limits for specific actions (employment initiative, Horizon 2020, partnership on migration).In my opinion, if there is a possibility of increasing the amount for such important programs with several benefits, it should be used.In addition, the resolution mentions more flexibility and the removal of certain restrictions, which I welcome.Therefore, I voted in favor.

name: Miriam DALLI
text: in writing. ‒ The Multiannual Financial Framework (MFF), which sets the framework for the EU’s annual budget, needs to be revised to allow for additional funding and greater flexibility. This helps the EU to deal with the unprecedented number of challenges that Europe is facing and will be facing in the future. The report points out the insufficiency of available resources as well as criticism for the Commission’s proposal. This is why I have voted in favour of the position on the Commission’s proposal on the revision of the MFF 2014-2020.

name: Daniel DALTON
text: in writing. ‒ I could not support a resolution that, by seeking to link the MFF and the 2017 Budget, could result in the MFF ceilings being broken and increased national contributions. I do not support such an attempt to hold the 2017 budget hostage in order to achieve higher national contributions. The EU spending limits should be respected and we should not put agreement of the budget at risk like this at a time when Europe is facing multiple crises.

name: Michel DANTIN
text: in writing. - This resolution concerns the European Commission proposal for a mid-term review of the multiannual financial framework. The multiannual financial framework constitutes the framework for the Union's resources and expenditure over a period of seven years. The European Commission proposal aims to increase the flexibility of this framework and to remove certain restrictions in order to allow the reuse of previously unused margins. It also proposes to create a Union crisis reserve to finance crisis responses, in particular migration, agricultural and humanitarian crises. If these proposals are positive, it seems to me essential that the ceilings of the multiannual financial framework be revised upwards in order to finance the priorities of the Union, which must face up to a whole series of crises, while financing the common agricultural policy, infrastructure and research policies or even cohesion policies. Considering all of these elements, I voted in favor of this resolution.

name: William (The Earl of) DARTMOUTH
text: in writing. ‒ The Multi-Annual Financial Framework is the long-term budget planning for the EU, which sets the maximum the EU can spend. The current period is for 2014-2020, set at EUR 960 billion. When the current MFF was agreed, David Cameron came back from Brussels claiming that he had achieved a cut in the European Union budget. Fast-forward three years, and we see the use of a ‘Flexibility Instrument’ and an Emergency Aid Reserve which operate outside these MFF spending limits. Money collected from fines is no longer returned to the Member States, but used to increase the EU budget through the back door. In practice, this has led to an EU budget of over EUR 1 trillion in today’s prices over the seven-year term of the MFF. This MFF ‘review’ adds to the flexibility; unspent money in any area will be used to increase the budget in others. This resolution calls for the MFF ceilings to be amended and for more resources to be given to the EU budget. Anything which costs British taxpayers even more money in EU spending is inappropriate in the light of the mandate received from the British people on the Brexit vote.

name: Rachida DATI
text: in writing.- I supported this resolution on the mid-term review of the multiannual financial framework (MFF).I welcome the European Commission's proposal to create a European Union crisis reserve intended to finance responses to crises, in particular migration, agricultural and humanitarian crises.In addition, it is very important that the Commission provides the budgetary authority with all the relevant information in order to take into account the budgetary implications on the current multiannual financial framework of the British referendum of 23 June 2016 and, ultimately, of the exit from theUnited Kingdom of the European Union.

name: Tamás DEUTSCH
text: in writing. - The EP motion insists on the Parliament's report adopted at the July plenary session, which gives an opinion in advance on the revision of the 2014-2020 financial framework. In this, despite the united protests of the People's Party MPs, the MEPs of the Hungarian left parties voted against the interests of the country, attacking all Hungarian citizens in the back with their decision on forced resettlement. MEPs from left-wing parties in Hungary supported the forced resettlement and the harsh financial sanctions of countries that rejected it by a firm and proud vote on the motion. At the same time, the vast majority of Hungarian voters have a clear position: they said no to forced resettlement. Therefore, Fidesz MEPs will only adopt a revision of the financial framework and an EU budget in which these penalties are not even at the level of ideas. In the review, the European Commission proposes an increase of € 12.8 billion. At the same time, we must avoid a liquidity crisis during the previous seven-year framework, when the Commission was unable to pay the invoices submitted to the Member States for the projects implemented. All proposals can only be supported if we receive the right guarantee: there will be sufficient resources in the annual budgets for the catching-up programs and agricultural subsidies that are already in place. As the text of the motion for a resolution confirms the EP report calling for a fine against Member States that did not adopt mandatory quotas in July, I rejected the motion.

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: in writing. - The Multiannual Financial Framework, as a means of expressing the Union's economic policy, is a failed model. The current MFF has failed to meet the challenges posed in the first half of its implementation. Planning the allocation of financial resources over a period of 7 years using ceilings per year and enforcing them while pursuing growth and innovation, leads to distortions of any political priorities and strategic objectives, but also to the subdued response to emerging threats and challenges.

name: Norbert ERDŐS
text: in writing. - The EP motion insists on the Parliament's report adopted at the July plenary session, which gives an opinion in advance on the revision of the 2014-2020 financial framework. In this, despite the united protests of the People's Party MPs, the MEPs of the Hungarian left parties voted against the interests of the country, attacking all Hungarian citizens in the back with their decision on forced resettlement. MEPs from left-wing parties in Hungary supported the forced resettlement and the harsh financial sanctions of countries that rejected it by a firm and proud vote on the motion. At the same time, the vast majority of Hungarian voters have a clear position: they said no to forced resettlement. Therefore, Fidesz MEPs will only adopt a revision of the financial framework and an EU budget in which these penalties are not even at the level of ideas. In the review, the European Commission proposes an increase of € 12.8 billion. At the same time, we must avoid a liquidity crisis during the previous seven-year framework, when the Commission was unable to pay the invoices submitted to the Member States for the projects implemented. All proposals can only be supported if we receive the right guarantee: there will be sufficient resources in the annual budgets for the catching-up programs and agricultural subsidies that are already under way. As the text of the motion for a resolution confirms the EP report calling for a fine against Member States that did not adopt mandatory quotas in July, I rejected the motion.

name: Jill EVANS
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this resolution because it updates the position of Parliament adopted in 2013 and reflects the changes that have taken place since then, such as the adoption of EFSI and the Paris Agreement. It is also a reaction to the fact that the UK, including Wales, voted to leave the EU.

name: José Manuel FERNANDES
text: in writing.- The revision of the Multiannual Financial Framework is a unique opportunity to address the budgetary difficulties that currently undermine the credibility of the European Union, and the Council must assume its responsibilities in order to align words and actions and ensure a budgetrealistic, credible, consistent and sustainable EU strategy for the rest of the current perspective.The Commission's proposal for values, estimated at 12.8 billion euros, includes different components, including complementary contributions to the Horizon 2020 program and MIE-Transport (0.4 billion euros each), the Erasmus programs+ and COSME (0.2 billion euros each) and the Youth Employment Initiative (1 billion euros).

name: João FERREIRA
text: in writing. - It is an evidence and corresponds to a position we have had for a long time (we could even say a position as usual) that the ceilings of the EU budget lines for areas such as cohesion should be revised upwards. The limits imposed on the Multiannual Financial Framework do not in any way allow the implementation of the so-called principle of economic and social cohesion. They prevent any redistributive function that the EU budget should have. Without following the approach followed in this report, and even expressing our deep divergence from some of the formulations used, we recognize that it advances with some pertinent considerations. But everything is very insufficient. There is a need for a considerable increase in available resources to combat the migration and refugee crisis, in agreement, but in a perspective completely contrary to what has been the policy adopted by the EU. In other words, resources are needed, yes, but directed towards social and humanitarian support to refugees and not to feed persecutory policies. We advocate a substantial reinforcement of the EU budget, based on contributions from Member States, depending on their level of relative wealth (GNI). This is the only way to carry out the redistributive function of the budget. About this, the report says nothing or points in a different direction. We voted against.

name: Monika BEŇOVÁ
text: in writing.- This report is the European Parliament's response to the mid-term review of the multiannual financial framework.It is important that we clearly name the problems, which certainly include the lack of funding in the current programming period 2014-2020, but also the fact that the European Commission does not deal in detail with the issue of payments that would be beyond the current financial framework, which wouldcould help to create a kind of European Union reserve for the crisis.

name: Lorenzo FONTANA
text: in writing.- I am voting against this resolution because it would make more sense to review existing priorities, identifying the costs to be cut and avoiding increasing the overall spending ceilings.

name: Lampros FOUNTOULIS
text: in writing. - The Multiannual Financial Framework as a means of expressing the Union's economic policy is a failed model. The current MFF has failed to meet the challenges posed in the first half of its implementation. The planning of the allocation of financial resources over a period of 7 years, using ceilings per year and enforcing them, while at the same time pursuing growth and innovation leads to distortions of any political priorities and strategic goals, but also to the subdued response of emerging threats and challenges. For the above reasons, I am voting against the Interim revision of the MFF.

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: in writing. ‒ Although I welcome the Commission’s decision to propose a revision of the MFF Regulation, after many concerns regarding the structural insufficiencies and scarcity of resources available under the current Framework, I believe that the only way for the EU to live up to its responsibilities and protect its citizens, whilst also responding to the crises, is to raise the ceilings and enhance the flexibility of the MFF. The MFF revision should be used to fully compensate the cuts in Horizon 2020 and CEF funding, as well as to ensure sufficient funding for those programmes which boost growth, jobs and competitiveness. Therefore, I support an adequate response to the challenges that require a substantial amount of additional funding from the EU budget that could not been fully provided in the first years of the current perspective due to the scarce financial resources available under the current MFF.  In addition, I am of the opinion that an in-depth reform of the system of financing the Union would make the EU budget more stable, more sustainable, and more predictable, while improving transparency for the citizens. This would consequently, minimise direct contributions from national budgets.

name: Kinga GÁL
text: in writing. - The EP motion insists on the Parliament's report adopted at the July plenary session, which gives an opinion in advance on the revision of the 2014-2020 financial framework. In this, despite the united protest of the People's Party MPs, the MEPs of the Hungarian left parties voted against the interests of the country. MEPs from left-wing parties in Hungary supported the forced resettlement and the harsh financial sanctions of countries that rejected it by a firm and proud vote on the motion. At the same time, the vast majority of Hungarian voters have a clear position: they said no to forced resettlement. Therefore, Fidesz MEPs will only adopt a revision of the financial framework and an EU budget in which these penalties are not even at the level of ideas. As the text of the motion for a resolution confirms the EP report calling for a fine against Member States that did not adopt mandatory quotas in July, I rejected the motion.

name: Ildikó GÁLL-PELCZ
text: in writing. - The EP motion insists on the Parliament's report adopted at the July plenary session, which gives an opinion in advance on the revision of the 2014-2020 financial framework. In this, despite the united protests of the People's Party MPs, the MEPs of the Hungarian left parties voted against the interests of the country, attacking all Hungarian citizens in the back with their decision on forced resettlement. MEPs from left-wing parties in Hungary supported the forced resettlement and the harsh financial sanctions of countries that rejected it by a firm and proud vote on the motion. At the same time, the vast majority of Hungarian voters have a clear position: they said no to forced resettlement. Therefore, Fidesz MEPs will only adopt a revision of the financial framework and an EU budget in which these penalties are not even at the level of ideas. In the review, the European Commission proposes an increase of € 12.8 billion. At the same time, we must avoid a liquidity crisis during the previous seven-year framework, when the Commission was unable to pay the invoices submitted to the Member States for the projects implemented. All proposals can only be supported if we receive the right guarantee: there will be sufficient resources in the annual budgets for the catching-up programs and agricultural subsidies that are already under way. As the text of the motion for a resolution confirms the EP report calling for a fine against Member States that did not adopt mandatory quotas in July, I rejected the motion.

name: Francisco de Paula GAMBUS MILLET
text: written.- I voted in favor of the report concerned about the insufficient resources available in the current Multiannual Financial Framework.It is important to highlight that attention to the new crises and priorities that have emerged in recent years, specifically the migration and refugee crisis, emergency situations abroad, internal security issues, the agricultural crisis, the financing of theEuropean Fund for Strategic Investments and the persistent high level of unemployment, especially among young people, require a Union capable of tackling such important challenges.Therefore, the revision of the Multiannual Financial Framework offers a unique opportunity to tackle budgetary difficulties that jeopardize the credibility of the Union.

name: Iratxe GARCÍA PÉREZ
text: written. - I voted in favor of the resolution on the mid-term review of the 2014-2020 Multiannual Financial Framework to give a clear political response to the presentation of the review of the MFF package presented by the Commission on 14 September. While broadly welcoming the Commission's decision to propose a review of the MFF, I emphasize the limited resources available under the current framework to meet the Union's political commitments and strategic objectives, and in this regard we highlight , once again, the responsibility of the Member States to match the promises with the necessary means to ensure a response in line with the emerging challenges. I welcome the proposal on flexibility, although I regret that an upward revision of the ceilings of the current MFF is not being proposed, which is necessary if we are to face present and future challenges and meet our objectives. Finally, I call on the Council to start negotiating the financial framework urgently as we will not be able to negotiate the 2017 budget without having a framework under which to negotiate.

name: Eider GARDIAZABAL RUBIAL
text: written. - I voted in favor of the resolution on the mid-term review of the 2014-2020 Multiannual Financial Framework, to give a clear political response to the presentation of the review of the MFP package presented by the Commission on 14 September. While I broadly welcome the Commission's decision to propose a review of the MFF, I emphasize the limited resources available under the current framework to meet the Union's political commitments and strategic objectives, and in this regard We emphasize, once again, the responsibility of the Member States to match the promises with the necessary means to ensure a response in line with the emerging challenges. I welcome the proposal on flexibility, although I regret that an upward revision of the ceilings of the current MFF is not being proposed, which is necessary if we are to face present and future challenges and meet our objectives. Finally, I call on the Council to start negotiating the financial framework urgently as we will not be able to negotiate the 2017 budget without having a framework under which to negotiate.

name: Enrico GASBARRA
text: in writing.- It is urgent to equip Europe with adequate resources to respond to the many open political emergencies.I therefore share the report of the Budget Committee which strongly underlines the concern about the insufficiency of the resources available under the current multiannual financial framework, drawing attention precisely to the number of new crises and priorities that have emerged in recent years, inin particular the migration and refugee crisis, internal security issues, the persistence of a high unemployment rate, especially among young people.

name: Elena GENTILE
text: in writing. - I voted in favor of the resolution on the 2014-2020 mid-term review of the multiannual financial framework (MFF) because I believe that after passing the resolution of 6 July on the review of the functioning of the MFF, an adequate response to the challenges we face requires a volume of additional funds from the EU budget. This is a unique opportunity for the EU to address the difficulties that are undermining the EU's credibility and the achievement of its objectives. The EU needs a realistic and credible budget and the review could be the way to ensure the balance between achieving the EU's long-term political priorities and responding to current challenges, which need an immediate response, which, however, cannot be found at the expense of existing policies and programs. For these reasons, I strongly supported the creation of a permanent reserve within the European budget; that it can be mobilized in the event of a crisis to avoid solutions based on "off-budget" funds and which the Commission incorporated in the proposal published in September, as well as the need for a flexible revision to respond promptly to challenges such as the migration crisis, the terrorism, internal security problems.

name: Arne GERICKE
text: written.- I voted against the report on the mid-term review of the multiannual financial framework (MFF).There is no point in running such a report if the reporters end up being blind in at least one eye.Real control looks different.

name: Jens GIESEKE
text: written.- I agree to the mid-term review of the multiannual financial framework (MFF).In the last few years it has been shown above all that the current flexibility provisions are of essential importance for the European Union's ability to act.Especially in times of migration and refugee crisis.

name: Michela GIUFFRIDA
text: in writing. - Reality runs much, much faster than fantasy, let alone European budget review procedures. We have been talking for years about immigration, reception costs, border control and even now we are discussing a Commission proposal on the revision of the multiannual financial framework which does not add a euro to what has already been established, but makes the courtesy to reschedule, that is, it moves and allocates the migration of resources to the emergency. It almost seems like a joke. The efforts for "simplification" are even more surreal. To simplify, the Commission brings together in a single regulation, Omnibus, the revision of the basic acts of the major European policies, cohesion and agriculture, dangerously limiting the European Parliament's scope for action. Some might think that even in Europe, as in the Sicily of the Leopard "Everything needs to change, so that everything remains the same". But I am sure that this will not be the case, because Europe cannot afford to remain the same, at least this Parliament will have to fight for something to really change.

name: Bruno GOLLNISCH
text: in writing. - The debates on the revision of the multiannual financial framework of the European Union follow one another and are similar. Always more expenditure, financed if possible by a European tax. Austerity is good for others, while year after year, the Court of Auditors struggles to fully approve the use made of taxpayers' money by the Commission, even criticizing certain costly and doubtful. In July, the debate took place after some colleagues had asked for it to be postponed, given the unprecedented situation created by the Brexit victory. We don't know much more, but we discuss it anyway. A novelty, however, with this crucial proposal to fight against “populism”: to offer a free “interrail pass” to young Europeans for their 18th birthday. Without a doubt, the existence of such an advantage would have been decisive in the British referendum! Supposing the Eurostar is not delayed by the presence of migrants on the tracks! Your contempt for the people is such that you think you can fight with a rattle the growing aversion that your policies arouse in their victims. It's no wonder that more and more of them want to flee.

name: Tania GONZÁLEZ PEÑAS
text: written. - The European Parliament does not have powers to define the Multiannual Financial Framework, which is the scheme that structures and limits the evolution of the budget over 7 years. It is the Council who decides. However, the pressure of the Union's crisis circumstances has generated a parliamentary consensus on the need to strengthen European budgets to face existing challenges (refugees, investment crisis, security, employment, etc…). The Resolution points out many positive aspects. Urges to increase resources, reform the own resources system, assess the new flexibility conditions of the new MFF, criticize the Council, ask to withdraw the "rebates" (discounts on contributions from more than 10 Member States to the European budget), give the possibility of reusing non-used resources and unity of the Union budget against intergovernmental funds. However, the resolution seems like a good-looking facelift to legitimize itself, because a negotiation in which Parliament decides is not really at stake. In fact, the budget proposal for 2017 goes in the opposite direction, thereby reducing the credibility of this resolution. That is why I have abstained.

name: Theresa GRIFFIN
text: in writing. ‒ Labour MEPs voted to oppose an increase in the EU budget for 2017 – we believe the first resort should be finding money for EU priorities within existing budget lines. We remain committed to the principle of prioritising the jobs and economic growth agenda whether inside or outside of the European Union and hope to continue close cooperation with our neighbours as a means of protecting the UK economy.

name: Antanas GUOGA
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against. I believe that the revision of the multiannual financial framework provides a unique opportunity to respond to the budgetary difficulties currently jeopardising the credibility of the European Union. However, the Council should take its responsibility to ensure a realistic, credible, coherent and sustainable EU budget for the remaining years of the current perspective. Therefore, serious actions should be taken in order to strengthen the commitments of the MFF by starting with responsible control mechanism of the fund.

name: Sergio GUTIÉRREZ PRIETO
text: written. - I voted in favor of the resolution on the mid-term review of the 2014-2020 Multiannual Financial Framework, to give a clear political response to the presentation of the review of the MFP package presented by the Commission on 14 September. While I broadly welcome the Commission's decision to propose a review of the MFF, I emphasize the limited resources available under the current framework to meet the Union's political commitments and strategic objectives, and in this regard We emphasize, once again, the responsibility of the Member States to match the promises with the necessary means to ensure a response in line with the emerging challenges. I welcome the proposal on flexibility, although I regret that an upward revision of the ceilings of the current MFF is not being proposed, which is necessary if we are to face present and future challenges and meet our objectives. Finally, I call on the Council to start negotiating the financial framework urgently as we will not be able to negotiate the 2017 budget without having a framework under which to negotiate.

name: András GYÜRK
text: in writing. - The EP motion insists on the Parliament's report adopted at the July plenary session, which gives an advance opinion on the revision of the 2014-2020 financial framework. In this, despite the united protests of the People's Party MPs, the MEPs of the Hungarian left parties voted against the interests of the country, attacking all Hungarian citizens in the back with their decision on forced resettlement. MEPs from left-wing parties in Hungary supported the forced resettlement and the harsh financial sanctions of countries that rejected it by a firm and proud vote on the motion. At the same time, the vast majority of Hungarian voters have a clear position: they said no to forced resettlement. Therefore, Fidesz MEPs will only adopt a revision of the financial framework and an EU budget in which these penalties are not even at the level of ideas. In the review, the European Commission proposes an increase of € 12.8 billion. At the same time, we must avoid the liquidity crisis that arose during the previous seven-year framework, when the Commission was unable to pay the invoices submitted to the Member States for the projects implemented. All proposals can only be supported if we receive the right guarantee: there will be sufficient resources in the annual budgets for the catching-up programs and agricultural subsidies that are already in place. As the text of the motion for a resolution confirms the EP report calling for a fine against Member States that did not adopt mandatory quotas in July, I rejected the motion.

name: Takis HADJIGEORGIOU
text: in writing. - We disagreed with the logic of the austerity of the Multiannual Financial Framework (MFF). However, in a revision we could agree to an increase in funding for Erasmus + and COSME, for example, although we know that these programs are not enough to change the EU's philosophy on public investment and voluntary (instead of indirectly compulsory) immigration. We voted to abstain from the mid-term review of the MFF, in order to take a specific position when we have clear indications of the revised MFF.

name: Marian HARKIN
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this resolution on the mid-term revision of the multiannual financial framework. (MFF) 2014-2020. After a review of the performance of the MFF in the first half of this programming period as presented in the resolution of 6 July 2016, this resolution outlines that a substantial amount of additional funding from the EU budget is required. It highlights a number of new crises and priorities that have emerged over the past years, notably the migration and refugee crisis, external emergencies, internal security issues, the crisis in agriculture, the funding of the European Fund for Strategic Investments (EFSI) and the persistent high level of unemployment, especially among young people. I was particularly pleased that the motion emphasised our core values of peace and stability by highlighting the importance of the Good Friday Agreement, and the need to protect specific measures and programmes to ensure support for the regions particularly affected in the event of a negotiated exit from the EU upon the invocation of Article 50 of the Treaty of Lisbon.

name: Hans-Olaf HENKEL
text: written. - The report states that the appropriations entered in the current Multiannual Financial Framework (2014-2020) are far too low. In the logic of the current majority in the European Parliament, this is understandable, since in recent years Parliament has always irresponsibly asked for more funds than the Commission proposed, and at the same time always rejected all the cuts proposed by the Council, at the expense of this of European taxpayers. It should be emphasized that the current EU budget does not take sufficient account of the principle of subsidiarity, as some of the planned expenditures could be dealt with much better by the national states or regions and municipalities than at the European level. In addition, especially in cohesion policy and also in individual areas of agricultural policy, there is often a lack of sustainability, goal-orientation and professional success control based on measurable results. Finally, the report also calls for a direct link to the 2017 budget, which is also to be criticized. That is why I rejected the report.

name: Cătălin Sorin IVAN
text: signed up.- I voted in favor of revising the MFF;it is an opportunity to continue reforms at European level and to implement the agreed political priorities for the MFF 2014-2020.The MFF review also consists of stimulating economic growth and the recovery of the European Community space, as well as reorienting the EU budget towards concrete results and facing internal and external challenges.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: written. - I voted in favor of the mid-term review of the MFF 2014-2020 (2016/2931 (RSP)), which highlights concerns about the lack of funds available within the current multiannual financial framework and the problem of new crises and priorities have emerged in the past period especially in relation to the refugee and migrant crisis. All this requires significant additional resources from the EU budget, which due to scarce financial resources within the current MFF could not be made available at the beginning of this financial perspective. In the remaining years of the current financial perspective, a realistic, credible, coherent and sustainable EU budget needs to be guaranteed, which must be an expression of the balance between meeting the Union's long-term political priorities and responding to new challenges. Parliament takes a positive view of the proposed amendments to the MFF, but regrets that the Commission has not proposed an increase in the current MFF ceilings, in particular with regard to important policies such as competitiveness for growth and employment; economic, social and territorial cohesion; security and citizenship; global Europe. The mid-term review of the MFF should serve as a good basis for the consensus-building process on the MFF after 2020, which should also be included in the reform of the own resources system.

name: Jean-François JALKH
text: in writing.- This text seeks to increase the ceilings of the multiannual financial framework and therefore to increase the contributions of the Member States.Likewise, it encourages, driven by Europeanist propaganda, the mobility of young Europeans under the age of 18 through free train tickets.Finally, considering the objectives of increasing the resources of the EU, everything suggests that we are heading towards the creation of a European tax.For all these reasons, I voted against.

name: Petr JEŽEK
text: in writing. ‒ I supported the motion for resolution on the mid-term revision of the multiannual financial framework which calls for a real revision of the MFF to address EU current challenges. I welcome the fact that the Commission presented a revision of the MFF, which was too restrictive, to deal with the security and migrations challenges we are facing. This ambitious reform reflects EU political commitments and ensure European money is spent where it is most needed. It was essential for the European Parliament to link the revision of the multiannual financial framework to the 2017 annual budget, as the decisions on the former one are expected to be integrated into the latter. That is why in the EP position the 2017 budget reflects the smart proposal of the mid-term review made by the Commission.

name: Marc JOULAUD
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of the resolution on the mid-term review of the multiannual financial framework (MFF).This proposed revision of the MFF is in line with the European Parliament's desire to make the budget more flexible.For this, the provisions relating to the simplification of budgetary rules and the establishment of a budgetary reserve were widely approved.This flexibility should make it possible to respond better to crises (agricultural, humanitarian or migratory) and to avoid the multiplication of "off-budget" funds.This report was adopted by a large majority, which I welcome.

name: Philippe JUVIN
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of this resolution.To the goodwill of the Commission to increase flexibility and remove certain restrictions to allow the reuse of previous margins or to create a European Union crisis reserve intended to finance responses to crises (migratory, agricultural, humanitarian,etc.), Parliament adds its political will to increase the ceilings in certain headings: growth and employment, security and citizenship, or even economic, social and territorial cohesion.

name: Eva KAILI
text: in writing.- We can only emphasize the inadequacy of the MFF in relation to the real needs of the European Union, such as the recent crises in the refugee, agricultural products, the adequacy of EFSA funding and the high financial needs that arise for the Union inemergency conditions.Significant expansion of the MFF is needed.

name: Petra KAMMEREVERT
text: written. - The proposal contained in A 40 to give all EU citizens an Interrail ticket on their 18th birthday is populist nonsense and calls into question successful EU mobility programs. We urgently need to increase the mobility of young people, but with the Interrail debate the discussion is taking a wrong turn. This means that rail travel through Europe is partially paid for, according to the “watering can principle” without a concept or educational support, and should ultimately benefit wealthier northern Europeans. That sounds sexy, but it's not an investment in the future. ERASMUS + works and lets schoolchildren, trainees and students experience the EU live. The money necessary for a free Interrail pass (according to estimates, the Interrail initiative could cost up to 1.5 billion a year) should flow here so that all young people under 25 years of age can have an international experience through ERASMUS +.
