This is the only way that socially disadvantaged people and young people from middle educational levels can be specifically addressed and better promoted through tailored offers that are regularly accompanied by educational support. We must not allow ERASMUS + to fall behind in favor of a media-effective idea. However, since I support the proposals for medium-term financial planning and an individual vote on this point is not possible, this explanation of vote is necessary.

name: Barbara KAPPEL
text: written.- This motion for a resolution calls for additional funding without giving sufficient reasons.The MFF is to be adjusted accordingly in order to provide funding for the migration crisis, an extension of the EFSI and other programs.I would not have voted in favor of this resolution.

name: Bernd KÖLMEL
text: written. - The report states that the appropriations entered in the current Multiannual Financial Framework (2014-2020) are far too low. In the logic of the current majority in the European Parliament, this is understandable, since in recent years Parliament has always irresponsibly asked for more funds than the Commission proposed, and at the same time always rejected all the cuts proposed by the Council, at the expense of this of European taxpayers. It should be emphasized that the current EU budget does not take sufficient account of the principle of subsidiarity, as some of the planned expenditures could be dealt with much better by the national states or regions and municipalities than at the European level. In addition, especially in cohesion policy and also in individual areas of agricultural policy, there is often a lack of sustainability, goal-orientation and professional success control based on measurable results. Finally, the report also calls for a direct link to the 2017 budget, which is also to be criticized. That is why I rejected the report.

name: Béla KOVÁCS
text: in writing.- In assessing the budget report, I indicated that a mid-term review of the multiannual financial framework for the period 2014-2020 was warranted due to unforeseen emergencies in the Union.These include the migration and refugee crisis, external emergencies, internal security issues, the agricultural crisis, European Fund for Strategic Investments (EFSI) funding and persistently high levels of unemployment.I fully agree with the report, as it is an unacceptable attitude that rich Member States, which levy all profits through their companies, are unwilling to contribute even 1% of their GDP to solving such significant problems.It is very timely for the Council to take the lead not only in nice voices but also in deeds.

name: Ilhan KYUCHYUK
text: in writing. – The mid-term review/revision of the MFF is a real opportunity to adjust the agreed figures and rules in the context of both expected and unexpected developments. In light of this, the current MFF covers the 2014-2020 period and it the first to take the form of a regulation, and the first to contain provisions providing for a mid-term review that may lead to its revision. In fact, there are many current and long—standing economic and political problems such as the refugee crisis, the increased threat of terrorism, the war in Ukraine, the protracted economic crisis in Greece and Brexit require immediate actions. Therefore, although barely two years have passed since the beginning of the current MFF, in order to accommodate these needs and ensure smooth implementation of the EU budget, adjustments and changes should be made.

name: Giovanni LA VIA
text: in writing.- The proposal aims to ensure greater flexibility in the MFF and annual budgets and to better reflect the new EU priorities, which emerged as a result of the crises and challenges that could not be foreseen when it was decided on the seven-year budget for 2014-2020.The mid-term review of the MFF was a clause strongly desired by Parliament at the time of the negotiations, precisely to allow the European budget to be aligned to future needs.We are therefore ready to start talks with the Council, to reach an agreement on a budget that is truly efficient, capable of responding promptly to the migratory and refugee crises, of terrorism and internal security, of the crisis in agriculture and capable of countering,with the help of the Member States, the increase in the unemployment rate especially among young people.

name: Gilles LEBRETON
text: in writing.- I voted against this resolution because it calls for giving more financial means to the EU by increasing the ceilings of the multiannual financial framework (MFF), in particular to face the “challenges” of migration and terrorism (and therefore by increasingState contributions).

name: Bogusław LIBERADZKI
text: in writing.- The problems that the European Union is currently facing, such as migration, the internal security crisis and youth unemployment have necessitated a mid-term review of the Multiannual Financial Framework 2014-2020.Good Commission proposals are greater flexibility and the creation of a crisis reserve.However, it is regrettable that the European Commission has not proposed to raise the current MFF ceilings.I hope that the solutions proposed by the Commission are only a starting point for further negotiations.This revision is not only a chance to find money for new needs, but also the possibility of preventing a shortage of funds for unforeseen liabilities.

name: Sander LOONES
text: written. - The MEPs of the N-VA are of the opinion that the call by the majority of the political groups for higher ceilings for the remainder of the current MFF is not in line with the reforms required of the Member States. For the N-VA, the various programs under the different headings must be tested for their effectiveness and efficiency. Spending priorities should reflect a positive view of the future and not update the status quo. Unfortunately, the circumstances under which the current revision takes place are unchanged from those under which the MFF was negotiated in 2013 and the total MFF commitment appropriations were reduced to 1.00% of the EU's combined gross national revenue: a stagnating economy with Member States in full restructuring. The N-VA delegation therefore does not agree with the request for an increase in the expenditure ceilings and will therefore vote against the motion for a resolution.

name: Javi LÓPEZ
text: written. - I voted in favor of the resolution on the mid-term review of the 2014-2020 Multiannual Financial Framework, to give a clear political response to the presentation of the review of the MFF package presented by the Commission on 14 September. While I broadly welcome the Commission's decision to propose a review of the MFF, I emphasize the limited resources available under the current framework to meet the Union's political commitments and strategic objectives, and in this regard We emphasize, once again, the responsibility of the Member States to match the promises with the necessary means to ensure a response in line with the emerging challenges. I welcome the proposal on flexibility, although I regret that an upward revision of the ceilings of the current MFF is not being proposed, which is necessary if we are to face present and future challenges and meet our objectives. Finally, I call on the Council to start negotiating the financial framework urgently as we will not be able to negotiate the 2017 budget without having a framework under which to negotiate.

name: Juan Fernando LÓPEZ AGUILAR
text: written. - I voted in favor of the resolution on the mid-term review of the 2014-2020 Multiannual Financial Framework, to give a clear political response to the presentation of the review of the MFF package presented by the Commission on 14 September. While I broadly welcome the Commission's decision to propose a review of the MFF, I emphasize the limited resources available under the current framework to meet the Union's political commitments and strategic objectives, and in this regard We emphasize, once again, the responsibility of the Member States to match the promises with the necessary means to ensure a response in line with the emerging challenges. I welcome the proposal on flexibility, although I regret that an upward revision of the ceilings of the current MFF is not being proposed, which is necessary if we are to face present and future challenges and meet our objectives. Finally, I call on the Council to start negotiating the financial framework urgently as we will not be able to negotiate the 2017 budget without having a framework under which to negotiate.

name: Paloma LÓPEZ BERMEJO
text: written.- The resolution reiterates Parliament's priorities for the revision of the MFF, endorsing the financialisation of investments, the austerity conditionality of cohesion and development funds, the privatization of research, the commercialization of agricultural policies and the use of fundsexternal forces to reinforce strong Europe and the geopolitical adventurism of European elites.I have voted against to express my criticism of the current use of European funds, which have become one more instrument of neoliberal policies.

name: Bernd LUCKE
text: written. - The report states that the appropriations entered in the current Multiannual Financial Framework (2014-2020) are far too low. In the logic of the current majority in the European Parliament, this is understandable, since in recent years Parliament has always irresponsibly asked for more funds than the Commission proposed, and at the same time always rejected all the proposals for cuts made by the Council, at the expense of this of European taxpayers. It should be emphasized that the current EU budget does not take sufficient account of the principle of subsidiarity, as some of the planned expenditures could be dealt with much better by the national states or regions and municipalities than at the European level. In addition, especially in cohesion policy and in individual areas of agricultural policy, there is often a lack of sustainability, goal-orientation and professional success monitoring based on measurable results. Finally, the report also calls for a direct link to the 2017 budget, which is also to be criticized. That is why I rejected the report.

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this resolution that calls on the Council to respond to the Commission’s proposal and commence negotiations with Parliament, to ensure that an agreement on both the 2017 budget and the MFF revision can be reached before the end of 2016.

name: Petr MACH
text: in writing.- I voted against.I do not agree with the statement that the EU has little money from citizens and Member States.I also do not agree with the proposal for a new spending program 'European network ticket Interrail for the 18th birthday', I consider it to be Europopulism and a waste of taxpayers' money.

name: Ivana MALETIĆ
text: written. - The European Parliament's concern about the lack of funds available in the Multiannual Financial Framework (MFF) stems from a number of new priorities that have emerged in recent years, such as migration and the refugee crisis, internal security issues, the agricultural crisis, and European funding. the Strategic Investment Fund (EFSI) and the consistently high unemployment rate, especially among young people. Responding to these challenges requires additional funding from the EU budget that cannot be realized due to the limited financial resources available in the current MFF, so the budget must align with the European Union's political commitments and strategic objectives. The proposed changes should fit into the 2017 budget, in particular the flexibility of the MFF. The Commission intends to simplify the financial rules, which is an important conclusion for a medium-term audit, and the simplification itself must be aimed at improving and implementing the user environment. The mid-term review of the MFF should also be the beginning of the alignment process that is important for the post-MFF 2020, so I supported this resolution.

name: Vladimír MAŇKA
text: in writing.- The revision of the Multiannual Financial Framework set for 2014-2020 clearly shows the need for greater flexibility and clarity so that it can respond more proactively to changing conditions and needs.I therefore agree with the Commission's proposal to carry out a full revision of the Financial Regulation, as well as to amend 15 sectoral rules in order to achieve simplification of the financial rules.Simplified and transparent financial rules will be clearer not only for the professional but also for the general public of the Union, while at the same time enabling effective and more effective control over the management of budgetary resources.

name: Louis-Joseph MANSCOUR
text: in writing. - During the negotiation of the multiannual financial framework (MFF) 2014-2020, the European Parliament had obtained that a mid-term review be planned. This is what the Commission proposed when it presented this draft revision on September 14th. The text begins by recalling the shortcomings of the current MFF in the face of the challenges that have emerged since its adoption. It recommends that the ceilings be revised upwards for the headings which are in dire need of new liquidity: competitiveness for growth and employment, economic, social and territorial cohesion, security and citizenship and Europe in the world. This report, which also proposes measures to avoid a payments crisis, underlines the importance of continuing to finance the Youth Employment Initiative, but also of offering more flexibility in the budget. Faced with the humanitarian disaster born of the refugee crisis, the deep economic and social crisis that continues in Europe and the strengthening of the terrorist threat, this text calls on the EU to endow itself with a budget to meet these challenges . I therefore support this report.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: in writing.- I am voting against the motion for a resolution on the mid-term review of the MFF 2014-2020, for the reasons I mentioned in detail in my speech to the Plenary Session of the European Parliament in Strasbourg on 25 October 2016, and because this report is incomplete and well-founded.

name: Emmanuel MAUREL
text: in writing. - Faced with a monetary union that deprives the monetary tool and exchange rate policy, fiscal union is still in its infancy. Indeed, the European Union sees its budget over 7 years (the multiannual financial framework, MFF) limited to 1% of its GDP. During the last legislature, it was even lowered below this figure! However, since that date, the Greek crisis, the launch of the Juncker Plan, the refugee crisis and the fight against youth unemployment have led to a stronger commitment from the Union. This commitment cannot be translated eternally into financial artifices or “extra-program” arrangements. In the resolution on the MFF, the Social Democrats managed to get the European Parliament's own-initiative report on this issue to remain a firm line: it is imperative to create the EU's own resources to respond to the payments crisis . States agree to open commitment appropriations each year, but refuse to increase or even often reduce payment appropriations (the money disbursed). This situation is based on the excessive dependence of the Union budget on national contributions. This resolution is clear on these points, I voted in favor.

name: Georg MAYER
text: written.- This European Parliament resolution is about the multiannual financial framework (MFF).Increased funds are to be made available here for dealing with new crises.I am opposed to a further increase as I want the funds to be used more efficiently.I therefore reject this resolution.

name: Valentinas MAZURONIS
text: in writing.- The revision of the Multiannual Financial Framework is an appropriate opportunity to respond to the budgetary difficulties currently facing the EU.In recent years, many new crises have emerged and new priorities have emerged: a crisis of migrants and refugees, external emergencies, internal security problems, an agricultural crisis, and high levels of unemployment, especially youth unemployment.I therefore welcome the Commission's proposal for changes to the MFF package.

name: Jean-Luc MÉLENCHON
text: in writing. - This report finally opens the debate, promised in 2014 during the European elections, on a revision of the European budgetary framework for the period 2014-2020, which was adopted in 2013. This budgetary framework is placed under the sign of austerity since 'he cut 50 billion credits. Meanwhile, the population of the EU has increased by 10 million inhabitants compared to the previous programming! The report repeats its demands for a review of the 2014-2020 framework, in identical terms to what Parliament has been saying since 2013 ... in vain. But he does not draw any conclusions from this in relation to the Commission and the Council. It welcomes the Commission's decision to propose an amended regulation of the financial framework. However, the Commission is only proposing redeployments and no increase in budget ceilings, while Parliament considered them too low. And the report calls in a completely hypocritical way to integrate from the 2017 budget the “revised framework” finally obtained. At the same time, however, he supports the Commission's 2017 budget proposal, which precisely does not include this “revised framework”. I vote against this gibberish which endorses emptiness and submission.

name: Joëlle MÉLIN
text: in writing.- This text calls for giving more financial means to the EU by increasing the ceilings of the MFF, in particular to face the migratory and terrorist "challenges" (and therefore by increasing the contributions of States).An opening is also mentioned with regard to the increase in the EU's own resources and therefore the idea of a European tax.I therefore voted against this resolution.

name: Nuno MELO
text: in writing.- The EU budget must correspond to the European Union's political commitments and strategic objectives.The revision of the Multiannual Financial Framework is a unique opportunity to respond to the budgetary difficulties that currently undermine the credibility of the European Union.Hence my vote in favor.

name: Roberta METSOLA
text: in writing. ‒ I supported this resolution, which calls for more resources in the Multiannual Financial Framework in order for the Union to tackle the multiple crises that have arisen over the past few years. It is my hope that the mid-term revision will yield positive results to overcome the existing disparities.

name: Louis MICHEL
text: in writing. - The European Union must be careful not to make a budget say what it cannot accomplish. Therefore, in parallel with the annual budgetary exercise, it is essential to take into account the multiannual financial framework (MFF) established for the period 2014-2020. A mid-term review of it is therefore a wise proposition. In this regard, I spoke in favor of the motion for a resolution relating to the mid-term review of the 2014-2020 MFF. Faced with new security and migration challenges, we must call on the Member States on the need to reform EU finances. This political link established between the annual budgetary exercise and the revision of the MFF is a challenge for the Council, which will examine the two dossiers in two different bodies. Indeed, the "General Affairs" Council will start examining the proposed revision of the MFF on November 15, while the budgetary conciliation will be held with the "Economic and Financial Affairs" Council on November 17 and 18, 2016.

name: Marlene MIZZI
text: in writing. ‒ The Multiannual Financial Framework (MFF), which sets the framework for the EU’s annual budget, needs to be revised to allow for additional funding and greater flexibility. This helps the EU to deal with the unprecedented number of challenges that Europe is facing and will be facing in the future. The report points out the insufficiency of available resources as well as criticism for the Commission’s proposal. This is why I have voted in favour of the position on the Commission’s proposal on the revision of the MFF 2014-2020.

name: Csaba MOLNÁR
text: in writing. - the draft resolution of the Committee on Budgets highlights a number of new crises and priorities in recent years, namely migration and refugee crises, external emergencies, internal security issues, the agricultural crisis, the financing of the European Fund for Strategic Investments and persistently high unemployment, particularly among young people, and the recent ratification of the climate change agreement by the Union. In this context, it reiterates the European Parliament's constant concern that the resources available under the current multiannual financial framework are insufficient. He emphasized that a significant additional resources from the EU budget were needed to respond adequately to these challenges. It recalls in this context that, under Article 311 TFEU, "the Union shall provide itself with the means necessary to attain its objectives and carry through its policies". It is convinced that the revision of the multiannual financial framework offers a unique opportunity to overcome the budgetary difficulties currently threatening the credibility of the European Union. He also points out that restoring confidence in the European project requires an EU budget that is more transparent and accessible to citizens. He therefore calls on the Council to assume its responsibilities and ensure a realistic, credible, comprehensive and sustainable EU budget for the remaining years of the current financial framework. I supported the draft.

name: Cláudia MONTEIRO DE AGUIAR
text: in writing. - The lack of resources available under the current multiannual financial framework (MFF) is, as the rapporteur expresses, a constant concern of the European Parliament. The new crises and priorities that have emerged over the past few years, namely the migration and refugee crisis, external emergency situations, internal security issues, the crisis in agriculture, the financing of the European Fund for Strategic Investments (EFSI) and the persistence of high levels of unemployment, especially among young people, as well as climate change, oblige us to permanently rethink the MFF. I support the Commission's proposal to create an EU crisis reserve as an instrument for reacting quickly to crises, as well as events with serious humanitarian or security implications; I believe that the mobilization of this special instrument in the event of a crisis will provide a clear and effective solution to the necessary additional funding; I also support the proposal to use canceled appropriations.

name: Sophie MONTEL
text: in writing.- This text aims to increase the financial capacities of the EU, which would potentially result in an increase in the States' contribution to the EU budget.It is even envisaged a European tax.This text must therefore be rejected.

name: Nadine MORANO
text: in writing.- I voted for this text relating to the mid-term review of the multiannual financial framework.While the European Parliament, unlike the Commission, is in favor of increasing the ceilings, it nonetheless supports the latter's proposals.Indeed, better flexibility to allow the reuse of previous margins and the creation of a crisis reserve to finance responses to different crises are two essential elements today.

name: Luigi MORGANO
text: in writing. - By voting in favor of this resolution, as I did, Parliament is taking a clear position on the future of financing the EU budget. Although brief, this resolution highlights many of the salient data and issues that have characterized the implementation of the MFF so far: critical issues and delays in the implementation of programs; the need to revise the ceilings of commitment and payment appropriations upwards; the urgent need to find new sources of financing beyond national contributions, ie the "own resources" of the European Union. Among the general issues, an important reference to the strengthening of the Youth Guarantee, the request to continue the restoration of the programs implemented for the launch of the Juncker plan for strategic investments, the need to support the mobility of young people through the "Interrail pass for eighteen-year-olds ", albeit with the remarks I have already reported in another Plenary. We use the MFF to show that our strategic priority is a Europe that is more cohesive within itself, stronger and a global player, truly closer to its citizens. But from a dry discussion like that on the financial perspectives, it is possible, through the choices made, to recover a renewed Europeanism that places the 500 million citizens we represent here at the center of the action.

name: József NAGY
text: in writing.- It is very important that the European Union's financial instruments are used properly and that the budget is set up in accordance with the EU's principles and objectives.Today, we discussed priorities, assessed the current situation and agreed on a mid-term review of the multiannual financial framework.The multiannual financial framework covers the years 2014-2020, and I think it is timely to update it.We had the opportunity to evaluate the effectiveness of the financial instruments used so far and to rethink our future plans.I am particularly pleased that we have also managed to smuggle the topic of funding the People's Party Interrail proposal into the debate.

name: Victor NEGRESCU
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted for this motion for a resolution that stresses the deficiency of available resources under the current multiannual financial framework (MFF) and will also respond to budgetary difficulties that are currently putting in danger the credibility of the European Union.

name: Norica NICOLAI
text: signed up. - I have decided to abstain from today's vote on the revision of the EU's multiannual financial framework, as the proposals contained in this report are contrary to Romania's interests, and their adoption will directly reduce the funds allocated to the country I represent. Of course, the challenges of recent years on migration and economic instability, which could not be anticipated at the time of the initial planning of the 2014-2020 budget year, now require more than ever the revision of the MFF to redistribute funds. Unfortunately, much of this money will be unfairly taken from money not absorbed by the Member States. In this context, I cannot claim that these reallocations should be made by moving the amounts from funds of major importance for Romania's development. Although the Romanian authorities are to blame for the weak attraction of EU funds, I do not think that all citizens should be punished for this slowdown in public administration, which I hope will recover in the near future.

name: Luděk NIEDERMAYER
text: in writing.- I supported the resolution on the mid-term review of the multiannual financial framework, drawing attention to the lack of resources under the current multiannual financial framework (MFF) in connection with the migration and refugee crisis, crisis events abroad and internal security problems.I am pleased that our group has succeeded in emphasizing the mobility of young people in the face of the threat of populism and the spread of misinformation, and in supporting the implementation of the new 'European Interrail 18th Birthday Network Ticket' initiative, which means that every European citizen shouldwhen he was eighteen, he received a free Interrail network ticket.The most appropriate and budget-friendly way to finance this initiative will still need to be found, but it is important to express political support at this stage.

name: Franz OBERMAYR
text: written.- I also spoke out against this report, as more money is being asked for the migration crisis.The extension of EFSI and other programs is also requested.In total, the report only contains requests for additional financial resources without justification for which programs they should be used.

name: Urmas PAET
text: in writing.- I supported.Since the establishment of the multiannual financial framework, Europe has been hit by crises that have not been taken into account.In the current review, it is important to adapt the framework to enable the EU to address its budgetary challenges and thus ensure a realistic and sustainable EU budget.

name: Demetris PAPADAKIS
text: in writing. - The multiannual financial framework (MFF) for 2014-2020 is not enough to enable the EU to deal with the many new crises and priorities that have emerged in recent years. If we want to be serious about responding to critical issues such as immigration and the refugee crisis, terrorism and internal security, the crisis in agriculture or prolonged high unemployment, especially among young people, an ambitious MFF review is needed. There is frustration with the fact that the European Commission is not proposing any upward revision of the current MFF ceilings in its new proposal. However, I supported the resolution as the EP called for greater flexibility and the creation of a crisis reserve to be set up within the framework of the European budget in order to avoid ad hoc solutions, such as the creation of emergency funds.

name: Margot PARKER
text: in writing. ‒ The Multi-Annual Financial Framework is the long-term budget planning for the EU, which sets the maximum the EU can spend. The current period is for 2014-2020, set at EUR 960 billion. When the current MFF was agreed, David Cameron came back from Brussels claiming that he had achieved a cut in the European Union budget. Fast-forward three years, and we see the use of a ‘Flexibility Instrument’ and an Emergency Aid Reserve which operate outside these MFF spending limits. Money collected from fines is no longer returned to the Member States, but used to increase the EU budget through the back door. In practice, this has led to an EU budget of over EUR 1 trillion in today’s prices over the seven-year term of the MFF. This MFF ‘review’ adds to the flexibility; unspent money in any area will be used to increase the budget in others. This resolution calls for the MFF ceilings to be amended and for more resources to be given to the EU budget. Anything which costs British taxpayers even more money in EU spending is inappropriate in the light of the mandate received from the British people on the Brexit vote.

name: Aldo PATRICIELLO
text: in writing.- I thought it appropriate to come out in favor of the MFF mid-term review as I consider the proposed changes to the MFF package to be positive.These changes appear to be consistent with the objectives set by the institutions, so I voted in favor.

name: Marijana PETIR
text: written. - I believe we all share the concern about the lack of funds available within the current Multiannual Financial Framework (MFF). We are witnessing the emergence of new crises and priorities whose scale we could not have foreseen a few years ago. The refugee and migration crisis, internal security problems and various unforeseen external situations, the financing of the European Fund for Strategic Investments and the long-term high level of unemployment are major challenges for our community. A satisfactory response requires an adequate amount of additional resources from the European Union Budget which, due to the scarcity of the current MFF, could not be provided in the first years of this financial perspective. As some commendable proposals from the Commission's statement on this subject, I would like to highlight the announcement of simplification of financial rules and extension of flexibility provisions, which have already proved crucial for financing the response to the migration crisis and several new policy initiatives. The EU budget simply needs to be aligned with its political commitments and strategic objectives. The very credibility of the European Union is at stake, and I am therefore voting in favor of this Resolution on the revision of the MFF in the middle of 2014-2020. and I call on the Council to take responsibility, reconcile words and deeds and ensure a realistic, sustainable and credible budget in the remaining years of the current financial perspective.

name: Florian PHILIPPOT
text: in writing.- This text always recommends more resources for the EU and provides for the funding of very expensive propaganda projects, such as the free inter-rail pass for all 18-year-olds.He also calls for the creation of a European tax.I am obviously opposed to all these abuses and I vote against the orientations of this mid-term review.

name: Pina PICIERNO
text: in writing. - The Commission's proposal to revise the multiannual financial framework goes in the right direction as regards flexibility, but does not address the real problem of this issue, namely the amount of appropriations for the headings most under pressure due to the huge political challenges to which Europe faces. Migration flows, youth employment and the development of neighboring countries are issues to be addressed with the highest priority and the allocations that we find ourselves today in the MFF are completely insufficient because they are calibrated on a situation, that of 5 years ago, totally different from today's one. This revision will be one of the few opportunities to restore breath and credibility to this EU which should look more at the lives of its citizens and not just at the budgets of its member states. If we want a Europe that is not just about markets and the economy, but above all about rights and solidarity, we must demonstrate this with an adequate budget, but at the same time with respect for the treaties by all Member States: two elements that either go hand in hand, or both of them are missing.

name: Tonino PICULA
text: written. - The European Parliament has previously expressed its concern about the insufficient budgetary resources available under the current Multiannual Financial Framework (MFF). The problem is a series of serious crises that have emerged over the past few years, especially the migration and refugee crisis, internal security problems, external contingencies, the crisis in the agricultural sector, high youth unemployment, environmental challenges, etc. A revision of the MFF is needed. the aim is to ensure a balance between meeting long-term policy priorities and being able to adequately respond to new challenges. I welcome the Commission's decision to revise the MFF. An important provision is the establishment of the EU crisis reserve as an instrument of prompt response to crises and unforeseen situations with serious humanitarian or security implications. The mobilization of this special instrument in the event of a crisis will provide an effective solution for additional funding if needed in a given situation. On the other hand, the Commission unfortunately does not propose to raise the current MFF ceilings. The ceilings relating to Competitiveness for Growth and Employment, Economic, Social and Territorial Cohesion, Security and Citizenship, and Global Europe are insufficient and need to be revised more if the EU is to respond to existing challenges and meet its policy objectives.

name: João PIMENTA LOPES
text: in writing. - In the context of this review, we follow the need for the ceilings of headings 1a (Competitiveness for growth and employment), 1b (Economic, social and territorial cohesion) and 2 (PAC and PCP) to be revised upwards so that the Union can respond to the challenges and fulfill its political objectives, such as Parliament's demands for full compensation for EFSI-related cuts affecting the Horizon 2020 program and the Connecting Europe Facility, the continuation of the Employment Initiative for Young people at the same level as the 2014 and 2015 annual allocations. However, there are red lines in this report that have to do with budget financing, in which we continue to advocate that the RBN route be privileged, and with the unanimity rule that should prevail as a guarantee of having a budget that is positive for all national States and not just for some, and we will even say for the minority of Member States that today hold the majority of wishes.

name: Pavel POC
text: in writing. - The current multiannual financial framework no longer meets the current needs and challenges facing the Union. That is why I supported the motion for a resolution on the revision of this budgetary instrument. In 2013, when this framework was approved, it was not yet known to what extent the old continent would be affected by the migration and refugee crisis, for how long it would not be possible to restart investment and mobilize young people and their employment. I voted in favor of this report, although the resolution is based on the content of its predecessor, ie the MFF resolution of 6 July 2016. Unlike the earlier report, however, it does not correctly contain regressive regulations to address the migration crisis causing further disintegration on the European continent. It is necessary to realize that the European budget needs more flexibility, only then will it be able to respond to current and future challenges. I firmly hope that the outcome of the vote in Parliament will be reflected by the Council and that the Slovak Presidency will be given a mandate so that interinstitutional negotiations can take place as soon as possible, going hand in hand with approving the future budget. If the representatives of the Member States are procrastinating, the blame for the fact that the EU budget continues to face several serious problems will lie solely on their shoulders. As announced in the current framework regulation, the European Parliament is ready to actively seek a solution.

name: Franck PROUST
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of this text, which follows the proposals of the European Commission, wishing to send a clear message: the European Union's long-term multiannual financial framework (MFF) must know how to adapt and resistto crises.Like the budgetary approach for 2017, the revision of the MFF must be made in the light of emerging priorities for European public action.Clearly, current financial resources at European level are not sufficient and new mechanisms must be put in place, such as a permanent financial reserve which could be mobilized in the event of a crisis (migration, humanitarian, agricultural, etc.).We must also salute here the desire of the European Commission to simplify the mobilization and use of the various financial instruments, which is therefore part of an ambitious revision of the general financial rules.

name: Paulo RANGEL
text: in writing. - The possibility of revising the Multiannual Financial Framework is important in order to respond to the new challenges facing Europe, such as the migrant crisis, the maintenance of internal security and the change in the persistent and high numbers of youth unemployment. It is essential to ensure compensatory measures for cuts related to the European Strategic Investment Fund on programs such as Horizon 2020 and the Connecting Europe Facility, as well as continuing funding for the Youth Employment Initiative at the same levels as 2014 and 2015. Likewise , funds must be made available to provide an adequate solution to the migrant crisis. I welcome the Commission's intention to simplify the financial rules, as well as to create a European crisis reserve in order to serve as an instrument for quick reaction in more problematic situations. I support this motion for a resolution on the revision of the Multiannual Financial Framework.

name: Julia REID
text: in writing. ‒ The Multi-Annual Financial Framework is the long-term budget planning for the EU, which sets the maximum the EU can spend. The current period is for 2014-2020, set at EUR 960 billion. When the current MFF was agreed, David Cameron came back from Brussels claiming that he had achieved a cut in the European Union budget. Fast-forward three years, and we see the use of a ‘Flexibility Instrument’ and an Emergency Aid Reserve which operate outside these MFF spending limits. Money collected from fines is no longer returned to the Member States, but used to increase the EU budget through the back door. In practice, this has led to an EU budget of over EUR 1 trillion in today’s prices over the seven-year term of the MFF. This MFF ‘review’ adds to the flexibility; unspent money in any area will be used to increase the budget in others. This resolution calls for the MFF ceilings to be amended and for more resources to be given to the EU budget. Anything which costs British taxpayers even more money in EU spending is inappropriate in the light of the mandate received from the British people on the Brexit vote.

name: Sofia RIBEIRO
text: in writing. - I voted in favor, considering that the resources available under the current multiannual financial framework (MFF) are insufficient in view of the number of new crises and priorities that have emerged over the last few years, namely the migration and refugee crisis, external emergency situations , internal security issues, the crisis in agriculture, the financing of the European Fund for Strategic Investments (EFSI) and the persistence of high levels of unemployment, especially among young people. An adequate response to these challenges requires a substantial amount of additional funding from the EU budget, which could not be fully provided in the early years of the current perspective due to the scarcity of financial resources available under the current MFF. The revision of the Multiannual Financial Framework is a unique opportunity to respond to the budgetary difficulties that currently undermine the credibility of the European Union; the Council is therefore urged to assume its responsibilities in order to align words and deeds, and to ensure a realistic, credible, consistent and sustainable EU budget for the remaining years from the current perspective.

name: Inma RODRÍGUEZ-PIÑERO
text: written. - I voted in favor of the resolution on the mid-term review of the 2014-2020 Multiannual Financial Framework, to give a clear political response to the presentation of the review of the MFF package presented by the Commission on 14 September. While I broadly welcome the Commission's decision to propose a review of the MFF, I emphasize the limited resources available under the current framework to meet the Union's political commitments and strategic objectives, and in this regard We emphasize, once again, the responsibility of the Member States to match the promises with the necessary means to ensure a response in line with the emerging challenges. I welcome the proposal on flexibility, although I regret that an upward revision of the ceilings of the current MFF is not being proposed, which is necessary if we are to face present and future challenges and meet our objectives. Finally, I call on the Council to start negotiating the financial framework urgently as we will not be able to negotiate the 2017 budget without having a framework under which to negotiate.

name: Ulrike RODUST
text: written. - The suggestion in paragraph 10 to give young EU citizens an Interrail ticket on their 18th birthday is questionable as it undermines the successful EU mobility programs. Of course, the mobility of young people needs to be increased, but I am convinced that the Interrail debate sets the wrong tone in this discussion. The undifferentiated measure would give preference to richer young people in Europe (since in addition to the train ticket there were also accommodation and maintenance costs), there is still a lack of concepts or educational objectives. There is no doubt about the functioning of the existing ERASMUS + program, because it opens up the EU to schoolchildren, trainees and students. The estimated up to 1.5 billion annually, which the Interrail measure would cost, should rather benefit ERASMUS +, so that all young people under the age of 25 can have an experience abroad. This would also allow the programs to be geared towards the socially disadvantaged and young people from the middle-class. Apart from this point, I support the proposal on medium-term financial planning - but since it is not possible to vote individually on this point, I decided to give this explanation of vote.

name: Claude ROLIN
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of this report because I firmly believe that it is necessary to go further than the extensions of budgetary flexibility proposed in the MFF package (multiannual financial framework).This is what I pleaded for as shadow rapporteur for the opinion of the Employment and Social Affairs Committee on this subject.Among the major challenges facing the European Union is the employment of young people.In this regard, I bitterly regret the Commission’s decision to only propose 1 billion in reinforcement until 2020 when we have already used 6 billion euros so far.I also deeply regret that several sections have not seen their ceiling raised.

name: Virginie ROZIÈRE
text: in writing. - I supported this resolution calling for the alignment of the Union's political objectives with its resources. Faced with the chronic investment deficit, youth unemployment, the migration crisis, the climate emergency, the European Union budget must allow an operational response to all these challenges. The multiannual financial framework is now obsolete due to the multiple crises affecting the European Union. It will therefore have to be revised at the same time as the European Union's budget for 2017 is adopted. This is the meaning of this resolution, which gives Parliament a mandate to obtain from the Council the flexibility proposed by the European Commission, higher ceilings and additional resources on a number of priority programs. Parliament calls for negotiations to also cover the next financial perspective in order to put an end to the structural shortage caused by the growing imbalance between the weakness of own resources and national contributions. Parliament's message is therefore clear, for the Member States now to take a stand for a budget that finally meets our needs!

name: Fernando RUAS
text: in writing. - The past few years have unfortunately increased the number of crises and urgencies that the EU has to deal with, which include managing the migratory crisis, external emergency situations, internal security, combating unemployment, sustainability of agriculture and the financing of the European Strategic Investment Fund. In view of this scenario, the adequate response to these pressing challenges requires a substantial amount of additional funding from the European budget, which cannot be provided in the coming years, due to the scarce financial resources available under the current multiannual financial framework. Therefore, there is an urgent need to review it in order to respond to the current budgetary difficulties that jeopardize the EU's credibility with regions, municipalities, young people, companies, farmers, researchers, among others. This motion for a resolution calls for a review of the current framework, which ensures a realistic, credible, coherent, sustainable budget and which respects the just aspirations of European citizens. As I agree with its content, I voted in favor, since only a revision based on the proposed molds will ensure a balance between those that are the urgent needs in the face of the great current challenges and those that are the future European commitments.

name: Tokia SAÏFI
text: in writing. - I voted in favor of this resolution which sets Parliament's priorities in the mid-term review procedure of the multiannual financial framework for 2017-2020. This text insists on the fact that the European Union must update its long-term financial framework in order to better resist unforeseen crises and respond to new priorities that have emerged in recent years. It is indeed crucial that the Union's budget be more flexible in order to respond more quickly and efficiently to current challenges such as terrorism, internal security, the migration crisis, the agricultural crisis and even high unemployment. As such, this resolution welcomes the fact that the Commission has incorporated, in its MFF review project, Parliament's proposal to create a permanent reserve within the European budget which could be mobilized in the event of a crisis. Finally, I supported this text because it calls for taking the opportunity of the revision of the MFF to make post-2020 commitments such as a reform of the Union's own resources system.

name: Lola SÁNCHEZ CALDENTEY
text: written. - The European Parliament does not have powers to define the Multiannual Financial Framework, which is the scheme that structures and limits the evolution of the budget over 7 years. It is the Council who decides. However, the pressure of the Union's crisis circumstances has generated a parliamentary consensus on the need to strengthen European budgets to face existing challenges (refugees, investment crisis, security, employment, etc…). The Resolution points out many positive aspects. Urges to increase resources, reform the system of own resources, assess the new flexibility conditions of the new MFF, criticize the Council, ask to withdraw the "rebates" (discounts on contributions from more than 10 Member States to the European budget), give the possibility of reusing non-used resources and unity of the Union budget against intergovernmental funds. However, the resolution seems like a good-looking facelift to legitimize itself, because a negotiation in which Parliament decides is not really at stake. In fact, the budget proposal for 2017 goes in the opposite direction, thereby reducing the credibility of this resolution. That is why I have abstained.

name: Maria Lidia SENRA RODRÍGUEZ
text: written.- The resolution reiterates Parliament's priorities for the revision of the MFF, endorsing the financialisation of investments, the austerity conditionality of cohesion and development funds, the privatization of research, the commercialization of agricultural policies and the use of fundsexternal forces to reinforce strong Europe and the geopolitical adventurism of European elites.I have voted against to express my criticism of the current use of European funds, which have become one more instrument of neoliberal policies.

name: Branislav ŠKRIPEK
text: in writing.- I voted against.I am of the opinion that there is no need to revise the MFF, with an increase in individual items and an increase in drawing limits.I would rather welcome resources to support SMEs, support youth employment and support for migration programs, by shifting funding from other budget lines and making more efficient use of existing EU resources.

name: Monika SMOLKOVÁ
text: in writing. - When the Multiannual Financial Framework (MFF) for 2014-2020 was approved, one of the conditions for its approval was that a mid-term review be carried out. This is also due to the fact that in 2013, the year of its design and approval, we could not have foreseen many of the circumstances that have arisen in the meantime. These include the migration and refugee crisis, external emergencies, internal security issues, the agricultural crisis, the financing of the European Fund for Strategic Investments and the persistent unemployment rate, especially for young people. The revision of the multiannual financial framework provides a unique opportunity to respond to the budgetary difficulties that currently threaten the credibility of the European Union. As part of the revision of the MFF, the Commission proposes to simplify the financial rules, which the EP agreed to. We also supported the Commission's proposal for a full revision of the Financial Regulation, as well as for amendments to 15 sectoral rules. This simplification should contribute to improving and streamlining the implementation conditions for beneficiaries.

name: Igor ŠOLTES
text: in writing.- The mid-term review of the MFF represents a unique opportunity to respond to the crises currently plaguing the European Union.Since the adoption of the said financial framework in 2013, the Union has not fully recovered in economic and social terms.The European Fund for Strategic Investments has been launched and the European Union has made new commitments (the Paris Agreement), so the new financial framework should take these changes into account.The report proposes an increase in the budget for most priorities and a more environmentally friendly budget in general, but at the same time calls for more flexibility and supports the Commission's proposal in this area.Due to the recent decision of the United Kingdom to leave the European Union, the audit also mentions the financial aspects of this process and the introduction of a change in the management of funds for the next financial framework, which will start in 2020.supported

name: Joachim STARBATTY
text: written. - The report states that the appropriations entered in the current Multiannual Financial Framework (2014-2020) are far too low. In the logic of the current majority in the European Parliament, this is understandable, since in recent years Parliament has always irresponsibly asked for more funds than the Commission proposed, and at the same time always rejected all the cuts proposed by the Council, at the expense of this of European taxpayers. It should be emphasized that the current EU budget does not take sufficient account of the principle of subsidiarity, as some of the planned expenditures could be dealt with much better by the national states or regions and municipalities than at the European level. In addition, especially in cohesion policy and also in individual areas of agricultural policy, there is often a lack of sustainability, goal-orientation and professional success control based on measurable results. Finally, the report also calls for a direct link to the 2017 budget, which is also to be criticized. That is why I rejected the report.

name: Ivan ŠTEFANEC
text: in writing.- European financial instruments need to be flexible and more adaptable to the current economic situation and challenges.Following the opening of the multiannual financial framework, we could reassess its headings and, if necessary, move the funds released to areas of higher priority, such as job creation.

name: Beatrix von STORCH
text: written.- I did not agree to the resolution of the EU Parliament on the “mid-term revision of the MFF 2014-2020”.With chutzpah, the report claims that the resources available in the current Multiannual Financial Framework (MFF) are insufficient.It is really a cheek to say that the funds available are insufficient.Quite hidden at the end, the report also calls for a reform of the own resources system - which includes the introduction of new own resources, which can significantly reduce the share of GNI contributions to the EU budget.In other words, the EU is demanding its own tax collection right.

name: Dubravka ŠUICA
text: written.- There is a visible lack of funds needed to achieve the EU's objectives and policies set out in the Multiannual Financial Framework (MFF).In the past few years, unforeseen crises have arisen, which require a revision of the MFF.The new priorities relate primarily to large-scale migration and the refugee crisis that has gripped Europe.External and internal security problems have emerged, crises in agriculture and investment, rising unemployment among European citizens, and the recent ratification of the Paris Agreement on Climate Change require some resources to implement it.I support the motion for a resolution on the revision of the MFF in the middle of the period 2014-2020, as I believe that the revision of the MFF provides an opportunity to overcome the current budgetary difficulties.

name: Patricija ŠULIN
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of the motion for a resolution at the end of the debate on the Commission statement on the mid-term review of the Multiannual Financial Framework 2014-2020.We are facing many challenges that could not be predicted in the preparation of the multiannual financial framework, especially migrant or.refugee crisis.We will need considerable additional funding from the European budget to respond adequately to all challenges.The EU budget must be in line with the European Union's political commitments and strategic objectives: migration challenges and slow economic growth following the economic crisis, funding for research and infrastructure projects, as well as projects to tackle youth unemployment

name: Neoklis SYLIKIOTIS
text: in writing. - We disagreed with the logic of the austerity of the Multiannual Financial Framework (MFF). However, in a revision we could agree to an increase in funding for Erasmus + and COSME, for example, although we know that these programs are not enough to change the EU's philosophy on public investment and voluntary (instead of indirectly compulsory) immigration. We voted to abstain from the mid-term review of the MFF, in order to take a specific position when we have clear indications of the revised MFF.

name: Eleftherios SYNADINOS
text: in writing. - The Multiannual Financial Framework as a means of expressing the Union's economic policy is a failed model. The current MFF has failed to meet the challenges posed in the first half of its implementation. The planning of the allocation of financial resources over a period of 7 years, using ceilings per year and enforcing them, while at the same time pursuing growth and innovation leads to distortions of any political priorities and strategic goals, but also to the subdued response of emerging threats and challenges.

name: Tibor SZANYI
text: in writing. - I voted in favor of the motion for a resolution stating that the resources available under the multiannual financial framework are insufficient. I agree that new crises and priorities have emerged in recent times, such as the refugee issue, external emergencies and internal security issues, the crisis in agriculture, persistently high unemployment and climate policy challenges. In the light of all this, and in the light of the conclusions of the review carried out in the first half of the financial cycle, I believe that the possibility of adding additional resources should be examined. Only in this way can political commitments and the EU's strategic objectives meet, and only in this way can we maintain the credibility of the European Union. I agree that all this cannot be achieved with a simple reallocation of resources, as all this would be to the detriment of existing programs and policies. The proposal explicitly calls for the reductions made at the start of the European Structural and Investment Fund to be reinstated in the second half of the financial cycle, as these reductions have had a significant impact on Horizon 2020 and the European Network Development Facility. He also called for an increase in the chapters on migration and the refugee crisis. Together with the motion, I also agree with the plan to simplify financial instruments initiated by the European Commission.

name: Adam SZEJNFELD
text: in writing. - Changes to the multiannual financial framework are absolutely necessary. The EP report believes that the revision of the multiannual financial framework provides a unique opportunity to respond to the budgetary difficulties currently threatening the credibility of the European Union, while calling on the Council to ensure a credible, coherent, realistic and balanced EU budget for the remaining years of the current financial perspective. The document reiterates its call for the full rebalancing of the European Fund for Strategic Investments (EFSI) cuts to Horizon 2020 and Connecting Europe Facility. It also called for the continuation of the Youth Employment Initiative. Moreover, in view of the current migration and refugee crisis, which was unpredictable when the MFF was established, it is necessary to increase the resources available to deal with the effects of the current situation. At the same time, it called for a significant increase in the flexibility of the EU budget so that it could respond more effectively to the new challenges currently facing the Community.

name: Marc TARABELLA
text: in writing.- I voted for the mid-term review of the MFF.Let us stress, however, that the insufficient resources available in the multiannual financial framework are a source of constant concern for the European Parliament.It cannot be denied the number of new crises and new priorities that have emerged in recent years, including the migrant and refugee crisis, external emergencies, internal security issues, the agricultural crisis, thefinancing of the European Fund for strategic investments and the persistence of high unemployment, especially among young people.

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the MFF resolution backing the main elements of the Commission’s proposal to revise the multiannual financial framework (MFF) 2014-2020. Indeed, I welcome the proposals in the MFF package as regards extending the budgetary flexibility and I believe that the proposal to create an EU crisis reserve as an instrument to make it possible to react swiftly to crises and other events with serious humanitarian or security implications is important.

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: written.- Basic function of the Multiannual Budget Framework 2014-2020.is to set limits on the amount of money the European Union can spend each budget year.Last month, the Commission announced a proposal to revise the multiannual budgetary framework in the middle of the programming period, requesting a budget increase of € 3.8 billion.As the tendency of most groups in the European Parliament is to link this proposal to the vote on the 2017 budget, and in line with the reasons for my opposition to the budget proposal, this proposal did not receive my support either.

name: Romana TOMC
text: in writing. - I supported the motion for a resolution on the mid-term review of the Multiannual Financial Framework 2014-2020. The post-election revision of the MFF is one of Parliament's main demands in the negotiations to establish the current financial framework, and therefore welcomes the Commission's decision to propose a revision of the MFF Regulation and the Interinstitutional Agreement after reviewing the 2014-2020 MFF. The Commission's proposal for amounts is estimated at EUR 12.8 billion and consists of various parts. Additional funding will be for Horizon 2020 and IPE-Transport (0.4 billion each), Erasmus + and COSME (0.2 billion each) and the Youth Employment Initiative (1 billion), for a total of € 2.2 billion. appropriations. Successful implementation of the EU budget is a top priority for Parliament. The mid-term review of the multiannual financial framework is also the beginning of a process to reach agreement on a multiannual financial framework for the period after 2020.

name: Estefanía TORRES MARTÍNEZ
text: written. - The European Parliament does not have powers to define the Multiannual Financial Framework, which is the scheme that structures and limits the evolution of the budget over 7 years. It is the Council who decides. However, the pressure of the Union's crisis circumstances has generated a parliamentary consensus on the need to strengthen European budgets to face existing challenges (refugees, investment crisis, security, employment, etc…). The Resolution points out many positive aspects. Urges to increase resources, reform the system of own resources, assess the new flexibility conditions of the new MFF, criticize the Council, ask to withdraw the "rebates" (discounts on contributions from more than 10 Member States to the European budget), give the possibility of reusing non-used resources and unity of the Union budget against intergovernmental funds. However, the resolution seems like a good-looking facelift to legitimize itself, because a negotiation in which Parliament decides is not really at stake. In fact, the budget proposal for 2017 goes in the opposite direction, thereby reducing the credibility of this resolution. That is why I have abstained.

name: Ulrike TREBESIUS
text: written. - The report states that the appropriations entered in the current Multiannual Financial Framework (2014-2020) are far too low. In the logic of the current majority in the European Parliament, this is understandable, since in recent years Parliament has always irresponsibly asked for more funds than the Commission proposed, and at the same time always rejected all the cuts proposed by the Council. It should be emphasized that the current EU budget does not take sufficient account of the principle of subsidiarity, as some of the planned expenditures could be dealt with much better by the national states or regions and municipalities than at the European level. In addition, especially in cohesion policy and also in individual areas of agricultural policy, there is often a lack of sustainability, goal-orientation and professional success control based on measurable results. Finally, the report also calls for a direct link to the 2017 budget, which is also to be criticized. That is why I rejected the report.

name: Ramon TREMOSA i BALCELLS
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of Parliament’s recommendation even though it still not sufficient to adapt to all the challenges. It is fundamental that Member States understand that tackling the current and emerging crisis is an urgent issue for the EU.

name: István UJHELYI
text: in writing.- The revision of the multiannual financial framework provides a unique opportunity to overcome the budgetary difficulties currently threatening the credibility of the European Union.I voted in favor of the S&D position.

name: Miguel URBÁN CRESPO
text: written. - The European Parliament does not have powers to define the Multiannual Financial Framework, which is the scheme that structures and limits the evolution of the budget over 7 years. It is the Council who decides. However, the pressure of the Union's crisis circumstances has generated a parliamentary consensus on the need to strengthen European budgets to face existing challenges (refugees, investment crisis, security, employment, etc…). The Resolution points out many positive aspects. Urges to increase resources, reform the own resources system, assess the new flexibility conditions of the new MFF, criticize the Council, ask to withdraw the "rebates" (discounts on contributions from more than 10 Member States to the European budget), give the possibility of reusing non-used resources and unity of the Union budget against intergovernmental funds. However, the resolution seems like a good-looking facelift to legitimize itself, because a negotiation in which Parliament decides is not really at stake. In fact, the budget proposal for 2017 goes in the opposite direction, thereby reducing the credibility of this resolution. That is why I have abstained.

name: Ivo VAJGL
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the motion for a resolution on the mid-term revision. The resolution stresses the European Parliament’s constant concern regarding the insufficiency of resources available under the current multiannual financial framework (MFF). The number of new crises and have emerged over the past years, notably the migration and refugee crisis. It equally underlines, after conducting a review of the functioning of the MFF in the first half of this programming period, that an adequate response to those challenges requires a substantial amount of additional funding from the EU budget that could not have been fully provided in the first years of the current perspective owing to the scarce financial resources available under the current MFF. I voted in favour because I believe that the EU budget must match the political commitments and strategic objectives of the European Union.

name: Marco VALLI
text: in writing.- I voted against the resolution because, although more flexibility was proposed, significant additional resources were also foreseen: it is clear that the States do not want and cannot engage in new economic efforts (also in the light of all the budgetary constraints that theEurope).Indeed, it would be more sensible to proceed with a review of priorities, identifying the budget lines where it is possible to intervene to find the necessary resources without increasing the overall ceilings.However, the 5 Star Movement had tried to improve the text through several amendments, including one - unfortunately rejected - regarding the TEN-T program which asked not to use the appropriations to finance projects without real added value, such as the new linehigh speed Turin Lyon.

name: Ángela VALLINA
text: written.- The resolution reiterates Parliament's priorities for the revision of the MFF, endorsing the financialization of investments, the austerity conditionality of cohesion and development funds, the privatization of research, the commercialization of agricultural policies and the use of fundsexternal forces to reinforce strong Europe and the geopolitical adventurism of European elites.I have voted against to express my criticism of the current use of European funds, which have become one more instrument of neoliberal policies.

name: Hilde VAUTMANS
text: written.- I voted in favor of the report, but I do not agree with new initiatives such as the recently proposed "Interrail Pass for Europe on its 18th anniversary" program, which means that every European citizen who turns 18 receives a free Interrail pass.The European Union faces bigger problems than this.In times of migration crisis and financial-economic crisis, we can spend our money better.

name: Miguel VIEGAS
text: in writing. - In the context of this review, we follow the need for the ceilings of headings 1a (Competitiveness for growth and employment), 1b (Economic, social and territorial cohesion) and 2 (PAC and PCP) to be revised upwards so that the Union can respond to challenges and meet its political objectives, such as Parliament's demands for full compensation for EFSI-related cuts affecting the Horizon 2020 program and the Connecting Europe Facility, the continuation of the Employment Initiative for Young people at the same level of the annual allocations for 2014 and 2015. However, there are red lines in this report that have to do with budget financing, in which we continue to advocate that the RBN route be privileged, and with the unanimity rule that should prevail as a guarantee that we have a budget that is positive for all national States and not just for some, and we will even say for the minority of Member States that today hold otos.

name: Harald VILIMSKY
text: written.- This motion for a resolution considers the resources available in the current Multiannual Financial Framework (MFF) to be insufficient due to the migration and refugee crisis and other emergencies and calls for an increase in funding.These will then be used, among other things, for the purpose of shaping political opinion among young people against the "threats of populism and the spread of false information".I believe that this can be combated in a different way than with additional funds from the EU budget, which is why I rejected the request.

name: Lieve WIERINCK
text: in writing. – I voted in favour of this resolution since I believe that it points to the number of new crises and priorities that have emerged over the past years, notably the migration and refugee crisis, external emergencies, internal security issues, the crisis in agriculture, the funding of the European Fund for Strategic Investments (EFSI) and the persistent high level of unemployment, especially among young people. Points also to the recent ratification by the EU of the agreement on climate change. I agree that the revision of the multiannual financial framework provides an opportunity to respond to the budgetary difficulties currently jeopardising the credibility of the European Union. This revision highlights the need for an EU budget that is more transparent and accessible for European citizens, in order that they may regain trust in the European project.

name: Anna ZÁBORSKÁ
text: in writing. - The European Union is currently facing many crises and challenges, such as the migration crisis, the agricultural crisis, the high unemployment rate among young people, the ratification of the Climate Change Agreement. All the more it is necessary to emphasize the importance of the resources available for the so-called the Multiannual Financial Framework (MFF), which is a multi-annual plan of expenditure in various areas of EU activity. However, the current situation is unsatisfactory and does not reflect current requirements. That is why the revision of the MFF 2014-2020 needs to be undertaken. The changes must be incorporated into the EU budget for 2017 without delay. I agree with the Commission's statement proposing the creation of an EU crisis reserve as a rapid response tool . On the other hand, I see room for discussion, especially on raising the MFF financial ceilings. The current situation does not meet the needs and, if the EU is to be able to fully meet its policy objectives, it must raise these ceilings in the following areas: - Competitiveness for growth and employment, - Economic, social and territorial cohesion, - Security and citizenship, and - Global Europe. I consider the support of young people and their mobility to be particularly important. By strengthening European identity and awareness as such, we can successfully prevent the spread of misinformation and thus fight extremism and populism more effectively.

name: Marco ZANNI
text: in writing. - On 6 July, Parliament approved a report on the preparation of the post-electoral review of the MFF (Multiannual Financial Framework) 2014-2020: this text was preparatory to the Commission proposal, which is now finally on the table. The resolution we voted on today, presented by the Committee on Budgets, takes note of this proposal received, and with this text intends to reaffirm Parliament's priorities. The two co-rapporteurs strongly insisted on the need to produce this new document which, in their view, should serve to strengthen Parliament's position in view of the negotiations with the Council. On the merits, the proposal does not differ much from what was already expressed in the summer, i.e. greater flexibility is required (a point that I am in full agreement with) and considerable additional resources are also requested to face new challenges and problems: on this I have reservations , since it is clear that states do not want or can engage in new economic efforts also in the light of all the budgetary constraints that Brussels imposes. In my opinion, it would be more sensible to proceed with a review of priorities, identifying in the case also budget lines where you can intervene to find the necessary resources, but certainly not to increase the overall ceilings.

name: Tomáš ZDECHOVSKÝ
text: in writing.- I have decided to support this report.The revision of the multiannual financial framework is very important at the moment, as we can no longer live on the financial programming that was approved in 2013. I am aware that the report mentions the 'European Interrail 18th Birthday Network Ticket' initiative, which Ilong-term opponent.However, because of this detail, I could not reject such an important report as a whole, which is why I voted in favor.

name: Auke ZIJLSTRA
text: written.- The PVV voted against the mid-term review of the MFF.The EP calls for more flexibility within and between EU budget items.Such flexibility exempts the European Parliament from setting policy priorities.All political goals are therefore equally important and Parliament does not have to make any choices.This flexibility gives the EP the legitimacy to evade budgetary discipline.Moreover, this undermines the veto of Member States on revisions.The PVV cannot support the resulting waste of scarce resources.

name: Milan ZVER
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of the European Parliament resolution on the mid-term review of the multiannual financial framework for the period 2014-2020.I agree that the revision of the multiannual financial framework is a unique opportunity to respond to the budgetary difficulties that currently call into question the credibility of the European Union.We need a more transparent EU budget that is easier for European citizens to understand in order to restore confidence.I therefore join the calls for the Council to take responsibility, coordinate its words and actions and ensure a realistic, credible, coherent and sustainable EU budget for the remaining years of the current perspective.

name: Isabella ADINOLFI
text: in writing.- On 11 May 2016, Estonia submitted an application for a financial contribution (1.1 million euros) from the EGF following the redundancies made by three petrochemical companies.Although I support the situation of the workers affected by these measures, I cannot, however, be in favor of support, albeit indirect, for an energy sector - such as the petrochemical one - which contrasts with the objectives of environmental and energy sustainability which have always been central elements of the Movement's policy.5 stars.For these reasons I abstained.

name: Tim AKER
text: in writing. – UKIP voted against this budgetary report giving consent to the use of EU funds. This vote was to approve EUR 1 131 358 (60% match funding) for 800 redundant workers in Estonia. The money will be used for things like payments for the cost of training, language training (since there is a large number of Russian speakers), debt counselling, psychological counselling, study allowances and mobility allowances, etc. The application relates to 3 enterprises (which manufacture chemicals and petroleum products) in Estonia that made 1550 people redundant. UKIP opposes this use of EU dole money and British taxpayer’s having to pay for poor economic decisions in other countries.

name: Marina ALBIOL GUZMÁN
text: written.- I voted in favor of the mobilization of this European Globalization Adjustment fund, maintaining a consistent position with the rest of the mobilization requests for this fund, since it may result in compensation for Estonian workers affected by the impacts of thecapitalist globalization.Being aware that this is nothing but a band-aid on a wound, these funds can bring relief to these workers, hence my positive vote.

name: Martina ANDERSON
text: in writing. – 1 550 workers made redundant in 3 different Estonian companies, 2 in shale gas production, including the leading energy company in the Baltic States and one in chemicals production. The report outlined many of the positive elements of how the EGF would be put to work such as debt and psychological counselling as well as a study allowance of EUR 260 per month for example. There were also provisions for active consultation of trade unions, discussion with Ministry of Social Affairs took place, discussing a possible application for EGF co—funding. Therefore to help the workers we voted in favour.

name: Pascal ARIMONT
