As a result, the Estonian economy highly suffered from the recent volatility in the global oil and a general decrease in Europe’s international trade. The high concentration of industries dependent on oil and gas prices in Northern area of Estonia was in particular badly hit by redundancies in the manufacture of petroleum and chemicals products. I voted in favour of the mobilisation of funds, EUR 1 131 358, which will benefit 1 550 Estonians in need of assistance to find employment and social security.

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: written. - Estonia has applied for a financial contribution from the European Globalization Adjustment Fund following the redundancies in the economic sectors of coke and refined petroleum products and the production of chemicals and chemical products. Joint measures have been proposed to be financed with the requested amount of EUR 1.1 million and include, inter alia, payment of training costs, compensation of training costs for employers, training for the labor market, mobility compensation and the like. The report states that the European Union has lost its leading position in global sales of chemicals, and due to falling oil prices, Estonian exports of mineral fuels have decreased and much of Estonia's industries depend on oil and gas prices. It is clear from the above data that the proposed measures cannot help the recovery of highly disadvantaged sectors vis-à-vis third countries, such as China, as well as redundant workers. The long-term solution is to stimulate the production and development of the European Union's economy by cutting red tape and lowering taxes. So I voted against.

name: Romana TOMC
text: in writing. - I supported the motion for a resolution on the proposal for a decision of the European Parliament and of the Council on the mobilization of the European Globalization Adjustment Fund. The European Globalization Adjustment Fund was set up to provide additional assistance to workers affected by the consequences of major structural changes in world trade patterns. On 28 September 2016, the Commission adopted a proposal for a decision on the mobilization of the EGF in favor of Estonia, in order to support the reintegration of redundant workers in Eesti Energia AS, Nitrofert AS and Viru Keemia Grupp AS, classified in Section 19 of NACE Revision 2 ( Production of chemicals and chemical products) in the district of Ida-Virumaa (NUTS level 2: EE00- Eesti), to the labor market. This is the ninth application to be examined under the 2016 budget, amounting to a total of EUR 1,131,358 from the EGF for Estonia. It refers to 800 redundancies. In order to mobilize the Fund, the Commission has submitted to the budgetary authority a transfer request for a total amount of EUR 1,131,358 from the EGF reserve.

name: Estefanía TORRES MARTÍNEZ
text: written.- I voted in favor.It is a fund to compensate, with mainly training actions, 800 workers laid off by four Estonian companies, most of them Russian-speaking, from the petrochemical sectors, with clear problems of competitiveness with China.As we usually say, this fund does not solve the employment problem, which can only be remedied with new investment plans with sectoral transitions, but it is a mechanism that at least provides support to the victims of these processes.Alternatively, the companies that use these funds should be monitored, because one of the risks is that in practice they could be facilitating relocation processes.It does not seem the case.But it certainly leads to rethinking in terms of thinking about an alternative line to these funds.

name: Kazimierz Michał UJAZDOWSKI
text: in writing. - The European Globalization Adjustment Fund is an instrument that allows to offset the negative effects of mass layoffs, which are a consequence of global changes in the labor market and trade. Estonia's request to mobilize assistance from the fund is a result of the turmoil in the world oil markets and the weakening of Europe's position in the international fertilizer trade. These changes meant that Estonian companies Eesti Energia AS, Nitrofert AS and Viru Keemia Grupp AS, operating in these two industries, were forced to close their plants or reduce production, which resulted in the dismissal of 800 employees. Trainings, apprenticeships, scholarships for education and encouragement to learn the Estonian language from the fund will be an indispensable support for these employees in their return to the labor market. Policies favoring growth and employment deserve support. In principle, however, I doubt whether the European Globalization Adjustment Fund mechanism is really a tool that can effectively help the redundant workers to integrate into the labor market. I believe that each situation requires individual and careful assessment. The mobilization of resources from the fund on this particular issue is, in my opinion, justified, which is why I voted in favor of this resolution.

name: István UJHELYI
text: in writing.- The European Globalization Adjustment Fund has been created in order to provide additional assistance to workers suffering from the consequences of major structural changes in world trade patterns.I supported the relevant proposal.

name: Miguel URBÁN CRESPO
text: written.- I voted in favor.It is a fund to compensate, with mainly training actions, 800 workers laid off by four Estonian companies, most of them Russian-speaking, from the petrochemical sectors, with clear problems of competitiveness with China.As we usually say, this fund does not solve the employment problem, which can only be remedied with new investment plans with sectoral transitions, but it is a mechanism that at least provides support to the victims of these processes.Alternatively, the companies that use these funds should be monitored, because one of the risks is that in practice they could be facilitating relocation processes.It does not seem the case.But it certainly leads to rethinking in terms of thinking about an alternative line to these funds.

name: Ernest URTASUN
text: written.- I voted in favor of mobilizing the fund, to reduce the impact of relocations on the economy of the affected countries.

name: Ivo VAJGL
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report on the proposal for a decision of the European Parliament and of the Council on the mobilisation of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (application from Estonia – EGF/2016/003 EE/petroleum and chemicals). The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund has been created in order to provide additional assistance to workers suffering from the consequences of major structural changes in world trade patterns. The Commission adopted a proposal for a decision on the mobilisation of the EGF in favour of Estonia to support the reintegration in the labour market of workers made redundant to Eesti Energia AS, Nitrofert AS and Viru Keemia Grupp AS operating in the NACE Rev. 2 Division This is the ninth application to be examined under the 2016 budget. It concerns 800 workers made redundant. 19 (Manufacture of chemicals and chemical products) in the Ida-Virumaa County (NUTS level 2: EE00 – Eesti). According to the Commission, the described measures constitute active labour market measures within the eligible actions set out in Article 7 of the EGF Regulation. I voted in favour because I believe that the coordinated package of measures is compatible with the shift towards a resource-efficient and sustainable economy.

name: Ángela VALLINA
text: written.- I voted in favor of the mobilization of this European Globalization Adjustment fund, maintaining a coherent position with the rest of the mobilization requests for this fund, since it may result in compensation for Estonian workers affected by the impacts of thecapitalist globalization.Being aware that this is nothing but a band-aid on a wound, these funds can bring relief to these workers, hence my positive vote.

name: Hilde VAUTMANS
text: written.- I have agreed to the intention of the European Commission to pay EUR 1 131 358 to Estonia because of 1 550 layoffs at Eesti Energia AS, Nitrofert AS and Viru Keemia Grupp AS, resulting in collective termination of employment contracts.This amount corresponds to 60% of the total cost of EUR 1,885,597 for personalized services, which consists of support for formal study payment of training costs, reimbursement of training costs to employers, training for the labor market, work experience, debt counseling, psychological counseling, scholarship forthose attending formal studies, and scholarship and travel and subsistence allowance for Estonian language courses.The layoffs were due to cheaper imports from China and the globalizing effects on the market.

name: Miguel VIEGAS
text: in writing.- Estonia submitted the application 'EGF / 2016/003 EE / petroleum and chemicals' to a financial contribution from the EGF, following the dismissals of 1 550 workers.This perverse instrument, intended to cover the effects of capitalism, deserves our condemnation.Our vote in favor only stems from our solidarity with workers who are victims of a system that is fed by the EU, with the consequences of which we end up dealing with every session and every day in each country.

name: Harald VILIMSKY
text: written.- The European Globalization Adjustment Fund was set up to support workers suffering from the consequences of far-reaching structural changes in the world trade structure as a result of globalization.Specifically, this proposal concerns the use of this fund for the benefit of workers in Estonia who have been made redundant at the companies Eesti Energia AS, Nitrofert AS and Viru Keemia Grupp AS.On the positive side, Estonia, due to the fact that the redundancies affect the same region, has combined two sectors of the economy in one regional application, which has led to a reduction in the administrative burden.I think the request is justified and I have agreed.

name: Julie WARD
text: in writing. ‒ Yet again, this is an example of how the European Union supports people in its Member States to face the adverse effects of globalisation. Where workers in these heavy industries face redundancy, the EU provides financial assistance, expressing the core concept of European solidarity. Although UK workers have not benefited from Globalisation Adjustment Funds, this kind of protection from global markets is one of the marked benefits of membership in a large trading bloc, and this is one among the many reasons the UK must remain a member of the European single market in any future eventuality.

name: Marco ZANNI
text: in writing. - On 11 May, Estonia applied for financial assistance from the EGF following redundancies by three companies operating in the coke and petroleum refining and chemical manufacturing sectors; the beneficiaries of the interventions are expected to be 800 out of a total of 1 550 redundancies, with a contribution from the EGF of approximately € 1.1 million. Although the three companies operate in two different economic sectors (mineral fertilizers and shale oil), Estonia has decided to combine the redundancies in a single regional application, as they occurred in the same place and in the same period and also involved workers with very similar situations. Basically, I always vote in favor of the requests regarding the EGF, but in this case, given the nature of the companies involved and their particular activity, I thought it more appropriate to abstain, since on the one hand I do not want to penalize workers, on the other I do not want to penalize workers. I don't even want to give a message of support, albeit indirectly, to these energy production sectors, which do not reflect my priorities in this area.

name: Jana ŽITŇANSKÁ
text: in writing. - I did not support Estonia's request to mobilize the Globalization Adjustment Fund. As with the vote on previous requests from various Member States, I agree that workers who experience such a negative impact on structural changes in world trade need help, and I appreciate that Member States will, in most cases, start helping these redundant workers in advance, whether whether or not they will receive money from the fund. However, I have a problem with the fund itself. So far, there is no comprehensive assessment of the fund's effectiveness, there are no precise figures that tell us what percentage of redundancies have been re-employed with the help of the fund and what percentage would have been able to do so without its intervention. I therefore think that this fund must first be thoroughly examined to see if this funding could be used in a better and more efficient way than the fund's CV courses.

name: Milan ZVER
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of the European Parliament resolution on the proposal for a decision of the European Parliament and of the Council on the mobilization of the European Globalization Adjustment Fund.Estonia has submitted an application EGF / 2016/003 EE / petroleum and chemicals for a financial contribution from the EGF for redundancies.Estonia is thus entitled to a financial contribution of EUR 1,131,358, which includes support for formal education, payment of training costs, reimbursement of employers' training, labor market training, work placements, debt counseling, psychological counseling, study allowance inregarding participation in formal education, scholarships and transport and accommodation allowances for learning Estonian.

name: Monica MACOVEI
text: - Mr President, this directive requires that the websites of the European institutions be made accessible to citizens of the Union, and this can be done by harmonizing legislation. That is what I asked for in this directive, which I just voted on. In this way, people will have access to information, services, will be able to find jobs more easily and also all costs will be reduced. Imagine that if sites talk to each other and communicate, people access them and we reduce the costs of maintaining these sites. In addition, the directive also provides facilities for people with disabilities, for example, people who are partially or totally blind; for them you can change the color or size of the text on these sites. You can also add a new option for reading the text and audio description of the image. It is, therefore, a welcome directive. The problem is how to put it into practice. Let's make sure that the Member States put it into practice for the benefit of the people. Thanks.

name: Jiří POSPÍŠIL
text: - Madam President, I supported this proposal for a directive. I spoke at the plenary yesterday, but I did not have time to say my whole statement, which is why I use this institute. On the one hand, I very much welcome making the websites of public institutions accessible to EU citizens and people with disabilities in general who want to work with the site and want information from the public sector. On the other hand, and this is what I did not have time to add yesterday, I do not agree with the part which introduces, in principle, bureaucratic scrutiny of this directive, where states will have to send an annual report on how the directive is being implemented to the Commission and officials. evaluate. It seems to me to be an unnecessary, problematic burden, I think it would be better for the public authorities to respond only to citizens' complaints if there is a mistake, not for thousands of reports to gather here in Brussels and then be evaluated by someone. So a good idea, but the control, in my opinion, is not very conceited.

name: Matt CARTHY
text: – Go raibh maith agat, a Leas-Uachtaráin. Chaith mé vóta i bhfabhar na tuairisce seo. Dé réir na tuairisce ba chóir go mbeadh riachtanais bhunúsacha ann maidir le soláthar eolais ar shuíomhanna eagraíochtaí poiblí. Tagann an tuairisc seo ó Choinbhinsiún na Náisiún Aontaithe um Chearta na nDaoine faoi Mhíchumas (CPRD), atá sínithe ag Rialtas na hÉireann ó 2007, ach nach bhfuil curtha i bhfeidhm acu go fóill.  Cuirfidh na rialacha seo le héascaíocht léitheoireacht agus úsáid, mar aon le leagan amach. Déanfaidh na rialacha seo teacht ar eolas níos éasca tríd apps nó suíomhanna na n-eagraíochtaí poiblí. Tá athruithe mar seo thar a bheith tábhachtach do dhaoine faoi mhíchumas, gó háirithe i dtíortha mar Éire, inar tháinig laghdú ar thacaíocht do dhaoine faoi mhíchumas de dheasca ciorruithe le hocht mbliana anuas. Go raibh maith agat.

name: Seán KELLY
text: – Go raibh maith agat, a Uachtaráin. Bhíos i bhfabhar dar ndóigh na tuarascála seo agus glacadh leis gan vóta agus mo ghrúpa agus mé féin ina bhfabhar. The recommendation, which aims to introduce standardised accessibility features on websites of public sector bodies, and the proposed policy, would render said platforms more accessible, enhance monitoring and reporting standards and identify the dissemination of information as a priority.  I note the exclusion of websites held by public service broadcasters and their subsidiaries, thus essentially distinguishing the web accessibility directive from the Audiovisual Media Services Directive. I believe that these recommendations will enhance the application of current frameworks in this domain whilst providing the foundation for future policy. This again is another step in the right direction as we try and move to a digital single market, which would add billions to the European economy as part of the policy of this Commission.

name: Clara AGUILERA
text: written. - Around 80 million people in the Union have a disability. With the aging of the population, the number of people with disabilities or difficulties associated with age to access the internet will continue to increase. As a socialist, I believe that it is our responsibility as a society to improve the living conditions of our fellow citizens, and for this it is essential to increase the accessibility to public sector information and services in the digital age. That is why I voted in favor of this directive, which represents an important step towards an inclusive digital society. With the new regulations, the web pages and mobile applications of all public bodies - government agencies, courts, police, hospitals, universities or libraries - will have to comply with common accessibility standards and, from this Chamber, we have also ensured that the applications used in mobile phones and tablets will be subject to the new legislation.

name: Marina ALBIOL GUZMÁN
text: written.- I voted in favor of this report as accessibility to public services must be the priority of any public sector web application.I consider it essential that the public sector should be at the forefront both in the development of web applications and in all kinds of accessible services to guarantee access and effective participation in the rights of all citizens.Functional diversity should not be a limit to the exercise of the right, and it is essential that the public sector be the guarantor of this maxim, which should be universally applicable.This is why I have decided to vote in favor of this report.

name: Nikos ANDROULAKIS
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of the recommendation for second reading on the position of the Council at first reading with a view to the adoption of the Directive of the European Parliament and of the Council on the accessibility of websites and mobile applications of public sector bodies, because I believe that,In an inclusive digital society, it is important to ensure that everyone has access to the websites and mobile applications of public sector operators.

name: Pascal ARIMONT
text: written.- The aim of this guideline is to establish new rules on accessibility, which are intended to ensure that websites and mobile applications of public bodies are accessible to all.The aim of this guideline is to enable people with disabilities or the elderly to have barrier-free access to information and services on the Internet.This can be achieved, for example, by providing videos with subtitles, offering image enlargement programs or by creating means that enable a computer to be operated without a mouse.I warmly welcome this proposal.

name: Marie-Christine ARNAUTU
text: in writing.- The proposed directive aims to harmonize the laws and regulations as well as the administrative practices of the Member States with regard to the accessibility requirements of websites and mobile applications of public sector bodies which must be 'perceptible, usable, robust and understandable ”, in order to improve the functioning of the internal market.It also lays down the rules under which Member States must ensure that websites, regardless of the device used to access them, and mobile applications of public sector bodies comply with accessibility requirements (peopleelderly and disabled).Improving the single market would be a very good reason to vote against, but the attention the text pays to the elderly and disabled justifies abstaining.

name: Jonathan ARNOTT
text: in writing. ‒ This report was approved in Parliament without a vote.

name: Zigmantas BALČYTIS
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of the report on the Council position at first reading with a view to the adoption of a directive of the European Parliament and of the Council on the accessibility of public sector bodies' websites and mobile applications.I agree with the need to ensure the accessibility of websites and mobile applications not only for consumers but also for people with disabilities in public sector institutions.

name: Nicolas BAY
text: in writing.- This is a directive on which my opinion is mixed.The attention paid to the elderly and disabled, for whom the accessibility of the sites and mobile applications of public sector organizations should be made optimal, is necessarily a step in the right direction but the text as a whole works to strengthen the market.unique, which can only be done to the detriment of French workers.So I preferred to abstain.

name: Hugues BAYET
text: in writing. - This proposal for a directive concerns the accessibility for all users of the content of websites of public sector bodies and websites operated by entities fulfilling public missions, and in particular for people with disabilities and the elderly. I voted in favor of this text because it seems important that all European citizens be able to benefit from the information they need in their interactions with public administration. In order to achieve this objective, this proposal for a directive aims to approximate the laws and regulations as well as the administrative practices of the Member States. It establishes minimum requirements for websites and mobile applications of public sector bodies while ensuring that these do not impose a disproportionate burden on such bodies. Member States should also encourage and facilitate training programs relating to the accessibility of websites and mobile applications.

name: Brando BENIFEI
text: in writing. - The great digital revolution that is taking place before our eyes brings with it numerous opportunities but also various unknowns, especially for those people who, being in conditions of disability, risk being more vulnerable to exclusion phenomena due to a lack of adaptation of new technologies to their needs. Already today 80 million European citizens have a disability and with the aging of the population this figure seems destined to grow, reaching 120 million by 2020. The Charanzová report, which I supported today with my vote, addresses the issue of accessibility of websites and mobile applications of mobile entities starting from these considerations. Thanks to the new rules, websites and mobile applications of public bodies such as administrations, courts, public hospitals and universities will have to meet common accessibility standards. Public bodies will also be obliged to provide and regularly update a detailed accessibility statement on the compliance of their websites and applications with the Directive, including explanations in case of inaccessible content which will have to be duly justified.

name: Xabier BENITO ZILUAGA
text: written. - I voted in favor of this report on accessibility to websites, because it raises the harmonization of minimum requirements at European level that guarantee access to information on web pages. The text is a second reading, for which the Commission made its first proposal in 2012, in the context of the adoption of the United Nations Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities in 2006. This particular proposal was made to increase web accessibility (websites and mobile applications) of public service providers for all people, including people with disabilities. The Directive which establishes harmonized minimum requirements to guarantee access for all, especially in the area of ​​access to information. Parliament tried to extend the scope of the Directive and apply additional measures in the field of surveillance, reporting and enforcement. At second reading the Council reached an agreement, which is supported by Parliament without amendment.

name: Izaskun BILBAO BARANDICA
text: written.- I want to congratulate the rapporteur, Mrs Charanzová, for this report on the accessibility of websites and mobile applications of public sector bodies.It is a Recommendation for the second reading in which it transcends the agreement reached by the two legislative institutions.It is essential that this Directive is transposed within the deadlines set in the text so that it enters into force as soon as possible in the Member States.

name: Dominique BILDE
text: in writing.- I preferred to abstain from this report concerning the accessibility of websites and mobile applications of public sector bodies.While I welcome the intention to make public sector websites more accessible, especially for people with disabilities or even the elderly, who are often victims of generational divides, we should be clear about the intentions of the European Commission.For some time now, it has taken up the issue of accessibility - which had never seemed to be one of its priorities - to make it the Trojan horse of ever more integration withthe expansion of the internal market and the digital single market.I condemn this political recovery of an issue that touches on the concrete problems facing people with disabilities or the elderly.

name: Mara BIZZOTTO
text: in writing.- I believe that the objectives of the proposal for a directive on the accessibility of websites and mobile applications of public bodies can be shared and appreciated.Nowadays it is important to guarantee this type of service to citizens, especially to those who until now have not been able to use it, for example people with visual difficulties and the elderly.Web technology services can indeed prove to be a valuable help, which is why I am in favor of this proposed directive.

name: José BLANCO LÓPEZ
text: written. - Around 80 million people in the Union have a disability. With the aging of the population, the number of people with disabilities or difficulties associated with age to access the internet will continue to increase. As a socialist, I believe that it is our responsibility as a society to improve the living conditions of our fellow citizens, and for this it is essential to increase the accessibility to public sector information and services in the digital age. That is why I voted in favor of this directive, which represents an important step towards an inclusive digital society. With the new regulations, the web pages and mobile applications of all public bodies - government agencies, courts, police, hospitals, universities or libraries - will have to comply with common accessibility standards and, from this Chamber, we have also ensured that the applications used in mobile phones and tablets will be subject to the new legislation.

name: Vilija BLINKEVIČIŪTĖ
text: in writing. - I voted in favor of this recommendation, in which we supported the adoption of the crucial directive on the accessibility of public sector bodies' websites and mobile applications. This important European decision will affect millions of people with visual, mobility or other disabilities. The new rules aim to make public sector websites and mobile applications more accessible to people with disabilities and the elderly. At present, the content of some websites is not tailored to them or does not have more accessible means, such as alternative text describing images, or no audible information. People with disabilities can use a computer and browse the Internet with a variety of assistive devices, such as screen readers or equipment to help control the computer with head movements. The new rules have already been agreed with all Member States, so with Parliament's approval today, there are no longer any obstacles to the entry into force and improvement of the use of mobile applications by people with disabilities. Member States will have 21 months to transpose them into national law.

name: Andrea BOCSKOR
text: in writing. - As is well known, the Kósa report, adopted by the European Parliament on 25 October 2011, has already emphasized that innovative and knowledge-based economies cannot emerge without accessible content and forms accessible to people with disabilities. These include smartphone applications that facilitate the daily lives of people with disabilities and media tools, as well as websites accessible to the blind, content for people with hearing impairments, including mass communication services, and online services for sign language users. This is why it is a great achievement that not only the websites of public sector organizations, but also those of public organizations, can be gradually and fully accessible in order to enable people with disabilities to live independently and participate in all areas of life, as defined in the UN Convention. in society. Therefore, in the interests of social inclusion, the websites of public sector bodies and websites providing basic services to the public, such as overheads and health, education, social and key document services, should be made accessible to all people, as far as technologically possible and reasonable, or information and services provided by interest groups. Another important success is that the representatives and experts of the organizations involved must be involved in the implementation. So it was clear that I also voted in favor of the legislation.

name: Biljana BORZAN
text: written.- I support this report.We live in a digital age and all citizens should be treated equally when it comes to access to information.This Directive is an important step towards an inclusive digital society, ensuring that websites and mobile applications will have to be accessible to all in public sector bodies.

name: Marie-Christine BOUTONNET
text: in writing.- The improvement of the single market is a very good reason to vote against, but the attention that the text pays to the elderly and disabled people would rather motivate the choice of abstention.There is no vote because the text was in second reading.

name: Renata BRIANO
text: in writing. - Article 9 of the United Nations Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities requires Member States and the EU to take appropriate measures to ensure equal access for such persons also to information and communication technologies, including the Internet. Already in 2012, the European Commission presented a proposal for a directive aimed at guaranteeing equal access to information, web browsing and management of mobile applications of public bodies both for people with physical or mental disabilities, and for people with an advanced age and a lack of familiarity with the digital tool. The Internet has become an essential tool for obtaining and providing information and services. It is therefore more important than ever to ensure that all citizens can perceive and understand websites and mobile applications and interact with them appropriately. Around 80 million people in the EU have a disability. And as Europe's population ages, that figure is expected to rise to 120 million by 2020. A common approach to ensuring web accessibility is a prerequisite for an inclusive digital society, which takes full advantage of the digital single market to promote dignity, participation and correct information.

name: Soledad CABEZÓN RUIZ
text: written. - Around 80 million people in the Union have a disability. With the aging of the population, the number of people with disabilities or difficulties associated with age to access the internet will continue to increase. As a socialist, I believe that it is our responsibility as a society to improve the living conditions of our fellow citizens, and for this it is essential to increase the accessibility to public sector information and services in the digital age. That is why I voted in favor of this directive, which represents an important step towards an inclusive digital society. With the new regulations, the web pages and mobile applications of all public bodies - government agencies, courts, police, hospitals, universities or libraries - will have to comply with common accessibility standards and, from this Chamber, we have also ensured that the applications used in mobile phones and tablets will be subject to the new legislation.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: in writing. - After careful reading and discussion in the classroom, I gave my positive vote to the recommendation for second reading on the accessibility of websites and mobile applications of public bodies, on the basis of the following considerations: - the need to access information and services public administration in a complete, rapid and transparent way passes through the use of web platforms, not only for the retrieval of general information, but also for those of sensitive data and for the extraction of certificates; - this translates into an implementation of transparency and administrative efficiency, two fundamental parameters for evaluating the good governance of the PA; - as a result, the concept of administrative efficiency has progressively and quickly transferred from the real to the virtual world, which has posed new challenges, such as the development of sites accessible to all users, in particular to people with functional limitations between which the disabled; - with this in mind, websites must be structured in such a way as to allow a one-to-one correspondence between user-citizen and administrative machine, also allowing to download forms and to carry out the evasion of digital practices and authentication, as well as transactions.

name: David CASA
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report in which this EU Directive is expected to set minimum conditions for accessibility to public sector bodies’ websites and it also requires regular monitoring and reporting of the sites and apps accessibility by Member States. The European Parliament worked hard at covering also mobile applications. Certain content will be excluded, but only of not needed for essential administrative procedures. This is all done without creating a disproportionate burden and the exclusion of websites held by public service broadcasters and their subsidiaries. Monitoring and reporting mechanism worked on a two layered system ensuring better application.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of this text requiring the websites of public bodies and their 'mobile' applications to be accessible to the more than 167 million citizens with disabilities living within the EU.The proposal indicates some common standards that the websites of public bodies must respect in terms of navigation, interaction, readability, understanding, website design.In this way, public bodies will have to provide and regularly update a detailed, complete and transparent declaration on the compliance of their websites with the Directive, highlighting any inaccessible parts of the content and the reasons for such inaccessibility.

name: Caterina CHINNICI
text: in writing. - We live in a digital age, in which communication technologies allow us to be always informed and in constant connection also with our public institutions. All European citizens must be able to enjoy the benefits offered by digitization, especially as regards the accessibility of websites and mobile applications of public bodies. I voted in favor of the document because I strongly support the goal of improving the accessibility of online services offered by public bodies, especially for people with disabilities. There must be no obstacles to accessing these services, every EU citizen must have the same opportunities to be informed and communicate online with public bodies. Last, but not least, I believe that the harmonization measures provided for in the directive will, more generally, bring significant benefits to the digital single market, fostering a common approach and clarity in the rules on the accessibility of websites.

name: Lefteris CHRISTOFOROU
text: in writing.- We support the enactment of a legislative framework that will ensure the accessibility of all persons with disabilities to all websites and websites of public organizations and services.

name: Alberto CIRIO
text: in writing. - We live in the digital age, our children grow up learning to deal with technological devices even before they know how to read and write, consequently States must take note of modern times and adapt by providing adequate answers. I therefore voted in favor of a proposal that firmly emphasizes the need for all public service providers to secure the transmission of information and to protect personal data. From this it follows that compliance with the requirements on web accessibility and related security should be subject to continuous monitoring by a competent authority in each Member State as the body responsible for control. The directive will also establish minimum conditions for accessibility. The expected outcome is to streamline, facilitate and speed up contact with public bodies and their services, thus contributing to economic and employment growth. Too often, in fact, we have witnessed projects sunk by biblical times or by impediments of a communicative nature, so we are preparing to eradicate phenomena of this kind.

name: Deirdre CLUNE
text: in writing. ‒ I supported the vote on the accessibility of the websites and mobile applications of public sector bodies and noted no objections.

name: Carlos COELHO
text: in writing. - This Directive aims to approximate the laws, regulations and administrative provisions of the Member States related to the accessibility requirements of public sector bodies' websites and mobile applications, thus allowing those websites and mobile applications to be more accessible for users, in particular for people with disabilities. I support the Charanzóva Report, which approves the Council's position at first reading, thus allowing the elimination of obstacles within the internal market, resulting from the lack of harmonization of national approaches to web accessibility. It is inconceivable that, Today, the Internet is not a reality for everyone, with segregation in access to information and the full realization of their rights by millions of European citizens. I am pleased that this new Directive will make it easier for these people to access information and public services on the Internet, contributing to an inclusive society and the realization of the digital single market, by passing the websites and mobile applications of public sector bodies , such as administrative, judicial and police services to hospitals, universities and libraries, having to meet common European standards on accessibility.

name: Birgit COLLIN-LANGEN
text: written.- I voted in favor of the report because I support the result of the directive negotiated with the Council.We have to make it easier for disabled and elderly people to access data and services on the Internet and for this we need supporting “tools”.With this guideline we are creating a balanced solution: Establishing the specific minimum requirements for barrier-free access without burdening the public authorities with an unreasonable administrative burden.

name: Lara COMI
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of the recommendation because the directive concerns a very important area for the relationship between the administration and citizens, namely accessibility to the websites of public bodies.Accessibility will also be guaranteed through applications for mobile devices and the legislation will be applicable to entities in all public sectors, setting minimum accessibility conditions and providing that only content that is not necessary for essential administrative procedures may not be reachable.on websites.Furthermore, the directive will allow citizens to request information on demand if the content sought is not present on the website and will have the possibility, through a feedback mechanism, to notify the institution of any malfunctions of the service.

name: Javier COUSO PERMUY
text: written.- I voted in favor of this report as accessibility to public services must be the priority of any public sector web application.I consider it essential that the public sector should be at the forefront both in the development of web applications and in all kinds of accessible services to guarantee access and effective participation in the rights of all citizens.Functional diversity should not be a limit to the exercise of the right, and it is essential that the public sector be the guarantor of this maxim, which should be universally applicable.This is why I have decided to vote in favor of this report.

name: Andrea COZZOLINO
text: in writing. - I voted in favor of this resolution which intends to adopt the directive on the accessibility of websites and mobile applications of public bodies, as I believe it is an important step towards an inclusive digital single market at European level. This directive aims, in fact, to make the internet increasingly accessible to all citizens, in view of the need to benefit from the digital society to access and provide information and services. The European market for products and services related to web accessibility has an estimated value of 2 billion euros, accessible websites do not exceed 10% and 120 million European citizens will be affected by disabilities by 2020. These data confirm that there is a large margin for improvement and usefulness in the implementation of a digital market and economy at the service of citizens. Therefore, I support the process of harmonization of web accessibility policies, primarily in favor of public bodies, so that they can perform their functions in the best possible way and reach the greatest number of people.

name: Edward CZESAK
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of the directive on the accessibility of public sector websites and mobile applications because I fully support its aim.It is very important to harmonize the rules in force in the Member States to increase the accessibility of both websites and applications mainly for people with disabilities (especially the blind, visually impaired and hard of hearing).The ability to change the color and size of the text, the provision of a speech function to read the text and describe images, and the ability to view without a mouse are some of the main practical solutions to facilitate accessibility for people with disabilities.I welcome the provisions of the directive, which is why I voted in favor.

name: Miriam DALLI
text: in writing. ‒ Websites and mobile applications should be accessible for all. We are living in a digital age and all citizens should be treated equally when it comes to access to information. This is why I am in favour of this directive as it aims at approximating the laws of the Member States on the accessibility of websites of public sector bodies by defining harmonised requirements. I believe that this directive provides a framework for cheaper web accessibility and would be beneficial for governments and citizens. I am in favour of this report as it also improves the accessibility for the blind, the deaf and persons with functional disabilities and promotes an inclusive digital society.

name: Daniel DALTON
text: in writing. ‒ I very much welcome this report, which will help ensure that, as digital tools are increasingly used by public sector administrations, improving their efficiency, these tools are developed with the needs of people with disabilities in mind, helping to achieve equality of access for all. This is very much in line with the work the UK has already undertaken in ensuring integrated support for people with disabilities in digital policy, and achieving the same level of accessibility across the EU is to be welcomed.

name: Nicola DANTI
text: in writing. - Since the late 1960s, when it first developed for defense reasons, the Internet has become the primary means of mass communication and one of the essential tools for providing and obtaining information and services from around the world. With today's overwhelming majority vote, the European Parliament gives the green light to a set of rules at EU level that will serve to make it easier and increase the full accessibility of websites and also of mobile applications of public bodies, such as smartphones and tablets, for operations such as tax returns, to pay taxes or to enroll at university. A key step in the context of the creation of a more inclusive and universal digital single market that aims to break down all the obstacles that are still present, especially for people belonging to the weakest categories, such as the disabled, the elderly and the blind. The full diffusion and accessibility of digital technologies, the web and mobile applications that provide e-government services, represent the fundamental requirements for spreading to everyone - without exception - the benefits of the digital revolution underway.

name: Michel DANTIN
text: in writing. - This legislative report aims to improve the accessibility of websites of public bodies to people with disabilities and older people, and follows the Commission's proposal to establish a European directive. This text sets minimum conditions for the accessibility of the websites of administrations, public hospitals, police services and courts, in order to facilitate Internet browsing and online procedures, such as the tax declaration. The Member States will have to appoint an authority to ensure the follow-up and the correct application of these rules. Citizens will also be able to report a problem with accessing websites or request the content of information that is not available. Considering that access to information, public bodies and online services can significantly improve the lives of people with disabilities and older people, and of all European citizens, I supported this report.

name: Rachida DATI
text: in writing.- I supported this text relating to the accessibility of websites and mobile applications of public sector organizations.As public bodies increasingly use websites to fulfill their public service mission, it is essential to ensure that these platforms are accessible to all citizens, especially the elderly and disabled.By harmonizing the legislation relating to the accessibility of websites and mobile applications of public sector bodies, we ensure that all European citizens have full access to the internet platforms of public bodies, we allow these public bodies to benefit from'a more competitive market and we are restructuring the market so that economic operators can develop.

name: Gérard DEPREZ
text: in writing. - I voted in favor of this resolution, which aims to make the websites and applications of public administrations, hospitals, courts and other public sectors more accessible to people with disabilities and the elderly. These sites and applications used on mobile devices will now have to meet common accessibility standards. Utilities will now need to provide and regularly update a detailed, complete and clear accessibility statement regarding compliance with these standards by their websites and applications. A reporting mechanism should also be put in place to allow users to report problems and request specific information if the targeted content is not accessible. However, certain types of content are excluded from the scope of the directive. These are contents that are not necessary in administrative procedures.

name: Tamás DEUTSCH
text: in writing. - As is well known, the Kósa report, adopted by the European Parliament on 25 October 2011, has already emphasized that innovative and knowledge-based economies cannot develop without content and forms introduced by mandatory legislation accessible to people with disabilities. These include smartphone applications that facilitate the daily lives of people with disabilities and media tools, as well as websites accessible to the blind, content for people with hearing impairments, including mass communication services, and online services for sign language users. This is why it is a great achievement that not only the websites of public sector organizations, but also those of public organizations, can be gradually and fully accessible in order to enable people with disabilities to live independently and participate in all areas of life, as defined in the UN Convention. in society. Therefore, in the interests of social inclusion, the websites of public sector bodies and websites providing basic services to the public, such as overheads and health, education, social and key document services, should be made accessible to all people, as far as technologically possible and reasonable, or information and services provided by interest groups. Another important success is that the representatives and experts of the organizations involved must be involved in the implementation. So it was clear that I also voted in favor of the legislation.

name: Mireille D'ORNANO
text: in writing.- The proposed directive aims to harmonize the laws and regulations as well as the administrative practices of the Member States with regard to the accessibility requirements of websites and mobile applications of public sector bodies.These must be "perceptible, usable, robust and understandable" in order to improve the functioning of the internal market.The text also sets out the rules under which Member States must ensure that regardless of the device used to access them, the websites and mobile applications of public sector bodies comply with accessibility requirements (peopleelderly and disabled).Although this text is an additional justification for the highly criticized single market, the attention it pays to the elderly and disabled made me prefer abstention.

name: José Manuel FERNANDES
text: in writing.- More and more public administration is making online services available to citizens.However, there are currently around 80 million people in the EU with some type of disability for whom access to these types of services is not easy.The new directive already agreed between negotiators from the European Parliament and national governments aims to ensure that public sector bodies take the necessary steps to make their websites and mobile applications more accessible by making them understandable, operable, understandable and robust..Public authorities will have to develop tools, such as magnifying glasses or screen readers, to help the elderly and people with disabilities to use their websites and applications.I voted in favor.

name: Edouard FERRAND
text: in writing.- Abstention: technical text.The improvement of the single market is a very good reason to vote against, but the attention that the text gives to the elderly and disabled people would rather motivate the choice of abstention.

name: João FERREIRA
text: in writing. - We consider the proposal to introduce mandatory accessibility for certain types of public sector sites (State, region, local and public law bodies) to be essential, in essential electronic government services, such as network services, in the banking sector. , in education, social security, health services, social inclusion services and cultural activities. This directive aims to improve the lives of citizens, especially people with disabilities and the elderly, with regard to the accessibility of these sites of public bodies, taking into account that much of the information available is online. However, we believe that it must be safeguarded that Member States that have already developed their national accessibility policies and standards, based on WCAG 2, should be exempt from the application of this directive. In this way, additional costs for national, regional, local and other public authorities are avoided. On the other hand, the availability of these services on a digital platform cannot under any circumstances mean the suppression or limitation of access to the same services through traditional infrastructures. The lack of access to the internet or the inability to use this resource and functional illiteracy are a reality that cannot be neglected and that affects a significant part of the population.

name: Monika BEŇOVÁ
text: in writing.- The main objective of this Directive is to improve the accessibility and accessibility of public sector websites and their content for people with certain disabilities, but also for the elderly population.These measures will help mainly visually impaired people or people with severely impaired vision, as well as people who have hearing problems or suffer from certain mobility problems.The European Union must keep in mind that the digitalisation of society is advancing at a tremendous pace and that we live in a digital world.All citizens should have equal opportunities in accessing information.This directive will bring positive results in building a digital society.

name: Lorenzo FONTANA
text: in writing.- I am voting in favor of the proposal to improve the accessibility of the websites and smartphone applications of public bodies.

name: Lampros FOUNTOULIS
text: in writing.- I am voting against the report, as I do not believe that any effort to organize and introduce public sector electronic technology, which is of course necessary, should be linked to the single market or the unrestricted movement of people.At the same time, this initiative loses its real purpose and creates normal and justified reactions.

name: Ashley FOX
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report as it will help improve government transparency for citizens. I welcome the commitment to improving access to websites for those with a disability. It is important that everyone should be able to access and contact bodies which make decisions that affect their lives. The UK has been at the forefront of the digitalisation of services and information and I am glad the EU recognises the importance of access to digital information.

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: in writing. ‒ Considering the fact that we live in a digital age, all citizens should be treated equally when it comes to access to information, this Directive is an important step towards an inclusive digital society, ensuring that public sector bodies’ websites and mobile applications will have to be made accessible to everyone. I welcome the achievements made by the report, such as limiting vast exclusions in the scope as suggested by the Council, e.g. inclusion of school websites insofar as relates to essential administrative functions. Further, I welcome the fact that we achieved the extension of the scope to mobile applications, and inclusion of an enforcement and feedback mechanism in the implementation of the directive in the Member States.

name: Kinga GÁL
text: in writing. - As is well known, the Kósa report, adopted by the European Parliament on 25 October 2011, has already emphasized that innovative and knowledge-based economies cannot emerge without accessible content and forms accessible to people with disabilities. This is why it is a great achievement that not only the websites of public sector organizations, but also those of public organizations, can be gradually and fully accessible in order to enable people with disabilities to live independently and participate in all areas of life, as defined in the UN Convention. in society. Therefore, in the interests of social inclusion, the websites of public sector bodies and websites providing basic services to the public, such as overheads and health, education, social and key document services, should be made accessible to all people, as far as technologically possible and reasonable, or information and services provided by interest groups. Another important success is that the representatives and experts of the organizations involved must be involved in the implementation. That is why I also voted in favor of the legislation.

name: Ildikó GÁLL-PELCZ
text: in writing. - As is well known, the Kósa report, adopted by the European Parliament on 25 October 2011, has already emphasized that innovative and knowledge-based economies cannot emerge without accessible content and forms accessible to people with disabilities. These include smartphone applications that facilitate the daily lives of people with disabilities and media tools, as well as websites accessible to the blind, content for people with hearing impairments, including mass communication services, and online services for sign language users. This is why it is a great achievement that not only the websites of public sector organizations, but also those of public organizations, can be gradually and fully accessible in order to enable people with disabilities to live independently and participate in all areas of life, as defined in the UN Convention. in society. Therefore, in the interests of social inclusion, the websites of public sector bodies and websites providing basic services to the public, such as overheads and health, education, social and key document services, should be made accessible to all people, as far as technologically possible and reasonable, or information and services provided by interest groups. Another important success is that the representatives and experts of the organizations involved must be involved in the implementation. So it was clear that I also voted in favor of the legislation.

name: Francisco de Paula GAMBUS MILLET
text: written.- I voted in favor bearing in mind that we must ensure that eGovernment is accessible to all European citizens.We need reforms applicable also to the services offered by the private sector, from banking to television networks and private hospitals.Therefore, we need to adopt a European standard soon to ensure that both public and private services are accessible.With the new regulations, the web pages and mobile applications of all public bodies - government agencies, courts, police, hospitals, universities or libraries - will have to meet common accessibility standards.

name: Iratxe GARCÍA PÉREZ
text: written. - Around 80 million people in the Union have a disability. With the aging of the population, the number of people with disabilities or difficulties associated with age to access the internet will continue to increase. As a socialist, I consider that it is our responsibility as a society to improve the living conditions of our fellow citizens and for this it is essential to increase the accessibility to information and services of the public sector in the digital age. I have therefore voted in favor of this directive, which represents an important step towards an inclusive digital society. With the new regulations, the web pages and mobile applications of all public bodies - government agencies, courts, police, hospitals, universities or libraries - will have to comply with common accessibility standards and, from this Chamber, we have also ensured that the applications used in mobile phones and tablets will be subject to the new legislation.

name: Eider GARDIAZABAL RUBIAL
text: written. - Around 80 million people in the Union have a disability. With the aging of the population, the number of people with disabilities or difficulties associated with age to access the internet will continue to increase. As a socialist, I believe that it is our responsibility as a society to improve the living conditions of our fellow citizens, and for this it is essential to increase the accessibility to public sector information and services in the digital age. That is why I voted in favor of this directive, which represents an important step towards an inclusive digital society. With the new regulations, the web pages and mobile applications of all public bodies - government agencies, courts, police, hospitals, universities or libraries - will have to comply with common accessibility standards and, from this Chamber, we have also ensured that the applications used in mobile phones and tablets will be subject to the new legislation.

name: Enrico GASBARRA
text: in writing.- It is regrettable that even today, in the midst of the digital age, information on websites and accessibility to public sector applications are subject to restrictions that prevent their widespread and indiscriminate use.A civilized and emancipated society cannot allow categories that live with hardships and disabilities on a daily basis to be alienated from a free and simplified access to information.I therefore welcome the invitations contained in the report "Accessibility of websites and mobile applications of public bodies" which I supported with my vote, in the hope that knowledge, knowledge and information do not remain trapped in sterile, useful barriers.only to strengthen the threat of social exclusion for the most vulnerable categories.

name: Arne GERICKE
text: written.- As a member of the parliamentary “Disability Intergroup”, I naturally voted in favor of the report “Barrier-free access to the websites and mobile applications of public authorities”.I support the concern to make public bodies completely accessible digitally.

name: Lidia Joanna GERINGER DE OEDENBERG
text: in writing. - There are around 80 million disabled people in the European Union. By 2020, this number could rise to as much as 120 million as the population is aging. With the internet becoming one of the main sources of information as well as an important service delivery tool, it is imperative that everybody has access to websites and mobile applications. The European Parliament today backed the first EU rules to make public sector bodies' websites and mobile applications accessible to disabled and elderly people. The aim of the directive is to guarantee the accessibility of websites and applications by making them more functional and understandable. There are also a number of tools that allow people with disabilities to use websites, such as special screen readers or devices that allow you to work on a computer without using a mouse. Joint action by all Member States to ensure the accessibility of websites to Union citizens will contribute to the development of an inclusive digital society and the dissemination of the benefits of the single market. Meeting these requirements for public sector sites is particularly important as they will enable citizens to access a range of public services.

name: Tania GONZÁLEZ PEÑAS
text: written. - I voted in favor of this report on accessibility to websites, because it raises the harmonization of minimum requirements at European level that guarantee access to information on web pages. The text is a second reading, for which the Commission made its first proposal in 2012, in the context of the adoption of the United Nations Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities in 2006. This particular proposal was made to increase web accessibility (websites and mobile applications) of public service providers for all people, including people with disabilities. The directive which establishes harmonized minimum requirements to guarantee access for all, especially in the field of access to information. Parliament tried to extend the scope of the Directive and apply additional measures in the field of surveillance, reporting and enforcement. At second reading the Council reached an agreement, which is supported by Parliament without amendment.

name: Theresa GRIFFIN
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report. We live in a digital age. All citizens should be treated equally when it comes to access to information. This directive is an important first step towards an all-inclusive digital society, ensuring that public sector bodies’ websites and mobile applications will have to be made accessible to everyone.

name: Sergio GUTIÉRREZ PRIETO
text: written. - Around 80 million people in the Union have a disability. With the aging of the population, the number of people with disabilities or difficulties associated with age to access the internet will continue to increase. As a socialist, I consider that it is our responsibility as a society to improve the living conditions of our fellow citizens and for this it is essential to increase the accessibility to information and services of the public sector in the digital age. I have therefore voted in favor of this directive, which represents an important step towards an inclusive digital society. With the new regulations, the web pages and mobile applications of all public bodies - government agencies, courts, police, hospitals, universities or libraries - will have to comply with common accessibility standards and, from this Chamber, we have also ensured that the applications used in mobile phones and tablets will be subject to the new legislation.

name: András GYÜRK
text: in writing. - As is well known, the Kósa report, adopted by the European Parliament on 25 October 2011, has already emphasized that innovative and knowledge-based economies cannot emerge without accessible content and forms accessible to people with disabilities. These include smartphone applications to facilitate the daily lives of people with disabilities and forms of information used in the media, as well as websites accessible to the blind, content for people with hearing impairments, including mass communication services, and online services for sign language users. This is why it is a great achievement that not only the websites of public sector organizations, but also those of public organizations, can be gradually and fully accessible in order to enable people with disabilities to live independently and participate in all areas of life, as defined in the UN Convention. in society. Therefore, in the interests of social inclusion, the websites of public sector bodies and websites providing basic services to the public, such as overheads and health, education, social and key document services, should be made accessible to all people as far as technologically possible and reasonable, as well as information and services provided by interest groups. It is an important success that the representatives and experts of the relevant organizations must be involved in the implementation.

name: Marian HARKIN
text: in writing. ‒ This proposed Directive aims at the approximation of the laws, regulations and administrative provisions of the Member States on the accessibility of websites from public sector bodies, in order to improve the functioning of the internal market. It lays down the rules according to which Member States must ensure that the websites and mobile applications of public sector bodies respect the accessibility requirements. This directive would provide valuable guidelines in this area and therefore, I voted in favour of the regulation.

name: Brian HAYES
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour since I have no objections.

name: Hans-Olaf HENKEL
text: in writing. ‒ The report outlines the accessibility requirements for websites and mobile applications of public sector bodies. These requirements will be a clear improvement for people with disabilities. Moreover, the directive tried to ensure that these new rules do not impose too much of a burden on public sector bodies. Since this is a balanced report, my group and I have voted in favor of it.

name: Filiz HYUSMENOVA
text: In written form. - I support the report on the accessibility of websites and mobile applications by public sector bodies, as I believe that it will help build a strong and inclusive digital society. Harmonizing the rules on digital accessibility measures in Europe will contribute to greater integration of the single market, provide greater information and choice for European citizens and, last but not least, facilitate access to and use of services for European citizens. people with disabilities.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: written.- I voted in favor of the draft legislative resolution on the Council's position at first reading with a view to the adoption of a directive of the European Parliament and of the Council on easier access to websites and mobile applications of public sector bodies (09389/1/2016 - C8-0360 / 2016 - 2012/0340)), given that this aims to ensure dignity, equal rights, make life easier, make it better and provide new opportunities for better integration into the working, social and private lives of the elderly and disabled.Digital time brings new opportunities, but also new obstacles.It is this law that brings new solutions that should bring "e-government" even closer to be accessible to everyone, especially to citizens with disabilities.Price should not be an obstacle to facilitating access to public sector websites and applications.I support this law, which should be adopted and implemented as soon as possible at all levels of public authority in the EU and the Member States.

name: Jean-François JALKH
text: in writing.- This text, whose sincere commitment to the defense of plants cannot be criticized, implies a questioning of the globalization with which I am associated.The fact remains that a worthy cause does not always have the most appropriate means.While there is clearly a need for better control of the bodies, the Commission is at the same time strengthening its prerogatives.Consequently, it is up to her to draw up the list of pests and to arrange for the elimination of the contaminated plants.I therefore abstained.

name: Petr JEŽEK
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of the adoption of a directive of the European Parliament and of the Council on the accessibility of websites and mobile applications of public sector bodies, which addresses barriers for people with disabilities, as there is a need to ensure that barriers are removed in this area.The directive will ensure adequate access to information for blind, deaf and otherwise disabled people.For example, audio files on websites will be subtitled and visually impaired people will be provided with an audio description of the graphics.

name: Marc JOULAUD
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of the report by my colleague Dita Charanzoza on the accessibility of websites of public sector bodies.The directive requires Member States to adopt rules respecting accessibility requirements, in particular for people with disabilities, of content available on the Internet and of mobile applications.I welcome this initiative, which is part of the European strategy for people with disabilities.I am delighted that this report was adopted by a large majority.

name: Philippe JUVIN
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of this text.Indeed, the directive on the accessibility of websites and mobile applications of public sector bodies aims to introduce binding accessibility criteria at Union level, in order to make the content of these sites accessible to all.users and more particularly disabled and elderly people.The EPP managed to impose several points during the negotiations, resulting in a text that combines accessibility rights and reasonable requirements.

name: Barbara KAPPEL
text: written.- The report on accessibility to websites and mobile applications of public authorities aims to create improved conditions for easier access to basic services for citizens within the framework of the European Disability Strategy 2010-2020 - eGovernment Action Plan.I would have approved this report.

name: Afzal KHAN
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report. We live in a digital age. All citizens should be treated equally when it comes to access to information. This Directive is an important first step towards an all-inclusive digital society, ensuring that public sector bodies’ websites and mobile applications will have to be made accessible to everyone.

name: Dieter-Lebrecht KOCH
text: written. - I am delighted that we have finally succeeded in finalizing the directive on barrier-free access to websites and apps of public authorities. Now that more and more public bodies are starting to offer their services to citizens via the Internet, people with mental or physical disabilities have often been denied access to them. There are around 80 million people with disabilities in the EU. You have the same rights and obligations as everyone else. So we mustn't forget them, especially when it comes to technical progress! But on the contrary. We have to create suitable structures and instruments in order to further dismantle existing barriers. The directive on accessibility to websites and apps of public authorities is another important step in the right direction. It creates minimum requirements for barrier-free access and will enable everyone to access the websites and apps of public bodies in the future. It was possible to find a balanced solution that will benefit all those affected. Too far-reaching regulations would have increased the risk that less content will simply be published. Which would be to the detriment of all users.

name: Ádám KÓSA
text: in writing. - As you know, in my report adopted by the European Parliament on 25 October 2011, I have already emphasized that innovative and knowledge-based economies cannot develop without content and forms that are accessible to people with disabilities and introduced by mandatory legislation. These include smartphone applications that facilitate the daily lives of people with disabilities and media tools, as well as websites accessible to the blind, content for people with hearing impairments, including mass communication services, and online services for sign language users. This is why it is a huge achievement that not only the websites of public sector organizations but also those of public service organizations can be gradually and completely accessible so that people with disabilities can lead independent lives as defined in the relevant UN Convention and in all areas of life. participate in society. Therefore, in the interests of social inclusion, the websites of public sector bodies and websites providing basic services to the public, such as overheads and health, education, social and essential document services, should be made accessible to all people, as far as technologically possible and reasonable, or information and services provided by interest groups. Another important success is that the representatives and experts of the organizations involved must be involved in the implementation. So it was clear, I also voted in favor of the legislation.

name: Stelios KOULOGLOU
text: in writing. ‒ This report concerns a proposal from the UN on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities. The aim of this report is to increase the web-accessibility (websites and mobile applications) of public service for all people, including people with disabilities. There was some improvements in this second reading, the report presented some new technical specificities in particular that some common accessibility requirements must be fulfilled. I voted in favour of this report.

name: Andrey KOVATCHEV
text: In written form. - I expressed my support for the creation of a Directive on the accessibility of websites and mobile applications of public sector organizations, as it aims to approximate the laws, regulations and administrative provisions of the Member States on the accessibility of websites of public authorities. It sets out harmonized technical requirements that are essential for the participation of citizens in the economy and social life, as well as for the full enjoyment of their rights. The accessibility of the websites of public institutions will be subject to constant monitoring. The adopted directive primarily concerns the pages of tax offices, employment offices, social security institutions, as well as those providing services such as issuing passports and driving licenses, registering motor vehicles, issuing building permits, birth certificates and concluding birth certificates. marriage. The scope also includes health-related services, such as interactive advice, online services and doctor's appointment, as well as those related to education - applying to a university, access to library catalogs.

name: Ilhan KYUCHYUK
text: in writing. ‒ There is no doubt that we should approve the directive on the accessibility of the websites and mobile application of public sector bodies. It is our moral duty to guarantee that people with disabilities will have better access to information published on the websites and mobile applications of public services. Thus, in this matter, we will not only help Europeans with disabilities to participate fully in society but also will make another step in the process of building of EU digital society.

name: Giovanni LA VIA
text: in writing.- I give a favorable opinion on the proposal on the accessibility of websites and mobile applications of public bodies.According to statistics, almost 80 million people in the Union have a disability that limits their access to the internet, numbers that are likely to increase to 120 million by 2020. For these reasons, Parliament's recommendation outlines the minimum conditions forto make the websites of public bodies, including administrations, courts, hospitals, and universities accessible to the disabled and the elderly.By doing so, these people will have access to some content even through mobile and tablet applications, and will be able to carry out activities such as tax returns, claiming benefits and paying taxes.I have decided to vote in favor of the recommendation.

name: Philippe LOISEAU
text: in writing.- The proposed directive aims to harmonize the laws and regulations, as well as the administrative practices of the Member States, with regard to the accessibility requirements of websites and mobile applications of public sector bodies, in order to improvethe functioning of the internal market.It also lays down the rules under which Member States must ensure that websites, regardless of the device used to access them, and mobile applications of public sector bodies comply with accessibility requirements (elderly and disabled).Despite our constant opposition to the single market, the special attention paid to older people and people with disabilities would have pushed us to abstain, but the text passed without a vote at second reading.

name: Javi LÓPEZ
text: written. - Around 80 million people in the Union have a disability. With the aging of the population, the number of people with disabilities or difficulties associated with age to access the internet will continue to increase. As a socialist, I believe that it is our responsibility as a society to improve the living conditions of our fellow citizens, and for this it is essential to increase the accessibility to public sector information and services in the digital age.
