That is why I voted in favor of this directive, which represents an important step towards an inclusive digital society. With the new regulations, the web pages and mobile applications of all public bodies - government agencies, courts, police, hospitals, universities or libraries - will have to comply with common accessibility standards and, from this Chamber, we have also ensured that the applications used in mobile phones and tablets will be subject to the new legislation.

name: Juan Fernando LÓPEZ AGUILAR
text: written. - Around 80 million people in the Union have a disability. With the aging of the population, the number of people with disabilities or difficulties associated with age to access the internet will continue to increase. As a socialist, I believe that it is our responsibility as a society to improve the living conditions of our fellow citizens, and for this it is essential to increase the accessibility to public sector information and services in the digital age. That is why I voted in favor of this directive, which represents an important step towards an inclusive digital society. With the new regulations, the web pages and mobile applications of all public bodies - government agencies, courts, police, hospitals, universities or libraries - will have to comply with common accessibility standards and, from this Chamber, we have also ensured that the applications used in mobile phones and tablets will be subject to the new legislation.

name: Paloma LÓPEZ BERMEJO
text: written.- I voted in favor of this report as accessibility to public services must be the priority of any public sector web application.I consider it essential that the public sector should be at the forefront both in the development of web applications and in all kinds of accessible services to guarantee access and effective participation in the rights of all citizens.Functional diversity should not be a limit to the exercise of the right, and it is essential that the public sector be the guarantor of this maxim, which should be universally applicable.This is why I have decided to vote in favor of this report.

name: Antonio LÓPEZ-ISTÚRIZ WHITE
text: written.- This proposal for a Directive establishes specific technical provisions by which Member States make the content of certain types of websites of public sector bodies accessible (which offer essential information and services for the participation of citizens in the economy and society).The purpose of the Directive is to approximate the laws, regulations and administrative provisions of the Member States on the accessibility of the websites of public sector bodies, by defining harmonized requirements.I vote in favor of this important legislative instrument to promote the accessibility of websites and mobile applications, aware that there is still a long way to go to achieve full accessibility.

name: Ivana MALETIĆ
text: written. - In 2012, the Commission presented its proposal for a Directive on the accessibility of public sector websites aimed at presenting accessibility for all users. Although many Member States have already taken steps to facilitate access to websites, there are still significant differences between the legislations. The availability of web content is of great importance to public sector bodies, so that they can expand their reach and meet their public obligations, while their number itself is growing rapidly. The Directive aims to approximate the laws, regulations and administrative provisions of the Member States regarding accessibility to all users for the content of public sector bodies' websites. The Directive will lay down minimum requirements for the availability of websites and requires regular monitoring and reporting on their availability by Member States. Thanks to Parliament's efforts, the Directive also covers mobile applications and has been extended to all public sector bodies. The Directive also allows individuals to request certain information "on request" if the content is unavailable. In addition, users have the ability to report any irregularities to the website or application. Since citizens will benefit from wider access to online public sector services, I supported this recommendation.

name: Andrejs MAMIKINS
text: in writing. ‒ I support the proposed directive, which aims at the approximation of the laws, regulations and administrative provisions of the Member States on the accessibility of websites from public sector bodies, in order to improve the functioning of the internal market. It lays down the rules according to which Member States must ensure that the websites and mobile applications of public sector bodies respect the accessibility requirements.

name: Vladimír MAŇKA
text: in writing. - In connection with digitization and expanding electronic services, the requirements for accessibility of websites and mobile applications of public sector entities are increasing. By providing such services, the public sector can better, more efficiently and more flexibly communicate with citizens, inform them about its services and activities, and thus increase its transparency and accountability. This form of communication is particularly important for people with disabilities, who thus have a secure opportunity to obtain the necessary information and a better opportunity for active civic life. At the same time, there is a wide space for companies doing business with electronic services and creating websites and mobile applications. There is a need to unify and harmonize the minimum requirements for the provision and creation of these services, which is why I support the proposal for a directive of the European Parliament and of the Council on the accessibility of public sector bodies' websites and mobile applications.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: in writing.- I support the recommendation for second reading on the position of the Council at first reading with a view to the adoption of the Directive of the European Parliament and of the Council on the accessibility of websites and mobile applications of public sector bodies, for the reasons set out inI mentioned in detail in my speech at the Plenary Session of the European Parliament in Strasbourg on 25 October 2016, as well as because this report is sufficiently substantiated.

name: Dominique MARTIN
text: in writing.- Digital technology is an excellent way to impose single market harmonization on Member States by establishing common rules.However, the fact that it promotes easy access to websites cannot be viewed negatively.

name: Valentinas MAZURONIS
text: in writing.- I supported the recommendation on the accessibility of public sector bodies' websites and mobile applications.This solution will increase access to public sector websites and mobile applications for people with visual, mobility or other disabilities.The new rules provide for specific measures, such as alternative text describing images or the provision of audible information on websites.These rules have been agreed with all the Member States, so with Parliament's approval today, there are no longer any obstacles to the entry into force and improvement of the use of mobile applications by people with disabilities.Member States will have 21 months to transpose them into national law.

name: Jean-Luc MÉLENCHON
text: in writing. - This directive specifies the implementation of accessibility on all public sector websites. Accessibility is governed by technical rules of the W3C (World Wide Web Consortium) and the WAI (Web Accessibility Initiative) to allow access to web content to people with disabilities (deaf, blind, motor disabled) and to people with disabilities. seniors (loss of vision, etc.). It is fundamental to promote web accessibility for the greatest number of people. This is one of the principles that I defend with web neutrality and the protection of the data of users of internet services. This approach is therefore in the right direction. However, this report takes place (as always) in the context of the constitution of the digital single market: standardization of accessibility rules in all the countries of the Union in order to be able to call, potentially, on all the agencies of the Union. Under the guise of improving the access of people with disabilities to websites, it is in fact a matter of strengthening competition and pressure on Member States. The process is unfair. I voted against this text at first reading, I maintain my opposition and vote against to be as incomprehensible as the texts in question.

name: Joëlle MÉLIN
text: in writing.- The proposed directive aims to harmonize the laws and regulations as well as the administrative practices of the Member States with regard to the accessibility requirements of websites and mobile applications of public sector bodies in order to improve the functioning of theindoor market.It also lays down the rules under which Member States must ensure that websites, regardless of the device used to access them, and mobile applications of public sector bodies comply with accessibility requirements (peopleelderly and disabled).Despite our constant opposition to the single market, the special attention paid to the elderly and the disabled would have prompted us to abstain, but the text passed without a vote at second reading.

name: Nuno MELO
text: in writing. - This Directive will assist Member States to fulfill their national commitments regarding accessibility of the web, as well as their commitment under the United Nations Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities with regard to public sector bodies. . What is proposed is the harmonization of national measures for the public sector at EU level as a necessary condition to end this fragmentation and lack of confidence in the web accessibility market. This Directive focuses on the websites of public sector bodies. , because these bodies provide essential information and services for citizens and because public orders alone can already create a safe and reasonably sized market for website creators. Harmonization will lead to the creation of better market conditions, more jobs , reducing the cost of web accessibility and creating more accessible websites: a triple win for governments, businesses and citizens. Hence my vote in favor.

name: Roberta METSOLA
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this legislative resolution, which calls for measures to improve the accessibility of the sites and apps run by public sector bodies. It is of the utmost importance that no segment of the Union’s population is left behind in our drive towards a digital economic and the sharing of information between governments and citizens.

name: Louis MICHEL
text: in writing. - The number of websites providing e-government services (around 380,500 in the Union) and public sector websites (over 761,000 in the Union) is growing rapidly. Most Member States have already either adopted legislative measures or taken other measures on web accessibility. However, there are still considerable differences between these laws and measures. However, non-harmonized national approaches to web accessibility create obstacles within the European internal market. This Directive aims to approximate the laws and regulations as well as the administrative practices of the Member States with regard to accessibility requirements for websites and mobile applications of public sector bodies, in order to improve the functioning of the indoor market. It lays down the rules under which Member States must ensure that websites, regardless of the device used to access them, and mobile applications of public sector bodies comply with accessibility requirements by making them perceptible, usable, understandable and robust. I therefore very much welcome this objective of harmonization.

name: Marlene MIZZI
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted in favour of the report because we all live in a digital age, and therefore all citizens should be treated equally when it comes to access to information. This directive is an important step towards an inclusive digital society, ensuring that public sector bodies’ websites and mobile applications will have to be made accessible to everyone.

name: Csaba MOLNÁR
text: in writing.- The Commission has proposed to the European Parliament and the Council the adoption of a Directive of the European Parliament and of the Council on the accessibility of public sector bodies' websites and mobile applications.Parliament adopted its position at first reading on 26 February 2014.Following subsequent consultations, the Council also adopted its position at first reading, and the Committee on the Internal Market and Consumer Protection recommends in its report that Parliament agree at second reading.I voted accordingly

name: Bernard MONOT
text: in writing.- The proposed directive aims to harmonize the laws and regulations as well as the administrative practices of the Member States with regard to the accessibility requirements of websites and mobile applications of public sector bodies which must be 'perceptible, usable, robust and understandable ”, in order to improve the functioning of the internal market.This Directive also lays down the rules under which Member States must ensure that websites, regardless of the device used to access them, and mobile applications of public sector bodies comply with accessibility requirements (elderly and disabled).The concern brought by the text to these fragile audiences would have tempered our desire to oppose the text (adoption without a vote).

name: Cláudia MONTEIRO DE AGUIAR
text: in writing. - The evolution towards a digital society offers users new ways to access information and services. Information and service providers, as well as public sector bodies, increasingly rely on the Internet to produce, collect and make available a wide range of information and services electronically, which are essential for the public. Within the scope of this Directive, the term "accessibility" should be understood as the principles and techniques to be observed in the design, construction, maintenance and updating of websites and mobile applications, in order to make their content more accessible to users, in particular people with disabilities. I advocate a close relationship in order to help Member States to fulfill their national commitments regarding accessibility of the web, as well as their commitment under the United Nations Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities with regard to bodies the public sector.

name: Sophie MONTEL
text: in writing.- Improving the single market and extending it to all sectors of the economy should not be an end in itself.I note a desire to make certain services more accessible to the elderly, which is positive.No vote on this text.

name: Claude MORAES
text: in writing. ‒ We live in a digital age, and all citizens should be treated equally when it comes to access to information. This directive is an important first step towards an all-inclusive digital society, ensuring that public sector bodies’ websites and mobile applications will have to be made accessible to everyone.

name: Nadine MORANO
text: in writing.- This report related to the accessibility of websites and mobile applications of public sector bodies.It was a second reading text for which no rejecting amendment was tabled.This text was therefore approved without a vote.

name: Victor NEGRESCU
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted for this recommendation regarding the adoption of a directive on the accessibility of the websites and mobile applications of public sector bodies.

name: Luděk NIEDERMAYER
text: in writing.- I supported the EP-Council agreement at second reading, which means increasing the accessibility requirements of public administrations' websites and mobile applications and the full involvement of all citizens, including the elderly and people with disabilities, in the information society and the digital single market.In fact, the approved directive takes over existing technical standards (eg the ability to navigate websites without the use of a mouse) in terms of content and ensures that accessibility requirements do not impose a disproportionate administrative burden on public authorities.

name: Franz OBERMAYR
text: written.- I consider the report on barrier-free web access for the disabled and the elderly to be a very good demand, which I can only support.I therefore voted in favor of this report.

name: Urmas PAET
text: in writing.- I supported.The directive harmonises the laws of the Member States in order to improve the functioning of the common market.

name: Demetris PAPADAKIS
text: in writing. - I voted in favor of the report as the accessibility of the websites and applications for mobile devices of public sector organizations, ie the providers of information and services necessary for the citizens, must be ensured for all users, especially for people with disabilities. 80 million people and make up 15% of the EU’s potential active population. Member States and the EU must take appropriate measures to ensure, on an equal basis, access for people with disabilities, including Communication and information technologies, including the Internet Non-harmonized national approaches to web accessibility create barriers to the internal market. It is therefore proposed to harmonize national public sector measures at EU level as a prerequisite for ending this fragmentation and lack of confidence in the web accessibility market. Harmonization will lead to better market conditions, more jobs, lower web-accessibility costs and more accessible websites.

name: Aldo PATRICIELLO
text: in writing.- There is no doubt that the internet has become an essential tool for obtaining and providing information and services, therefore, it is therefore more important than ever to ensure that all citizens can be able to perceive and understand websites and mobile applications and interact with them.I believe that the proposal under consideration is a necessary step to ensure the accessibility of the websites and mobile applications of institutions by all.Therefore, I voted in favor.

name: Marijana PETIR
text: written. - Establishment of websites of public bodies that offer information and services essential for the participation of citizens in society and the economy, such as information on taxes, social security, vehicle registration, personal documents, etc. are a subject of public interest. Citizens, and especially the elderly and people with disabilities, have difficult access to this information. Therefore, efforts should be made to edit such websites in a way that is accessible and easy to use - so that users can easily and consistently view and search pages with easy interaction and understanding of the content. I support this Directive because it is necessary to establish and harmonize the laws and administrative provisions of the Member States regarding access to the websites of public bodies, which is what this Directive requires. It also sets out technical provisions on how Member States will make the website accessible to all. This Directive is important in order to improve the market for services related to digital data access and to provide access to all citizens, especially the elderly and people with disabilities. With all that said, it is crucial to allow users to give their opinion, critiques and suggestions so that such websites can be further developed.

name: Florian PHILIPPOT
text: in writing.- The proposed directive aims to harmonize the laws and regulations as well as the administrative practices of the Member States with regard to the accessibility requirements of websites and mobile applications of public sector bodies which must be 'perceptible, usable, robust and understandable ”, in order to improve the functioning of the internal market.The cause of the disabled is thus hypocritically used to defend the internal market and European integration ... This text was adopted without a vote.

name: Tonino PICULA
text: written. - We are creating a digital society in Europe and we need new ways to access information and services. Public sector bodies, as well as other providers, are increasingly relying on the Internet to produce, collect and offer a wide range of information and services of fundamental importance to the public. We must also take into account all our citizens with disabilities when creating pages, bearing in mind the UN Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities. Easy access to the website is of great importance for public sector bodies, expanding the reach as much as possible is key to fulfilling their duties. The number of websites offering public services is growing and further work on harmonizing national measures at EU level is needed. We need to put an end to market fragmentation as well as the loss of faith in offering online services. We must provide citizens with disabilities with easy access to public services on the Internet, to help them enjoy their rights throughout our Union. This is an important step towards a digital society in which all citizens participate.

name: João PIMENTA LOPES
text: in writing. - We consider the proposal to introduce mandatory accessibility for certain types of public sector sites (State, region, local and public law bodies) to be essential, in essential electronic government services, such as network services, in the banking sector. , in education, social security, health services, social inclusion services and cultural activities. This directive aims to improve the lives of citizens, especially people with disabilities and the elderly, with regard to the accessibility of these sites of public bodies, taking into account that much of the information available is online. However, we believe that it must be safeguarded that Member States that have already developed their national accessibility policies and standards, based on WCAG 2, should be exempt from the application of this directive. In this way, additional costs for national, regional, local and other public authorities are avoided. On the other hand, the availability of these services on a digital platform cannot under any circumstances mean the suppression or limitation of access to the same services through traditional infrastructures. The lack of access to the internet or the inability to use this resource and functional illiteracy are a reality that cannot be neglected and that affects a significant part of the population.

name: Salvatore Domenico POGLIESE
text: in writing. - The directive will establish minimum conditions for making the websites of public bodies accessible to people with disabilities. Thanks to Parliament's efforts, the agreement will also cover mobile phone applications and the scope will be extended to all public sector entities (thus beyond the 12 categories initially proposed by the Commission). Some contents may be excluded, but only if not necessary for essential administrative procedures. Public bodies will have to prepare an "accessibility statement" regarding their compliance with the directive, explaining which parts of their website or application are not accessible. The directive will also make it possible to request specific information "on demand" if the content is inaccessible. This is a common sense legislative proposal that will concretely improve the lives of those citizens who suffer from disabilities. I voted in favor of approving this recommendation.

name: Franck PROUST
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of this report on the accessibility of websites and mobile applications of public sector organizations.The aim of this directive is to introduce binding criteria at European Union level, to make the content of sites more accessible, particularly to the disabled.

name: Paulo RANGEL
text: in writing. - In 2012, the Commission presented a proposal for a Directive related to the standardization of accessibility requirements for public bodies' web pages and mobile applications. After the European Parliament's approval at first reading, and following an agreement in the negotiations with the Council, a second reading is now put to a vote. The purpose of the proposal is to facilitate access to the content of public bodies' platforms to all users, with special attention to those with special needs. The Directive stipulates the introduction of minimum accessibility conditions, as required by the monitoring and regular communication of websites and mobile applications of public bodies in the Member States. Because the information and public services available on the Internet must meet the standards of an inclusive society, I support this text and, in that sense, my vote is in favor.

name: Frédérique RIES
text: in writing. - The European Parliament today approved a new directive ensuring that the websites of public sector bodies are always accessible to people with disabilities. According to liberal rapporteur Dita Charanzová, more than 80 million citizens will benefit from this new legal framework which will come into force in about two years. It will therefore soon be over with the obstacle course that mainly blind, deaf and people with functional limitations live on a daily basis. With this new directive, citizens with visual impairments will hear, for example, descriptions of images when using a screen reader, and the hearing impaired will see subtitles for audiovisual files if they access to sites of public sector bodies within the Union. Web accessibility for all citizens will henceforth be the law of the land in Europe for all websites and applications of government authorities. As the promotion of equality should not stop at the digital door, it is important to already consider the next step, namely to think about the adoption of a legislative act on accessibility. private sector web (e-commerce, banking and insurance) for people with disabilities.

name: Liliana RODRIGUES
text: in writing.- This Directive aims to improve accessibility to public sector websites and their content by citizens with some type of disability, but also for the elderly.We live in a digital age and all citizens must be treated equally with regard to access to information.This Directive is an important step towards an inclusive digital society, ensuring that public sector institutions make their websites and applications accessible to everyone.

name: Inma RODRÍGUEZ-PIÑERO
text: written. - Around 80 million people in the Union have a disability. With the aging of the population, the number of people with disabilities or difficulties associated with age to access the internet will continue to increase. As a socialist, I believe that it is our responsibility as a society to improve the living conditions of our fellow citizens, and for this it is essential to increase the accessibility to public sector information and services in the digital age. That is why I voted in favor of this directive, which represents an important step towards an inclusive digital society. With the new regulations, the web pages and mobile applications of all public bodies - government agencies, courts, police, hospitals, universities or libraries - will have to comply with common accessibility standards and, from this Chamber, we have also ensured that the applications used in mobile phones and tablets will be subject to the new legislation.

name: Claude ROLIN
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of this draft legislative resolution on the Council's position at first reading on the directive on the accessibility of websites and mobile applications of public sector bodies.This directive will allow better accessibility of the websites and mobile applications of public sector organizations for people with disabilities.This is essential since more than 80 million people in the Union are affected by a disability and it is part of the European strategy 2010-2020 in favor of people with disabilities and Article 9 of the conventionof the United Nations on the rights of persons with disabilities.Its imminent entry into force underlines the European desire to assume a leading role in this area.

name: Fernando RUAS
text: in writing. - In 2012, the European Commission presented its proposal for a Directive on accessibility to the websites of public sector bodies. In addition to the objective of introducing standardized accessibility features within the EU, it is also intended that the process of accessing that content should be easy and accessible to all users. This directive aims to establish minimum conditions for the accessibility of websites on an equal basis, requiring, for this purpose, regular monitoring of the functioning evaluation by the Member States. In addition, mobile applications are now included in the Directive, following a proposal by the European Parliament. Public bodies must also prepare a "declaration of accessibility" - in accordance with the Directive under consideration, thus allowing the new legislation to citizens to request more specific information, in case the content is or is inaccessible, while also having the opportunity to notify any failures of the website or application. For the substantial improvements that I believe this Directive will bring to the current system after it has been implemented, I voted in favor of this report.

name: Lola SÁNCHEZ CALDENTEY
text: written. - I voted in favor of this report on accessibility to websites, because it raises the harmonization of minimum requirements at European level that guarantee access to information on web pages. The text is a second reading, for which the Commission made its first proposal in 2012, in the context of the adoption of the United Nations Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities in 2006. This particular proposal was made to increase web accessibility (websites and mobile applications) of public service providers for all people, including people with disabilities. The directive which establishes harmonized minimum requirements to guarantee access for all, especially in the field of access to information. Parliament tried to extend the scope of the Directive and apply additional measures in the field of surveillance, reporting and enforcement. At second reading the Council reached an agreement, which is supported by Parliament without amendment.

name: Sven SCHULZE
text: written.- I voted in favor of the report on accessibility to websites of public authorities.The Commission's proposal on barrier-free access to websites of public authorities dates from 2012 and is intended to define standardized access features across the EU.This guideline introduces minimum requirements for barrier-free access.Member States are requested to monitor and report on the barrier-free access requirement to the sites and apps.This was also extended to the area of mobile applications.

name: Maria Lidia SENRA RODRÍGUEZ
text: written.- I voted in favor of this report as accessibility to public services must be the priority of any public sector web application.I consider it essential that the public sector should be at the forefront both in the development of web applications and in all kinds of accessible services to guarantee access and effective participation in the rights of all citizens.Functional diversity should not be a limit to the exercise of the right, and it is essential that the public sector be the guarantor of this maxim, which should be universally applicable.This is why I have decided to vote in favor of this report.

name: Remo SERNAGIOTTO
text: in writing.- Thanks to the new directive, rules will be established for the first time at EU level that will guarantee accessibility to the websites and mobile applications of public bodies such as, for example, administrations, police departments, hospitals for people with disabilities and the elderly, universities, libraries and courts.There are currently around 80 million people in the EU who have a disability and it is estimated that with the aging of the population the number of people with difficulties accessing the web will increase to 120 million by 2020. In carrying out operations such as tax returns, payment of taxes or university enrollment, it is often important for disabled people to be able to transform text into voice, images into text, or use PCs without a mouse.I have therefore decided to express myself in favor of this directive, with the hope that the new provisions will be quickly transposed by the Member States.

name: Siôn SIMON
text: in writing. ‒ Today I voted for the Accessibility of websites and mobile applications of public sector bodies. We live in a digital age, all citizens should be treated equally when it comes to access to information, this Directive is an important first step towards an all-inclusive digital society, ensuring that public sector bodies’ websites and mobile applications will have to be made accessible to everyone.

name: Monika SMOLKOVÁ
text: in writing. - The current rapidly growing market for greater access to digital products and services includes a whole range of economic operators, including creators of websites or software tools for creating, managing and testing websites or mobile applications. To date, several Member States have taken measures based on internationally used guidelines for creating accessible websites, but unfortunately technical differences at national level and inconsistent national rules limit the potential benefits of exchanging experiences with partners at national and international level. I supported the current motion for a resolution because I think it is necessary to ensure that websites and mobile applications of public sector bodies are more accessible on the basis of common accessibility requirements and that the inconsistency of the internal market is ended. I believe that by approximating national measures at Union level on the basis of agreed accessibility requirements for public sector bodies' websites and mobile applications, we will remove all obstacles to the functioning of the internal market and reduce costs for public sector bodies and others to procure products and services related to website accessibility. and mobile applications.

name: Igor ŠOLTES
text: in writing. - The aim of this 2012 proposal is to remove unnecessary barriers to the internal market resulting from a fragmented approach to accessibility, especially in the segment of digital administration and public administration websites. In its proposal, the Commission has established technical details that can make Member States more accessible to the content of certain types of websites. The harmonized access standard is expected to be technology-neutral in the future so that it can be used on different devices with different software. The proposal is otherwise limited to certain parts of public administration and digital administration, as the Commission anticipates that these areas will also have an impact on other areas (i.e. spill-over effect). Negotiations with the European Council have shown that the Council is trying to exclude as many areas for potential harmonization as possible, and in the end a compromise has been reached, including limited exclusions on material that would impose a disproportionate burden on public administration. , taken from the Public Procurement Directives, and applications to be included with a delay. Modernizing public administration across the European Union is very important. At the same time, it is good that all Member States include certain innovations in their work. For all the above reasons, I voted in favor of the recommendation.

name: Ivan ŠTEFANEC
text: in writing.- We are interested in digitizing citizens' communication with the authorities and using all the tools that new technologies offer us to save costs and improve services.In this endeavor, we must not forget citizens with disabilities, which do not allow them to perceive and control websites and mobile applications in the same way as the majority population.We are therefore introducing a rule that all forms of online communication between public institutions should also be available in a version for the disabled.

name: Patricija ŠULIN
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of the recommendation for second reading on the Council's position at first reading with a view to the adoption of a directive of the European Parliament and of the Council on the accessibility of public sector bodies' websites and mobile applications.The Internet has become key to accessing information and services in recent years.It is important to give everyone access to the website.I welcome the pan-European rules for more accessible public sector websites and mobile applications, especially for the blind, deaf and hard of hearing.The digital single market must serve all citizens, so a common approach to ensuring online accessibility is a step in the right direction.

name: Eleftherios SYNADINOS
text: in writing.Every effort to organize and introduce public sector electronic technology, which is of course necessary, must be related to the single market or the unrestricted movement of people.This initiative loses its real purpose and creates normal and justified reactions.

name: József SZÁJER
text: in writing. - As is well known, the European Parliament has already emphasized in the Kósa report adopted on 25 October 2011 that innovative and knowledge-based economies cannot emerge without content and forms introduced by mandatory legislation that are accessible to people with disabilities. These include smartphone applications that facilitate the daily lives of people with disabilities and media tools, as well as websites accessible to the blind, content for people with hearing impairments, including mass communication services, and online services for sign language users. This is why it is a great achievement that not only the websites of public sector organizations, but also those of public organizations, can be gradually and fully accessible in order to enable people with disabilities to live independently and participate in all areas of life, as defined in the UN Convention. in society. Therefore, in the interests of social inclusion, the websites of public sector bodies and websites providing basic services to the public, such as overheads and health, education, social and key document services, should be made accessible to all people, as far as technologically possible and reasonable, or information and services provided by interest groups. Another important success is that the representatives and experts of the organizations involved must be involved in the implementation. So it was clear that I also voted in favor of the legislation.

name: Tibor SZANYI
text: in writing. - I voted in favor of the second reading recommendation on accessibility of websites. The Recommendation concerns the adoption of a Directive of the European Parliament and of the Council on the accessibility of public sector bodies' websites and mobile applications. The report clearly targets the disabled, but the draft also affects the elderly. With the exception of a few types, the draft requires all public administrations to make their website and mobile application accessible. All this to help the blind and visually impaired, the deaf and hard of hearing, and people with reduced mobility. At the time of drafting the recommendation, there was a debate on the involvement of public service broadcasters, and the final agreement is that this area will be covered by a separate sector-specific legislation. I believe that, living in the digital age, not only must all citizens be treated equally, but there are also the technical conditions for this when it comes to access to information. I share the view that this directive is an important step towards an inclusive digital society that ensures that public administration websites and mobile applications are accessible to all.

name: Adam SZEJNFELD
text: in writing. - Equal access of citizens, including people with disabilities, to public information is a cornerstone of modern democracy and civil society. It is extremely important in both the real and virtual world. It is of key importance when it comes to people with disabilities, because for some of them, contact with public institutions via the Internet is the only chance to maintain a bond with their authority, their country. Therefore, the idea implemented in the presented project deserves our full support. The virtual world will be one of the main areas for the self-realization of citizens, which is why the final work of the European Parliament is so important. However, it should be remembered that the concepts must not be mixed and the obligations of public institutions and the private sector equal. The tasks we are discussing today must be effectively carried out by the public sector, but should not be imposed top-down on the private sector. In view of the extreme importance of this report, especially for people with disabilities, I have decided to vote in favor of it.

name: Claudiu Ciprian TĂNĂSESCU
text: signed up. - In the knowledge society, or digital society, where the basic pillars are information, connection of information and communication, accessibility of websites and mobile applications in the public sector (of public bodies or managed by entities performing public tasks) is essential, and adopting a harmonized approach at EU level would reduce costs for all actors involved. The Internet, considered the most interesting tool of balance that man has ever made, generates new models of organization and economic activity, offering users new opportunities to access information and services, but also new and unique jobs. Today, the Internet has become an essential tool for access to education, information and social development. As such, for personal and professional development, citizens must have extensive access to online public services, but also to information, cultural and entertainment websites, in order to ensure their fundamental rights.

name: Claudia ȚAPARDEL
text: signed up. - The European Union is the guarantor of respect for the rights of all its citizens at all levels, without discrimination. In these circumstances, the European institutions must consider providing adequate services for people with disabilities. These services include public websites and mobile phone applications for public use. They must be designed to provide accurate and complete information for all citizens of the Member States, including the blind or partially sighted, deaf or hard of hearing. The Commission came up with a proposal in this regard as early as 2012, but it included a wide range of public broadcasters, without taking into account the specific conditions of each area of ​​public communication. The current document concerns only electronic broadcasting channels, leaving the audiovisual field to another specific regulation. Given the time needed to adopt this regulation, I believe that it should be adopted without delay in order to enable people with disabilities to benefit from the implementation of the measures. For this reason, I support the adoption of this report.

name: Marc TARABELLA
text: in writing.- Still too many websites and mobile applications in the public sector are not accessible to everyone.In Europe, 15% of the total population, or 80 million disabled citizens or the elderly, suffer from this situation.Filing a tax return, applying for unemployment benefits, paying a bill or enrolling a child in school then becomes a horrible adventure.After the vote in the European Parliament this afternoon, public administrations, hospitals, courts, universities and other public sector organizations will be forced to be fully accessible on the internet or through mobile applications.

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: in writing. ‒ National differences in the accessibility of website and mobile applications within the EU often impose unnecessary burdens and barriers on companies as well as citizens, especially the ones that use assistive technologies, such as the visually and hearing impaired. I voted in favour of the proposal because I believe that in harmonising national differences in website and application accessibility, we can ensure consistency across the board in the EU and ensure that people with disabilities have access to the same public services as anyone else.

name: Patrizia TOIA
text: in writing.- Our daily life is radically changing thanks to mobile applications and digital technologies, there are many positive aspects, but questions related to the dissemination of data and privacy remain.The report by my colleague Charanzova represents an essential element for the protection of the citizen, since it establishes that everyone should be treated equally when it comes to access to information.This Directive is an important step towards an inclusive digital society, as it will allow accessibility to public sector websites and all content for disadvantaged groups such as citizens with disabilities, the elderly, the blind and people with impaired vision., the deaf and people with functional disabilities.

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: written. - I supported the Directive on easier access to websites and mobile applications of public sector bodies, which aims to ensure better accessibility of these bodies, especially for people with disabilities. As a number of public consultations and studies have been conducted to identify problems and needs related to their accessibility, I believe that the final text is in line with the United Nations Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities. I demand that public sector bodies explain the reasons why some content is inaccessible, which is particularly important, as it can ensure transparency and information of citizens, and new rules that make significant progress in accessibility for blind, partially sighted and visually impaired people are extremely useful. by hearing impairment. This primarily refers to the ability to change the size or color of the text, the introduction of a text-to-speech function and a function for describing images, and a search without the use of a mouse. As this will improve the availability of public sector body content in practice, I supported this report.

name: Romana TOMC
text: in writing. - I supported the draft legislative resolution on the Council's position at first reading with a view to the adoption of a directive of the European Parliament and of the Council on the accessibility of websites and mobile applications by public sector bodies. Online accessibility is very important for public sector bodies, as they can expand their reach and fulfill their public responsibilities. The number of websites providing eGovernment services (around 380,500 in the EU) and public sector websites (over 761,000 in the EU) is growing rapidly. Most Member States have already adopted laws or other measures to make them accessible online. However, there are major differences between these laws and measures. Non-harmonized national approaches to online accessibility create barriers in the internal market. The proposed harmonization of national measures for the public sector at EU level is a necessary condition to eliminate the fragmentation of the framework and mistrust in the online accessibility market. Harmonization will create better market conditions, more jobs, cheaper online accessibility and more accessible websites: a threefold benefit for the public sector, businesses and citizens.

name: Estefanía TORRES MARTÍNEZ
text: written. - I voted in favor of this report on accessibility to websites, because it raises the harmonization of minimum requirements at European level that guarantee access to information on web pages. The text is a second reading, for which the Commission made its first proposal in 2012, in the context of the adoption of the United Nations Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities in 2006. This particular proposal was made to increase web accessibility (websites and mobile applications) of public service providers for all people, including people with disabilities. The directive which establishes harmonized minimum requirements to guarantee access for all, especially in the field of access to information. Parliament tried to extend the scope of the Directive and apply additional measures in the field of surveillance, reporting and enforcement. At second reading the Council reached an agreement, which is supported by Parliament without amendment.

name: Ramon TREMOSA i BALCELLS
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour as this is one more step in the direction of more transparency and information to our citizens. The public access to information and documents is essential in order to contribute to the improvement of administrative practice.

name: Mylène TROSZCZYNSKI
text: in writing.- This directive aims to harmonize the laws and regulations as well as the administrative practices of the Member States with regard to the accessibility requirements of websites and mobile applications of public sector bodies which must be "perceptible, usable,robust and understandable ', in order to improve the functioning of the internal market.It also lays down the rules under which Member States must ensure that websites, regardless of the device used to access them, and mobile applications of public sector bodies comply with accessibility requirements (peopleelderly and disabled).This text aims to improve the single market against which I am against, but the attention it pays to the elderly and people with disabilities motivates my abstention.

name: István UJHELYI
text: in writing.- I also supported the proposal for a Council position at first reading with a view to the adoption of a directive of the European Parliament and of the Council on accessibility of public sector bodies' websites and mobile applications, which is part of the ordinary legislative procedure.

name: Miguel URBÁN CRESPO
text: written. - I voted in favor of this report on accessibility to websites, because it raises the harmonization of minimum requirements at European level that guarantee access to information on web pages. The text is a second reading, for which the Commission made its first proposal in 2012, in the context of the adoption of the United Nations Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities in 2006. This particular proposal was made to increase web accessibility (websites and mobile applications) of public service providers for all people, including people with disabilities. The Directive which establishes harmonized minimum requirements to guarantee access for all, especially in the area of ​​access to information. Parliament tried to extend the scope of the Directive and apply additional measures in the field of surveillance, reporting and enforcement. At second reading the Council reached an agreement, which is supported by Parliament without amendment.

name: Ivo VAJGL
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the recommendation for second reading on the Council position at first reading with a view to the adoption of a directive of the European Parliament and of the Council on the accessibility of the websites and mobile applications of public sector bodies. The new directive aims at the approximation of the laws, regulations and administrative provisions of the Member States on the accessibility of websites from public sector bodies. The directive supports Member States to achieve their national commitments regarding web-accessibility as well as their commitment to the United Nations Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities regarding websites of public sector bodies. Web-accessibility refers to principles and techniques to be observed when constructing websites, in order to render the content of these websites accessible to all users, in particular those with disabilities. I voted in favour because I believe that in a harmonised framework, the web-developers industry should face fewer barriers to operate in the internal market, while costs for governments and others procuring web-accessibility products and services should be reduced.

name: Ángela VALLINA
text: written.- I voted in favor of this report as accessibility to public services should be the priority of any public sector web application.I consider it essential that the public sector should be at the forefront both in the development of web applications and in all kinds of accessible services to guarantee access and effective participation in the rights of all citizens.Functional diversity should not be a limit to the exercise of the right, and it is essential that the public sector be the guarantor of this maxim, which should be universally applicable.This is why I have decided to vote in favor of this report.

name: Hilde VAUTMANS
text: written.- The Council position indicates that the accessibility of websites is of great importance to public authorities as it allows them to extend their reach and fulfill their public tasks.The number of websites offering eGovernment services (about 380 500 in the EU) and public sector websites (more than 761 000 in the EU) is growing rapidly.Most Member States have already adopted legislation or other measures in the area of web accessibility.However, there are major differences between these laws and measures.This proposal harmonises the national legislation of the Member States, thus removing the obstacles in the internal market.This proposal on the harmonization of national measures for the public sector at EU level received my support.

name: Miguel VIEGAS
text: in writing.- The proposal for a directive on the accessibility of the websites of public sector bodies (COM (2012) 721) presented by the EC sets out specific technical provisions whereby Member States must make the content of certain types of information accessible.websites of public sector bodies (which provide essential information and services for citizen participation in the economy and society).The Directive aims to approximate the laws, regulations and administrative provisions of the Member States relating to the accessibility of the websites of public sector bodies, by defining harmonized requirements.

name: Harald VILIMSKY
text: written.- The concept of "barrier-free Internet access" includes methods and techniques that must be observed when creating websites in order to make their content accessible to people with disabilities.Accessible access to websites is of great importance for public authorities as it enables them to reach more people via the Internet and thus to fulfill their public responsibilities.I think this measure makes sense and I have therefore agreed.

name: Anna ZÁBORSKÁ
text: in writing. - In today's modern age, the importance of the Internet and online services is unquestionable. The number of websites providing e-government services and the entire public sector is growing dynamically from year to year. Although most Member States have enacted legislation on website availability, there are significant differences between them. The main problem is the lack of harmonization in this area, which creates several obstacles in the internal market. Businesses do not have the knowledge and skills to master local specifications and procedures, which ultimately increases their costs and is demotivating. Harmonization will have a positive impact not only on citizens and businesses, but also on the governments of individual Member States, as market conditions will improve. The right to free movement and provision of services is a right for every EU citizen, and therefore citizens should benefit from greater availability of online public sector services and relevant information that will make it much easier for them to exercise their rights. I support the proposal because it aims to help small and medium-sized enterprises operate not only locally, but especially within the wider EU framework.

name: Tomáš ZDECHOVSKÝ
text: in writing.- I support this directive with my voice and I am glad that it has finally been successfully completed.It is clear that in recent years more and more communication has been moving to the Internet and that most areas of human life are being digitized.That is why I very much welcome the fact that the European Union is also responding to this trend and introducing legislation on the accessibility of websites and applications of public sector bodies.Personally, I see the greatest potential of the directive for disabled people and the elderly.Enabling e-communication with government authorities or, for example, hospitals or the police will save them both time and money, but above all will make their lives easier.

name: Auke ZIJLSTRA
text: written.- This document was adopted without a vote.However, the PVV is against the text because the resulting obligations are contrary to the principle of subsidiarity.

name: Jana ŽITŇANSKÁ
text: in writing. - Of course, I support the European Parliament's recommendation on the Council's position at first reading with a view to adopting a directive on the accessibility of public sector bodies' websites and mobile applications. I think that the accessibility of websites and mobile applications is extremely important for people with visual or hearing impairments. It will help them to have the necessary information on the activities of public authorities on their own, making it easier to deal with matters of everyday life. The adoption of this directive has not been easy, as a proposal for its adoption was submitted as early as 2012, but due to many shortcomings, it was not possible to complete the legislative process. That is why I appreciate the work of various organizations of people with disabilities, which have provided practical comments on the proposal. Thanks to them, it was also possible to reach this compromise text, and the directive will thus bring about the approximation of rules in the EU Member States, which in practice will make life easier for people with disabilities. I believe that this compromise is a step forward.

name: Milan ZVER
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of the European Parliament's legislative resolution on the Council's position at first reading with a view to the adoption of a directive of the European Parliament and of the Council on the accessibility of public sector bodies' websites and mobile applications (09389/1/2016 - C8-0360 / 2016 - 2012/0340 (COD))(Ordinary legislative procedure: second reading).The aim of this proposal is to remove unnecessary barriers to the internal market resulting from a fragmented approach to accessibility, especially in the segment of digital administration and public administration websites.

name: Peter JAHR
text: on behalf of the PPE Group.-  Mister President!World trade is basically a good thing.It is, if you will, the peaceful sharing of a created surplus value in human society.However, with the exchange of agricultural products and the worldwide trade in plants, unknown pests are also introduced.Not only do we have to observe this situation, we also have to act in this situation.We have now given the Commission a mandate to act, so to speak, to combat unknown pests here and, if you will, to control them upon entry.I think it is extremely important, because otherwise these pests will also damage our crops in the European Union.I now hope for a good end result, together with the Commission and together with the European Council.

name: Rosa D'AMATO
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, this new regulation is the fruit of months of constant work with the rapporteur and colleagues, but it is above all a great success for the defense of agriculture and the environment. By replacing a 15-year-old directive, we finally go beyond the contradictions of the Commission which with the xylella affair is showing many gaps in the management of emergencies. Yes, because, after having imposed simply impracticable measures to combat the bacterium, the Commission, through the voice of Commissioner Andriukaitis, has implemented an infringement procedure against Italy, denying it the possibility of carrying out an environmental impact assessment. The reason is that this would entail a delay with respect to the obligation to act immediately and therefore to eradicate hectares of olive groves, even secular ones. Environment Commissioner Vella, however, does not think so exactly. Responding to my question, he stresses that the plans for the eradication of harmful organisms to plants of agricultural interest must be subject to environmental assessment, thus not excluding emergencies. But in addition to this purely political quarrel, we should move on parallel tracks and therefore on the technical and scientific level, but we have on the one hand Italy, which for months has provided only information on the pathogen and on potential vectors, and on the other France, which was unable to provide evidence of any kind on its infected plants and which, after discovering that it was using a wrong test, unable to identify the xylella pauca strain, accuses Italy of contagion and also discovers , that in its territory a sub-species has already generated different strains, giving rise to well-founded suspicions of a long presence of xylella in French soil. I repeat, then, what I have been saying for months: let us standardize scientific research at EU level. Is the problem European? Here, then as such it should be treated. It is only a matter of time and more new outbreaks will be discovered. It is useless to sanction the Member States: it is not with disrespectful eradications of the environment, nor with economic blackmail that phytosanitary emergencies are countered, but with far-sighted political actions and regulations such as the one we voted today.

name: Jiří POSPÍŠIL
text: - I was asked by citizens in my country, the Czech Republic, whether the EP needed to adopt such regulation, whether individual Member States should not comprehensively address the issue of plant pests themselves. At first glance, it seems that this is perhaps a European unnecessary adjustment. I myself am not in favor of too much European legislation and too much dissemination of European legislation. I respect the principle of subsidiarity, but in this case I voted in favor of this proposal because it is clear that only individual nation states cannot fight pests that have a pan-European presence. In short and well, the pest does not respect and knows no national borders, and the fight can be effective if we work together and if the EU coordinates this. This proposal contributes to this. That is why I supported him, because the fight against pests will certainly be more effective than if each state acted alone.

name: Seán KELLY
text: – Mr President, this proposal reminds me of an experience I had a number of years ago on my one and only visit to New Zealand. When I was going to New Zealand I was stopped at customs because I was eating an apple and I would not be let in. I was told there was a danger of bringing diseases into the country. I was fined NZD 120 and when I said, ‘I am going to eat the apple’ I was asked, ‘What are you going to do with the core of the apple?’ and I said, ‘I will throw it away’. He said, ‘Exactly, you are not entitled to, you can bring in a disease’.  This is what is required here because there is a danger, and I understand that now, through globalisation and climate change that pests etc. could damage plants within the European Union. For that reason, it is only right that we should be very vigilant in that regard and have a sensible approach to it because we have to protect our environment and we have to protect our plants. While we do not have to charge people NZD 120 if they eat an apple, there is a certain logic, I suppose, in it. I learned my lesson.

name: Isabella ADINOLFI
text: in writing.- The issue of harmful organisms for plants is becoming, with the passage of time, a very delicate issue.In fact, just look at what is happening in Italy with the Xylella parasite, which is killing thousands of olive trees in the Puglia region.It is therefore clear that there is a need to introduce a regulation introducing tighter import regimes and restrictive conditions for environmental protection.That is why I have decided to vote negatively on the rejection amendment.

name: Marina ALBIOL GUZMÁN
text: written.- Despite the fact that there are aspects in this report that can be improved, such as the implementation of preventive measures and measures to combat and adapt to climate change, I have voted against the amendment proposed by ALDE that requests the rejection of the proposallegislative.I consider it important that this report be adopted and I find the progress made throughout the negotiations to be very positive, through which the regulation imposed strict controls on the importation of plant material into the Union.Something essential to avoid future outbreaks of pests and diseases in plants (such as the problem of "Xylella fastidiosa" in olive trees).

name: Eric ANDRIEU
text: in writing. - I was among the first to sound the alarm in the face of the Xyllela fastidiosa, the chestnut beetle or the olive fly. Our farmers need to be better protected against the entry of these pests, which cause extensive damage to their crops. In order to fight against health threats of this type, I had advocated tirelessly for a system of border protection which would allow better control of the entry of plant pests into the European Union. It is now done. The European Union will finally apply rules of reciprocity in health matters with its major trading partners! We were asking for an import control system based on risk management. This draft regulation will allow the implementation of a real preventive strategy. Indeed, thanks to a preliminary assessment, plants and plant products presenting a high risk will be identified and prohibited from importation until a phytosanitary risk assessment has been carried out. This text will allow better protection of plant health and, consequently, of our ecosystem and of the biodiversity of the European Union.

name: Nikos ANDROULAKIS
text: in writing. - I voted in favor of the recommendation for second reading on the position of the Council at first reading with a view to the adoption of a Regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on protection against plant pests, amending Regulations (EU) No 1095/2010 228/2013, (EU) no. 652/2014 and (EU) no. Regulation (EC) No 1143/2014 of the European Parliament and of the Council and repealing Directives 69/464 / EEC, 74/647 / EEC, 93/85 / EEC, 98/57 / EC, 2000/29 / EC, 2006/91 / EC and 2007/33 / EC because the new legislation should ensure a high level of security for the EU with regard to imports of plants and plant products.

name: Pascal ARIMONT
text: written.- Parliament passed a regulation to curb the introduction and spread of plant pests such as the "olive tree killer bacterium" Xylella fastidiosa.The new regulation, which I welcome, will introduce preventive and rapid response mechanisms for suspicious plant imports, intensify pest control efforts in the EU and oblige all Member States to draw up outbreak plans.

name: Marie-Christine ARNAUTU
text: in writing. - The general objective of this text is to respond to the risks to plant health, caused by new harmful organisms and diseases, imported from third countries. A critique of globalization and its effects on trade therefore remains in the background. The text aims to modernize control instruments, both within the internal market (improvement of traceability) and in the context of trade with third countries, while strengthening a risk-based approach. To this end, this draft lays down the rules making it possible to determine the pest risk presented by any species, strain or biotype of pathogenic agent, animal or parasitic plant harmful to plants, as well as the measures aimed at reducing this risk to a acceptable level. While the text increases controls on the entry and movement of new bodies in the internal market, it also increases the power of the Commission. It will thus be responsible for drawing up the list of pests and deciding on the eradication of affected plants, as it did this year with the olive trees affected by Xylella fastidiosa in Puglia. I abstained on the reject amendment.

name: Jonathan ARNOTT
text: in writing. ‒ This was not a final vote but a vote to reject the Council position at the second reading. I voted in favour of stopping this legislation.

name: Jean ARTHUIS
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of establishing a transparent, sustainable and European common regulatory framework aimed at controlling and preventing the deamination of non-native pests.This European framework is necessary, because we can no longer be only in the reaction, but we need anticipation.

name: Zigmantas BALČYTIS
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of the report on plant protection products amending the regulations of the European Parliament and of the Council.The overall objective of the Regulation is to halt the risks posed by new pests and diseases in the plant health sector arising from global trade and climate change.The aim is to modernize plant health measures for both intra-EU and third-country trade, focusing on risk-based approaches.

name: Nicolas BAY
text: in writing.- I abstained on this vote because while the text as a whole increases controls on the entry and movement of new bodies in the internal market, it also increases the power of the Commission.This is a further attack on the sovereignty of France that I cannot condone.

name: Hugues BAYET
text: in writing. - The Union’s phytosanitary regulatory framework aims to protect European agriculture and forestry by preventing the entry and spread of non-native pests. However, the current regulatory framework suffers from certain limitations in view of new challenges linked to the globalization of trade and climate change such as the more frequent arrival of new pests as well as the establishment of organisms that previously did not survive in Europe. In view of the importance of establishing a regulatory framework capable of protecting the health of our citizens as well as our economy, I therefore voted in favor of this proposal for a directive. This indeed proposes to redefine the rules making it possible to determine the phytosanitary risk presented by any species, strain or biotype of pathogenic agent, animal or parasitic plant harmful to plants or plant products and the measures aimed at reducing this risk to an acceptable level. In particular, Member States will need to develop and maintain a separate plan for each priority quarantine pest likely to enter and establish itself in its territory. The text also provides for the modernization of phytosanitary instruments linked to trade (in particular by improving traceability on the internal market).

name: Beatriz BECERRA BASTERRECHEA
text: written.- I voted in favor of new measures being put in place to curb the entry into the EU of plant pests such as Xylella fastidiosa and equip Member States with the means to combat their spread.The new Regulation introduces preventive and rapid response mechanisms for suspicious imports, intensifies surveillance within the EU and obliges all Member States to have emergency plans for possible outbreaks.These measures serve to protect citizens of the Union from pests that a plant, plant product or other object from a third country could introduce.

name: Brando BENIFEI
text: in writing. - The outbreak of the Xylella fastidiosa epidemic, which has damaged many olive groves in Italy, has brought the fundamental issue of plant health to public attention. The McIntyre report, which I supported, aims precisely to define a series of protective measures against harmful organisms affecting the plant world. In a globalized time, with continuous commercial traffic and climate change, the extent of risks is constantly increasing and requires the use of innovative tools that are able to respond effectively to new challenges. The new regulation represents a response to this need; it provides for rapid response mechanisms for suspected plant imports, the establishment of emergency plans for outbreaks in all Member States and a general increase in pest surveillance efforts in the Union. The request for a phytosanitary certificate will be extended for all plants and plant products from third countries, as will the use of the "plant passport" within the EU. Member States will be allowed to impose eradication measures even in private places subject to the correspondence of fair compensation to those farmers who suffer these measures.

name: Xabier BENITO ZILUAGA
text: written. - I am voting against this amendment. I agree with this regulation as its objective is to prevent the entry and spread of pests in plants of two types: quarantine pests and regulated non-quarantine pests. In the last AGRI committee on October 13, this report was approved with 28 votes in favor. Thanks to the modifications made by the shadow of the report, this document on plant pests calls for the implementation of strict controls on imports of plant material into the European Union with the intention of avoiding future pests and plant diseases (such as Xylella Fastidiosa that attacks olive trees and caused a 20% rise in the price of oil in 2015). After this second reading, we believe that it would be good if it were adopted, so we believe that it is important to vote against this amendment proposed by the ALDE parliamentary group. ALDE votes against because it considers the proposal very restrictive regarding the import regime, while we want a restrictive import regime that protects our plants and crops.

name: Izaskun BILBAO BARANDICA
text: written.- I voted in favor of the agreement on protection measures against plant pests, against my group and the amendment presented by it contrary to the agreement.The report calls for new measures to curb the entry into the EU of plant pests such as the bacterium Xylella fastidiosa and to equip Member States with the means to combat their spread.The new Regulation introduces preventive and rapid response mechanisms for suspicious imports, intensifies surveillance within the EU and obliges all Member States to have emergency plans for possible outbreaks.This Regulation will entail certain measures that will have to be put into effect as soon as possible.

name: Dominique BILDE
text: in writing. - I chose to abstain on the rejection amendment tabled by the ALDE group on the second reading of the draft legislative resolution on protective measures against plant pests. In itself, the legislative proposal carries a rather laudable desire, that of limiting the risks posed to our plants by new harmful organisms or diseases imported from third countries. It is therefore a question of modernizing the control instruments, in particular by improving traceability, which I am in favor of. However, I am concerned that the Commission is using this precautionary principle for political recovery, in particular by increasing its powers in this area, sometimes to the detriment of our national farms. Responsible for drawing up the list of harmful organisms, the Commission will thus be able to decide on the eradication of the affected plants, as it did for the olive trees affected by Xylla fastidiosa in Puglia, undermining the olive oil sector. 'Italian olive.

name: Mara BIZZOTTO
text: in writing.- The adoption of a new regulation on protection measures against plant pests can be a good starting point for combating more effectively the growing phytosanitary problems, in particular those caused by the spread of pests from distant countries,that damage the crops and the environment of our territories.However, we must be careful that the new regulation does not entail new bureaucratic burdens for our businesses.

name: José BLANCO LÓPEZ
text: written.- I voted in favor of the definitive approval of the agreements reached with the Commission and the Council on the new basic European regulations for plant health.The Union's plant protection regime is crucial for the development and competitiveness of European agriculture.The final agreement does not include the positive list system in force for animal health, which we would have liked to apply also to plant health, but it does substantially improve the Commission's initial proposal through a closed system for plants and vegetables from"high risk".Those classified "as low risk" will continue under the current import control system but with the addition of the phytosanitary passport, now implemented at European level.

name: Vilija BLINKEVIČIŪTĖ
text: in writing. - I voted in favor of this recommendation, which deals with protection against plant pests. Plant health is essential for plant production, forests, natural habitats and planted areas, natural ecosystems, ecosystem services and biodiversity in the Union. Plant health is threatened by species harmful to plants and plant products, the introduction of which into the territory of the European Union is currently at greater risk due to the globalization of trade and climate change. In order to combat that threat, it is necessary to adopt measures to identify and reduce to an acceptable level the phytosanitary risks posed by those pests. It has long been recognized that such measures are necessary. Criteria should therefore be laid down to identify the pests for which measures need to be adopted in order to prevent their introduction into and spread throughout the EU. Such pests are called quarantine pests in the European Union. Criteria for the identification of pests for which it is necessary to adopt control measures applicable only to one or more parts of that territory should also be laid down. Such pests are called protected area quarantine pests. Where those pests are plants, the implementation of this Regulation should pay particular attention to those plants which are parasitic to other plants and which are most harmful to plant health.

name: Andrea BOCSKOR
text: in writing.- The draft phytosanitary regulation, based on a political agreement between the European Parliament and the Council, is mainly aimed at simplification and standardization.In addition to consolidating a number of pieces of legislation (mostly directives), it has become necessary to emphasize the principle of prevention in the fight against plant pests, to prioritize pests more rationally, to strengthen scientific research and to share costs and responsibilities fairly.The final text is in line with Hungarian national interests.That is why I voted against the attempt by one of the parliamentary groups to block the adoption of the text.

name: Simona BONAFÈ
text: in writing. - As a result of the globalization of markets, we are witnessing an increase in the volumes of trade flows but, at the same time, also the multiplication of the risks of contagion by diseases and other harmful organisms. This is why an agreement at European level is needed to protect agriculture, a key sector of the European economy. I therefore welcome an agreement aimed at strengthening prevention in this sector, to limit the entry of harmful organisms into European territory through the trade in plants. In fact, the new regulation introduces a risk pre-assessment mechanism; essential to ensure that plants and other plant protection products considered to be at risk can no longer cross EU borders.
