In addition to greater scrutiny, there is also considerable trade facilitation, which aims to improve collaboration between Member States, as well as a significant streamlining of certification practices. The instruments contained in the agreement will therefore allow the European Union to develop a more proactive policy in defense of biodiversity and the competitiveness of our agricultural sector.

name: Biljana BORZAN
text: written.- I support this Report on Protective Measures against Plant Harmful Organisms.I believe that the new law will provide a high level of security for the European Union with regard to imports of plants and plant products.With the new system, the import of some pests will be much more difficult, and new quarantine measures will be tailored to each case and farmers will be supported in eradication procedures, in addition to receiving compensation for their loss.

name: Marie-Christine BOUTONNET
text: in writing.- This report calls for strengthening the competence of the Union as regards the definition of harmful organisms and plants to be eradicated if necessary, while I consider that this should remain the competence of the Member States.On the other hand, it contains an interesting critique of the effects of globalization, in particular on trade.I abstained on the rejection amendment.

name: Renata BRIANO
text: in writing. - The European Parliament approved, at first reading, a legislative resolution on the proposal for a Council regulation on protective measures against plant pests. Attention must be paid to the risk of introducing plant pests into the Union territory, as this risk has increased due to the globalization of trade and climate change. Parliament therefore stressed the importance of adopting preventive and protective measures, and early identification of the presence of harmful organisms to ensure rapid and effective eradication. The regulation should lay down rules on phytosanitary inspections and phytosanitary measures to prevent the introduction of harmful organisms from other Member States or third countries. Furthermore, it is necessary to make available to the public all information on the possible economic, environmental and social impacts of plant parasites. Also of paramount importance is raising awareness and training in pest control, professionals, local government officials, garden centers, importers, researchers, government department officials, politicians and individuals. The text also plans to modernize commercial phytosanitary tools, favoring a risk-based approach.

name: Steeve BRIOIS
text: in writing.- This report aims to protect plants from harmful organisms, in particular imported from third countries.To achieve this, the text recommends modernizing control instruments, particularly in terms of traceability, both within the internal market and within the framework of trade with third countries.To this end, this draft resolution lays down the rules for determining the pest risk presented by any species, strain or biotype of pathogenic agent or by any parasitic plant harmful to plants, as well as the measures aimed at reducing this risk to a levelacceptable.Admittedly, this report promotes stricter controls on the entry and movement of new bodies in the internal market.However, it also helps to strengthen the power of the European Commission, now responsible for listing these pests.That’s why I abstained on this text.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: in writing.- Today we approved new EU rules to help prevent the spread of parasites in plants, such as Xylella fastidiosa in olive groves, in Europe, and to stem potential outbreaks.This regulation introduces new preventive rapid response mechanisms for suspected plant imports, intensifies pest surveillance efforts in the EU and requires all Member States to develop contingency plans for outbreaks.Pests and diseases do not respect national borders.That is why it is so important to have rules across the EU to protect our agriculture, horticulture and forestry, through a proportionate and risk-based approach, including better cooperation between Member States.

name: Matt CARTHY
text: in writing. ‒ This file came before the Parliament as a second reading, therefore there was no vote on the overall report – only one amendment to reject the result of inter-institutional negotiations.  The regulation imposes strict controls on importing plant material into the EU in the hopes of avoiding future outbreaks of plant diseases, such as the recent xylella fastudiosa attacking olive trees in France, Germany and Italy. The regulation will make it possible to protect against plant material that could be dangerous from a phytosanitary point of view by implementing a sort of quarantine system. Delegated and implementing acts will come later, listing pests to be designated as either priority pests, quarantine pests or non-regulated quarantine pests. Given these good elements, I voted against the amendment to reject the compromise text.

name: David CASA
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of an agreement at second reading. Generally the new regulation is to address the increased risks in the plant health sector from new pests and diseases arising from globalisation and climate change, as well as the risk associated with plants imported from third countries. It introduces for example the idea of a ‘plant passport system’ to all movements of plants for planting within the EU, including those ordered through distance sales, with the exception of home gardeners.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: in writing. - The phytosanitary factor is of crucial importance for a sustainable and competitive agriculture, horticulture and forestry but also important for both the protection of biodiversity and economic services. Pests from other continents have proven to be particularly dangerous and can cause serious economic losses by compromising the competitiveness of our farmers. This regulation, which will replace a 15-year old directive, contains favorable elements and measures such as: containment and prevention measures in cases where eradication is no longer possible, increases compensation for the affected territories, guarantees greater transparency through the creation of an ad hoc register for emergencies, the conditions for identifying a priority test of social and environmental conditions are mentioned for the first time and in particular reference is made to tree species of great importance in terms of landscape and heritage cultural or historical for the Union (secular olive trees), with the reference to EFSA as the main scientific interlocutor removed.

name: Caterina CHINNICI
text: in writing. - Plant health is a key factor for the competitiveness of the agriculture, horticulture and forestry sectors. Pesticides or harmful organisms such as insects, fungi, bacteria and viruses, especially from other continents, can cause serious damage to plants and spread rapidly in the absence of an adequate protection system. I would like to recall the case of Xylella fastidiosa, a bacterium from America, which in 2104 devastated about 30,000 hectares of olive groves in the Italian region of Puglia, causing significant economic losses for growers. Also in the light of this dramatic event, I believe it is necessary to modify the basic legislation to deal with the risks associated with the arrival of new parasites on the territory of the Union as a consequence of the processes of globalization and climate change. I therefore believe that the new regulation, aiming at a higher degree of security of the import system, goes in this direction. For these reasons, I voted in favor of the recommendation.

name: Lefteris CHRISTOFOROU
text: in writing.- We are voting against this report which contains many points of friction.

name: Alberto CIRIO
text: in writing. - The proposal presented welcomes all my favor since Italy, thanks to its climate, enjoys a particularly flourishing territory, yet it is also sadly exposed and vulnerable to the risk of introduction of new pathogenic organisms, whose presence is over to increase for trade and climate change. Suffice it to consider how viruses, fungi and insects are heavily attacking our excellences of the earth, one above all: chestnuts, whose production has been killed by the wasp, a Chinese parasite that causes trees to dry up, causing damage of over 200 million. This provision requires an update of phytosanitary certificates for non-EU trade and for plant passports in intra-EU trade. In conjunction with this, an electronic system for notification of information is set up and the nature of a pest being classified as quarantine is established in order to facilitate rapid protection against pathogens. I therefore renew the mandate addressed to the Commission to identify organisms for which priority intervention obligations must necessarily be established and, at the same time, to draw up a list of high-risk plants and products for which special measures should be prescribed.

name: Deirdre CLUNE
text: in writing. ‒ I did not support the amendment on the protective measures against pests of plants and I am in favour of accepting the Council position on the matter.

name: Lara COMI
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of the recommendation on the introduction of the procedure for suspending imports of plants considered dangerous.The requirement of the phytosanitary certificate for the transport of plants in the luggage for both importers and consumers, and the extension of the system of the "plant passport" for the movements of plants to be planted within the EU,they strengthen and modernize the control mechanisms of plant diseases, which are particularly important for the European countries most exposed to the risk of introducing new pathogens.

name: Javier COUSO PERMUY
text: written.- Although there are aspects in this report that can be improved, such as the implementation of preventive measures and measures to combat and adapt to climate change, I have voted against the amendment proposed by ALDE, which requests the rejection of the proposallegislative.I consider it important that this report be adopted and I find the progress made throughout the negotiations to be very positive, through which the regulation imposed strict controls on the importation of plant material into the Union.Something essential to avoid future outbreaks of pests and plant diseases (such as the Xylella fastidiosa problem in olive trees).

name: Andrea COZZOLINO
text: in writing. - Through this legislative resolution, the European Parliament approves the position of the Council with a view to adopting the regulation on protective measures against organisms harmful to plants. With my vote in favor, I wanted to support this resolution because I believe that the protection of the agricultural and forestry sectors is a top priority for the EU economy and for the health of its citizens. The environmental damage and economic loss of farmers caused by the Xylella pest to olive groves in the southern Member States must no longer be repeated. The regulation takes note of the rapid spread of pests and diseases across national borders and makes important improvements to the existing legislative framework. The current European objectives are: to prevent the entry of harmful plant organisms into the EU, to eliminate them when they are already present and to avoid the spread of any outbreaks. Among the measures envisaged to achieve the identified objectives, a better protection regime for importable products, clearer rules for protected areas and harmonization of phytosanitary passports at European level have been identified.

name: Edward CZESAK
text: in writing.- I voted against the regulation on protective measures against plant pests.Although the report sets the ambitious goal of laying down rules for identifying phytosanitary risks related to any type of plant pest or plant product, the Regulation does not address the most important issues.In my opinion, the most important steps that should be taken in this area are trade defense and avoiding excessive bureaucracy.The regulation does not focus on such important issues at all, which is why I voted against.

name: Miriam DALLI
text: in writing. ‒ I am in favour of this report as this new framework reinforces the synergies with the plant reproductive material regime to protect EU agriculture from the entry and spreading of plant pests. The report also asks for better surveillance and the early eradication of outbreaks of new pests whilst introducing a plant passport, which is an innovative way to ensure a high degree of traceability. I am confident that the new legislation will assure a higher degree of security for the European Union with regards to imports of plants and plant products whilst also ensuring support for farmers.

name: Michel DANTIN
text: in writing. - This report deals with the reform of the European Union's system of monitoring and combating health hazards that could affect plants. I was particularly mobilized on this file in parliamentary committee, because it perfectly embodies the action of the European Union to protect its citizens. This text seems to me all the more necessary as public opinion and we ourselves want the use of fewer pesticides to protect our crops. The best way to protect crops is to prevent primary infection. For there to be no primary infection, we need to have more active controls on the various movements of goods, which are increasing due to globalization. I prefer to have effective controls at the airport of Antwerp or Paris, rather than our farmers hanging around in front of infected crops, unable to treat them because we will not have any product to do so and because the research is not going fast enough. We can see it clearly with Xylella, a plague that affects my constituency! With this legislation, a case like Xyllela can in the future be avoided. For these reasons, I voted in favor of this report.

name: Rachida DATI
text: in writing.- I supported this text, the general objective of which is to deal with the increased risks facing the plant and variety production sector in Europe and which result from the appearance of new harmful organisms and new diseases.This text also provides for the establishment of a phytosanitary certificate with which professional operators importing plant products must be provided, as well as customers of postal and internet services and passengers carrying risky varieties in their luggage.This makes it possible to modernize the phytosanitary instruments linked to trade, favoring a risk-based approach.

name: Angélique DELAHAYE
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of this report on protective measures against plant pests.These measures seem to me to be entirely relevant and will allow better protection of the health of plants, forests, natural spaces and biodiversity.The report proposes in particular to put in place harmonized surveillance and control for quarantine pests, phytosanitary certificates to control and regulate the import of varieties at risk, as well as variety passports to manage the movements of these species.within the EU.Plant products presenting a high risk will be identified and prohibited from importation until a phytosanitary risk assessment has taken place.These traceability and risk control obligations will allow effective protection of the territories of the European Union, which is essential.

name: Jean-Paul DENANOT
text: in writing.- Faced with the succession of health accidents due to the importation of harmful organisms such as Xyllela fastidiosa, it is important that measures be taken at European level in order to avoid the spread of this type of parasite which can cause destructionwhole crops and undermine an entire regional agroeconomy.This text constitutes real progress for the protection of Union territory and I welcome its adoption.

name: Marielle DE SARNEZ
text: in writing.- Since 2013, the Italian region of Puglia has been facing a major ecological disaster.The olive groves are wiped out by a bacterium for which there is no treatment, "Xylella fastidiosa", which has spread to Corsica.This bacterium, previously unknown in Europe, is believed to originate from South America.The Union must protect plant production and biodiversity.This is why it must identify plants and plant products presenting a risk and prohibit them from importation until a phytosanitary risk assessment has been carried out.The surveillance system must be improved, and a traceability obligation for all plant products put in place.

name: Martina DLABAJOVÁ
text: in writing.- The position agreed by the European Parliament at first reading has moved significantly in line with the wording of the Council's position.Nor do I agree with the new proposal for an import regime, because, above all, there must be a balance between import restrictions and the protection of commercial interests.The safeguard measures proposed in this version of the proposal do not guarantee this.For these reasons, I agree with the proposal to reject the Council's proposal.

name: Mireille D'ORNANO
text: in writing. - The general objective of this text is to respond to the risks to plant health caused by new pests and diseases from third countries. It aims to modernize control instruments, both within the internal market, such as improving traceability, but also within the framework of trade with third countries. It sets the rules for determining the phytosanitary risk presented by any species, strain or biotype of pathogenic agent, animal or parasitic plant harmful to plants (or plant products), as well as measures aimed at reducing this risk to an acceptable level. While the text strengthens controls on the entry and movement of new bodies in the internal market, it also increases the power of the Commission. The latter will thus be responsible for drawing up the list of harmful organisms. It will also be able to decide on the eradication of affected plants, as it did this year with olive trees affected by Xylella fastidiosa in Puglia. Also, I preferred to abstain.

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: in writing. - Recent experience with Xylella fastidiosa demonstrates gaps in regulations on plant pests. Globalization, e-commerce and new conditions must be taken into account in order to protect Europe's flora. The Union must, of course, realize that there are other ways to deal with diseases other than eradication and must develop a phytosanitary management strategy to reduce treatment time. We note that eradication carries other risks and that national and regional authorities must be given the option of restraint.

name: Norbert ERDŐS
text: in writing.- The draft phytosanitary regulation, based on a political agreement between the European Parliament and the Council, is mainly aimed at simplification and standardization.In addition to consolidating a number of pieces of legislation (mostly directives), it has become necessary to emphasize the principle of prevention in the fight against plant pests, to prioritize pests more rationally, to strengthen scientific research and to share costs and responsibilities fairly.The final text is in line with Hungarian national interests.That is why I voted against the attempt by one of the parliamentary groups to block the adoption of the text.

name: Jill EVANS
text: in writing. ‒ I did not vote to reject the Council’s position on this regulation as it will impose strict controls which will help to avoid future outbreaks of plant diseases. Whilst there was concern about the timescale for implementation, I believe the measures are important for farmers and producers in Wales.

name: Fredrick FEDERLEY
text: written.- Unfortunately, this second settlement agreement has become more protectionist compared to the mandates that Parliament last gave for negotiations.In the end result, we see that the provisions on import restrictions based on diseases in plants have gone from being a regular risk-based assessment based on science to to a greater extent opening up to overly arbitrary assessments and large administrative burdens for importers.For me, the EU's rules to prevent the spread of plant diseases should not be a tool for setting up disproportionate barriers to trade, and unfortunately, in my opinion, this report has gone too far in that direction.

name: José Manuel FERNANDES
text: in writing.- Plant health represents an essential factor for sustainable and competitive agriculture, horticulture and forestry.It is necessary to have healthy seeds and propagating material in order to obtain profitable crops and to guarantee jobs, plant innovation and security of food supply.Pests from other continents are particularly dangerous.In general, European plants and trees do not have adequate genetic resistance against alien pests, which, moreover, do not usually have natural enemies here.When introduced to Europe, alien pests cause serious economic damage.Economic losses, sometimes serious, compromise the profitability and competitiveness of agriculture and forestry.Therefore, I agree with the protection measures recommended in the report.

name: Edouard FERRAND
text: in writing.- Abstention: this concerns the recommendation for second reading on the Council's position at first reading.The AGRI Committee recommended that Parliament approve the Council's position at first reading without making any amendments.There is no final vote at second reading.The vote in plenary is on a rejection amendment tabled by the ALDE group.

name: João FERREIRA
text: in writing. - The purpose of this regulation is to prevent the entry and spread of plant pests of two types, quarantine pests and unregulated quarantine pests that are allowed up to a limit. One of the main concerns raised by the legislative proposal was the registration and certification of producers, which represented a risk of potential impact on small producers with low-risk products, selling only small volumes of low or zero risk plants (including seeds), which they would have to pay to register and face prohibitive fines, when they should not be the target for which these measures are intended. There was yet another group unintentionally affected, seed supply organizations that carry out actions to conserve rare varieties and species and ensure genetic biodiversity. These concerns were duly safeguarded in the final version of the regulation. During the negotiations it was also possible to guarantee (thanks to pressure from the countries of the South) that this regulation imposes strict control over the import of plant material into the EU, thus hoping to prevent future outbreaks of plant diseases (such as the recent attack by Xylella fastidiosa in the olive trees). Even though all the concerns were not removed, but the main ones were removed, the text was improved throughout the process of its discussion.

name: Monika BEŇOVÁ
text: in writing.- Plant health is a key factor for the future and presentation of a sustainable and competitive agricultural and forestry industry in the European Union.It is very important that we focus on protecting agriculture in Europe by preventing the entry and spread of harmful organisms and pests, such as insects, fungi, bacteria and viruses, which can cause serious damage to plants, especially if they come from other continents andEurope lacks genetic resistance to them.The new legislation should bring about a significant increase in safety for plant health and plant products in the European Union.The introduction of a plant passport is also an innovation that will bring a high level of traceability in the future.

name: Lampros FOUNTOULIS
text: in writing. - I am voting against plant protection pests as the recent experience with Xylella fastidiosa shows the gaps in the regulations on plant pests. Globalization, e-commerce and new conditions must be taken into account in order to protect Europe's flora. The Union must, of course, realize that there are other ways to deal with diseases other than eradication and must develop a phytosanitary management strategy to reduce treatment time. I note that eradication carries other risks and that national and regional authorities must be given the option of restraint.

name: Ashley FOX
text: in writing. ‒ I voted for this report as it strikes a good balance between avoiding unnecessary bureaucracy and making sure that we have the tools to respond to large scale pest threats. Strengthening health and safety in food is something that the EU does well. Much of our food comes across borders and we ensure that the customer buys something that passes rigorous tests and meets high standards.

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: in writing. ‒ I am confident that the new legislation will assure a high degree of security for the European Union with regards to imports of plants and plant products. With the new system, the introduction of pests such as Xyllela fastidiosa in southern Italy or Asian long-horned beetle in the UK would be much more difficult. Also the new measures for quarantine will be tailor-made for each case and farmers would be supported in the eradication procedures also receiving compensation for their losses. The introduction of a plant passport is also an innovation brought in by this regulation which would ensure a high degree of traceability.

name: Enrico GASBARRA
text: in writing.- I welcome the proposal for a new regulation on protective measures against plant pests and harmful organisms.The safety of the EU phytosanitary regime is essential for safeguarding the agricultural economy, but also for health.For this we need more organized and strict controls, a prevention framework and certain rules for our safety and traceability of plant movements in the EU capable of dealing with the new frontiers of online business.I particularly appreciate the idea of the plant passport, to ensure full-scale monitoring especially on potentially risky imports from third countries into the Union.

name: Elena GENTILE
text: in writing. - I voted in favor of the resolution on the Council's first reading position with a view to adopting a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on protective measures against pests of plants, amending Regulations (EU) No. 228/2013, (EU) no. 652/2014 and (EU) no. 1143/2014 of the European Parliament and of the Council and repeals Directives 69/464 / EEC, 74/647 / EEC, 93/85 / EEC, 98/57 / EC, 2000/29 / EC, 2006/91 / EC and 2007 / 33 / EC of the Council, because I think it is important to definitively approve the reform of the EU legislation on plant protection. As demonstrated by the Xylella affair, the current EU legislation is inadequate to guarantee the protection of plant organisms from harmful organisms, due to various defects such as import controls, standard emergency interventions not related to the specific characteristics of the territories and organisms affected, absence of compensatory measures, delays in the implementation of good agricultural practices. Interinstitutional negotiations have made it possible to find good compromises, eliminating the 10% limit for pesticide quarantine and introducing an approach to imports based on the precautionary principle, and the obligation for importers to show the phytosanitary certificate. I therefore hope for rapid approval of the new legislation.

name: Arne GERICKE
text: written.- I voted in favor of the report on measures to protect against plant pests.It is essential for biodiversity in Europe to find ways of effective, yet environmentally friendly control of pests.

name: Michela GIUFFRIDA
text: in writing. - If until a few years ago the phytosanitary aspects of agriculture were the subject of professionals, today things have changed a lot. Cases such as that of Xylella in Puglia, and that of Tristeza today in Sicily, turn the spotlight on a problem, that of plant infection, which creates enormous damage to an agricultural sector already heavily in crisis. This regulation certainly intervenes to improve the alert system: better surveillance and early eradication of new outbreaks, as well as the modernization of trading tools are important measures. But more needs to be done. Both ex ante and ex post. Ex ante controls of products arriving from third countries must be much stricter and the Commission must be prompt in the event of interception of infested products, the "precautionary principle" must be strengthened. Today the trade associations, for example, tell us the citrus black spot on which to intervene immediately. Ex post, when unfortunately it is now necessary to remove and replant, farmers must be adequately supported with direct aid without leaving everything to the RDPs. The European Union is perhaps excessively exposed to the entry of goods from third countries and this has very serious repercussions, especially on our agriculture, safety must remain the priority.

name: Sylvie GODDYN
text: in writing. - This report aims to combat new harmful organisms and new diseases from third countries which present a danger to our crops and crops. However, even if this text indirectly mentions the effects of globalization on the proliferation of invasive species and organisms, it is content to respond to these threats by a simple desire to improve controls and traceability. This includes reducing the risks posed by these invasive species and organisms to an acceptable level. But increased controls will not end the entry of these species into the internal market and substantially increase the powers of the European Commission. This will be able to decide in particular on the eradication of affected plants, as it did this year with the olive trees affected by Xylella fastidiosa in Puglia. I therefore abstained from this report, which does not address the causes of the problem, namely the opening of borders without respecting environmental balances. In reality, the Commission will not hesitate to completely eradicate cultures, sometimes ancestral, which are very important to our regions, while it is itself partly responsible for the proliferation of invasive species that attack these cultures.

name: Bruno GOLLNISCH
text: in writing. - Globalization is definitely not happy, no more for plants than for humans. Importing anything and everything from any country indeed leads to bringing in undesirable people (diseases, parasites, predatory plants, etc.) to which the local vegetation is vulnerable. A bit like fighters from the "Islamic State" group in the flow of Syrian or Iraqi migrants that we are called upon to welcome. The text before us today aims to strengthen controls on imports potentially carrying organisms harmful to plants and to improve protection measures (quarantines, phytosanitary certificates, etc.) depending on the risk involved. However, it is the Commission alone which is responsible for both the risk analysis and the decision. In the case of the bacterium Xylella fastidiosa, which attacks olive trees in southern Italy, I understood that its capacity for discernment was not completely reliable, since it recommended the felling of hundred-year-old trees ( and therefore the ruin of their owners), while the bacteria in question did not represent a danger for the quality of olives or for health. What more favored the extra-European imports. In terms of importing harmful organisms, whether terrorists or bacteria, experience shows that nothing should be left in Brussels.

name: Tania GONZÁLEZ PEÑAS
text: written. - I am voting against this amendment. I agree with this regulation as its objective is to prevent the entry and spread of pests in plants of two types: quarantine pests and regulated non-quarantine pests. At the last AGRI committee on October 13, this report was approved with 28 votes in favor. Thanks to the modifications made by the shadow of the report, this document on plant pests calls for the implementation of strict controls on imports of plant material into the European Union with the intention of avoiding future pests and plant diseases (such as Xylella Fastidiosa that attacks olive trees and caused a 20% rise in the price of oil in 2015). After this second reading, we believe that it would be good if it were adopted, so we believe that it is important to vote against this amendment proposed by the ALDE parliamentary group. ALDE votes against because it considers the proposal very restrictive regarding the import regime, while we want a restrictive import regime that protects our plants and crops.

name: Theresa GRIFFIN
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the regulation as it sets up a robust and cohesive framework drawn up with a view to preventing contamination and outbreaks of plant diseases, as well as setting out measures to deal effectively with the consequences of the spread of plant pests. In a globalised world in which climate change adds an additional layer of uncertainty, it is necessary that all countries trading on the EU single market adopt a cohesive and comprehensive legal framework to protect their own farmers, horticulturalists, foresters and other operators from the spread of non-native plant diseases.

name: Françoise GROSSETÊTE
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of a text aimed at responding to the increased risks facing the plant and variety production sector in Europe, which result from the appearance of new harmful organisms and new diseases (caused by the globalization of tradeand climate change).This regulation also provides for the modernization of phytosanitary instruments linked to trade, whether within the EU (improved traceability on the internal market) or from third countries, favoring a risk-based approach.These new measures will apply to invasive alien species, whether pests or not, on a list basis.

name: Marian HARKIN
text: in writing. ‒ I voted to approve the Council’s position at first reading of the legislation. The general objective of the proposed regulation is to deal with the increased risks facing the phytosanitary sector and resulting from the emergence of new pests and new diseases. The text also aims to modernise phytosanitary trade-related instruments, either within the EU (improved traceability in the internal market) or from third countries, favouring a risk-based approach.

name: Hans-Olaf HENKEL
text: in writing. ‒ The agreement reached in this report permits new EU rules to be used as preventive measures for imported plants and creates a mechanism for high-risk pests. Since the rapporteur ensured that there would be no unnecessary bureaucracy and that the tools available would allow for a coordinated response across the EU, I have voted in favour of this report.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: written.- I voted in favor of the draft European Parliament resolution on the Council's position at first reading with a view to the adoption of a Regulation of the Parliament and of the Council on protective measures against organisms harmful to plants and amending Regulation (EU) no.228/2013, (EU) no.652/2014 and (EU) no.1143/2014 of the Parliament and of the Council and repealing Council Directives 69/464 / EEC, 74/647 / EEC, 93/85 / EEC, 98/57 / EC, 2000/29 / EC, 2006/91 / EC and 2007 /33 / EC because plant protection is crucial to achieve the sustainability and competitiveness of the agricultural and forestry sectors.It is necessary to preserve European biodiversity and prevent the infestation of plants with pests found on imported plants.Therefore, I believe that it is necessary to strengthen preventive measures in order to avoid infections and strengthen controls in the form of successful phytosanitary safety.A rapid response system to possible infections contributes to preventing economic damage, and I therefore support this recommendation.

name: Marc JOULAUD
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of the report by my colleague Anthea McIntyre on protective measures against plant pests.These rules aim to protect European agriculture and forestry by preventing the entry of harmful organisms.For this, the text provides for the modernization and improvement of the traceability of plant protection products from third countries.In addition, it requires that import decisions be governed by the precautionary principle in order to avoid the risks of contamination or the spread of indigenous pests.I am delighted that this report was adopted by a large majority.

name: Philippe JUVIN
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of this text.It aims to take into account the increased health risks posed by the emergence of new pests and diseases resulting from globalization and climate change, as well as the risk associated with imports from third countries.

name: Barbara KAPPEL
text: written.- I would not have approved the report “Measures to protect against plant pests” because my party is in favor of changing these regulations.

name: Afzal KHAN
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the regulation as it sets up a robust and cohesive framework drawn up with a view to preventing contamination and outbreaks of plant diseases, as well as setting out measures to deal effectively with the consequences of the spread of plant pests. In a globalised world in which climate change adds an additional layer of uncertainty, it is necessary that all countries trading on the EU single market adopt a cohesive and comprehensive legal framework to protect their own farmers, horticulturalists, foresters and other operators from the spread of non-native plant diseases.

name: Andrey KOVATCHEV
text: In written form. - I supported the proposal for a regulation on plant protection measures against pests, as their health is a key factor for sustainable and competitive agriculture, horticulture and forestry. Healthy seeds and seedlings are needed to achieve fertile crops and to provide jobs, innovation in crop production and food security. The adopted legislation aims to protect European agriculture and forestry by preventing the introduction and spread of alien pests, while also taking into account invasive alien species, under the mechanism provided for in the EU Biodiversity Strategy. The Regulation also lays down the basic provisions for quarantine points where the use of such points is required by virtue of the same or a secondary act. Another novelty is the introduction of a condition that requires the export of plants, plant and other products to third countries to be carried out in a strictly defined order. The requirements for the importation of plants through travelers' luggage are also being updated, as existing gaps are becoming an increasing risk to the Union's phytosanitary status. An electronic notification and reporting system is being set up.

name: Giovanni LA VIA
text: in writing. - In recent years we have been witnessing the entry, from third countries, of pathogens of different nature that have attacked crops, plantations and ornamental plants, with a daily bulletin of ordinary devastation in terms of crop loss and economic damage. This vote represents a great achievement for Europe as the risk of invasion by pathogens from third countries continues to be high. In recent years we have witnessed the destruction of part of our production-ornamental heritage, due to not very strict controls and the failure to block imports when necessary. The time has come to change gears and I am sure that only through a more serious analysis of the EU's incoming plant material will we be able to avoid other cases of invasion. The "plant passport", an important novelty of the regulation, will guarantee, in fact, that the plant material entering the EU is free from pathogens and therefore will significantly reduce the risk of importing harmful organisms from third countries. Organisms which, it is worth remembering, represent a real threat to European production, damage to consumers and a cost that can reach billions of euros. Today's vote represents a victory for our agriculture.

name: Gilles LEBRETON
text: in writing.- I abstained.Admittedly, this is a text which increases controls on products potentially carrying organisms harmful to plants, imported from third countries.Nevertheless, it leaves the Commission the sole analyst and decision-maker as to the list of these organisms and the possibilities of quarantine.

name: Marine LE PEN
text: in writing. - I abstained on the report on protective measures against plant pests. The objective of this text is to respond to the risks to plant health caused by harmful organisms from third countries. On the positive side, it should be emphasized that this text calls into question, in the background, globalization and its excesses. In addition, it calls for more controls, both within the internal market (in particular on traceability requirements) and within the framework of trade with third countries. All while reinforcing a risk-based approach. On the other hand, the main problem of this text is of size: it leaves the Commission analyst and decision-maker. Clearly, it will be responsible for drawing up - alone - the list of organisms harmful to plants, establishing the various related quarantine possibilities and arbitrarily deciding on the measures to be taken. As a recent example, the decision - radical and unilateral - it has taken on the problem of the bacterium Xylella fastidiosa, in Puglia, is based on total interference, coupled with a precautionary principle penalizing for the Italy and beneficial for a third country (Tunisia).

name: Philippe LOISEAU
text: in writing. - The general objective of this text is to respond to the risks to which plants are exposed concerning their health. This is in fact threatened by new harmful organisms and by diseases from third countries. A critique of globalization and its effects on trade as well as on the issue of climate change remains in the background. The text aims to modernize control instruments, both within the internal market (improvement of traceability) and within the framework of trade with third countries. To this end, this draft resolution lays down the rules for determining the phytosanitary risk presented by any species, strain or biotype of pathogenic agent, animal or parasitic plant harmful to plants, as well as the measures aimed at reducing this risk to an acceptable level. However, this project also increases the power of the Commission. It will thus be responsible for drawing up the list of harmful organisms and may even decide on the eradication of affected plants. There is no final vote at second reading, but I abstained on the rejecting amendment tabled by the ALDE Group.

name: Sander LOONES
text: written.- The European Parliament has given the go-ahead for new measures to better protect plants against disease.An agreement on this has already been reached with the Council.The N-VA delegation supports this agreement.The regulation is part of a package of measures designed to strengthen health and safety standards throughout the agricultural food chain.A European approach is necessary here: pests and diseases do not stop at the border.A well-known example is Xylella fastidiosa, a wood-eating bacteria that affects olive trees.The new rules should enable Member States to take faster decisions, react more quickly and cooperate better.Moreover, this is a balanced and proportional agreement that avoids unnecessary administrative burdens and does not unnecessarily hinder free trade.

name: Javi LÓPEZ
text: written.- I voted in favor of the new basic European regulation for plant health because the Union's plant protection regime is crucial for the development and competitiveness of European agriculture.The report includes strengthening the border control system and the phytosanitary requirements for imports, which we Socialists defended.The report also includes that plant pests classified "as low risk" will continue under the current import control system but with the addition of the phytosanitary passport, now implemented at European level.

name: Paloma LÓPEZ BERMEJO
text: written.- Although there are aspects in this report that can be improved, such as the implementation of preventive measures and measures to combat and adapt to climate change, I have voted against the amendment proposed by ALDE that requests the rejection of the legislative proposal.I consider it important that this report be adopted and I find the progress made throughout the negotiations to be very positive, through which the regulation imposed strict controls on the importation of plant material into the Union.Something essential to avoid future outbreaks of pests and plant diseases (such as the Xylella fastidiosa problem in olive trees).

name: Antonio LÓPEZ-ISTÚRIZ WHITE
text: written.- With a view to protecting European agriculture by preventing the entry and spread of pests on European territory, as these entail serious economic problems, this draft legislative resolution of the European Parliament adopts the position of the Council at first reading as regardsIt refers to the adoption of the Regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on protection measures against plant pests, which modifies part of the existing regulation.I am voting in favor because Parliament's position has been respected.With this regulation, we will protect the health, the economy and the competitiveness of the Union's plant production sector, maintaining our policy of open trade.

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in support of legislation to address increased risks in the plant health sector from new pests and diseases arising from intra EU trade and plants imported from third countries.

name: Ivana MALETIĆ
text: written.- The current Union regulatory framework for plant health (Directive 2000/29 / EC) aims to protect European agriculture and forestry and prevent the entry and spread of foreign pests.This system is necessary to protect the health, economy and competitiveness of the EU plant production sector, as well as to maintain the Union's open trade policy.However, this framework has been criticized for its inability to stop the influx of new dangerous organisms harmful to plants.The proposed amendment to the regulations replaces and repeals Directive 2000/29 / EC, which seeks to establish a transparent and sustainable regulatory framework for plant health, so I voted against the proposal to reject the Council's position.

name: Andrejs MAMIKINS
text: in writing. ‒ I share the general objective of the proposed regulation to deal with the increased risks facing the phytosanitary sector and resulting from the emergence of new pests and new diseases. The important aims are to modernise phytosanitary trade-related instruments, either within or from third countries, favouring a risk-based approach.

name: Vladimír MAŇKA
text: in writing.- I support the adoption of a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on plant protection measures, which amends existing rules in this area.Due to climate change and the globalization of trade, there is an increasing infiltration of foreign plant pests into the countries of the Union.These pose a potential risk to human and animal life and health and to the environment.The regulation therefore focuses on tackling plant pests from outside the EU.The aim is to eliminate risks and to establish procedures and measures for the protection of plant health with an emphasis on plant production, forests, native and artificially planted areas, natural ecosystems and biodiversity in the Union.

name: Louis-Joseph MANSCOUR
text: in writing.- The recent epidemics of Xyllela fastidiosa and the olive fly have demonstrated that there are serious failings in the health controls currently in force and that European agriculture is not sufficiently protected against the entry of newharmful organisms from third countries.It therefore became urgent and imperative for the Union to adopt ambitious measures to protect against organisms harmful to plants.This European regulation represents real progress for the protection of the territory of the European Union, in particular in the fight against the appearance of new organisms.I welcome this all the more since it will also provide a complete system for a preventive, graduated and risk-based approach.I support this text because it will allow European farmers to no longer be victims of insufficient protection at our borders

name: Notis MARIAS
text: in writing. - I support the recommendation for second reading on the position of the Council at first reading with a view to the adoption of a Regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on protection measures against plant pests, amending Regulations (EU) No 1095/2010. 228/2013, (EU) no. 652/2014 and (EU) no. Regulation (EC) No 1143/2014 of the European Parliament and of the Council and repealing Directives 69/464 / EEC, 74/647 / EEC, 93/85 / EEC, 98/57 / EC, 2000/29 / EC, 2006/91 / EC and 2007/33 / EC, for the reasons I have set out in detail in my speech to the European Parliament in Strasbourg on 25 October 2016, and because this report is sufficiently substantiated.

name: Dominique MARTIN
text: in writing.- I abstained on this text.The at first glance interesting idea of limiting the phytosanitary risks linked to the globalization of agricultural trade does not conceal the Commission's intention to assume additional powers.It could impose radical standards and measures on all Member States, which we are opposed to.

name: Georg MAYER
text: written.- The general aim of the regulation is to reduce the risk of new pests and diseases.The text also aims to modernize phytosanitary trade-related instruments.Better traceability in the internal market or from third countries should also be guaranteed.I have approved this regulation.

name: Valentinas MAZURONIS
text: in writing.- I supported the EP recommendation on changes to plant health regulations.The current EU plant health regulatory framework aims to protect the European agricultural and forestry sectors from harmful organisms by preventing them from entering and spreading in the EU.Increased imports in recent years have led to major outbreaks of dangerous pests, which have caused very serious damage to forestry.2010The evaluation of the system put in place in 2006 showed that the basic legislation needs to be amended to cover all aspects of this growing risk.The amendments adopted focus more on prevention, prioritize pests at EU level and in all 28 Member States, introduce more effective measures to control the emergence and spread of pests, and improve measures to regulate intra-EU movements.

name: Jean-Luc MÉLENCHON
text: in writing. - The globalization of trade and climate change favor the introduction and spread within the EU of new, particularly dangerous plant pests. The report aims to take measures to promote plant protection in this context. In terms of control, the report remains with “reasoned control” solutions (prevention, crop rotation, no automatic pesticides) which date back 30 years. But it strengthens controls on imports of plants or plant products from third countries, via phytosanitary certificates. Specific provisions have also been added concerning the introduction of wood packaging materials into the Union, as well as their circulation in and out of the Union. Finally, I regret that GMOs are not part of the list of harmful organisms, given that they have the main characteristics: organisms not present on European territory (GMOs are not naturally present) and which can present risks. for plants (contamination of other plants by GMO plants). Nevertheless, I vote in favor.

name: Joëlle MÉLIN
text: in writing. - The general objective of this text is to respond to the risks to which plants are exposed concerning their health. This is in fact threatened by new harmful organisms and by diseases from third countries. A critique of globalization and its effects on trade as well as on the issue of climate change remains in the background. The text aims to modernize control instruments, both within the internal market (improvement of traceability) and within the framework of trade with third countries. To this end, this draft resolution lays down the rules for determining the phytosanitary risk presented by any species, strain or biotype of pathogenic agent, animal or parasitic plant harmful to plants, as well as the measures aimed at reducing this risk to an acceptable level. However, this project also increases the power of the Commission. It will thus be responsible for drawing up the list of harmful organisms and may even decide on the eradication of affected plants. There is no final vote at second reading but I abstained on the ALDE Group's rejection amendment.

name: Nuno MELO
text: in writing.- Plant health represents an essential factor for sustainable and competitive agriculture, horticulture and forestry.It is necessary to have healthy seeds and propagating material in order to obtain profitable crops and to guarantee jobs, plant innovation and security of food supply.In the case of trees and shrubs, the protection of plant health is essential for the preservation of forests, landscapes and public and private green areas across the Union. Plant health is also important for the protection of biodiversity and ecosystem services.The proposal is part of a package of reviews related to plant health, the quality of plant reproductive material, animal health, official controls on plants, animals and food for human and animal consumption and Union expenditure on these policies.Hence my vote in favor.

name: Roberta METSOLA
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against the motion to reject the Council position as new rules are needed to curb the number of plant pests that infect the Union’s ecosystem. I welcome the new measures that will allow for a rapid response to suspect plant imports and the new contingency plans across the Union in case of an outbreak.

name: Miroslav MIKOLÁŠIK
text: in writing. - Plant health is threatened by species that are harmful to plants and plant products. Due to the globalization of trade and climate change, the risk of the introduction of various pests into the Union is increasing. The proposal aims to modernize the instruments for trade in herbal medicines and products in order to reduce the risk of pests to an acceptable level. This needs to be done within the EU (to improve traceability in the internal market), but it also applies to goods that travel from third countries to the Union (by applying a potential plant risk approach). Prevention, protection measures and early detection of pests are important for the timely and effective eradication of pests. Member States should further establish multi-annual survey programs to detect the presence of Union quarantine pests in areas where those pests were not known. The so-called plant passport should be extended to any movement of plants intended for cultivation within the EU, including those ordered at a distance. Only products supplied to end-users such as gardeners will be exempt. In the event of the suspicion or detection of Union quarantine pests, the Commission shall be empowered to adopt measures, in consultation with the Member States. I support the proposal with my voice.

name: Marlene MIZZI
text: in writing. ‒ I believe that the new legislation will assure a high degree of security for the European Union with regards to imports of plants and plant products. With the new system, the introduction of pests such as Xyllela fastidiosa in southern Italy or Asian long-horned beetle in the UK would be much more difficult. Also the new measures for quarantine will be tailor-made for each case and farmers would be supported in the eradication procedures also receiving compensation for their loses. The introduction of a plant passport is also an innovation brought in by this regulation which would ensure a high degree of traceability. Therefore I have voted in favour of the report.

name: Csaba MOLNÁR
text: in writing.- The Commission has proposed to the European Parliament and the Council measures for the control of plant pests, amending Regulations (EU) No 228/2013, (EU) No 652/2014 and (EU) No 1143/2014, and amending Directives 69/464 / EEC, 74/ 647 / EEC, 93/85 / EEC, 98/57 / EC, 2000/29 / EC, 2006/91 / EC and 2007/33 / EC.Parliament adopted its position at first reading on 15 April 2014.The Austrian Federal Council issued a reasoned opinion stating that the draft legislative act was incompatible with the principle of subsidiarity.Following subsequent consultations, the Council also adopted its position at first reading, and the Committee on Agriculture and Rural Development recommends in its report that Parliament agree at second reading.I voted accordingly.

name: Cláudia MONTEIRO DE AGUIAR
text: in writing. - The current EU plant health regulatory framework aims to protect European agriculture and forestry by preventing the entry and spread of alien pests. In recent times, this situation has come under criticism for being unable to stop the increase in new dangerous pests entering the EU due to the increase in international trade. This legal framework needs to be changed in order to fully address the growing risks and to modernize. The main problems identified relate to an insufficient concern with the prevention of high-risk goods, the need to set priorities among pests at the EU level and in the 28 Member States, the need to have better instruments to control the presence and spread of pests and the need to improve instruments for movement within the EU. I endorse the rapporteur's position that professional operators must be covered by the system of protection measures against plant pests, as well as fighting pests in public or private green areas. However, it is essential that this process is as transparent and predictable as possible.

name: Sophie MONTEL
text: in writing.- I am abstaining on this rejection amendment concerning an interesting text, which nevertheless gives too much importance to the European Commission.

name: Claude MORAES
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report, the new Plant Health regulation sets up a robust and cohesive framework drawn up with a view on preventing contamination and outbreaks of plant diseases as well as sets out measures to deal effectively with the consequences of the spread of plant pests. In a globalised world in which climate change adds up an additional layer of uncertainty, it is necessary that all countries trading on the EU single market adopt a cohesive and comprehensive legal framework to protect their own farmers, horticulturalists, foresters and other operators from the spread of non-native plant diseases. This has direct importance to the UK and European food security, biosafety and economic viability of farming, horticulture and forestry.

name: Nadine MORANO
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of this report, the aim of which is to tackle the dangerous consequences of the emergence of new pests and diseases for the plant sector.This text provides in particular for the establishment of a phytosanitary certificate for operators who import plant products into European territory.This text also provides for the possibility of suspending imports of a species if it does not comply with the requirements and criteria defined.

name: József NAGY
text: in writing.- I support the idea that we need to develop appropriate measures against plant pests.We need to protect the natural flora of the European Union, but at the same time we need to find a solution that will not complicate our daily lives with long lines of bureaucratic procedures.

name: Victor NEGRESCU
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted for this recommendation regarding the adoption of protective measures against pests of plants.

name: Franz OBERMAYR
text: written.- I spoke out against this report because the report contains some points that I believe are flawed and that urgently need to be revised.

name: Urmas PAET
text: in writing.- I supported.The aim is to find ways to deal with new diseases and pathogens in the phytosanitary field.Trade measures in this area will also be updated.

name: Aldo PATRICIELLO
text: in writing.- While taking into consideration the aspects presented in the document relating to protective measures against harmful organisms for plants and, admitting that I will follow the development of this argument with interest, I do not believe that the present objection corresponds to my thinking and therefore I am voting against.

name: Marijana PETIR
text: written. - We are witnessing difficult moments that recently hit Italian olive growers due to the destruction of their centuries-old olive groves attacked by the bacterium Xylella fastidiosa (Wells et al.) Which spread from South America by importing infected plants into the European Union via a European port. The agricultural sector is extremely important for Europe, and an important part of it is the care of phytosanitary protection. Dangerous parasites pose a great danger to European agricultural production and can also cause great economic damage. The general objective of the proposed regulation responds to the increased risks we face in the phytosanitary sector, which result in the emergence of new pests and new diseases. The proposal seeks to modernize trade-related phytosanitary instruments, either within the EU (improved traceability in the internal market) or from third countries, and gives priority to precaution. In order for this fight to be successful, it is necessary to ensure, among other things, the possibility of suspending the import of risky plants until a full risk assessment is carried out, to establish control mechanisms against importers and users of risky plants, to develop a special research program to ensure timely detection of dangerous pests. All that needs to be done is contained in the draft act. I support the recommendation and hope that this proposal will eventually be adopted.

name: Florian PHILIPPOT
text: in writing. - The objective of this text is to respond to the risks to plant health caused by new harmful organisms and diseases from third countries. He therefore criticizes globalization and its effects on trade. The text aims to modernize control instruments, both within the internal market (improvement of traceability) and within the framework of trade with third countries. All while reinforcing a risk-based approach. To this end, this draft legislative resolution lays down the rules for determining the pest risk presented by any species, strain or biotype of pathogenic agent, animal or parasitic plant harmful to plants (or plant products), as well as measures to reduce this risk to an acceptable level. The major flaw in this text is that it increases the power of the Commission. It alone will thus be responsible for drawing up the list of harmful organisms. It will also be able to decide on the eradication of affected plants, as it did this year with the olive trees affected by Xylella fastidiosa in Puglia. This is why I prefer to abstain.

name: Tonino PICULA
text: written.- I support better control and earlier prevention of the spread of new harmful organisms.Plant health is key to promoting sustainable and competitive agriculture, horticulture and the forestry sector.The EU phytosanitary regime is the cornerstone of health protection and economic sustainability of the plant production sector.That is why it is important to stop the entry and spread of foreign harmful species that are able to spread rapidly if there is no genetic resistance within the EU.I welcome the temporary ban on products that pose a potential risk, as well as the introduction of a 'plant passport' in order to better monitor their origin and distribution throughout the Union.I am convinced that the new regulation will ensure a high level of security for the EU when it comes to imports of plants and plant products.

name: João PIMENTA LOPES
text: in writing. - The dominant agricultural models, based on intensive monocultures, of an export nature, reduce the resilience of agricultural systems to pests and potentiate their devastating effects, which is why it is necessary, above all, to question and abandon these models, alongside the rejection of any form of privatization of genetic resources, namely through seed patenting. Pretending, under the pretext of combating pests, to impose registration and certification measures that, in practice, make the activity of small farmers unfeasible, traditional agriculture and traditional forms of plant propagation is not acceptable. On the contrary, it would mean committing to a sustainable response to the pest problem in the long term. As regards the import of plant material from third countries, strict phytosanitary control is fully justified, which eliminates risks of future outbreaks of plant diseases, with potentially devastating agronomic and ecological consequences.

name: Franck PROUST
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of this report on protective measures against plant pests.The main objective of this regulation is to deal with the growing risks visible in plant production in the European Union, due in particular to the increase in diseases from foreign countries or to climate change.To remedy this, this will include modernizing trade-related phytosanitary instruments in order to improve the traceability of organisms and products on the internal market.

name: Frédérique RIES
text: in writing. - This afternoon, Parliament validated a common position found with the European Council to better prevent the entry into Europe of organisms harmful to plants and improve the control of possible epidemics. Insects, fungi, bacteria and other viruses can cause serious damage to plants and crops, a trade worth 201 billion euros in Europe (7.4 billion in Belgium). We remember Xylella fastidiosa, which devastated nearly 30,000 hectares of olive trees in the Italian region of Puglia in 2014. The new rules will strengthen the European phytosanitary regime around three axes. Particular attention will be paid to prevention, to assess plants at risk from third countries more quickly and upstream. Better control instruments will be put in place against the spread of parasites that have managed to reach European territory, in particular through compulsory national emergency plans. The practice of plant passports will finally be extended to all plants intended for sale in Europe in order to strengthen the traceability of movements within the internal market, and the safety of consumers and producers alike.

name: Liliana RODRIGUES
text: in writing.- The new legislation must guarantee a high degree of security for the European Union with regard to the import of plants and plant products.With the new system, the introduction of pests such as Xyllela fastidiosa in southern Italy or the Asian long-horned beetle in the United Kingdom will be much more difficult.Also, the new quarantine measures provided for will take into account the specificity of each case and farmers will be supported in the eradication procedures and will receive compensation for losses.The introduction of the phytosanitary passport is also an innovation brought about by this regulation, with the aim of ensuring a high degree of traceability.

name: Inma RODRÍGUEZ-PIÑERO
text: written.- I voted in favor of the definitive approval of the agreements reached with the Commission and the Council on the new basic European regulations for plant health.The Union's plant protection regime is crucial for the development and competitiveness of European agriculture.The final agreement does not include the positive list system in force for animal health, which we would have liked also to apply to plant health, but it does substantially improve the Commission's initial proposal through a closed system for plants and vegetables from"high risk".Those classified "as low risk" will continue under the current import control system but with the addition of the phytosanitary passport, now implemented at European level.

name: Claude ROLIN
text: in writing.- I voted against the ALDE Group amendment to the legislative resolution, which sought to reject the Council's position at first reading with a view to adopting the regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on protective measures against organismsharmful to plants, amending Regulations (EU) No 228/2013, (EU) No 652/2014 and (EU) No 1143/2014 of the European Parliament and of the Council and repealing Directives 69/464 / EEC, 74/ 647 / EEC, 93/85 / EEC, 98/57 / EC, 2000/29 / EC, 2006/91 / EC and 2007/33 / EC of the Council.Given the scale that such phenomena can take, it was relevant to confirm the agreement that the European Parliament had reached with the Council.These new measures are essential as they will harmonize the existing plant passport regime and more effectively eradicate early outbreaks of pests.

name: Fernando RUAS
text: in writing. - Plant health represents an essential factor for sustainable and competitive agriculture, horticulture and forestry, allowing profitable crops and functioning as a guarantee of job preservation, innovation, security of food supply and protection of biodiversity. Pests from other continents are particularly dangerous, given that European agriculture does not have genetic resistance against alien pests that are already causing serious economic damage, compromising the profitability and competitiveness of European agriculture and forestry. The current EU regulatory framework for plant health has been the target of several criticisms. Among the shortcomings identified, there are insufficient preventive measures with regard to increased imports of high-risk goods, the need to set priorities among EU pests for Member States, the lack of control tools the presence and natural spread of pests in case they reach the territory of the Union, the lack of modernization and updating of instruments related to intra-EU circulation, and the need to provide for additional resources. The purpose of this review is to remedy the identified gaps and establish a robust, transparent and sustainable regulatory framework, adapted to its objectives, which is why I voted in favor of this resolution.

name: Lola SÁNCHEZ CALDENTEY
text: written. - I am voting against this amendment. I agree with this regulation as its objective is to prevent the entry and spread of pests in plants of two types: quarantine pests and regulated non-quarantine pests. At the last AGRI committee on 13 October, this report was approved with 28 votes in favor. Thanks to the modifications made by the shadow of the report, this document on plant pests calls for the implementation of strict controls on imports of plant material into the European Union with the intention of avoiding future pests and plant diseases (such as Xylella Fastidiosa that attacks olive trees and caused a 20% rise in the price of oil in 2015). After this second reading, we believe that it would be good if it were adopted, so we believe that it is important to vote against this amendment proposed by the ALDE parliamentary group. ALDE votes against because it considers the proposal very restrictive regarding the import regime, while we want a restrictive import regime that protects our plants and crops.

name: Sven SCHULZE
text: written.- I voted in favor of the report on measures to protect against plant pests.The report mentions the growing risks in the crop sector from diseases and pesticides.The corresponding directive is due to come into force in 2017.

name: Maria Lidia SENRA RODRÍGUEZ
text: written.- Although there are aspects in this report that can be improved, such as the implementation of preventive measures and measures to combat and adapt to climate change, I have voted against the amendment proposed by ALDE that requests the rejection of the legislative proposal.I consider it important that this report be adopted and I find the progress made throughout the negotiations to be very positive, through which the regulation imposed strict controls on the importation of plant material into the Union.Something essential to avoid future outbreaks of pests and plant diseases (such as the Xylella fastidiosa problem in olive trees).

name: Remo SERNAGIOTTO
text: in writing.- The shortcomings of the EU phytosanitary regime currently in force make a reform of these rules necessary.The emphasis should be on prevention, introducing new mechanisms to prevent entry into the EU of "high risk" parasites, as well as intensifying parasite surveillance tools in the EU.It is important that Member States develop emergency measures for outbreaks, such as Xylella fastidiosa in olive groves, in order to respond to these threats in a coordinated way across the Union.I decided to express myself in favor as I believe it is of fundamental importance to strengthen the application of health and safety standards for the entire agri-food chain.

name: Siôn SIMON
text: in writing. ‒ Today I voted in support of the proposed regulation on Protective measures against plant pests. The new Plant Health regulation sets up a robust and cohesive framework drawn up with a view on preventing contamination and outbreaks of plant diseases as well as sets out measures to deal effectively with the consequences of the spread of plant pests.

name: Branislav ŠKRIPEK
text: in writing.- I support protection measures aimed at protecting EU agricultural areas against plant pests.The present Regulation should improve the rules for determining the phytosanitary risks associated with any type of harmful organisms destroying plants or plant products.These measures also aim to improve the prevention of pests entering EU territory from third countries.For this reason, I voted against the amendment, which sought to reject the entire proposal for a regulation.

name: Monika SMOLKOVÁ
text: in writing. - Plant protection has always been a key factor for sustainable and competitive agriculture, horticulture and forestry. Unfortunately, in recent decades, in connection with the globalization of trade, significant intrusions of foreign pests into Europe have emerged, causing serious economic damage to plants. As plants and trees in Europe are usually not genetically resistant to pests from other continents and are highly likely to penetrate Europe in the future, it is essential that we examine and overcome these shortcomings and put in place a reliable, transparent and sustainable regulatory framework that accurately correspond to the purpose. I supported the resolution because I think that, in order to protect plant health and reduce the phytosanitary risks that plant pests pose, we will take measures that reduce these risks to an acceptable level and prevent major crop failures. I am aware that plant protection methods have undergone many changes over time; therefore, I expect the EU and its Member States to amend the legislation so that the increased risks can be fully addressed.

name: Igor ŠOLTES
text: in writing. - The Recommendation contains a proposal for strict rules on protection against the spread of pests. The problem with such rules, of course, is the link between pests and seeds, as the spread of pests can also limit seed storage and exchange. The outbreak of diseases and pests affecting individual plant species and crops is likely to be curbed by new rules that are currently being negotiated and will regulate strict controls. At the same time, there are fears that there will be undesirable consequences in the field of seed storage and conservation of certain plant species, based on the diversity of domestic seeds and the exchange of seeds between farmers. Although certain exceptions are expected to be recorded in the implementation of the new rules, discussions with the Directorate-General for Health and Food Safety (DG Sante) have shown that these exceptions will not be determined until 2020 to 2025. Main concerns related to the proposed regulation include, in particular, the registration of seed producers, which could endanger smaller producers, the registration of plant species and the passports for plants and seeds. At the same time, the Commission has hardly consulted with NGOs working in this field on the challenges. For all the above reasons and the many difficulties associated with the proposal, despite the good intentions following the regulation of this area, I abstained.

name: Ivan ŠTEFANEC
text: in writing.- Climate change and the increased movement of goods are also bringing with them the entry of invasive and non-native plant and animal species into the European Union.These are often spreading aggressively and can have a devastating effect on native European species and even threaten our agro-sector.We must therefore take adequate measures against them, but at the same time take care to preserve species diversity and protect nature as a whole, which is not defined by political boundaries.

name: Patricija ŠULIN
text: in writing.- I voted against the ALDE proposal to reject the recommendation for second reading on the Council's position at first reading with a view to adopting a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on plant protection measures, amending European Parliament and Council regulations and repealing Council directives.The regulation has a very clear goal of protecting European production from harmful organisms that we have imported from other countries.We should pay attention to what one country imports, because importing plants into one country could cause problems in other countries as well.We need to combat the risk posed by unknown plants, especially in terms of their potential harmfulness.

name: Neoklis SYLIKIOTIS
text: in writing. Plant health is a very important issue throughout Europe and the agreement reached between the European Parliament and the Council on plant pest protection measures is a really important achievement. This regulation, despite its individual imperfections, will enhance plant and biodiversity security through a proportionate risk approach, enabling faster decision-making, faster action and better cooperation between Member States. That is why we supported the proposal.

name: Eleftherios SYNADINOS
text: in writing. - Recent experience with Xylella fastidiosa demonstrates gaps in regulations on plant pests. Globalization, e-commerce and new conditions must be taken into account in order to protect Europe's flora. The Union must, of course, realize that there are other ways to deal with diseases other than eradication and must develop a phytosanitary management strategy to reduce treatment time. We note that eradication carries other risks and that national and regional authorities must be given the option of restraint.

name: Tibor SZANYI
text: in writing. - In May 2013, the European Commission proposed new legislation on plant pest control measures. The regulation includes new tools, such as a system of risk analysis criteria, which groups these pests according to their most serious consequences. It also places greater emphasis on high-risk commercial products from third countries and allows for better monitoring and early eradication of new pests. There is also a need for closer joint European action in the field of plant health, which is why I did not vote in favor of the liberal recommendation rejecting the agreement. Plant health is a key factor in sustainable and competitive agriculture, horticulture and forestry, and through them has a significant public health impact.
