The Socialist and Democratic Group is committed to guaranteeing the highest level of security and is a major supporter of the precautionary import system. The new rules allow for temporary bans on products that pose a risk of new pests or that pose a suspected health risk. It also stipulates that organizations importing plants or plant products, even in the case of internet trade, must have a phytosanitary certificate and that a plant passport system will be introduced for plants purchased for planting.

name: Claudiu Ciprian TĂNĂSESCU
text: signed up.- Plant health is very important for plant production, public and private green spaces, natural ecosystems, ecosystem services and biodiversity in the EU.Therefore, strengthening measures to prevent, monitor and take rapid action in the event of outbreaks of plant pests in the EU is obviously of major importance, starting from the detection of the presence of quarantine pests for the EU in areas where the presence of these organisms was notknown to date, surveillance, early eradication of outbreaks of new pests, informing the public about the economic, social and environmental impact of plant pests, coupled with financial support for companies and phytosanitary authorities in the Member States.

name: Claudia ȚAPARDEL
text: signed up. - Plant health is a matter of the greatest interest to the European Union and the Common Agricultural Policy (CAP), which supports the sustainable development of the agriculture, horticulture and forestry sectors. The main threat in these sectors is from harmful organisms, which are insects, fungi, bacteria or viruses that can cause significant damage to crops, especially when they come from other continents. To this end, the European institutions may regulate the treatments required to increase the resistance of native plants or may provide for more rigorous controls on plants coming from other geographical areas. The latter category of measures can provide very effective protection against the spread of harmful organisms and plant diseases. The Commission has therefore proposed a higher level of security for plant imports, depending on the risks involved in each case. In the case of lower risk plant imports, it has also been proposed to introduce plant passports in order to avoid any possibility of the spread of pests. In extreme cases, temporary bans, mandatory phytosanitary certificates and the creation of contingency plans for emergencies are provided for. I support the adoption of this necessary report.

name: Marc TARABELLA
text: in writing.- I was of course in favor of the text proposed by my colleague McIntyre on the Council's position at first reading with a view to adopting a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on protective measures against plant pests,amending Regulations (EU) No 228/2013, (EU) No 652/2014 and (EU) No 1143/2014 of the European Parliament and of the Council and repealing Directives 69/464 / EEC, 74/647 / EEC, 93/85 / EEC, 98/57 / EC, 2000/29 / EC, 2006/91 / EC and 2007/33 / EC of the Council.

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: in writing. ‒ The new rules outlined in the protective measures against pests and plants seeks to introduce new preventive and rapid response mechanisms for plant imports into the EU and increase pest surveillance efforts in the EU in the aim of protecting European farmers. However, the measures will make it more difficult and more expensive for traders to import plants and plant products into the EU since almost every plant that is grown outdoors will be faced with the possibility of being banned by the EU Commission from entering the EU. For this reason, I voted against the proposal because I believe that the action is disproportionate to the risk.

name: Isabelle THOMAS
text: in writing. - Anthea McIntyre's report comes in a context where health accidents follow one another, highlighting the urgency of strengthening protection against organisms harmful to plants. This question had already been the subject of a report during the previous legislature, but this text, however central, of the health package had remained blocked in the Council. Indeed, the organization of health controls is plagued by serious failures and does not sufficiently protect the territory of the EU against the entry of new harmful organisms from third countries. During the previous legislature, we had already deplored that the Commission's legislative proposal did not envisage any modification of the existing system. The Socialists' amendments in favor of a new control strategy, of a preventive type, based on a risk management approach, were not accepted, however, as the right wing did not support them. The Commission and the Council seem to have realized the serious shortcomings of the current legislation. We are happy that things are progressing. Farmers can no longer be the victims of insufficient border protection.

name: Patrizia TOIA
text: in writing.- Plant health is a key factor in promoting the agricultural and forestry sectors.The EU phytosanitary regime is essential to protect the health, economy and competitiveness of EU plant production, also in consideration of the latest real epidemics in Europe, such as the Xylella case that risks destroying part of the olive heritageof southern Italy.These problems are due to the uncontrolled importation of infected plants and organisms from third countries, which have found fertile ground in our territory.A common and effective response is needed, for nature and for workers.

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: written.- The European Union should protect European agriculture and forestry from the entry and spread of organisms harmful to plants from other continents.Namely, these organisms are especially dangerous because they endanger biodiversity and the ecosystem.Therefore, first of all, it is necessary to improve the mechanisms that prevent their entry into the territory of the Member States.Colleague McIntyre of the Group of European Conservatives and Reformists recognized this problem and proposed in the report a solution to be achieved through a transparent and sustainable legislative framework that strengthens coordination between plant health authorities and Member States' plant reproductive material.In addition, the proposed solutions have avoided an unnecessary increase in bureaucracy, which I particularly support.These are the reasons why I voted in favor of this report.

name: Romana TOMC
text: in writing. - I supported the draft legislative resolution on the Council's position at first reading with a view to the adoption of a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on plant protection measures. Plant health is a key factor in ensuring sustainable and competitive agriculture, horticulture and forestry. Healthy seeds and propagating material are needed to ensure the profitability of agricultural plants, jobs, plant innovation and food security. A unique feature of the EU's phytosanitary regime (plant health regime) is its openness: movements of plants and plant products into and after the Union are allowed provided that specific restrictions and requirements are respected. However, due to the large volume of imports from other continents, there is a high probability that outbreaks of non-native pests will occur in the future. The assessment of the regime (2010) showed that changes in fundamental legislation will be needed to fully address such increased risks. This Regulation forms part of a package of audits relating to plant health, the quality of plant propagating material, animal health, official controls on plants, animals, food and feed, and Union expenditure relating to those policies.

name: Estefanía TORRES MARTÍNEZ
text: written. - I am voting against this amendment. I agree with this regulation as its objective is to prevent the entry and spread of pests in plants of two types: quarantine pests and regulated non-quarantine pests. In the last AGRI committee on October 13, this report was approved with 28 votes in favor. Thanks to the modifications made by the shadow of the report, this document on plant pests calls for the implementation of strict controls on imports of plant material into the European Union with the intention of avoiding future pests and plant diseases (such as Xylella Fastidiosa that attacks olive trees and caused a 20% rise in the price of oil in 2015). After this second reading, we believe that it would be good if it were adopted, so we believe that it is important to vote against this amendment proposed by the ALDE parliamentary group. ALDE votes against because it considers the proposal very restrictive regarding the import regime, while we want a restrictive import regime that protects our plants and crops.

name: Mylène TROSZCZYNSKI
text: in writing.- The general objective of this text is to respond to the risks to plant health caused by new pests and diseases from third countries.A critique of globalization and its effects on trade as well as on the issue of climate change remains in the background.The text aims to modernize the control instruments, both within the internal market (improvement of traceability), and within the framework of trade with third countries.All while reinforcing a risk-based approach.The legislative procedure for the adoption of the text is completed.Today's vote is on a rejection amendment on which I abstained.

name: Kazimierz Michał UJAZDOWSKI
text: in writing.- The report is technical and industry-specific, but its political sense is positive.It is to result in more effective enforcement of standards that translate into the health and safety of plants, animals and humans.The envisaged trade restrictions do not go beyond what is necessary to achieve the objective.The new law should not lead to excessive bureaucracy.Therefore, I voted in favor of the resolution.

name: Miguel URBÁN CRESPO
text: written. - I am voting against this amendment. I agree with this regulation as its objective is to prevent the entry and spread of pests in plants of two types: quarantine pests and regulated non-quarantine pests. At the last AGRI committee on October 13, this report was approved with 28 votes in favor. Thanks to the modifications made by the shadow of the report, this document on plant pests calls for the implementation of strict controls on imports of plant material into the European Union with the intention of avoiding future pests and plant diseases (such as Xylella Fastidiosa that attacks olive trees and caused a 20% rise in the price of oil in 2015). After this second reading, we believe that it would be good if it were adopted, so we believe that it is important to vote against this amendment proposed by the ALDE parliamentary group. ALDE votes against because it considers the proposal very restrictive regarding the import regime, while we want a restrictive import regime that protects our plants and crops.

name: Ernest URTASUN
text: in writing. ‒ Although the Pests of Plants regulation as negotiated will impose strict controls on importing plant material into the EU, so hopefully avoiding future outbreaks of plant diseases (like the recent Xylella fastidiosa attacking olive trees), there will be increased costs and unintended consequences for seed-saving operations by plant conservation charities under the restrictions on internet sales and distribution, and also on farmer-saved seed, whereby farmers breed their own seed varieties using seed exchanges. This is why I abstained in the final vote.

name: Ivo VAJGL
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the recommendation for second reading on the Council position at first reading with a view to the adoption of a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on protective measures against pests of plants, amending Regulations (EU) No 228/2013, (EU) No 652/2014 and (EU) No 1143/2014 of the European Parliament and of the Council and repealing Council Directives 69/464/EEC, 74/647/EEC, 93/85/EEC, 98/57/EC, 2000/29/EC, 2006/91/EC and 2007/33/EC. The aim of the Regulation is to curb the growing influx into the EU of plant pests, such as olive grove killer Xylella fastidiosa, and better equip Member States to tackle their spread. The new regulation introduces preventive and rapid response mechanisms for suspect plant imports, steps up pest surveillance efforts in the EU and requires all Member States to draw up outbreak contingency plans. I voted in favour because I strongly believe that all Member States must establish multi-annual survey programmes to ensure timely detection of dangerous pests and contingency plans for each pest capable of entering their territory.

name: Ángela VALLINA
text: written.- Although there are aspects in this report that can be improved, such as the implementation of preventive measures and measures to combat and adapt to climate change, I have voted against the amendment proposed by ALDE that requests the rejection of the legislative proposal.I consider it important that this report be adopted and I find the progress made throughout the negotiations to be very positive, through which the regulation imposed strict controls on the importation of plant material into the Union.Something essential to avoid future outbreaks of pests and plant diseases (such as the Xylella fastidiosa problem in olive trees).

name: Hilde VAUTMANS
text: written.- I did not agree with this position of the Council because a total import ban is disproportionate to the risk.I believe that a system is being created whereby it becomes too easy for Member States to impose an import ban on almost all plants and plant products, based on too weak a prior assessment.In addition, the bureaucratic burden this entails for traders would significantly increase costs and trade distortions, and threaten the EU trade in plants (worth around EUR 30 billion).We must ensure that our trading interests are not harmed by very broad precautions.

name: Miguel VIEGAS
text: in writing. - The dominant agricultural models, based on intensive monocultures, of an export nature, reduce the resilience of agricultural systems to pests and potentiate their devastating effects, which is why it is necessary, above all, to question and abandon these models, alongside the rejection of any form of privatization of genetic resources, namely through seed patenting. Pretending, under the pretext of combating pests, to impose registration and certification measures that, in practice, make the activity of small farmers unfeasible, traditional agriculture and traditional forms of plant propagation is not acceptable. On the contrary, it would mean committing to a sustainable response to the pest problem in the long term. As regards the import of plant material from third countries, strict phytosanitary control is fully justified, which eliminates risks of future outbreaks of plant diseases, with potentially devastating agronomic and ecological consequences.

name: Harald VILIMSKY
text: written.- The general aim of the regulation is to reduce the risk of new pests and diseases.The text also aims to modernize phytosanitary trade-related instruments.Better traceability in the internal market or from third countries should also be guaranteed.As I am in favor of changing the regulation in this direction, I have rejected the amendment.

name: Lieve WIERINCK
text: in writing. – I voted against the Council position on this issue. Imports of plants products and material should be analysed using a risk-based approach. There is a restriction on the import, in order to not allow import of diseases.

name: Tomáš ZDECHOVSKÝ
text: in writing.- Plant health is a topical issue and needs to be protected.I therefore support this text, which deals with protection measures against harmful organisms.Diseases and pests spread between plants do not respect national borders and can spread unstoppably throughout the European Union.I therefore believe that we need a common approach and appropriate tools to help us prevent such cases.The whole problem is exacerbated by the fact that many plants are imported into Europe from third countries, so it is necessary to have clear rules for their import so as not to introduce unwanted organisms into the EU and damage European agriculture as such.

name: Jana ŽITŇANSKÁ
text: in writing.- I supported Mrs McIntyre's report on the Council's position at first reading with a view to the adoption of a regulation on plant protection measures.It is part of a package of measures to strengthen the application of health and safety standards throughout the agricultural chain.The Regulation lays down rules for deciding on phytosanitary risks caused by plant pests.It also contains measures to reduce these risks and prevent third-country pests from entering EU territory.The rapporteur's aim was, inter alia, to protect trade and avoid unnecessary bureaucracy while taking sufficient measures.The novelty of the regulation is the possibility to temporarily restrict plants or plant products that have not been subject to a risk assessment, or the possibility to claim compensation for farmers who have had to destroy the crop as a result of pest infestation.

name: Milan ZVER
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of the European Parliament's legislative resolution on the Council's position at first reading with a view to the adoption of a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on plant protection measures, amending regulations (EU) no.228/2013, (EU) no.652/2014 and (EU) no.1143/2014 of the European Parliament and of the Council and repealing Council Directives 69/464 / EEC, 74/647 / EEC, 93/85 / EEC, 98/57 / EC, 2000/29 / EC, 2006/91 / EC and 2007/33/ EC (08795/2/2016 - C8-0364 / 2016 - 2013/0141 (COD)).The Recommendation contains a proposal for strict rules on protection against the spread of pests.

name: Momchil NEKOV
text: S & amp; D). - Mr President, unemployment rates, and especially youth unemployment, are still alarmingly high, despite the reported improvement over the past year. In my country, Bulgaria, the shrinking and aging workforce, the weak participation in the labor market and the discrepancies between the demand and supply of skills are emerging as lasting and worrying. I argue that facilitating the transition from education to work goes through providing internship and apprenticeship opportunities that provide young people with clearly defined rights, including decent pay and social protection. Last but not least, I believe that the priority given to reducing macroeconomic imbalances must be balanced by the need to maintain minimum standards in the field of education, especially in higher education, especially in countries with low GDP. Ensuring equal opportunities, inclusive and quality education is a key factor in stabilizing the European economy.

name: Isabella ADINOLFI
text: in writing.- The report deals with the country-specific recommendations made by the Commission under the European Semester.The text is completely focused on respecting budgetary constraints and on the inadequacy of structural reforms implemented by the Member States and completely missing a part that discusses the need to implement measures to manage the trade surpluses of the Member States that create riskeconomic imbalances.For the reasons described above I have decided to express myself negatively towards the proposal.

name: Clara AGUILERA
text: written. - The economic recovery in Europe remains slow, fragile and above all, very uneven: growth is weak, unemployment rates continue to be very high in many countries and investments are at historic lows. Europe as a whole must strengthen the investment plan so that instead of a sum of parts, it is a true Union policy, and the countries with a trade surplus must invest more to balance their economies and improve domestic demand. Furthermore, we call on the Member States for effective measures to guarantee decent jobs with decent wages, adequate social protection and decent public pensions. We also need a fairer rather than serious taxation not only on middle and working income but also on capital income. And finally, we need a European Minimum Income Framework to lift the 120 million people who today live in the Union at risk of social exclusion out of poverty. Only in this way can we overcome this long and painful crisis in a fair and sustainable way. For all these reasons I have voted in favor of this report and I deeply regret that the rest of the groups on the left have not joined in these requests.

name: Tim AKER
text: in writing. – Whilst the report identifies problems faced by the eurozone, it does not include the obvious solution (namely a plan to disentangle Member States from the straight-jacket of the single currency), and describes free movement of people as ‘fundamental’.  Accordingly, UKIP voted against.

name: Marina ALBIOL GUZMÁN
text: written.- I voted against this report because, despite the inclusion of significant references to the social problems that austerity policies are causing in the Member States of the European Union, it continues to bet on austerity as the only way, even legitimizing thepossible sanctions against Spain and Portugal that are under discussion.I totally reject the imposition of austerity policies, because they are a complete economic contradiction, which only increases poverty and inequalities.Likewise, with the macro conditionality that, if applied in the Iberian Peninsula, can seriously impact, accelerating the destruction of our economy.The report is unable to propose an alternative, appealing for more austerity.This is what we are fighting against and consequently I have decided to vote against it.

name: Eric ANDRIEU
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of this resolution which underlines the need to improve the Union's overall capacity to generate growth, to create and maintain quality jobs, and therefore to fight against interest rateshigh unemployment by putting in place a regulatory framework conducive to growth.

name: Nikos ANDROULAKIS
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of the report on the European Semester for Economic Policy Coordination and the Implementation of the 2016 Priorities, because the EU and its Member States should make the most of the revised economic policy mix, which aims to increaseand is linked to the objectives of the Europe 2020 strategy, including quality of employment, education and innovation.

name: Marie-Christine ARNAUTU
text: in writing. - The European Semester is a process for coordinating the economic policies of EU Member States. The purpose of this report is to take stock of the application of the recommendations for 2016. Despite an overhaul of the format last year (recommendations further upstream of national finance laws, more precise and less numerous), the state of affairs the spirit remains the same. It is about imposing the famous structural reforms, thus the liberalization of the markets, by the incentive, and ultimately by the pressure. In this regard, we will recall the context in which the EU considered, for the first time, to suspend the payment of structural funds to Spain and Portugal for non-compliance with this type of recommendation. The report accumulates a large amount of commonplace banalities on macroeconomic uncertainties, the need for targeted investments, job creation, etc., proof of Parliament's difficulty in formulating clear criticisms, as for example to the address of the German trade surplus. Some positive elements can be noted on the questions of inequalities or the competence of States. Both the principle of the Semester and its supranational logic and the content of the recommendations justify voting against this report.

name: Jonathan ARNOTT
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against this report for two primary reasons. The report repeatedly describes the free movement of people as ‘fundamental’ to the European project. A project that has failed the people of Europe. The report also welcomes ‘tax coordination’ across the European Union and calls for EU Investment funds to be used for social as well as economic ends.

name: Zigmantas BALČYTIS
text: in writing.- According to the European EconomicAccording to spring forecasts, the EU economy will grow at a slower pace than expected, with GDP in the euro area expected to grow by only 1.6%.and 2017will reach 1.8 percent.The EU also faces challenges related to the deteriorating international environment, unimplemented sustainable reforms.I therefore welcome the fact that the Commission, in its 2016The country-specific recommendations focus on three key priorities for further growth: supporting investment in innovation, growth and jobs, pursuing structural reforms and promoting responsible public finance management.However, the Commission should step up its efforts to support fiscal sustainability in line with the Stability and Growth Pact, while fully applying its flexibility provisions in line with the 2015 Pact.January 13Commission communication.

name: Zoltán BALCZÓ
text: in writing.- The name European Semester is a typical EU language invention that obscures the point.In fact, it is a six-month process, the essence and purpose of which is the central adoption of the basic data and socio-economic goals that determine the budgets of the member states for the next year, and the enforcement of the EU goals.This practically drastically limits sovereign national parliaments in one of their most important tasks on their own, in drafting the budget law.The economic and social policies formulated in the context of the European Semester are neoliberal, austerity-centered, federalist and anti-democratic.The report submitted is fully in line with this view, so I have, of course, rejected it.

name: Gerard BATTEN
text: in writing. ‒ Whilst the report identifies problems faced by the eurozone, it does not include the obvious solution (namely a plan to disentangle Member States from the straight-jacket of the single currency), and describes free movement of people as ‘fundamental’.  Accordingly, UKIP voted against.

name: Nicolas BAY
text: in writing.- By voting against this text, I wanted to oppose hard-line liberalism in certain areas (internal market, competition), the refusal to denounce the attitude of Germany, or even emphasize the role ofeuro in macroeconomic imbalances.It is out of the question to support the supranational logic of the European Semester.

name: Hugues BAYET
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of this report, which calls for a review of the economic measures currently in place.In this text, we recall the need for taxation at European level, we call for sustained investment in public infrastructure.It is also necessary to review and recalibrate the austerity policies imposed on the Member States and which do not meet the expectations expected by some.

name: Beatriz BECERRA BASTERRECHEA
text: written. - I have abstained in this Resolution on the European Semester for the coordination of economic policies. Although the Resolution has a social vision that I share, many of the contributions and proposals put forward by my political group were not taken into account. However, I voted against my group's line of withdrawing the paragraph where it welcomes the Commission's focus on the 2016 country-specific recommendations to support investment in innovation, growth and job creation, and calls for the pursuit of socially balanced structural reforms and the promotion of responsible public finances. I believe that these recommendations are especially necessary for Spain's economic recovery and progress. I have also rejected the amendments in favor of an exit from the single currency and to reinforce the sovereignty of the Member States, proposed by the Eurosceptic political groups. I have also voted in favor of an amendment by The Greens that calls for the creation of a European Deposit Guarantee System, which will make it possible to strengthen the banking union in the face of the weakness that the financial system has shown during the crisis.

name: Brando BENIFEI
text: in writing. - In a complicated international context, in which the consequences of Brexit are linked to possible uncertainties in the economic field and low growth prospects, it is essential to clearly define the priorities that the Union must pursue in terms of economic policy coordination. My vote in support of the Sant report is based on the conviction that stimulating domestic demand and investment is a priority in order to be able to effectively address the challenges posed by globalization, the digital revolution, aging and climate change. The Union must increase funding opportunities, in particular for SMEs, by making banks healthier and strengthening their ability to lend to the real economy. We need to complete and implement the Banking Union as soon as possible, develop the Capital Markets Union and prevent the fragmentation of the euro area financial markets. In general, the Commission must strive to implement all those measures that can reduce obstacles to investment in crucial sectors such as transport, energy and communications, while helping to reduce the tax wedge on labor in member countries. Only by adopting these instruments will Europe be able to live up to the expectations of its citizens.

name: Xabier BENITO ZILUAGA
text: written.- I voted against this report, because I am opposed to the European Semester mechanism as a whole.The aim of the European Semester is to subject the governments' budgets to an audit by the European Commission, which ensures compliance with certain macroeconomic objectives and the implementation of the so-called structural reforms.The facts show that the effect of the austerity measures has been pro-cyclical, that is, they have worsened the economic crisis.Although the work of the shadow rapporteur of the GUE / NGL has managed to include positive references to public investment, I still do not share the diagnosis or the solution.

name: Izaskun BILBAO BARANDICA
text: written.- I appreciate the work carried out in the ECON Committee on this report on the European Semester for the coordination of economic policies and its implementation of the priorities for 2016, but I have abstained in the final vote on this report as the key points of ourgroup have not been covered by the speaker.On the contrary, I voted in favor of two amendments which, on the one hand, called for progress towards the establishment of a European Deposit Guarantee Scheme and, on the other, that the EU institutions initiate and support a process ofrenegotiation of public debt in the most indebted countries.

name: Dominique BILDE
text: in writing. - Obviously I voted against this report on the implementation of the European Semester, which is only a straitjacket aimed at the European institutions to take control of the economic policies of the Member States. The modest words "European Semester" in reality hide the enactment by Brussels of the famous "structural reforms", including austerity policies towards countries that do not follow ultra-liberal diktats: let us note that the EU has already considered suspending the payment of structural funds to Spain and Portugal for non-compliance with its beneficial recommendations. The report, in line with this ideology, welcomes massive immigration, a veritable “reserve army of capitalism” and, according to the rapporteur, supposed to counter the effects of the aging of the population (one wonders why it the implementation of real natalist policies is not rather envisaged). Obviously, the report omits the reality: nothing on the German trade surplus weighing down the other countries of the euro zone or on the macroeconomic imbalances created by this single currency.

name: Mara BIZZOTTO
text: in writing.- I do not agree with the report which analyzes the governance of the single market in the context of the 2016 European Semester. I believe that once again the usual, failing austerity policies of the EU are reappearing.Although the wishes for economic development, employment and growth present in the text can be shared, they clearly conflict with the basic structure of the EU which, based on budgetary constraints and the growing reduction of the possibility of direct intervention by the Member States,in fact, the economic recovery of our territories.For all these reasons I have spoken out against this text.

name: José BLANCO LÓPEZ
text: written. - The economic recovery in Europe remains slow, fragile and above all, very uneven: growth is weak, unemployment rates continue to be very high in many countries and investments are at historical lows. Europe as a whole must strengthen the investment plan so that instead of a sum of the parts, it is a true Union policy, and the countries with a trade surplus must invest more to balance their economies and improve domestic demand. Furthermore, we call on the Member States for effective measures to guarantee decent jobs with decent wages, adequate social protection and decent public pensions. We also need a fairer rather than serious taxation not only on middle and working income but also on capital income. And finally, we need a European Minimum Income Framework to lift the 120 million people who today live in the Union at risk of social exclusion out of poverty. Only in this way can we overcome this long and painful crisis in a fair and sustainable way. For all these reasons, I have voted in favor of this report and I deeply regret that the rest of the groups on the left have not joined these requests.

name: Vilija BLINKEVIČIŪTĖ
text: in writing. - I voted in favor of this report, which deals with the European Semester for Economic Policy Coordination - 2016. implementation of priorities. Although we are striving for growth and jobs throughout the European Union, the situation is not improving in many Member States, especially in the areas of social affairs, employment and education. In Europe, child poverty has risen sharply, with as many as 20 million children living in poverty or on the brink of poverty. I therefore call on the Commission and the Member States to set up a Child Guarantee, i.e. y. a specific measure with a specific budget to enable every child in Europe to receive free health and childcare, education, decent accommodation and proper nutrition. Therefore, the Commission and the Member States should ensure and implement in their policy agendas, in line with the EP's recommendations, the provision of necessary and adequate social protection, access to health and social services for all. Greater inclusion of vulnerable groups in the labor market, reduction of in-work poverty and promotion of gender equality are needed. In addition, it is necessary to promote health and safety at work, to strengthen the rights of precarious workers under atypical employment contracts and to ensure greater social protection for the self-employed.

name: Andrea BOCSKOR
text: in writing.- With regard to the report, I would like to emphasize that youth unemployment has fallen in most Member States recently, but this figure remains a matter of serious concern.In 2015, youth unemployment in Europe fell to 19.7%.According to the latest data, this rate fell to 18.9% in 2016.I would like to emphasize the importance of digital, entrepreneurial skills and 'soft' skills.A stable and high-quality workplace and a safe environment are very important for creating independence and starting a responsible family.Due to the aging of the population, Europe urgently needs to activate young people, encourage them to start a family and have children.

name: Franc BOGOVIČ
text: in writing.- I supported the report on the implementation of the European Semester priorities because Europe is still facing a large investment deficit and it is therefore necessary to increase domestic demand and correct macroeconomic imbalances.Uncertainty and thus a reduction in investment has increased due to political developments such as the outcome of the UK referendum, relations with Russia and uncertainty in the development of the global economy.A large share of low inflation was thus contributed by low oil prices and slow economic growth in early 2016. It is therefore necessary to increase investment, which plays an important role in job creation.The European Union, on the other hand, is facing 10.5 million long-term unemployed who need to find jobs.

name: Simona BONAFÈ
text: in writing. - Following the economic crisis, Europe is still in a slow phase of growth, with a deep investment deficit and high unemployment rates in many of its Member States. The EU therefore needs stronger and above all inclusive growth, capable of sustaining employment, proposing structural reforms and pursuing responsible fiscal policies. For this reason, I support the growth and investment orientation of which the report on the European Semester is the bearer, with the aim of recreating a favorable climate for both public and private investment. The 2016 European Semester focused on a limited number of priority areas, highlighting the need for socially sustainable reforms, focused on the growth of small and medium-sized enterprises and on training. At a time when some of its Member States are facing huge external pressures that put a strain on investment, the European Commission must keep in mind the key principles on which the Union is based, namely solidarity and collaboration, by applying fully the flexibility mechanisms in the scoreboard of national fiscal policies.

name: Biljana BORZAN
text: written.- I support this report.The EU and Member States need to better implement the revised economic policy mix, which aims to increase investment in EU 2020 policy goals, including quality employment, education and innovation.

name: Mercedes BRESSO
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the resolution on the implementation of 2016 priorities included in the European Semester programme because, on the one hand, it welcomes the main priorities to further strengthen economic growth identified by the Commission. On the other hand, it calls on the Commission to make full use of the flexibility clauses included in the Stability and Growth Pact. Indeed, I believe more flexibility is needed in Europe nowadays, while fiscal sustainability shall be guaranteed by Member States. In addition to that, I believe more measures should be taken in order to deal with the current levels of unemployment.

name: Renata BRIANO
text: in writing. - The European Parliament notes that the EU economy will grow less than the 2016 economic forecast. It therefore stresses the need to increase growth, cohesion, productivity and competitiveness; believing that the lack of sustainable investment and the shortcomings in the completion of the single market deprive the EU of its full growth potential. The priorities to further strengthen economic growth are to promote investment in innovation, growth and job creation, to pursue socially balanced structural reforms and to encourage responsible public finance management. He points out that the still too high unemployment rates show that some Member States are unable to create quality employment. It calls for a greater effort to reduce poverty, social exclusion and growing inequalities. He notes that monetary policy alone is not enough to stimulate growth if sustainable investment and structural reforms are lacking. Stresses the importance of completing and implementing the Banking Union, of developing the Capital Markets Union to create a stable environment for investment and growth and of creating an inclusive single market; as it is a key tool for improving growth, cohesion, employment and competitiveness as well as for safeguarding business and consumer confidence.

name: Steeve BRIOIS
text: in writing. - This report aims to take stock of the implementation of the recommendations resulting from the European Semester in each Member State. As a reminder, the European Semester is a process of coordination of the economic policies of the Member States which aims to require national governments to implement structural reforms. These notably include market liberalization, pension reform and labor market reform. The pressure tactics at the disposal of the European Union to force Member States unwilling to apply the Commission’s ultra-liberal potion can range from financial sanctions to the suspension of structural funds. As such, Spain and Portugal are currently the subject of a procedure to suspend the funds intended for them, for excessive budget deficit. We denounce the principle of the European Semester and its supranational logic as much as the content of the recommendations made therein. That’s why I voted against this text.

name: Soledad CABEZÓN RUIZ
text: written. - The economic recovery in Europe remains slow, fragile and above all, very uneven: growth is weak, unemployment rates continue to be very high in many countries and investments are at historic lows. Europe as a whole must strengthen the investment plan so that instead of a sum of parts, it is a true Union policy, and the countries with a trade surplus must invest more to balance their economies and improve domestic demand. Furthermore, we call on the Member States for effective measures to guarantee decent jobs with decent wages, adequate social protection and decent public pensions. We also need a fairer rather than serious taxation not only on middle and working income but also on capital income. And finally, we need a European Minimum Income Framework to lift the 120 million people who today live in the Union at risk of social exclusion out of poverty. Only in this way can we overcome this long and painful crisis in a fair and sustainable way. For all these reasons I have voted in favor of this report and I deeply regret that the rest of the groups on the left have not joined in these requests.

name: Matt CARTHY
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against this report, which was the second of the regular own—initiative (non-legislative) reports drafted in ECON on the framework of the European Semester. The Council adopted the country—specific recommendations (CSRs) on 12 July 2016, and this report is the response of the European Parliament to these recommendations and their implementation. Despite the inclusion of some positive recommendations, such as for minimum income schemes in Member States, the recommendations continue to focus on deregulation, privatisation, and a reduction of Member States’ deficits at the expense of investment, welfare and public services. This time CSRs have also been marked by the attempt to apply Article 23 of the common provisions regulation, which restricts access to the European Structural Funds to those countries that have not achieved the macroeconomic objectives set out in the economic governance framework (i.e., Spain and Portugal). Sinn Fein opposes the European Semester as the economic framework of the EU, so I voted against.

name: James CARVER
text: in writing. ‒ Whilst the report identifies problems faced by the eurozone, it does not include the obvious solution (namely a plan to disentangle Member States from the straight-jacket of the single currency), and describes free movement of people as ‘fundamental’.  Accordingly, UKIP voted against.

name: David CASA
text: in writing. ‒ I welcome the Commission’s focus in its 2016 country-specific recommendations (CSRs) on the three main priorities to further strengthen economic growth: supporting investment for innovation, growth and job creation, pursuing socially-balanced structural reforms and encouraging responsible public finance. I fully support the efforts made to ensure greater national ownership in the formulation and implementation of CSRs as an ongoing reform process. Europe’s long economic crisis has highlighted the need to facilitate investment in education, innovation and research and development, while enhancing the EU’s competitiveness by pursuing sustainable structural reforms to boost quality job creation and implementing responsible fiscal policies to create a better environment for jobs, businesses (especially SMEs) and investment. Unemployment rates are still high, especially for youth unemployment. Support measures to facilitate access to financing, particularly for SMEs, is vital if the continuing high unemployment in many Member States is to be tackled effectively.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: in writing.- The report is not legislative and concerns the Parliament's view on the country specific recommendations (CSRs) made by the Commission under the European Semester.The focus of the text is on compliance with budgetary constraints, the lack of and insufficient application of European governance rules and the inadequate implementation of structural reforms by the Member States.On the other hand, there is completely no criticism of the need to adopt corrective measures to manage the excessive trade surpluses, which are the cause of enormous macroeconomic imbalances within the eurozone.I voted no.

name: Caterina CHINNICI
text: in writing. - The report, for which I decided to vote in favor, contains the European Parliament's contribution to the second phase of the 2016 European Semester. The document sets the general economic and social priorities for the European Union and analyzes the specific recommendations addressed to individuals Member States from the Commission in their Annual Growth Report for 2016. I believe that colleagues from the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs (ECON) have done a great job of presenting a balanced text that combines the reference to socially acceptable structural reforms with growth of investments. Indeed, I believe that relaunching investment within the Union is essential in order to stimulate growth, the creation of quality jobs, innovation and the fight against inequality and poverty. I particularly appreciated the inclusion in the text of a procedure for social imbalances when drawing up the country-specific recommendations. It seems essential to me that macroeconomic structural reforms do not constitute a race to the bottom in terms of social and employment standards.

name: Lefteris CHRISTOFOROU
text: in writing.- We support the report and stress the need to improve the EU 's overall capacity to grow, create and maintain jobs, thus tackling high unemployment, by creating a growth - friendly regulatory framework.

name: Kostas CHRYSOGONOS
text: in writing.- We voted on the report on the European Semester on Economic Policy Coordination and in particular on the implementation of the 2016 priorities.society and citizens, without a disposition for change and self-criticism.We cannot aim for recovery by that logic, and that is why I voted against the report.

name: Angelo CIOCCA
text: in writing.- Negative vote on this report.Although shared hopes for economic development, employment and growth conflict with the basic structure of the EU, based on budgetary constraints and the growing impossibility of direct intervention by the Member States to invest in the various fronts of the crisis.

name: Alberto CIRIO
text: in writing. - Although I voted in favor of the provision, I do not deny that reading it in its entirety constituted for me the acceptance of one of the most inauspicious frameworks, since we take note of the dramatic situation which, for years now, has submitted our Union. All diseases are made up of several phases: first of all denial, then acceptance and struggle. For a long time we have tried to view stagnant growth as a provisional element or we have hidden unemployment under the veils of reforms never inaugurated, but with this measure we want to take note of the pathologies suffered by the Union to eradicate them, therefore it promptly sets out the challenges to be faced . These include the grim 4.2 million increase in the number of people at risk of poverty and social exclusion and the rise in inequality. Fortunately, Europe 2020 contains for the first time a program to fight poverty, it will be implemented in 2017. Overall the aim is to improve the capacity to generate growth and competitiveness while maintaining quality jobs as well as to introduce inclusive education systems sources of innovation and creativity relevant to the labor market.

name: Deirdre CLUNE
text: in writing. ‒ I supported the Report on the European Semester for economic policy coordination: implementation of 2016 priorities.

name: Carlos COELHO
text: in writing. - The European Semester is an important tool for coordinating Member States' economic policies. The projected growth rate for the EU is 1.8%, unemployment remains at high levels (10.5 million long-term unemployed) and political situations (Brexit, Russia or refugees) have important implications for the investment climate. I regret that the response rate of States to the recommendations of the European Semester is below 30%. I welcome the reference to the specific situation in Portugal and the call to consider the results of the structured dialogue for possible decisions on suspension of structural funds. I agree to reduce the number of recommendations, focusing on specific topics. Support for investment for innovation, socially balanced structural reforms and control of public finances are priorities that I follow. In the context of employment and social affairs, I support specific attention to youth unemployment, social inequalities and people at risk of poverty, as proposed by Mrs Sofia Ribeiro, in the Employment and Social Affairs Committee. Within the framework of the internal market, I share the priority given to the digital single market, to better harmonization in the field of VAT and the improvement of the system of recognition of qualifications. For these reasons, I support this report.

name: Lara COMI
text: in writing. - I voted in favor of the report because it highlights the key points of the policies and activities that the European Union will have to support in the short term, such as: facilitating investment in the most sensitive sectors, namely education, innovation, research and development; the decrease in the youth unemployment rate, through interventions supported by national authorities and social partners aimed at strengthening professional skills and making the labor market more inclusive; strengthening the single market by making greater use of the sources of financing and investment made available by the EU, especially as regards SMEs and achieving mutual recognition of qualifications; the modernization of public administration services, particularly through e-government procedures, better cross-border cooperation and a simplification of administrative procedures in order to improve relations between businesses and citizens with local government bodies.

name: Javier COUSO PERMUY
text: written.- I voted against this report because even though significant references have been made to the social problems that austerity policies are causing in the Member States of the European Union, it continues to bet on austerity as the only way, even legitimizing thepossible sanctions against Spain and Portugal that are under discussion.I totally reject the imposition of austerity policies, because they are a complete economic contradiction, which only increases poverty and inequalities.Likewise, with the macro conditionality that, if applied in the Iberian Peninsula, can seriously impact, accelerating the destruction of our economy.The report is unable to propose an alternative, appealing for more austerity.This is what we are fighting against and consequently I have decided to vote against it.

name: Andrea COZZOLINO
text: in writing. - The report on the European Semester offers many food for thought, given that the European Union is still struggling to regain economic growth and in some countries the tragedies of the economic and social crisis are still perceived. There are two key concepts that it is important to highlight. The first relates to the need for sustainable investments to boost demand on the continent: in this way it will be possible to sustain the growth potential. Second important element concerns the creation of jobs with the implementation of sustainable budgetary policies to create a better working environment. At the same time, growth-oriented fiscal policies must be promoted in order to complement the effect of monetary policy. In this sense, the flexibility included in the rules of the Stability and Growth Pact must be considered above all in the light of the importance of public investments in the European economic structure. I therefore vote in favor of this report, considering it balanced towards a reform of the European semester which takes into account the importance of sustainable growth, investment and the creation of quality jobs.

name: Edward CZESAK
text: in writing.- I voted against the report on the European Semester of Economic Policy Coordination: Implementation of Priorities for 2016, as I believe that this report should focus on other aspects of the EU.In my opinion, the report should focus more on the role of the Member States in carrying out structural reforms than on improving public sentiment, which is being set as a goal of the EU's economic recovery.Furthermore, the report calls for the completion of the banking union and the territorial alignment of the projects of the European Fund for Strategic Investments.For the above reasons, I voted against.

name: Miriam DALLI
text: in writing. ‒ The European Semester includes the Commission’s analyses of the fiscal and structural reform policies of every Member State by providing recommendations, and monitors their implementation; and the Member States’ implementation of the commonly agreed policies. The report focuses on the need to increase investment in the EU for growth, employment, poverty and social inequality. It also asks for an imbalance procedure for economic coordination and an EU minimum income framework for social inclusion. This is why I am in favour of this report as it is well balanced and outlines the main areas that require further attention.

name: Daniel DALTON
text: in writing. ‒ I cannot support a report that calls for implementation of the Banking Union, the need to address the lack of tax coordination through further EU powers in the area of tax, more fiscal consolidation, and a European minimum income. I believe that we need to look at meaningful structural reform if we wish to see a lasting economic recovery in Europe and not just a transfer of more fiscal powers to the EU.

name: Michel DANTIN
text: in writing. - This report concerns the implementation of the priorities in terms of economic policy coordination between the Member States for the year 2016. The report recognizes in this context the delicate situation with which the European Union is confronted, namely a deficit investment, as well as the need to increase domestic demand and correct macroeconomic imbalances. The report stresses the need to base the coordination of economic policies on three fundamental pillars: firstly, support for investment in innovation, growth and job creation, secondly the development of structural reforms. balanced from a social point of view, and finally the development of responsible public finances. Considering that it is necessary to limit the number of recommendations for Member States and to base the recommendations of the European Semester mainly on social and macro-economic aspects, I supported this report.

name: William (The Earl of) DARTMOUTH
text: in writing. ‒ Whilst the report identifies problems faced by the eurozone, it does not include the obvious solution (namely a plan to disentangle Member States from the straight-jacket of the single currency), and describes free movement of people as ‘fundamental’.  Accordingly, UKIP voted against.

name: Rachida DATI
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of the report on the European Semester for the coordination of economic policies and the implementation of priorities for 2016. Faced with a slowdown in the global economy, stagnation of investments in Europe and ahigh unemployment, Member States must coordinate their economic policies by following the recommendations of the European Semester.Likewise, it is essential that the European Parliament calls on the Member States to implement economic policies suited to the development of the internal market.These must focus on promoting innovation and growth, while meeting the criteria of both social justice and economic efficiency.

name: Martina DLABAJOVÁ
text: in writing.- I appreciate that the European Semester is now more focused on employment performance, especially in a situation where the EU is still achieving an incredibly high level of unemployment with more than 4 million unemployed people under the age of 25.Unfortunately, the report lacks crucial points, such as the emphasis on growth for modernizing the economy and setting binding recommendations for Member States.This report is a typical example of a "Christmas tree" on which other themes and areas are packed.For these reasons, I voted against the report.

name: Mireille D'ORNANO
text: in writing. - This report aims to take stock of the European Semester and its economic recommendations to Member States. Despite an overhaul of its format last year, with more precise recommendations, fewer in number and addressed more upstream of national finance laws, the principle remains the same. It is about imposing structural reforms and market liberalization. For the record, the EU had considered, for the first time, to suspend the payment of structural funds to Spain and Portugal for non-compliance with such recommendations. This report multiplies the clichés on macroeconomic uncertainties, the need for targeted investments and job creation. Despite positive elements relating to inequalities or the competence of States in social matters, the text praises the contribution of immigration to compensate for the aging of the population. Being opposed to this Semester and its supranational and ultraliberal logic (internal market, competition) and to the refusal to denounce the attitude of Germany or the role of the euro in macroeconomic imbalances, I voted against.

name: Angel DZHAMBAZKI
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted against this file. I disagree with the fact, that low public demand and a deteriorating international environment are the key challenges for the economic recovery of the European Union. In fact, Member States have undertaken many meaningful structural reforms. These important reforms should have been highlighted in the report instead.

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: in writing.- The solution to the problems caused by the European Union in the economies of the Member States of the region can not be "above the European Union".The Union's economic and monetary policy, combined with the immigration crisis that has flattened the peoples of the South, have failed and must be abandoned immediately.Continuation of the same failed policies will further inflate the problems faced by countries such as Cyprus and Greece.

name: José Manuel FERNANDES
text: in writing.- The Commission's spring 2016 economic forecasts point to growth rates of 1.6% for the euro area and 1.8% for the EU in 2016. Unemployment in the EU in general (and theStructural unemployment, in particular), remains one of the main challenges facing Member States, as it currently reaches a very high level (10.5 million long-term unemployed in the EU).The evolution of the political situation, namely the result of the United Kingdom referendum, relations with Russia and uncertainties regarding the evolution of the world economy have further inhibited investment.I therefore believe it is important to improve the EU's overall capacity to grow, create and maintain quality jobs and thus tackle high levels of unemployment by creating a regulatory framework that supports growth.

name: João FERREIRA
text: in writing. - This report addresses the European Semester process, with a view to defending, legitimizing and consolidating it. Obviously, we voted against. The reasons abound. The European Semester represents a significant qualitative leap in the process of attacking national sovereignties and the concentration of power in supranational institutions, controlled by the EU directory, at the service of big capital. The way it was configured takes on neo-colonial contours. It was not by chance that it was first claimed and defended later by the organizations of the great European employers. The goal is to tie states to neoliberal policies and options. Social democracy plays its role in this process, legitimizing the European Semester and trying to give it a “social” appearance. The report calls for the completion of the Banking Union and the Capital Markets Union. He praises the so-called Report of the Five Presidents - the flight ahead rehearsed by the EU bureaucracy, in the face of the explosive worsening of the contradictions of the capitalist integration process, especially with regard to Economic and Monetary Union. Some positive recommendations that the report contains do not change its fundamental matrix. We actively intervened in the discussion of this report by presenting several amendments and stages in different commissions, 11 of which were presented in plenary.

name: Monika BEŇOVÁ
text: in writing.- As last year, this year's progress report on the European Semester for economic policy coordination is accompanied by various problems, whether with labor market flexibility, productivity-based wages and weakening labor and worker protection through structural reforms in some Member States.The European Union and the Member States must work to better implement a modernized economic mix aimed at increasing investment linked to the EU 2020 program, which includes quality employment, education and innovation.

name: Lorenzo FONTANA
text: in writing.- I am voting against the report, in addition to some shareable "wishes", the basic structure remains based on budgetary constraints and on the growing reduction of the possibilities for direct intervention by the Member States.

name: Lampros FOUNTOULIS
text: in writing. - I am voting against the European Semester for Economic Policy Coordination: Implementing the 2016 Priorities. The Union's economic and monetary policy, combined with the immigration crisis that has flattened the peoples of the South, have failed and must be abandoned immediately. Continuation of the same failed policies will further inflate the problems faced by countries such as Cyprus and Greece.

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: in writing. ‒ I support the report as it clearly focuses on the need to increase investment in the EU in order to create more growth, convergence, quality jobs and fight poverty and inequality. Hence, I strongly support the introduction of the social imbalance procedure into the economic coordination and the proposed European minimum income framework to fight social exclusion in the EU. The EU and the Member States need to better implement the revised economic policy mix, which aims at increasing investment linked to EU2020 policy objectives including quality employment, education, innovation and growth enhancing policies. The single market is a pillar of the EU economy, therefore I am in favour of an inclusive single market, with enhanced governance, which favours better regulation and competition, which I believe is a crucial instrument to improve growth, cohesion, employment and competitiveness and to preserve the confidence of the business sector and consumers. The Commission should monitor the progress made by the Member States, the formal inclusion of the single-market pillar in the European Semester is very important to enable continuous monitoring of single-market indicators, allowing for systematic follow-up and assessment of Member States’ progress on CSRs.

name: Ildikó GÁLL-PELCZ
text: in writing.- The crisis has highlighted the need for Europe to take steps to improve its economic model and restore its competitiveness.This requires both public funding and targeted investment.At present, however, the potential of the single market is not being realized.The Union must support the Member States in significantly increasing cross-border trade and also take urgent action to make better use of digital technologies.I voted in favor of this report, and I myself believe that the highest level of political oversight needs to be restored, the transposition and implementation of EU rules need to be standardized, and more effective tools need to be developed to ensure that the single market really benefits citizens and businesses.become.

name: Francisco de Paula GAMBUS MILLET
text: written.- I voted in favor of the report bearing in mind that the Union economy will grow less than expected according to the European economic forecasts, since the GDP of the euro area is expected to increase by only 1.6%, to reach1.8% in 2017. Therefore, there is a need to improve growth, cohesion, productivity and competitiveness by enhancing sustainable investments and addressing shortcomings in the completion of the single market, which are depriving theUnion to reach its full growth potential.We must support investment in innovation, growth and job creation, pursue socially balanced structural reforms, and promote responsible public finances.Likewise, it is especially important to make labor markets more inclusive and reduce social exclusion and growing disparities in income and wealth.

name: Iratxe GARCÍA PÉREZ
text: written. - The economic recovery in Europe remains slow, fragile and above all, very uneven: growth is weak, unemployment rates continue to be very high in many countries and investments are at historic lows. Europe as a whole must strengthen the investment plan so that instead of a sum of parts, it is a true Union policy, and the countries with a trade surplus must invest more to balance their economies and improve domestic demand. Furthermore, we call on the Member States for effective measures to guarantee decent jobs with decent wages, adequate social protection and decent public pensions. We also need a fairer rather than serious taxation not only on middle and working income but also on capital income. And finally, we need a European Minimum Income Framework to lift the 120 million people who today live in the Union at risk of social exclusion out of poverty. Only in this way can we overcome this long and painful crisis in a fair and sustainable way. For all these reasons I have voted in favor of this report and I deeply regret that the rest of the groups on the left have not joined in these requests.

name: Eider GARDIAZABAL RUBIAL
text: written. - The economic recovery in Europe remains slow, fragile and above all, very uneven: growth is weak, unemployment rates continue to be very high in many countries and investments are at historical lows. Europe as a whole must strengthen the investment plan so that instead of a sum of the parts, it is a true Union policy, and the countries with a trade surplus must invest more to balance their economies and improve domestic demand. Furthermore, we call on the Member States for effective measures to guarantee decent jobs with decent wages, adequate social protection and decent public pensions. We also need a fairer rather than serious taxation not only on middle and working income but also on capital income. And finally, we need a European Minimum Income Framework to lift the 120 million people who today live in the Union at risk of social exclusion out of poverty. Only in this way can we overcome this long and painful crisis in a fair and sustainable way. For all these reasons, I have voted in favor of this report and I deeply regret that the rest of the groups on the left have not joined these requests.

name: Enrico GASBARRA
text: in writing.- I congratulate my colleague Sant for the drafting of this important report, which focuses on a relevant aspect of the so-called European Semester procedure, namely that of implementation.I would like to underline that last year the S & amp; D group voted against a similar report, then edited by another rapporteur, since it was considered too oriented towards austerity measures, this year our rapporteur instead introduced numerous forecasts that aim to framethe structural reforms on the objective of growth, employment and social equity, I consider a very significant step forward.

name: Elena GENTILE
text: in writing. - I voted in favor of the EP resolution on the European semester for economic policy coordination: implementation of priorities for 2016 as this exercise is a useful opportunity to reflect on the state of the EU economy from the perspective of the EC recommendations to states members. In other words, to highlight what went wrong and what remains to be done. The balance sheet is not satisfactory, although there are signs of a recovery, albeit weak, the prerogative of some economies and not generalized. The state of the EU economy in the last two years still remains worrying, for this fundamental reason the EP report focused on certain fundamental points: the importance of long-term investments, which are essential for consolidating long-lasting and sustainable growth paths. , promotion of SMEs, increase of investment opportunities and access to credit. The role of the EFSI is fundamental but it is not sufficient, it is necessary to mobilize capital for new investments because the data on youth unemployment are not positive, although there is a slight decrease. For this reason, social investments in human capital must become a fundamental complementary measure, since human capital is a growth factor and an engine of competitiveness and development.

name: Arne GERICKE
text: written.- I voted against the “Report on the European Semester for the Coordination of Economic Policy: Implementation of the Priorities for 2016”, because in it above all the colleagues on the left unpack their “socialist bouquet” and thus the effectiveness of this important financial and economic policyDilute instruments.

name: Jens GIESEKE
text: written.- The European Union is currently not in top shape.Among other things, there are deficits in the completion of the internal market that are holding back the EU's potential for growth.These deficits need to be addressed.Long-term investments in the field of transport, communication, the digital economy, education, research, climate change, energy and environmental protection should also be further promoted and financing options for SMEs should be facilitated.We must give another priority to the fight against unemployment in the European Economic Area, and above all to fight against youth unemployment.In addition, more and more trade barriers need to be dismantled and tax policy coordination in the area of VAT needs to be intensified.Furthermore, I support an increased reduction in bureaucracy in public administration and the increased introduction of e-government.

name: Bruno GOLLNISCH
text: in writing. - The European Semester is the exercise which consists in putting under supervision the national budgets and, consequently, the policies, in particular economic and social, of the States which have adopted the euro as currency. They must in fact avoid any excessive budgetary imbalance, on pain of sanctions. That’s why I voted against this report, which often enchains banalities in analysis but does not call into question this absurd exercise. To tell the truth, I only fully approve of two things in this report: - the condemnation of the absurd sanction envisaged (this is a first) against Spain and Portugal (to cut them off the European regional funds that they receive) , while these two countries have been engaged for years in austerity policies, particularly painful for their peoples, dictated by Brussels; - the amendments which underline the destabilizing effects of the single currency on the economies of the euro zone and denounce the surpluses accumulated by Germany to the detriment of its European partners. They assume that German imbalances should also be sanctioned, in accordance with European texts. The future of Germany does not lie in the preservation of its income and the prosperity of its retirees. I hope the next election will prove it.

name: Tania GONZÁLEZ PEÑAS
text: written.- I voted against this report, because I am opposed to the European Semester mechanism as a whole.The aim of the European Semester is to subject government budgets to an audit by the European Commission, which ensures the fulfillment of certain macroeconomic objectives and the implementation of the so-called structural reforms.The facts show that the effect of the austerity measures has been pro-cyclical, that is, they have worsened the economic crisis.Although the work of the shadow rapporteur of the GUE / NGL has managed to include positive references to public investment, I still do not share the diagnosis or the solution.

name: Theresa GRIFFIN
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report. The EU and the Member States need to better implement the revised economic policy mix which aims at increasing investment linked to EU2020 policies objectives including quality employment, education, innovation and growth-enhancing policies.

name: Françoise GROSSETÊTE
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of this report because it provides an opportunity to take stock of the implementation, in the Member States, of the economic measures in favor of growth recommended by the Commission in the framework of the European Semester.Highlighting the fragility of the current economic recovery, and the alarming unemployment figures, which particularly affect young people, the report rightly points out that monetary policy alone cannot be enough to stimulate growth if it is not.not accompanied by sustainable investments and structural reforms.It is also a message addressed to Francois Hollande and the Socialists, who failed to reform France.Our country must complete its reforms, consolidate its public finances and simplify the labor market.

name: Enrique GUERRERO SALOM
text: written. - The economic recovery in Europe remains slow, fragile and above all, very uneven: growth is weak, unemployment rates continue to be very high in many countries and investments are at historic lows. Europe as a whole must strengthen the investment plan so that instead of a sum of parts, it is a true Union policy, and the countries with a trade surplus must invest more to balance their economies and improve domestic demand. Furthermore, we call on the Member States for effective measures to guarantee decent jobs with decent wages, adequate social protection and decent public pensions. We also need a fairer rather than serious taxation not only on middle and working income but also on capital income. And finally, we need a European Minimum Income Framework to lift the 120 million people who today live in the Union at risk of social exclusion out of poverty. Only in this way can we overcome this long and painful crisis in a fair and sustainable way. For all these reasons I have voted in favor of this report and I deeply regret that the rest of the groups on the left have not joined in these requests.

name: Antanas GUOGA
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report. The EU economy will grow less than expected on the basis of the European economic spring forecast 2016, as GDP in the eurozone is expected to increase by only 1.6%, reaching 1.8% by 2017. However, the EU responsible institutions should focus on three main priorities to further strengthen economic growth: supporting investment for innovation, growth and job creation, pursuing socially balanced structural reforms and encouraging responsible public finance.

name: Sergio GUTIÉRREZ PRIETO
text: written. - The economic recovery in Europe remains slow, fragile and above all, very uneven: growth is weak, unemployment rates continue to be very high in many countries and investments are at historic lows. Europe as a whole must strengthen the investment plan so that instead of a sum of parts, it is a true Union policy, and the countries with a trade surplus must invest more to balance their economies and improve domestic demand. Furthermore, we call on the Member States for effective measures to guarantee decent jobs with decent wages, adequate social protection and decent public pensions. We also need a fairer rather than serious taxation not only on middle and working income but also on capital income. And finally, we need a European Minimum Income Framework to lift the 120 million people who today live in the Union at risk of social exclusion out of poverty. Only in this way can we overcome this long and painful crisis in a fair and sustainable way. For all these reasons I have voted in favor of this report and I deeply regret that the rest of the groups on the left have not joined in these requests.

name: Marian HARKIN
text: in writing. ‒ I abstained from the vote as some ALDE amendments have not been incorporated in the compromises or adopted in committee. The amendments which the ALDE group proposed sought to stress the importance for growth to continue modernising economies and improving business environment. Moreover, key ALDE points such that measures should be taken to improve the business environment to incentivise investment and that a fully integrated EU labour market should be created, have been rejected in the vote in committee. However, there is a reference to the Commission Communication advocating flexibility in the Stability and Growth Pact, which I fully support and I voted in favour of this amendment.

name: Hans-Olaf HENKEL
text: written. - In its annual report on the Commission's country-specific recommendations in the context of the European Semester, the European Parliament identifies weak public demand and a deteriorating international environment as key challenges for the European Union's economic recovery. But this starts in the wrong place. It is much more important that the Member States carry out further structural reforms. The crisis-ridden southern European countries in particular must continue to improve their international competitiveness in order to recover economically. The report also calls for the completion of the banking union. However, this goes way too far. According to the Commission's plans, the third pillar of the banking union provides for a mutualisation of deposit insurance. But it must not be the case that banks and savers in one country have to be jointly liable for a failed banking policy in another country. For these reasons I do not agree with the report.

name: Cătălin Sorin IVAN
text: in writing. ‒ I believe that the European Union and the Member States should better implement the revised economic policy mix which aims at increasing investment linked to EU2020 policies objectives (more growth, convergence, quality jobs and fight poverty and inequality).

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: written. - I voted in favor of the Report on the European Semester for economic policy coordination: implementation of priorities for 2016 (2016/2101 (INI)), which states that, unfortunately, the EU's economic recovery is still very slow and unsatisfactory. Namely, the EU economy will grow less than expected and GDP in the euro area is expected to grow by only 1.6% and reach 1.8% by 2017. Of particular concern is the still high youth unemployment rate and the large gap in the economic performance of different parts of the EU.
