The importance of coherence between cohesion policy instruments and the wider economic governance framework was recognized to support recovery efforts to achieve compliance with the rules of the European Semester. Unfortunately, the economic situation is still characterized by excess liquidity and interest rates at zero lower limit, weak demand and limited investment and consumption by households and economic entities. The implementation of the new policy mix presented by the Commission is needed to stimulate growth, as monetary policy alone is not enough to stimulate growth if other elements such as investment and sustainable structural reforms are lacking.

name: Jean-François JALKH
text: in writing.- Although previously amended in its form, this report continues to want to impose structural reforms on the Member States, by all means.In the absence of a fundamental critical approach, the whole is incomplete.As long as the cases of excessive liberalism, the destabilizing role of the euro or even the attitude of Germany are not studied in depth, all will be vain chatter.I voted against.

name: Marc JOULAUD
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of the report by my colleague Alfred Sant on the implementation of the European Semester for 2016. The European Semester allows the European Commission to issue recommendations and guidelines to Member States to promote growth andemployment.The Sant report supports the Commission's approach, but notes that the GDP and unemployment figures are disappointing compared to forecasts and calls for streamlining the European Semester by addressing as a priority the social and macroeconomic objectives set for the next eighteen months.This report was adopted by a large majority, which I welcome.

name: Philippe JUVIN
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of this report which presents the opinion of the European Parliament on the European Semester for the coordination of economic policies.In addition to the priorities issued by the Commission to which I subscribe, namely the revival of investment, the pursuit of structural reforms and the implementation of responsible budgetary policies, I was in agreement with the philosophy of the various elements present in this report.report, knowing that no prescriptive tax model was included and that a call for public investment to the detriment of private investment was avoided.

name: Eva KAILI
text: in writing. - Fiscal harmonization in the EU is a prerequisite for achieving economic integration. However, Member States' differing views on fiscal policy are delaying this development. The European Semester is still the main vehicle for fiscal harmonization, but unfortunately it works unbalanced for the Member States, especially for those with major budgetary problems. We need a progressive European Semester that supports policies capable of reducing unemployment, absorbing macroeconomic shocks and enabling sustainable growth.

name: Barbara KAPPEL
text: written.- The economic policy coordination report takes stock of the current economic situation in the Member States.It was stressed that the Commission should henceforth limit itself to priority issues of macroeconomic and social importance.In addition, national ownership is required through the involvement of national parliaments and regional and local authorities, and the individual national reform programs in the respective parliaments of the member states are subject to proper democratic control.However, since the report calls for the completion of the banking union in the area of priorities and gives the Commission further powers, I would have abstained from this report.

name: Afzal KHAN
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report. The EU and the Member States need to better implement the revised economic policy mix which aims at increasing investment linked to EU2020 policies objectives including quality employment, education, innovation and growth-enhancing policies.

name: Bernd KÖLMEL
text: written. - In its annual report on the Commission's country-specific recommendations in the context of the European Semester, the European Parliament identifies weak public demand and a deteriorating international environment as key challenges for the European Union's economic recovery. But this starts in the wrong place. It is much more important that the Member States carry out further structural reforms. The crisis-ridden southern European countries in particular must continue to improve their international competitiveness in order to recover economically. The report also calls for the completion of the banking union. However, this goes way too far. According to the Commission's plans, the third pillar of the banking union provides for a mutualisation of deposit insurance. However, it must not be the case that banks and savers in one country are jointly liable for a failed banking policy in another country. For these reasons I do not agree with the report.

name: Kateřina KONEČNÁ
text: in writing. - On 26 October 2016, at the plenary session of the European Parliament in Strasbourg, we voted on the report on the European Semester for economic policy coordination: implementing the priorities for 2016. The European Semester, like the budget, is one of the financial instruments voted on each year. Anyone who has been watching me for a long time knows that I am not a big fan of this instrument. However, this instrument exists and will continue to exist, which is why our political group seeks to improve it at least a little every year to lead to greater social justice, tackling social exclusion and intergenerational solidarity. Given that our key amendments, rejecting the blind policy of cuts in the budgets of the financial crisis plagued by the Member States, aimed at greater control and the tying up of the financial sector, or giving the opportunity to leave those members of the monetary union that are free to withdraw from it, including the subsequent financial and expert assistance with this step, have not passed, I ultimately had to vote against this document, as always.

name: Béla KOVÁCS
text: in writing.- There are a number of eligible amendments to the report that highlight the fundamental problems of the EU's economic philosophy.I have to underline many times that the roots of the problems are systemic, the particular neoliberal economic philosophy has not offered real solutions so far, and it will not.Until now, the necessary changes have been expected to take place in response to market effects, while the state's job is only to control the budget deficit and ensure the freedom of the markets.Slowly, I will not continue to do so.Of course, if the goal is not a union of sustainable development and livable member states, then the road may be good.

name: Andrey KOVATCHEV
text: In written form. - I support the report on the implementation of the priorities for 2016 in the framework of the European Semester for economic policy coordination. I believe that continuing structural reforms, overcoming the investment gap and responsible fiscal policies are key to the economic recovery of the EU Member States. In addition to economic policies, the European Semester also serves to monitor and promote progress towards the objectives of the Europe 2020 strategy. Here, unfortunately, progress in some areas has been very limited in recent years. I think it is important to reaffirm the EU's commitment to fulfilling these ambitions.

name: Ilhan KYUCHYUK
text: in writing. ‒ Unfortunately, EU economy will grow less than expected on the basis of the European economic spring forecast 2016, as GDP in the Eurozone is expected to increase by only 1.6%, reaching 1.8% by 2017. The slow economic growth highlights that the EU and some of its Member States continue to struggle with the implementation of sustainable reforms. Furthermore, the slow economic growth signals that EU economy lacks cohesion, productivity, competitiveness, sustainable investments and that it suffers from too high unemployment rates. In this regard, it is important to note that the European Semester process has a real potential to facilitate economic growth, to provide answers to existing social challenges and to ensure more competitiveness of the EU economy. However, the key to the success of the European Semester process are its priorities, which for 2016 are: supporting investment for innovation, growth and job creation, pursuing socially balanced structural reforms and encouraging responsible public finances. Therefore, the EU should work to meet 2016 priorities in order to facilitate economic growth and to kick start its economy.

name: Giovanni LA VIA
text: in writing.- The report underlines the need to improve the EU's overall capacity to create and maintain jobs.To this end, it becomes important to address the structural challenges in the areas of demography, the labor market and taxation, which must be integrated with efficient public spending, in particular in socially and environmentally sustainable investments.In order to be able to support structural reforms in line with common economic priorities, the use of the European Structural and Investment Funds must be promoted, to achieve the key priorities through measures that link the effectiveness of these Funds to sound economic governance.These initiatives, which I support, aim to relaunch investments within the EU, constituting a fundamental stimulus for growth, the creation of new jobs, and the fight against inequality and poverty.

name: Gilles LEBRETON
text: in writing.- I voted against this report because it denounces neither in form nor in substance the process of the European Semester which, under the guise of coordination, participates in the liberal straitjacket imposed by Brussels on national economies, with the results that weknows.

name: Marine LE PEN
text: in writing.- I voted against the report on the European Semester for the coordination of economic policies.The report does not denounce, neither in form nor in substance, the process of the European Semester which, under the guise of coordination, participates in the liberal straitjacket imposed by Brussels on national economies, with the results that we know.We must denounce ultra-liberalism in certain areas (internal market, competition) and the refusal to denounce Germany's attitude or the role of the euro in macroeconomic imbalances.

name: Philippe LOISEAU
text: in writing.- The European Semester is a process for coordinating the economic policies of EU Member States.It results in country-specific recommendations, rarely followed by states.The purpose of this report is to take stock of the implementation of the recommendations for 2016. The report is very descriptive, which proves the difficulty of Parliament in formulating a clear criticism while our approach is, on the contrary, transparent, both on theprinciple of the European Semester only on the recommendations in question.We do indeed want to denounce, among other things, ultra-liberalism in certain areas (savage competition), and conversely the hold of Germany and the euro over our economies and their roles in macroeconomic imbalances.So I voted against this file.

name: Javi LÓPEZ
text: written. - The economic recovery in Europe remains slow, fragile and above all, very uneven: growth is weak, unemployment rates continue to be very high in many countries and investments are at historic lows. Europe as a whole must strengthen the investment plan so that instead of a sum of parts, it is a true Union policy, and the countries with a trade surplus must invest more to balance their economies and improve domestic demand. Furthermore, we call on the Member States for effective measures to guarantee decent jobs with decent wages, adequate social protection and decent public pensions. We also need a fairer rather than serious taxation not only on middle and working income but also on capital income. And finally, we need a European Minimum Income Framework to lift the 120 million people who today live in the Union at risk of social exclusion out of poverty. Only in this way can we overcome this long and painful crisis in a fair and sustainable way. For all these reasons I have voted in favor of this report and I deeply regret that the rest of the groups on the left have not joined in these requests.

name: Juan Fernando LÓPEZ AGUILAR
text: written. - The economic recovery in Europe remains slow, fragile and above all, very uneven: growth is weak, unemployment rates continue to be very high in many countries and investments are at historic lows. Europe as a whole must strengthen the investment plan so that instead of a sum of parts, it is a true Union policy, and the countries with a trade surplus must invest more to balance their economies and improve domestic demand. Furthermore, we call on the Member States for effective measures to guarantee decent jobs with decent wages, adequate social protection and decent public pensions. We also need a fairer rather than serious taxation not only on middle and working income but also on capital income. And finally, we need a European Minimum Income Framework to lift the 120 million people who today live in the Union at risk of social exclusion out of poverty. Only in this way can we overcome this long and painful crisis in a fair and sustainable way. For all these reasons I have voted in favor of this report and I deeply regret that the rest of the groups on the left have not joined in these requests.

name: Paloma LÓPEZ BERMEJO
text: written.- I voted against this report because even though significant references have been made to the social problems that austerity policies are causing in the Member States of the European Union, it continues to bet on austerity as the only way, even legitimizing thepossible sanctions against Spain and Portugal that are under discussion.I totally reject the imposition of austerity policies, because they are a complete economic contradiction, which only increases poverty and inequalities.Likewise with the macro conditionality that, if applied in the Iberian Peninsula, can seriously impact, accelerating the destruction of our economy.The report is unable to propose an alternative, appealing for more austerity.This is what we are fighting against and consequently I have decided to vote against it.

name: Bernd LUCKE
text: written. - In its annual report on the Commission's country-specific recommendations in the context of the European Semester, the European Parliament identifies weak public demand and a deteriorating international environment as key challenges for the European Union's economic recovery. But this starts in the wrong place. It is much more important that the Member States carry out further structural reforms. The crisis-ridden southern European countries in particular must continue to improve their international competitiveness in order to recover economically. The report also calls for the completion of the banking union. However, this goes way too far. According to the Commission's plans, the third pillar of the banking union provides for a mutualisation of deposit insurance. However, it must not be the case that banks and savers in one country are jointly liable for a failed banking policy in another country. For these reasons I do not agree with the report.

name: Petr MACH
text: in writing.- I voted against.The report only states that the EU "is growing more slowly than expected".My group's amendments, which name the causes of the eurozone's economic difficulties, have not passed.I do not agree with the call for deeper coordination of tax policies.On the contrary, I am in favor of tax policy remaining fully within the competence of the Member States.

name: Ivana MALETIĆ
text: written. - From year to year we repeat the same and we all know that the prerequisites for growth: investment, structural reforms and smart fiscal consolidation that leaves room for innovation, research and development, thoughtful policies that encourage entrepreneurial projects and raise competitiveness. It is also stated all the time that specific recommendations are not being implemented and that more synergies are needed between European policies and instruments and national policies and budgets. To change this, we need more concrete examples of successful change and development projects in the Member States that we highlight and motivate all members to take similar steps, more benchmarks to monitor the success of coordination of EU national policies and objectives, and greater knowledge sharing. experience, not only between Member States, but also the use of successful examples outside the EU. I am pleased with the Commission's proposal and the introduction of a support program for the implementation of structural reforms. This is an important step in helping Member States answer the question of how to design and implement reforms. We need more practical instruments and incentives, but within the framework of existing regulations, which will build confidence and strengthen the political will and will to implement change in the Member States, so I supported this report.

name: Andrejs MAMIKINS
text: in writing. ‒ The Commission’s focus in its 2016 country-specific recommendations on the three main priorities to further strengthen economic growth: supporting investment for innovation, growth and job creation, pursuing socially balanced structural reforms and encouraging responsible public finances. I think that European semester is very useful instrument. On the example of Latvia we can see that many reforms started after recommendation from European Commission was received. The Commission should do more to ensure economic growth and necessary reforms in the EU member countries and also take into consideration specific of the countries.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: in writing.- I am voting against the report on the European Semester for economic policy coordination: implementation of the 2016 priorities, for the reasons I set out in detail in my speech at the European Parliament plenary session in Strasbourg on 25 October 2016, and because this reportis not complete and documented.

name: Dominique MARTIN
text: in writing.- I voted against this text.This text continues to provide the same ultra-liberal solutions to the ills of the European economy.Alongside the recommended structural reforms, there is a tightening of the EU, which suspends aid to countries in the South in a situation of excessive macroeconomic imbalances.Finally, resorting to mass immigration is recognized as beneficial in compensating for the demographic deficit of European countries, which we strongly oppose.

name: Gabriel MATO
text: written.- My support for the implementation of the priorities of the European Semester for the coordination of economic policies, which emphasizes the need to improve the Union's overall capacity to grow, create and maintain quality jobs and thus fight againsthigh unemployment rates.Another of the measures is committed to promoting inclusive education systems, which promote innovation and creativity and teach relevant skills for the labor market.We must also work on policies that promote sustainable development, including real attention to spending on research and development.

name: Georg MAYER
text: written.- Each member state of the European Union should be able to decide on its own budget.Interventions in the budgetary sovereignty of the member states are strictly to be rejected, and so is this report.

name: Valentinas MAZURONIS
text: in writing.- I supported the EP report reviewing the 2016Implementation of the priorities of the European Semester for Economic Policy Coordination.I welcome the fact that the Commission's country-specific recommendations focus on three key priorities for growth: investing in innovation, growth and jobs, and implementing structural reforms.However, I believe that the Commission should step up its efforts to support fiscal sustainability in line with the Stability and Growth Pact, as well as to take new effective measures to combat social inequality, exclusion and poverty.

name: Jean-Luc MÉLENCHON
text: in writing.- This report defends the idea that all of the economic problems facing the EU stem from the failure to implement specific recommendations per country, in other words failure to respect commitments to reduce the deficit.On the other hand, the report does not take the time to question the role of the ECB in monetary policy or the unrealistic pursuit of the absurd objectives of the Stability and Growth Pact.Despite some positive recommendations on the importance of public investment or access to a minimum income, the essential liberal mantras are recited during the report.In the end, the rapporteur is content to ask for "sustainable structural reforms" and "to remove obstacles to investment and the development of the internal market".I vote against this text.

name: Joëlle MÉLIN
text: in writing.- The European Semester is a process for coordinating the economic policies of EU Member States.It results in country-specific recommendations, rarely followed by states.The purpose of this report is to take stock of the implementation of the recommendations for 2016. The report is very descriptive, which proves the difficulty of Parliament in formulating a clear criticism while our approach is, on the contrary, transparent, both on theprinciple of the European Semester only on the recommendations in question.We would indeed like to denounce, among other things, ultra-liberalism in certain areas (savage competition) and, conversely, the hold of Germany and the euro over our economies and their roles in macroeconomic imbalances.So I voted against this file.

name: Nuno MELO
text: in writing.- The Commission's spring 2016 economic forecasts point to growth rates of 1.6% for the euro area and 1.8% for the EU in 2016. Europe is still faced with a major investment deficit,therefore it is necessary to increase domestic demand and correct macroeconomic imbalances, while increasing investment in the EU.The challenges facing the EU are linked to the deteriorating international situation, the inability to carry out structural reforms and the divergences in economic and social performance in different parts of the Union. It is necessary to increase growth, cohesion, productivity and competitiveness.The lack of sustainable investment and deficiencies in the completion of the single market prevent the EU from reaching its full growth potential.Hence my vote in favor.

name: Roberta METSOLA
text: in writing. ‒ I chose to support this resolution which welcomes the Commission’s efforts to streamline the European Semester by focusing on the key policy areas. In the current economic climate it is essential that the Union continues to support innovation and job creation whilst not pursuing policies that may breach the principle of subsidiarity in the areas of tax policy.

name: Louis MICHEL
text: in writing. - In a common space, such as the European Union, it is essential that the Member States coordinate their economic and budgetary policies, in order to guarantee a certain cohesion. The annual stage of the European Semester is essential at this level if we are to relaunch growth and create jobs. I would like to stress once again the need to strengthen the major European projects underway, such as the Banking Union or the Capital Union, and even the Energy Union. In any case, what is striking is the dire lack of investment. The European Union has a major role to play here, in particular via the Juncker Plan which must be strengthened if we want to boost the European economy. But we also need to look for other alternatives that complement it in order to create a dynamic framework that allows investors to feed the European economy. As for the budgetary situations of the Member States, I call once again on the Commission to guarantee a certain flexibility in order to allow the Member States to invest both in the material and in the immaterial if this expenditure guarantees greater growth .

name: Marlene MIZZI
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted in favour of the report because the EU and the Member States need to better implement the revised economic policy mix, which aims at increasing investment linked to EU2020 policies objectives including quality employment, education, innovation and growth enhancing policies.

name: Csaba MOLNÁR
text: in writing. - The report of the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs outlines the main economic developments expected for 2016: low growth, investment deficit, high unemployment, especially among young people, negative inflation. It notes that the goal of reducing poverty in the EU set out in the Europe 2020 strategy, which is part of the EU's anti-poverty program for the first time, will not be achieved. The overall conclusion is that the EU's growth capacity needs to be improved, allowing quality jobs to be created and maintained. It takes action against excessive tax burdens on work. It attaches particular importance to inclusive education systems that enable the acquisition of skills that meet the needs of the labor market, in particular vocational training, and emphasizes the importance of research and development and the renewal of education systems and vocational training, especially lifelong learning. It covers closing the innovation gap between the EU and other economies, with a focus on research and development spending. It states that public and private funding to support research and higher education institutions is essential for a more competitive European economy, and that the weakness or lack of such infrastructure puts some countries at a significant disadvantage. I voted in favor of the draft resolution.

name: Bernard MONOT
text: in writing. - Despite an overhaul of the format last year (recommendations further upstream of national finance laws, more precise and fewer), the spirit of the European Semester remains the same. It is about imposing on the member states the famous structural reforms, i.e. the liberalization of the markets, by incentive and, ultimately, by pressure. In this regard, it will be recalled that the EU initiated, for the first time, a procedure for suspending structural funds against Spain and Portugal for failure to comply with this type of recommendation. The report accumulates a large amount of commonplace banalities about macroeconomic uncertainties, the need for targeted investments, job creation, etc. We note some positive elements, in particular on issues of inequalities or some incidents in favor of State competence (for example in social matters). The whole is very often bland and descriptive. Our approach is much more critical, both on the principle of the Semester and its supranational logic, and on the content of the recommendations. We must denounce hard-line liberalism in certain areas (internal market, competition), Germany’s attitude in managing its surplus, or the role of the euro in macroeconomic imbalances. Unfavorable vote.

name: Cláudia MONTEIRO DE AGUIAR
text: in writing. - in view of the spring 2016 European economic forecasts, the growth of the EU economy is expected to be less than expected, as GDP growth in the euro area is expected to be only 1.6%, with growth expected to reach 1, 8% in 2017. I endorse the rapporteur's position regarding the importance of an integrated and competitive single market that works correctly for the recovery of the European economy after the financial crisis. The single market is the backbone of the EU economy. I advocate an inclusive single market, with strengthened governance that provides better regulation and fosters competition. In this way, we improved growth, cohesion, employment and competitiveness, preserving the confidence of the business sector and consumers. I note that the European Semester places a special focus on employment and social performance. I believe it is important for the EU to call on Member States to take urgent measures to guarantee decent work and wages that allow them to live in dignity, access to adequate minimum income and social protection and quality public services, advocating the development and the creation of a truly sustainable social security system.

name: Sophie MONTEL
text: in writing.- The European Semester is a tool of oppression of the peoples, who are thus forced to submit to austerity policies which have already proved their failure.I am obviously voting against this report.

name: Nadine MORANO
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of this report on the implementation of the priorities for 2016 of the European Semester.This report first makes the observation that Europe is still today plagued by unemployment and a high deficit, which is hurting investment in particular.This is why it is necessary to act by allowing growth to return in a more sustainable way to the European continent.This report therefore poses avenues to be explored, such as tax coordination within the European Union, which will in particular facilitate the financing of SMEs.

name: Alessia Maria MOSCA
text: in writing. - The report on the European Semester for Economic Policy Coordination is the European Parliament's contribution to the second phase of the 2016 Semester and analyzes the implementation of the country-specific recommendations. This text is to be welcomed as it is balanced and focuses on the need to increase investment and promote structural reforms that also emphasize the social dimension. In fact, in particular, the report emphasizes improving the European Union's capacity to create growth, convergence and quality jobs, as well as to combat poverty, inequality and social exclusion. Furthermore, the text, incorporating suggestions from the parliamentary commission on employment and social affairs, calls for the inclusion of a social imbalance procedure within the coordination of economic policies, and proposes the introduction of a European income framework. minimum. Through this report, the European Parliament voices the need for a better implementation, both by the Union and by the member states, of the economic policy mix so as to expand investments aimed at achieving the objectives set by the EU2020 Strategy. .

name: Victor NEGRESCU
text: in writing. ‒ I voted for this report on the European Semester for economic policy coordination that calls for the implementation of sustainable reforms to improve growth, cohesion, productivity and competitiveness following the slow growth rates of only 1.8% for the EU in 2016.

name: Dan NICA
text: signed up. - I voted in favor of the European Parliament resolution on the European Semester for Economic Policy Coordination: Implementing Priorities for 2016. In the Commission's 2016 country-specific recommendations, it paid particular attention to the three priorities aimed at further strengthening economic growth: supporting investment in innovation, development and job creation, carrying out socially balanced structural reforms and encouraging the responsible management of public finances. Numerous country-specific recommendations support a functioning and integrated single market, including the creation of financing and investment opportunities that foster the development of enterprises and, in particular, SMEs, contributing to job creation and the proper functioning of e-government. , public procurement and mutual recognition, including mutual recognition of qualifications. However, more efforts are needed from the Commission to support the sustainability of public finances under the Stability and Growth Pact, making full use of its flexibility clauses. We call on the Commission to give priority to measures that reduce obstacles to larger investment flows, which are hampered at EU level by the lack of clarity on the strategies to be followed, in particular in the following areas: energy, transport, communications and the digital economy.

name: Norica NICOLAI
text: in writing. ‒ I am in support of the report as it addresses the challenges facing Europe in the context of the global economic slowdown. Firstly, it recognises the importance of coherence between European Union’s framework on economic governance and policy instruments to strengthen cohesion among Member States in the EU by reducing regional development disparities of the Member States. Secondly, the report stresses that the lack of sustainable investment and the shortcomings in completing the single market are depriving the EU of its full growth potential which is imperative given the deteriorating international environment, the failure to implement sustainable reforms and the divergences in the economic and social performance in different parts of the Union. Thirdly, I am in full support of the report’s confirmation and welcome of the agreement of the Paris climate conference (COP21) in December 2015 and its call on the Member States and the Commission to implement it.

name: Franz OBERMAYR
text: written.- I spoke out against this report because every state should be responsible for its own finances, and therefore there must not be any direct financial aid or loans of any kind, as is fundamentally provided for in the EU treaties.

name: Urmas PAET
text: in writing.- I abstained.The European Semester sets very general objectives that have no direct added value for Member States.There is also no ex-post evaluation of the framework, which undermines the European Parliament's supervisory role, so the semester cycle does not provide sufficiently precise guidelines and specific actions and recommendations to Member States are lacking.

name: Margot PARKER
text: in writing. ‒ Whilst the report identifies problems faced by the eurozone, it does not include the obvious solution (namely a plan to disentangle Member States from the straight-jacket of the single currency), and describes free movement of people as ‘fundamental’.  Accordingly, UKIP voted against.

name: Aldo PATRICIELLO
text: in writing.- While taking into consideration the aspects presented in the documents relating to the resolution on the European Semester for economic policy coordination and admitting that I will follow with interest the development of this topic, in particular by comparing the growth of the EU economy with the economic forecasts ofspring 2016, carefully evaluating the points object of the objection, I believe that they do not fully correspond to my idea and therefore I do not feel like supporting it and I vote negatively.

name: Marijana PETIR
text: written. - Aware only of all the complexities of the situation in which the European Union finds itself today, which are strongly expressed in this area as well. The current account surplus continues to grow, but we still face a large deficit of investments despite theoretically favorable conditions for private and public investments supported by often extremely low interest rates on government borrowing. Member States, especially those on the periphery of the Union, are still struggling to cope with high unemployment, in which unemployed young people have a worryingly high share. I support this Resolution on the European Semester for economic policy alignment: the implementation of priorities for 2016, which clearly sets out a number of challenges facing Europe in the field of investment in the light of the slowdown in global economic growth this year, policy responses and concrete conclusions. I welcome the Commission's encouraging approach of limiting the number of recommendations and focusing the semester on key macroeconomic and social priorities in setting policy goals for the next 18 months, as well as the improved policy mix we requested under the 2016 Parliamentary Annual Growth Survey Resolution.

name: Florian PHILIPPOT
text: in writing.- The whole of this text is very often bland and descriptive, proof of the difficulty of the Parliament to formulate clear criticisms, as for example in the address of the German trade surplus.I am much more critical, both on the principle of the Semester and its supranational logic, and on the content of the recommendations.We must denounce end-to-end liberalism in certain areas (internal market, competition) and the refusal to denounce Germany's attitude or the role of the euro in macroeconomic imbalances.I therefore vote against this text.

name: Pina PICIERNO
text: in writing. - This report, which I wanted to support, highlights the urgent need to revive economic growth in Europe through investment, to implement sustainable structural reforms and to reduce the economic and social divergences that have arisen in various areas of the EU . An increase in the level of investment is indispensable to stimulate the growth, productivity and competitiveness of businesses and to reduce the economic and social gap as a result. I am happy to see that the emphasis is on the need for sustainable growth, rather than on reforms aimed at further precarious the labor market. Excessive economic inequalities, as recently also noted by the OECD and the IMF, are harmful not only for social cohesion, but also for growth itself. In an economic situation such as the one we are experiencing, with liquidity and current account surpluses, with weak demand and private investment, monetary policy alone is no longer sufficient to boost growth without an adequate level of investment. The fiscal policy of the States and the investment policy of the EU should therefore, in a calibrated and complementary way, make up for the shortcomings and foster a climate of confidence that attracts additional resources from private investments.

name: Tonino PICULA
text: written. - The Commission's forecast shows expected growth rates of 1.6% in the euro area and 1.8% for the EU in 2016, which means that the EU economy will grow less than expected. The long economic crisis has highlighted the need to facilitate investment precisely in areas such as education, innovation, research and development. I support the Commission's recommendations for the three Member States to exit the excessive deficit procedure (EDP) as well as a large number of CSRs that support a functional and integrated single market. Unlike last year’s report, in this report the emphasis is on socially balanced structural reforms and increased investment which is of course a positive change. This report clearly focuses on the need to increase investment in the EU to achieve growth, to create and maintain quality jobs, and to combat high levels of unemployment, poverty and inequality. The report also proposes the introduction of a social imbalance process in the design of CSRs and calls on the Commission to fulfill its promise to introduce a European minimum income to cover basic living expenses.

name: João PIMENTA LOPES
text: in writing. - For us, the European Semester represents the main obstacle to our development. It was the demands of the euro, imposed through the European Semester, that were the basis of an austerity policy that represented for Portugal a decades-long regression in terms of investment, income and social rights. It was the rules of the euro that underpinned a debt that became unsustainable and prevented policies to relaunch our economy with effective support for key productive sectors. It is the European Semester that underlies an intolerable blackmailing operation around our budgetary policy. The report speaks highly of the recommendations by countries. But these are very clear, require more flexibility in labor laws, more privatization in transport and freeze on wages. There is no economic rationale in the European Semester. The European Semester, with the false purpose of supporting countries in their fiscal policy, represents rather an instrument designed to impose a neoliberal agenda at the service of capital and that the peoples will, sooner or later, reject.

name: Miroslav POCHE
text: in writing. ‒ The European Semester is the EU’s annual cycle of economic policy guidance and surveillance. I am pleased to share the European Parliament’s input into the second phase of the Semester 2016 focusing on the country specific implementation of priorities agreed within the Annual Growth Survey 2016 report in February. Last year’s heavily right-wing report was replaced by socially balanced structural reforms and increased investment as supported by the S&D Group. Thankfully, the report now clearly focuses on the need to increase investment in the EU in order to create more growth, convergence, quality jobs and fight poverty and inequality. Also following the inclusion of the opinion from the Employment and Social Affairs Committee, the report now calls for a social imbalance procedure to be introduced into the economic coordination and a European minimum income framework to fight social exclusion in the EU. I urge that the EU and the Member States better implement the revised economic policy mix which aims at increasing investment linked to EU2020 policies objectives including quality employment, education, innovation and growth enhancing policies.

name: Franck PROUST
text: in writing.- I voted for this report because it is part of a process of harmonizing the economic policies of the Member States of the European Union.The Union can only be strong if the states that make it up implement common means to achieve common ambitions at European level: growth, employment, security mainly.In economic matters, the European Semester was created so that the budgetary and structural policies of each Member State are examined at European level and that the European Commission can make recommendations for the following 12 to 18 months.It is not a question of supranational control, but of indications that take into account the objectives of the European Union (Europe 2020 strategy) so that these can be part of national public action.

name: Paulo RANGEL
text: in writing. - Europe is currently faced with a worrying investment deficit, making it necessary to increase domestic demand and correct macroeconomic imbalances, while increasing investment in the European Union. In this context, the challenge of combating youth and long-term unemployment should be a priority, despite the evolution of the political situation, namely the result of the United Kingdom referendum, relations with Russia and uncertainties regarding the evolution of the world economy. . I support the importance given by the Commission, in the 2016 country-specific recommendations, to the three main priorities for strengthening economic growth: supporting investment for innovation, growth and job creation, pursuing sustainable and balanced structural reforms view and promote responsible public finances. I highlight the importance of coherence between the cohesion policy instruments and the broader economic governance framework in order to support the efforts needed to ensure compliance with the rules of the European Semester. Therefore, I support this report.

name: Evelyn REGNER
text: written. - I voted in favor of the European Parliament's resolution on the European semester for economic policy coordination because I am convinced that the Sant report is a step in the right direction. 21.2 million people in the EU Member States are unemployed. We are now in the ninth year of the crisis. So far, the response of the relevant institutions to the crisis has been that undesirable developments can only be corrected by lowering wages and reducing social benefits. Economic impulses through public investments had no place here. The crisis worsened. The focus on investments in the European Semester must create a departure from the neoliberal wrong path. Only with investments in health, social infrastructure, energy and environmental projects and the digital sector can the social effects of the crisis be cushioned. We will only create jobs by investing in the future. We will only overcome the crisis with the implementation of a social Europe.

name: Julia REID
text: in writing. ‒ Whilst the report identifies problems faced by the eurozone, it does not include the obvious solution (namely a plan to disentangle Member States from the straight-jacket of the single currency), and describes free movement of people as ‘fundamental’.  Accordingly, UKIP voted against.

name: Frédérique RIES
text: in writing. - Supported by 423 MEPs against 210, with 48 abstentions, the resolution voted on this afternoon sets the European Union's economic priorities for 2017. Innovation, growth and job creation are at the heart of Parliament’s concerns. Still timid investments, lower growth forecasts in Europe, and a high unemployment rate among young people convinced MEPs that Europe should do more to stimulate investment by facilitating access for small businesses. and medium-sized enterprises to private funding and European aid programs, which remain underutilized. The energy, transport, telecommunications and digital sectors are particularly highlighted. MEPs also called for reducing the tax burden on work so as not to discourage return to work - instead preferring environmental taxes. This vote marks the start of the European Semester, an annual consultation process to coordinate the budgetary, economic and employment policies of EU countries. The ball is now in the court of the Member States, who must develop national action programs to implement these European guidelines. The Commission will then address individual recommendations to each country on this basis.

name: Inma RODRÍGUEZ-PIÑERO
text: written. - The economic recovery in Europe remains slow, fragile and above all, very uneven: growth is weak, unemployment rates continue to be very high in many countries and investments are at historic lows. Europe as a whole must strengthen the investment plan so that instead of a sum of parts, it is a true Union policy, and the countries with a trade surplus must invest more to balance their economies and improve domestic demand. Furthermore, we call on the Member States for effective measures to guarantee decent jobs with decent wages, adequate social protection and decent public pensions. We also need a fairer rather than serious taxation not only on middle and working income but also on capital income. And finally, we need a European Minimum Income Framework to lift the 120 million people who today live in the Union at risk of social exclusion out of poverty. Only in this way can we overcome this long and painful crisis in a fair and sustainable way. For all these reasons I have voted in favor of this report and I deeply regret that the rest of the groups on the left have not joined in these requests.

name: Claude ROLIN
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of this draft resolution of the European Parliament concerning the implementation of the 2016 priorities of the European Semester for the coordination of economic policies.This resolution pleads the overall need for the European Union to generate growth, create quality jobs, fight against youth unemployment or invest in education and training.Moreover, this resolution rightly underlines that without sustainable investments and structural reforms, monetary policy alone will not be able to stimulate growth.

name: Fernando RUAS
text: in writing. - In the Opinion that I made as rapporteur of the Committee on Regional Development for this Resolution (which I voted in favor of), in addition to the important positions on Regional Policy voted (and enriched by amendments by my peers) at the Headquarters of the Commission, I found it important to underline the decisions of the European Commission (EC) and the Council in canceling the fines to Portugal and Spain following the enormous effort of reforms and fiscal consolidation carried out in recent years in an adverse economic environment and taking into account the commitment of the two States to comply with the rules of the Pact of Stability and Growth. With regard to the Funds Suspension procedure, which is in the structured dialogue phase between the EC and the European Parliament, it does not seem to me to make sense to apply a suspension of Funds to the two countries (even referring to "commitments" and not " payments ”), after the prior cancellation of the fine! The arguments that were true for the cancellation, remain true for the suspension! In addition, no one would understand how the «Central Government» was not penalized with fines and then the Regions, Municipalities, Companies, the Academy or Associations would be penalized with a suspension of the Structural and Investment Funds. It would be an incomprehensible irrationality. It seems obvious to me!

name: Tokia SAÏFI
text: in writing. - I voted in favor of this report which takes stock of the implementation of the priorities issued by the European Commission within the framework of the European Semester for the year 2016. This report underlines the fragility of the economic recovery in 2016 in within the Member States, in particular by recalling the worrying unemployment figures, in particular that of young people. This text recognizes the importance of consistency between the instruments of cohesion policy and the economic governance framework, with a view to supporting the recovery efforts necessary to ensure compliance with the rules imposed by the European Semester. The main objective of the coordination of economic policies is to ensure sustainable economic growth in the Union. Thus, while it is crucial that all Member States take fiscal consolidation measures in order to ensure the sustainability and viability of their economic models, it is essential that these be accompanied by measures to encourage investment. , the reduction of inequalities as well as employment.

name: Lola SÁNCHEZ CALDENTEY
text: written.- I voted against this report, because I am opposed to the European Semester mechanism as a whole.The aim of the European Semester is to subject government budgets to an audit by the European Commission, which ensures the fulfillment of certain macroeconomic objectives and the implementation of the so-called structural reforms.The facts show that the effect of the austerity measures has been pro-cyclical, that is, they have worsened the economic crisis.Although the work of the shadow rapporteur of the GUE / NGL has managed to include positive references to public investment, I still do not share the diagnosis or the solution.

name: Maria Lidia SENRA RODRÍGUEZ
text: written.- I voted against this report because even though significant references have been made to the social problems that austerity policies are causing in the Member States of the European Union, it continues to bet on austerity as the only way, even legitimizing thepossible sanctions against Spain and Portugal that are under discussion.I totally reject the imposition of austerity policies, because they are a complete economic contradiction, which only increases poverty and inequalities.Likewise, with the macro conditionality that, if applied in the Iberian Peninsula, can seriously impact, accelerating the destruction of our economy.The report is unable to propose an alternative, appealing for more austerity.This is what we are fighting against and consequently I have decided to vote against it.

name: Monika SMOLKOVÁ
text: in writing. - The report assessing the economic situation in the EU suggests that European economies still face many challenges. Unemployment remains one of the main problems across Europe. The overall state of the EU's economies is marked by a deteriorating international environment, the lack of sustainable reforms, but also differences in economic and social performance in different parts of the Union. I supported the draft report, but I would like to emphasize that I am concerned about the long-term unemployment, especially of young people. Member States should therefore make greater efforts to stimulate long-term sustainable growth and the creation of quality jobs. In many countries, governments are exposed to a cumulative lack of investment, but nevertheless the cohesion policy operational programs for the current period have been adopted late. Cohesion policy through the Structural and Investment Funds is still one of the largest sources of investment supporting the Union's social, economic and territorial cohesion. It should therefore be implemented as a matter of priority and in coordination with similar initiatives such as the European Fund for Strategic Investments. The combination of these funds represents an opportunity for the regions to use public and private resources at the same time. Cohesion policy is a legitimate instrument that has historically been enshrined in the Treaties as a key instrument of solidarity, and it is therefore necessary to maintain its original role in reducing regional disparities in the future.

name: Igor ŠOLTES
text: in writing. - The main focus of the report is on investment and highlights the need to increase investment in education, human capital, innovation and research, which could be more focused on European Union policy. The report mentions avoiding the so-called bottom-up race over wages and employment standards. This seems to me to be the key to the European Union's future policy, as in the event of a different strategy, jobs based on minimum wages and precarious conditions will emerge, which can certainly not lead to inclusive and fair growth. As the report mentions, the European Union will not be able to achieve its poverty reduction targets by 2020. The report focuses mainly on structural reforms, which alone cannot provide a recipe for growth, as they must include the social policies that accompany them. Due to the inclusion of important points in the field of social policy at the level of the European Union and the important mention of increasing investment in the fields of education and human capital, I supported the report.

name: Joachim STARBATTY
text: written. - In its annual report on the Commission's country-specific recommendations in the context of the European Semester, the European Parliament identifies weak public demand and a deteriorating international environment as key challenges for the European Union's economic recovery. But this starts in the wrong place. It is much more important that the Member States carry out further structural reforms. The crisis-ridden southern European countries in particular must continue to improve their international competitiveness in order to recover economically. The report also calls for the completion of the banking union. However, this goes way too far. According to the Commission's plans, the third pillar of the banking union provides for a mutualisation of deposit insurance. However, it must not be the case that banks and savers in one country are jointly liable for a failed banking policy in another country. For these reasons I do not agree with the report.

name: Ivan ŠTEFANEC
text: in writing.- I welcome the European Commission's efforts to channel surplus public finances into large investment and infrastructure projects.We are also creating additional fundraising opportunities for small and medium-sized businesses.However, we are still unable to create enough new jobs, especially for young people.In order to improve the functioning of the European Union's economy and the quality of life of our citizens and to facilitate the development of businesses, we must also continuously break down the barriers that still exist in our internal market.

name: Beatrix von STORCH
text: written.- I did not agree to the resolution of the EU Parliament on the “European semester for the coordination of economic policy: implementing the priorities for 2016”.The European Semester is an expression of the misguided view that the fiscal and economic policies of the Member States must be coordinated and planned at EU level.Europe was a laboratory in which nations experimented what the best economic and financial policies could look like.The EU sees Europe as a petri dish in which it grows its favorite culture without taking into account the cultural and political diversity of Europe.I also see the European Semester as the nucleus of an EU economic government hoped for and conceived by the EU chauvinists.I refuse.

name: Dubravka ŠUICA
text: written.- Slow economic growth and investment deficit are currently visible in the European Union.Inflation is below zero, unemployment is rising, and the number of people at risk of poverty and social exclusion has increased.The international situation, which is particularly shaped by Brexit, relations with Russia and mass migration, affects investments in the European Union.In order to increase the EU's economic growth, productivity and competitiveness in the market, it is necessary to invest in transport, telecommunications, digitalisation, environmental protection, education and research and innovation.It is also important to implement cohesion policy, to provide recovery aid to certain Member States and to bring the EU closer to its citizens.I support the report on the European Semester for economic policy coordination and implementation of priorities for 2016, as it supports the functioning of the single market, investment in the European Union and measures for economic growth and recovery.

name: Patricija ŠULIN
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of the report on the European Semester for economic policy coordination: implementing the priorities for 2016. Despite the introduction of the Strategic Investment Fund, Europe still faces a lack of investment, so investment in the EU needs to be further increased.I agree that the EU's challenges are related to the deterioration of the international environment, the failure to implement sustainable reforms and the differences in economic and social performance in different parts of the Union.By supporting investment in innovation, growth and job creation, the European Commission is a step in the right direction, but could do more in the area of fiscal sustainability in line with the Stability and Growth Pact, as the report rightly points out.

name: Eleftherios SYNADINOS
text: in writing.- The solution to the problems caused by the European Union in the economies of the Member States of the region can not be "above the European Union".The Union's economic and monetary policy, combined with the immigration crisis that has flattened the peoples of the South, have failed and must be abandoned immediately.Continuation of the same failed policies will further inflate the problems faced by countries such as Cyprus and Greece.

name: Tibor SZANYI
text: in writing. - I voted in favor of the report on the European Semester for economic policy coordination. I welcome the fact that the report repeatedly refers to the importance of solidarity within the Union and recalls that socially responsible reforms must be based on solidarity, integration, social justice and the fair distribution of goods. I agree with the report's policy call to avoid imposing excessive tax burdens on work, as excessive taxes discourage the return of the inactive, unemployed, second earners and low-income earners to the labor market. Like the report, I welcome the fact that the European Semester is now more focused on employment and social performance, all the more so as the European Semester process should contribute to addressing existing and emerging societal challenges, thus ensuring a more efficient economy. I fully support the report's call on the Member States to take urgent action to ensure a decent income for decent work and people to have access to an adequate minimum income and social protection. It would also be a useful step for the Commission to include social impact assessments in the main structural reforms advocated by the CSRs, in particular to better understand the impact on job creation and economic growth.

name: Adam SZEJNFELD
text: in writing. - The European Semester, i.e. the procedure during which the economic and budgetary policy in the European Union is coordinated, is also a great opportunity to see how individual EU countries implement reforms aimed at building a well-functioning and integrated European single market. In my opinion on the report assessing the implementation of this year's priorities under the European Semester, the Committee on the Internal Market and Consumer Protection strongly emphasized that many Member States are delaying or not implementing EU directives and regulations fully. Extensive support for SMEs and start-ups, combating excessive administrative burdens, full implementation and application of the Services Directive, recognition of professional qualifications and ensuring access to regulated professions, and finally building a digital single market are examples of areas that both the European Commission and individual Member States should be given priority. Otherwise, we will not be able to unlock the full potential of the European single market, and this is, after all, an opportunity for economic growth and job creation that Europe so badly needs.

name: Marc TARABELLA
text: in writing.- I voted positively.I am also concerned that the Union's economic growth will be lower than the European economic forecast for spring 2016, given that the euro area's GDP is only expected to grow by 1.6% and reach 1.8% in2017. The challenges facing the Union are linked to the deterioration of the international context, the lack of implementation of lasting reforms and the discrepancies between the economic and social results obtained in the different parts of the Union.We must not forget the need to boost growth, cohesion, productivity and competitiveness.We cannot deny either the absence of sustainable investments and the shortcomings observed in the completion of the internal market which deprive the Union of its full growth potential.

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against this report as key ALDE points such as a reference to the importance that wages should be in line with productivity, that measures should be taken to improve the business environment to incentivise investment, that a fully integrated EU labour market should be created, or that CSRs should become binding, have been rejected in the vote in committee. Moreover, there is a reference to the COM Communication advocating excessive flexibility in the SGP, which the Group has not supported in the past.

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: written.- This report analyzes on its own initiative the European Semester as part of the annual cycle of the European Union related to economic governance and supervision policy.Namely, in the first quarter of the year, the Commission begins a detailed analysis of the budget plans of individual Member States, including an analysis of macroeconomic and structural reforms.On this analysis, the Commission bases the publication of Specific Recommendations for each Member State individually - in May each year.The report is Parliament's response to the Commission's publication.I voted against because I believe that the report's focus has gone in the wrong direction - instead of being based on the importance of implementing structural reforms in individual Member States of the Union, the report identified weak public demand and a deteriorating international environment as key challenges facing Europe.towards economic recovery.

name: Romana TOMC
text: in writing. - I supported the motion for a resolution on the European Semester for economic policy coordination: implementation of priorities for 2016. EU economic growth is lower than expected on the basis of the 2016 spring economic forecast for Europe, as euro area GDP is projected to increase by only 1.6%. The current account surpluses point to the need to stimulate demand and investment, especially in the long term, in order to meet future challenges in the areas of transport and communications, the digital economy, education, innovation and research, climate change, energy, the environment and aging. Further steps are needed to increase financing opportunities, especially for SMEs, and to reduce non-performing loans in the euro area in line with EU law, in order to improve banks 'balance sheets and thus increase banks' ability to lend to the real sector. Monetary policy must be accompanied by appropriate fiscal policies to increase growth in the EU, in accordance with the rules of the Stability and Growth Pact, including flexibility provisions.

name: Estefanía TORRES MARTÍNEZ
text: written.- I voted against this report, because I am opposed to the European Semester mechanism as a whole.The aim of the European Semester is to subject the governments' budgets to an audit by the European Commission, which ensures compliance with certain macroeconomic objectives and the implementation of the so-called structural reforms.The facts show that the effect of the austerity measures has been pro-cyclical, that is, they have worsened the economic crisis.Although the work of the shadow rapporteur of the GUE / NGL has managed to include positive references to public investment, I still do not share the diagnosis or the solution.

name: Ulrike TREBESIUS
text: written. - In its annual report on the Commission's country-specific recommendations in the context of the European Semester, the European Parliament identifies weak public demand and a deteriorating international environment as key challenges for the European Union's economic recovery. But this starts in the wrong place. It is much more important that the Member States carry out further structural reforms. The crisis-ridden southern European countries in particular must continue to improve their international competitiveness in order to recover economically. The report also calls for the completion of the banking union. However, this goes way too far. According to the Commission's plans, the third pillar of the banking union provides for a mutualisation of deposit insurance. However, it must not be the case that banks and savers in one country are jointly liable for a failed banking policy in another country. For these reasons I do not agree with the report.

name: Kazimierz Michał UJAZDOWSKI
text: in writing. - The analyzed annual report is the European Parliament's response to the country-specific recommendations published by the European Commission in May 2016. Documents of both institutions constitute the so-called the European Semester, the annual cycle of guidelines on the economic policy and surveillance of the European Union. To prepare the recommendations, the Commission analyzed the fiscal, macroeconomic and structural reform plans of the individual Member States. Given the importance of this procedure, I must stress that I do not agree with some points in Parliament's report, including a call for the end of the banking union or the territorial adjustment of projects from the European Fund for Strategic Investments (EFSI). I believe that the report should focus more on the importance of the Member States carrying out major structural reforms, which is why I voted against.

name: István UJHELYI
text: in writing.- The European Union's economy will grow at a slower pace than expected, according to the European Economic Forecast for Spring 2016, as GDP in the euro area is expected to grow by only 1.6% and reach 1.8% by 2017., which is a smaller increase than previously estimated.In the European Union, the challenges relate to the deteriorating international environment, the failure to implement sustainable reforms and the disparities in economic and social performance in different parts of the Union.I voted in favor of the report.

name: Miguel URBÁN CRESPO
text: written.- I voted against this report, because I am opposed to the European Semester mechanism as a whole.The aim of the European Semester is to subject the governments' budgets to an audit by the European Commission, which ensures compliance with certain macroeconomic objectives and the implementation of the so-called structural reforms.The facts show that the effect of the austerity measures has been pro-cyclical, that is, they have worsened the economic crisis.Although the work of the shadow rapporteur of the GUE / NGL has managed to include positive references to public investment, I still do not share the diagnosis or the solution.

name: Ernest URTASUN
text: written.- I voted in favor of this report, for which I have been shadow rapporteur, as it introduces interesting elements in the framework of the semester process, calling for increased investment and overcoming austerity policies and structural reforms aimed at internal devaluation.

name: Ivo VAJGL
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the Report on the European Semester for economic policy coordination: implementation of 2016 priorities. Europe still faces a major investment deficit, and the need is to increase internal demand and correct macroeconomic imbalances, while further increasing investment in the EU. Unemployment in general remains one of the main challenges that Member States are facing. The report notes with concern that the EU economy will grow less than expected on the basis of the European economic spring forecast 2016, as GDP in the eurozone is expected to increase by only 1.6%, reaching 1.8% by 2017. Moreover, it stresses that the challenges in the EU are linked to the deteriorating international environment, the failure to implement sustainable reforms and the divergences in the economic and social performance in different parts of the Union. I voted in favour because I believe that further measures are needed to increase financing opportunities, notably for SMEs, and to reduce non-performing loans (NPLs), in the euro area and in conformity with EU legislation, in order to make bank balance sheets sounder and thereby increase the ability of banks to lend to the real economy.

name: Marco VALLI
text: in writing. - I voted against this unacceptable resolution of the Parliament which welcomes the work done so far by the Commission in the context of the European Semester on country-specific recommendations, completely ignoring the harmful and counterproductive impacts of its economic recipes and the failure of the current coordination mechanism of national tax policies. Like the previous recommendations, those for 2016 are also inspired by a suicidal economic strategy based on the usual neoliberal mantra that still calls for rigor, structural reforms, liberalizations and private investments, but this parliamentary resolution does not seem to feel the need for a real change of route. Once again, Parliament is giving up an important opportunity to question the sustainability of the euro and its role in preventing competitiveness recoveries between countries, to point the finger at the arbitrary application of the rules by the Commission , harsh and inflexible with weak countries and indulgent with the strong, and deplore their inertia towards the excessive German surplus, responsible for instability and imbalances throughout Europe, as well as to highlight the negative link between the absence of public investment and absurd constraints budget. These fundamentally important issues are unfortunately deliberately silenced in the resolution, in order to support and religiously defend the construction of the economic and monetary union and its indispensable governance mechanisms.

name: Ángela VALLINA
text: written.- I voted against this report because even though significant references have been made to the social problems that austerity policies are causing in the Member States of the European Union, it continues to bet on austerity as the only way, even legitimizing thepossible sanctions against Spain and Portugal that are under discussion.I totally reject the imposition of austerity policies, because they are a complete economic contradiction, which only increases poverty and inequalities.Likewise, with the macro conditionality that, if applied in the Iberian Peninsula, can seriously impact, accelerating the destruction of our economy.The report is unable to propose an alternative, appealing for more austerity.This is what we are fighting against and consequently I have decided to vote against it.

name: Hilde VAUTMANS
text: written.- I voted in favor of this report because I am concerned that the EU economy will grow less than expected on the basis of the 2016 European spring economic forecast, as GDP in the euro area is projected to grow by only 1.6% before 2017to arrive at 1.8%.The long economic crisis in Europe has made it clear that there is a great need for investment in, for example, education, innovation and research & amp;development, and that the EU's competitiveness must be enhanced through sustainable structural reforms.There is a need for a better environment for jobs, business (especially SMEs) and investment.

name: Paavo VÄYRYNEN
text: written.- In today's report on the European Semester for Economic Policy: Implementing the 2016 Priorities, I opposed the adoption of the report.I supported some of the amendments, which emphasized the Member States' own power to decide on economic policy and, if they so wished, to leave the euro area.However, these proposals did not receive the support of the majority, so I finally voted against this weak report as a whole.

name: Marie-Christine VERGIAT
text: in writing. - This report makes a number of observations that I share: the need to increase domestic demand on European markets, the urgent need to take up the challenge posed by structural unemployment and in particular youth unemployment, the need for better use of European funds to correct to a greater extent macroeconomic imbalances, the requirement for long-term investments in education, innovation and research and development. He further asserts that under current conditions "the goal of poverty reduction cannot be achieved." This should have led our institution to question the logic of flexibilization of the labor market and all-out liberalization which underlies the injunctions made to the Member States within the framework of the European Semester. Yet it is not. The Stability and Growth Pact remains the keystone of all the proposals in this text. Recommendations for "labor tax relief", which have been shown to be ineffective, are lauded. The full transposition of the liberalizations contained in the "services" directive is called for. So I voted against it.

name: Miguel VIEGAS
text: in writing. - For us, the European Semester represents the main obstacle to our development. It was the demands of the euro, imposed through the European Semester, that were the basis for an austerity policy that represented a regression of decades in terms of investment, income and social rights for Portugal. It was the rules of the euro that were the basis of a debt that became unsustainable and that prevented policies to relaunch our economy with effective support to fundamental productive sectors. It is the European Semester that underlies an intolerable blackmailing operation around our budgetary policy. The report speaks highly of the recommendations by countries. But these are very clear, require more flexibility in labor laws, more privatization in transport and freeze on wages. There is no economic rationale in this European semester. The European Semester, with the false purpose of supporting countries in their fiscal policy, represents rather an instrument designed to impose a neoliberal agenda at the service of capital and which the peoples will, sooner or later, reject.

name: Harald VILIMSKY
text: written.- The primary goal of the European Semester is to review and control budget discipline and the reforms proposed by the member states.This patronizing encroachment on the budget sovereignty of the nation-states is to be rejected on fundamental grounds.In addition, the report contains a number of critical restrictions on national sovereignty in budgetary matters - such as the implementation of a redistribution policy to counteract “social exclusion” - which is why I rejected the motion.

name: Julie WARD
text: in writing. ‒ I would like to reiterate my call that the European Semester must include a strong social pillar, including a gender equality pillar. Macroeconomic policy must not undermine social inclusion, but rather stimulate truly sustainable and truly inclusive growth, with all aspects of social and economic policy being made compatible and coherent in working holistically towards that goal.

name: Iuliu WINKLER
text: signed up.- I voted on the own-initiative report on the European Semester for Economic Policy Coordination: Implementing Priorities for 2016. It also includes the opinion of the Committee on Regional Development, which recommends the use of the European Fund for Strategic Investments (EFSI) in a complementary and complementary way.ESI funds, so that the full potential of public and private investment can be exploited and a more equitable geographical balance ensured.

name: Anna ZÁBORSKÁ
text: in writing. - In connection with the slowdown in the global economy, we can also expect lower GDP growth in the EU. The slowdown in economic growth is due to the deteriorating international environment and the failure to implement sustainable reforms, as well as differences in economic and social performance in different parts of the EU. The high unemployment rate, especially of the young, is a persistent problem and demonstrates the inability of some Member States to create stable jobs, so further measures are needed to make the labor market more inclusive. I welcome the fact that the report points to the fact that the number of people at risk of poverty and social exclusion increased by 4.2 million between 2008 and 2014. The fight against poverty and social exclusion must be one of the priorities of all Member States, as they have a major impact on sustainable economic growth. In addition, it must be borne in mind that the fight against long-term unemployment is not easy, as these people have largely lost their work habits and their integration into the labor market is difficult. Therefore, effective measures must be taken to restore work habits or retraining.

name: Marco ZANNI
text: in writing.- We voted today on the annual own-initiative report that the European Parliament presents on the country-specific recommendations (CSR) made by the Commission in the context of the European Semester.I voted against because I believe that the final text is completely unsatisfactory: it focuses on compliance with budgetary constraints, the lack of and insufficient application of European governance rules and the inadequate implementation of structural reforms by the Member States.Furthermore, there is no criticism of the need to take corrective measures to manage the excessive trade surpluses that are the cause of huge macroeconomic imbalances within the eurozone.The conclusion drawn by the report is that there is no need to question the existing rules, much less to amend the treaties, which I totally disagree with.

name: Carlos ZORRINHO
text: in writing. - I voted in favor of the Sant report for agreeing with the priorities presented for 2016 that focus on increasing investment in areas such as education, innovation, research and development and the creation of quality jobs. I regret that the lack of sustainable investment and deficiencies in the completion of the single market prevent the EU from reaching its full growth potential.
