I therefore recall the importance of coherence between economic policy instruments, always as an expression of European solidarity, with the main objectives of strengthening economic, social and territorial cohesion in the EU, by reducing disparities between the levels of development of the various regions and bringing the EU closer to its citizens. I also highlight the Commission's new approach to limit the number of recommendations and its commitment to streamline the Semester, by including mainly priority areas of macroeconomic and social importance in the definition of policy objectives for the coming months.

name: Milan ZVER
text: in writing. - I voted in favor of the motion for a resolution on the European Semester for economic policy coordination: implementing priorities for 2016. The findings show that EU economic growth will be lower than expected from the 2016 spring economic forecast for Europe, as GDP will in the euro area is projected to increase by only 1.6%. The European economic crisis has highlighted the importance of fostering investment in areas such as education, innovation, research and development, while increasing the EU's competitiveness by implementing sustainable structural reforms to promote quality job creation and responsible fiscal policy to create better jobs. environments for jobs, businesses (especially SMEs) and investment. I agree that further steps are needed to increase funding opportunities, especially for SMEs, and to reduce non-performing loans in the euro area in line with EU law, in order to improve banks 'balance sheets and thus increase banks' ability to lending to the real sector. Monetary policy must also be accompanied by appropriate fiscal policies to increase growth in the EU, in accordance with the rules of the Stability and Growth Pact, including flexibility provisions.

name: Biljana BORZAN
text: - Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the European Union must take action against the obesity epidemic and related diseases, as this is probably the greatest long-term threat to public health. According to the World Health Organization, over 50% of Europeans are overweight, and we are the worst in the world in terms of death rates, from cardiovascular disease, diabetes and cancer. The main reason for this is precisely eating habits and unhealthy food composition. It is estimated that 660,000 people die each year from heart and cardiovascular disease in the European Union, and industrial trans fats have been identified as the single most harmful ingredient. The Commission has an obligation to legally limit their share of food production, as the common market makes national measures insufficiently effective. Even large food manufacturers have realized this and are reducing the proportion of trans fatty acids in their products themselves. I supported this resolution and I hope that the Commission will react as soon as possible because the price we pay in terms of the costs of treatment and sick leave and human lives is simply too high.

name: Seán KELLY
text: – Go raibh maith agat, a Uachtaráin. Arís vótál mé ar an ábhar seo le mo ghrúpa. Ní raibh aon deacracht againn agus ba mhaith liom na rapóirtéirí a mholadh, duine díobh ó mo thír féin, Lynn Boylan. Is ábhar tábhachtach é.  I support this motion for a resolution in light of its vital recommendations in this field of public health and the provision of nutritional literacy to consumers across the European Union. This motion for a resolution reminds us that we must remain keenly aware of the health risks associated with the consumption of trans fats (TFAs), including, but not limited to, cardiovascular disease, infertility and obesity. Thus we must endeavour to harmonise the EU approach to TFAs, boosting awareness across industries and within the home across the EU.  Agus sa tslí sin cabhróimid le sláinte ár saoránach a chur chun cinn, agus tá sin tábhachtach. Mar a deirtear, i nGaeilge, níl aon rud níos tábhachtaí ná an sláinte: “is fearr an tsláinte ná na táinte”. Go raibh maith agat.

name: Isabella ADINOLFI
text: in writing.- Hydrogenated fats represent a serious danger to human health: it is proven that they greatly increase the risk of contracting cardiovascular diseases and related diseases, and for this reason they should be completely eliminated from the diet.Since there have been no attempts at harmonization to date in the area of trans fatty acids and individual initiatives by Member States may not be enough, I have decided to vote in favor of the resolution.

name: Tim AKER
text: in writing. – UKIP is very concerned about the health implications of TFAs and believes that the UK Parliament should be free to legislate on this very important issue. For this reason we decided to abstain on this non—binding motion for a resolution.

name: Marina ALBIOL GUZMÁN
text: written.- I voted in favor of this resolution, because I consider it important to regulate and establish limits on the presence of industrial trans fats in food.Consuming these trans fats through industrially produced partially hydrogenated vegetable oils has been associated with an increased risk of cardiovascular disease, infertility, Alzheimer's disease, obesity, and some types of cancer.It is therefore urgent for the Commission to issue a legislative proposal setting legally binding limits for trans fats.

name: Martina ANDERSON
text: in writing. – We voted in favour of this resolution which called on the European Commission to finally come forward with legislation to put mandatory limits on the amounts of transfats permitted in food. Trans fats are dangerous types of fats mainly used in industrially-produced foods which increases the risk of heart disease more than any other nutrient. Whilst there has been a general decline in trans fats levels in foods over the past decade there are still products on the market which contain 40-50% transfats (when the WHO recommends that less than 1% of total energy intake should be derived from them, at a maximum). Furthermore, transfat-heavy foods tend to be consumed by those on lower incomes, thus exacerbating already existing health inequalities. It is well overdue that the European Commission now follow the example of certain Member States, such as Denmark, and put public health first by imposing mandatory legal limits.

name: Eric ANDRIEU
text: in writing.- I supported this resolution which reminds us that industrial trans fatty acids are the most dangerous nutrient for heart health, and that it is not necessary to add them to processed foods.They should therefore be banned at EU level, as they have already been in Denmark, Austria, Latvia and Hungary.We call on the Commission to present a text as soon as possible, in order to save tens of thousands of lives a year.

name: Nikos ANDROULAKIS
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of the motion for a resolution on trans fats, because consuming large amounts of these fats poses significant risks to human health.

name: Pascal ARIMONT
text: written.- This is a motion for a resolution which aims, among other things, to introduce binding limit values for industrial trans fatty acids (TFA) in food.TFAs increase the risk of developing cardiovascular disease, infertility, Alzheimer's disease, diabetes and obesity and are mainly found in industrially produced partially hydrogenated vegetable oils.I expressly support the introduction of such a limit value.In Denmark, the upper limit for industrial TFA introduced in 2003, which limited the TFA content in oils and fats to 2%, significantly reduced the number of deaths from cardiovascular diseases.

name: Marie-Christine ARNAUTU
text: in writing. - Trans fatty acids induce risks for human health: increased risk of the development of cardiovascular diseases, gallstones, diabetes and certain cancers in particular. To date, the European Food Safety Authority recommends consuming "as little as possible" of trans fatty acids. However, there are no European regulations in this area. The motion for a resolution proposes the introduction of new EU regulations on the content of trans fatty acids in foods. Preceded by an impact study, this would be introduced within two years. My colleague from the National Front, Mireille d'Ornano was co-editor of this motion for a resolution: it is indeed imperative to limit the content of trans fatty acids in view of their deleterious effects, now proven, on human health. The ENF group emphasized two other essential points: the fact that trans fatty acids of natural origin are harmless and that regulation of the content of trans fatty acids in foods must take into account national specificities. . I therefore voted in favor of this resolution.

name: Jonathan ARNOTT
text: in writing. ‒ This motion for a resolution calls on the Commission to establish an EU legislative proposal aiming at eliminating TFAs from the EU food supply chain in the long term, either through the introduction of EU mandatory TFA content labelling or through an EU legal limit on the industrial TFA content of all food.  In principle I believe that these issues should be decisions taken by nation states, not at European Union level, and therefore (particularly in view of the decision of the British people on Brexit) I could not vote in favour. Nevertheless, I recognise the health benefits which such policies can give when introduced. I note the relative success of the policy introduced in New York limiting the use of trans fats, and I would be broadly supportive of similar moves in the United Kingdom. I therefore could not vote against this resolution. Consequently, I abstained.

name: Jean ARTHUIS
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of this resolution because it is necessary for the Commission to consider establishing a legal European limit on the content of trans fatty acids in all foods.My decision is supported by studies conducted by EFSA and the WTO which recommend that consumption be as low as possible.

name: Zigmantas BALČYTIS
text: in writing.- Trans fats are found in foods that are mostly industrially produced, which can increase the risk of cardiovascular disease, Alzheimer’s or diabetes, as well as promote obesity.Also, as many as a third of consumers are unaware of trans fats, even though they are mentioned on food labels.Against this background, I agree that, in addition to product labeling at EU level, there should be a limit on the amount of these fats in food.

name: Gerard BATTEN
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP is very concerned about the health implications of TFAs and believes that the UK Parliament should be free to legislate on this very important issue. For this reason we decided to abstain on this non-binding motion for a resolution.

name: Nicolas BAY
text: in writing.- Trans fatty acids induce serious risks for human health: increased risk of developing cardiovascular diseases, gallstones, diabetes or even certain cancers.The motion for a resolution proposes the introduction of new EU regulations on the content of trans fatty acids in foods, which would be introduced within two years.It is indeed necessary to limit the content of trans fatty acids in view of their deleterious effects, now proven, on human health.I voted in favor of this resolution, co-written by my colleague from the Front National and coordinator of the ENL group, Mireille d´Ornano.

name: Hugues BAYET
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of this resolution which stresses the need to reduce trans fatty acids (TFAs) in foodstuffs and therefore considers it necessary to take ad hoc measures both at European and national level.Noting the limited effectiveness of labeling, it invites the Commission in particular to propose, within two years, a legal European limit on the EGT content (as an ingredient but also as a final product) in allfoods to reduce their consumption in all population groups.

name: Beatriz BECERRA BASTERRECHEA
text: written. - This proposal is timely and is based on health considerations, consolidated and updated consumer and market information, and based on EU and WHO evidence. We emphasize that measures cannot be exclusively national and that, to reduce the average intake of TFA, measures must be taken at Union level. A trans fat labeling policy may be the most difficult measure to enforce effectively. The financial impact of the trans fat ban has been shown to be minimal in the countries that have implemented it, due to low enforcement and monitoring costs. The reporting labeling strategy would only affect certain foods, but not those that are not packaged or those served in restaurants. We also request that the Commission carry out a thorough impact assessment to assess the costs and benefits of different thresholds and specifically take into account the effects on SMEs. We also ask the food industry to give priority to alternative solutions, such as the use of improved oils, new fat modification procedures or combinations of TFA substitutes.

name: Ivo BELET
text: written.- Anyone who eats food products with a lot of industrial trans fats is three times more likely to die from cardiovascular disease.Moreover, the current, separate approach in the various member states leads to complex regulations for European companies.In addition to a reduction in the amount of trans fatty acids, there is also a need for more awareness about the risks.In Belgium, we have had those trans fatty acids under control for several years, but the problem persists due to the import of foodstuffs.Moreover, they are also more common in cheaper food, which means that they also hit certain population groups harder.The European Commission must now come up with binding limit values within two years.

name: Brando BENIFEI
text: in writing. - Trans fatty acids (TFAs) are a type of unsaturated fat found in foods obtained from ruminants and in partially hydrogenated vegetable oils produced industrially. According to several studies, their consumption can increase the risk of cardiovascular disease, infertility, Alzheimer's disease, diabetes and lead to obesity. I voted in favor of the motion for a resolution presented today in Parliament because I consider it a priority, in the light of the data presented, to limit the use of fatty acids following the example of Denmark, which since 2003 has acted in this direction, obtaining positive results and reducing considerably the deaths caused by cardiovascular diseases. TFAs are used in cheaper foods with the consequence that people with a lower socioeconomic status are the most exposed to their consumption and therefore more exposed to a risk that widens health inequalities. In this context, the resolution asks the Commission to introduce new EU rules to limit, preferably within two years, the level of industrial TFAs in products.

name: Xabier BENITO ZILUAGA
text: written. - At the end of 2015, the European Commission presented a report on the health problem posed by trans fats in food, but did not present the corresponding draft legislation. After a year of waiting and continuous complaints from civil society, consumer organizations, medical societies and other entities, I have voted in favor of this report to achieve a single legislation in the Union on this issue. The United States has banned the use of artificial trans fats in food products as of 2018, so this legislation would accompany European industry in its exports. The homologation of quality standards upwards should be reciprocal and not as expected to happen according to the ATCI. It is important to clarify that the incentive to legislate should be to reduce cardiovascular diseases, as the main cause of death in Europe and not the market, an issue that I understand is not clear in the report.

name: Izaskun BILBAO BARANDICA
text: written.- I voted in favor of this report on trans fatty acids as I believe that the EU should set mandatory limits for these industrially produced acids, as they can increase the risk of cardiovascular disease, infertility, Alzheimer's, diabetes and obesity in people.consumers.According to the Commission, only one in three consumers in the EU is aware of trans fatty acids and this shows that measures on labeling are insufficient.That is why I voted in favor of the ECR Group amendment calling for mandatory labeling.Unfortunately it has not been approved.What the European Commission is being asked to do is propose a legal limit in the EU to the content of these acids in all foods as soon as possible, preferably within two years.

name: Dominique BILDE
text: in writing. - On the resolution aimed at creating a European regulation on the limitation of the content of trans fatty acids in foods, I wanted to oppose it and support the alternative resolution tabled by the ENL group. While everyone agrees to recognize the health risks posed by trans fatty acids, in particular with regard to cardiovascular and obesity problems, the aim of the proposal is to bring the European regulatory framework closer to the American framework in the perspective of TTIP. Furthermore, I stress that this problem must be treated as a priority by the Member States, if only because of national specificities in terms of food, a point particularly true concerning France since our gastronomy is recognized as an intangible cultural heritage by UNESCO. I am, moreover, worried about the ambiguity that the text maintains between trans fatty acid of industrial origin and trans fatty acid of natural origin: it would not be a question of once again attracting the opprobrium on our industry. dairy particularly in difficulty at present.

name: Mara BIZZOTTO
text: in writing.- Although it is a text that can be shared in part, there are some unclear passages that could open up to future critical issues.I therefore expressed myself with an abstention vote.

name: Vilija BLINKEVIČIŪTĖ
text: in writing. - I voted in favor of this resolution because the issue of trans fats (RRT) is a priority for Parliament and it reiterates its concern about the risks to human health posed by RRT. The European Parliament emphasizes that the US has already reported that, in the light of the 2015 conclusion, trans fatty acid trans isomers are generally not recognized as safe from 2018 onwards. mid-year food producers will have to remove partially hydrogenated oils from products sold on the domestic market. Furthermore, Parliament emphasizes that many EU citizens, especially the most vulnerable, lack information on trans fatty acid trans isomers and their effects on health, which can hamper consumers' informed choice of products. Thus, according to the World Health Organization (WHO), most funding is likely to be needed to implement the labeling of fatty acid transomers, and in countries that have implemented a ban on fatty acid transomers, the financial impact of the ban has been minimal given the low implementation and monitoring costs. The European Parliament calls for such a proposal to be accompanied by an impact assessment assessing the costs of industrial restructuring due to the mandatory limit value and the possibility of passing these costs on to consumers. It also calls on the Commission to work with the Member States to raise public awareness of nutrition and provide consumers with healthier choices, and to work with industry to promote healthier products.

name: Andrea BOCSKOR
text: in writing. - A decisive amount of scientific evidence proves the harmful effects of trans fats produced by industry. Excessive consumption of them not only increases the risk of cardiovascular disease, but can also be associated with morbid obesity as well as type 2 diabetes. Mandatory labeling, voluntary commitments by industry alone, do not provide sufficient protection for consumers. A similar conclusion was reached in a report published by the European Commission in December 2015: the most effective means of prevention may be a legal restriction on the content of industrial trans fats. Hungary was one of the first to regulate the highest acceptable level of trans fatty acids in foods in 2014, after Denmark and Austria. The regulation does not allow the placing on the market of foods with a trans fat content of more than 2 grams per 100 grams of total fat content. The Hungarian example has since been followed by Latvia. In the short term following the introduction of binding legislation, the proportion of foods containing trans fats above the legal limit has decreased significantly in the countries concerned, with significant public health benefits. Based on all this, I voted in favor of the resolution.

name: Franc BOGOVIČ
text: in writing.- The motion for a resolution on trans fatty acids has received my support.Namely, frequent consumption of trans fatty acids is associated with an increased risk of developing cardiovascular disease, infertility, gallstones, Alzheimer's and diabetes, obesity and some cancers.Further research shows that only one in three consumers in the EU is aware of trans fatty acids and that measures to label the content of these acids are ineffective.EU legislation does not regulate the content of trans fatty acids in food and does not require their labeling.However, the effectiveness of these restrictions is demonstrated by Danish legislation, which in 2003 tightened the permitted content of trans fatty acids in oils and fats to two percent.As a result, the number of deaths from cardiovascular disease has decreased significantly.

name: Simona BONAFÈ
text: in writing. - Trans fatty acids (TFAs) are found in many industrially produced foods with the aim of ensuring a longer shelf life. They pose a real risk to human health; It has long been scientifically proven that the consumption of these hydrogenated fats is associated with an increased risk of cardiovascular disease, one of the main causes of mortality in the European Union. This data is even more alarming if we consider that the subjects most inclined to consume foods with a high TFA content are above all younger and low-income citizens. I therefore support the invitation addressed to the Commission, contained in the report voted today, for the introduction of a legislative framework that substantially reduces the amount of TFA present in foods deriving from industrial production, in order to protect consumers from the risks due excessive intake. The European Union must therefore act on two fronts: first of all, to protect the health of its citizens, encouraging them to make healthier and more informed food choices, and secondly by facilitating the transition of the food industry by promoting healthy reformulation of products that now contain TFA.

name: Marie-Christine BOUTONNET
text: in writing.- This report stresses the need to put in place a real European regulation concerning the consumption of these trans fatty acids, given that the current recommendations have not brought about any significant improvement.Since these substances can increase the risk of cardiovascular disease, gallstones, diabetes, and certain cancers, we need to act.I therefore voted for this resolution.

name: Mercedes BRESSO
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the resolution on trans fats because the Parliament is committed to protecting the human health of citizens and the trans-fatty acids pose a risk to it. Mainly for that reason, I believe both the food industry and consumers have to choose products that comply with health and environmental standards.

name: Renata BRIANO
text: in writing. - Trans fatty acids (TFAs) are unsaturated fats present in foods obtained from ruminants and in partially hydrogenated vegetable oils produced industrially. Their consumption has been associated with an increased risk of cardiovascular disease. The EU should place binding limits on the quantities of TFAs in food, as these can increase the risk of cardiovascular disease, infertility, Alzheimer's disease, diabetes and obesity for consumers. In a resolution approved with 586 votes in favor, it is highlighted that according to the European Commission only one in three consumers has knowledge of TFA; this shows how the labeling measures have failed to be effective and therefore the Commission should propose the introduction of EU rules to limit the content of industrial TFAs. The introduction of binding limits for industrial TFAs in Denmark has led to positive results, significantly reducing deaths from cardiovascular disease. Additionally, as TFAs tend to be used in cheaper foods, people with lower socioeconomic status are more exposed to foods with a high TFA content, which increases the risk of widening health inequalities.

name: Steeve BRIOIS
text: in writing.- This motion for a resolution aims to limit the content of trans fatty acids in foods.Indeed, the latter induce risks for human health, in particular with regard to cardiovascular diseases, gallstones and diabetes.In addition, the report underlines the insufficiency of Regulation (EU) No 1169/2011 of 25 October 2011 concerning information to consumers on foodstuffs, in particular concerning the immediate identification of the trans fatty acid content, by readingof its labeling.I voted in favor of this text, which aims to protect the public from the risks associated with the consumption of foods with levels of trans fatty acids well above the maximum recommended standards.

name: Alain CADEC
text: in writing. - Trans fatty acids are types of unsaturated fatty acids naturally present in foods derived from ruminants (milk, meat, etc.), in certain plants and products of plant origin and artificially in partially hydrogenated vegetable oils. In these industrial oils, trans fatty acids help extend shelf life. We cannot deny that the consumption of these increases the risks of coronary heart disease, cardiovascular disease, obesity and type 2 diabetes. This resolution calls on the Commission to act to limit the consumption of trans fatty acids by imposing a legal limit for the content of trans fatty acids in all foods. We must act in this direction, it is a matter of public health. However, we should not stigmatize the trans fatty acids found naturally in foods such as milk, meat and certain plants which do not present these health risks. I voted in favor of this resolution.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: in writing. - Today I voted in favor of this resolution calling for the introduction of an EU legal limit on the content of industrial trans fatty acids (TFA) in food. In Europe, this measure has already been adopted by Austria, Denmark, Latvia and Hungary. TFAs are fats produced mostly through chemical processes, highly harmful to our body, cause of coronary heart disease, diabetes and obesity. Their intake is mainly linked to the consumption of industrially produced vegetable oils, such as margarine for example, which are found in large quantities in baked goods and long-life foods, consumed mainly by children. TFAs are also present in nature, in particular in dairy products and meat, but in such modest quantities as not to represent - according to the WHO - any danger to human health. The report calls on the Commission to work with Member States to improve nutritional literacy, encourage consumers to make healthier food choices and engage with industry to encourage healthy reformulation of products.

name: Matt CARTHY
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this resolution, co-authored by my colleague Lynn Boylan. Trans-fatty acids (TFAs) are unsaturated fats found in foods obtained from ruminants and in industrially-produced, partially hydrogenated vegetable oils. Consumption has been associated with an increased risk of cardiovascular disease, infertility, Alzheimer’s disease, obesity and some types of cancer. High TFA intake is, in particular, a risk factor for developing coronary heart disease – a disease that is conservatively estimated to account for 660 000 deaths annually in the EU, or 14% of overall mortality. The Commission was required by a 2014 regulation to submit a report to the European Parliament and the Council on the presence of TFAs in foods and was invited to accompany the report with a legislative proposal if appropriate. In its report published in December 2015, the Commission considered possible options to limit TFA consumption in the EU, but refrained from making a legislative proposal. The resolution highlights that TFA legal limits can bring rapid and significant health benefits, (for example, as they have in Denmark). It calls on the Commission to propose mandatory limits on industrial TFAs in order to reduce their intake as soon as possible, which I support.

name: James CARVER
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP is very concerned about the health implications of TFAs and believes that the UK Parliament should be free to legislate on this very important issue. For this reason we decided to abstain on this non-binding motion for a resolution.

name: David CASA
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report calling the Commission to propose introducing limits for trans fats (TFAs) in industrially-processed foods as excess consumption of TFAs causes health problems. As only a limited number of people can actually make sense of TFA labelling, it is even more important to introduce TFA limits in processed food. Although high-in-TFAs non-pre-packaged food and fried-on-the-spot food is exempt from these limits. Although the introduction of TFA limits should not be a problem for the food industry as a whole, as limits already exist in some Member States, smaller producers may face difficulties in adapting to future standards. In order to counteract this possibility we have asked the Commission to carry out a substantial impact assessment before presenting its proposal.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: in writing.- Trans fats (also called hydrogenated) are those fats that have undergone the process of hydrogenation, so that our body perceives them as saturated.These fats, used in many preparations such as sweets and ice cream, significantly increase the risk of cardiovascular disease and should be completely eliminated from the diet.We therefore try to identify a harmonized approach at EU level for law enforcement;I agree with the end and the means chosen and I definitely voted in favor.

name: Lefteris CHRISTOFOROU
text: in writing.- We support the proposal and call on the Commission to establish as soon as possible at EU level a legal limit for industrial trans fats (both in terms of ingredients and in terms of final product) in all foods, in order to reduce their intake in allpopulation groups.

name: Kostas CHRYSOGONOS
text: in writing.- The motion for a resolution to reduce the use of materials such as trans fats calls on us to act for the benefit of the people of Europe.As the negative effects of using similar ingredients in food have now been proven, I decided to vote in favor.

name: Alberto CIRIO
text: in writing. - I express my satisfaction with the measure passed since it concerns unsaturated fatty acids of industrial production, maintaining firmly the axiom that healthy fats contribute to the regular functioning of our organism. A frequent consumption of trans fats, on the other hand, is associated with the increase of cardiovascular diseases, infertility, diabetes and obesity, therefore it is urgent to reach a harmonized approach at European level quickly. Indeed, a mosaic of national regulations would not only result in different impacts on citizens' health, but would create distortions of the internal market and obstacles to innovation in the food industry. In light of these realities, the Commission must introduce a legal limit as soon as possible, also assessing the costs of industrial reformulations that companies in the sector would have to face. Limiting TFAs can bring rapid and significant health benefits as can be deduced from the example of Denmark which, by introducing a national limit to their presence of 2% in oils and fats in 2003, has seen a consistent decrease in deaths related to cardiovascular diseases . Without forgetting, then, that growing social inequality affects food choices, forcing people with lower incomes to follow unhealthy regimes as they are cheaper and this phenomenon demands a solid and timely barrier.

name: Deirdre CLUNE
text: in writing. ‒ I supported the motions for resolutions on trans fats and noted no objections. I supported this vote because excess consumption of TFAs causes health problems, and cutting out or reducing transfats could save up to 50 000 lives in Europe every year. MEPs have asked the Commission in this vote to carry out a substantial impact assessment before presenting a legal proposal, and this means that local producers will not unfairly suffer.

name: Birgit COLLIN-LANGEN
text: written.- I voted for the resolution because I believe that there is an urgent need for action to reduce the consumption of trans fats.I support the introduction of an EU-wide limit value for trans fatty acids for industrially manufactured products.And I welcome the Commission's announcement that it will carry out an impact assessment to assess the costs and benefits of various possible caps, in particular the impact on SMEs.

name: Lara COMI
text: in writing. - I voted in favor of the resolution because TFAs, which are partially hydrogenated oils contained in industrially derived food products such as biscuits, cakes, fried foods and baked foods, can pose a long-term danger to consumers. Considering that the intake of TFA aggravates the development of coronary heart disease and that the aforementioned pathologies cause about fourteen percent of deaths within the European Union, Parliament has requested the intervention of the Commission to ensure that two years, legislation is enacted that sets the maximum possible percentage of TFA contained in food products at a level similar to that contained in the Danish standards (ie two percent per hundred grams). In addition, the Parliament requested the Commission to carry out an impact assessment for the costs associated with the inclusion of the TFA thresholds, with particular attention to the SMEs concerned in the sector.

name: Javier COUSO PERMUY
text: written.- I voted in favor of this resolution, because I consider it important to regulate and establish limits on the presence of industrial trans fats in food.Consuming these trans fats through industrially produced partially hydrogenated vegetable oils has been associated with an increased risk of cardiovascular disease, infertility, Alzheimer's disease, obesity, and some types of cancer.It is therefore urgent for the Commission to issue a legislative proposal setting legally binding limits for trans fats.

name: Andrea COZZOLINO
text: in writing. - I voted in favor of this resolution because it notes the risks posed by trans fatty acids (TFAs) to human health and highlights the need for a uniform legislative framework at European level to reduce the average intake of TFA. At present, there are no European provisions regarding the TFA content in food and the obligation of corresponding labeling. Some Member States, such as Denmark, have adopted a restrictive regulatory regime (national limit of 2% on the content of trans fats in oils and fats), while most of the other Member States have opted for voluntary measures. TFAs not only cause cardiovascular disease, but are also more present in cheaper food products, exposing lower-income citizens to excessive consumption of harmful foods. In addition, consumers, under current EU rules, may have difficulty understanding the difference between hydrogenated oils (which do not contain TFA but only saturated fatty acids) and partially hydrogenated oils. Therefore, I support the call to the Commission to work with Member States to improve nutritional literacy and to introduce a legal EU limit on industrial TFA content in all food products.

name: Edward CZESAK
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of the motion for a resolution on reducing the consumption of trans fats at EU level.Trans fatty acids are unsaturated fats found in food produced from ruminants and in artificial, partially hydrogenated vegetable oils.Unfortunately, society is very vulnerable to their consumption, often without being aware of it, as the products currently made using trans fats include fast food, quick meals or snacks (salty and spicy).Consuming these fats, research shows, leads to cardiovascular disease or coronary heart disease, with around 660,000 people dying from these diseases each year in the EU.The draft concerns a very important problem that should be resolved as soon as possible, which is why I voted in favor.

name: Miriam DALLI
text: in writing. ‒ Industrial trans-fats are the single most dangerous nutrient for heart health, and adding them to processed foods isn't necessary. I am in favour of this report as I believe that trans-fats should be addressed as their consumption has been associated with an increased risk of cardiovascular disease. I call on the Commission to propose as soon as possible mandatory limit on industrial trans-fats in order to reduce their intake amongst all population groups.

name: Daniel DALTON
text: in writing. ‒ I agree that a reduction in trans fats is a good thing for general public health, however I do not agree with the approach taken in this resolution. The inflexible approach it takes is a mandatory limit on trans fatty acids, which risks passing on significant price increases to consumers. I am also concerned that such a one-track approach will not help reduce trans fatty intake in the longer term. Better labelling, self-regulation and voluntary agreements between industry and governments have all seen significant improvements in trans-fat levels in a number of Member States. We need to continue to do more work in this area and should not just reject all the progress of the last few years in these areas. For these reasons I voted against this motion.

name: Michel DANTIN
text: in writing. - In this resolution, we call on the European Commission to limit the use of trans fatty acids in processed foods. These unsaturated fats are used in the food industry and are present in high doses in products such as pastries, ready meals or fried foods. However, the consumption of trans fatty acids carries a risk of cardiovascular disease, diabetes and Alzheimer's disease, causing nearly 660,000 deaths annually in the Union. We therefore call on the Commission to set limits for the use of trans fatty acids in industrial food products as soon as possible. It should be remembered that these limits do not apply to foods such as milk or meat which naturally contain such fats. Considering that these measures aim to strengthen consumer protection and the health of European citizens, I voted in favor of this resolution.

name: William (The Earl of) DARTMOUTH
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP is very concerned about the health implications of TFAs and believes that the UK Parliament should be free to legislate on this very important issue. For this reason we decided to abstain on this non-binding motion for a resolution.

name: Rachida DATI
text: in writing.- Natural trans fatty acids (TFAs) are, according to the World Health Organization, unlikely to pose a risk to health unlike industrially produced trans fatty acids discussed in this resolution.I supported this resolution which insists on the need to take measures, both at national and Union level, to considerably reduce the general consumption of trans fatty acids and point the finger at the lack of consumer awareness byreport on the negative effects of TFAs on health.It is therefore essential that the European Commission establishes, as quickly as possible, a limit for TFAs for all industrial foods.

name: Angélique DELAHAYE
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of this resolution on trans fatty acids.These acids are dangerous to health when consumed in too large quantities.It is therefore important that the Commission sets a limit level for all processed foods, which we consume very widely.It is essential to protect European consumers.In this regard, it is important to clearly distinguish the fatty acids naturally present in agricultural products such as meat and milk, from non-natural fatty acids for which this legislation is necessary.

name: Andor DELI
text: in writing. - A decisive amount of scientific evidence proves the harmful effects of trans fats produced by industry. Excessive consumption of them not only increases the risk of cardiovascular disease, but can also be associated with morbid obesity as well as type 2 diabetes. Mandatory labeling, voluntary commitments by industry alone, do not provide sufficient protection for consumers. A similar conclusion was reached in a report published by the European Commission in December 2015: the most effective means of prevention may be a legal restriction on the content of industrial trans fats. Hungary was one of the first to regulate the highest acceptable level of trans fatty acids in foods in 2014, after Denmark and Austria. The regulation does not allow the placing on the market of foods with a trans fat content of more than 2 grams per 100 grams of total fat content. The Hungarian example has since been followed by Latvia. In the short term following the introduction of binding legislation, the proportion of foods containing trans fats above the legal limit has decreased significantly in the countries concerned, with significant public health benefits. It is noteworthy that the food industry, recognizing its social responsibility, is playing an increasingly important role in reducing trans fatty acids. Taking advantage of the consensus situation, it is therefore important for the European Commission to propose EU limit values ​​for these artificial fats as soon as possible. Based on all this, I voted in favor of the resolution.

name: Marielle DE SARNEZ
text: in writing.- Trans fatty acids (TFA) are a category of fats contained in industrially produced vegetable oils such as frying oil or certain margarines used in baking.According to the European Food Safety Authority, frequent consumption of these TFAs increases the risk of developing cardiovascular disease, infertility, Alzheimer's disease, diabetes or certain types of cancer.Some Member States introduced, as early as 2003, a limitation on the maximum rate of AGT of industrial origin.These measures have led to a reduction in the number of deaths linked to cardiovascular diseases.That is why the Union must extend this limitation to European level.The Union must also ensure that consumers are better informed with the systematic labeling of products containing TFAs.

name: Mireille D'ORNANO
text: in writing.- Trans fatty acids increase the risk of cardiovascular disease, gallstones, diabetes and certain cancers in particular.The European Food Safety Authority recommends consuming "as little as possible" of trans fatty acids.However, to date there are no European regulations in this area.The purpose of this resolution is to limit through European regulations the content of trans fatty acids in foods.Preceded by an impact study, this would be introduced within two years.As the co-editor of this motion for a resolution, of course I voted in favor.

name: Angel DZHAMBAZKI
text: in writing. ‒ I voted for this resolution. I generally support the motion to set a mandatory limit on industrial trans fats in food. European markets and especially citizens in all Member States will benefit from this measure. High levels of trans fats pose serious health risks to people, such as cardiovascular diseases. In my country, the risk is significantly lower because the average diet focuses on quality-products, which are also found on the Bulgarian market. A reduction in industrial trans fats will result in the support of the production and use of high-quality and natural foods, which I highly welcome. Nonetheless, I am not convinced that this is a measure which should be discussed on a European level.

name: Norbert ERDŐS
text: in writing. - A decisive amount of scientific evidence proves the harmful effects of trans fats produced by industry. Excessive consumption of them not only increases the risk of cardiovascular disease, but can also be associated with morbid obesity as well as type 2 diabetes. Mandatory labeling, voluntary commitments by industry alone, do not provide sufficient protection for consumers. A similar conclusion was reached in a report published by the European Commission in December 2015: the most effective means of prevention may be a legal restriction on the content of industrial trans fats. Hungary was one of the first to regulate the highest acceptable level of trans fatty acids in foods in 2014, after Denmark and Austria. The regulation does not allow the placing on the market of foods with a trans fat content of more than 2 grams per 100 grams of total fat content. The Hungarian example has since been followed by Latvia. In the short term following the introduction of binding legislation, the proportion of foods containing trans fats above the legal limit has decreased significantly in the countries concerned, with significant public health benefits. It is noteworthy that the food industry, recognizing its social responsibility, is playing an increasingly important role in reducing trans fats. Taking advantage of the consensus situation, it is therefore important for the European Commission to propose EU limit values ​​for these artificial fats as soon as possible. Based on all this, I voted in favor of the resolution.

name: Jill EVANS
text: in writing. ‒ I voted for this motion for a resolution because I am in favour of more effective action to reduce the intake of trans-fatty acids. High TFA intake is a particular risk factor in developing coronary heart disease. Cardiovascular disease accounts for around 30% of deaths in Wales, of which the largest single cause is coronary heart disease. I believe that mandatory limits on industrial TFAs could help reduce their intake.

name: Fredrick FEDERLEY
text: written.- The resolution on trans fats is well balanced and could be voted in favor.Setting a maximum level for the use of trans fats in food is of value to both the Center Party and ALDE.The WHO study that formed the basis for the resolution focuses on public health and cardiovascular diseases, which is a widespread problem in the EU and which is often the result of a high intake of trans fats (TFA).The limit value of 2% is an achievable target and follows the Danish example, which has been proven and has shown an actual reduction in TFA in food.The industry welcomes the limit value and considers it feasible.With regard to trade in the internal market, it is important to standardize the use of TFA to create incentives for good practice, while the resolution advises against a replacement of TFA with palm oil - which is harmful to both the environment, public health and the producer.

name: José Manuel FERNANDES
text: in writing.- The proposal provides for the establishment of a legal limit for industrial trans fatty acids in all food products, taking into account the risks that these fats pose to public health.The high consumption of these unsaturated fats is a risk factor for the development of coronary heart disease, responsible for about 660 thousand deaths per year in the EU, that is, about 14% of the total mortality.The fact that only one in three European consumers have knowledge about trans fatty acids (TFAs) shows that labeling measures are not effective and that measures must be taken to raise public awareness.This proposal must be accompanied by an impact assessment designed to calculate the costs of industrial overhaul that may result from the imposition of mandatory limits and to assess the risk that these costs will be borne by consumers.

name: Edouard FERRAND
text: in writing.- Vote in favor: very interesting contribution from Ms Mireille d´Ornano, coordinator of the ENF group within the ENVI committee and co-editor of this motion for a resolution.It is indeed imperative to limit the content of trans fatty acids in view of their deleterious effects, now proven, on human health.

name: João FERREIRA
text: in writing. - Transesterified fatty acids (TFAs) are unsaturated fats that can be found in foods obtained from ruminant animals or in the production of industrially produced partially hydrogenated vegetable oils. They are a cheap and easily obtained raw material. The consumption of this type of oils has been associated with an increased risk of cardiovascular disease, infertility, obesity and some types of cancer. The products that currently have more in their composition this type of unsaturated fats are called fast food and snacks (savory or sweet) and foods classified as highly processed. According to the responsible agencies - WHO, EFSA and FDA - these fatty acids are not considered safe for human consumption and their consumption should be as low as possible. We are in favor of limiting the use and consumption of this type of trans fatty acids as much as possible, in order to prevent disease and promote healthy eating habits. We generally agree with the content and content of this resolution. But we cannot fail to mention that the issues of promoting a healthy diet and the consumption of fresh, little processed products, are not resolved only by legislating on the labeling or limiting the use of AGT in processed foods. The reasons for economic failure are, in this context, unavoidable.

name: Monika BEŇOVÁ
text: in writing.- Trans fatty acids pose a major risk to the health of European Union citizens.Most people in the European Union, especially the most vulnerable, do not have enough information about trans fats and the health consequences of consuming them, which can prevent consumers from making informed choices.If the average intake of trans fatty acids is to be significantly reduced, measures should not be taken exclusively at national level, but measures at European Union level are needed.The European Parliament therefore considers it its duty to call on the food industry to prioritize alternative solutions that comply with health standards, such as the use of improved oils, new fat treatment processes or a combination of trans fats.

name: Lorenzo FONTANA
text: in writing.- I abstain from the report: the problem of the excessive intake of artificially produced TFAs is certainly real, however I think a voluntary approach is preferable, by encouraging the food industry to use alternative production methods.

name: Lampros FOUNTOULIS
text: in writing.- I am voting in favor of the report, as it is a positive step with significant benefits for the health of European citizens, although for us it is not the ideal proposal as we would require even more restrictions.We also disagree with the very long margin given to the Commission to set a maximum permissible trans fat content.

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: in writing. ‒ Trans Fatty Acids (trans fats) are a type of unsaturated fatty acids that have been widely used in the food industry since the 1950s. They are added to foods because they enhance the texture of processed foods and increases their shelf life, or as a cheap alternative to other fats. There is now broad scientific consensus that high consumption of trans fats significantly increases the risk of coronary heart disease, and may also be associated with other diseases. Industrial trans fats are the single most dangerous nutrient for heart health, and adding them to processed foods isn’t necessary. Therefore they should be banned EU-wide, just as they already have been in Denmark, Austria, Latvia and Hungary. The Commission must come forward with legal limits as soon as possible, because it has the potential to save tens of thousands of lives annually.

name: Kinga GÁL
text: in writing. - A decisive amount of scientific evidence proves the harmful effects of trans fats produced by industry. Excessive consumption of them not only increases the risk of cardiovascular disease, but can also be associated with morbid obesity as well as type 2 diabetes. Mandatory labeling, voluntary commitments by industry alone, do not provide sufficient protection for consumers. A similar conclusion was reached in a report published by the European Commission in December 2015: the most effective means of prevention may be a legal restriction on the content of industrial trans fats. Hungary was one of the first to regulate the highest acceptable level of trans fatty acids in foods in 2014, after Denmark and Austria. The regulation does not allow the placing on the market of foods with a trans fat content of more than 2 grams per 100 grams of total fat content. The Hungarian example has since been followed by Latvia. In the short term following the introduction of binding legislation, the proportion of foods containing trans fats above the legal limit has decreased significantly in the countries concerned, with significant public health benefits. It is noteworthy that the food industry, recognizing its social responsibility, is playing an increasingly important role in reducing trans fats. Taking advantage of the consensus situation, it is therefore important for the European Commission to propose EU limit values ​​for these artificial fats as soon as possible. Based on all this, I voted in favor of the resolution.

name: Ildikó GÁLL-PELCZ
text: in writing. - A decisive amount of scientific evidence proves the harmful effects of trans fats produced by industry. Excessive consumption of them not only increases the risk of cardiovascular disease, but can also be associated with morbid obesity as well as type 2 diabetes. Mandatory labeling, voluntary commitments by industry alone, do not provide sufficient protection for consumers. A similar conclusion was reached in a report published by the European Commission in December 2015: the most effective means of prevention may be a legal restriction on the content of industrial trans fats. Hungary was one of the first to regulate the highest acceptable level of trans fatty acids in foods in 2014, after Denmark and Austria. The regulation does not allow the placing on the market of foods with a trans fat content of more than 2 grams per 100 grams of total fat content. The Hungarian example has since been followed by Latvia. In the short term following the introduction of binding legislation, the proportion of foods containing trans fats above the legal limit has decreased significantly in the countries concerned, with significant public health benefits. It is noteworthy that the food industry, recognizing its social responsibility, is playing an increasingly important role in reducing trans fats. Taking advantage of the consensus situation, it is therefore important for the European Commission to propose EU limit values ​​for these artificial fats as soon as possible. Based on all this, I voted in favor of the resolution.

name: Francisco de Paula GAMBUS MILLET
text: written.- I voted in favor of the motion for a resolution, aware that the issue of TFAs is a priority for the European Parliament because of the risks they pose to the health of European citizens.Limiting TFAs has been shown to bring rapid and significant health benefits, as exemplified by the successful experience of Denmark which in 2003 established a national limit of 2% TFA in oils and fats.Similarly, it is important to bear in mind that the majority of the Union population, in particular the most vulnerable people, lacks information on TFA and the health consequences of their consumption, which can prevent them from making informed decisions..Therefore, from the institutions of the Union we must take measures to considerably reduce the average intake of TFA.

name: Enrico GASBARRA
text: in writing.- I can only fully support the parliamentary questions, to the Commission and the Council, regarding the request for monitoring and an urgent intervention to stem the risks associated with the spread and consumption of industrial fatty acids present in certain foods.The health of European citizens is at stake.Several studies have in fact highlighted how harmful these substances can be for the safeguard of our well-being.The message of the European Parliament with this vote is clear: we can no longer wait, urgent action is urgently needed to limit the intake of TFA in the EU.Immediate actions and responses are needed to safeguard the health of European citizens.A battle that the S & amp; D group has carried out with conviction to which today we formally give full support.

name: Elena GENTILE
text: in writing. - I voted in favor of the resolution on EU-wide limits on trans fats in food because I believe that the European Union should place binding limits on the quantities of industrially produced trans fatty acids (TFAs) in food as these can increase the risk of cardiovascular disease, infertility, Alzheimer's disease, diabetes and consumer obesity. The resolution highlights the lack of information among consumers, according to EC data only one in three consumers is adequately informed about TFA, demonstrating the lack of clarity of the labeling. Hence the EP's request to the Commission to introduce binding European standards to limit the content of industrial TFAs, already in the next two years. Denmark already set a national limit of 2% in 2003, and other Member States have followed suit, these are good practices that other Member States should take inspiration from, but the matter can only be efficiently regulated by establishing common rules at European level. I therefore look forward to a forthcoming legislative proposal from the EC that is clear and binding.

name: Arne GERICKE
text: written.- I voted for the report on trans fats.Trans fats are everywhere in our modern diet.These include French fries, chips, all fried foods such as chicken wings, in Berliners and puff pastry, ready-made soups, gravies, sausage and even in muesli bars or breakfast cereals.The negative effects of these fats should not be underestimated.Even if the food looks extremely appetizing at first glance, there are dangers lurking here that should not be underestimated.The consumption of hydrogenated fats or oils carries high health risks.

name: Jens GIESEKE
text: written.- Excessive consumption of trans fats can lead to significant health risks.Since many European citizens are not aware of this, the European Parliament is proposing to the European Commission to introduce certain limits for trans fats in manufactured foods.By restricting the consumption of trans fats in this way, the health of European citizens can be protected over the long term.

name: Sylvie GODDYN
text: in writing. - Trans fatty acids are found in fats used in the food industry. These fatty acids are particularly involved in the onset of cardiovascular disease. Faced with these public health issues, the European Parliament has proposed that legislation be put in place to limit the presence of these trans fatty acids in products of the food industry. Indeed, faced with such technical subjects, labeling alone cannot suffice. I raised, through proposals for amendments with my colleagues on the ENVI committee, that such a proposal should in no way affect dairy products which can also be sources of trans fatty acids but whose effects on the health are very different from trans fatty acids from industrial fats. I also indicated by these same amendments that it would be better to support companies that engage in the reduction of trans fatty acids. Several experiments in some Member States have shown that it is economically and technically possible to reduce these trans fatty acids. To facilitate the work of our many exporting SMEs and to protect the health of consumers, I therefore supported this motion for a resolution.

name: Tania GONZÁLEZ PEÑAS
text: written. - At the end of 2015, the European Commission presented a report on the health problem posed by trans fats in food, but did not present the corresponding draft legislation. After a year of waiting and continuous complaints from civil society, consumer organizations, medical societies and other entities, I have voted in favor of this report to achieve a single legislation in the Union on this issue. The United States has banned the use of artificial trans fats in food products as of 2018, so this legislation would accompany European industry in its exports. The homologation of quality standards upwards should be reciprocal and not as expected to happen according to the ATCI. It is important to clarify that the incentive to legislate should be to reduce cardiovascular diseases, as the main cause of death in Europe and not the market, an issue that I understand is not clear in the report.

name: Theresa GRIFFIN
text: in writing. ‒ Artificial trans fats are linked to a number of health problems, including heart disease, which is the leading cause of death in Europe. Labour MEPs are seeking to protect consumer health by demanding legal limits on the amount of trans fats in food.

name: Françoise GROSSETÊTE
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of this resolution because it seems to me essential to set a limit for trans fatty acids for industrially produced foods.Often present in large amounts in ready-made meals and processed foods, these unsaturated fats pose an increased risk of cardiovascular disease.Today, it is clear that these fatty acids represent a risk for public health, that they are present in too large quantities in industrial foodstuffs, and that the labeling measures in force have proved ineffective in reducing theirconsumption.It is necessary to limit their presence in foodstuffs.However, there is no question of stigmatizing agricultural products such as milk or meat, in which fatty acids are naturally present.

name: Antanas GUOGA
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour. With the given resolution the EU places mandatory limits on industrially-produced trans-fatty acids (TFA) which may increase the risk of cardiovascular disease, infertility, Alzheimer’s, diabetes and obesity for consumers. Denmark was the first EU Member State to limit the content of trans fats in oils and fats by law in 2003.The statistics showed that it was a successful legal decision because it significantly reduced deaths caused by cardiovascular disease.

name: Jytte GUTELAND
text: written. - We support the resolution's call on the European Commission to limit the content of industrial trans fats in food. High intake of trans fats is a risk factor especially for coronary heart disease, which causes approximately 660,000 deaths a year in the EU. Despite convincing evidence of the health benefits of limiting industrial trans fats in food, there is a lack of sufficient EU legislation on the subject. Although we generally welcome food labeling as an important tool for providing consumers with information on food content, we are aware that labeling alone is insufficient to reduce the EU population's intake of trans fats. It is then more important that the EU introduces a mandatory EU legal limit value for industrially produced trans fats in all foods as soon as possible. Such an actual limit value would be an effective tool and have a broader impact as it also includes unpackaged food and restaurant food. It is also important that EU action does not encourage food manufacturers to increase the amount of palm oil in their products, as this risks leading to high environmental and social costs and serious human rights violations.

name: András GYÜRK
text: in writing. - A decisive amount of scientific evidence proves the harmful effects of trans fatty acids produced by industry. Excessive consumption of them not only increases the risk of cardiovascular disease, but can also be associated with morbid obesity as well as type 2 diabetes. Mandatory labeling, voluntary commitments by industry alone, do not provide sufficient protection for consumers. A similar conclusion was reached in a report published by the European Commission in December 2015: the most effective means of prevention could be a legal restriction on the content of industrial trans fats. Hungary was one of the first to regulate the highest acceptable level of trans fatty acids in foods in 2014, after Denmark and Austria. The regulation does not allow the placing on the market of foods with a trans fat content of more than 2 grams per 100 grams of total fat content. The Hungarian example has since been followed by Latvia. In the short term following the introduction of binding legislation, the proportion of foods containing trans fats above the legal limit has decreased significantly in the countries concerned, with significant public health benefits. It is noteworthy that the food industry, recognizing its social responsibility, is playing an increasingly important role in reducing trans fats. Taking advantage of the consensus situation, it is therefore important for the European Commission to propose EU limit values ​​for these artificial fats as soon as possible.

name: Marian HARKIN
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this resolution that concerns EU legislation to regulate the content of industrially produced TFAs in foodstuffs. Scientific evidence shows that TFAs can lead to an increased risk of cardiovascular disease, infertility, endometriosis, gallstones, Alzheimer’s disease, diabetes, obesity and some cancers. Unfortunately, labelling measures have failed to be effective as only one in three consumers in the EU have knowledge about TFAs. Action must be taken to raise awareness through the education system and media campaigns. This resolution calls on the Commission to collaborate with the Member States with a view to increasing nutritional literacy, encouraging and enabling consumers to make healthier food choices and engaging with the industry to encourage the healthy reformulation of their products.

name: Brian HAYES
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour since I have no objections.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: written.- I voted in favor of the European Parliament Resolution on trans fatty acids primarily because of the negative consequences they have on health.This is a big problem for young people who often consume fast food and thus ingest an excessive amount of the acids in question, which are cheap but harmful.Another problem is that a large part of consumers are not aware of what trans-fatty acids are and what negative consequences they bring.Therefore, I support the proposal to limit the amount of the same in products and to launch information campaigns on the health effects of trans fatty acids.I believe that, for example, olive oil can be a healthy and effective alternative to trans-fatty acids.

name: Jean-François JALKH
text: in writing.- I am convinced of the need to limit, as much as possible, the amount of trans fatty acids in our diet, because of their scientifically recognized harmful effects on our health.The group to which I belong, the ENF, has also underlined the absence of harmfulness of trans fatty acids of natural origin and calls for consideration of national particularities in the regulation of the content of foods in trans fatty acids..I voted for.

name: Benedek JÁVOR
text: in writing. - The European Parliament, with the support of the Green Group (586 in favor, 19 against, 38 abstentions), voted in favor of the resolution on trans fats, calling on the European Commission to set a legal EU limit for the use of industrial trans fats as soon as possible. further steps are needed. Indeed, several studies and international organizations have shown that high levels of trans fats pose a risk to human health. Industrially produced foods and soft drinks contain high levels of trans fatty acids, especially foods made from cheap ingredients or industrially produced foods. Excessive consumption of trans fatty acids can cause obesity and increase the risk of certain cancers and cardiovascular disease. The European Union has a duty to take action against their excessive use. Adequate consumer information remains unresolved, but more importantly, the introduction of regulation at European level goes beyond the specific measures of the Member States.

name: Petr JEŽEK
text: in writing. ‒ Industrial trans fats can be found in anything from fast food to bakery products, chips and margarine, however scientific research has linked the excessive consumption of them with obesity, diabetes, infertility, Alzheimer’s and cardiovascular diseases. With 660 000 deaths annually in the EU, heart disease is one of Europe’s biggest killers. Given that trans fats bring more risk of heart disease than any other macro-nutrient on a per-calorie basis, it is important that we limit their consumption and that consumers know when they are eating them. Currently, no EU legislation regulates the content of trans fats in food products or requires their labelling, although some countries do. Imposing limits proved efficient and reduced death caused by heart disease significantly, like in Denmark. I believe the EU should follow this path, which is what the text calls for.

name: Marc JOULAUD
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of the report on trans fatty acids (TFA).Present in many industrial food products, TFAs consumed in too large quantities participate in the formation of cardiovascular problems, diabetes, infertility or obesity.This text calls on the European Commission to set a European limit for all foods containing trans fatty acids.I welcome this decision, which also falls within the framework of strengthening social justice in favor of consumers, as TFAs are generally present in the cheapest foods, exposing lower-income people more.I am delighted that this report was adopted by a large majority.

name: Philippe JUVIN
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of this resolution which asks the Commission to set a limit for trans fatty acids for all processed foods, like what is already done in countries such as Denmark, Austria orHungary.However, I voted against all the paragraphs and amendments that would have had the effect of stigmatizing agricultural production.Their protection is guaranteed since the resolution confirms that the limit content would only concern trans fatty acids of industrial production.

name: Afzal KHAN
text: in writing. ‒ Artificial trans fats are linked to a number of health problems, including heart disease, which is the leading cause of death in Europe. Labour MEPs are seeking to protect consumer health by demanding legal limits on the amount of trans fats in food.

name: Kateřina KONEČNÁ
text: in writing. - On 26 October 2016, at the plenary session of the European Parliament in Strasbourg, we voted on an oral question to the European Commission, followed by a resolution on the issue of trans fats. Trans fats in food have been shown to increase the level of unhealthy cholesterol in their consumers, contribute to the development of cardiovascular disease and to the development of diabetes and some types of tumors and allergies. They are even associated with Alzheimer's infertility. It is found, for example, in various spreads, margarines, long-lasting pastries, confectionery, chocolate substitutes, potato chips, biscuits and mayonnaise. That is, in a relatively wide range of everyday foods. The present resolution calls on the European Commission to propose a binding limit for industrially used trans fats as soon as possible in order to reduce their intake among all sections of the population. In addition, the text mentions a number of very important related issues, such as the proper labeling of prepacked foods containing trans fatty acids, the lack of information for consumers and even the alarming tendency to choose unhealthy foods in low-income households. I am very glad that I was able to support such a proposal.

name: Ádám KÓSA
text: in writing. - A decisive amount of scientific evidence proves the harmful effects of trans fatty acids produced by industry. Excessive consumption of them not only increases the risk of cardiovascular disease, but can also be associated with morbid obesity as well as type 2 diabetes. Mandatory labeling, voluntary commitments by industry alone, do not provide sufficient protection for consumers. A similar conclusion was reached in a report published by the European Commission in December 2015: the most effective means of prevention could be a legal restriction on the content of industrial trans fats. Hungary was one of the first to regulate the highest acceptable level of trans fatty acids in foods in 2014, after Denmark and Austria. The regulation does not allow the placing on the market of foods with a trans fat content of more than 2 grams per 100 grams of total fat content. The Hungarian example has since been followed by Latvia. In the short term following the introduction of binding legislation, the proportion of foods containing trans fats above the legal limit has fallen significantly in the countries concerned, with significant public health benefits. It is noteworthy that the food industry, recognizing its social responsibility, is playing an increasingly important role in reducing trans fats. Taking advantage of the consensus situation, it is therefore important for the European Commission to propose EU limit values ​​for these artificial fats as soon as possible. Based on all this, I voted in favor of the resolution.

name: Stelios KOULOGLOU
text: in writing. ‒ The report aims to assess the impact of appropriate means that could enable consumers to have healthier food. Trans fats are not considered as safe and their percentage should be as low as possible. The resolution establishes a legal limit on the percentage of trans fats on the total fats per product. I voted in favour of this resolution, which had a large support within the European Parliament.

name: Giovanni LA VIA
text: in writing. - Trans fatty acids (TFAs) are unsaturated fats which can be found in foods obtained from ruminants and in partially hydrogenated vegetable oils produced industrially. Unfortunately, the high consumption of these fats is proportional to an increased risk of cardiovascular disease, diabetes, obesity, infertility and Alzheimer's disease, and are more frequently used in cheaper foods, causing consumers of lower socioeconomic status. are more exposed to such diseases. Denmark was the first Member State to have implemented a national plan regulating the use of TFAs and which has had positive results in decreasing deaths from cardiovascular disease. Parliament's motion for a resolution calls on the Commission to introduce European standards to limit the quantities of industrially produced TFAs within two years and to improve nutritional literacy by helping consumers to make informed and informed nutritional choices. Citizens are often exposed to unhealthy foods and, as chairman of the Committee on the Environment, Health and Food Safety, I believe it is the duty of the institutions to ensure that this is regulated. For these reasons, I have decided to support the motion for a resolution on trans fatty acids.

name: Gilles LEBRETON
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of this motion for a resolution, co-authored by Mireille d'Ornano, because it aims to regulate the content of "trans fatty acids" in foods in the European Union.

name: Constance LE GRIP
text: in writing.- Consuming too much tans fatty acids causes increased risks of cardiovascular disease, diabetes and cancer.However, the labeling measures that currently exist are insufficient to prevent them.I therefore supported this resolution, which calls on the Commission to act in favor of consumer protection by limiting the content of trans fatty acids in industrial foodstuffs.Attached to the enhancement of agricultural products, I believe that such measures should not concern foods in which these fatty acids are naturally present, like milk or meat.

name: Marine LE PEN
text: in writing. - I voted for the resolution on trans fatty acids. These induce risks for human health: increased risk of developing cardiovascular diseases, gallstones, diabetes and certain cancers in particular. Certain inexpensive foods have trans fatty acid contents well above the maximum recommended standards: these are in particular bakery products and industrial biscuits or similar products. The report underlines the insufficiency of Regulation (EU) No 1169/2011 of 25 October 2011 concerning information to consumers on foodstuffs: this does not allow the immediate identification of the content of trans fatty acids in a food by reading its labeling. The resolution proposes the introduction of new regulations on the content of trans fatty acids in foods. Preceded by an impact study, this would be introduced within two years. Rightly, Mireille d´Ornano, co-editor of the resolution, stressed that a regulation of the content of trans fatty acids in foods must take into account national specificities (consumption habits, gastronomy, etc.). The ENF group also insisted that naturally occurring trans fatty acids are harmless.

name: Bogusław LIBERADZKI
text: in writing.- Trans fats are one of the most dangerous food ingredients.They increase the risk of heart disease and the circulatory system.They are commonly added to foods to improve their texture and extend their shelf life.The World Health Organization reports that removing hydrogenated vegetable fats from the diet has significant health benefits.We should follow the example of Denmark, Austria, Latvia and Hungary, which already have a ban on the addition of trans fats to food, and the United States, where the Food and Drug Administration has instructed food manufacturers to completely exclude trans fats from food by 2018.This will potentially save the lives of tens of thousands of lives each year.

name: Philippe LOISEAU
text: in writing.- My colleague Mireille d´Ornano, from the ENVI committee, was the co-editor of this motion for a resolution.It is indeed imperative to limit the content of trans fatty acids, given their deleterious effects, now proven, on human health.Our group stressed that trans fatty acids of natural origin are harmless, that regulation of the content of trans fatty acids in foods must take into account national specificities (consumption habits, gastronomy) and that it is appropriatenot to neglect incentive measures for agro-food companies.I therefore voted FOR this motion for a resolution.

name: Javi LÓPEZ
text: written.- I voted in favor of this resolution, because it includes a series of measures in relation to trans fatty acids;They are a type of unsaturated fatty acids that have been widely used by the food industry since the 1950s. Measures such as: reporting their presence in food and in the general diet of the Union population.Present current approaches to limiting its use worldwide and the effectiveness of such approaches, with an emphasis on legal limits, mandatory labeling, and voluntary reformulation.The report suggests that setting a legal limit for its industrial content in food would be the most effective measure in terms of public health, consumer protection and compatibility with the single market.In principle, the prohibition or limitation of these fats in food and the regulation by the Commission are advocated.

name: Paloma LÓPEZ BERMEJO
