text: written.- I voted in favor of this resolution, because I consider it important to regulate and establish limits on the presence of industrial trans fats in food.Consuming these trans fats through industrially produced partially hydrogenated vegetable oils has been associated with an increased risk of cardiovascular disease, infertility, Alzheimer's disease, obesity, and some types of cancer.It is therefore urgent for the Commission to issue a legislative proposal setting legally binding limits for trans fats.

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this motion that calls for the introduction of mandatory limits on industrially-produced trans-fatty acids (TFAs).

name: Petr MACH
text: in writing.- I voted against.The report encourages the EU to regulate the proportion of so-called trans-fatty acids in food, and I believe that a Europe-wide regulation on the maximum proportion of so-called trans-fatty acids in food would be difficult to control.I would leave it to the Member States to control whether they want and can control the content of so-called trans fatty acids in food.Different national practices would then show what type of regulation is most effective.

name: Ivana MALETIĆ
text: written. - Frequent consumption of industrially produced, partially hydrogenated vegetable oils is associated with increased risks of cardiovascular disease, infertility, endometriosis, gallstones, Alzheimer's disease, diabetes, obesity and some forms of cancer. It is recommended by EFSA that the intake of trans fatty acids be as low as possible within a diet that meets nutritional needs. International research shows that policies aimed at limiting the content of trans fatty acids in food lead to a reduction in the level of trans fatty acids without increasing the total fat content, and EU legislation does not prescribe the content of trans fatty acids in food products or require their labeling. Appropriate decisions to reduce the intake of industrial trans fatty acids should be taken at EU level. As consumers are not aware of the negative health effects of trans fatty acids, mandatory labeling of trans fatty acids in order to reduce trans fatty acid intake among European citizens is an important step, so I supported this resolution.

name: Vladimír MAŇKA
text: in writing. - According to WHO recommendations, daily consumption of trans fats, which are naturally found in plant and animal foods, should not exceed 1% of daily intake. However, there are high levels of foods with industrially produced trans fats in the EU market, the consumption of which poses a health risk to humans. They are mainly contained in cheaper foods that poorer people buy. Evidence confirms that restriction of these substances can significantly contribute to improving the health of the population. The USA and some European countries (Denmark, Austria, Latvia, Hungary) have already introduced measures restricting the use of industrially produced trans fats in the food industry. The protection of health and the safety of safe and wholesome food are among the Union's priorities, and the Member States and the Commission must urgently propose measures in this area to limit the nutritional use of industrially produced acids, while ensuring awareness and information on these substances.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: in writing.- I am voting in favor of the motion for a resolution on trans fats, for the reasons I mentioned in detail in my speech to the European Parliament in Strasbourg on 25 October 2016, and because this motion for a resolution is complete and well-founded.

name: Dominique MARTIN
text: in writing.- I voted for this motion for a resolution.This proposal aims to strengthen European legislation on standards and identification of the content of trans fatty acids in foods, especially in the food industry, because of its harmfulness to human health.The ENF group is co-editor, and insists on taking national dietary habits into account in order to adapt standards.

name: Georg MAYER
text: written.- This resolution deals with trans fats and their effects on public health.Consumer protection is to be strengthened through mandatory labeling.I can only support that and therefore I agree with this resolution.

name: Valentinas MAZURONIS
text: in writing. - I voted in favor of the EP resolution on trans fats (RRT). Industrial trans fats are used in a variety of foods, from fast food and margarine to chips and candy. However, research suggests that their overuse can lead to cardiovascular disease, diabetes, atherosclerosis and obesity. 660,000 people die of heart disease in the European Union every year. people, accounting for 14% of total EU mortality. This resolution therefore seeks to limit the use of these artificial fats. So far, neither the restriction nor the labeling of trans fats is regulated at EU level. However, certain measures are in place in individual Member States. For example, 2006 U.S. food manufacturers have been required to label their products for the presence of trans fats. This has led the food industry to significantly reduce their use. The introduction of mandatory restrictions is the most effective solution and would help reduce the exposure to the largest sources of trans fats and save lives.

name: Jean-Luc MÉLENCHON
text: in writing.- Trans fatty acids (TFA) are unsaturated fatty acids found in dairy products and meat as well as in industrial vegetable oils.These AGTs are used by the food industry for their specific characteristics (consistency) and above all for their low production cost.They are found in fast food, prepared meals and generally in all kinds of processed foods.Their increased consumption leads, according to the European Food Safety Authority (EFSA), to an increase in cholesterol and triglycerides, and promotes the appearance of cancers.The resolution recommends limiting TFAs with the establishment of a% limit for each type of product.I vote for this text regretting that the impact of industrial processes is not more strongly questioned in the food and health sector.

name: Joëlle MÉLIN
text: in writing.- My colleague Mireille d'Ornano from the ENVI committee was the co-editor of this motion for a resolution.It is indeed imperative to limit the content of trans fatty acids in view of their deleterious effects, now proven, on human health.Our group stressed that trans fatty acids of natural origin are harmless, that regulation of the content of trans fatty acids in foods must take into account national specificities (consumption habits, gastronomy) and that it is appropriatenot to neglect incentive measures for agro-food companies.I therefore voted for this motion for a resolution.

name: Nuno MELO
text: in writing.- Trans fatty acids (TFAs) are a specific type of unsaturated fat.The issue of TFAs is a priority for Parliament, which reiterates its concern about the risks that TFAs pose to human health.The food industry sector should favor alternative solutions that respect health and environmental standards, such as, for example, the use of improved oils, new fat modification processes or the combination of AGT replacement ingredients (fibers, celluloses, starches), protein mixtures, etc.).We must work for a healthier diet.Hence my vote in favor.

name: Roberta METSOLA
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this resolution which seeks to set mandatory limits on industrially-produced fatty acids that put people at greater risk of a vast range of diseases.

name: Louis MICHEL
text: written. - It would be good to end trans fatty acids in our diet. Trans fatty acids do not contribute to a better nutritional value or a higher quality of the diet. On the contrary - the consumption of foods containing trans fats puts a heavy burden on our health and trans fatty acids have been shown to increase the risk of cardiovascular disease, Alzheimer's, diabetes and obesity. Consumers are hardly aware of the health risks of trans fatty acids. It seems plausible that labeling, even mandatory labeling, can lead to a change in consumer behavior. Still, in my opinion this does not guarantee less consumption and therefore fewer health risks. It is therefore more appropriate, as also argues in the resolution, to better inform consumers through other channels about the existing risks and to impose maximum standards on food manufacturers for the use of these harmful fats. In Denmark there is a maximum standard for trans fatty acids of 2%. The positive health effect of this has now been clearly demonstrated. In the US, trans fatty acids will be banned from foods in 2018. So if we want to do public health a service and preserve the export opportunities for quality food to the US, we would do well to limit the use of trans fatty acids in food.

name: Marlene MIZZI
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report, which calls to accept an EU legal limit subject to the need for a comprehensive impact assessment on industry and the availability of the necessary instruments to assist industry in an eventual transition. Using palm oil is one way to lower trans fat levels. The semi-fluid or solid consistency of palm oil makes it a suitable alternative to partially hydrogenated oils and fats, which contain increased levels of trans fatty acids. In food applications, palm oil is usually blended with other vegetable oils, rich in polyunsaturated fatty acids (PUFA). This improves the nutritional composition of the final food product (i.e. by increasing the PUFA content of the final food product whilst retaining the palm oil functionalities).

name: Csaba MOLNÁR
text: in writing. - The report of the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Food Safety assumes that trans fatty acids are mostly consumed in the form of industrially produced, partly hydrogenated, vegetable oils modified with added hydrogen atoms. Now, both the European Food Safety Authority, the WHO and the US Food and Drug Administration consider it important to reduce the consumption of trans fatty acids, recognizing that they are dangerous to health. The draft therefore calls for EU action to significantly reduce the population's intake of trans fats, asking the Commission to set a legal EU limit value for industrial trans fats as soon as possible. He notes that, according to the WHO, a labeling policy for trans fats is the most costly solution, while in countries where a ban on trans fats has been introduced, the financial impact has been minimal given the low implementation and control costs. I voted in favor of the motion.

name: Bernard MONOT
text: in writing.- The report underlines that despite the proven dangers of the consumption of trans fatty acids for human health, their consumption persists among the most modest categories of the population, even if, for the European population as a whole, it remains low.below WHO recommendations.Indeed, some inexpensive foods have trans fatty acid contents well above the maximum recommended standards (bakery, industrial cookies).In addition, the report highlights the insufficiency of consumer information.The motion for a resolution therefore recommends the introduction of new European regulations on the content of trans fatty acids in foods within two years.I voted for.

name: Cláudia MONTEIRO DE AGUIAR
text: in writing. - Trans fatty acids (AGT) are a specific type of unsaturated fat that can be found naturally in foods derived from ruminants, such as dairy products and meat, and also in some plants and products of plant origin. They are essentially present in partially hydrogenated vegetable oils of industrial production (vegetable oils that are altered with the addition of hydrogen atoms and used for frying and cooking and in processed foods, in order to extend the shelf life). This resolution only concerns industrially produced fatty acids. The theme of AGT is a concern with the risks that it can pose to human health. I agree that the proposal must be accompanied by an impact assessment to calculate the costs of industrial overhaul that may result from the imposition of mandatory limits and to assess the risk that these costs will be borne by consumers. I argue that the Commission should work with Member States to increase knowledge in the field of nutrition, by encouraging consumers and allowing them to make healthier food choices.

name: Sophie MONTEL
text: in writing.- This report underlines that despite the proven dangers of the consumption of trans fatty acids for human health, their consumption persists among the most modest categories of the population, even if, for the European population as a whole, it remains low.- below WHO recommendations (less than 1% per day).It is therefore important to seek to reduce the consumption of these fatty acids and I am therefore in favor of this report.

name: Claude MORAES
text: in writing. ‒ Artificial trans fats are linked to a number of health problems, including heart disease, which is the leading cause of death in Europe. Labour MEPs are seeking to protect consumer health by demanding legal limits on the amount of trans fats in food.

name: Nadine MORANO
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of this text on trans fatty acids, the excessive consumption of which increases the risk of disease, especially cardiovascular disease.While these acids are naturally present in many foods (milk, meat, etc.), they are also used in industrial foods.It is therefore necessary to set a limit for trans fatty acids for these processed foods.This is particularly the aim of this text.

name: József NAGY
text: in writing. - I voted in favor of the motion for a resolution on trans fats. In today’s rushed world, people tend to pay less attention to getting the substances, minerals, vitamins they need for their bodies with the help of a proper, healthy diet. We only begin to understand the close link between diet and health when we experience the negative effects of malnutrition on our own skin. This can start with constant exhaustion, headaches, but can also lead to quite serious problems such as heart disease. Trans fatty acids are dangerous and we are often unaware of how many foods show up. They are very popular with fast food chains, for example, as they are cheap and can be used multiple times. In the United States, for example, by 2018, food manufacturers will have to phase out such acids. We have many tools at our disposal to regulate the subject, we just have to find the most appropriate one. I certainly welcome the fact that the petitioner has drawn attention to this issue.

name: Victor NEGRESCU
text: in writing. ‒ Trans-fatty acids (TFAs) are a type of unsaturated fats that are uncommon in nature but became commonly produced on an industrial scale from vegetable fats to be used for producing margarine, snack food, packaged baked goods and frying fast food. I have voted for this motion for a resolution that reiterates the concern of the risks posed by TFAs to human health.

name: Franz OBERMAYR
text: written.- I voted in favor of this report because this motion for a resolution strengthens consumers' rights and combats obesity, while at the same time advocating consumer health.

name: Urmas PAET
text: in writing.- I supported.Trans fats are harmful to human health, but for various reasons it is often used in the food industry and people are often unaware of its effects on their health.Therefore, in order to reduce the use of trans fats in the food industry, it is necessary to approach the issue at EU level and to establish common standards to limit the use of trans fats.

name: Demetris PAPADAKIS
text: in writing. - High consumption of trans fats is a risk factor, especially for the development of coronary heart disease, a disease that is responsible for around 660,000 deaths per year in the EU. These fatty acids are used more in cheaper foods, which means that people with low income are more exposed to foods high in trans fats. This, of course, exacerbates health inequalities. I voted in favor of this resolution, which calls for mandatory limits on the use of industrially produced, partially hydrogenated vegetable oils (trans fats) which increase the risk of cardiovascular disease, infertility, Alzheimer's, diabetes and obesity. The labeling of these products is important but as a measure is not enough. It must be accompanied by the imposition of mandatory limits.

name: Kostas PAPADAKIS
text: in writing. - The resolution on "trans - fatty" acids proves that the EU, by serving business profits, puts the lives and health of workers at great risk. The specific acids present in natural foods are mainly contained in industrial vegetable oils and processed foods to extend their shelf life. They are used in cheap foods intended for the working class and are blamed for causing serious diseases. The resolution calls on the Commission to introduce legislation to impose a "trans-fat" content limit on food, but combines it with a report on the economic impact on industrial enterprises, under the guise of passing on costs to consumers. Characteristic was the intervention of the relevant industries that demanded and managed not to ban, in case of restriction of "trans - fats", the use of substitutes, such as palm oil, which are equally dangerous. The KKE European Parliamentary Group is in favor of a complete ban on the use of "trans-fatty" acids and a ban on their substitution by products of corresponding danger. He emphasizes that even the health of workers is sacrificed on the altar of the profitability of business groups, until the working people decide to take the keys of power and the economy into their own hands.

name: Margot PARKER
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP is very concerned about the health implications of TFAs and believes that the UK Parliament should be free to legislate on this very important issue. For this reason we decided to abstain on this non-binding motion for a resolution.

name: Aldo PATRICIELLO
text: in writing.- Considering that TFAs are a particular type of unsaturated fat and that a high intake of TFA increases the risk of developing coronary heart disease and, taking into account the WHO recommendations regarding the consumption of these fats, I believe that efforts should be intensifiedat a European level to limit the intake of industrial TFAs.I am also convinced that it is up to the EU to take appropriate decisions to regulate this sector and therefore I voted in favor.

name: Piernicola PEDICINI
text: in writing. - It is scientifically proven that the intake of trans fats increases cardiovascular risk, obesity and diabetes. It is almost superfluous to remember that these types of non-communicable diseases are the leading cause of death in the world. Yet trans fatty acids are found in industrially produced partially hydrogenated oils used in cookies, cakes, popcorn, crackers, margarines, and many other supermarket products. In short, all foods that are eaten mainly by children. We bear in mind that the WHO has reported that 1 in 3 children between 6 and 9 years of age in the EU is obese and that around 7% of European health expenditure is used in the treatment of diseases related to obesity such as diabetes, arterial hypertension, cardiovascular pathologies. With this resolution we call on the Commission to introduce a legal limit on trans fat content to reduce their intake by EU citizens. I therefore voted positively on both the final text and our unfortunately not passed amendment, which asked to ensure that policies aimed at limiting the TFA content in processed food products do not incentivize food producers to increase the amount of palm oil. in these products.

name: Marijana PETIR
text: written. - I supported the Resolution asking the European Commission to propose a legal limit for the level of industrial trans fatty acids in food products within two years. Consumption of trans fats is associated with increased risks of cardiovascular disease, diabetes, infertility, gallstones, endometriosis, Alzheimer’s disease, and some forms of cancer. Also, in view of the increasing incidence of obesity, including in children, I welcome the efforts made by the European Parliament to adopt, in cooperation with the Commission, the necessary acts to reduce the intake of trans fatty acids in food. Although there are regulations in Croatia that limit the level of trans fatty acids in food, this problem must be regulated at the European level due to the single market. That is where I see the value of this initiative of the European Parliament. Trans-fatty acids exist in foods of natural origin, and their industrial production is exclusively related to reducing the cost of food production. A balanced and natural diet with quality agricultural products is once again proving to be the right choice, while various forms of “artificial” and industrially produced food, often motivated solely by profit, are once again proving harmful to health.

name: Florian PHILIPPOT
text: in writing. - The purpose of this motion for a resolution is to lead to European regulations on the content of trans fatty acids in foods. The report underlines that despite the proven dangers of the consumption of trans fatty acids for human health, their consumption persists among the most modest categories of the population, even if, for the European population as a whole, it remains unchanged. below WHO recommendations (less than 1% per day). Indeed, some inexpensive foods have trans fatty acid contents well above the recommended maximum standards: these are in particular bakery products as well as industrial biscuits or similar products. In addition, the report underlines the insufficiency of Regulation (EU) No 1169/2011 of 25 October 2011 concerning information to consumers on foodstuffs: this does not allow immediate identification of the fatty acid content. trans of a food by reading its labeling. The motion for a resolution therefore proposes the introduction of new European regulations on the content of trans fatty acids in foods. Preceded by an impact study, this would be introduced within two years. I therefore voted for this text.

name: Tonino PICULA
text: written. - This resolution applies only to industrially produced fatty acids, the consumption of which is associated with increased risks of cardiovascular disease, infertility, diabetes, obesity, some forms of cancer, etc. EFSA, WHO and FDA agree on the harmful effects of trans fatty acids on human health. To date, the EU does not prescribe the content of trans fatty acids in food products or require their labeling. However, in some Member States such as Denmark, Austria, Latvia and Hungary, there is legislation restricting the content of trans fatty acids in food products. Denmark is proof that such legislative solutions can successfully reduce the number of deaths from cardiovascular diseases. It is necessary to introduce just such measures at Union level. The mere introduction of mandatory labeling of trans fatty acids on products is an insufficient mechanism compared to mandatory restrictions, as consumers are not aware of the negative impact of trans fatty acids. S & amp; D has warned about this problem before. Parliament is now quite united in its message to the Commission, and I believe that the Commission must establish legal limits for the values ​​of industrial trans fatty acids as soon as possible, because such a solution alone can save tens of thousands of lives a year.

name: João PIMENTA LOPES
text: in writing.- The consumption of this type of fats has been associated with the risk of cardiovascular disease, infertility, obesity and some types of cancer.Agencies like the WHO, EFSA and FDA warn of the dangers of this consumption and recommend that it be kept as small as possible.We are therefore in favor of limiting the use and consumption of trans fatty acids.However, the promotion of healthy eating and fresh, low-processed products is not only done by legislating to improve labeling.It is important to bear in mind that many of these products are distinguished by their low price.In other words, the consumption of processed foods is now associated with situations of economic failure, which prevents access to quality and healthy products.No strategy to promote healthy eating should ignore this fact.Plus, you must actively fight it.

name: Miroslav POCHE
text: in writing. - I supported the proposed resolution focusing on the harmfulness and health risks associated with the consumption of foods containing industrially produced fatty acids. For example, these substances are found in foods that are sold in many fast food establishments because fats containing trans fatty acids are cheaper and can be used repeatedly. It is no secret that consuming such foods can have serious consequences for human health, as it causes cardiovascular disease, gallstones and, last but not least, can result in various cancers. That is why I fully agree with Parliament's call for states to introduce legal limit values ​​for industrially produced trans-fatty acids, thus protecting the health of their citizens. A positive example in this respect is Denmark, where the introduction of similar measures has had a positive effect on reducing the number of deaths due to cardiovascular disease.

name: Tomasz Piotr PORĘBA
text: in writing. - The motion for a resolution sets out Parliament's strategic goals to reduce the consumption of artificial trans fats at EU level. Trans fatty acids are unsaturated fats found in food produced from ruminants and in artificial, partially hydrogenated vegetable oils. The consumption of artificial vegetable oils has been associated with an increased risk of cardiovascular disease. High consumption of trans fats is a risk factor that particularly favors the development of ischemic heart disease. The products currently produced with the use of trans fats are fast food, quick meals or salty and savory snacks and therefore are classified as highly processed food. While most EU Member State citizens consume little trans fat, their consumption is still significant in some social groups, contributing to excessively high mortality in these groups. Important evidence has emerged since the adoption of Regulation 1169/2011 of the benefits of reducing artificial trans fats in food. The resolution calls on the Commission to propose mandatory limits on artificial trans fats to protect public health. The restriction on trans fat in food has undoubtedly positive health effects, and the industry is not suffering any negative consequences. I hereby supported the motion for a resolution.

name: Franck PROUST
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of the resolution allowing progress on the subject of industrial trans fatty acids (TFAs).These unsaturated fatty acids are present in many food products and can constitute a risk and facilitate the onset of diseases, especially coronary heart disease.It is also interesting to note that the European Union, which is being set up as a model in terms of food protection and standards, is just starting to reflect on the risks of TFAs.However, the United States or Canada, with which we have just ratified the CETA trade agreement, have already started to ban TFAs or already consider them to be not without risk.Manufacturers must quickly find a replacement for these TFAs, which is not easy because it could transform both the texture and above all the taste of certain foods.Either way, consumer health comes first!

name: Laurenţiu REBEGA
text: signed up.- Industrially produced fatty acids are most often used in cheap foods, directly affecting low-income people, who are more exposed to the risk of developing cardiovascular disease, infertility, Alzheimer's, diabetes and obesity.I believe that the imposition of mandatory limits on industrially produced fatty acids, especially in connection with the consumption of industrially produced, partially hydrogenated oils, means paying more attention to the health of citizens.

name: Julia REID
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP is very concerned about the health implications of TFAs and believes that the UK Parliament should be free to legislate on this very important issue. For this reason we decided to abstain on this non-binding motion for a resolution.

name: Sofia RIBEIRO
text: in writing.- I voted in favor, since trans fatty acids (TFAs) are a specific type of unsaturated fat.TFAs are essentially present in partially hydrogenated vegetable oils from industrial production.Considering that frequent consumption of partially hydrogenated vegetable oils from industrial production has been associated with an increased risk of cardiovascular disease, infertility, endometriosis, gallstones, Alzheimer's disease, diabetes, obesity and some types of cancer, this report asks the CommissionEuropean Union to establish as soon as possible a legal limit for industrial AGT in all food products in order to reduce their consumption by all groups of the population.

name: Frédérique RIES
text: in writing. - It is by an overwhelming majority of 586 votes to 19 that this afternoon, the European Parliament adopted a resolution to limit as much as possible trans fatty acids in the diet. These added industrial fatty acids are harmful to everyone's health, increase bad cholesterol and constitute an increased risk of developing cardiovascular disease, diabetes, obesity, etc. TFAs are found en masse in products as varied as fast food, ice cream, pastries, frozen pizzas and margarines. TFAs naturally present in foods derived from ruminants (dairy products and meat) or in certain products of plant origin (leeks, peas, lettuce, rapeseed oil) are therefore not in the sights of MEPs. These, according to the doctors, are not a problem. It is hoped that the Commission will soon make a proposal based on today's vote and will limit the presence of AGT in oils and fats to 2%. The European Union would thus translate at the level of the 28 States the ambitious policies put in place in Denmark since 2003 and in three other Member States since that date, which have made it possible to reduce the number of deaths caused by cardiovascular diseases.

name: Liliana RODRIGUES
text: in writing. - Although trans fatty acids (AGT) are found naturally in foods derived from ruminants, such as dairy products and meat, and also in some plants and products of plant origin (leeks, peas, lettuce, rapeseed oil), they are essentially present in production partially hydrogenated vegetable oils. This resolution only concerns industrially produced fatty acids. Many restaurants and fast food establishments use AGT to fry food, as these fats are cheap and can be reused several times in industrial fryers. The frequent consumption of these has been associated with an increased risk of cardiovascular disease (more than any other factor), infertility, endometriosis, gallstones, Alzheimer's disease, diabetes, obesity and some types of cancer. The consumption of TFA should be as low as possible in the context of a nutritionally adequate diet (less than 1% of the daily energy dose). It is necessary for the European Commission to establish as soon as possible a legal limit for industrial AGT (both as an ingredient and as a final product) in all food products in order to reduce their consumption by all groups of the population.

name: Inma RODRÍGUEZ-PIÑERO
text: written. - Trans fatty acids (TFA) are a type of unsaturated fatty acids that have been widely used by the food industry since the 1950s. They are added to foods because they improve the texture of processed foods, increase their shelf life, or as a cheap alternative to other fats. There is now a broad scientific consensus that high trans consumption significantly increases the risk of coronary heart disease, and may also be associated with other diseases more than any other nutrient per unit of calories. Despite the fact that the average consumption of these fats in the Union is below the recommended levels at national and international level, this is not the case for all population groups. For these reasons, I have voted in favor of this oral question calling for legislative measures aimed at eliminating in the long term the presence of TFA in the Union food supply chain, either through the introduction of mandatory labeling on TFA content , or by means of a Union legal limit to the content of industrial TFA in all food products.

name: Claude ROLIN
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of the motion for a legislative resolution on industrially produced trans fatty acids (TFAs) calling for community action to reduce their overall consumption.Indeed, there is an urgent need to establish a European limit on the legal content of TFAs in all foods in view of the risks they represent for the health of European citizens.

name: Fernando RUAS
text: in writing. - (PT) I voted strongly and favorably for this motion for a European Parliament resolution on trans-industrial fatty acids (TFAs). In practice, the aim is for the European Commission to implement, within two years, a legal limit for TFAs in all food products, taking into account the high risk that this type of fats represents for public health. The proposal also contains the idea of ​​proposing to the food industry sector that it adopt alternative solutions to this type of fatty acids that are respectful of environmental and health standards and that, in this way, also allow to reduce inequality between consumers, since their inclusion tends to be used in cheaper foods. To that extent, this motion for a resolution is extremely pertinent and will represent a significant evolution in terms of promoting a healthier lifestyle, by impelling the community executive to adopt legislation that regulates the content and imposes the labeling of this type of acids in food products. .

name: Tokia SAÏFI
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of this resolution which calls for setting a limit for trans fatty acids for industrial foodstuffs.Heavy use of these trans fatty acids in industrially produced foods increases the risk of developing serious health problems.It is urgent that the European Union act, because these trans fatty acids, which come from industrial production, constitute a real danger for the health of European citizens, in particular by taking measures to correct the current labeling system which is currently under way.'is found to be ineffective.

name: Lola SÁNCHEZ CALDENTEY
text: written. - At the end of 2015, the European Commission presented a report on the health problem posed by trans fats in food, but did not present the corresponding draft legislation. After a year of waiting and continuous complaints from civil society, consumer organizations, medical societies and other entities, I have voted in favor of this report to achieve a single legislation in the Union on this issue. The United States has banned the use of artificial trans fats in food products as of 2018, so this legislation would accompany European industry in its exports. The homologation of quality standards upwards should be reciprocal and not as it is expected to happen according to the ATCI. It is important to clarify that the incentive to legislate should be to reduce cardiovascular diseases, as the main cause of death in Europe and not the market, an issue that I understand is not clear in the report.

name: Daciana Octavia SÂRBU
text: in writing. ‒ Trans fats cause heart disease, and heart disease is one of Europe’s biggest killers. That’s why in this resolution the European Parliament is calling for EU-wide legal limits on industrial trans fats in foods. This policy has already been tested elsewhere. We know it works, and we know it saves lives. The solid medical evidence for the harmful effects of trans fats is in stark contrast to the low public awareness about the dangers of this macronutrient. So we need to act now, with legislation, to improve public health across Europe and especially to protect those vulnerable sub groups of the population who have greater exposure to industrial trans fats in processed food and fast food. I call on the European Commission to act as quickly as possible and to make the necessary legislative proposals to protect public health.

name: Olga SEHNALOVÁ
text: in writing. - The current situation regarding fats containing trans fatty acids in food is in many ways incomprehensible. Health and consumer organizations have long been drawing attention to the negative impact of trans fats on human health. Consumers often consume them against their will, because legislation prohibits their presence on the packaging. The Commission initially ignores the legislative commitment to publish a report with a delay of one year that heart disease is the leading cause of death in the EU and that high intakes of trans fats significantly increase the risk of heart disease. It also acknowledges that food products high in industrially produced trans fats are available on the market and that there is room for improvement in public health if their intake is reduced. A European solution is in sight, so some Member States are introducing national legislative restrictions in the meantime. I believe that it is high time to adopt common rules in the internal market, a legislative proposal to reduce trans fats in food, which is why I supported this resolution.

name: Maria Lidia SENRA RODRÍGUEZ
text: written.- I voted in favor of this resolution, because I consider it important to regulate and establish limits on the presence of industrial trans fats in food.Consuming these trans fats through industrially produced partially hydrogenated vegetable oils has been associated with an increased risk of cardiovascular disease, infertility, Alzheimer's disease, obesity, and some types of cancer.It is therefore urgent for the Commission to issue a legislative proposal setting legally binding limits for trans fats.

name: Remo SERNAGIOTTO
text: in writing.- Consumption of industrially produced trans fatty acids (TFAs) has been associated with an increased risk of various diseases, such as, for example, infertility, Alzheimer's disease, diabetes, obesity and cardiovascular disease.Unfortunately, the currently envisaged labeling measures have not led to a decrease in the consumption of foods containing these substances, since according to some studies these substances are known only by one in three consumers across the EU.It is therefore important for the Commission to present a proposal on the limits of trans fatty acids, accompanied by an impact assessment that examines the costs and benefits of industrial production, especially for small and medium-sized enterprises.I have therefore decided to vote in favor of the motion for a resolution.

name: Siôn SIMON
text: in writing. ‒ Today I voted in support of the Motion for a Resolution on Transfats. Artificial transfats are linked to a number of health problems, including heart disease, which is the leading cause of death in Europe. Labour MEPs are seeking to protect consumer health by demanding legal limits on the amount of transfats in food.

name: Monika SMOLKOVÁ
text: in writing. - I supported the European Parliament's resolution on trans-fatty acids because I agree with the widely held view that a high intake of these acids increases the risk of several diseases. Our aim in this resolution is to point out industrially produced fatty acids. Fats containing trans fatty acids are often used in restaurants and fast food establishments to immerse food fry, as they are inexpensive and can be used repeatedly. According to available sources, frequent consumption of trans fatty acids leads to a higher risk of coronary heart disease, and consumption of industrially produced vegetable oils has an impact on cardiovascular disease, infertility or gallstones. I therefore agree with the rapporteur that it is essential to raise citizens' awareness at European level of the consequences of excessive consumption of these acids. Some EU countries, such as Austria, Denmark, Latvia and Hungary, have already passed laws restricting the content of trans fats in food. The Commission should therefore come forward with a proposal setting a legal limit for industrially produced trans fats. Nutrition that benefits human health is an investment in the development of the individual. If people ate cautiously, they would reduce their medical treatment costs in the future.

name: Igor ŠOLTES
text: in writing. - Trans fatty acids are unsaturated fats that can be found in foods made from ruminants and in industrially produced foods that are partially hydrogenated. Consumption of oils containing such fats is associated with an increased risk of cardiovascular disease. High intake of such food is a risk factor for the development of coronary heart disease, which is responsible for around 660,000 deaths per year or otherwise - as much as 14% of all deaths in the European Union each year. Trans fatty acids lower the price of the final product, so they are mainly used in the preparation of fast food, certain snacks and other highly processed foods. Denmark first set restrictions on the use of trans fatty acids as early as 2003 and has achieved a reduction in cardiovascular disease to date. In a report published in December 2015, the European Commission took note of the situation and stated that it would try to limit the use of trans fatty acids in the European Union and announce the expected results. To date, the European Commission has done nothing in this area, so the European Parliament has made a proposal to limit its use. As these are substances that have a major impact on health in the long term, I supported the motion for a resolution.

name: Bart STAES
text: written. Trans fatty acids are a type of unsaturated fatty acids that, unlike unsaturated fats, are not good for health. They occur naturally in ruminants, in whose stomach bacteria provide a natural hardening of those fats. It is mainly industrially produced, partly hardened vegetable oils that have a negative effect on cardiovascular disease. Trans fats are mainly found in baking and frying fats, frying oils and hard margarines and are found in pastries, cakes and snacks. Every year 660,000 people die from heart disease or vascular disease, which is 14% of all deaths. In a December 2015 report, resulting from Regulation 1169/2011, the European Commission shows awareness of the problem, is considering various options to limit the use of trans fats and points out the consequences of this ban, but does not legal proposal. The resolution I co-approved today reiterates the call to severely limit industrial trans fats for all sections of the population. While Christian Democrats are content to label these trans fats more clearly on foodstuffs, the resolution clearly advocates limiting industrial trans fats. Studies show that limiting trans fats leads to health gains very quickly.

name: Ivan ŠTEFANEC
text: in writing.- There is an interest in raising consumer awareness of the negative effects of trans fats on human health.At present, European Union regulations do not regulate the content of trans fatty acids in food products.The proposal should establish a European Union legal limit for industrially produced trans fats in foods in order to limit their intake.

name: Beatrix von STORCH
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against the motion for a resolution which calls on the Council to support legislative options aiming at eliminating TFAs from the EU food supply chain in the long term, either through the introduction of EU mandatory TFA content labelling or through an EU legal limit on the industrial TFA content of all food. It is somewhat ironic that the very same regulators who wish to mimic Denmark’s supposed success in regulating TFAs fail to see that this undermines their justification for EU regulation. If a Member State has successfully implemented such legislation then it follows that other Member States are surely capable of similar legislation through their own democratic processes should they desire it.

name: Dubravka ŠUICA
text: written.- Trans fatty acids are naturally found in food obtained from ruminants, in some plants and in human breast milk.However, most of the trans fatty acids consumed are produced industrially.There are data on health risks that result from the consumption of trans fatty acids and are the cause of human obesity.I support the motion for a resolution on trans fatty acids (2016/2637 (RSP)), as informing about the harmful effects of industrial trans fatty acids and limiting their use can prevent the health risks of Europeans.

name: Patricija ŠULIN
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of the motion for a resolution on the oral questions on trans fatty acids.The content of trans fatty acids in food has already been significantly reduced on a voluntary basis, but unfortunately not everywhere.And even where this content has been reduced, consumption is still too high for some groups of the population, young people, low-income people.When we talk about basic foods such as milk and meat, we cannot talk about the fact that the content of trans fatty acids is harmful, as it is contained in such small quantities that do not harm health.The resolution concludes that we are aware of some of the negative effects of trans fatty acids and that it is time to take action.

name: Neoklis SYLIKIOTIS
text: in writing. - The report emphasizes the need to set mandatory limits on the use of industrially produced trans-fatty acids, which may increase the risk of cardiovascular disease, infertility, Alzheimer's, diabetes and obesity. It is also rightly emphasized that the existing measures concerning the labeling of products are not sufficient, with the result that consumers are not aware of the existence of trans-fatty acids. The report therefore calls on the Commission to propose, as soon as possible, a maximum permissible limit for the use of trans-fatty acids in all foods. For these reasons, we voted in favor of the report.

name: Eleftherios SYNADINOS
text: in writing.- It is a positive step with very significant benefits for the health of European citizens, although for us it is not the ideal proposal as we would require even more restrictions.We also disagree with the very long margin given to the Commission to set a maximum permissible trans fat content.

name: József SZÁJER
text: in writing. - A decisive amount of scientific evidence proves the harmful effects of trans fatty acids produced by industry. Excessive consumption of them not only increases the risk of cardiovascular disease, but can also be associated with morbid obesity as well as type 2 diabetes. Mandatory labeling, voluntary commitments by industry alone, do not provide sufficient protection for consumers. A similar conclusion was reached in a report published by the European Commission in December 2015: the most effective means of prevention could be a legal restriction on the content of industrial trans fats. Hungary was one of the first to regulate the highest acceptable level of trans fatty acids in foods in 2014, after Denmark and Austria. The regulation does not allow the placing on the market of foods with a trans fat content of more than 2 grams per 100 grams of total fat content. The Hungarian example has since been followed by Latvia. In the short term following the introduction of binding legislation, the proportion of foods containing trans fats above the legal limit has fallen significantly in the countries concerned, with significant public health benefits. It is noteworthy that the food industry, recognizing its social responsibility, is playing an increasingly important role in reducing trans fats. Taking advantage of the consensus situation, it is therefore important for the European Commission to propose EU limit values ​​for these artificial fats as soon as possible. Based on all this, I voted in favor of the resolution.

name: Tibor SZANYI
text: in writing. - Trans fatty acids are unsaturated fatty acids that have been used by the food industry since the 1950s in foods of ruminant origin, such as dairy and meat products and vegetable products (leeks, peas, lettuce and rapeseed oil), as well as in industrially produced, partially hydrogenated products prepared for baking in a stove and oven. According to the WHO, naturally occurring trans fatty acids, due to their relatively low intake, are unlikely to pose a health risk in current diets. However, the frequent consumption of partially hydrogenated vegetable oils carries an increased risk of developing diseases (cardiovascular disease, infertility, endometriosis, gallstones, Alzheimer's disease, diabetes, overweight and certain cancers), so EFSA recommends There has to be. The motion for a resolution reiterates its concern about the dangers of trans fats to human health and describes that the restriction of trans fats has been shown to have rapid and significant health benefits. It therefore calls on the Commission to set a legal EU limit for industrial trans fats as soon as possible in order to reduce the intake of trans fats in all sections of the population. As these fatty acids are not needed in processed foods and are even unhealthy, I voted in favor of the motion.

name: Claudia ȚAPARDEL
text: signed up. - One of the priorities of the European Union is to defend the health of its citizens. In these circumstances, the regulation of the content of food marketed in the Union is of paramount importance. One of the compounds that has caused concern in recent years is fatty acids used in the food industry to change the texture of some foods, in order to extend their shelf life or as a more convenient alternative to other fats. Following studies conducted by specialists in the field at the international level, it was discovered that a high consumption of fatty acids increases the risk of coronary heart disease and can cause other diseases. Given that four Member States (Denmark, Austria, Hungary and Latvia) have decided to limit the content of fatty acids in food by law, which has saved lives, it is necessary to take restrictive measures at European level as well. Even the World Health Organization has recommended the elimination of partially hydrogenated vegetable oils, which are part of the category of fatty acids, and in the United States, they will be banned from July 2018. In this context, it is necessary to limit, in a first phase , of the use of these compounds, so that, in the end, they are completely banned. I support this resolution.

name: Marc TARABELLA
text: in writing. - Cardio-vascular disease, infertility, Alzheimer's disease, diabetes and obesity, these are the risks that European citizens run if they consume excessively trans fatty acids in their diet. The problem is, only 30% of consumers know what a trans fatty acid (TFA) is, which exposes the other two-thirds of Europeans to potentially serious medical problems. This is why, with the vote this afternoon, we want clear labeling. This is not enough, however: the presence of these acids must also be limited. In the text voted on today, we are therefore in favor of imposing mandatory limits on industrially produced trans fatty acids which are excessively present in food. We cannot accept that citizens put their health at risk for longer. Due to the lack of national legislation in many countries, it is up to Europe to take the lead.

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: in writing. ‒ Industrial trans fats have harmful health effects and are not well understood by many consumers in the EU. The best way to mitigate the risk that trans fats cause consumers would be to effectively lower the consumption of unhealthy trans fats by establishing legal limits for them, an effort which was already tested and found to be successful in Denmark. I voted in favour of the motion for resolutions because I believe the EU needs to protect its citizens, who are often ill-informed, against a lethal and under-regulated product that is found hidden in nearly every food product on the shelves.

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: written. - Since the voters have chosen us to represent their interests at the level of the European Union, our primary goal should be their well-being in every respect, and we should pay special attention to the protection of their health. This resolution points out the harmfulness of trans fatty acids used in food products to contribute to the desired coexistence of food products and ensure a long shelf life. Namely, high intake of trans fatty acids is associated with an increased risk of cardiovascular disease, and this also refers to the development of coronary heart disease, which is the cause of about 14% of the overall mortality rate in the European Union. From the above arguments it is clear that trans fatty acids are just a cheap ingredient in the production process and I believe that it is not enough to provide consumers with information about trans fatty acids and promote healthier food choices, but we must take concrete steps to maintain health. I therefore supported the call to the European Commission to propose restrictions on the use of trans fatty acids in food in order to protect public health.

name: Romana TOMC
text: in writing.- I supported the motion for a resolution on trans fatty acids.Trans fatty acids are a special type of unsaturated fats naturally present in foods derived from ruminants such as dairy products and meat, certain plants and plant products, and are found mainly in industrially produced partially hydrogenated vegetable oils.In 2010, the European Food Safety Authority found that trans-fatty acids derived from ruminants had similar effects to those from industrial products covered by this resolution.Limiting trans fatty acid content has been shown to have rapid and significant health benefits.Unfortunately, only one in three consumers in the EU is aware of trans fatty acids, which shows that measures to label the content of these acids have not been effective and that awareness-raising measures need to be taken in the education system and media campaigns.

name: Estefanía TORRES MARTÍNEZ
text: written. - At the end of 2015, the European Commission presented a report on the health problem posed by trans fats in food, but did not present the corresponding draft legislation. After a year of waiting and continuous complaints from civil society, consumer organizations, medical societies and other entities, I have voted in favor of this report to achieve a single legislation in the Union on this issue. The United States has banned the use of artificial trans fats in food products as of 2018, so this legislation would accompany European industry in its exports. The homologation of quality standards upwards should be reciprocal and not as expected to happen according to the ATCI. It is important to clarify that the incentive to legislate should be to reduce cardiovascular diseases, as the main cause of death in Europe and not the market, an issue that I understand is not clear in the report.

name: Ramon TREMOSA i BALCELLS
text: in writing. ‒ I want to recall that the issue of TFAs is a priority for this Parliament, and I want to reiterate my concern regarding the risks that TFAs pose to human health. This resolution highlights the fact that the US has already announced that food manufacturers will have to remove partially hydrogenated oils from products sold on its domestic market from mid-2018, in the light of the conclusion from 2015 that trans fats are not generally recognised as safe; it recalls evidence that TFA limits can bring rapid and significant health benefits; highlights in this context the success of the experience in Denmark, which brought in a national limit of 2% of TFAs in oils and fats in 2003; it emphasises that most of the EU population – in particular the most vulnerable people – lack information about TFAs and the health consequences of their consumption, which can preclude consumers from making empowered choices. Vulnerable groups, including citizens with lower education and socioeconomic status, and children, are more inclined to eat food with higher TFA content.

name: Mylène TROSZCZYNSKI
text: in writing. - Trans fatty acids induce risks for human health: increased risk of the development of cardiovascular diseases, gallstones, diabetes and certain cancers in particular. The European Food Safety Authority, meanwhile, recommends consuming "as little as possible" of trans fatty acids. However, to date there are no European regulations in this area. The purpose of this motion for a resolution is to lead to European regulations on the content of trans fatty acids in foods. The report underlines that despite the proven dangers of the consumption of trans fatty acids for human health, their consumption persists among the most modest categories of the population, even if, for the European population as a whole, it remains unchanged. below WHO recommendations. Indeed, some inexpensive foods have trans fatty acid contents well above the maximum recommended standards. It is indeed important to limit the content of trans fatty acids in view of their deleterious effects, now proven, on human health. It is also important not to neglect the incentive measures for agro-food companies: these have demonstrated their effectiveness. I voted for this text.

name: Kazimierz Michał UJAZDOWSKI
text: in writing.- Trans fats are used mainly in highly processed foods - fast food and salty and spicy snacks.Consumption of such products increases the risk of cardiovascular diseases, including heart ischemia.Mandatory restrictions on trans fats in the internal market would reduce their consumption.On the example of countries that have introduced such a solution, we can see positive effects on the health level of citizens.For these arguments, I voted in favor of the resolution.

name: István UJHELYI
text: in writing.- An analysis of the latest available data confirms that, despite the reduction in trans fats in certain foods, there are still many foods in certain EU food markets that contain high levels of trans fats.I supported S & D's position on the issue.

name: Miguel URBÁN CRESPO
text: written.- At the end of 2015, the European Commission presented a report on the health problem posed by trans fats in food, but did not present the corresponding draft legislation.After a year of waiting and continuous complaints from civil society, consumer organizations, medical societies and other entities, I have voted in favor of this report to reach a single legislation in the Union on this issue.The United States has banned the use of artificial trans fats in food products as of 2018, so this legislation would accompany European industry in its exports.

name: Ernest URTASUN
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this text which calls on the Commission to propose as soon as possible mandatory limits on industrial TFAs in order to reduce their intake amongst all population groups.

name: Ivo VAJGL
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the motion for a resolution on trans fats (TFAs). Trans fats or trans-fatty acids (TFAs) are a type of unsaturated fatty acid that have been widely used in the food industry since the 1950s. Foods that may be high in trans fats include ready-made meals, frying fat for industrial use, margarine used in pastry, pre-packed bakery products, cakes, biscuits and wafers, microwave popcorn, deep-fried foods and soups and sauces. International studies show that policies aimed at restricting the TFA content of food entailing reducing TFA levels without increasing total fat content are feasible, achievable and likely to have a positive effect on public health. The European Union does not currently have legislation regulating the content of trans fats in food products or requiring their labelling. I voted in favour because I believe that the EU should introduce legal limits on the amount of industrial trans fats in processed food what would reduce exposure to the biggest sources of trans fats and save lives.

name: Ángela VALLINA
text: written.- I voted in favor of this resolution, because I consider it important to regulate and establish limits on the presence of industrial trans fats in food.Consuming these trans fats through industrially produced partially hydrogenated vegetable oils has been associated with an increased risk of cardiovascular disease, infertility, Alzheimer's disease, obesity, and some types of cancer.It is therefore urgent for the Commission to issue a legislative proposal setting legally binding limits for trans fats.

name: Hilde VAUTMANS
text: written.- Trans fats are unsaturated fatty acids that are not good for health.It is mainly the industrially produced trans fats that have a negative effect on cardiovascular disease.Trans fats are mainly found in baking and frying fats, cooking oils and hard margarines and are found in pastries, biscuits and snacks.The resolution we approved reiterates the call to severely limit industrial trans fats for all population groups.

name: Miguel VIEGAS
text: in writing.- The consumption of this type of fats has been associated with the risk of cardiovascular disease, infertility, obesity and some types of cancer.Agencies like the WHO, EFSA and FDA warn of the dangers of this consumption and recommend that it be kept as small as possible.We are therefore in favor of limiting the use and consumption of trans fatty acids.However, the promotion of healthy eating and fresh, low-processed products is not only done by legislating to improve labeling.It is important to bear in mind that many of these products are distinguished by their low price.In other words, the consumption of processed foods is now associated with situations of economic failure, which prevents access to quality and healthy products.No strategy to promote healthy eating should ignore this fact.Plus, you must actively fight it.

name: Harald VILIMSKY
text: written.- The motion for a resolution calls for the strengthening of consumer and consumer protection in health issues and criticizes the harmful effects of the currently still diverse and frequent use of trans fatty acids in the food industry and gastronomy.In view of the increasing obesity (obesity) and other diet-related diseases of the population and the enormous costs they cause for the health system, I have approved the application.

name: Lieve WIERINCK
text: in writing. – I voted in favour of this resolution since I believe that mandatory labelling of TFAs can incentivise healthier consumer choices. TFAs are very damaging, and are found in a lot of different products, but a lot of consumers may not be aware of that. Is very important that consumers know what they are assuming and what can be found in certain products. The health of the citizens is one of the main priorities of my group, especially considering food. I agree with the request that such a proposal has to be made within two years. Moreover it has to be accompanied by an impact assessment evaluating the industrial reformulation costs and consequent analysis and economic adaptations.

name: Anna ZÁBORSKÁ
text: in writing. - As a doctor, I must point out that trans fats have a negative effect on human health. That is why I support any initiative aimed at reducing their use in food. Several expert studies in the field of healthy nutrition agree on a significant and rapid health improvement in the reduction of trans fatty acids. At the same time, we must not forget the prevention and protection of the most vulnerable sections of the population, namely children. It is they who tend to consume foods high in trans fatty acids. At the same time, awareness of the health risks of consuming such foods needs to be improved. Although there is legislation on the obligation to label trans fatty acids, I consider this to be insufficient, as it only applies to certain foods and does not apply, for example, to meals served in restaurants. In addition, according to the World Health Organization (WHO), labeling policy is much more costly than a blanket ban and monitoring compliance. We therefore need to draw inspiration from the example of Denmark and adopt a similar limit on the restriction of trans fats in food at EU level. The approach of all Member States needs to be unified. Dialogue with representatives of the food industry will also be a decisive factor in the fight against trans fats.

name: Sotirios ZARIANOPOULOS
text: in writing. - The resolution on "trans - fatty" acids proves that the EU, by serving business profits, puts the lives and health of workers at great risk. The specific acids present in natural foods are mainly contained in industrial vegetable oils and processed foods to extend their shelf life. They are used in cheap foods intended for the working class and are blamed for causing serious diseases. The resolution calls on the Commission to pass legislation to impose a "trans-fat" content limit on food, but combines it with a report on the economic impact on industrial enterprises, under the guise of passing on costs to consumers. Characteristic was the intervention of the relevant industries that demanded and managed not to ban, in case of restriction of "trans - fats", the use of substitutes, such as palm oil, which are equally dangerous. The KKE European Parliamentary Group is in favor of a complete ban on the use of "trans-fatty" acids and a ban on their substitution by products of corresponding danger. He emphasizes that even the health of workers is sacrificed on the altar of the profitability of business groups, until the working people decide to take the keys of power and the economy into their own hands.

name: Jana ŽITŇANSKÁ
text: in writing. - I supported the resolution of Parliament's Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Food Safety (ENVI). Consumption of so-called trans fats cause a higher risk of cardiovascular disease, but can also be associated with infertility problems or susceptibility to Alzheimer's disease. However, despite these risks, only a part of the population is aware of the harmfulness of these acids, and given that trans fats are found mainly in cheaper food products, their consumption is higher among socially disadvantaged groups. In this resolution, we therefore called on the European Commission to come forward with a proposal within two years for limits on industrial trans-fatty acids for all types of food. This is to prevent the population from taking in increased amounts of these harmful substances. In addition, there is a need to raise awareness of the problem so that the citizens of the European Union have the opportunity to make informed decisions that will not be detrimental to their health.

name: Carlos ZORRINHO
text: in writing. - (PT) I voted in favor of the resolution on trans fats because I agree with the need to impose a legal limit on industrial trans fatty acids in all food products, taking into account the risks that these fats pose to public health. I emphasize that the high consumption of these unsaturated fats is a risk factor for the development of coronary heart disease, responsible for approximately 660 thousand deaths per year in the EU, representing about 14% of the total mortality. The fact that only one in three European consumers has knowledge about trans fatty acids shows that labeling measures are not enough and additional measures have to be taken to raise public awareness. In this context, I underline the European Parliament's request for the Commission to present within two years a proposal establishing a legal limit for industrial fatty acids in all food products in order to reduce their consumption.

name: Marco ZULLO
text: in writing. - Trans fats (also called hydrogenated, in abbreviation TFA) are those fats that have undergone the hydrogenation process, ie the addition of hydrogen on the double carbon bonds of unsaturated acids. While saturated fats in moderate quantities are essential for our body, trans fats should be completely eliminated from the diet. The intake of these fats is, in fact, associated with a significant increase in the risk of contracting cardiovascular disease, infertility, Alzheimer's disease, diabetes and obesity. TFAs are used in many industrial preparations such as confectionery and ice cream and are mostly used in cheaper foods, with the consequence that people with lower socio-economic status are more exposed to TFA intake. With this resolution, to which I voted in favor, we are calling on the Commission to place binding limits on the quantities of industrially produced trans fatty acids (TFA) in food. TFA reduction strategies to date have suffered from the lack of a harmonized approach at EU level and individual actions by Member States may have different health effects from one state to another. Health must be a protected and equal right for all European citizens.

name: Milan ZVER
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of the European Parliament resolution on trans fatty acids.Limiting trans fatty acid content has been shown to have rapid and significant health benefits.The findings show that only one in three consumers in the EU is aware of trans fatty acids, indicating that measures to label these acids have not been effective and that awareness-raising measures need to be taken in the education system and media campaigns.

name: David Maria SASSOLI
text: This concludes the explanations of vote.

name: Ioan Mircea PAŞCU
text: The next item is the debate on the annual report of the Court of Auditors - 2015 [2016/2839 (RSP)] On this occasion, allow me to greet Mr Klaus Heine-Lehne, who is a former colleague.of ours and, at the moment, he is the president of the Court of Accounts.Welcome!I also greet the Vice-President Georgieva Kristalina, who is a regular here in our Parliament.

name: Klaus-Heiner LEHNE
text: President of the European Court of Auditors. - Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Madam Vice-President of the Commission! First of all, I would like to take the opportunity to express my joy at being able to speak in this House again after two and a half years, albeit in a different, new role. This is my first time doing this in this new role. This has been done by my predecessor, Mr Vítor Caldeira, for the last eight years, who also helped prepare this annual report under his chairmanship. I would therefore also like to take this opportunity to thank him most sincerely for the work he has done and, of course, also my colleague, Lazaros Lazarou, who is the rapporteur in the Court and who, as rapporteur, was in charge of preparing this subject. But now to my lecture. Many citizens of the European Union are currently turning their backs on the Europe project. Why is this so? Because to some extent the European institutions have lost the trust of many EU citizens. The European Union will face the major challenge of regaining this confidence. The Court of Auditors will also have an important role to play in this. It is clear that we need further reforms. Whatever the form of these reforms, however, they must be based on stable financial foundations. According to the Court of Auditors, four elements are particularly important. Firstly, the European Union must keep accounts properly. How can people trust us if they are not convinced that we are taking good care of their money and keeping proper records and accountability? The 2015 EU annual accounts give a true and fair picture. However, the amounts to be paid this year and in the years to come are still very high. And the commission hasn't made a cash flow forecast for the next seven to ten years. Such a forecast would help rebuild confidence. I would also like to say, however, that the Commission's medium-term payment forecast is a first step in the right direction. Second, the European Union needs to ensure that its financial rules are properly followed. Although the inflows and outflows of the current European budget are precisely recorded, too many errors are still being made in the use of funds, especially in the Member States. According to our statistical calculations, the estimated error rate for 2015 is 3.8%. On the whole, it is as high as in previous years and continues to be above the materiality threshold of 2%. While the Commission has taken steps to improve its risk assessment and increase the impact of the corrective actions, we believe there is still room for improvement. It would be far better for European taxpayers if the Commission and Member States spent the money properly in the first place, rather than the laborious and time-consuming process of recovering it after errors were discovered. We can also reduce the error rate by improving the design of spending rules. Citizens cannot trust a system that they do not understand themselves. Legal foundations that are simple and clear, procedural regulations that are understandable lead to fewer errors. The more complex, the more mistakes - this is a principle that has been proven to be true every time it is checked. Now to the third element of sound financial governance. Our citizens rightly expect the European Union to ensure that funds are used as effectively as possible. They must feel that the European Union can offer them added value. Were at the European projects in the 2015 budget year have the funds used optimally? Were the project goals realistic from the start? Was the associated cost reasonable? Was the program or project more expensive or cheaper than it would have been if it had been carried out by another level of administration or government? These questions are difficult to answer until there are adequate reporting arrangements in place. There needs to be real incentives to get the most out of resources, not just to meet spending targets without breaking any rules. Even if all funds are correctly reported and all regulations are observed, this does not mean that EU-funded projects always and everywhere achieve a good cost-benefit ratio. If people cannot be sure that a system will be of use to them, neither can we ask them to trust that system. You need to see results and know the means by which they were achieved. This relationship, the value that is achieved through the use of resources - I would even say the added value - needs to be made much clearer. Trust also requires transparency and reliability as the fourth element of sound financial governance. The increased use of financial instruments that are not funded directly from the EU budget or that are not fully subject to our scrutiny increases the risks to transparency, accountability and coordination of European Union policies and actions. In terms of assurance, our audits not only provide independent assurance, but also result in recommendations for improving EU financial management. Incidentally, most of our recommendations are accepted and implemented by the Commission. In conclusion, to get back to the point: If we want to create an EU financial system that has the unreserved trust of the citizens, there is still a lot to do and to move. I call on all of us to do this.

name: Kristalina Georgieva
text: Vice-President of the Commission. – Mr President, I would like to start by joining President Lehne in acknowledging the work of his predecessor, President Caldeira, and the gratitude of the Commission for this work and then add our warm welcome to a partnership with the Court under your leadership. We have here the two rapporteurs, the rapporteur for Parliament, Mr Zeller, and the rapporteur for the Court, Mr Lazarou. Thank you for all the work you have done. I will start from where President Lehne ended, that we have work to do. We recognise that our responsibility to our taxpayers is, day-in-day-out, to make sure that their sacrifice, their money, is well spent. Also to say that we are committed and we are working very hard towards that objective to do better. The evidence, I believe, is in front of us. First, we had the Court of Auditors for the ninth year in a row giving a clean opinion on the EU accounts. We will of course continue to work hard to sustain that record. Secondly, while I agree with President Lehne that the error rate is still above the materiality threshold of 2%, for the first time in a long while it is under 4%, at 3.8%. It does not mean that we have succeeded, but it means that we are mobilising the Commission and Member States to do the right thing. Just for the record, it was 4.4% last year. Not a big difference, I agree, but it demonstrates an effort on the side of the Commission. There is also a positive story on the administrative expenditures, and it is an error rate of 0.8%, way under the materiality threshold of 2%. The Court found no errors in the transactions that have been examined on the revenue side of the budget. Again, it does not mean that we can relax, but it means that the Commission staff is doing a good job and deserves recognition for that. Next, the question is what we do next, and there our concentration in the Commission is to continue to bring down the risks of errors by focusing on a number of actions that I would like to highlight here. First, concentrate on where we have persistently high error rates – why? Understand the reasons and tackle these reasons. Second, apply good practice. When something works, like for example simplified cost options, spread them as far as we can go. Third, further efforts on simplification. The Court has told us so many times simple rules are easier to follow. In that context, just to recall that we have made a proposal for the midterm review and revision of the budget to also include revision of the Financial Regulation: the omnibus regulation that allows us to go further on this road to simplification. Of course, all these are actions that aim to prevent errors from going up and their actions to educate us. So prevention, which, as you said last time when you made a presentation, is much better than cure, is being pursued. But there has to be more, and where we go more is on the side of corrections. Corrections have been a very powerful tool, not only to claw back money that is not spent according to the rules but also to encourage compliance with the rules, because when you know if you do not follow the rules you will lose your money, you are incentivised to follow the rules. Last year we collected EUR 3.9 billion. This is the highest we have had. We also last year have done for the first time a careful examination of what we call ‘amount at risk at closure’. When all is being done in terms of corrective action, what percentage of the funding is at risk? I am very pleased to report that, when all is done, the amount at risk at closure for 2015 is somewhere between 0.8% and 1.3%. Of course, we know that this is not the error rate measure, but I believe it is important to look at the end after implementation of multi-year programmes carefully. Finally, value for money. Value for money, as President Lehne said, is not just to follow the rules. We have to walk on two legs – follow the rules and focus on results. What is it that we get? A road built with zero error that goes to nowhere is 100% waste of money. This is why we are complementing our work on compliance with what we call ‘budget focus on results’. I will conclude by saying that we also believe in what the Court has been asking us to do to improve reporting. This year we have introduced the first integrated financial reporting package – much easier to follow. You actually can give a brochure to people, who can read and understand what on earth we have done: where the money comes from, where the money goes, how we control it. We will continue in that direction, counting on the Court to push us forward.
