name: Joachim ZELLER
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. - Mr President, dear President of the Court of Auditors, dear Klaus-Heiner Lehne, dear Lazarou, dear Vice-President! Dear Mr Lehne, first of all, thank you very much - in addition to congratulating you on your election as President of the Court of Auditors, of course - for the cooperation that has been shown so far, both with the members of the Commission and with the members of the Court of Auditors at the start of the budget discharge procedure for the Commission for 2015. The Court of Auditors has presented an opulent work of around 300 pages, which the audit report for the 2015 financial year includes. Together with the many special reports that the Court of Auditors regularly sends us, this is a very good basis for our further work. I mean, not only in the Committee on Budgetary Control, but I also recommend these documents to my colleagues in the specialized committees, because they are just as affected by them. It cannot just be the job of the Court of Auditors to establish the numbers. The European Court of Auditors found an error rate of 3.8% for the past financial year - a decrease compared to 2014. That is correct, but - the President of the Court of Auditors also pointed out - the materiality threshold of 2% has not been reached. However, it is more important for me to emphasize that the error rate determined every year is not synonymous with fraud or - as voices critical of the EU like to proclaim - with a waste of taxpayers' money. Of course, we keep seeing cases of poor project execution and even fraud, which, moreover, are, without exception, prosecuted by the anti-fraud authority OLAF. In most cases, however, we encounter formal errors, incorrect tenders or the billing of ineligible costs. I don't want to downplay the importance of such mistakes. However, the Court of Auditors has once again found that a large number of these errors could have been prevented if the Member State authorities had used the information available to them in good time. We should also make this fact clear to our citizens. Instead of having to repeat our recommendations and criticism from year to year, we should also focus together on effective error prevention. Unfortunately my two minutes have already been exceeded. But we still have a few weeks of work ahead of us, and we will be able to discuss all the other points that I have noted here. I look forward to further cooperation.

name: Inés AYALA SENDER
text: on behalf of the S & amp; D Group. - Mr President, I too want to pay tribute to President Vítor Caldeira for all the fruitful years of collaboration with this Parliament, and to Mr Lázaro, who has done a little - let's say - bridging, until the arrival of the new President, Mr Lehne , whom I warmly congratulate, because, in addition, as a connoisseur of the two institutions, I believe that it will also help us - and a lot - to improve the scrutiny task of this Parliament, simplifying and offering the necessary instruments to face with guarantees of efficiency and professionalism the new approach to the European budget based not on spending for spending, but on visible and understandable results for our citizens. His arrival, in addition, will allow us to take stock of what has been achieved - you have said it yourself in the conversations we have had - and the progress, precisely, the reduction of errors and risks in the implementation and learning of good use of the budget with the priorities that the citizens demand of us. Once the very positive reform of the Court has also been consolidated, we can only thank you for the new annual report that allows us to confirm and better identify the sources of the most frequent and complex errors: reimbursements, competitions, financial instruments. I also thank you for your specific attention to Horizon 2020 and I turn to you to help us, together, to convince the Council that the best that Member States can do is precisely to improve, since they consume most of our budget, and follow through on your commitments.

name: Ryszard CZARNECKI
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. –  Mr President, Madam Vice-President of the Commission, Mr President of the European Court of Auditors, congratulations to you. This is a big challenge, and obviously I am crossing my fingers for you. Thank you, Mr President, for your really comprehensive annual report. We can observe some progress here because the estimated level of error for 2015 payments is 3.8%, which is obviously an improvement, but still it is above the materiality threshold. I would like to concentrate on one specific issue, which was reported in the past by the European Court of Auditors, as well as indicated by the current members. This is that a long, seven-to-ten-year, cash flow forecast is needed. The Commission was requested to prepare this, but still has not done it. Short-term cash flow forecasting by the Commission, to ensure that that the immediate payment obligations of the EU can be met, is not enough.  Finally, as you can see, amounts to be paid in the current and future years remain at a high level. The Commission made a high level of commitments in 2015, consisting in part of appropriations brought forward from 2014. Amounts to be funded from the future budget rose to EUR 339 billion. However, the Commission has not produced yet a cash flow forecast spanning a seven-to-ten-year horizon.

name: Martina DLABAJOVÁ
text: for the ALDE Group. - The European Court of Auditors' 2015 Annual Report was issued at a time when the European Union's budgetary policy is at a crucial crossroads. The report itself makes important observations regarding the sharing of money from European funds, to which citizens of all 28 Member States contribute, and should therefore be vital. At first sight, the report's conclusions in terms of legality, regularity and error are not significantly different from those of previous years. But I still perceive one difference very strongly. It is a trend to take into account, in addition to the factual correctness in drawing European funds, also the added value of individual projects and investments. In this spirit, I also drafted my report on last year's performance of the European Commission for 2014, and I appreciate that this effort is intertwined in small steps into other activities of all European institutions. This time, in the Court's report, this results-oriented approach was widely used in Horizon 2020, the largest of its kind in the world. This program concerns the field of science and research, where results are expected almost automatically, as support is directed to high-quality and high-level projects. In future reports from the European Court of Auditors on the Commission's management, I can imagine that budget chapters will not only be assessed in terms of error rates, but will also take into account or use integrated and comprehensive result indicators. Evaluating the effectiveness of projects, taking into account results and performance, is a new way forward. The priorities to be funded from the European budget change significantly over time, as do the conditions around us. And using the budget must respond to them. Drawing needs to be more flexible, focused on European added value, undoubtedly simpler and even more results-oriented, and not just on paper. If our common goal is, in particular, the added value of every euro invested, we must change the established rules (drawing and controls) and set new ones, corresponding to the real needs of 21st century Europe. Thank you to both institutions, the Commission and the European Court of Auditors, for the journey that we are slowly but surely going together.

name: Dennis de JONG
text: on behalf of the GUE / NGL Group. - Of course, my congratulations also to Mr Lehne on his appointment as President of the Court of Auditors. It is a great pity that we have to re-establish that too many mistakes have been made and that no unqualified explanation could be given. I think we all realize that that is bad for the image and that we need to find ways to deal with it. Some say that these are just errors and that you should make it clear that the irregularities can also be very small things. You may have made a mistake, or you may have forgotten to submit a form. If I then think how that looks to the citizens ... when they file their tax returns, they can also make mistakes, but they do have consequences and they are generally not tender. I also don't think the same small mistakes can be made year after year, especially when it comes to procurement. I have three concrete proposals for improvement: firstly, a review of the funds. Concentrate them, stop pumping, that prevents a lot of unnecessary things. Second, requires Member States to issue a national auditor's report. And third, treat recurring errors as fraud and don't always believe in good faith.

name: Bart STAES
text: on behalf of the Verts / ALE Group. - On behalf of our group too, many congratulations to Mr Lehne, the new President. I hope we can work well together. The figures in the debate have already been mentioned. An error rate of 3.8 percent, much too high. I agree with what Mr De Jong says about this. But a second element is that the Court's report also states for the umpteenth time that the corrections could have been much greater than the Member States, for all those cases where there is shared management between the Member States and the Commission, made use of the information available to them. Without those corrections, it would have been 4.4 percent, but if they had used all that information, that figure could have gone down from 3.8 percent. Hence the need for action. I think that one of the elements is naming and shaming Member States that go wrong, that are not doing their job. This is discussed in detail in the Court's report. We also see a lot of examples and I think that's a good thing. Second element, Mrs Georgieva has emphasized it very explicitly: spending money, correctly and on time, that is one thing, but getting value for money, getting value for money, that is another matter. I am very pleased, Mr Lehne, that you and your colleagues and all your staff are also paying particular attention to this in this report by the Court of Auditors. Are the objectives realistic, were the costs reasonable, was there sufficient output? Finally, a third matter. We see an increasing use of financial instruments. The Court cannot audit those instruments. That means that it entails a danger, a danger of cheating and carelessness. Mr Zeller, I hope that you as rapporteur, along with the shadow rapporteurs, will also pay particular attention to this in your report.

name: Jonathan ARNOTT
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. – Mr President, I am reminded of the film ‘Groundhog Day’, in which Phil Connors is doomed to repeat the same day over and over again, trapped in a never—ending cycle where he experiences the second of February time and time again, until he finally learns his lesson and – as with any great, or at least good, romantic comedy – gets the girl and is able to experience another day. That is comedy. This is reality. The reality is that the Court of Auditors, for the 21st year in a row, has issued an adverse opinion on the legality and regularity of the payments underlying the accounts of the European Union, which of course would be a very serious thing indeed in accountancy circles. If any business found that they had an adverse opinion on anything to do with their accounts at all, it would be treated very seriously indeed by the authorities if that happened time and time again. The reality is that the error in the European Union budget is still at a level of 3.8% of the budget, which is far above – almost double – the 2% materiality threshold. That is just, of course, the errors that we know about. The reality is that we are not at a point where value for money is being properly assessed. I think Commissioner Georgieva is absolutely right when she says that if there were a road to nowhere but it had zero error, that would not make it value for money. I think what we have seen from this Court of Auditors report is example after example: whether it is the EUR 3 500 on the panoramic spyglass, the EUR 10 000 donation to a church, the EUR 4 000 mountain bike, the building materials in Slovakia that were charged for at six times the going rate, or the EUR 100 000 on dry stone walls with no link to EU expenditure. The reality is that there are a lot of things that are going on here which certainly do not in any way, shape or form provide value for money. I would say normally that a report like this would put the European Union on notice to improve or to risk losing support. I do believe that is what the Commission is genuinely trying to do, but this has happened over and over again now. We are on year 21. I think this kind of thing is not the only reason for Brexit – far from it – but it is part of the package and, if this carries on, the UK will not be the only country heading out of the exit door. ‘Groundhog Day’ is romantic comedy. It is not exactly Shakespeare, but perhaps Shakespeare would be more appropriate. I am thinking, of course, of the ‘Comedy of Errors’.

name: Louis ALIOT
text: on behalf of the ENF group. - Mr President, dear colleagues, the Court of Auditors posed the problem: confidence. If the level of error is not an indication of fraud, inefficiency or waste, what does it reveal? The Court says that this is an incorrect estimate of the payments because the amounts paid were not used according to the rules. How is it possible? Even if the errors are less important from one year to the next, the fact remains that 5.5 billion euros escape rigorous control and monitoring. It's not nothing. If it is not a human problem or an accounting problem, it is therefore a problem of operation and general architecture. Of all the institutions, the Court of Auditors is the one that functions the best, but it is clear that not all the institutions can say the same. We must therefore rethink the general architecture and get out of an institutional and accounting scheme that no citizen of Europe understands any more and that the institutions - and you show the proof - themselves find it difficult to apply. The confidence of the people is inversely proportional to the opacity of our operating rules and to their lack of transparency. Subsidiarity, freedom and transparency should lead Europe to move forward with its nations and around its nations, without trying to impose everything and complicate everything with opaque rules. When things don't work or no longer work, it's okay to change them. This is now what the peoples will have to do.

name: Diane DODDS
text: – Mr President, for over two decades, the Court of Auditors has refused to give the European Union accounts a clean bill of health. If this was a business it would bring remorse and resignations, in the heart of a national government it would bring independent inquiries, but for the European Commission it is a cause for quiet satisfaction. A 3.8% error rate may seem small to some, but it in fact equates to billions of euro. Money taken from families and households and spent without sufficient accountability. I listened very carefully to Mr de Jong, who talked quite frankly about the effect that this has on the citizen and surely we must agree that, at the core of any effective government, should be trust between citizens and political institutions. Taxpayers should have confidence that their hard-earned money will make a difference and not be misspent. These are not small matters and as some colleagues have indicated today, they are not matters of form or process.  I think that for too long these institutions have actually turned a deaf ear to this and I hope that our former colleague, now the President of the Court of Auditors, will take a very strong view on these types of things.

name: Tamás DEUTSCH
text: - Ladies and gentlemen, Madam Vice-President. Allow me also to pay tribute to the newly elected President of the European Court of Auditors, our former fellow Member. Dear those present! It is a particularly sad fact for me that the confidence of European citizens in the European Union, in the EU institutions, is declining. In the light of this, it is an even sadder fact that the individual EU institutions - those who want to strengthen their powers at the expense of the Member States, who have a purely federal vision - are insulting pro-Europeans in a different way, instead of dealing with those who reject all forms of European cooperation. It is also a fact that the Union's bureaucracy, which is difficult to see, obviously also contributes to the loss of confidence. Part of this bureaucracy is budget management, which may be difficult to review. The European Court of Auditors reports that in 2015, the Union's total budget expenditure was € 145 billion. This means that every European citizen spends 78 cents a day on the Union. We can decide whether it is a lot or a little. In the context of cohesion policy, I would like to draw attention to the serious dangers of using so-called other financial instruments in favor of grants. This complicates the issue of controlling EU funds.

name: Bogusław LIBERADZKI
text: - Mr Chairman! Mr. President! Vice-President Georgieva! I would like us to stop saying at some point how bad, difficult, exceptional, theatrical or cinematic it is, because an event like the discharge and the Court of Auditors' report take place here every year. This is perfectly normal. Secondly, I would like to point out that today's debate is different from the previous ones, because we have a new president. And the new president, above all, declared that all that is good will be continued (as I am the shadow rapporteur, we will be watching this good thing together with Mr. Zeller). But he also declared efforts to regain or actually build trust. And I would treat this as a very important thing: building trust. Ms Georgieva, in turn, mentioned one more thing, which is simplification. There is an opinion that the procedures become more and more complex with each passing year, and the effect is unsatisfactory. Why not bring these two together and build trust by simplifying procedures? However, I emphasize once again very clearly: we are focused on the results we achieve, and not necessarily on the lost half percent.

name: Richard ASHWORTH
text: – Mr President, having participated for a number of years in these debates, I can say that this report gives some encouragement and, as such, I would say bears evidence that the Commission’s efforts are beginning to bear fruit. I compliment the Commissioner. However, there are three points which I would make. Firstly, that 3.8%, as said earlier, is still too high. Errors invariably relate to the level of complexity and so I welcome the Commissioner’s simplification proposals. Secondly, I would say that the level of error in the Member States remains persistently a problem and I call on those governments to give greater urgency to compliance. Thirdly, while this report is, by definition, about compliance, I encourage the Commission to give equal weight to outcomes and performance. Too often we lack real clarity in objectives of EU spending and in consequence we run the risk of weakness in value for money and weakness in added value.

name: Marco VALLI
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, then the administrative errors this year amounted to 3.8%, but I like to talk about figures, so we are at 5.4 billion, which is not a negligible figure, of which many are serious errors on procurement rules, therefore an issue that we are dealing with in the budget committee and that should be dealt with much more effectively. However, it means that in any case the rest of the expenditure we do not know if it has been spent well or badly, if there is or is not an administrative error, so we need more and more detailed performance assessments to try and evaluate whether this expense achieves results. Above all, the important thing, which I noticed in this two-year work in the budget control committee, is that we need transparency and controls on these national authorities that go on to do, then after, the certifications on the expenditure of European funds, of which the Commission then uses to give precisely these data, precisely because these controllers are appointed by those who must be checked in the Member States. So what happens? That there is, perhaps, a conflict of interest. So on this we need to consider how to act because, in fact, there could be these conflicts.

name: Gerolf ANNEMANS
text: - Colleagues, I welcome the annual report of our Court of Auditors and I thank the Court for it. One thing is particularly disturbing and that is the lukewarm and bland reception of the conclusions about money not ending up in the right place; in fact, this is little taken into account here at the political level. The Commission's responses are overflowing with vagueness and noncommittalism. Member States are "invited to remedy shortcomings". The Commission will “continue to pay attention to the shortcomings”. New procedures “can lead to a financial correction”. No wonder that results are lacking and only a small improvement can be seen. You curse and spit here several times a day what you call “the populists”. But the political level here in this European Parliament should be much tougher. After all, the annual report of the Court of Auditors is about tax money, a lot of tax money. And the margins of error re-established here are a thorn in the side of taxpayers, who - even the Court of Auditors makes that connection - are rapidly losing confidence in the European institutions.

name: Marian-Jean MARINESCU
text: - Thank you, Mr President, Commissioner, Mr President of the Court of Auditors. I also want to thank the person who has been president so far, because he started doing things, I think, very positive and I congratulate you for this position. I think that what started so far must be continued, the error rate is important, it is an important indicator, but we must also look at the results. Special reports are an extremely positive thing and are very useful. Perhaps, if he had taken exactly the method from the special reports and introduced an article, a chapter in your regular discharge reports would be something that would add to those reports. Of course, your controls should be risk-based, first and foremost, and differentiate between error and fraud. On the other hand, I think that the reports have to be complete even if things can go well, then it should be said in these reports that it is good. Maybe you also look at the contribution in kind and property rights and maybe based on all these things you also make proposals for simplification. And one last thing, you have been a member of the Committee on Legal Affairs and the Committee on Constitutional Affairs, maybe do something this year with the discharge for the Council, because not granting the discharge for a large number of years without any consequences danger, I think, the credibility of this process. (The speaker agreed to answer a question following the collection of the blue card in accordance with Rule 162 (8)).

name: Tibor SZANYI
text: Blue card question.- Honorable Member!We agree that it is very important that the accounting methodologies of the Commission and the Court of Auditors converge very much, and that we have obtained more realistic error rates.But I ask if you see a mechanism by which the figures generated in each year can be interpreted for the whole financial cycle, so in Hungarian, so that there is no terrible problem with it, if it is better in one year and less in another.the error rate is good, but then overall it is still good.

name: Marian-Jean MARINESCU
text: blue-card answer. – This intervention is an answer. I did not see a question in this intervention. Did you see one?

name: Marian-Jean MARINESCU
text: blue-card answer. – Of course. They know very well how they make all the verifications. They cannot check 1 000 billion in seven years, so I think that for the moment they are doing a good job. They have to improve it, of course.

name: Georgi PIRINSKI
text: S & amp; D). - In its 2015 Annual Report, the Court of Auditors rightly draws attention to the need to restore the confidence of European citizens by showing that their funds are being used in the best possible way. In this regard, the report rightly highlights the declining error rate, as well as the fact that 96.2% of resources have been spent in compliance with the rules, while, of course, objectively naming the existing problems. Moreover, the Court emphasizes the crucial importance of the end results, not just compliance with the rules themselves. At the same time, this year's report appears at the time of the mid-term review of the MFF, which is obliged to mobilize all the necessary resources in the fight against youth unemployment, poverty and social exclusion, as well as the challenges of migration. In view of the above, I am convinced that the Court deserves to be commended for its work in this highly meaningful and value-added report.

name: Beatrix von STORCH
text: -  Mister President! 2015 is the third year in a row that the Commission's expenditure exceeds the forecast ceiling. The EU is not sticking to its budget. Now it is resorting to ever new financing mechanisms that bypass the EU budget entirely. It forms shadow budgets, which are then no longer subject to the audit by the Court of Auditors. The EFSI is a completely new quality of this shadow budget. We shouldn't call it the Juncker Fund, but Juncker's shadow budget. The Court of Auditors suggests that the Commission has considerable discretion in not classifying this fund as a joint operation. 285 euros for every citizen of the European Union are spent without being checked by the Court of Auditors. You wonder why you are losing people. They wonder why more and more people are turning away from the European Union - among other things because of something like that. You should ask yourself how you can win back people: “Unbrell” yourself!

name: Olaf STUGER
text: - I would like to congratulate the Members of the European Court of Auditors for they are the rock in the surf in the middle of the sea of waste.I would therefore like to call on them on behalf of the taxpayer to continue this work - bold, with guts and with courage.But I have a less cheerful message for my colleagues from the major groups - the PPE, S & amp; D, ECR and ALDE Groups - who have been supposedly very critical once a year for 21 years, and all other days of theyear blind drawing any budget they are given.Madam President, that is the hypocrisy that the EU is undergoing - and I am not at all against it - and that is also the reason why the Dutch taxpayer is dropping out en masse with every expenditure and every policy of the EU.[The speaker addressed a “blue card” question under Rule 162 (8).]

name: Tomáš ZDECHOVSKÝ
text: a question asked by raising a blue card.- Mr Stuger, here in this venerable House, you will allow ourselves to evaluate the work of Members of the PPE, S&D, ALDE and other groups and criticize the fact that we criticize the budget here once a year.What do you know about our work?How many times have you been to the budget meeting in the CONT committee, how many times have you seen our work, how many times have you seen passing discharge?Mr colleague, would it not be worthwhile for you to really start working in this House sometime and attend CONT meetings?Thank you for answer.

name: Olaf STUGER
text: "blue card" answer.Thank you for your question.I'm not talking about your quality.I'm talking about your principles: you deny the taxpayer.You have been doing this here for 21 years and you will continue to do so.In doing so, you cause your own downfall, and we will continue to see that in the years to come.[The speaker addressed a “blue card” question under Rule 162 (8).]

name: Michael THEURER
text: Ask about the “blue card” procedure.-  Colleague!I would like to clarify the question again: in the two and a half years as chairman of the Committee on Budgetary Control, I have not seen you once with us to do the work of budgetary control, nor in the past two years.So how many times have you been there?What applications did you make?And how do you come to insulting the house when you cannot say specifically what you did in budget control?

name: Olaf STUGER
text: "blue card" answer.Thank you for your question, sir.I've been here for two and a half years now.I've seen enough here.I've been through enough.I have read enough and I have always voted against things that are hindering the Dutch taxpayer and on which the Dutch taxpayer spends an awful lot of money.You did not and you are reminded of it every day.Just look at the polls.Just look at Brexit.Just look at all the referendums that are being held.You and your establishment will be voted out in one go.

name: Tomáš ZDECHOVSKÝ
text: - I did not want to use my time to react to a colleague's speech, but it is clear that he knows nothing about our work. I hope that by the next sitting, he will find out that the work of an MEP is not just about voting on here in Strasbourg. The EU is currently facing, Mr President and Vice-President of the European Commission, a number of major events affecting the future. The deepest impact on our functioning is certainly the loss of confidence of European voters and the general dissatisfaction of citizens with the EU. But that is something we need to change. We are the EU, we are responsible for the EU. It's not about spending some money headlong, it's about thinking about efficiency. I will not criticize the 3.8 or 2.2% error rate here, because those who do not know the context and do not know, for example, that the government in Moldova has changed five times in one year and that you do not have partners to negotiate anything in that country, then he will criticize here that there is a certain error rate. They are, ladies and gentlemen, just numbers. On the contrary, in the future, we must prevent European citizens from seeing European funding only as an opportunity for fraud and corruption. One last thing, Mr President, let me mention that I believe in the ambition of the Commissioner and I believe that she will try to get the error rate to 2% or less.

name: Zigmantas BALČYTIS
text: - The need to restore the confidence of our citizens in the European institutions has rightly been pointed out, and the role of the Court of Auditors is very important in this process. For a number of years, they have emphasized in their reports the need for better financial management at both Commission and Member State level. However, this year, too, it was found that the error rate remained high in 2015, especially in cost reimbursement schemes. This situation is unsatisfactory and the Commission and the Member States are not making sufficient efforts to change the principles of payment and control. It should be noted that there is a growing number of financial instruments, such as the Strategic Investment Fund, which are not financed from the European Union budget and do not fall within the scope of the audit. This poses a serious threat to financial reporting and distorts the principles of sound financial management and control. The Commission must undertake reforms to improve the financial management of the European Union in order to ensure and create real added value and greater credibility for the European Union as a whole and its citizens.

name: Claudia SCHMIDT
text: - Mr President, Mr President of the European Court of Auditors, Commissioner, dear colleagues! First of all, thank you for the very extensive but also interesting report. However, there are some critical points to note. First and foremost, the most important thing: checking whether EU spending makes sense. Every euro must be used sensibly. The use of EU funds must bring results. It is not enough to check that the legal framework has been met. Citizen added value is more important than any plan-fulfillment theory. There is a massive need for improvement. Second, the selection of controlled projects does not seem transparent and comprehensible enough to me. A sampling system that does not treat everyone equally or puts its fingers on the known wounds, but rather controls known problem countries such as Bulgaria as often as Austria for example, seems illogical to me. Taxpayers' money must be spent responsibly, and this should be reflected in control. Therefore, the way to the representative sample should be approached quickly. And I hope that next year's report will take all of these suggestions into account.

name: Petri SARVAMAA
text: – Mr President, I would like to thank the President of the Court of Auditors for this annual report. It is a piece of good work. The error rate this year is 3.8. Those are errors, not fraud, but finding them cost a lot of time and money. To me these errors are proof that too many people have a hard time understanding the rules to begin with. So we clearly need simplification of rules. In addition, we need more transparency in the use of EU money. It is impossible to fix problems if we do not know exactly where the problems are. In shared management we should be able to count on the information provided by the Member States; we hear about this every year, so clearly this is something that we need to pay special attention to. So may the force be with you in this extremely important task.

name: Ivana MALETIĆ
text: - Mr. President, I thank all colleagues for this good report, especially colleagues in the Court of Auditors. Of course, it is unquestionable that our common goal is good management of public money and the role of the Court of Auditors in this is very important. It is important to us not only the legal and purposeful use of funds, but also the efficient and effective use of funds, and I am very glad that Vice President Georgijeva pointed out the focus on results. That’s exactly what prompted me to get in touch. You have also pointed out the simplified costing method, and it is important to ask why Member States do not use this method, even though it is available. We will not change anything by changing the regulations if the position of the auditor does not change. Member States often say that it is the auditors who are still focused on inputs and less on outputs and outcomes, and it is the simplified cost method that insists on outcomes, so I call on the Court of Auditors to step up training and knowledge sharing on this topic.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, thank you President of the Court of Auditors for the excellent report. The use of structural funds by the Member States is often slowed down by bureaucratic reasons and by the overlapping of European and national regulations in the accounting field. The Commission should draw on the experience gained in previous programming periods and conduct an analysis of national eligibility rules, providing guidance to Member States on how to simplify and avoid unnecessarily complex and burdensome rules that do not add value to the results to be achieved. For example, it is urgent to clarify the concept of recoverable VAT to the Member States, especially for public beneficiaries, in order to avoid differences in interpretation and suboptimal use of EU funds. I fully agree with the Court of Auditors' recommendation that the Commission clarify in detail the links between the Europe 2020 strategy, the multiannual financial framework and its priorities in order to strengthen the monitoring and reporting arrangements.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: ECR). - Mr President of the Court of Auditors, the devaluation of the European Union that you mentioned is mainly due to the policies it pursues and the results of its actions, because Europe today is full of armies of unemployed people. We have the poor, we have huge problems. Next, the question always arises as to how the European Union's money is spent. Do they really reach the unemployed? Do they really reach small and medium enterprises? And here is the issue of transparency to which everyone has referred. At the same time, there is the issue of efficiency: does the European Union's money take up space? So I want you to look at the refugee issue, where some money is being spent. Not much, especially what is given for Greece, but 345,000,000 have been allocated. The question is: where does this money go, because at the moment the NGOs that take the money are having a party. Audits must be carried out in order to be effective in the amounts allocated for the support of immigrants and refugees in Greece.

name: Igor ŠOLTES
text: - I think that - of course - public confidence is also strengthened by the rational and correct use of public funds, and that is why the reports sent by the Court of Auditors to the public are all the more important.I think that we should also point out the need to increase the role of internal auditors in the Member States and thus reduce the risk of error, so that the error rate could fall below 2.5%, which is already close to the threshold of importance..It is true, however, that the error rate ... is not a comprehensive answer to how we spent the funds.Therefore, of course, there is still a lot of room for questions about efficiency, effectiveness.And - of course - I would warmly recommend to the Court of Auditors to carry out as many so-called "follow up" audits as possible, in which they would test the implementation of their recommendations.So that the report is not compiled again every year.

name: Eleftherios SYNADINOS
text: NI). - Mr President, the conclusions of the Court of Auditors' report raise strong concerns about the real pursuit of the Union's policies. The Commission refuses to draw up a cash flow forecast of 7 to 10 years to facilitate those involved in assessing future payment needs. This hinders entrepreneurship and sustainability. They increase the financial instruments and are not financed directly from the Union budget nor are they subject to the control of the Court of Auditors. This enhances opacity. These two elements are enough to capture the reality. A vague and vague environment is created, where the credits are directed where the selfish political interest of some imposes. This report makes this very clear. The European institutions have, to some extent, lost the trust of the citizens of the Union. The leaders of the institutions must change their policy, stop the manipulation techniques, think of the citizens and not their interests.

name: Kristalina Georgieva
text: Vice-President of the Commission. – Mr President, it is a bit unfortunate that the Court of Auditors report, which is a very serious analytical document that helps us improve our work year after year, is also used to make claims that are simply false. Our accounts have been signed for the ninth year in a row. We have been given a clean bill of health from that perspective.  An error of 3.8% is exactly what it says. This is not money that has been stolen. This is not money wasted. It is money that is not accounted for properly in accordance with the rules. This is simply a fact, but it is also important that in this reflection we take from the Court of Auditors the messages that are helpful for us to do better, including in terms of bringing down the risks and the materiality of error, and that is the commitment I give. My huge respect goes to the people who implement projects. In their vast majority they do a very good job and as a result of that there are better roads, more jobs, more functioning municipalities, and even a Noble Prize won because of EU funding being used wisely! It is for these people I want to finish, by saying that yes, we have to push where there are problems, but we also have to be grateful to those who make the life of European citizens better and I will finish by expressing my appreciation for them.

name: Klaus-Heiner LEHNE
text: President of the European Court of Auditors. - Mr President, Madam Vice-President, ladies and gentlemen! First of all, I would like to thank you once again for the congratulations, which have been expressed by many, and also for the words of praise. Allow me to make a few comments for clarification, including on what has been said. I believe that if you look back at the development of EU finances over a period of 20 years, then an enormous amount has been achieved through the cooperation between the Court of Auditors, Parliament and the Commission. When we talk about an error rate of 3.8% today, that is still too much objectively. But compared to the conditions that prevailed towards the end of the 90s, this is a huge, a huge step forward, if I can say so clearly at this point. That is a joint effort that has been achieved here. It is still a long way from where we have to go, but it is already tremendous progress that has been achieved over the last 20 years. It is also correct, Mr Zeller mentioned, that the number of cases of fraud we uncovered - but when I speak of uncovered, that does not mean that these are finally resolved cases, but that there was only sufficient initial suspicion during the audits that we did for this exam year - exactly twelve - the number12 - was. The cases have, of course, been passed on to OLAF directly and I assume that OLAF will investigate these issues intensively and, where the facts of fraud become established, will also draw the appropriate conclusions from them. EUR 5.5 billion - it cannot be said - has not been wasted. EUR 5.5 billion was not spent according to the rules. That's a huge difference. It is nowhere near the same. We have complex and complicated regulations in this European Union - everyone knows that. All of you sitting here are involved in deciding on these rules. Mistakes happen - too many, no question about it. But mistakes also happen because of the complexity of these rules. But that does not mean that the money that was then spent was actually spent pointlessly. They were just issued incorrectly. Our audit as part of the annual report now focuses on the review of so-called compliance. We are forced to do this according to the contract, we have to do it according to the contract, to check the legality and the mathematical accuracy. Such errors are discovered and they are then taken into account in the error rate and in our reporting. I think that this is once again a very necessary and clear clarification. However, we are of the opinion - and I already said that in the speech, and I believe that is also evident from the report - that it is also the task of the Court of Auditors not to deal solely with the issue of compliance, but also with the question of performance, and that the aspect of performance is becoming increasingly important. The Vice-President of the Commission pointed this out, and many of our special reports also show that it does not help if a road or a port or airport is built correctly, but the building actually makes no sense. This is something that has to be taken into account and addressed to a far greater extent in the context of the examinations so that such things no longer happen in the future, but that the funds are not only spent correctly but also sensibly. That is why a particular focus of the audits and the Commission's activities must also focus on this aspect. On the subject of transparency: that has been mentioned several times, that is really one of the central points. I fully understand the political needs in view of the enormously rigid European budget, which has basically been laid out relatively inflexibly for seven years, so that when new challenges arise, politicians suddenly have to decide to find new sources of finance, new ideas and new instruments with which to approach these challenges. But we must never lose sight of the fact that this constant creation of new financial instruments does not contribute to clarity, that this of course also entails risks, that it does not contribute to transparency. So we must not lose sight of the fact that at some point in the future - I hope in the not too distant future - we will have to bring everything back together under one roof so that transparency is ultimately maintained. I don't need to say anything more about the topic of added value. We actually want to include more qualitative elements in the evaluation and we also expect the Commission to take these qualitative elements into greater account. For the sake of simplicity, this has been raised by Mr Liberadzki, Mr Ashworth and Mr Valli: this is a very crucial point. I'll say that again here: simple rules are better. But if they are too simple i.e. That is, if they no longer allow control in terms of meaningfulness and performance, they also make no sense. That is, the simplification of the rules has to go hand in hand with a stronger examination of efficiency and what really comes out of it in the end. This is a key requirement for simplification. Both must happen and happen in one step. Mr. Zdechovský and Mr. Marinescu pointed out that there have been positive developments in the past, and rightly so. Regarding Mr Pirinski's comment and what Mrs von Storch said, I would just like to point out that we will be delivering our position on both the mid-term review of the multiannual financial framework (MFF) and the EFSI in the next few days and weeks . I don't want to say anything about that now, you can read it when it's finished. Regarding Ms. Schmidt's comment: The selection of samples is an internationally recognized method; they are chosen at random. I believe there is no doubt about that on the part of experts and specialists. I am very grateful to Mr Šoltes for emphasizing the role of the Court once again. He himself has relevant experience through his professional experience and work in this area. It really is like this: It is our job to put our finger in the wound, to identify risks as early as possible, to describe problems, but always with the aim of ultimately drawing conclusions from them and improving the situation. And again, when I look back into the past: At the moment the steps are of course slower and harder. But when I look back into the past, I do believe that clearly positive changes can be identified over a medium-term - also long-term - period. I think, for the sake of honesty, it is also part of saying this here.

name: Ioan Mircea PAŞCU
text: The debate was closed.Written declarations (Rule 162)

name: Julia PITERA
text: in writing. - The European Court of Auditors is responsible for auditing the finances of the European Union. It is an independent, external auditor whose task is to audit the legality and regularity of all EU expenditure and revenues and to assess the rationality and correctness of budget management. The ECA operates throughout the European Union. It cooperates with the Supreme Audit Institutions of the Member States and the international organizations INTOSAI and EUROSAI. As part of them, he participates in the development of international standards of public finance control. The ECA College has twenty-eight members, one from each EU Member State. They are appointed for six years by the Council of the European Union after consulting the European Parliament. Opinion on candidates for the ECA is a right of the European Parliament resulting from Art. 286 paragraph. 2 of the Treaty. The requirements to be met by a candidate to the European Court of Auditors are detailed in Art. 286 of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union. And only these criteria should decide about its appointment by the Council to the ECA, because only they form the basis of the transparently adopted opinion by the European Parliament. It is therefore of deep concern that over the last three years - in 2013 (1 candidate) and in 2016 (2 candidates) - the Council has appointed three members of the Court with a negative opinion from the European Parliament. A negative opinion of the European Parliament deprives them of their legitimacy under the Treaty.

name: Ioan Mircea PAŞCU
text: The next item is the debate on the oral question on EU policies and actions to protect children in the context of migration, addressed to the Commission (O-000126/2016 - B8-1804 / 2016) (2016/2954 (RSP)).

name: Gianni PITTELLA
text: Author. - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Osarugue, aged 16, is a young girl who left her family in Nigeria in search of a better life in Europe. A Nigerian smuggler arranged for her to travel to Europe and ordered her to do hard labor to recover the money to pay for the trip. For many weeks this girl, working in Libya, in order to reach the agreed sum, was forced to be sexually abused and exploited until she was finally able to get on this boat to reach the island of Lampedusa. Without water for hours and hours, unable to move, she and several other boys were herded into a dark hold at the bottom of the boat. It took more than 12 hours to be rescued by the Italian Coast Guard. Colleagues, this girl's story is not an isolated story. Unfortunately, it is the story of some 50 million girls and boys who have crossed the borders of the world. Of these, more than half are girls and boys who fled violence and insecurity. These children are refugees, displaced persons or internal migrants, but no matter where they come from or who they are, they are first of all children! We Democratic Socialists have submitted a formal request for help to the European Commission so that unaccompanied minors, victims of the migration crisis, are adequately protected. And I expect a positive response from the Commissioner, whom I respect very much. Building on the existing action plan for the protection of unaccompanied minors, we require an approach that includes concrete measures for all children and not limited to asylum seekers only, an approach based on the principle of non-discrimination, as enshrined in the United Nations Convention . Much more must be done especially to protect and prioritize children on a resettlement basis and to prohibit arbitrary detention of children. I want to conclude with a quote from a man who is in the hearts of all of us, Nelson Mandela, who said "there can be no more acute revelation of the soul of a society than the way it treats children".

name: Nathalie GRIESBECK
text: author. - Mr President, Commissioner, our debate concerns children in the context of migration and I would like to come back to the situation of unaccompanied children, that is to say those who arrive or find themselves alone in our territory European. In September 2013, Parliament adopted a report on the situation of these unaccompanied minors. More than three years ago, as rapporteur, I proposed and called for the adoption of a real strategy, real measures and minimum common standards, the need for which I stressed in order to protect these children properly. Almost nothing has been done since. At the time, there were 13,000 unaccompanied minors and we were already denouncing the urgency of the situation. Today, 96,000 unaccompanied children have arrived in Europe and, naturally, we have no more strategy and no more adapted responses. Realize, Commissioner, that the images of these lonely and frightened children who are the prey of networks participate in the risk of collective disaster which threatens our Europe. I want to highlight three points. First, Commissioner, we need a comprehensive strategy for unaccompanied children. However, in the European agenda on migration, the word "children" appears only once to indicate that the action plan is being followed up. I'm asking you where this follow-up is. Second point, relocation. I appeal here to the Member States of the Union which have committed to relocating 160,000 refugees from Italy or Greece. We all know that this is clearly not the priority of states since today only 6,000 people have been relocated since last year. Among them, only 75 unaccompanied minors were relocated. It's a shame! I don't even understand how this can be possible. Third, Dublin. We cannot ignore the current revision of the Dublin regulation, an unfortunate revision not in itself, but by the elements which are envisaged therein. Your proposal concerning unaccompanied minors is the exact opposite of the clear case law of the Court which prohibits tossing children from one country to another. In conclusion, faced with the courage of these children who have crossed part of the planet, we respond with a sort of inability to welcome them as it should. The solutions are there. It is simply a matter of having a political will commensurate with the values ​​that our Union normally carries.

name: Cornelia ERNST
text: Author. -  Mister President! Last year, our group visited refugees in several countries. Most of them were almost always children. Most of them have never seen the inside of the school or for years. They live in camps, on streets, in demolished houses, in slums, but also in deportation prisons like in Turkey. The IOM estimates that 15,000 children have been lost between 2014 and July 2016. Lost - that is missing, dead, drowned in the Mediterranean, died of thirst in the Jordanian desert, lost on the Balkan route, sold to Da’esh, sausage by organ dealers in Kosovo. There is no protection, no help whatsoever for children on the run. And if they are unaccompanied, then they are completely on their own. That is true for 100,000 children in 2015. And the fact that there are no legal routes to Europe exposes these children to existential threats to life and limb. The EU, which always boasted so full of the Nobel Peace Prize, fails miserably here. And no matter how you feel about refugee policy, how you think about it, it doesn't matter: You can't let these children down. We have a humanitarian duty to help these children. We, as the United Left Group, demand the creation of a humanitarian corridor that allows children to enter the EU legally. No child belongs in a deportation prison, no child may simply be deported. We demand that these children have a legal right to rapid family reunification. We require that unaccompanied children receive free legal assistance. We demand that refugee children be given equal rights to children in the Member States in all rights. In conclusion, I will say: these children cannot wait, especially since winter is just around the corner. Action must be taken now, and I expect the same from the Commission.

name: Anna Maria CORAZZA BILDT
text: author. – Mr President, Commissioner: Europe should mean safety for migrant children. There are more and more children coming to Europe, and they are younger and younger: 80 000 only this year, out of which 70 000, according to UNHCR, are accompanied minors. Behind every number there is a tragedy. There is a heart-breaking story. Children are now trafficked, abused, exploited and exposed to terrible suffering. It is happening in Europe today. We have an emergency of more than tens of thousands of children that are going missing. They are running away from reception centres and becoming victims of organised crime. The police, the judiciary, law enforcement authorities have to prioritise children. We need better rules for cross-border cooperation, better cooperation with Europol, better interoperability of the databases, and yes, welcome to the Commission proposal to reduce the age of fingerprinting from 14 to 6, because it is a way to bring the children and to keep the children into the protection system. And that is our duty: to make sure they enter the protection system and to build the trust, to make sure that they remain in the protection system, not by detaining them. Arbitrary detention of children should not have a place in Europe. Still we do not have zero tolerance for impunity for abuse of children in Europe, and it is about time that we build this policy. Children should be identified, registered and given the right to ask for asylum. Member States should accelerate the procedures for granting asylum for children. Fast-tracking, relocation and resettlement programmes should be giving priority to children. I want to conclude by saying that I met, in Sweden, Afghan children, in an organisation they have themselves built, helping each other. Let us start to change the rhetoric. They can be an asset and a benefit to our society if we give them access to education, to health care, to psychological support and to dignified shelter. They are an opportunity for our societies.

name: Jean LAMBERT
text: author. – Mr President, at the last Parliament session here we picked up on the issue about what was happening in Calais, and I want to use that as the basis for what I say this afternoon. We saw some of the first children brought from Calais to the UK only in the last few days, where they were greeted by the press saying: ‘My God, these do not look like children’. So you think, well, how do you expect a child who spent two years walking from Afghanistan to get to the border of France to look? Not exactly like the 13-year-olds, for example, that we might see in our own classrooms and our own streets.  What we have seen at Calais, and I think we have seen in a number of other places, has been a deliberate foot-dragging by the authorities, even to work with the Dublin system to reunite those with families. We see a lack of dedicated staff for dealing with under-18s. We see children who are identified by NGOs such as Safe Passage, who are then lost by the authorities because they have really got no system to deal with them. We see a lack of support to local authorities who are willing to accept unaccompanied minors, to provide them with school places and foster care. We see a lack of support for family members who may, for example, be not in a good situation to take on their young family members themselves.  How do you feel as a 24-year-old living alone when you are suddenly asked to look after your 14-year old brother that you last saw 10 years ago? We know that there are significant issues around guardianship and child protection. We have known that for years in this House. We know it for children from Europe themselves, as well as for those coming in. So is the Commission satisfied that the new asylum proposals provide a genuine framework for looking after those children from the moment of their arrival to determination of status and beyond? Or are we once again looking at the words, not the reality?

name: Dimitris Avramopoulos
text: Membro della Commissione. – Signor Presidente, onorevoli deputati, io vorrei ringraziare il presidente Gianni Pittella e gli altri membri del Parlamento per quello che avete detto. Le vostre parole parlano al nostro cuore e ora vi comunicherò quello che penso. Thank you for scheduling this very timely debate, because it is really very timely. Let me assure you that the protection of children in the context of migration and the current refugee crisis is central to our overall migration policy, both for their short-term as well as their long-term needs. The Commission, as you will remember, announced in its communication of 10 February 2016 a comprehensive approach to the protection of all children in migration, including unaccompanied minors. These actions are geared towards strengthening child protection systems in the Member States and are now being implemented. The Commission will also evaluate and report by the end of this year on the implementation of the 2010-2014 Action Plan on Unaccompanied Minors. All our efforts are concerted to address the complex and urgent issues that need to be resolved to ensure the adequate protection of migrant children arriving in Europe. Member States must ensure that they are capable of respecting the rights and meeting the needs of children in migration and addressing several gaps. These gaps include: providing adequate reception conditions, including psycho-social care; prevention of children going missing, and ensuring adequate responses in case they do; effective guardianship; access to information; access to legal counsel and assistance and other procedural safeguards and procedures, such as Dublin transfers and family reunification; and the use of arbitrary administrative detention and inappropriate detention conditions. Let me remind you that detention is never the objective, but can only be a last resort. The Commission is acting to address all these gaps. The recent legislative proposals to reform the Common European Asylum System include stronger provisions on the protection, care and procedural safeguards for children. These new proposals aim at strengthening the protection of children, including those who are unaccompanied. They address key areas such as ensuring adequate reception conditions, ensuring access to specialised services and education for migrant children, ensuring psycho—social support for victims of trauma, and speeding up family reunification procedures. Nevertheless, more needs to be done to ensure that alternatives to detention are available and used, and to ensure the expansion of family-based care, such as foster care, for unaccompanied children. With regard to family reunification, our Dublin proposal provides for clear and precise rules and will enhance the efficiency of the system significantly without compromising any essential safeguards. The procedures will be shorter, and current shifts of responsibility between Member States will no longer be possible. It also broadens the concept of ‘family members’ to include the applicant’s siblings. One of the main gaps has been on effective guardianship, where we have seen long delays in appointment and guardians being assigned unworkable caseloads of up to 1 000 children. Our asylum reform proposals address this issue. I count on your support and that of the Member States to agree on these reforms, so we can ensure these safeguards in reality as soon as possible. In addition, the recent Action Plan on Integration Actions addresses education for children in migration. For children in reception centres our asylum reform proposals aim at further strengthening a child’s right to access to education, including if they are in detention. Under the Emergency Support Instrument, targeted funding is allocated to additional education activities for children. Outside the European Union, EU funding has been made available to programmes for vulnerable Syrian refugees and host community children and adolescents. According to the Council decisions on relocation, applications made by unaccompanied children and vulnerable persons shall be prioritised. Despite this, so far very few unaccompanied children have been relocated from Greece and very few Member States have made places available for them. To date, no children have been relocated from Italy. In our recent report we have also raised this issue. As you know, the Commission is monitoring the situation in Greece and Italy very closely and is in continuous dialogue with Member States, urging them to make pledges to relocate unaccompanied children. Finally, to foster a discussion between those working in asylum and migration and those working in child protection, the Commission is dedicating the 10th European Forum on the Rights of the Child on 29 November 2016 to the protection of children in migration, where there will also be a dedicated side meeting on the guardianship of unaccompanied children. As I said at the beginning, protecting the most sensitive and the most vulnerable in this refugee crisis – and those are indeed children – is of paramount importance to the Commission. It is one of our priorities. But it needs many more stakeholders and actors involved to make this happen. The Commission counts on the European Parliament as its partner on this. I would like to close by saying that this is not an issue that should in fact be debated. It is an issue that should simply be addressed, urgently and jointly.

name: Roberta METSOLA
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. – Madam President, in this House we have listened to every single side of the migration debate. I am convinced that we can have a situation where we are humane with those in need of protection, but firm with those who are not eligible. This careful balance must be the basis of any policy and I am happy to debate this at any time. But when it comes to children, politicians do not have the luxury of time.  The anguish of parents who pack a little plastic bag and send their children, often alone, on rickety boats, to Europe, knowing the dangers – but who do it anyway because even a small chance of a better life for their child is better than the certainty that awaits them if they stay behind – is almost unimaginable. The truth is that often those children who survive the journey find themselves in no man’s land, alone, vulnerable and easily exploited. The statistics are heart-breaking; thousands of children have gone missing, but only 46 unaccompanied minors have been relocated – forty-six. Yes, we need to make sure that no one abuses loopholes in our system; and yes, we need to ensure that proper age determination is carried out; but states cannot turn their backs.  We need our responses to improve, and we are calling for a series of measures to protect children, including quicker processing times, improving guardianship and access to education, ending arbitrary detention, and getting children reunited with their families. We can do better, and we must do better, because it is true that, as one famous poet put it, no one puts their child in a boat unless the water is safer than the land.

name: Enrique GUERRERO SALOM
text: on behalf of the S & amp; D Group.- Madam President, in all humanitarian crises - whether due to natural causes or conflicts - the weakest link is always the children: on the one hand, they lose their living conditions and, on the other, those who are being put at riskwill have in the future.Only one in six migrant or displaced children in the world lives in the European Union, but it is a very important number.Last year, more than 300,000 applied for asylum;it was double the previous year.The European Union has to commit itself to several issues.In the first place, scrupulously respect the Declaration of the Rights of the Child.Second, to provide the reception centers with material means and qualified advice, and to offer humane - human! - alternatives to what are today detention or retention centers.Finally, provide them with education.Without education, there is no future for anyone, not even for children.

name: Cecilia WIKSTRÖM
text: for the ALDE Group. - Madam President! The children who flee alone without any adult support are the most vulnerable people on European soil. We see their vulnerability and how they risk being exploited and exposed to violence and exploitation of unscrupulous adults. Many are disappearing, and we know that Europol describes how 10,000 have disappeared in the past year. The most shocking and sad thing is to see the lonely children who lived in the so-called jungle in Calais, even though they have the right to be reunited with their families in Britain. This is a shame for the European Union, because behind the anonymous faces with blank stares facing visiting visiting TV cameras, there is a name, a life story, a story. In my work as rapporteur for the revision of the Dublin Regulation, we will try to find special ways to create safety and security for these children. No child should live on landfills in Europe, alone in the cold and rain, potential victims of unscrupulous adults. No one on earth has the right to take away their childhood in this way. Our mission is to give them back their childhood. To give them life, hope and future. No more and no less.

name: Malin BJÖRK
text: for the GUE / NGL Group. - Madam President! I think it's time to stop talking with double tongues. At the same time, one cannot stand behind the wall policy, which we are developing here, and at the same time say that one stands for children's rights. The new asylum proposals currently being negotiated are child - hostile. How can it be said that it is in the children's best interests to deprive them of the best chance they have of security, namely to do as in the proposal, make the permanent residence permits impossible? How can you put children in custody, defend it and say that it is in the best interests of children? Deporting children is child-hostile. Closing agreements with third countries to send back as many as possible is also child-hostile. While we are talking here, the demolition of "the jungle" is taking place in Calais, where we receive reports of police violence against children. How difficult can it be for the UK to receive 1,000 children? It is also their right to get there; they have family there. In Greece, children and families are stranded because member states do not receive the redistribution to which they are entitled. Yes, it is like this: If we are to live up to the Convention on the Rights of the Child, then we must change the refugee policy. Then we must put children's safety and security at the center and then we must also make amends and put a stop to the walls' policy.

name: Laura FERRARA
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, among the vulnerable categories, unaccompanied foreign minors are most victims of the absence of a uniform reception system at European level, capable of guaranteeing both the protection and protection of rights, and adequate tools for those who must take charge of the welcome. In Italy, out of over 14,000 foreign minors surveyed, more than 6,000 are untraceable. Calabria and Sicily are the first-line regions in Italy that host the highest number of foreign minors. In the first phase of reception it is often the mayors of the municipalities who have the greatest responsibility by law in meeting the needs of minors, carrying out this task with great difficulty, in terms of economic and human resources and logistical resources. In order to reduce exposure to risks affecting health and psychophysical integrity and to better meet the needs and opportunities for development and education, it is necessary to propose specific legislative instruments or measures, based on the best practices in the reception of minors. which facilitate and clarify above all the duties, functions and competences of guardians.

name: Janice ATKINSON
text: on behalf of the ENF Group. – The UK is about to leave the sinking Titanic and I worry there aren’t enough lifeboats left for your children and citizens. There are 65 million migrants in the world looking for a new home, and they all want to land on the mother ship. Let’s take a reasonable assumption that a quarter of them are children. Where are the millions going to go? It’s interesting to note the changing language. Until today every migrant was a refugee; now they are migrants. Is this a change in policy? Or are you at last being honest with your real aims to destroy our Western civilisation? My country has taken hundreds of children from Calais, and some man-boys pretending to be children. Where were the French social services for these children? The French lecture us but they abandoned their responsibilities. I believe charity begins at home; but in the UK we cannot even help out own children in need. We need an extra 8 400 foster families; 80 000 are children in care; our social workers are at breaking point. We can’t do any more, so please don’t lecture the UK. Finally when the Titanic sinks along with Western civilisation you will have achieved your goal and genuine child refugees will have been cast adrift, and that’s a real shame.

name: Lampros FOUNTOULIS
text: NI). - Madam President, minors entering Europe fall into two categories, refugees and immigrants. The first category is the one that needs real help, since they leave their country against their will, with measures that will ensure care and human living. Their education should be in the language of their country of origin and following its educational system as much as possible. In addition, we must make every effort to end the situation that forced them to become refugees, so that they can return to their countries an hour earlier. In the second category of minors, and provided that their migration has been done through legal channels, it is the responsibility of the parent, who chose to drag his child in this adventure, to take care of his well-being. Immigration of minors should not be allowed, as changing the country of residence is a very serious choice that no one should impose. Minor illegal immigrants must be provided with a humane and dignified life until they are repatriated to their countries of origin as soon as possible so that they can be reunited with their families. Strict penalties should be imposed on those who use underage children, alone or unaccompanied, as a means of crossing the borders of the European Union at risk.

name: Jiří POSPÍŠIL
text: - I am very pleased that this item has been included here in the negotiations and that we are explicitly talking about children as vulnerable. I have listened to the Commissioner's statement that the plan is ready and that it is now being implemented. So let's hope that it will also be implemented and fulfilled, not only that we will only be debating it, and let me make a few remarks. From what the Commissioner has said here, I think that the Commission should place more emphasis on the fight against organized crime, where children are the victims of organized crime. It has been lost several times here, thousands of children have been lost, unfortunately sad statistics, and more needs to be done to make the European institutions, the judiciary and individual Member States more combating this extremely dangerous crime, so that EU interior ministers can talk more about this. their advice so that this topic does not fit. The topic of the asylum procedure was also mentioned here. I personally believe that children need to have specific conditions. In short and well, the return policy of children to their countries of origin is, in my view, very ethically difficult, especially if the child spends several months or years in Europe and should suddenly be returned. The European Commission should, rather than debate the centralized asylum procedure, address how to enable children who have been in Europe for some time to stay in Europe, how to integrate them into European society and to educate them. I think this is the most appropriate and best we can do for them. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162 (8))

name: Tibor SZANYI
text: Blue card question.- Thank you very much for the opportunity.Dear Representative!You rightly mentioned that these children need special care and special treatment.At the same time, there is a characteristic moment that these are mostly teenage, even fifteen, sixteen, seventeen year old children.They move from one moment to the next until they are 18 years old, and by then they will be subject to completely different rules.While we’re talking about the same person who’s barely been here in Europe for maybe a year or two.How do you intend to skip this threshold with these special rules?He was 18 years old because he had grown up after that.

name: Jiří POSPÍŠIL
text: answer the question posed by raising a blue card.- So, of course, this is a very serious, burning question of analogy in criminal law.When someone is 17 years old and commits a crime and then he is 19 years old, he commits a crime under different conditions.It is necessary that transitional rules are simply set for the age close to the age of majority, so that there is really no complete break at the age of 18 and completely different rules apply to those people.As I said, if there is a young person in Europe, unless there are clear compelling reasons, then he should be integrated, not returned, and it is up to the Commission to set these rules.

name: Juan Fernando LÓPEZ AGUILAR
text: - Madam President, Commissioner, all of us in this session have spoken and we speak of the most vulnerable in this migratory crisis - the so-called refugees - and in its most tragic dimension, which is the one that affects minors because, indeed, they are the most vulnerable. But the most shocking thing is that they grow exponentially in number: 350,000 arrived in the last two years; 96,000 of them, unaccompanied, that is, without a father or mother or person to ensure their guardianship, custody and guardianship; 40% in the hottest spots - Italy and Greece -; 1,500 drowned in the Mediterranean: not just the boy Aylan, who effectively tragically broke the communication barrier, but many more unknown "Aylans." And to do so, to face this situation, it is not enough simply that we invoke here the European Agenda on Migration 2010-2014, nor our own Law in force, nor the parliamentary resolutions, nor the Convention on the Rights of the Child. Specific actions are needed, actions regarding family reunification, reception and reception procedures; prohibition of arbitrary detention of minors and, where appropriate, legal assistance and judicial protection; support for the health, education and psychological development of minors; and, of course, adequate relocation and resettlement programs to ensure the guardianship and custody of unaccompanied minors. Because if Europe is a civilization founded on law, it is portrayed exactly in the way it treats the most vulnerable people: minors in the context of the migration crisis.

name: Hilde VAUTMANS
text: - This debate is actually much too late, I think. It is good that it is being fed, but right now, today, the camp in Calais is being cleared. I was there a week ago, 1022 children, asleep in a miserable igloo tent while it's near freezing outside. That is the picture of how we in Europe deal with asylum seekers, with children. So, colleagues, let's really bang on the table. Now let us make a real effort with the Commission to revive that action plan. 10,000 children are missing in Europe. Europol warns and says they are in prostitution and killed for their organs, what about us? We do nothing! So two things. First, let's make a solid action plan: how do we catch them? How do we ensure that they do not fall back into the hands of people smugglers? Secondly, Commissioner, what are we going to do to find those 10,000 children? Because if we think that they cannot sit in cellars, with people as we have known in Belgium, the so-called Dutroux, then we dream. Let's find and save them. That is our duty. [The speaker addressed a “blue card” question under Rule 162 (8).]

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: blue-card question. – Ms Vautmans, do you not think that we ought to call immediately on the Commission to adopt a clearly defined and measurable policy framework, a clear mechanism – I might even call it a special mechanism – with a view to employing a comprehensive approach to prevent violence, exploitation and abuse, and strengthen protection systems for the most vulnerable, especially for children?

name: Hilde VAUTMANS
