text: "blue card" answer.- Yes, of course, colleague.I can't be against that.Of course we can do that and I will go even further.I have visited many asylum centers in Belgium and there are very good practices that allow us to prevent children from disappearing again in Europe.Just let us share those good practices.Let's also report it to the police immediately and distribute posters if a child disappears from an asylum seekers' center.And not, like now, only report after a week and then be completely lost.So of course I agree;you will have our support.

name: Ignazio CORRAO
text: - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, about 20,000 unaccompanied minors arrived in Europe via Italy this year, while about 12,000 had arrived in 2015. A significant increase which, however, finds the Italian reception system inadequate to respond to their needs, even the most basic and essential ones. This year alone, more than 5,000 minors have been reported missing from reception centers. We are talking about 28 children a day who become so invisible and, consequently, even more vulnerable to phenomena of abuse, violence and exploitation. Many of them find themselves confined for an indefinite time in centers they cannot leave, forced to live in inadequate and insecure housing, with no information about their rights and in total uncertainty about their fate. Sicily today hosts about 5,000 foreign minors, a much higher figure than those of other Italian regions. As if that were not enough, 400 communities for unaccompanied foreign minors on the island are in total collapse, with workers without salaries for a year and ready to open their doors. It seems obvious to me that, faced with this situation, the European Union must intervene decisively and without any delay.

name: Georg MAYER
text: - Madam President! Children - wherever they are in the world - need special protection. It was only seen differently in the dark Middle Ages. Ideally - and this should be the focus of our interest - they will get this special protection in their families and in their home countries. And if a child has a right to asylum - I think we can put that out of the question - then it also has a right to special protection in the country where this right of asylum is granted. A special situation is - this has already been mentioned several times today - the escape. The escape from a child is of course a particularly exceptional situation. We know, for example, from escaping girls that they are abused, that they are held up in camps, that some of them succumb to severe imprisonment, and that this happens through IS, for example, but also by other Islamic groups. This is also very reminiscent of the Middle Ages. And that is probably one of the reasons why 86% of the minors who seek asylum in Europe are male. That is a question to which we should also attach particular importance.

name: Stanislav POLČÁK
text: - I consider the problem of the 65 million children at risk to be extremely serious. I want to emphasize that the number is incredibly huge. I'm almost reluctant to believe that the number is real, but I firmly believe that the basis is correct. In my judgment, we must agree that, of course, children are the most vulnerable. On the other hand, we should place the greatest emphasis on precautionary measures so that these situations do not occur, so that such a huge number of unaccompanied minors do not embark on a dangerous journey. The measures we have talked about many times and de facto are constantly being repeated. We should also contribute to the fact that the problem that will increase, the migration will undoubtedly continue to grow, so other EU policies should address it, as well as just being too limited to migration. We should involve our other tools, which we have to solve this problem, because without real preventive measures and then the follow-up measures that we will implement in solving the problem of children, we will not really move even a millimeter further.

name: Julie WARD
text: – Madam President, the number of what we call unaccompanied minors reached a record of more than 95 000 last year. Those children – and this is the proper word to use, because we are dealing here with human beings, not legal entities – are at serious risk of abuse, trafficking and exploitation. They experience traumatic situations on a daily basis.  I have visited the Calais and Dunkirk camp several times and I have seen hundreds of desperate children stuck in limbo. Only last weekend I talked to Yazidi children in a camp in Kurdistan where the Turkish authorities are doing nothing. I am particularly concerned today by the situation that will result from the clearance of the Calais Jungle taking place as we speak.  Beyond the issues of relocation and identification procedure, which must be ethical and compassionate, we must ensure access to education and put in place mechanisms to support and heal children who are very often experiencing immense suffering and trauma, often resulting in serious mental health issues. This must be done by taking into account the special needs of children with disabilities and young women and girls. I also want to highlight the role of non-formal and informal learning, including sport, volunteering, arts and culture, which by providing safe spaces for intercultural dialogue and exchange not only facilitate the social inclusion of refugee children into their new communities, but also address stereotypes, prejudices and discrimination in the host countries. We must act in a concerted way at European level to offer protection to children in the context of migration. A whole generation of children, especially girls and young women, face a bleak future without education. The eight-year-old Yazidi girl I talked to on Saturday is desperate to go to school. We need to invest in her future and the future of all displaced children.

name: Caterina CHINNICI
text: - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, thank you Commissioner for your presence and sensitivity, but too many times in the debate on migration we have focused on the dramatic situation of minors and, in particular, unaccompanied minors who often disappear into thin air and , without being registered or followed, they continue to move, with the lights off, across Europe, thus facing the risk of violence and exploitation. Commissioner, you said it yourself, we now need a specific European strategy, dedicated to migrant and unaccompanied minors. And the intergroup on children's rights, which I chair, has been asking and repeating it for some time. We need simplified procedures that allow rapid recognition and relocation. It is necessary that minors stay as short as possible in the hotspots and that the reception centers respect the minimum standards of protection for children. The regions most exposed to migratory flows need to be able to use structural funds to invest in structures and services for the reception of minors and safe and legal access routes to Europe suitable for minors and their families. Essentially, the best interests of the child must guide European policies and specific actions to protect migrant children.

name: Elly SCHLEIN
text: - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, the images of Calais, where hundreds of minors live in desperate conditions, are still burning in the eyes, trying to jump into trucks to join their families in the United Kingdom. It also happens at Como station, where hundreds of people have camped throughout the summer who tried to cross the Swiss border every night and were constantly rejected, preventing them from seeking asylum when many of these minors would have been entitled to family reunification. In Italy and Greece, the facilities for the reception of minors are completely insufficient, causing promiscuity and inadequate reception conditions. The guardians are often not appointed and a European definition of this figure and its delicate role is still missing. The Dublin reform proposal risks worsening the situation of minors, providing for double transfers and the possibility of returning them to the first country where they applied, forgetting the Court of Justice ruling 648 of 2013 on the supreme interest of the child. We need to put an end to the detention of minors, ensure the continuity of their education and we need to ensure rapid and priority procedures for minors in relocation and family reunification. Only by giving them a clear and certain perspective on their future can we prevent them from escaping, hiding or ending up in the hands of organized crime. They cannot pay for the slowness and inefficiency of our reception system! Dear Commissioner, we have a great responsibility.

name: Ana GOMES
text: - Mr President, reports I heard in Lesbos, Athens, Indomeni, Rome, Calais, Malmö and other places of arrival for immigrant refugees are heartbreaking, revolting, uncomfortable, especially when they come from children who lack everything, including access to education, counseling specialized legal aid, psychological support, often parents and family members, with the risks that lost generations represent both for their countries of origin and for Europe. There are still the most vulnerable among the vulnerable: unaccompanied children, people with disabilities, minorities and thousands of them reported as missing by Europol. In Malmö, police officers told us that if a Swedish child disappeared, they would revolve the country in search of her and those responsible for the disappearance, but if she was a migrant or refugee there was not enough means. And our European governments have the nerve to invoke security reasons when they deliver children to predators of all kinds, associated with the networks of traffickers and, therefore, with the organized crime associated with them, which they go unpunished and whose business, of in fact, they feed. Let us start somewhere against this denatured, dehumanized Europe. Commissioner, we look at the children at least.

name: Cécile Kashetu KYENGE
text: - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, thank you Commissioner.The global approach to the migratory phenomenon must guarantee protection policies for the support and protection of minors.We already spoke out last April, giving clear indications to the Commission and the Member States on the way forward.We have chosen, we have asked for access for minors to legal, health and psychological assistance, housing, education, the humanitarian mission, family reunification.Children are a resource and not a burden.We cannot place our responsibilities on the shoulders of volunteers and NGOs who work tirelessly showing the true face of solidarity to the whole of Europe.We don't want jungles, we don't want walls, we don't want barriers, we don't want roadblocks against welcoming 12 women and 8 children, 8 children guilty of believing in a better world.Europe, this House has already expressed itself, its voice cannot go unheard.

name: Teresa JIMÉNEZ-BECERRIL BARRIO
text: - Madam President, I have a minute to defend the need to adopt urgent measures to defend migrant and refugee children who are arriving in Europe en masse.In this Europe of lost children it is estimated that very many of these children are missing.These boys and girls are victims of sexual abuse and forced labor.These are invisible children.Their dignity has been stolen.We need the Commission, with the support of this Parliament and the Council, to adopt a clear and effective political framework that is capable of defending at least three of the fundamental rights of children, such as the right to education, the right toprotection and the most important of all rights, the right to life.I agree with you, Commissioner, we should not be debating this, we should all agree and be ashamed of what we are seeing happening with unaccompanied minors.

name: Soraya POST
text: - Madam President!In 2015, 35,369 children sought asylum in Sweden.Of these, 300 girls and boys disappeared.And this is not the first time.According to the Swedish Migration Agency, about 300 unaccompanied children disappear each year in Sweden.This is - as the report shows - a problem across Europe.According to Europol, 10,000 children have disappeared.Many are believed to have ended up in the sex industry, and the dark numbers are very large.In Skåne, in southern Sweden, the coordinator against human trafficking has documented around 40 cases of missing, asylum-seeking children.Most are suspected of being used for sexual purposes.These disappearances have been reported to the police.The answer was that the police do not have the resources to investigate.It makes me very upset.It is our duty to prioritize children in the migration issue.

name: Helga STEVENS
text: - Children are at great risk as a result of the unprecedented migration to Europe.Last summer, I visited Greek refugee camps, including the camp in Moria, where migrants set fire to the EASO office during riots yesterday.The Greek authorities must better maintain order and prevent children from being sold or forced into prostitution, as we saw in Greece last summer.But we shouldn't be naive either.Current legislation encourages deception.Adults pretend to be minors.Photos of alleged children leaving the camp in Calais this week show that they are young people over 18.Let us first protect the children who need our protection, and then punish those who take advantage of this by lying.

name: Beatriz BECERRA BASTERRECHEA
text: - Madam President, Commissioner Avramopoulos, I have listened very carefully to your speech. He has gone over everything the European Union has to do to protect children in the context of migration and I am not going to repeat it, but I especially liked how he concluded: 'We should just do it'. And so it is. I would like to endorse the concern that my colleagues have expressed, the one that this Parliament has, and I want to share a little reflection with you. There are fewer Syrian refugees in labor slavery in Turkey, as the BBC recently denounced. What percentage of the 6 billion we allocate to Turkey for migration will we dedicate to ending it? The hundreds of children in Skaramagas, in Dunkirk, in Calais are minors, with whom the governments do not know well what to do, how to proceed, overcome and blocked. Can we give municipalities legal and financial tools to act in coordination with a willing citizenry? And finally, the last instruments of the terrorist attacks in France, Germany, and also the imams of Ibiza wanted them to be in Spain are minor. Do we understand the importance of a common policy to prevent, detect and intervene in radicalization processes in young people?

name: Neoklis SYLIKIOTIS
text: GUE / NGL). - Madam President, Europol estimates that more than 10,000 unaccompanied refugee children have gone missing in Europe due to the Union's lack of policies and its refusal to provide them with security and shelter. At the same time, the symbol of shame and failure of European policies for the reception of refugees, the camp in Calais, is being demolished without taking the appropriate measures to ensure the safety of unaccompanied minors. Those of these children who did not make it to the UK and those who will not be squeezed onto buses for transport to other parts of France are more likely to fall victim to smugglers and traffickers. Even today the fate of some 1,300 unaccompanied minors remains uncertain. Thousands of refugee children are also being exploited in Turkey. Commissioner, ensuring the safety and smooth accommodation of unaccompanied minors is an obligation of the Union under the Charter of Fundamental Rights, the Charter of the Rights of the Child and the United Nations Convention on the Rights of the Child.

name: Igor ŠOLTES
text: - Fifteen million people with children are fleeing war.Among them, of course, are children, those with an escort and also those without, and these children must be adequately protected.Those who are unaccompanied should be provided with additional security and should be provided with custody and appropriate legal representation.Many of them never reach the goal.15,000 children get lost along the way and end up in slavery or even lifeless.These kids are exhausted, without everything and really need our help.What a society we are if we do not stand by their side.And the age limit has started to drop significantly since 2009 - for these children.Now there are very, very young and also small children, and we must never deprive them of their future.

name: Dimitris Avramopoulos
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, let me start by expressing my thanks for your interventions. This only confirms how important the issue is for all of us and I am glad that we share this determination. As you know, the Commission is employing a comprehensive approach to the protection of all children in migration, including, as I said in the beginning, unaccompanied minors. Actions announced in February are being implemented and new actions have been and will continue to be identified as part of an ongoing process.  We are now working in order to complete the implementation of the Action Plan on Unaccompanied Minors for the period 2010 to 2014, and we will evaluate and report on this by the end of the year.  Let me reiterate that the Commission is committed to improving the situation of unaccompanied minors on the ground, and is acting on this commitment. Operationally, including by fighting smugglers, but also legally through our proposed reforms. Right now in Greece and in Italy we are offering financial and logistical support for improving the reception conditions for the children.  We are also offering support to relocate unaccompanied children from Greece and Italy to other Member States. In addition, we are monitoring compliance with EU law in terms of the reception conditions and standards offered to minors, as well as with the procedural safeguards stipulated for the benefit of children. Our asylum reform is aimed at improving the conditions and protection safeguards for children – not lowering their standards.  I count on Parliament to support our proposals in the upcoming negotiations with the Member States. Our debate today proves what I said earlier: we are not debating or questioning the issue of protection of migrant children. We all agree on its necessity and the urgency to act.

name: Kinga GÁL
text: in writing. "Every child has a right to safety and security, so we must act for their rights at all times!" Among minors, migrant children seeking access to Europe are also most at risk of harassment and exploitation and are the earliest victims of human trafficking. That is why it is very important to help children by improving the living conditions in camps close to their homeland, thus avoiding having to travel to Europe at the risk of their lives and at countless dangers. One of the most important elements of this is ensuring access to appropriate education, as this is essential for the healthy development of children, but also for the future of their own community - whole generations must not be left out of education. Providing education and employment opportunities in these camps will help prevent young people from becoming radicalized. That is why Hungary also supports the provision of education in the refugee camps in Lebanon, Jordan and Iraq, and urges the construction of a hospital.

name: Michela GIUFFRIDA
text: in writing. - The numbers of the humanitarian crisis we are experiencing are dramatic. And, as always, the children pay the biggest price. Extremely authoritative sources, such as UNHCR, Unicef, Oxfam, give us a tragic situation. More than 50% of the refugees are children or young people under the age of 18, in the first 7 months of 2016 there were 13,705 unaccompanied minors landed in Italy and then, the most dramatic, in the first six months of 2016, 5,222 unaccompanied minors were been declared "disappeared". The reception of minors cannot follow the rules, times, procedures of that of adults. Children need care, attention, they need psychological support, they need reassurance, they need to feel safe. Europe is still the land of hospitality, we all have in our memory the photo of Emilia Kamvisi, the "grandmother" of Lesbos who gave milk to the newborn who arrived on the coast of the island. Europe is proud of its "grandmothers", of its "fishermen" of all the makeshift heroes who save the lives of thousands of people. But for children like the one in Emilia's arms, Europe must not only save their lives, it must offer them a future.

name: Josu JUARISTI ABAUNZ
text: written. - Demolishing the "Jungle" without first taking into account the protection of the most vulnerable people is a crime. Like Save the Children and other NGOs, I urge the French authorities to stop the dismantling of the "Jungle" until a safe place is found for all children. Many of the 1,300 children in the 'Jungle' remain in danger and the situation is increasingly unstable and tense. On the other hand, this Parliament should demand that the Commission and the Member States of the Union not expel unaccompanied minors under uncertain agreements with unsafe third countries, such as Afghanistan. Lastly, the well-being and dignity of the 60,000 people trapped in Greece for six months, many of them girls and boys, is also the responsibility of the Union, since it gave the green light for the closure of the Balkan Route. And we are neither helping Greece properly, nor are we prepared for an eventual, non-disposable collapse of the infamous agreement with Turkey. It is time for the Union to assume its responsibility and for concrete solutions to truly protect children in the context of migration. Thank you very much.

name: Afzal KHAN
text: in writing. – Even as the process of dismantling the Calais jungle began, the fate of about 1 300 unaccompanied child migrants is uncertain. Both the British and French authorities haven’t done enough to re-unite children and offer them protection. Now many of them are at risk of disappearing into the hands of smugglers and people-traffickers, adding to the 10 000 children who have already gone missing in Europe. The camp has become a symbol of Europe’s failure to respond to the migration crisis, as Member States fight over who should take in those fleeing war and poverty. The refugee crisis hasn’t been met with anything close to equitable responsibility-sharing. While developing countries host 86% of the world’s refugees, the developed states turn their backs on the world’s most vulnerable people, adopting policies aimed at preventing refugees to enter their territory. There’s a chronic shortage of facilities and professional care available for child refugees. Many will spend years waiting to be resettled, lacking access to education, healthcare and protective services, which feeds into longer-term issues. With the today’s oral question we ask the Commission to adopt a clearly defined policy framework with a view to employing a comprehensive approach for the most vulnerable.

name: Christine REVAULT D'ALLONNES BONNEFOY
text: in writing. - Half of the 65.3 million uprooted people in the world are children, alone or with their families. These minors find themselves in situations of high vulnerability, facing the risks of psychological manipulation, physical or sexual violence, but also of exploitation by criminal groups. The best interests of the child should always take precedence over other considerations, such as immigration control. Yet migrant and refugee minors are not granted the specific assistance and protection they need. The European Union and its Member States have a responsibility to develop appropriate policies to remedy this shortcoming, also by strengthening the coordination of efforts on the ground, between civil society, national and European authorities. This requires in particular more efficient asylum procedures for children, the facilitation of family reunification procedures, the prohibition of administrative detention for minors, but also decent reception and integration conditions. It is also essential to designate a guardian for each unaccompanied minor. This humanitarian emergency cannot wait any longer. Europe must stop turning a blind eye to the rights of these children, whose only crime is being born on another continent.

name: Dimitris Avramopoulos
text: on behalf of the Vice-President of the Commission/High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy. – Madam President, I welcome this timely opportunity to join you today. The military campaign to retake Mosul is a critical step in defeating Daesh as a military force and bringing an end to Daesh rule, which has had such disastrous consequences for the people of the region and continues to pose a threat to all of us. The crimes and the atrocities committed by Daesh, including the killings of innocent civilians in and around Mosul over the past days, are a reminder, if a reminder was needed, of the complete depravity of this organisation. Whilst over the past days there has been progress in the military campaign, we need to be aware that this is an extremely complex operation which will need endurance, perseverance and pressures. There are bound to be setbacks. Many fears and concerns have been expressed about the conduct and consequences of the campaign. These are real and valid concerns, and they require all of us to watch the events on the ground closely. At the same time, there are two reasons that give me cause for cautious optimism, at least in this opening phase of the campaign, which I would like to share with you. The first is that the military campaign is based on comprehensive planning and coordination between the Federal Government, the Government of the Kurdistan region and the global coalition. This has led to improved political ties between Baghdad and Erbil. It has seen the Iraqi army enter Kurdish territories for the first time in 25 years with the full agreement of the Kurdistan region. This was unimaginable even a few months ago. The second reason is that we are confident that the Federal Government, under Prime Minister Al-Abadi, has taken on board the message concerning the need to protect civilians and for the Iraqi army to enter Mosul as a liberator, not as an occupying force. Not only that, it is now the Iraqi Government which is the most vocal advocate of the protection of civilians with government instructions to its forces and to the United Nations and the humanitarian community, reflecting their approach. This helps to explain why the Shia militia, with the Pershmerga, have been ordered to keep out of the campaign for the city centre. It is the national institutions of the Iraqi army and the federal police, backed by Sunni tribes, that will fight for the city. Again, a year ago this seemed an unlikely scenario but, as I said, we need to keep a watchful eye. You are all aware of the humanitarian situation and concerns about massive displacement. The way hostilities are conducted will have a huge impact on the safety of the citizens of Mosul, on the perception of the campaign, on civilian infrastructure and on returns and reconciliation. We also need to bear in mind that the behaviour of both Daesh and the militias is inherently unpredictable and will need to be managed as the campaign develops. Currently, the European Union is ensuring the delivery of principal life-saving humanitarian assistance for all civilians most in need, whoever and wherever they are. This is our top priority. To date we have allocated EUR 134 million to respond to the needs of Iraqi internally displaced persons. Equipment is pre-positioned and humanitarian contingency planning has been done jointly with the Iraqi Government and the United Nations. We are also ready to respond to stabilisation challenges that post-Daesh Mosul poses. Stabilisation after the military campaign is as important as the military campaign itself. One area in which the European Union is very proactive is the removal of improvised explosive devices, which is a precondition for the return of the internally displaced people. I am confident that Daesh will be defeated on the battlefield, but we can only defeat extremist ideology by addressing root causes which have given terrorist groups a foothold. In Iraq non-inclusive policies have allowed Daesh to flourish. Therefore, we need to help Iraq in rebuilding an inclusive, peaceful, multi-ethnic and multi-religious society trustful of its state institutions. Inclusiveness, national reconciliation and the rule of law are essential. On regional dynamics, Iraq’s relations with its neighbours are crucial. We are strongly in favour of dialogue between all countries of the region. This is essential as we focus on the primary task of fighting and defeating Daesh in an effective way. Looking ahead, it is our collective moral responsibility to remain a strong partner of Iraq during these difficult moments. Iraq needs all the help we can give at this critical moment for the country’s stability. If we do not do our utmost to help now and ensure that Mosul is both liberated and then stabilised, we will have a much worse situation to deal with, which will have knock-on effects for all the neighbours. The Council has therefore been looking at what more the European Union can do in Iraq. I call on the Parliament to continue to support all the strands of EU actions, to tackle in a comprehensive manner the multiple causes and consequences of the crisis. Thank you very much for your attention and I look forward to our discussion.

name: Lars ADAKTUSSON
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. – Madam President, I would like to thank Commissioner Avramopoulos for the important introductory statement. Today we all share the anxiety when it comes to the humanitarian situation in northern Iraq and the risk for extensive loss of lives. In these difficult times we have a responsibility to assist fellow human beings and support a peaceful transition. For centuries Mosul has been a multi-ethnic city which has surrounding areas like the Nineveh Plain. But let us be clear: without international commitment and a European strategy, sectarian conflicts might replace the ethno-religious coexistence and put an end to 1 700 years of Christian presence in the region. In order to restore human rights and property rights, the resolution we are about to debate supports the idea of establishing an autonomous Nineveh Plain province within the framework of the Iraqi constitution. Furthermore, the resolution emphasises the need for security arrangements and military support to regional defence forces. This is imperative in order to make it possible for refugees and IDPs to return to their ancestral homelands. By passing this resolution, this Parliament will take a lead in the political efforts for a sustainable solution in northern Iraq and its vulnerable minorities.

name: Victor BOŞTINARU
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. – Madam President, I will first express my Group’s gratitude for the manner in which all political groups were cooperating yesterday in order to adopt swiftly a very balanced and a very serious piece of positioning ourselves under situation in Mosul in the northern part of Iraq. And, once again, our gratitude to all. The fight for Mosul shows a quick territorial win for the Iraqi-led coalition forces. Mosul is more than a symbol. It is a decisive step in our effort to defeat Daesh. This being said, this is foreseen to be a long-lasting operation and our absolute priority is to protect the civilians. We have to ensure that they will not remain trapped in Mosul under heavy gunfire and bomb attacks, and they are not used as human shields by Daesh. We have to ensure that the military on all fronts will open humanitarian corridors for the citizens and IDPs that flee the fighting. Therefore my Group calls on all parties to abide by international humanitarian law, to respect principles of proportionality and distinction, and to take all precautions to minimise casualties and to ensure that civilians and civilian infrastructure will be protected, like schools and hospitals, and then they will not be bombed. The evidence of the war crimes and crimes against humanity committed by Daesh should be preserved as a fundamental priority in order to ensure accountability for the perpetrators. With Mosul the Daesh scourge could be largely vanished in Iraq, but Daesh is just a symptom of a larger problem in the Middle East. Until there is a political accommodation between Shia and Sunnis in Iraq and in the region we will not achieve peace in Syria and the terrorism will remain. Finally, it is important to take this opportunity to express our full support for the sovereignty, territorial integrity of Iraq. And then the dramatic need, after Daesh, of a strategy which will involve further humanitarian aid, the re-establishment of the governance, basic services such as healthcare, electricity and education, but also guarantee for the safe return and reintegration of refugees and IDPs, the protection of vulnerable minorities, and the political participation of all religious minorities.

name: Charles TANNOCK
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Madam President, ten days ago the complex military operation finally began to liberate Mosul. Whilst we should welcome the ultimate removal of the evil scourge of ISIS from a city of 1 million people and the demise of its regime, we should not forget that there will be a heavy price to be paid in human terms. The barbarity of ISIS’s war crimes is already clear, as reports emerge of civilians being used as human shields and brutal beheadings carried out, including of boys, to create a culture of fear and repression amongst the population. As well as many IDPs we must also be prepared for the movement of ISIS fighters. As Mosul falls there is a credible risk that as many as 5 000 jihadists will escape the city and make their way to other Islamist hotspots across the globe, notably Libya, Somalia and Yemen. We will also see some reach Europe, unfortunately. The battle for Mosul is seeing a powerful alliance come together, from the air support offered by the US and EU Member States to the Iraqi security forces and Shia militias on the ground.  As the European Parliament’s Chair of the Friends of Kurdistan, I wish today to salute the particularly brave courage of the Peshmerga forces of the KRG who have, and continue to play, a vital role in the fight against ISIS in the Middle East. They have proved to be one of the most effective forces on the ground and we should give them our thanks.

name: Javier NART
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. - Madam president; there is an old Napoleon phrase that is true: "War is waged with money, money and money." Well, the Islamic State has been financing for two years, in the face of our scandalous passivity, with the smuggling of oil that gave from about 14 to 50 million dollars a month. In the month of September 2014, the same month in which I took the act of parliamentarianism, I urged that in sections 5 and 6 of the Resolution of September 2014 a paragraph or some mentions or criteria for sanctioning those who negotiated , trade or carry out any traffic with the Islamic State. Since 2014, from the following October, I have continuously addressed the European Commission and the High Representative, asking them to explain to me what was the balance of the investigations they had done, what was the data they had regarding the companies that They were carrying out this obscene and criminal trade, and what concrete sanctions had been carried out to stop this trade, to stop the war by stopping the blood of war, which is trade and money. I put questions to the Commission and the High Representative in October 2014, January 2015, October 2015, December 2015, January 2016 and March 2016. The answers, which are a monument to diplomatic hypocrisy, consisted of telling me which ones They were the Resolutions that meant prohibition and sanction. No, I did not ask to be explained what the code was, but where the criminals were and what sanctions had been taken. None. Look, in Castilian, in Spanish, there is a phrase that says: "First we create misery and then we arrive with charity." I, frankly, am happy for what is happening now and deeply ashamed of our hypocrisy for two years, which has meant suffering for hundreds of thousands of people in northern Iraq.

name: Javier COUSO PERMUY
text: on behalf of the GUE / NGL Group. - Madam President, it is clear to everyone that Daesh must be defeated in Mosul, but in a military action of this magnitude we must ensure strict compliance with international humanitarian law and the law of war. Unfortunately, when faced with an unscrupulous enemy and with aerial or artillery bombardments, it will negatively affect the population. We really know little about what is happening in Mosul, in the face of stifling propaganda about what is happening in Aleppo. Fortunately, in Mosul we do not call the lords of Al Qaeda rebels and we know that these terrorists are using the civilian population. We are concerned, in this context, by the Turkish invasion of Iraqi territory, carried out against the will of the legal Iraqi Government. We are concerned about news of a corridor tolerated by Turkey, where terrorists move into Syria and attack Kurdish and Syrian forces. No, it does not end like this with Daesh, with that tolerance or buying its oil. We are concerned about proposals to arm militias or local forces, because that fuels the fire; only the federal government should be supported. We are concerned about the lack of funding from UNHCR: the European Union must become fully involved and allocate more funds. The territorial integrity must be preserved and the error of a sectarian government must be avoided. We started this in 2003, we aggravated it with other invasions and by supporting sectarianism by interests. Stop.

name: Bodil VALERO
text: for the Verts / ALE Group. - Madam President! What we have all been waiting for a very long time, ie. the liberation of Mosul and all the civilians who are there has now begun. But it will not be a dance on roses where the Iraqi government goes in one day and proclaims victory the next. The civilian population in Mosul is facing a humanitarian catastrophe and we must be ready to help. Some from Mosul have managed to escape to the immediate area, but also to Rojava in Syria. From Mosul there are no safe ways out and people do not even dare to go out on the street, let alone leave the city. The day they come, it can be up to 1 million people. Aid organizations on the ground testify that today they have the capacity to receive perhaps 60,000 in camps and at most 200,000. Therefore, increased efforts are required from the international community for humanitarian aid and assistance to the area. The aid must also reach those who manage to get to Rojava, where it is testified that the aid does not reach due to Turkey's unwillingness to open the border for relief shipments. Liberating Mosul will not lead to long-term peace as long as there is no strategy for guaranteeing the continued existence of all ethnic groups and the right to return to their homes. The area is home to many minorities such as Chaldeans, Syrians, Assyrians, Yazidis, Kurds, Shabaks, Turkmens, Kakai and Shiites. If the Iraqi authorities do not listen to the minorities' demands for autonomy and increased self-determination and include them in negotiations on future forms of government after the liberation, then the risk is very high that new internal conflicts will arise, instead of the long-term peace we all want for Christmas. (The speaker agreed to take a blue card question under Rule 162 (8)).

name: James CARVER
text: blue-card question. – I share your concerns, colleague. Only last week someone involved in a major NGO in Iraq highlighted to me how, with winter approaching, there is a severe lack of supply of temporary shelters, and there is a huge humanitarian disaster heading this way. Obviously, as the situation in Mosul changes, more refugees will be fleeing.  Will you join me in calling for the international community to be looking again at this and really looking at the number of temporary shelters that are currently being made available?

name: Bodil VALERO
text: answer (“blue card”).- Of course, I think it is extremely important that we all, in different ways, ensure that there are more resources for the organizations that now work in the area.We spoke today with The Norwegian refugee council, who visited us in the group and who told us about their difficulties in getting these many beds needed.They were the ones who told us about the 60,000 today, what they have, and that it says or that we say "We will be able to receive 700,000".They also warned that we may not be able to have more than 200,000 beds.That is why it is so important that we support it.Not only in the immediate area, but also outside.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, the operation that will lead to the liberation of Mosul from the jihadists of the Caliphate has begun. Finally, we would like to say, were it not for the fact that the disagreement that hitherto prevented it remains to this day and paints a gloomy picture of the future of the entire Middle East. To the political and military influence of Tehran on the Iraqi government and to the shared aspirations of the brave Kurds for self-determination is added the unacceptable position of the Turkish government that has deployed troops on Iraqi soil without the Baghdad agreement, thus violating its sovereignty. Erdogan's cryptic declarations concerning the borders of Turkey fixed in Sèvres to be reviewed, combined with the desire not to be a spectator in the reconquest, suggest a dangerous expansionist will that we cannot ignore. As we are doing with this resolution, which in fact not only does not condemn, but does not even mention these very serious facts. Staying on the subject of silence, the American one weighs heavily in view of the presidential elections. A quick conquest of Mosul is undoubtedly an important victory that can be announced at the end of the campaign, but it cannot be achieved at any cost and if the price is to create an easy corridor towards Syria for the jihadists with the aim of further destabilizing it and aggravate the situation of civilians, we, that price, can not accept it. The choices of political players cannot, as too often happens, forget the suffering of civilians. Our role as European champions of humanitarian aid is not enough if it is not accompanied by a clear vision of the destinies of the liberated territories. We support the creation with an inclusive process of new autonomous provinces for the Nineveh Plain, in Tal Afar, Sinjar and wherever it is necessary to guarantee security and democracy to minorities in their ancestral territories. However, we will not accept that Mosul's ashes and oil become the object of a shameful bargaining at the table on the skin of its citizens, because Mosul will eventually fall, and I think soon, too great a disproportion of forces. It might have already fallen for some time if discord and opposing selfishness did not harbor the minds of the powers involved. Recent history teaches us that in Iraq the difficulty is not winning the war, the difficult is certainly not losing the peace.

name: Mario BORGHEZIO
text: on behalf of the ENF Group. - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, the information that has been provided by the Commissioner is meager and even a little irenic, as if we were faced with a situation that is, after all, manageable. Instead we are faced with a situation that could turn into a kind of Stalingrad of the East. God forbid! There will be house-to-house fights, whoever knows even superficially the modus operandi of ISIS can easily imagine what the resistance will be. They will use chemical weapons because, in the carelessness of the West, these warriors of Allah provide themselves with chlorine weapons and mustard gas. Inside there are human shields, inside there are many Christians and among other things there is already an activity of kidnapping of entire populations of the areas bordering Mosul who are brought inside just to be used. Faced with this, what does Europe tell us? what does he do? Nothing more than the vague irenic behavior of an NGO. An absent Europe, which does not even know how to tell us exactly how things stand, how long this siege will last, what risks are there for foreign fighters to flee, which measures are taken at the international level to prevent a worldwide invasion of warriors of the 'ISIS ready to act, maybe even here in Europe, maybe even here in Brussels. You are not doing anything! You are helpless and you leave us defenseless in the face of these risks!

name: Aymeric CHAUPRADE
text: - Madam President, the offensive against Mosul has been launched. It is necessary. Islamic State must finally be destroyed. I want to salute our French soldiers who commit their lives to this fight against totalitarianism. I am also thinking of soldiers from other European countries, of the Americans, of the Russians who, despite the divisions, are all fighting against the same objective: the elimination of this Islamic State. The bells are starting to ring again in several villages near Mosul. For the Christians of the East, who have survived so many genocidal attempts on the part of the conquering Islam, the hope of a return is reborn, as it is reborn for other communities. I think of the Yazidis, who endured these criminals denying all humanity to women, children and all those who oppose their sharia. The Islamic Territorial State will disappear, but this monster will mutate. Other serious problems for the European Union will arise. In Syria, the size of the Free Syrian Army is already growing strangely as defections from the Islamic State increase. We must therefore stop distinguishing the Islamic State from other Islamic components. They form, in fact, the various facets of one and the same evil: Islamic totalitarianism. As for the supporters of the Islamic State who are nationals of the European Union, they will return, alas, to sow death and desolation among us. Rest assured, the collapse of the Islamic State is only the prelude to a planetary war of great intensity between the jihadists and all other civilizations. Under these conditions, Madam President, dear colleagues, the voice of reason is cooperation between all civilizations.

name: Cristian Dan PREDA
text: - Madam President, the EPP Group insisted on including on the agenda the debate on the situation in Mosul because, beyond the primary issue of the fight against Daesh, it is a humanitarian situation extremely delicate. In fact, more than 200,000 people could be displaced in the coming weeks. We must make it a top priority to protect these populations in battle, especially vulnerable communities such as Christians, who overwhelmingly have fled their land. Christians, as well as Yazidis and Turkmens, must be allowed not only to return to their homes, but also to participate in the political and social life of the city. The fate of civilian populations is all the more worrying as the UN has received reports of the atrocities that Daesh fighters are committing. In fact, they use civilians as human shields. The battle for Mosul is decisive for the future of Iraq and the visit of the Iraqi Foreign Minister last week to Brussels is a clear signal of the importance of the Union's assistance in preparing for the post-crisis. reconquest. Even if it does not provide military support, the Union must play a key role at the humanitarian level and for the stabilization of the country, in close collaboration with our partners, and in particular the United States. The Union's strategy towards Iraq set the right priorities: the destruction of explosive devices as well as support for the security services and the rule of law. It is now a question of speeding up their implementation. (The speaker accepts to answer a "blue card" question (Rule 162 (8) of the Rules of Procedure))

name: Jean-Luc SCHAFFHAUSER
text: question "blue card".- Sir, I do not understand why you do not denounce about Aleppo - Do you denounce about Mosul?It is exactly the same situation.Check with the Bishop of Aleppo or the Bishop of Mosul.I know both, they will describe the exact same situation to you.Why two weights, two measures?What you said is very good.Why don't you say it for Aleppo?

name: Cristian Dan PREDA
text: answer "blue card".- Mr Schaffhauser, we have made inquiries.We also spoke with very important religious figures.Unfortunately, we do not find ourselves in their positions, which are delicate when they support people like Bashar Al-Assad in Syria.The protection of Christian communities cannot go hand in hand with the support of dictators or friends of these dictators, in particular your great friend Vladimir Poutine.

name: Enrique GUERRERO SALOM
text: - Madam President, it is estimated that there are more than a million people in the city of Mosul and, since the military actions began, only 10,000 have managed to leave the city. For those who remain trapped within it, the most important thing right now are safe routes to exit and reliable places to go. And, therefore, the first effort must be to plan these safe routes, communicate them appropriately to the population, preserve those who leave the city and ensure protection along those routes. Then we will have to give a humanitarian response to avoid Aleppo's mistakes. I know that the European Union has displaced resources and is prepared for it, but it will be another very important humanitarian crisis and we have to make sure, in that humanitarian crisis, that we have learned from the mistakes of Aleppo and other parts of Syria and apply the international humanitarian law and the protection of the most vulnerable.

name: Anna FOTYGA
text: On October 17, the long-awaited offensive on Mosul began - the last, great bastion of jihadists in Iraq.This attack is being carried out from several directions at the same time by the Iraqi special forces and the Kurdish peshmerga, supported mainly by the American and British.Prime Minister al-Abadi has already expressed his satisfaction with the speed of the operation, but we all know that it will probably be long and very difficult, especially for the civilian population.Let us hope it will lead to the final liberation of this people.I am a supporter of the most far-reaching involvement of the European Union in humanitarian aid and cooperation within the framework of the United Nations and other organizations.I also believe that Mr Adaktusson's proposals on the subsequent solutions concerning minorities, including Christians, deserve our attention, because they are very interesting.

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: – Madam President, of course the only way to defeat ISIS is to take back the territory. I think that victory hopefully not far from us in Mosul and later on in Iraq, are the best signs of the weakening of ISIS. But victory is not the end. Victory, as the Commissioner also hinted, is the start. I think that we all know that the Sunni residents are not keen on the government in Baghdad or on the Shiites and we do have political, social and other dilemmas that have been in Iraq for years. We will need to find an answer. I think that is where, Commissioner, as you have also said, we will have to work with the Iraqi Government, with the regional governments, with the international community, to come up with a strategy, to have a long-lasting solution. There is one other point that we have to be prepared for, of course. Defeating ISIS on the ground does not mean that the jihadists will not change and reinforce what they have been doing in the past and that is terrorist attacks in Europe. We need to be prepared for that as well and we should debate both issues in the future here in the plenary.

name: Barbara LOCHBIHLER
text: - Madam President!We all know the reports of the Islamic State's reign of terror in Iraq and Syria.We are therefore hopeful that the Islamic State's terror regime in Mosul will soon end.It is now important for the EU to intensify humanitarian aid and to coordinate it well, in the event that a mass exodus from Mosul occurs in the near future.In addition, all parties fighting IS in Iraq must ensure that they respect international law and that violations are punished.When Fallujah was liberated in May 2016, Iraqi government forces and paramilitary militias committed human rights violations and war crimes;kidnappings, torture and executions took place.Such incidents must not be repeated.The EU must also demand peace-building measures for the period after the end of IS rule.

name: James CARVER
text: – Madam President, if we are serious about peace in the Middle East we must control and limit Turkish actions in Iraq and also in Syria. Their presence complicates the situation in Mosul and raises serious questions about their possible aspirations in the Sinjar region. Yesterday the Turkish Foreign Minister stated that Turkey may attack Kurdish troops in Iraq if it felt it to be in the national interest, before accusing the Iraqi Government of tying itself to a terrorist organisation, ignoring, of course, how Kurdish forces are at the forefront of the fight against the Islamic State. Madam President, whilst Turkey claims to be part of the international effort to liberate Mosul, they legitimise their military forward station at the Bashiqa military camp outside Mosul, at the very time that the Iraqi Government has stated how Turkey sends its troops into Iraq without permission, hence Baghdad’s repeated demands that Turkish groups withdraw. We must all support a speedy end to the fighting in Mosul and continue to respect the brave sacrifices of Kurdish groups in the fight against Islamic State.

name: Marie-Christine ARNAUTU
text: - Madam President, I also welcome the decline of the Islamic State. The liberation of Mosul and the Nineveh Plain in fact gives hope to the civilian populations who have suffered or fled the atrocious yoke of the Islamists. However, some still have short memories. The Atlanticist international coalitions are primarily responsible for the chaos in the Middle East, but skilful communicators are already explaining to us, hand on heart, that the Western powers have the best intentions in the world and are using gentle democratic bombs that bring tomorrows that sing, unlike the nasty Russian bombs. Those who today praise the bombing of the coalition, are they not the same who, by their policy, allow the Islamists to hold the inhabitants of East Aleppo hostage; the same people who applauded the neoconservatives when they preached the crusade against Saddam Hussein, whose overthrow is ultimately at the root of the current disaster; the same people who sympathize with Qatar and Saudi Arabia; the same ones, moreover, who are swooning over the antics of warmonger Bernard-Henri Lévy? I believe the hypocrisy must finally end.

name: Tunne KELAM
text: – Madam President, Iraqi traditional minorities have suffered most as a result of regional conflict and ISIS terrorism. The European Parliament concluded in February that Daesh is committing genocide against Christians, Yazidis and other religious minorities. I think this message should be now taken with utmost seriosity because historic, religious and ethnic minorities face a challenge there: to be or not to be. The European Parliament has already supported the need to create safe havens for Chaldeans, Syriacs, Assyrians and others in the Nineveh Plains, Tal Afar and Sinjar areas. This could take the practical form of a special province of Iraq, which would provide for all religious and ethnic groups used to settle the region’s safety and equal opportunities. What we need is determined support by the international community and I think the EU assistance should not be substantially increased but also be allowed to be channelled directly to local churches, peace-based relief organisations and security forces who live among the people in need, and know best their problems. If rules make obstacles for that, the rules must be changed. There should not be an excuse, because it is about our common faith and future. Europe cannot continue to observe the destruction of the very roots of our civilisation, because this is about our common religious and cultural continuity.

name: Pier Antonio PANZERI
text: - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, it has been said that we have reached a decisive stage in the advance towards Mosul, the last stronghold of Daesh. Well, in this framework, what needs to be done? First of all, I think that the offensive on Mosul must necessarily be accompanied by a humanitarian intervention that can not only save civilians, who risk being used as human shields by terrorists, but above all offer safe corridors and shelter the forced evacuees. to escape from military action. Secondly, it is necessary to know that, if we want to safeguard the territorial integrity of Iraq, we must secure the areas that will gradually be liberated and international control would be useful because the risk, if we did not control situation is the recurrence of clashes and tensions. Here there is a space for European protagonism and I think the time has come to exercise it to avoid repeating the mistakes of the past.

name: Bas BELDER
text: - How can the EU contribute to the continued presence of the Christian and Shia minority in Northern Iraq after liberation from IS barbarism? To this crucial question that was running through my mind, I received a crystal clear answer last night by phone and email from Erbil, from the region itself, or rather, an urgent appeal for European help in the reconstruction of severely affected Christian areas in the plains of Nineveh to encourage the return of expelled and persecuted native Christians. The EU should press at national and regional level in Iraq for fair political representation of the Christian Shia minority in Northern Iraq. Independent local councils for the various minorities are the proposed - and in my opinion the most suitable - instrument for this purpose. It is also urgent that the EU is strongly urging the Iraqi government to amend recent discriminatory legislation against non-Muslim minorities. Why, for example, should only a non-Muslim be allowed to change their religion? See Section 26 of the National Identity Card Act.

name: Franz OBERMAYR
text: - Madam President! Even after the hoped-for retaking of Mosul, some questions remain unanswered. IS will continue to operate as a highly dangerous Islamist terrorist organization. Turkey currently operates between the Iraqi army, between the Shiite troops and the Kurdish peshmerga and knowingly violates international law just to prevent a contiguous Kurdish state, a contiguous Kurdish region. Commissioner, I miss the fact that you mention that too. I assume you know, but unfortunately you don't tell God. It is thanks to the Turkish journalist Can Dündar, a favorite for the Sakharov Prize, that these outrageous Turkish arms-trafficking with IS was exposed. If we say today: We want another multi-ethnic, multi-denominational, multi-cultural Iraq - yes, that is good, right and beautiful. It will also cost a lot. But of course we also miss the assignment of why it came to this. This catastrophic foreign policy of the United States - supported by some European states - ultimately led this poor state of Iraq into this chaos.

name: György HÖLVÉNYI
text: - Ms. President! It may sound strange in Parliament, and it sounds very strange, but there is a situation, there is a situation and there is a chance, there is a chance for the Iraqis and there is a chance for Europe to finally act in time. And that is why this report was important. I want two specific things in order to listen to the locals, we don’t have to figure everything out. A few rooms away, Nevroz Mad Rudd Amin, a Kurdish municipal minister, sits away. Half an hour earlier, we stopped the conversation and said the following: identity and security. There is a terrible danger of hundreds of thousands leaving the area uncontrolled and we do not know how the situation will turn out. For the time being, it is about water, for the time being it is about blankets, later it will be about education, the minister said, barely twenty minutes or half an hour ago. A few hours ago, I spoke to Chaldean Archbishop Irkiz of Kirkuk, Iraq. As a result of the local church war, it has been providing for hundreds of thousands of believers and internally displaced people for years. What he said? Three things: First, we need to restore health care, which is catastrophic. We have serious financial and technical capacities for this. On the other hand, there is an urgent need to start rebuilding homes and infrastructure. Thirdly, education needs to be organized so that young people have a vision ahead of them. He said a phone call from Kirkuk a few hours ago. Let’s build on the locals and finally do nothing about them, about them.

name: Afzal KHAN
text: – Mr President, last week’s EU-Iraq Cooperation Council gives hope that the military fight against Daesh in Iraq, and primarily Mosul, will soon come to a successful end. The EU has established itself as a key player in Iraq, providing vital humanitarian and stabilisation assistance to millions of people affected by the crisis. The EU and UK have pledged to provide another EUR 95 million in humanitarian crisis aid. This is good news, but I am worried about the political consequences of the Mosul operation. What is our next step in engaging with Iraq following the government’s declaration of victory over Daesh? In my view, we must use our leverage to pressure the Iraqi Government to end the marginalisation of Sunnis and other minorities. In the future this government must focus on good governance, power sharing, the reconciliation process and job creation. This is one of the main lessons of 2003 Iraq. If we do not ensure peace and justice in Iraq we are sowing the seeds for another post-Daesh extremist organisation.

name: David CAMPBELL BANNERMAN
text: – Mr President, as Chair of the Iraq delegation, I made it clear our priority must be to help destroy ISIS in Iraq, Syria and wherever it resides. I salute the courage of the Iraqi armed forces, and the Kurdish Peshmerga in particular, in their gruelling efforts to retake Mosul from the murderous tyrants of ISIS. Insha’Allah they will defeat ISIS and drive them out of Iraq.  A year ago I flew over Mosul and visited the Peshmerga on the front line. The fruits of that military success are already being seen and, for the first time in two years, church bells are rung in Bartella, a predominantly Christian town on Mosul’s outskirts. They leave behind, however, a bloodbath of victims – Christians, Yazidis, Turkmen Shiites and other minorities – and only now will we see the true extent of the underlying damage. The humanitarian challenge of 700 000 people needing help will be immense and so will the political challenge of what happens next.

name: Esther de LANGE
text: - Dear colleagues, Falloedja, Ramadi, Mosul - these are the names of cities that have already been conquered from IS or where the battle is still going on at the moment. Of course that is a good thing, but the experiences in Falloedja and Ramadi teach us that military success alone is not enough. That is why I am also pleased with the words spoken in that line by the Commissioner. The question is: what is our plan after that? That plan is insufficiently or not at all, not in Iraq, nor in the international community. The big question, of course, is: once that common enemy, IS, has been driven out, will the rivalries between all kinds of groups in Iraq and the tensions caused by foreign interference come to the surface again? I fear so when I look at a recent report from Amnesty International, which already points to serious human rights violations by the government army and by Shia militias. Much attention in our debates is often focused on the tension between Sunnis and Shias, the large groups in the country. But the small minorities are in danger of being completely ground up in Iraq. Of the 1.5 million Christian minorities in 2003, 200,000 to 300,000 people are now left. In a resolution of February this year, the European Parliament spoke of genocide by IS against these Christian minorities. How are the European Commission and the High Representative going to follow up on that resolution and, with Iraq, take care of that political plan, paying particular attention to those small minorities?

name: Kati PIRI
text: - The battle for Mosul is now entering its second week.More and more villages in the vicinity of IS are being liberated, but the terrorist group still controls Iraq's second city.At the same time, not only IS is circled, but also the one million civilian population.Thousands of people have since fled and it is expected that an unprecedented flow of refugees will arise in the coming days.A new humanitarian disaster if we are not there in time to help.The € 50 million that the EU has made available for humanitarian aid in Mosul is a good start, but it is also very important that a strategy is developed to provide civilians with safe shelter.And now that the situation is getting more dangerous by the day, it is almost time for that.

name: Mirosław PIOTROWSKI
text: - In the face of the offensive against Mosul, the subject of the situation in Iraq returns to the European Parliament.People, Christians, are dying there all the time.In February this year, our House emphasized in a special resolution that the so-calledIslamic State is committing genocide against Christians, Yazidis and other minorities.In the resolution currently being prepared by our group of European Conservatives and Reformists, we show the scale of these crimes.Thirteen years ago, Iraq had 1.5 million Christians.Currently, their number is estimated at 200,000 to 350,000.There are Christian self-defense forces in this area that work with the Iraqi army, but they need the help they need.This is what we also call for in our resolution.It is also imperative that the European Union becomes more involved in humanitarian aid.

name: Francisco José MILLÁN MON
text: - Mr President, I very much welcome the progress in the offensive against Daesh made in recent months by the Iraqi armed forces, the Kurdish peshmerga and the other forces of the international coalition. In this campaign, Mosul is now a priority target, as has already been said. The news of rapid progress is encouraging, but caution is required. In any case, I trust that this complex operation will culminate as soon as possible with the least possible loss of human life and with full respect for international humanitarian law. The entry into Mosul should be led by the Iraqi army, assisted by the forces of the international coalition, avoiding interference by third parties that could jeopardize the success of the mission and the subsequent stage. It seems particularly important to me to avoid all kinds of sectarian revenge and possible mass exoduses. In addition, the military victory will then pose significant humanitarian security challenges, the population's access to basic services, as well as reconstruction and reconciliation, which must be urgently addressed, as noted at the high-level meeting. from Paris last week. In short, it is necessary for the Iraqi population to be able to resume its normal life, so to speak. Finally, Mr President, in Mosul, as in the rest of Iraq and in most of the Middle East, it is also necessary to overcome sectarian confrontations of a religious, ethnic or territorial nature. There will be no viable political solution or peace or stability if political and social inclusion, territorial integrity and reconciliation do not prevail.

name: Francisco ASSIS
text: - Mr President, the battle for the liberation of Mosul is, as we know, a huge military challenge, due to the nature of the enemy, and a huge humanitarian challenge, due to the number of civilians affected. But in the battle of Mosul there is much more to it than the defeat of Daexe and the liberation of the city and its inhabitants. The future of Iraq is at stake. That Daexe will be defeated, it is a certainty! But we can no longer be sure that the defeat of Daexe will automatically start a time of peace in this martyred country. Some of the forces that today fight the Jihadists fought among themselves not so long ago. There are wounds and rivalries only temporarily suspended. The post-Daexe period will therefore be a critical period, full of dangers, but it will also be a historic opportunity for Iraq's reconciliation and development. As we know, Iraq is characterized by great ethnic-religious diversity. The country will only achieve peace and prosperity if it respects and preserves this diversity, creating conditions for the political participation of the diverse religious minorities and social currents. The goal of Iraq's stabilization and prosperity will depend on external and internal efforts. It will have to go through, among others, a dialogue between Shiites and Sunnis, as well as a dialogue with the various countries in the region and the European Union can, and should, play a very active role there. Thank you very much.

name: Andrzej GRZYB
text: - First, I would like to thank my colleague Lars Adaktusson, who was the initiator of this debate. It was he who suggested that we talk about it, bearing in mind the ongoing offensive in the outskirts of Mosul. We all agree that defeating ISIS, conquering Mosul is only the beginning of the whole problem that we will have to solve. I fully agree with what the Commissioner said that we need to find humanitarian solutions, but also help to reconcile, to build multi-ethnicity and multi-religion in this area. As a result of the hostilities, there will also be another wave of migration; we don't know how big. It all depends on the progress of the military forces. However, we can also take into account that there will be a humanitarian catastrophe there. On October 19, the media reported that the city of al Hamdanyia forty kilometers southeast of Mosul, a former Christian center, had been recaptured. How strange it sounds: "former center of Christians." After all, about one hundred and forty thousand Christians lived there. Few of them remained. We must therefore follow the appeal of Mr Lars Adaktusson and help Christians and followers of other religions return to territories that were once ethnically theirs too.

name: Ana GOMES
text: - Mr President, a few years ago I visited the brave Peshmerga in the front line next to Mosul and I realized how liberating this city is decisive to destroy the Daexe globally. But it is imperative that liberating forces respect international law, during and after the military operation and open humanitarian corridors under international monitoring. European Union governments have a duty to support the authorities of Iraq and the Kurdish regional government more and more effectively, working together in humanitarian as well as military aid, including in supporting the reconstruction and protection of liberated areas and minorities. , in deterring Turkey's territorial ambitions, in the Shiite-Sunni dialogue essential for reconciliation and democratic governance, in addition to making sure that the war crimes and crimes against humanity committed by Daexe and other forces are referred to the International Criminal Court, a global strategy to combat extremist and terrorist violence and its constituents and financiers.

name: Elmar BROK
text: - Mr President, Commissioner, colleagues! I believe that cracking down on ISIS is a necessary matter because these terrorists do not want to negotiate with anyone and do not need to find a reasonable settlement for anyone. It is therefore right that this should go ahead, despite all the sacrifices that are taking place there. Commissioner, we must also ensure that the consequence is no longer terror in Europe. So there is a connection here that they cannot find alternative battle sites there; We must also include this. I believe that if this is done sensibly in Iraq now, it will be possible that the people will return to their homeland and that there will be no refugee movement because of this, but that there will be hope, for which we must also do reconstruction work. But this will have only one credibility - in view of the great suffering Yazidis, Christians and others have had, as fought, tortured and killed by their neighbors at the beginning of ISIS 's operations - if the Iraqi state gets a sensible state structure . The Shiite government in Baghdad must know that this must be an organization where the Kurds in Ebril, as well as the other communities such as the Christians and the Sunnis, can find security through the organization of the state and do not run the risk of fear when they return to their homes, their villages, that they will soon be victims of another attack. I hope that all of the support we are now giving militarily - for example, the Federal Republic of Germany for the Peshmerga, which plays a major role and which is also important for the internal organization of the country - must be seen in context.

name: László TŐKÉS
text: - I congratulate Mr Lars Adaktusson on initiating a European Parliament resolution on the situation and future of ethnic and religious minorities in northern Iraq. It is our conscientious, moral, and political duty to act in faith to protect the indigenous Christians, Yazidis, Turkmen, and other minorities living in the Mosul area, on the Nineveh Plateau, who are threatened by their mere existence. The international and European community can only work together to end the genocide and genocide in the region, the war and the crimes against humanity. Saving Iraqi Christianity, which has shrunk from one and a half million to about 300,000, is a top priority. The main priority against further escalating migration is the repatriation of expelled Christians and other minorities to their homeland. I welcome and consider it exemplary that the Hungarian government has set up an independent secretary of state in ... (The President withdrew from the Member).

name: Rainer WIELAND
text: We now come to the catch-the-eye procedure.I have a lot more requests to speak than are allowed for this time unit.You will understand that I cannot take every political group into account for five minutes.Nor will I take into account those who have already spoken about the catch-the-eye procedure.Catch-the-eye procedure

name: Marijana PETIR
text: - Mr. President, I express my concern about the humanitarian situation in Iraq and support the activities being carried out to help save lives and provide assistance to all those in need, as well as to stop further displacement. Sectarian violence threatens the survival of minorities, and before 2003, Iraq was home to more than 1,400,000 Christians. Christians have become the target of extremist groups. Churches were destroyed, Christians abducted and killed, and those who survived and remained in Mosul ended up on the road as homeless. At the behest of ISIS, a proclamation was issued in 2014 according to which all Christians had to choose to either pay taxes and convert to Islam, leave the city, or die. They were only allowed to take with them the clothes they wore on their bodies. All the remaining 25,000 Christians left the city and then for the first time in history Mosul was left without Christians. I believe that ISIS will be defeated, but it is necessary to defeat their ideology and enable an inclusive democratic society. Perhaps establishing self-government could be the solution for Christians in Nineveh.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the offensive against the Daesh jihadists in Mosul, in northern Iraq, appears to be making progress.It is a question of freeing a city of over one million inhabitants living in dramatic conditions from merciless occupation.In order to resist and guarantee their lives for days, the Daesh militiamen have forced children and women to stay on the roofs of houses transformed into bunkers to avoid air raids.There is fear of a real humanitarian catastrophe.According to the UN representative in Iraq, Peter Hawkins, thousands of people are fleeing the Mosul area, the scene of the fighting.The conditions of the children, crammed into refugee camps, are particularly precarious.Europe and the international community must work for the protection of civilians now trapped in Mosul and the neighboring villages and ensure that aid and humanitarian assistance for the inhabitants of the Nineveh Plain arrives as soon as possible.

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: - Mr. President, it is believed that there are still about one and a half million civilians in Mosul, along with about 5,000 ISIL militants.In the last 10 days, more than 5,000 people have fled the conflict territory to a refugee camp across the border into Syria.They came to the al-Hol camp, which is already crowded and where the conditions are extremely bad.Current information is that another 1,000 refugees are waiting to cross the border and it is becoming increasingly certain that the world will soon face one of the biggest humanitarian crises of recent times.Therefore, I strongly support this resolution and believe that efforts should be made to force all parties to the conflict to respect international humanitarian law, to protect civilians and access humanitarian and medical assistance, and to enable civilians to leave areas affected by violence safely and with dignity.Urgent and uncompromising humanitarian support from the European Union and the rest of the international community to the people of Iraq is now imperative.

name: Ilhan KYUCHYUK
text: - Mr President, Commissioner, the offensive against the city of Mosul is remarkable not only for its lightning speed, but also for its importance on a global scale. We are witnessing an unprecedented unification of different religious and ethnic groups in the name of peace and the territorial integrity of Iraq. Sunnis, Shiites, Kurds and Christians are working together to fight the last major Islamic State bastion in Iraq. Unfortunately, we must acknowledge that the military intervention against Mosul puts the large civilian population to a serious humanitarian test. More than 1 million people are literally held hostage by Islamic State terrorists, and even children and women are being used as human shields. This situation could trigger a new wave of refugees in the short term, and I consider it extremely important to ensure the maximum protection of the civilian population during hostilities. We also need to continue to work together and for the international community to support the Iraqi Government with humanitarian aid during ongoing operations. The civilian population in the region needs our help, and the European Union must be an active player in implementing the peace plan in Iraq.

name: Csaba SÓGOR
text: – Mr President, the chances are very high that Mosul will be retaken from Islamic State. However, there is much uncertainty about the battles that will follow.
