The coalition should take extreme care that Mosul does not become another Aleppo, which is being bombed to the ground by Syrian and Russian forces. Once IS control of the city has weakened, there will also be an exodus of hundreds of thousands of civilians, and I fear that not enough has been done to prepare for this. For the future, much will depend on avoiding an armed free-for-all by rival militias and preventing a Shia takeover of the Sunni population of the city. Every care should be taken, already at this stage, that the battle will lead a real advance in the fight against the nihilism of jihad.

name: Dimitris Avramopoulos
text: on behalf of the Vice-President of the Commission/High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy. – Mr President, this has been really a very useful exchange and I would like to express my thanks to the Members for their interventions. From this debate I come to the conclusion that we all share a common interest in using EU diplomatic powers and EU instruments to their full potential in support of the Iraqi crisis. Some of you asked about the Turkish participation in the air strikes. I would like to remind you that Turkey is a member of the global coalition to counter ISIL/Daesh. However, the Turkish Government should consult with the Iraqi Government, and the global coalition, before taking any action on Iraqi soil. On Christians in the Middle East – I think Mr Brok raised it. The EU is doing all it can. It is delivering urgent humanitarian aid to all Iraqis in need. This certainly includes Christians, and the European Union has had a regular dialogue with church representatives from the region since the beginning of the crisis. We also regularly call on the Iraqi Government, and the Kurdistan region of Iraq, to apply non-sectarian and non-discriminatory humanitarian assistance policies. We will continue to look at how best to use all the instruments available to us in humanitarian relief, stabilisation, development assistance and political dialogue, and in specific support to human rights and democracy. May I close by signalling once again my appreciation of Parliament’s role in keeping this important issue at the top of your agenda.

name: Rainer WIELAND
text: To wind up the debate, seven motions for resolutions have been tabled under Rule 128 (5) of the Rules of Procedure.The debate is closed.The vote will take place tomorrow, Thursday 27 October.Written statements (Rule 162)

name: Mireille D'ORNANO
text: in writing. - The offensive by Iraqi forces, supported by the Kurds, on the Iraqi city of Mosul began last Monday. This offensive, if successful, would spell the end of the expansion of the Islamic State in Iraq, completed by the capture of this city of two million inhabitants on June 10, 2014. Located in the Nineveh plain, Mosul is home to many ethnic and religious minorities, including the Christian minority. They have been at the forefront of ISIS's persecution: from 1.5 million in 2003, the number of Christians is around 200,000 today. This massacre was described as genocide by the European Parliament on February 4, 2016. The battle for Mosul will lead to a major humanitarian crisis: 1.5 million refugees would be added to the 3.3 million Iraqis displaced since 2014. In this In an emergency context, I support the assistance effort deployed by the European Union, whose contribution has so far amounted to 134 million euros, including 50 million for the city of Mosul. We cannot, however, condone any interference by the European Union in Iraqi internal affairs, since it was Western interventionism that led to the collapse of this state from the 2003 US military operation.

name: Emil RADEV
text: In written form. - Dear colleagues, when Islamic State conquered Mosul in 2014, half of its population fled the city to escape certain death. Today, two years later, the city looks like an apocalyptic scene from a movie. A film whose main characters are mostly women, children, the elderly. And while the dilemma facing Iraq is how to recover politically after winning the battle against Islamic State, the dilemma facing the international community is how to ensure the safety of millions of civilians and how to help them return to their homes. It will take weeks, even months, for millions of civilians fleeing to conquer the city. It is necessary to provide these people with access to food, water, shelter, as well as a safe way out of the city as soon as possible, especially for the most vulnerable groups, including the Christian minorities there. The EU and the international community must work so that the civilian population of this country is protected and given the meaning to remain in their home country. Otherwise, if we fail to do so, then Europe could face a new refugee crisis, no less terrible than the current one.

name: Rainer WIELAND
text: The next item on the agenda is the statement by the Vice-President of the Commission and High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy on Afghanistan, in particular the EU's commitments and the role of the EP in the context of the joint action between Afghanistan and the EU on migration issues (2016/2948(RSP)).Commissioner Avramopoulos spoke on behalf of the High Representative.

name: Dimitris Avramopoulos
text: on behalf of the Vice-President of the Commission/High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy. – Mr President, let me start by expressing my thanks for the opportunity to discuss with you today the main elements of the Joint Way Forward on migration issues. This document was signed on 2 October between Afghanistan and the European Union. It should be seen not only in the context of EU—Afghan relations but, more importantly, in the context of the European Union’s new partnership framework with third countries under the European Agenda on Migration. This initiative falls under the package of efforts to address the ongoing migratory crisis and was welcomed by the last European Council. More than a year ago we adopted, as you will remember, the European Union’s Agenda on Migration which this House has welcomed. The EU Agenda on Migration set out our common strategy on the basis of this principle. A common challenge demands a common European response. It demands a comprehensive policy, which includes both short and long—term solutions and a coordinated approach of our internal and external policies in order to address all aspects of this phenomenon. Preventing irregular migration is one of the issues that demands a long-term policy and engagement with key third countries. Our engagement, therefore, with Afghanistan, along with other key countries of origin, is part of this comprehensive approach. It is in this spirit that the European Union and Afghanistan have decided to bring their cooperation to the next level. Let me stress the overall picture. Europe faced an unprecedentedly large number of irregular migrants of Afghan origin in 2015 and during 2016 Afghans continue to represent the second largest group of irregular migrants to the European Union. A large number of them will most likely be eligible for international protection either because they belong to specific categories of persons or because they originate from certain areas of the country. I do not have to repeat that every asylum seeker goes through a due and fair process, respecting her or his rights according to EU laws. Those who are not eligible for international protection will have to be returned. This is exactly the issue which needs to be addressed with the Afghan authorities. The Afghan authorities do not contest the international law principle of readmitting their nationals found in an irregular position. They are, however, concerned about the impact of their return on those who return and on their receiving communities as well. This issue has to be adequately and proactively managed. Their concern, which the European Union shares, is moreover amplified by the fact that other neighbouring countries, notably Pakistan and Iran, are already returning thousands of irregular Afghan migrants back to Afghanistan. These returns are happening without an accompanying measure in favour of those who return and of the communities that will receive and reintegrate them. Until 2 October the European Union did not have any cooperation framework with Afghanistan. This situation had created mistrust with limited possibilities for dialogue and cooperation, but also uncertainty for the migrants. The only ones profiting from the lack of a cooperation framework were the criminal organisations dealing with migrant smuggling. Now we have this framework for dialogue and cooperation to discuss the issues of return, readmission and reintegration of the irregular migrants in a comprehensive, balanced and sustainable manner. This will also help to address the concerns of the Afghan authorities I mentioned before. I would now like to give you an overview of what the Joint Way Forward is, what it is not, and what its key elements are. Let me start by reminding you that the Joint Way Forward does not refer to persons having been granted international protection status in the European Union or whose international protection request is still being examined. It only covers irregular migrants – persons who either have not requested asylum or whose asylum claim has been rejected and they have no right to stay in the European Union. In all cases the principle of non-refoulement will be preserved and respected. Secondly, the Joint Way Forward is not a legally binding international agreement. It does not set out new obligations. It represents rather a joint declaration in which are described the various initiatives which the European Union and Afghanistan, in accordance with their authority and internal procedures, intend to implement in order to organise the return, readmission and reintegration of the irregular migrants, while preventing further irregular migration flows. This declaration will enhance the mutual trust between the two parties. It proves that both the European Union and Afghanistan are committed to address the irregular migration phenomenon in a comprehensive, balanced and human manner. Thirdly, I would like to underline that the Joint Way Forward in fact goes much further than the return of irregular migrants. Not only does it describe how Member States and Afghan authorities will organise an orderly return of the irregular migrants, but it encompasses several other initiatives helping to give to this challenge a sustainable solution in a spirit of partnership. For instance, it also covers measures aimed at preventing further departures of irregular migrants, such as campaigns to sensitise the population to the risk of irregular migration and capacity building to fight against migrant smuggling. It also underlines that, in line with EU legislation, the EU side will give the necessary consideration to humanitarian aspects to ensure that vulnerable groups of migrants receive adequate protection, assistance and care throughout the whole process. In this context, the Joint Way Forward stresses the intention of the European Union to support the country as much as possible with the challenging task of sustainable reintegration of those who return. As mentioned earlier, Afghanistan is facing unprecedented migration challenges. It is in this spirit that the Commission is developing an important multi-country programme to assist returning migrants, members of third communities and the local authorities. The interventions foreseen under this programme will include vocational training and skills development, strengthening of local communities and the improvement of migration management systems and policies. This programme comes in addition to the existing bilateral development cooperation which addresses some of the root causes of irregular migration, for example as concerns the availability of basic services or economic opportunities. It represents just one aspect of the much broader financial and technical support which the European Union and its Member States have been giving and, as reiterated at the Brussels Conference on 5 October, will continue to give to Afghanistan to promote its overall stabilisation and development. The Joint Way Forward represents the beginning of a dialogue and cooperation for the European Union and the Member States with the Afghan authorities. Nothing should be taken for granted. Patient work and mutual respect in a spirit of partnership will ensure the effective success of the initiatives described in the Joint Way Forward. From the Commission’s side I can ensure you of our full commitment to make the Joint Way Forward a success story with a positive outcome for the European Union, for Afghanistan and, in particular, for the Afghan migrants involved. I can conclude by reassuring you that I am committed to come and inform you on the state of play of the Joint Way Forward whenever you request it in the future.

name: Jaromír ŠTĚTINA
text: for the PPE Group. - In October 2001, US planes began bombing Afghanistan. The same year, US ground troops entered the country. In 2002, there was a sudden turnaround in Afghanistan's demographics. Within a few months, about 5 million people had returned home, fleeing the Soviet occupation and the ensuing Mujahideen war with the Taliban. They returned mainly from Iran and Pakistan. The return of the refugees was spontaneous, no one organized or ordered their return. Five million people realized that the US intervention ended a twenty-five-year series of devastating wars. After foreign troops began to leave Afghanistan in 2013, the flow of refugees turned again. People began to leave Afghanistan. After Syrians, Afghans have thus become the strongest refugee group seeking to join the EU and seek asylum in the EU. I would like to draw your attention, ladies and gentlemen, to one fundamental fact that the EU should address. During the American presence and the presence of international ISAF troops, tens of thousands of Afghan citizens cooperated with these armed forces. Due to the withdrawal of international forces, these people are often laid off and lose their jobs. They and their families are often referred to by the Taliban as "traitors to the faith and the nation," and their lives are directly threatened. These people, ladies and gentlemen, have been our direct allies in the armed struggle against the Islamists, and we cannot leave them to their fate. It forms an essential part of the Afghan refugee wave. We must not allow a security vacuum in Afghanistan. If we allow it, nothing will deter young people from a dangerous journey to Europe. Europe, together with the international community, must not slacken in supporting Afghan national defense and security forces. The continued presence of NATO, US troops and the armed presence of the EU, for example through a police mission in Afghanistan, is essential.

name: Elena VALENCIANO
text: on behalf of the S & amp; D Group. - Mr President, Commissioner, we welcome the efforts of the European Union at the recent donors conference in Brussels, and yet we do not want to think that behind this agreement with the Government of Afghanistan, signed in secret, there are only selfish interests and unsupportive. Nor do we want to think that the Council is determined to ignore this Parliament, using forms of agreement that impede our legitimate task of control. We do not want to think that in order to achieve this agreement, pressure has been exerted, even in a diffuse way, with the help we give the country. And we do not want to think that the European Union is going to breach its obligation to protect thousands of people, including, Commissioner, unaccompanied minors, who will now be forcibly returned to a country ravaged by violence and poor as few others . We do not want to think badly, Commissioner, but it is very difficult for us not to. The European Union seems bent on blowing up its image abroad. This Parliament does not want to contribute to this in any way, but we are not going to remain silent, either in terms of content or in terms of the forms of a realpolitik, which, Commissioner, is increasingly moving away from our values.

name: Charles TANNOCK
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Mr President, this year nearly 46 000 Afghans made their way to Europe. They represent the second largest migrant group by nationality of the 327 000 registered arrivals for 2016 to date. The need for concluding a readmission agreement between Afghanistan and the EU is therefore paramount.  There are many in this House who are ideologically opposed to the very notion of readmission agreements and will oppose the Joint Way Forward regardless of its terms. The terms in this case are fair and contain a number of provisions that cover the issues of unaccompanied minors, the elderly, the disabled and the vulnerable. Furthermore, the agreement goes beyond merely concluding procedures for readmission and includes elements for assisting with the reintegration of those people who wish to return home.  Following the unprecedented numbers of people that have arrived on the EU shores over the past two years it is vital that our Member State governments and the EU demonstrate that they are able to find solutions to what many of our citizens discern to be the number one issue of political concern at the doorstep. Failure to do so will further propel the rise of the populist and the far-right parties and endanger the very nature and entire basis for the EU project.  Maintaining the confidence and viability of international treaties such as the 1951 Geneva UN Convention on Refugees will only be possible if we stick to its terms and properly implement them.  Nevertheless, and speaking personally, I believe that in the modern world of mass travel and communications a review of the Refugee Convention as it stands will be necessary in the longer term as it is no longer fit for purpose in the way it operates today.

name: Petras AUŠTREVIČIUS
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Mr President, the Brussels conference earlier this month sent a clear signal of hope and sent a momentum of action. It showed that political and financial commitment by the international community remain strong. The Afghan Government has committed to implementing a serious reforms programme. Self-reliant Afghanistan has to be grounded on good governance, rule of law, economic development and, most importantly, on security. In this regard, I deplore strongly the killing of 30 peaceful civilians in the Ghor province by bandits affiliated to ISIS. This is the very sad news of this morning.  I particularly welcome the signing of the Joint Way Forward. It is an extremely important agreement; important for both sides involved as it sets a clear framework for managing migration readmission. Having said this, I would like to regret strongly the lack of transparency in closing the deal on this and the fact that Parliament was not involved in its drafting at an earlier stage. Thus, I call on the High Representative and the Commission from now onwards to at least keep this House informed on progress regarding the agreement’s implementation.  Coming back to EU-Afghan relations, they must be based on reciprocity. The EU needs to respect its financial pledges and ensure its support for returnees, so they can find jobs and become valuable members of their communities. Afghanistan must uphold its obligations by facilitating readmission and the reintegration of its own citizens who do not fulfil the asylum application requirements. It is necessary that Afghanistan, the EU and the international community elaborate jointly on this momentum of the Brussels conference and do everything in their capacity to support the rebuilding of the state of Afghanistan and Afghanis’ hope for a better future.

name: Malin BJÖRK
text: for the GUE / NGL Group. - Mr President! Everyone in this room knows that Afghanistan is not a safe country. Not very safe for anyone, especially not for children and women. Not for teenage boys, especially not Hazaras. Everyone knows that the Taliban recruit teenage boys on a conveyor belt and that the security situation for them is extremely dangerous. There are no pretense words in the world that can erase the brutal reality that exists in Afghanistan. If Afghanistan is not safe enough for our European citizens to go to, then how can it be safe enough to deport children, Commissioner? I know that Sweden is one of the countries that has wanted this agreement with Afghanistan and I can only say that I am ashamed. This weekend, demonstrations took place throughout the country, throughout Sweden. Demonstrations are taking place in Kabul, and virtually every refugee rights organization has signed a petition calling for an end to this agreement. Something very serious is happening. Aid money is used as a means of pressure to force third countries to accept refugees that we send back. We must be very clear. We do not have a migration crisis. We have a political crisis. This agreement must be stopped. Other agreements with third countries as well.

name: Judith SARGENTINI
text: on behalf of the Verts / ALE Group. - In Afghanistan, women hardly have any rights, young men are recruited by Taliban and Daesh, and entire provinces are not under Kabul's authority. ECHO, our emergency relief organization, is warning of a humanitarian disaster this winter. And Europe is making a deal with that country! A kind of Turkey deal: elusive but very far-reaching. And if it quacks like a duck, swims like a duck, and looks like a duck, then it's a duck! This joint way forward on migration is a readmission agreement and the European Parliament has the right of consent to it. Then why not just submit that proposal to us? If Afghanistan wants it and the European Union wants it, can't it just be done with decent democratic decision-making? Now that you don't, take on the suspicion that something is wrong here. What's also wrong is the way we finance this. The Commission wants to use part of the money for the reconstruction of Afghanistan to reintegrate rejected asylum seekers from Europe. That is not allowed - there are rules for this: development money must be used for development cooperation and not to finance our repressive migration policy. Why do the Afghans actually agree to this? That also seems wrong to me. They draw the short straw on all sides, don't they? More people, less money. This deal will further destabilize that country and it is the umpteenth time that the West is helping to tear it down.

name: Mike HOOKEM
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. – Mr President, through the EU’s failure to tackle the migrant crisis it is now impossible for Member States to resettle and integrate all those still pouring through Europe’s borders. While I recognise that Afghanistan is a country still besieged by political, economic and insurgency problems, the mass exodus of its working-age population is not going to solve any of these issues. In fact, all it does is make the nation poorer as those with the skills to rebuild head for Europe instead. That is why I am calling for all migrants not under threat from direct large-scale conflicts to be declared as economic migrants and returned to their home countries. This measure should include migrants from many other nations, especially those in receipt of EU funds aimed at tackling the migrant crisis. How can the EU be throwing money at a national leader while at the same time declaring that same country’s citizens are refugees? It just does not make sense. Only by taking drastic action now can we stop the influx, secure our borders from terrorism and help countries rebuild and develop.

name: Emil RADEV
text: - For the last almost 15 years, and especially this year, Afghans are the most numerous group of candidates for international protection in my country Bulgaria or nearly 70%. If whole families are fleeing the war in Syria and we are witnessing children born in boats on their way to Europe, then men are mainly fleeing Afghanistan in search of economic benefits and jobs, but without going legally, often trying to force themselves to cross the external European border. I want to make it clear that the EU has no obligation to provide support and protection for anyone who wants to come here in search of a better life, especially when these people break the law by crossing borders illegally. The EU therefore needs effective readmission agreements to ensure the expeditious return of these economic and illegal migrants. Only in this way will the newly created European Border and Coast Guard be able to fully fulfill its mandate to return migrants. I believe that the agreement with Afghanistan is a step in the right direction. The European Union has long supported the country in its economic development and the establishment of lasting peace. We will not leave Afghanistan even now - I welcome the commitments made by the EU, including with regard to funding reintegration programs for returned migrants. In conclusion, I would like to emphasize once again the importance of European cooperation and cooperation with countries of origin and transit. Only in this way will we be able to control the migration crisis and prevent new waves of migration.

name: Birgit SIPPEL
text: -  Mister President!The European Parliament must be involved in international agreements.Instead, from the Turkey deal to the Joint Way Forward with Afghanistan.Why are the Commission and the Council trying to keep the European Parliament out of the picture with sleight of hand?The security situation in Afghanistan has deteriorated.Nevertheless, we are sending women, men and children back there.Yes, Europe cannot accept all the refugees in the world, but neither can we buy ourselves free with money.We must do our part to ensure that people in third countries can live safely and develop prospects.However, this is not apparent from the way in which agreements are knitted here.And: Turkey is a safe country, Afghanistan maybe a safe country of origin tomorrow?Then soon no Afghans would get any asylum status.

name: Sabine LÖSING
text: -  Mister President! Another deportation deal à la Turkey, and it shows what it should be about. The - I quote - “common way forward on migration issues has the goal that the EU states should send refugees back to Afghanistan much more easily in the future”. Only one thing is really certain about the situation in Afghanistan, and that is that it is not. Afghanistan is not a safe third country. To deny this is irresponsible, inhuman and cynical. The reality is appalling after 15 years of war: from January to September 2016 there were over 8,000 civilian casualties, as the latest figures from UNAMA show. That is why people fleeing this country need a right to stay. It is perfidious that in the run-up to the donor conference, the EU threatened Afghanistan with drastic cuts in development aid if it is not prepared to take back an estimated 80,000 refugees - and that as a Union that puts the protection of human rights at the top of its own Flag writes.

name: Ska KELLER
text: -  Mister President! In my view, the EU's agreement with Afghanistan is just another tombstone in the humanitarian values ​​of the European Union. Because all international organizations really say that things are going really wrong in Afghanistan: We have an increasing number of injuries, an increasing number of deaths, and especially the number of injured children is skyrocketing. Just in September, the UN Security Council once again complained that the security situation in Afghanistan was deteriorating further. The UNHCR has noticed a serious deterioration, and even the Federal Foreign Office has issued massive warnings against traveling to Afghanistan. Do you want to deport people into such a situation? It doesn't really matter what status people have: You can't send people to war! Those who flee Afghanistan need our protection. I think we should - as the European Union - invest in protection and reception and not in a deportation system.

name: Linda McAVAN
text: – Mr President, as Chair of the Committee on Development, I agree with everybody here who said that this Parliament must be consulted before agreements like the Way Forward are signed and not just hear about them afterwards. I also think we are seeing a worrying drift in the EU’s relations with third countries because everything is being seen through the prism of the migration issues and no longer through the prism of tackling the root causes of migration, which are global poverty and inequality.  That is why my Committee has expressed reservations about aspects of the way the Commission proposes to use development assistance, DCI, to fund readmission for those not given asylum. We know that Amnesty are saying that between now and the end of this year half a million Afghans are expected to be repatriated to their country, mainly from neighbouring countries, not from the European Union. If the European Union is to spend resources, it must be on regions, to tackle poverty for all the people in those regions, not just to focus on the EU returnees. Please Commissioner, make sure you respect OECD guidelines on the use of development funding.

name: Lola SÁNCHEZ CALDENTEY
text: - Mr President, the Commission, with the humanitarian alibi of returning Afghans expelled from Bangladesh and Pakistan to their homes, is promoting a spurious agreement that covertly also includes the return of an unlimited number of Afghan immigrants from the countries members. These types of agreements must have the consent of the European Parliament, and the Commission has done nothing but ignore this House. This treaty uses development aid funds for very different purposes, such as the control of migratory flows and the outsourcing of border control. This has nothing to do with development aid or with the principles contained in our Treaties. Last but not least: it is illegal to return migrants to unsafe countries. And Afghanistan is not, and the European Union recognizes it. We demand the repeal of this treaty because —in addition to being absolutely ineffective this type of measure— violates, once again, against human rights and against our own norms.

name: Jean LAMBERT
text: – Mr President, we have been hearing a lot about the push factors – why people leave Afghanistan. Certainly parents can see for themselves that along with a lack of education and employment there is no stability, they know their sons can be recruited or forced into so-called Taliban jobs or maybe with Al Qaeda or IS and they are at risk if they refuse, so their sons are sent away. Returns risk further destabilisation on the ground. I really hope that we are looking at the cumulative effect of returns. We have seen over a quarter of a million sent back from Pakistan to Afghanistan this year alone, and we know that many more will be sent as well. I really hope that the European Union is looking at the cumulative effect which is destabilising: people face reprisals, it stretches resources, it increases tensions and we risk setting off yet another refugee spiral if we do not get this right.

name: Enrique GUERRERO SALOM
text: - Mr President, the Committee on Development certainly - and this Parliament, I think too - is opposed to the concept of 'flexible solidarity' which some Member States defend. And he also opposes migration "à la carte". For us, a Syrian should not have preference over an Iraqi, nor an Iraqi over an Afghan: any of them have the same rights and they should be respected. But at our borders, it is becoming increasingly difficult for an Afghan to obtain the corresponding status. The agreement we have reached is at the limit of what is considered development cooperation with third countries. The European Union has to ensure that this cooperation seeks to fight poverty, support the most vulnerable and guarantee well-being; And this happens by respecting the rules of the Union, starting with the provisions of the Treaties, including the ability of this Parliament to sanction this type of agreement. That is why I have proposed a mechanism for transparency and verification of these agreements in a forthcoming report on migration to be adopted by the European Parliament.

name: Afzal KHAN
text: – Mr President, I believe stability and equality are the key issues that we need to be focusing on. The Brussels conference on Afghanistan endorsed an ambitious Afghan reform agenda. Based on this, international community is committed to giving Afghanistan EUR 13.6 billion. Out of that, the EU committed to EUR 5 billion. I agree with the High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy, Federica Mogherini, that investing in the Afghan people is a way of investing in international stability. But to make that investment worthwhile, we must support a political settlement between the Afghan government and the Taliban. I applaud Pakistan and Qatar for their efforts to make this happen. We in Europe live in a time of austerity and slow economic growth. The European taxpayers are worried that the money given to Afghanistan will be disappropriated. As you know, Afghanistan features high on the global corruption index. Commissioner, what checks and balances has the EU put in place to ensure that the money we give finds its way to those that truly need it, and not in the pockets of profiteers?

name: Kati PIRI
text: - It is a good development that the EU is increasingly cooperating with other countries to shape migration policy. But the way in which a cooperation agreement with Afghanistan was completed behind closed doors at the beginning of this month does not deserve a beauty prize. Without any communication or consultation with the European Parliament, a joint statement was drawn up between the EU and Afghanistan. Moreover, the text of the statement appears to focus disproportionately on the return of rejected asylum seekers to Afghanistan. What is missing is how the EU will actually contribute to peace and security in that country, so that people no longer have to flee. It is necessary to have an effective return policy for those who have no right to asylum in Europe, but in the case of Afghanistan, caution is advised. Only 21 percent of asylum applications from the country are still rejected. Let us not forget that most people of that country have the right to international protection and deserve our solidarity.

name: Pina PICIERNO
text: - (IT) Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, the situation in Afghanistan - as has already been said by several colleagues - is, as we know, a very very complicated situation, very difficult and hard to evolve. The Brussels conference a few weeks ago finally gave a positive signal for the future of the Afghans, for the future of the peace process, because here we can only be satisfied and proud, obviously, of the generosity of the donor countries and also of the work done from the European Union, which has fielded an important figure. But it is good to be clear, as other colleagues who have preceded me have also been, we expect a meticulous, careful, precise monitoring of this aid that will be sent, so that it can be effectively used for the benefit of Afghans, especially women and of young people, and for development. Because, what is absolutely evident, is that all this cannot be translated into a surreptitious exchange to reduce the immigration pressure on the European Union.

name: Ana GOMES
text: - Mr President, the European Union's foreign policy is gaining ground from readmission agreement to agreement. Making development aid dependent on the number of repatriations accepted by a country is obscene! It is the Commission itself that classifies the situation in Afghanistan as being getting worse in documents that it refuses to comment on. How can Afghanistan, with millions of internally displaced people and millions of refugees in the neighborhood, receive these people, who are supposedly not eligible for asylum in the European Union? The vicious circle will not break returnees by force. Only if they cannot, will they stay in Afghanistan where we have returned them, therefore, by force. Because if they flee to save their lives, we feed the business of the traffickers, we jeopardize the European Union's own security, we totally discredit Europe. How can one even think of using development aid funds to build a terminal at Kabul airport especially to deal with returnees?

name: Notis MARIAS
text: ECR). - Mr President, Commissioner, Mr Dimitris Avramopoulos, first of all I would like to wish you a happy birthday today. Mr President, Afghanistan is a country that has been at war for 15 years since the US invasion. It is therefore not possible for Afghan nationals not to be able to join the relocation program, not to be considered refugees, at a time of war in their country. Let the European Union press the US to take its responsibilities and welcome the refugees from Afghanistan, which they themselves have caused. However, the more than ten thousand Afghans trapped in Greece, Mr. Avramopoulos, and you know it very well, must be relocated here and now, as is the case for the Syrians and the Iraqis. The joint immigration process would be an excellent initiative, if it involved Pakistan or Bangladesh. So we would like an update on this, too, Commissioner.

name: João PIMENTA LOPES
text: - Mr President, by omitting the EU's direct and indirect historical responsibilities in destroying Afghanistan, creating training and funding for the extremist forces that destabilize the country and the region, this agreement truly serves the objectives of your criminal migration policy. , in clear violation of international law, namely the principle of non-refoulement, the principle of protection against collective expulsion and the right to apply for asylum. It is the United Nations itself that warns of the worsening situation of hundreds of thousands of internally displaced people and hundreds of thousands of returnees, including tens of thousands of children, not only from Pakistan but also from the European Union. An agreement that allows unaccompanied children to return, violating the European Union's own commitments to guarantee and ensure the child's best interest. We are not tired of saying: the European Union is today one of the best examples of human rights violations, not only in its territory but also in third countries. Mr. Avramopoulos, be ashamed!

name: Takis HADJIGEORGIOU
text: GUE / NGL). - Mr President, I am sorry for the delay. I will be very brief. After all, everything has been said, I think. I just want to add the following ː while someone is trying to put out a fire in a house, but at the same time does not close the gas tap that feeds that fire, at least one can say that this is naive. And I say that because I think the main task of the European Union should be to try to consolidate peace, to try to prevent wars from happening and not the opposite, that is, to create wars and have all these problems. which we face today. In closing, I want to emphasize that what is important is the effort to consolidate peace. This is the real work, the only work that this body called the European Union can contribute. If it does not, then it will have to deal with this wave of refugees with all these difficulties we are facing.

name: Dimitris Avramopoulos
text: on behalf of the Vice-President of the Commission/High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy. – Mr President, honourable Members, thank you very much for the interventions. They were all very useful and to the point. I also take due note of all your remarks and recommendations. I would like to conclude by inviting this House one more time to look at the Joint Way Forward in a positive light. To look at it as a tool which, although having only the modest status of a mere joint declaration, can contribute to starting a dialogue and cooperation between the European Union and Afghanistan on migration issues. It will serve as a bridge of a provisional nature, allowing the two sides to meet and discuss, to start practical work and to build their mutual trust in addressing common challenges. I took note of what Ms Björk said before. Any decision regarding the possible return of children is based on an individual assessment of the best interest of the child, according to the provisions of the relevant EU legislation. I remind you of the Return Directive. The IOM has established referral and support systems. The unaccompanied minors who will be returned to Afghanistan will be assisted in the framework of the EU-funded reintegration project by the Afghan authorities and IOM Kabul, which has already put in place an effective referral and support system. In 2016 only a very low percentage of voluntary returnees from Europe were unaccompanied minors. As I have already stressed, the non-legally-binding nature of the Joint Way Forward gives us no guarantee that its provisions will be effectively implemented by the Afghan authorities. The situation of the country remains difficult at all levels, and yes, we have to exhaust all means in order to bring back peace and stability in the region. It remains one of the priorities of the European Union. But the poverty, instability, the insecurity and now also the emergency created by the massive return of migrants from Pakistan and Iran will make implementation challenging. This being said, we believe that the European Union and the Member States should do their best to support the Afghan authorities to cooperate on the basis of the Joint Way Forward. Should this cooperation work, it would represent an effective game-changer, not only because it would help solve one of the key challenges for Europe, namely the return of irregular migrants and the prevention of further arrivals of irregular migrants, but, most importantly, because it would have a positive impact on Afghan society by enhancing its capacity to provide assistance to the returnees and their receiving communities, and by supporting those deciding not to emigrate from the country to build up brighter opportunities for themselves at home. From the Commission side I will conclude by reiterating one more time our full commitment to make the Joint Way Forward a success story, but also to come and inform you about its implementation whenever you so request in the future.

name: Rainer WIELAND
text: The debate is closed.

name: Rainer WIELAND
text: The next item on the agenda is the debate on the statement by the Vice-President of the Commission and High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy on the situation in Belarus (2016/2934 (RSP)).Commissioner Creţu, speaking for the High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy, opened the debate.

name: Corina CREȚU
text: on behalf of the Vice-President of the Commission/High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy. – Mr President, the European Commission very much appreciates the European Parliament’s long-standing interest and our cooperation on this important neighbouring country. The High Representative’s intervention to you on Belarus dates from September last year and we had just witnessed the release of the remaining political prisoners and were hoping to engage in a longer-term strategy focused on building links between the European Union and Belarus and on supporting reforms for the people of Belarus, which are badly needed. One year on, there have been a number of noteworthy developments on the EU-Belarusian scene. In recognition of the political prisoners’ release and of a number of positive steps taken by Belarus over the last years, the EU lifted most of the restrictive measures against Belarus in February of this year. An important factor which contributed to this decision was Belarus’ constructive stance on this crisis in and around Ukraine which persists today. In the Council conclusion on Belarus adopted in February, the European Union and Member States expressed their concern about the human rights situation and particularly also about the continued application of capital punishment. At the same time, we agreed that there was an opportunity for our relationship – for EU-Belarus relations – to develop on a more positive agenda and that progress in a variety of fields can better be achieved through enhanced channels of communication. Since then, cooperation in areas of common interest has been stepped up. In April the Commission adopted a delegated act which made Belarus eligible for EIB lending. This will bolster support for the Belarusian private sector. An agreement was signed between OLAF and Belarus in July on customs cooperation, in particular in fighting the illicit trade in cigarettes, and the sectoral dialogue on customs and related topics is still foreseen to be launched by the end of the year. A trade dialogue was launched this month, on 13 October, between the European Commission DG for Trade and Belarus in view of improving trade, discussing Belarus’ access to the WTO and addressing existing barriers in international trade. A mobility partnership was signed also this month, also on 13 October, in view on enhancing cooperation on migration, asylum and border management. This will contribute in tackling the migration challenges, protection of refugees, prevention and combating trafficking in human beings. The European Union stepped up its financial support for 2016 to EUR 29 million – more than a doubling of the budget initially planned for 2016. Assistance is focused on regional and private sector development, support for migration and asylum management, and support for students. We are also intensifying our cooperation in the area of energy. As part of a re-engagement with Belarus, the Commission is considering relaunching the formal EU-Belarus energy dialogue in the near future. Nuclear safety issues have always been an overall EU concern, especially when new facilities are being constructed on the border with the EU, and are a key component of the exchanges on energy with Belarus. The Council’s conclusions adopted on 15 February 2016 reiterate the importance of ensuring nuclear safety beyond the borders of the European Union, and call on Belarus to cooperate constructively with the relevant international authorities in this regard. In this context, the high-level visit of the competent Commission services to Belarus took place on 19 and 20 September 2016. In addition, we have continued our strong assistance for civil society and for the promotion of people-to-people contacts. Civil society organisations received between 2011 and 2015 over EUR 50 million in programmes which strengthen their capacity and further a number of social, economic and human rights issues. Hundreds of exchanges are on-going in the areas of education, culture, science and technology and generally youth exchanges. On the human rights front, we have witnessed more openness by the Belarusian authorities to engage. EU Special Representative Mr Lambrinidis visited Minsk in March this year, where we had a meeting with President Lukashenko and participated in a conference on the death penalty. In June, the Belarusians hosted for the first time a European Union-Belarus human rights dialogue, for a part of which they also invited civil society representatives. At the same time we are fully aware that there have been no concrete or structural changes in Belarus democracy and the human rights situation. The application of capital punishment remains an issue which overshadows our relations with the country. This year alone we have learned about one execution, four confirmed death sentences and two new ones. Needless to say, this issue remains high on our agenda, and we will continue engaging with Belarus on this. Both the presidential election of October 2015 and the parliamentary election of last month were criticised by the OSCE for falling short of democratic standards and for not addressing a number of key OSCE and Council of Europe Venice Commission recommendations. Nevertheless we welcome the entry into parliament of the first non-establishment voices for the first time in 12 years, and we hope they can bring fresh air and new ideas into a chamber that during the last tenure introduced less than five new legislative initiatives. As indicated in our statement of 20 September, the European Union calls on Belarus to undertake comprehensive electoral reforms. The next elections are not so far away. Municipal elections will take place in 2018, and real progress on this and a number of other human rights-related topics will remain key for achieving the full potential of EU-Belarus relations. Therefore the EU’s policy towards Belarus remains for the time being one of critical engagement. We are not yet ready to launch negotiations with the Belarusian Government on a legal framework agreement, even if it remains a mid- to long-term goal. Our efforts will continue to focus on increasing engagement with all sectors of Belarus society and developing relations, including in the framework of the Eastern Partnership.

name: Bogdan Andrzej ZDROJEWSKI
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. - Mr Chairman! Commissioner! Ladies and gentlemen! Belarus is not an easy or spectacular topic, but it is undoubtedly an interesting topic, and I would warn against disregarding it. We are after double elections in Belarus: presidential and parliamentary. In both cases, there was a disregard for the OSCE's recommendations, so it can be said that these elections did not follow the standards that are close to us. But it is also difficult not to notice other elements that appear in Belarusian policy - and which the Commissioner also mentioned - that is, first of all, the release of political prisoners, reducing various types of repression, making some of these repressions more hidden or benign. They undoubtedly exist, only now if you want to throw students out of the university for their political views, they are simply judged negatively. The resolution we are proposing is a balanced resolution. It shows both the shortcomings that the Commissioner also mentioned, namely the lack of a memorandum on the use of the death penalty or non-compliance with democratic standards, but also some progress that has undoubtedly been made. Therefore, searching for new communication channels is our duty, our task. I want to thank all those who cooperated in unison on the proposed document. They were people on the left and right side of the political scene. Cooperation with Ms Hautala, Ms Kalniete or the representatives of the ECR made it possible to prepare a document which, on the one hand, defends European values ​​and, on the other hand, indicates the need to look for paths of dialogue leading to the interests of the Belarusian community, but not of the authorities. Finally, I would like to mention two representatives in the Belarusian parliament, who were elected not by the people but by the administration, but they are an element of a certain contact.

name: Jens NILSSON
text: for the S&D group. - Mr President! I have visited Minsk several times in the last year. I have done it to meet the opposition, to meet the representatives of civil society. I was there for the last time two weeks after the elections in September and there is no doubt that we must state that the parliamentary elections on 11 September were not open. It was not a democratic election. There was no transparency. We must be very critical of the fact that a new electoral law is not yet in place - something that the united opposition demanded a year ago. The restrictions that are taking place in the country regarding freedom of association, freedom of expression, freedom of assembly, freedom of the press are very serious, just like violations of human rights and the application of the death penalty. I am convinced that in order for a shift towards a more open and democratic climate in Belarus to be possible, there must be a functioning civil society. People must be able to organize in trade unions in order to have better conditions in their workplaces and be members of political parties. Freedom of expression must be respected and we must have free pressure. It is now important for the EU to establish a well-functioning and equal dialogue with all parties, in particular with civil society organizations and opposition parties, in order to support democratic development in Belarus. The outside world - especially those of us who are democratically elected politicians - must show solidarity with the people of Belarus in order to work for democratic development. It is attention that is required. Otherwise no change will take place.

name: Mark DEMESMAEKER
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. - Relations with the last dictatorship in Europe have never really wanted to flow. Time and again we bumped into Belarusian reality: a rigid, authoritarian style of government, with a lack of democratic standards and a lack of respect for human rights, an economy one-sidedly focused on the Russian market and the supply of cheap fuels, a deep-seated collective Soviet mentality. Lukashenko has been tied hand and foot to Moscow since he came to power 22 years ago. And yet Belarus is reluctantly trying to normalize its relations with the West. Especially now that big brother Russia is no longer able to fully support the economy financially. If Minsk orientates its foreign policy differently, it could have a positive impact on the domestic course, but the EU will have to draw clear red lines. One of my major concerns is the new nuclear power plant in Ostrovetz, a stone's throw from the border with the European Union. Lukashenko is proud to be building the cheapest nuclear power plant in the world there in record time, but international safety standards are not being met. I fear that the European Commission has not yet sufficiently taken up these concerns in its renewed dialogue and I ask ... [The Chairman cut the speaker from speaking.]

name: Petras AUŠTREVIČIUS
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Madam President, in February this year the Council decided not to extend the major restrictive measures vis-à-vis Belarus. The sanctions list is almost empty now. Has anything been delivered in return to those expectations voiced by the Council more than 10 months ago? Nothing at all. A total of zero. The so-called elections in September: yet another fake. The OSCE recommendations: entirely ignored, as many times before. None of the rights of former political prisoners reinstated. The NGOs continue to be persecuted by harsh legal measures, such as article 193. Death penalty: not abolished. Instead, two prisoners executed only in 2016. It is a shame. It is a shame of those who believe that change came. The fact is: the Council conclusions are completely disregarded. I am therefore shocked every time I hear the word ‘progress’ when one speaks about Belarus. In my view, the European Union seems to be continuously dragged into some kind of very dangerous experiment with Belarus. We are about to trade human rights for technical cooperation and promises. Another EU-Belarusian experiment is ongoing in the nuclear sector in haste and secrecy, in violation of the international conventions. On the EU border Russia is financing and building a nuclear power plant. I quote President Lukashenko: ‘the cheapest in the world.’ A dictator and the Kremlin’s always-loyal partner Lukashenko will soon be armed with nuclear capacities. The EU cannot just sit and observe silently this construction right on its border. This unsafe site must be frozen immediately.

name: Helmut SCHOLZ
text: on behalf of the GUE / NGL Group. - Madam President, Commissioner! I would like to use today's debate as an opportunity for reflection. The most recent parliamentary elections in Belarus have been held, and there was no follow-up repression this time. The election observers noted progress, but the elections themselves were far from meeting the standards to which they have committed themselves. So much for the facts, which alone do not adequately describe the country's complex and contradicting development processes. Processes of so-called catch-up nation-building are linked in Belarus with the question of what a modern and sustainable state should look like and what the future place of the country in the international division of labor and in the family of nations is. This also includes the social debate on aspects of the rule of law dialogue or the abolition of the death penalty, not just trade relations. As everywhere in the world, this takes place in the field of tension between preservation and departure and not free from the pressure of external conditions. So we shouldn't be surprised that despite a slump in the economy, the turnout was 75%.

name: Heidi HAUTALA
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Madam President, I think, no doubt, we have seen some very modest steps in Belarus in the past year towards what we could call democratic development. But I emphasise: very modest. For instance, now, after the elections, we can come to the conclusions that maybe there is a chance to open new channels of discussion. For instance, we have seen that there are two opposition members elected to the legislature. We do not know if this is a genuine signal of beginning of change or not, but I think we have to invite Belarus to take further steps. We have to be convinced by further steps. And notably, many colleagues have mentioned that this capital punishment, which is really a violation of human dignity, must be abolished. We must demand that. We must demand a new revision of the electoral law and process, and then perhaps we can see if there are new opportunities for our dialogue.

name: Jean-Luc SCHAFFHAUSER
text: on behalf of the ENF Group. - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I am astonished at the sudden leniency shown by the High Representative towards the man whom the European Union called the last dictator in Europe. The string is a little big: lifting of sanctions against rapprochement towards the Western camp, but search for an exit from the Russian orbit. Here, oddly, there is no longer any question of human rights. However, the Belarusian government continues to have strict control over the media and is not ready to waive the death penalty. But geopolitical blackmail is above the so-called European values, which are very fluctuating according to the interests of extra-European powers, moreover. Belarus remains a pillar of European integration, however. This is demonstrated by nuclear power plant projects with Russia or Russian and Belarusian airborne troops. My dear colleagues, let us try to build bridges and not walls erected against greater Europe.

name: Janusz KORWIN-MIKKE
text: - For ten years in Poland - Mr. Zdrojewski is a witness - I have been convincing that the only chance to save the independence of Belarus is to keep his Excellency Alexander Lukashenka in power.For two years I have been trying to convince you of this.Do you realize that if you introduced democracy in Belarus, in two years time Mr. Putin and his green men would join Belarus?Only Lukashenka, who cares for his stool, guarantees the independence of this state.And I want Belarus, Ukraine, Lithuania, which would separate Poland from Russia.I like Russia very much, but the farther it is from Poland, the more I like it.The same is true of the European Union.It is in the interest of the Union to defend the independence of Belarus - whether there is democracy there or not.It is important that it is a country that separates us from Russia.Finally, understand the basic principles of geopolitics, not your silly talk about human rights.

name: Sandra KALNIETE
text: – Madam President, elections in Belarus were not free and fair. We should not pretend that they were and that the parliament is fully legitimate. But we should recognise that there have been changes in the overall atmosphere. It has become more permissive and symbolically, for the first time in 20 years, two members of the democratic opposition were allowed – I underline ‘allowed’ – to have seats in the parliament. Therefore, we should expand the critical engagement with all segments of Belarusian society, from the civil activists to the government, to encourage more reforms.  In my opinion, one of the key tests for releasing the full potential of EU-Belarus relations will be further implementation of longstanding OSCE and Council of Europe recommendations. In due time, before the next local elections in spring 2018, we should consistently insist on this.  I would also like to address a particular problem we are having in relations with Belarus, such as building a nuclear power plant with questionable standards of safety right on the border with the EU. I would like to call on the Commission and the European External Action Service to coordinate more efficiently their actions and to use all leverages so as not to let a ticking time bomb be created on our doorsteps.

name: Zigmantas BALČYTIS
text: - The political situation in Belarus is still not in line with the principles of democracy, the rule of law, transparent and free elections, freedom of the media, respect for human rights and the abolition of the death penalty, which we uphold and promote. The last parliamentary elections again fell short of OSCE standards and cannot be considered transparent and fair. We hear in the press both criticism and praise for Alexander Lukashenko's end to the ruling party's twelve-year monopoly in parliament: the two non-electoral mandates for the opposition do not in any way demonstrate Belarus' determination to move towards greater democracy. The unfavorable geopolitical situation in the region and the growing pressure from Russia on the Eastern Partnership countries, the construction of the Astrava power plant are forcing us to seek dialogue with this country. We need to have a very clear strategy for moving Belarus towards Europe and finding a rational balance between what is happening in the country and Belarus's long-term perspective, bringing it closer to Europe, especially when the current rule ends. I believe that we must now find ways and means of gaining greater confidence in the European public in Belarus. At the same time, strengthening cooperation also with the opposition political parties in Belarus, with non-governmental organizations, civil society and other institutions that show a willingness to pursue their activities in a democratic way.

name: Ryszard CZARNECKI
text: - Madam Guide! Commissioner! Ladies and gentlemen! History teaches humility, and the European Union should too. I remember a number of years ago when two foreign ministers visited Mr. Lukashenka: the Polish Minister of Foreign Affairs, Mr. Sikorski, and the German Minister of Foreign Affairs, Mr. Westerwelle. Mr. Lukashenko took pictures with them, which then served him to show that he is a pretty cool guy. I am in favor of opening ourselves to Belarus. Yes, it is needed. This is what is needed to get Minsk out of Russia's hands. And this is the direction you should go, but you can't put out carte blanche. We cannot issue such checks to Mr. Lukashenka. Of course, you have to open up, but also check - trust and check - especially check. It seems to me that we should not be naive here. Geopolitically, this opening is very much needed, but let us be aware that Lukashenka will be maneuvering between Russia and us, and we must make sure that he is closer to European standards.

name: Bronis ROPĖ
text: - Minsk's steps to regain the European Union's favor can be welcomed. But let us ask ourselves, how worthy are Belarus' promises? For example, back in 2011. Belarus has made a political commitment to carry out so-called "stress tests" at the newly built Astrava nuclear power plant. Almost five years have passed, the atomic monster has already been seen from the Lithuanian hills, and "stress tests" have not yet begun. Moreover, after a Commission representative's visit to Astrava last month, it became clear that Belarus had not yet decided at all whether to carry out these "stress tests" in full in accordance with the European Union's methodology. Supposedly they will send the final answer by the end of this month. And today is the twenty-sixth of October. I therefore ask what pressure measures the Commission is prepared to apply by the end of October, if we do not receive concrete confirmation that Belarus will carry out the 'stress tests' on the new nuclear power plant in full. Thank you.

name: David McALLISTER
text: - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen! In May, I visited Belarus for the first time as part of an EPP delegation trip together with colleagues Sandra Kalniete and Bogdan Zdrojewski. My impression was that the situation in Belarus is indeed and remains worrying. Mr Lukashenko's regime stands for a poor balance sheet in terms of democracy and human rights. It restricts the freedom of the media and freedom of assembly, and there are elections that do not meet our democratic standards and standards. Nevertheless, we as the European Union should continue to pursue the approach of gradual rapprochement with Belarus, because this country is no longer looking exclusively to the east. For example, the legal non-recognition of the Russian annexation of Crimea or the resistance to a Russian air base in the country were positive signals. At the same time, the release of political prisoners in the country and the subsequent decision by the Council of Foreign Ministers not to extend the sanctions gave new impetus to EU-Belarus relations. However: Only with carefully coordinated steps and a policy of critical engagement will we actually achieve our goal of making Belarus a stable and reliable partner of the EU, with whom we not only share a common border, but also common values.

name: Ana GOMES
text: - Madam President, the so-called Belarus elections were neither free nor transparent. Instead of sending critics to prison, the government now imposes administrative fines on them worth several average salaries. The 2 deputies allegedly from the opposition in the "Parliament" are appointed by dictator Lukachenko, who hopes to receive help and funding in exchange for a democratic pseudo-change. Only those who want to be deceived. Opposition officials believe that European Union sanctions have been unwisely lifted, without reflecting any democratic progress. We must listen to them and help them, and here European political parties and their foundations have an important role to play. It is necessary to support the opposition in Belarus, to organize joint projects, helping them to converge and to be more effective in the fight for democratic freedoms. The European Union must pay attention and be audibly critical of human rights violations, press for changes in electoral legislation, so that the authorities stop restricting freedom of expression and the press and the activities of civil society parties and associations.

name: Monica MACOVEI
text: - As my colleagues said tonight, we have some good news from Belarus, namely two opposition candidates who have entered Parliament. I don't know if they won, if they were put there, if they were allowed to win, probably the last option is the real one. It is also true that the elections were not free and fair. We are now in this situation where we want to expand democracy and take Belarus in this area of ​​democracy, for the interest of the European Union and our security and for the interest of the citizens of Belarus. But we must be very careful. We must have a point of view, how to say, a very critical friendship with Belarus and always draw attention to the restriction of human rights. The press still has its muzzle on. Of course, political prisoners have also been released, but on the other hand, Belarus certainly plays an important role in Russia-Ukraine relations. So we want Belarus to enter our sphere, democracy, but we have to be very careful and check absolutely everything that Lukashenko says and does.

name: Jaromír ŠTĚTINA
text: - Parliamentary elections in Belarus were not free. The opposition had and still has a minimum of space for its implementation. In February this year, the EU lifted the sanctions imposed on Belarus as a gesture of goodwill, in particular with regard to the release of six political prisoners. However, these people have not been rehabilitated to date, they still do not have their civil and political rights. No party has been registered in Belarus since 2000. As the report of the UN Special Rapporteur on Human Rights in Belarus shows, human rights violations continue and no major change has taken place in this area. In March 2018, local elections are to take place in Belarus. Until then, the EU must use all available means to appeal to its Belarusian counterparts to implement the OSCE / ODIHR election recommendations well in advance. I reject any further gestures of goodwill on the part of the EU until there is real, clear and tangible progress on this issue and on human rights.

name: Agnieszka KOZŁOWSKA
text: - Mr Chairman! Ladies and gentlemen! Firstly, I would like to thank Mr Bogdan Zdrojewski for the resolution he is preparing and which breaks the tradition of this House of listing only what is not available in Belarus, and also lists positive facts about this country. It is an important neighbor of the European Union on its eastern wall and due to its geopolitical location it has to balance between the East and the West, understand and participate in both these worlds. I think it is good that the European Union is emerging from the policy of isolation and is intensifying dialogue with Belarus. We should develop this dialogue so that it is not only based on conversation, but also on joint ventures, projects in the field of economy, science and civil society. The economic situation in Belarus is quite tragic at the moment. Paradoxically, this is a very good moment to change, because Belarus has little to lose and can introduce significant and more radical changes in its economy and politics, and the European Union, which is one of the lenders and also a guarantor of loans from third countries for Belarus, is a donor money has a real tool to play a strengthening role in this process. How? First of all, by very scrupulous control of the funds spent, but also by additional requirements. After all, we can require that the money that goes to the development of medium and small enterprises in Belarus and such projects be partially spent by the business developing in Belarus for the benefit of civil society. We can require these companies to develop corporate social responsibility, to develop or join the social economy, popularizing the Belarusian language, and so on. A question for the Commission: are such additional conditions imposed as part of the financial assistance we provide to Belarus?

name: Michaela ŠOJDROVÁ
text: - The Commissioner informed us that the European Commission was trying to communicate with Belarus, but heard from us that we were not satisfied with the level of democracy and respect for human rights in Belarus. From left to right, we hear here in the EP that elections should not be recognized, civil rights are restricted, freedom in universities is also restricted, free access to education, the death penalty has been restored, which are typical features of a dictatorship. I find it very dangerous that Belarus, this undemocratic regime, is building a new nuclear power plant near Lithuania, close to the EU border. There are no security guarantees. I would like to call on the Commissioner and, through her, the European Commission, to work to monitor this newly built nuclear power plant. An audit by the International Atomic Energy Agency can be used. This is a major security risk that I see here. We know there was a malfunction. The Belarussian government has tried not to publish it, which is a regime that is non-transparent, which carries great risks precisely when building such a fundamental building. I ask the Commissioner to work on this audit within the European Commission and negotiations with Belarus.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, in Belarus, in the country called the last dictatorship in Europe, the opposition parties finally elected two representatives in parliament in the last elections. For too many years, the Belarusian parliament was the only parliament in Europe to have no opposition. Unfortunately, the Republic of Belarus remains an authoritarian regime, despite the appeals of the international community. The elections held in 2010 were defined by the OECD as neither free nor impartial and doubts remain even about the last elections. To this is added the knot of political prisoners, which remains one of the reasons that feed the harsh international criticism. In short, although attempts at dialogue must be facilitated to mitigate the difficult political situation and lighten the burden on citizens, Belarus remains an undemocratic regime, in which violations of human rights pose serious problems for facilitating dialogue with the European Union. , in the absence of respect for the democratic principles of civil liberty and human rights.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: ECR). Madam President, the death penalty in Belarus is back in the spotlight after two years. The decision to resume executions came just eight months after European Union foreign ministers decided to lift a freeze on assets and travel bans for more than 150 citizens and officials, including President Alexander Lukashenko. Belarus is the only country in Europe that still applies the last sentence. Reports claim that the rights of the defense in cases involving the death penalty are systematically violated, but also that the judicial authorities do not have the required independence. The European Union must ask the Belarussian government to formally suspend all executions, as a first step towards abolishing the death penalty. Belarus must take measures to protect fundamental rights and respect the rule of law. The right to life must not be taken away from anyone and in any way.

name: Takis HADJIGEORGIOU
text: GUE / NGL). - Madam President, relations between the European Union and Belarus must be strengthened for the benefit of all Europeans. For us, however, nuclear safety is a key issue. The European Union and Belarus must step up their discussions on this issue, which must be at the forefront of the efforts of all democratic peoples, states and societies. Alas if we neglect this task. The picture in Belarus is certainly a complex one and requires the full attention of Belarusians and Europeans. In closing, I too would like to condemn the fact that the death penalty still exists in a European country.

name: Anna FOTYGA
text: – Thank you. I acknowledge the very modest softening of the Lukashenko regime, yet I have to raise a very specific issue that was already mentioned by many of my colleagues, namely the Astravets nuclear power plant and also because this Russia-led, very unsafe construction is to be located in Grodno Oblast, a territory heavily populated by people of Polish descent. Therefore I share very much indeed the concern voiced by my Lithuanian colleagues. I think that this construction should be checked very specifically by the Commission and I consider efforts taken to date as very insufficient.

name: Corina CREȚU
text: on behalf of the Vice-President of the Commission/High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy. – Madam President, I very much welcome the discussion we just had today, and I can assure you that all your views will be duly taken into account. Let me assure you that tangible steps taken by Belarus to respect universal fundamental freedoms, rule of law and human rights will remain key for shaping of the EU future policy towards Belarus. About nuclear safety, I said in my introductory speech already that we are sharing this concern, even more so when new facilities are being constructed on the EU border. We are very much aware about this proximity – just 40 kilometres from Vilnius. So I just want to update you and say that the Commission is using all the fora and instruments at its disposal to address the construction of Ostrovets with the Belarussian authorities. We know that an integrated regulatory review service mission from the International Atomic Energy Agency to Belarus took place in October to review the regulatory process. And also, our aim is to ensure that the highest possible safety standards are followed. The European Commission in particular is financing experts who are assisting the Belarussian national regulator during the construction of the nuclear power plant and through working with Belarus in the area of nuclear stress tests. To this effect, a high-level mission by DG Energy took place from 19 to 20 September 2016. So thank you very much again for this debate. If I may say a few more words on some news that I have just learned, that a strong earthquake hit central Italy several minutes ago. I only hope and wish that the first news is exaggerated. However, I would like to express that the European Commission stands ready to help Italy with all means, and we are at its disposal as a Commission for regional policy. We have already been in touch for several months to assess the damage after the Amartrice earthquake, and I am very sad to hear now about this new tragedy.

name: Eduard KUKAN
text: in writing. - Belarus must be seen as one of the last strongly authoritarian regimes in Europe. Unfortunately, little has changed in this definition since the September elections. With a little optimism, we can say that the elections took place in a peaceful atmosphere and were not quite a step backwards. However, we should not close the door on Belarus. Our goal should be to intensify mutual relations. We should have a dialogue with Belarus that will help meet this goal. The focus should be on increasing diplomatic contacts in areas of common interest. However, a value-based dialogue is needed to support gradual change. We must not overlook cases of human rights violations and restrictions on personal freedoms. We must condemn the use of the death penalty, but also raise safety issues, such as the controversial construction of the Ostrovetsi nuclear power plant. Our policy should be aimed at supporting projects that will enable the modernization, gradual opening and development of Belarus - such as mobility partnerships, or investments in infrastructure modernization, environmental protection, education or the development of bilateral trade.

name: Corina CREȚU
text: on behalf of the Vice-President of the Commission/High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy. – Madam President, let me first of all thank the European Parliament for the opportunity to exchange views on this very important topic and subject. We all closely follow the developments in Turkey, a candidate country and key partner for the European Union. Our commitment to further developing and broadening our ongoing partnership and cooperation with Turkey remains strong.
