This is demonstrated by our continued solid engagement, including a recent visit to Turkey by High Representative Federica Mogherini and Commissioners Hahn, Avramopoulos, Stylianides and Šefčovič to Turkey and numerous meetings with Turkish authorities. The recent period has been a testing time for Turkey. The attempted coup of 15 July risked sending the country back in time to a darker era of its history. It would have been a dramatic blow to Turkey’s democracy and would have destabilised the whole region even further. On that night the people and the institutions of Turkey, including all political partners and parties, came together and stood up to defend their democracy. This is something we cannot forget or downplay. In this delicate moment for the country’s history, the Turkish institutions must recommit strongly to the same values that the Turkish people defended on the night of 15 July. Although the state is naturally entitled to take swift and decisive action in response to such a threat, any allegation of wrongdoing should be established by transparent procedures in all individual cases and ensure the right to respect for private and family life. Freedom of expression is one of the essential foundations of the European Union. We have repeatedly stressed that Turkey, as a candidate country, needs to aspire to the highest possible democratic standards and practices, including freedom of the media. This is our second debate on the situation of journalists in Turkey under this legislature. When we look at the situation of journalists and media freedom more generally, it has been deteriorating significantly, not just since 15 July but over the last couple of years. It is very worrying that, following the introduction of the state of emergency, the situation of media freedom in Turkey has been exacerbated even further. Arrest warrants have been issued against a large number of journalists, and many media outlets have been closed. There have been cases of foreign journalists facing difficulties in exercising their profession in Turkey, such as deportation, refusal of entry and refusal to renew their press accreditation. Turkish authorities need to restore safeguards to ensure freedom of expression, including pluralism of the media, and to take measures to limit intimidation and pressure exerted on journalists and media outlets. Turkey is encouraged to take measures, including the adoption of guidelines and training for the judiciary, to curtail the use of defamation and related criminal code articles as a means of putting pressure on critics. We urge that Turkish authorities refrain from blocking access to internet content and from takedowns. All these issues of concern are central for the European Union, and we very much encourage cooperation with the Council of Europe in this regard. Free, diverse and independent media is essential in any democratic society. Without freedom of expression and freedom of the media, an informed, active and engaged people is impossible. It is the strength of a democratic society to be able to respond to anti-democratic acts by strictly adhering to the standards, and this is absolutely critical for our relations. The curtailment of freedom of speech in Turkey is not limited only to journalists. On 20 May the Turkish parliament adopted a constitutional amendment on lifting the parliamentary immunity of a number of members of parliament. Prosecutors began to summon members of parliament to testify, and this raises further concerns about the respect for the rule of law and fundamental freedoms, in particular the freedom of expression. It is precisely this same issue that needs to be addressed under one of the seven outstanding benchmarks in the framework of the visa liberalisation dialogue related to anti-terror legislation. Let us be very clear: this benchmark is not about asking Turkey to reduce its capacity to fight terrorism. This benchmark is about making sure that the anti-terror legislation and its application are aligned with the case-law of the European Court of Human Rights – in short, that it cannot be used to jail journalists who only did their job and to curtail freedom of expression. The European Union believes that it is important to continue to address these important matters as a key element of a dialogue between the European Union and Turkey, a candidate country but also a key partner of the European Union. I am looking forward to our debate.

name: Renate SOMMER
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. - Madam President! Commissioner, thank you very much for these very clear words. I am delighted to hear that from the Commission and it is high time we made it this clear. Journalists have never had it easy in Turkey, but it has never been as bad as it is today. According to the ranking of Reporters Without Borders, Turkey is currently in 151st place out of 180 worldwide in terms of freedom of the press. There has long been no freedom of expression or freedom of the press. Since the attempted coup, there has been a real witch hunt, including on journalists, but also on many other professional groups: on business people, on professors. Only that is not the topic today. 2,300 media workers have been laid off and more journalists are now detained in Turkey than in China, Iran and Egypt combined. Detention conditions are unacceptable and there is mistreatment, Human Rights Watch reports. Those affected have no access to lawyers, no access to the rule of law. Since the attempted coup, 45 newspapers, 16 television stations, 23 radio stations, 3 news agencies and 15 magazine editorial offices have been closed and expropriated. This particularly affected opposition media, but also others: it particularly affected Kurdish channels and also an Alevi. Any criticism of President Erdoğan, his family, party, government or state institutions is prohibited. De facto, there has long been an opinion dictatorship and a presidential dictatorship. A single man rules the legislature, administration, justice, media, education and civil society. There is a climate of fear in Turkey. But, as you rightly said, Commissioner: a free and pluralistic press is a core element of any democracy, just like due legal proceedings, the presumption of innocence and an independent judiciary. Everything else is dictatorship and a dictatorship does not fit in with the European Union. (The speaker agreed to answer a question about the blue card procedure under Rule 162 (8) of the Rules of Procedure.)

name: Beatrix von STORCH
text: Ask about the “blue card” procedure.- After everything you have just said - everything, I believe, right - the only question that remains is: Can Turkey continue to be a candidate for accession to the European Union, or should the accession negotiations be terminated or broken off?

name: Renate SOMMER
text: Answer to a question about the “blue card” procedure.-  That is a difficult question.We all know that.We are in a dilemma.We have to keep talking to Turkey because Turkey simply has an important strategic regional location and is our direct neighbor.We have to keep talking.We also have to do this so that we can strengthen and support the opposition in Turkey and so that we can help things turn for the better in this country.It therefore seems essential that we continue to hold talks.However, I question whether these talks should still be called accession talks.

name: Kati PIRI
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. – Madam President, during the coup attempt on 15 July 2016, CNN Türk’s Ankara bureau chief, Hande Fırat, entered into our living rooms through our TV screens all around the world. In her hand was an iPhone. President Erdoğan was addressing the nation through FaceTime. Media plurality played a crucial role in preventing the coup plotters from succeeding in their attempt to illegally take over democratic institutions in Turkey that night. Let that not be forgotten. In the last years, media freedom in Turkey has been under great pressure, but the level of the crackdown the Turkish journalists are facing under the current state of emergency is unprecedented.  Not only were 150 media outlets closed and 2 300 journalists fired in the last two months, but 99 journalists and writers were also jailed, with no charges presented against most of them. This brings the number of media workers detained on charges, believed to be related to their work, to at least 130. This is the highest number of jailed journalists in Europe. That is not a cool list to be heading, especially not for an EU candidate country. In the European Parliament, we attach great importance to press freedom. One of this year’s candidates for the Sakharov Prize is Turkish journalist Can Dündar.   One year ago, we also had a debate about the freedom of media when the ‘Zaman’ newspaper was closed down. In the joint resolution that we will vote on tomorrow, all political groups are united in their call on the Turkish Government to immediately release these journalists; distinguished journalist of proven integrity, including former editor-in-chief Ahmed Altan, columnist Şahin Alpay, and well-known novelist Aslı Erdoğan, are being punished without due process through a long period of pre-trial detention. These people did not participate in the coup and the long period of pre-trial detention serves no public good. It seems the journalists are being punished purely for the opinions that they held, rather than for any incitement to violence or actual violence. The events of last night show that the curtailment of free speech in Turkey is not limited to journalists only. The co-mayors of Diyarbakır, Gültan Kışanak and Fırat Anlı, were detained yesterday. If democratically elected politicians are no longer allowed to freely express their opinion, then who can? To conclude, we understand that Turkey is going through a difficult time and people are traumatised by the deteriorating security situation, both inside the country and surrounding it. However, these threats can only be curtailed by strengthening democracy; by strengthening the rule of law, and by getting back to a normal situation. I hope, for all the people in Turkey, that this time starts in Turkey sooner rather than later.

name: Mark DEMESMAEKER
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. Erdogan's obsession with silencing the press in Turkey and only showing his truth goes so far as to silence even Mickey Mouse. Zarok TV, the Kurdish children's channel, is one of the 23 television stations that were taken off the air. Kurdish children now have to grow up thinking that watching cartoons in their native language is a crime. The so-called fight against terrorism goes a long way when a government sees a children's program as a threat to national security; then all proportions are lost. Even before the failed coup, journalists were outlaws in Turkey. Now the last critical voices are being stifled. 130 journalists are in prison. In the competent committee of the Turkish parliament, the court of justice confirms that new special forces are moving into prisons to torture them. I would like to explicitly mention the names of Inan Kizilkaya and Bilir Kaya, the editors of the Gündem newspaper, imprisoned in Silivri. Inan and Bilir confirm that they are being tortured and isolated. As a person and as a former journalist, I am horrified. Our Commissioners and the President of Parliament expressed their concern, their great concern, their utmost concern, but it has not made much of an impression on Erdogan. It is now too late: without free, independent media there is no democracy. Unfortunately, it has come to that in candidate country Turkey. We've given this regime a perspective it didn't deserve.

name: Marietje SCHAAKE
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Madam President, Turkey is a key country and a long-term partner for us Europeans and in NATO. And as someone who has always defended accession, even against the current of public opinion, these are painful times.  Painful because those who attempted the coup did no service to Turkey’s democratic future whatsoever. They have rightfully been strongly condemned. Painful, because the aftermath of the coup attempt has led to mass arrests that have taken place and have led to the centre of European societies and opinion, traditionally the most in favour of good relations with Turkey and of accession, to turn away from Turkey’s European future. I find that people simply do not see it happening anymore.  Press freedom and the position of journalists are a key reason for the political middle in Europe to worry and to fear that Turkey has taken a turn, not to return – a path of no return. This House, thankfully, has consistently voiced its concern and condemnation of the cracks in the rule of law, the lack of separation of powers and the violations of human rights and, particularly, press freedom and Internet freedom. And even though the post—coup environment has exacerbated the pressure and has seen the emergency measures being adopted, the banning of books, the arrest of journalists and the restrictions of press freedom and the stifling of oppositional voices has been systematic.  The Gülen movement, now accused of plotting the coup but previously a key ally of the Erdoğan government, was instrumental in creating an environment of fear, together with AK Party politicians. A climate in which critics were silenced, trials were unfair and the gap between the letter of the law and its actual implementation grew and grew.  As I said in the beginning, Turkey is and will remain an essential partner for us and we must act in the interests of all its people. Despite the low point that we see and that, frankly, is very disappointing, despite the bleeding of hearts, both in Europe and in Turkey, of those who hoped that Turkey would move towards the EU, we have to continue as Europeans to focus on what is really important in our path forward and focus on the rule of law and human rights, and, particularly, not be silent because we want the migration deal only. Press freedom should be on the top of the European agenda.

name: Takis HADJIGEORGIOU
text: on behalf of the GUE / NGL Group. - Madam President, what is happening in Turkey today is horrible. And the main thing that happens is the exploitation, the use of the coup, in order to impose the president of the country on every stone of this territory. In my view, the division in this country is so deep that it does not bode well for either the country itself or its neighbors. If Turkey is not pressured - I am referring to a top event in recent days - to immediately withdraw its forces from Mosul and stop the siege of this city, the whole region may explode and then we can think that what we have seen so far are just the prologue of a great tragedy. Regarding the situation in the journalistic world, which is also the subject of the debate, the content of the resolution is indicative of the oppression and denial of all freedom of expression. In closing, I would like to point out that, unfortunately, after the coup, to the extent that the oppression of half the country's population by the president increases, to the same extent, unfortunately, or even more, the criticism of the European Union decreases.

name: Rebecca HARMS
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Madam President, the night of the coup in Turkey was probably one of that saddest nights in my life, in my political life. Even only following by television what was going on in Turkey, I felt immediately that something was going to break.  I am clearly among those who say this coup must have consequences. There must be prosecutions, but prosecutions must be based on the rule of law in democratic states. For democracy, one of the things which matters most is independence; freedom of the media; pluralism of opinion. The situation for journalists, as Kati mentioned, was already awful in Turkey before the coup, but it has worsened a lot since the coup.  So what Turkey needs – rule of law and democracy – cannot happen if more and more journalists are jailed. It is very good to know that people like Can Dündar tried to help democratic development in Turkey. It is very good to know that famous writers, like the Altan brothers, are now paying in jail because they advocated liberal ideas, liberal democracy for Turkey. Knowing those names for us in our discussions and in our work for democratic development in Turkey is not enough. 130 people – men and women who worked with the pencil, with the camera, with the microphone, with the computer – are in prison right now because they did their jobs. Journalism is not a crime.  This is today our message to Turkey. It is our message to President Erdoğan and the whole of the Turkish Parliament: those 130 persons have names, and there is a list published by P 24 – a very courageous media platform in Turkey – and I would start to read the list: Abdullah Kılıç, Abdullah Özyurt, Ahmet Altan, Ahmet Memiç, Ahmet Metin, Ahmet Turan Alkan, Ahmet Yavaş ... (The president cuts off the speaker) I know that my time is gone, but I want all of you to know that 130 journalists is not only a figure. Behind this figure are persons, families, people who are waiting for those courageous people will be free again.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, it is admirable to hear from the Commission that they are well aware of the situation in Turkey today and, at the same time, continue to support an illegal agreement with Turkey and visa liberalization. So it means that there is full awareness that the real coup d'état actually succeeded Erdogan and the journalists of the Cumhuriyet newspaper are paying for it: our candidate, Can Dündar, al Sakharov for this year, the editor-in-chief of the Ankara office , Erdem Gül, and many others who have denounced over the years the troubled involvement of the national secret services, for example in arms trafficking in Syria. Meanwhile, the statistics are growing, we arrive at 100,000 websites blocked, we arrive in a country that is now 151st in terms of press freedom, 183 newspapers closed, 127 journalists arrested. I want to close this speech with the words of Can Dündar: "my office has two windows: one overlooks a cemetery, the other the court. They are the two most visited places by journalists in Turkey. After a while, a third one also appeared. window, that of the prison that awaited me ". Well, I tell the European Union and the Commission that freedom of expression is a right and not a crime, indeed it is the salt of democracy. And if we do not strongly reiterate it vis-à-vis the Turkish government, we will lose all credibility.

name: Edouard FERRAND
text: on behalf of the ENF Group. - Madam President, gentlemen, dear colleagues, today is Turkey Day. Mr Juncker announced this morning that he would resume negotiations with Turkey. I ask you: "What is this debate for?" You have all noticed it: it is almost 8:45 p.m., we are putting the debate as far as possible so as not to shock the good conscience of Eurocrats. What can I say about this debate? This week we have the in 't Veld report, which confiscates sovereignty, democracy, our freedoms and public freedoms. Today we are made to cry with Turkish journalists, but finally wake up! Do you want Turkey in Europe? Do you want Turkey to do the same for European journalists? Tomorrow, we will be told that things will start again, that the debates continue, that we are opening the 18th chapter of 32. Finally, a little cynicism or, at least, a little responsibility! I believe that what the peoples of Europe want is a Europe of nations and freedoms, a Europe without the Muslim Brotherhood of Mr Erdoğan. They want a free Europe, another Europe, that of the Europe of nations and freedoms.

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: NI). - Madam President, the persecution of publishers, journalists and, in general, those working in the press in Turkey is not a recent story. It lasts with various alternations for thirty years. In fact, the current ruling regime in the country does not discriminate politically. Since the Ergenekon affair, he has persecuted Kemalists and nationalist journalists alongside leftists and Kurds, accusing them of being involved in propaganda for the PKK, which is known to be a terrorist organization. Turkish authorities target three categories of journalists: those involved in corruption cases, those who criticize the government and the Kurds. They are accused of violating the anti-terrorism law as well as the Turkish penal code. In order to intimidate and silence them, they arrest them without proof, put them in high-security prisons with dangerous criminals without trial, leave them in prison for three to five years, and also blackmail their families. Even the mere reporting of these events is considered a crime. In fact, after the coup, more journalists have been persecuted than those who have been persecuted all over the world. The European Union is negotiating with this country, wants to include it in its ranks and succumbs to its blackmail.

name: Manolis KEFALOGIANNIS
text: PPE). - Madam President, we in this Chamber unequivocally condemn the military coup of 15 July. But this does not allow us to remain silent about the abolition of the rule of law. Thousands of military, judicial, civil servants, businessmen arrested, newspapers shut down, journalists arrested, all media silenced and's attempt to overthrow the bourgeois state, Kemal Ataturk's secular state, challenged international agreements such as The Treaty of Lausanne of 1923, which establishes the status of the straits, the new Turkish borders to all its neighbors, and the exchange of populations with neighboring countries, all of which are directly contrary to international law. The invocation of the National Oath of the Turkish National Assembly of 1920 for a referendum in all the provinces of the Ottoman Empire and the references to the "borders of our hearts", as Mr. Erdogan said, which include the borders of the old Ottoman Empire, provoke question marks to everyone. The assurances of Turkish officials, when they are abroad, that these statements are made for domestic consumption, do not reassure us, are not in line with the European acquis and European values, and remove Turkey from Europe and the European family, at its sole responsibility. leadership policy.

name: Miltiadis KYRKOS
text: S & amp; D). - Madam President, I will not repeat the contents of our substantive resolution. But I will emphasize our full solidarity with the hundreds of thousands of Turkish citizens and all the political parties that defended democracy on the night of July 15th. What is happening now does not suit Turkey and will not bring the expected results. They may give the illusion of absolute power, but it is not what the country needs right now. The democratic mindset of the citizens is proving very strong, because next to every journalist who goes to prison without incriminating evidence, we see hundreds of citizens joining the solidarity movements with which we are in solidarity today. And with the coup it became clear that Turkish democracy is not threatened by freedom of expression and fair trials. It is threatened by conflicts of strong interests, which threaten democracy from the very beginning. I close with the words of the Vice President of the Turkish National Assembly: "the only way to shield democracy is to strengthen the secular state."

name: Bas BELDER
text: - Conscientious, careful, independent journalism is of great social importance - repression of it does enormous damage to a society.Yet that is happening today in Turkey.As a former journalist, it hurts my eyes and heart to read on the Turkey Purge website that as many as 130 journalists are currently in detention on arbitrary grounds.This debate shows that we are not leaving them in the lurch and fortunately they are also supported in other ways within the European Union.Quality newspapers open their columns to Turkish colleagues as guest writers, whether or not active from their own territory.With great interest and pleasure I follow, for example, the letters from Istanbul from Bülent Mumay in the Frankfurter Allgemeine every week.Highly recommended, colleagues, because against the equalization of the Turkish media.And the EU must also fully defend itself against this equalization.

name: Hilde VAUTMANS
text: - Everyone has said it, 130 journalists in Turkey are in prison for doing their job. 2500 journalists who have lost their jobs since the failed coup. 150 media companies that have closed their doors. There can be no freedom of the press in an atmosphere of fear and mistrust. Any journalist who criticizes the policies of the current government is being watched. Self-censorship is commonplace. Turkey is now in 151st place on the World Press Freedom Index, after Tajikistan and after Congo. Even as far as Europe, the large Turkish community is unilaterally informed. Amnesty International is also concerned about human rights violations and Human Rights Watch spoke on torture practices in prisons last Tuesday. Colleagues, I think we should wake up. There is no point in negotiating with Turkey if journalists are kept in dark cellars. Freedom of expression and thought are fundamental rights in Europe and we must defend them. So let's end talks with Turkey. Let us call on Turkey to release journalists who are detained without evidence and let us send observers to check the situation in the prisons. Because journalists, also other prisoners, have rights.

name: Marie-Christine VERGIAT
text: - Madam President, democracy in Turkey is in danger. The attempted military coup denounced by all, in Turkey and elsewhere, serves as a pretext for a decline in the rule of law. The arrests of journalists, like those of magistrates, are a symbol of this. One hundred media have been closed; 200 journalists were arrested, two-thirds of whom are still in prison; 2,300 media workers have lost their jobs, while the storming of newsrooms by the police seems to be becoming a habit. Among these journalists is indeed Can Dündar, our candidate for the Sakharov Prize. All those who dare to criticize the policies of the Turkish government are threatened. Dozens of people have been charged with the sole reason of using a mobile application, ByLock, suspected of being used by supporters of Fethullah Gülen. However, Turkish ministers are currently using this application. Finally, the Kurds are paying a heavy price, once again. The arrest yesterday of the two co-mayors of Diyarbakir is a symbol of this. Sending back to back each other is not a solution. If we do not want Turkey to return to the darkest pages of its history, the European Union can no longer be silent, otherwise it will bear a heavy responsibility for the development of the situation.

name: Bodil VALERO
text: - Madam President! We all see that most things are going in the wrong direction in Turkey. We heard here about the latest unwanted interference in the liberation of Mosul. We also heard about the statements that could be perceived as President Erdoğan preferring to seize the whole area. Power has undeniably risen to the president's head and I wonder every day: "What will he invent today?". Because it's not just about imprisoning journalists and punishing their relatives. The state of emergency and terrorist legislation are used to circumvent freedom of expression and are also used in Kurdish, Turkish media abroad, e.g. the TV channel broadcast from Sweden, Newroz TV. This is certainly not what I expect from a democratically elected president. I would also like to read some of the names that Rebecca Harms previously started with: Atilla Taş Ayşe Nazlı Ilıcak, Ayşenur Parıldak, Aytekin Gezici, Aziz İstegün, Bayram Kaya, Bayram Parlak, Bünyamin Köseli ...

name: Beatrix von STORCH
text: - Madam President! Tonight we are not talking about freedom of the press in Turkey, but about lack of freedom. Since his coup, Erdoğan has closed over 131 media companies, made thousands of journalists unemployed, and imprisoned over 100 journalists. Almost every single one of the previous speakers has listed this. In terms of freedom of the press, Turkey ranks 151st out of 180 in the international ranking. We are sometimes more or less upset about this, depending on the current blackmail situation on the refugee issue. And you want to continue accepting Turkey into the EU. That is why you have the velvet gloves on and do not face any consequences. We're upset about Poland, which ranks 47th in freedom of the press, close to the US, Great Britain and France. Therefore: Stop it, leave the Poles alone and do not let Turkey into the EU! (The speaker agreed to answer a question about the blue card procedure under Rule 162 (8) of the Rules of Procedure.)

name: Michaela ŠOJDROVÁ
text: a question asked by raising a blue card.- Colleague, I am not in favor of Turkey's accession to the European Union.But I want to ask you.Do you think that President Erdogan wants to join the European Union?Do you really think that this person wants to join the Union of Values and respect human and civil rights?

name: Beatrix von STORCH
text: Answer to a question about the “blue card” procedure.- I hope that, if the move from the European Union is not made, he may end the talks.But we haven't heard anything about it yet.In this respect: he will certainly never share the values that we share, but he will continue to look for the way to this European Union if we do not finally break off these talks.

name: Anna Maria CORAZZA BILDT
text: – Madam President, the night if 15 July I felt close to the people standing up for democracy against tanks. Tonight I feel close to the hundreds of journalists unjustly detained. Turkish citizens do expect the government to bring those responsible to justice, but it must be within the rule of law, and most urgently, the Turkish authorities must ensure humane conditions in detention. Thousands of academics, lawyers and businessmen cannot possibly be terrorists, and I call on the Turkish authorities to stop the witch-hunt on journalists, release those imprisoned and restore freedom of speech. Over the past weeks I have been meeting many people from Turkish civil society and the opposition. They feel let down. They feel that Europe has turned its back on them. They see the EU as an anchor of democracy, preventing a drift towards autocracy. They urge us to show empathy and solidarity. They urge us to help them restore the rule of law. So let us stop the blame game. Inflammatory rhetoric does not help. It is clear that the EU has underestimated the trauma for the people in Turkey when we realise the extent of the Gülen infiltration in the state institutions. We have a responsibility to better understand the complexity of what is going on in Turkey before jumping to conclusions. Europe should engage in a constructive dialogue with Turkey on all issues of common concern. It is in our mutual interest. The Commission is doing it; let’s support them. The EU should therefore get ready to open Chapter 23 and 24 on justice and fundamental rights. When the day of a peaceful settlement with Cyprus comes, we must be ready. This negotiating framework is a driving force for reform. It is not a reward. It is a concrete way to show our dedication to human rights and freedom of media and to support the democratic forces of Turkey that rely on us. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Costas MAVRIDES
text: blue-card question. – I have a very simple question for Madam Bildt. I do not know what kind of people you meet from Turkey, Madam Bildt, but it is obvious that the people from Turkey that we meet, the vast majority of us, are very different from the ones that you meet because we get a very different opinion. But anyhow here is my question: with half the judges and the prosecutors having either been dismissed or put in jail, do you still believe that someone in Turkey can have a fair trial? Is Erdoğan for democracy or a new sultan? That is my question.

name: Anna Maria CORAZZA BILDT
text: blue-card answer. – I think that blaming and shaming does not make Turkey more democratic and does not help Turkey to restore the rule of law or fair trials. I think we should engage and help and support them; that is what our liberal friends, civil society and the opposition is asking the European Union. We should not let down the vital democratic forces in Turkey. We should help them restore justice and the rule of law.

name: Hans-Olaf HENKEL
text: - Madam President!Of all 57 Islamic states, Turkey was for a long time the only country in the world that was on the way to democracy, respect for human rights and freedom of the press.Since the attempted coup - we heard that today - it's all supposedly different.But I would also like to point out to Ms. Bildt that long before the attempted coup, human rights were trampled on in Turkey.Media houses were closed beforehand, journalists were arrested beforehand, and peaceful protesters were beaten up beforehand.We mustn't fall for it and now pretend it's all a result of the coup.When Erdoğan says, "It was a gift from God", he not only exposed himself, he was also profane.

name: Sofia SAKORAFA
text: GUE / NGL). - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, for the umpteenth time we are describing in dark colors the functioning of democracy in Turkey, and in particular with regard to freedom of expression, of the press and of journalists. The systemic deficit of the rule of law and respect for these freedoms is not a new phenomenon and is certainly not a symptom of the failed coup in the country. Let me remind you that, before the coup, Freedom House described the media as not free, while Turkey was ranked 151st out of 180 countries in terms of press freedom, most recently in Europe and the Balkans. With these data, Mr. Erdogan, more powerful inside his country, continues to blackmail Europe with refugees, pursues an expansionist policy in the wider region and the Union opens chapters and talks about visas !!! Ladies and gentlemen, Mr Erdogan will also ostentatiously ignore today's resolution. As long as the European Union pursues the same policy of relations with Turkey, we as the European Parliament will confine ourselves to resolutions of denunciation without any result.

name: Ernest MARAGALL
text: - Madam President, freedom of the press and that of journalists - we all know this - is the centerpiece of the democratic edifice. But in Turkey the well-known chain of repression, silence, abuse of power, widespread fear and the consolidation of an authoritarian regime has begun. When Can Dundär and one hundred and thirty other journalists are arrested, the rest of the country's professionals act with fear and naturally tend to practice self-censorship. And when journalists are silenced, society remains unprotected and defenseless against power. Like the mayors arrested in Diyarbakir, or like the exploited Syrian children in Gaziantep. Journalists in Istanbul or Ankara, mayors of Kurdish cities or Syrian children are the human links in that common chain of horror. The resolution that we will support tomorrow is not enough. It is not enough to protect or accompany the victims of arbitrariness. And it is not enough, Mrs Corazza Bildt - who is not listening to me - to ask the Turkish institutions once again to change their attitude and behavior. The only solution is the immediate return of freedom and full democracy. Our only role as MEPs is to work openly and hand in hand with Turkish society so that this return occurs as soon as possible.

name: Tunne KELAM
text: – Madam President, freedom of the media and expression is a fundamental principle of the EU. Still, I think the European Union has been rather modest to mainstream this principle in relations with Turkey, which is in 151st place out of 179 states regarding media freedom. Out of all the candidate countries, Turkey is the only one which has recently cut the wire on major social media channels, for example Twitter. Following the attempted coup d’état, Turkey’s government is clamping down with new intensity on the still-existing free media, both offline and online. I call upon the Turkish authorities to immediately stop the arbitrary detention and harassment of journalists and media workers. The names of 130 journalists arrested has been mentioned, and I agree with my colleague, Rebecca Harms, that this is not about statistics. Behind every name is a personal tragedy, family, freedom of expression. Clearly this all has nothing to do with the fight against terrorism. I equally call on the EU to take a strong stand on this issue, because defending freedom of expression for the Turkish people means solidarity in practice. To allow different opinions to be freely published would only reinforce Turkish society, and I think it should be regarded as a criterion as to whether the Turkish government will stay on the right path to join the European community of values.

name: Eugen FREUND
text: - Madam President, it is very simple and it is very sad, and so I will continue to read the names of the arrested Turkish journalists that my colleagues Ms Harms and Ms Valero began: Cemal Azmi Kalyoncu, Cihan Acar, Cihat Ünal, Cuma Kaya, Cuma Ulus, Cumali Önal, Eda Şanlı, Emre Soncan, Ercan Gün, Erdal Şen, Faruk Akkan, Fevzi Yazıcı, Gökçe Fırat Çulhaoğlu, Gültekin Avcı, Habip Güler, Hakan Taşdelen, Halil İbrahim Mert, Hanım Büşra Erdal, Haşim Söylemez, HüseyinAydin, Hüseyin Turan, İbrahim Balta, İbrahim Kareyeğen, İsa Siyi, Kenan Baş, Lalezar Sarıibrahimoğlu, Lokman Erdoğan, Mehmet Altan, Mehmet Kuru, Mehmet Özdemir, Aksoy Yeni, Murat Avcıoğlu, Murat Öztürk, Mustafa Erkan Acar, Mustafa Ünal.And the list goes on and on and on.

name: Eleni THEOCHAROUS
text: ECR). - Madam President, Turkey is a cruel and ruthless dictatorship. A vast prison, especially after the July coup. That is why the resolution rightly emphasizes that emergency measures, the suppression and the supposed fight against terrorism should be lifted. But the fight against press freedom is a key weapon of dictator Erdogan. The European Union continues to caress Turkey and succumb to its blackmail, even though everyone here has given horrible examples of totalitarianism. The resolution makes no suggestion that sanctions should be imposed on Turkey. The allegation that Turkey is allegedly the target of terrorist attacks is false. Turkey itself sponsors terrorism to the detriment of other countries. It is a terrorist state and illegally occupies Cyprus. He founded Islamic schools of fanaticism in occupied Cyprus, Kosovo, Skopje, Bosnia and Albania. If sanctions are not imposed on Turkey, tomorrow Erdogan will throw this resolution in the trash.

name: Patrick LE HYARIC
text: - Madam President, beyond verbal condemnations, our European institutions must be firm and energetic towards the Turkish authorities, of which the Nobel laureate, Orhan Pamuk, said he was establishing a regime of terror.Strong action is needed to obtain the release of journalists, judges and trade unionists as well as the restoration of elected officials to their rights.Let us therefore stop this hypocrisy which consists in making Turkey, in exchange for billions and a complicit silence, a place of retention of refugees.The European Union's external action services must launch observation and support missions for journalists, magistrates and trade unionists in prisons.Finally, we must immediately stop any process of enhancing our trade relations and consider economic and trade sanctions as long as freedom is not restored.

name: Michaela ŠOJDROVÁ
text: - Madam President, this month the Turkish Government extended the state of emergency in Turkey for another three months, extending the possibility of legitimizing further repression against journalists. Restrictions on the media are nothing new in Turkey, but in a state of emergency, these measures are even tougher on the media. The Turkish government therefore restricts freedom of speech in the country under the guise of the fight against terrorism and condemns journalists under anti-terrorism legislation. It intimidates them in this way, and this also means that those who can still work today limit their criticism of the regime because they are simply afraid. It reminds me very much of the atmosphere of the 1950s communist regime in Czechoslovakia, when journalists and writers were also imprisoned and intimidated to remain silent. I recently read a sad but very well-described quote from a Turkish journalist: "In the past, journalists met in cafes, today they meet in prisons and courtrooms." Ladies and gentlemen, human rights and their observance are part of the culture to which Turkey has committed itself, but the steps it is now taking are far from them. I very much doubt that President Erdogan is serious about further accession negotiations with the European Union today. By what he is doing today, President Erdogan is moving away from European culture, but I am convinced that we cannot throw overboard the citizens of Turkey who want to live in a democratic society, and we must be in solidarity with them.

name: Costas MAVRIDES
text: S & amp; D). - Madam President, journalists are imprisoned because they have an opinion. Teachers, professors, academics are persecuted because they do their job. Kurdish mayors and members of parliament are being persecuted because they are Kurds. Half of the judges have either been fired or are in prison. And finally, this country, whose name I did not say, is governed by presidential decrees and some here pretend to be a democracy. But I will continue, Madam President, with the following: why do we not demand that Turkey start implementing its commitments starting with Cyprus, which is a member state of the European Union? She is a journalist who is not in prison. Her name is Serena Shim. Why is she not in prison? Because the Turkish state and the secret services killed her, because she was the first to reveal Erdogan's filth with the Islamic State.

name: Nikolay BAREKOV
text: - Commissioner, I speak as a journalist and a politician. If we do not react to the genocide of the Erdogan regime towards freedom of speech, we become accomplices in murder and violence, as the Bulgarian government and its obedient media have recently become accomplices. Recently, Interior Minister Bachvarova, with the covert approval of the Bulgarian prime minister, returned innocent victims who had sought refuge in Europe from persecution to the Turkish regime. A journalist from the closed newspaper Zaman was captured on the Bulgarian border along with teachers and police officers and returned to the clutches of the obscurantist regime. A disgraceful act for the Bulgarian authorities and for the media - most of them dependent on them, who watch indifferently. Who is behind this shameful and illegal deal with the Turkish authorities? To return to slaughter inconvenient to the regime against stopping the wave of refugees. No journalist in Turkey is a criminal because he tells the truth about the regime. If we do not react, we become accomplices here. We must defend freedom of speech and condemn the shameful deals of European leaders with Erdogan.

name: Stelios KOULOGLOU
text: GUE / NGL). - Madam President, any coup attempt creates an emergency, but this coup seemed to be the best gift to Mr Erdogan. Hundreds of journalists in prison, thousands unemployed, hundreds of media outlets shut down. Do you know for how many years the more than 190 journalists who are accused face prison sentences? 2,150 years !!! For a trivial reason, Sakharov Prize nominee Can Dündar was indicted, imprisoned and convicted for making a journalistic revelation. And I hope he gets the Sakharov Prize, because that will be the best answer of our European Parliament in Turkey. We want good relations with the people of Turkey. We want good relations with the country. But good relations based on respect for democracy, freedoms and freedom of the press.

name: Lefteris CHRISTOFOROU
text: PPE). - Madam President, unfortunately once again we are spectators in the same work. We did not learn anything new. Turkey is doing well what it has been doing over time. It violates human rights, it violates principles, it violates values. Just the fact that it has turned into a vast prison and journalists are being persecuted the way they are being persecuted is the tip of the iceberg. We also support the resolution condemning Turkey on this issue, because we consider it self-evident that Turkey should be condemned on a daily basis for what it does not only to the detriment of its own people but also to all others. It does not come as a surprise to us, because for us this is Turkey. It is Turkey itself that continues to occupy Cyprus. It is Turkey itself that for 42 years has been violating basic human rights, it is an invader, it is an occupying power, it has an occupying army, it despises principles, values, resolutions of the United Nations and the Security Council. It is still Turkey itself that does not recognize a member state of the European Union. It is Turkey itself that has gone so far as to challenge international agreements today, the Lausanne Treaty for Greece, wanting to overthrow what the peace treaties require. It is Turkey itself that has done what it has done to the detriment of the Armenians, the Kurds, its neighbors, the Greeks over time. It goes through a consistent and stable course that despises principles and values. Against us we have this Turkey which is encouraged by our tolerance. I believe that now is the time for the European Union not to step backwards in the face of these principles and values. It is time for Turkey to understand that the European Union cannot be despised. Turkey has no right to despise all this.

name: Jean-Paul DENANOT
text: - Madam President, indeed, the situation of journalists and freedom of expression in Turkey - already not very brilliant, it must be said - has deteriorated sharply in recent months, and particularly since the abortive attempt at the coup d 'Status as of July 15. It turns out, however, that the state of emergency, which was extended - as many have said - by 90 days last week, has broken all barriers. He installed a climate of fear and generalized self-censorship pointed out by Reporters Without Borders, depriving the population of a free and diversified debate, when they need it most, to form an opinion on the Kurdish question, on the conflict in Syria and its extremely complex actor games, on the influx of refugees, of course, and on relations with the European Union. Instead, the Turks are showered with hate speech against journalists, guilty of simply doing their job, and suspected sympathizers of Mr. Gülen, who is accused of instigating the coup in the judiciary, the police, military and education. Imprisonment becomes the rule for all those who oppose. For all these reasons, Madam President, I express my solidarity with the struggles of the Turkish journalist, Can Dündar, nominated for the 2016 Sakharov Prize, and I deeply hope that he will obtain it.

name: Angel DZHAMBAZKI
text: ECR). - Violence against freedom of speech in Turkey is not news, any other allegation is hypocrisy. For years, Turkish Islamist authorities have suppressed freedom of speech, blocked social networks and cut off internet access. Dictator Erdogan calmly ordered the takeover of newspapers, radio, Internet agencies and magazines. With brute police force, with batons, tear gas and bullets. I recall the fates of editors and journalists from Cumhuriyet, Zaman, Samayulu TV. That was before the coup. And then there were people here who pretended not to see what was happening. Colleagues who favored the dictator negotiated visa liberalization with him, paying billions of euros to European taxpayers for his racketeering and extortion. After the coup, 3 more agencies, 45 newspapers, 16 TV channels, 23 radio stations, 15 magazines, 29 publishing houses were seized and closed. And in this room the hypocrisy continues. There are colleagues who continue to call the dictator a "strategic partner." Colleagues who pretend not to see the annexation of foreign territories in Syria and Iraq, the ongoing illegal occupation of Cyprus, hostile threats to the territorial integrity of members of the European Union, including against my homeland Bulgaria. Some of the perpetrators of this violence against freedom of speech are in this Chamber and in the seats of the European Commission. Erdogan is a dictator, Turkey is Islamizing. He who sows winds reaps storms.

name: Liliana RODRIGUES
text: - Madam President, dear Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, freedom of expression is also the right to disagree, this is called democracy. Journalists have the right to inform and they also have the right to their opinion. We are not going to talk about numbers, we have already talked about them here, but the greatest threat lies with the freedom to think, to say, to inform, to investigate. Turkey is already a dangerous regime, taking its people to the precipice of unique thinking. Is this a credible partner? Not at this moment. The situation of journalists has long been known, but also that of judges, academics, women, banned books, citizens who are silent. If the right to information were taken care of, perhaps we would have known earlier that there are dozens of children being enslaved in Turkey and that, instead of picking up books, they have a needle in their hands to sew the clothes of European multinationals. Of these, we await explanations. From Turkey, respect for the rule of law.

name: Georgi PIRINSKI
text: – Madam President, these claims by the Turkish President and Government that they are defending democracy, defending it against the coup, against subversion and against terrorism: the first message that this Chamber should send is that these claims are totally ridiculous given this situation regarding freedom of speech in Turkey. There are absolutely no grounds to take this Turkish Government seriously when it treats freedom of the press in this way which has been graphically described.  The second message that has to be sent from this Chamber is a very clear, categorical demand for all these people to be freed; to be set free as a first step if this Turkish Government wants to start re-opening any kind of meaningful dialogue with Europe.

name: Csaba SÓGOR
text: – Madam President, the fact that Reporters Without Borders in their survey of 180 countries rank Turkey in 150th place is very telling. Even Vladimir Putin’s Russia fares better in this regard. Turkey has 130 journalists in jail, 70 of them on charges related to the failed coup in July. Journalists are harassed, and the accusations range from ‘insulting the President’ to plain ‘terrorism’. In addition, as the government has been exercising emergency powers after the failed coup, there is virtually no possibility of checking Mr Erdoğan’s crackdown on perceived adversaries from the media, universities or public service.  The EU has to be clear that such practices cannot be accepted from a country that holds accession talks with it. The persecuted journalists expect no less from us.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, this is not the first time that this Parliament has called for greater freedom for the press and media in Turkey. Unfortunately, the events of last July worsened the situation, with an even greater contraction of freedoms, in particular that of expression. Some 2,500 journalists lost their jobs after the July 15 coup attempt. Reporters Without Borders reports at least 110 journalists in prison, including 70 arrested after the coup and 150 reported on the loose. In Turkey, a simple hypothesis by the investigators of affiliation with an outlawed organization or an insult to the President of the Republic is enough to end up in prison. Concrete respect, and not just in words, for rights and freedoms remains vital for a country aspiring to join the European Union. First of all, the European Union must work to ensure that European standards of democracy are guaranteed in this country, with no ifs and buts.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: ECR). - Madam President, recently the international public opinion has been watching Erdogan, the new Sultan, systematically and openly methodize the persecution and imprisonment of his political opponents. Press silencing is on the agenda. Following the failure of the coup, Erdogan has now revoked the licenses of dozens of media outlets and arrested hundreds of journalists. But instead of the European Union taking action against Turkey, it is voluntarily blinding and tolerating it. In other words, it tolerates Turkey, which continues to occupy 37% of the territory of the Republic of Cyprus. It tolerates Turkey, which constantly violates Greek airspace and maritime territorial waters. It tolerates Turkey and Erdogan, who are challenging the Lausanne Treaty. Finally, when will the European Union decide to take action against Turkey in order to really enforce international law in the region?

name: Javier COUSO PERMUY
text: -  Madam president;When I hear that Turkey is a country classified as safe for the European Union, I am outraged.Safe for whom?Because, for journalists, it is not.Taking advantage of the attempted coup against Erdogan, Erdogan is carrying out a coup against freedom of information: hundreds of journalists imprisoned, 150 media outlets closed.And this is a partner for the European Union?In this Parliament authentic inquisitorial autos-da-fé are being made against countries that, by no means, commit the atrocities of the Turkish Government;always small countries that dare to be sovereign against the powerful.But the European Union, today, sells its moral soul when it looks the other way for outsourcing control of refugees.Do something, something effective, or stop giving moral lessons to the world.Do you know why?Because they walk towards implosion out of moral unworthiness.

name: Klaus BUCHNER
text: - Madam President! I would like to draw your attention to the fact that two mayors were arrested tonight and a few hours ago at least two other members of the local Kurdish parliament. When I say "been arrested" it sounds very harmless. In the first time after their capture, these women are exposed to the most brutal mistreatment, above all incredibly brutal sexual assaults. In at least three of these cases, the arrests are directly related to a mission I attended over the weekend. We visited several Kurdish districts that have been attacked by the Turkish military, have been bombed, have been shelled even though there were still people there. Of course, the government didn't want us to see and document these things. A few weeks ago a sixteen-year-old was shot for taking a picture. I just want to see the brutal crackdown on any disclosure of information here.

name: Eduard KUKAN
text: - Our relations with Turkey are becoming significantly more complicated.I agree that we should make it clear that a country that wants to continue accession negotiations with the Union and calls for visa liberalization cannot suppress fundamental civil liberties, including freedom of the press.Censorship and arrest of journalists are not what bring confidence to our common dialogue.Nor are President Erdogan's sharp, unacceptable statements to the Union.Nevertheless, I think we need to continue the dialogue with Turkey.However, it is very important for us to make it clear that there are boundaries within which this dialogue should take place.I have such a very unpleasant feeling that we are currently moving far beyond these borders.

name: Julie WARD
text: – Madam President, on 28 September, RTÜK, which is the higher board of radio and TV in Turkey, issued a closure order covering 23 radio and TV stations, including Zarok TV, a Kurdish children’s cartoon channel. Colleagues, what have SpongeBob SquarePants or The Smurfs ever done or said that can be called a threat to society? The Zarok audience are children, who have been left staring at empty TV screens, wondering why they have been punished. The case of Zarok TV, an entity with no political aspect, has led many of us to believe that the Turkish government can ban anything Kurdish simply for being Kurdish.

name: Corina CREȚU
text: on behalf of the Vice-President of the Commission/High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy. – Madam President, thank you very much for this useful exchange. I thank all the honourable Members for their interventions. As I said at the beginning, this is not a new situation but it is a worrying situation. This is the second debate that we have had during this mandate about the freedom of the media in Turkey and what is happening now is totally unacceptable.  As I said at the beginning, free, diverse and independent media is essential in any democratic society. Without freedom of expression and freedom of the media an informed, active and engaged society is impossible. As you have underlined here, this is not only about the punishment of the journalists.  I was very happy to see many former journalists in this House, as I was one in my previous life, but I also think that it is the duty of all of us as politicians to fight, not only for the journalists but also for the elected people, the Members of Parliament, for the professors, the universities and for the mayors. So I think it is very important to address this issue. As I said at the beginning, I can assure you that the Commission addresses the issues raised here with the Turkish authorities at every engagement and continuously expresses concerns about the significant shortcomings affecting human rights in Turkey. We urge Turkey urgently to act to defuse a tense political climate which creates an environment restricting freedom of speech. These circumstances make continued engagement and a constructive dialogue with Turkey more critical than ever.  In any case the Commission continues to believe that the accession process is the best framework for advancing reforms in Turkey. Advancing the preparatory work towards opening Chapters 23 and 24, on fundamental rights, justice, freedom and security, would be important as it will provide Turkey with a comprehensive roadmap for enforcing these essential areas, including press freedom. Parliament adds, of course, a significant contribution to the debate on Turkey and we very much value this opportunity for an exchange of views.  Finally, I have also noted and welcome the presence here tonight of a Turkish journalist, Can Dündar, a prominent voice in the Turkish debate, and I would like to add his name in honour of the others who are in jail or who have suffered or been assassinated. So in this matter we, the Commission and Parliament, are working hand in hand. I would like just to inform you that the Commission will issue a country report early in November. Until now it has been called a progress report, but it is obvious that we cannot speak about a progress report in the case of Turkey. All your opinions will of course be taken into consideration when the Commission issues this country report.

name: Sylvie GUILLAUME
text: I have received eight motions for resolutions in accordance with Rule 123 (2).The debate is closed.The vote will take place on Thursday, October 27, 2016, at 12 noon.Written statements (Article 162)

name: Isabella ADINOLFI
text: in writing.- After the failed coup, the situation of journalists in Turkey is to be considered critical.Many of them were in fact arrested without any evidence of criminal activity.I believe that the detention of journalists for the content of their articles and the closure of a very large number of information centers are aspects that dangerously threaten the democracy of a country.The European Union cannot stand by, decisive action is needed to ensure that the fundamental rights of every human being are respected.

name: Petras AUŠTREVIČIUS
text: in writing. – The European Parliament has numerous times expressed its condemnation of the illegal military coup attempt of 15 July, however, the aftermath of the event and increasing restrictions of civil liberties are highly alarming. A country that has been planning on joining the European Union has been denying its citizens a core EU value – freedom of speech. President Recep Tayyip Erdoğan since the coup attempt has closed around 125 media outlets leaving thousands of Turkish journalists unemployed and around 130 journalists detained or currently in prison. Turkey has jailed more journalists than China or Iran, and has proved itself to be the biggest prison for journalists in the world. The failed military coup is now used by Erdoğan to implement Turkey’s anti-terrorism law which is the main tool of oppression used against journalists. This law was one of the key talking points in the discussion about visa liberalisation for the Turkish citizens, yet it has seen no reform. The dire situation in Turkey requires major attention from both the European Union and the European journalists in order to bring the attention of the world wide community to this issue and to further stop the erosion of civil liberties in Turkey.

name: Cristian-Silviu BUŞOI
text: signed up. - Turkey has a long-standing relationship with the European Union, being a strategic partner for both the Union and NATO, ensuring stability in the area. Today, however, democracy in this candidate state is under threat. The failed coup attempt, which I fully condemn, has come to serve as a pretext for resorting to excesses in relation to the rule of law. The situation of journalists in Turkey is a recurring topic on Turkey's European agenda, as it has deteriorated sharply in recent years, not just after 15 July. Freedom of expression is one of the fundamental values ​​of the Union, which the Turkish authorities must ensure, including media pluralism, free access to content on the Internet - currently blocked - and through transparent procedures for each court case (taking into account that 130 journalists and writers were arrested or charged). I therefore call on the Turkish authorities to stop the arbitrary deprivation of liberty of journalists and media people, completely restoring justice and ensuring the rule of law.

name: Sylvie GUILLAUME
text: The next item is the debate on the statement by the Vice-President of the Commission and High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy on nuclear security and non-proliferation (2016/2936 (RSP)).

name: Corina CREȚU
text: on behalf of the Vice-President of the Commission/High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy. – Madam President, thank you for this opportunity to address the issues of nuclear security and non-proliferation. The Vice-President/High Representative is in the Dominican Republic at a very important conference for Latin America. I will begin my remarks by saying that first of all, the risk of terrorists releasing nuclear or radiological materials needs to be taken into account in our overall efforts to prevent terrorist attacks. Responsibility for ensuring nuclear security lies with national governments, but international cooperation in this area is and will remain crucial. The EU is strongly committed to ensuring the highest level of nuclear security, both in Europe and worldwide. I have said before, during our debate on Belarus, what we are doing, and we are very much concerned about what is happening in this field. The commitment of the EU to nuclear security and the progress achieved in recent years are described in detail in a joint staff working document issued on 9 March 2016 entitled ‘EU efforts to strengthen nuclear security’. Allow me now to briefly highlight some of the EU policies and actions.  As regards the legislative framework, the Euratom Treaty continues to be the basis of the EU’s activity on nuclear issues. Through Euratom, the EU operates an effective regional nuclear safeguard system, which includes nuclear material accountancy, verification through onsite inspections, regular reporting, and technical and scientific support for the EU Member States. All this in close cooperation, of course, with the International Atomic Energy Agency.  The EU can claim major credit for promoting the entry into force, in May this year, of the crucial 2005 amendment to the Convention on the Physical Protection of Nuclear Material. All 28 EU Member States, as well as Euratom, have ratified the amendment and the European External Action Service has conducted diplomatic outreach on behalf of its entry into force. The European Union will continue to help states to fully implement the provisions of the amended Convention and the Atomic Energy Agency to promote universal adherence to it. In the area of combatting illicit trafficking of nuclear and radiological materials, the EU has supported the effective implementation worldwide of UN Security Council Resolution 1540 through financing and capacity building. We have established a network of chemical, biological, radiological and nuclear centres of excellence, which today counts 54 partner countries in eight regions of the world, with about 50 projects funded and around 300 people trained. It is funded under the Instrument contributing to Stability and Peace, in accordance with the EU CBRN Action Plan of 2010. The EU supports the central role of the International Atomic Energy [agency], and international cooperation for improving the level of nuclear security worldwide, and is looking forward to the International Conference on Nuclear Security being organised from 5 to 9 December 2016 in Vienna. Turning now to nuclear non-proliferation, the new EU global strategy, unveiled in June this year, confirmed that the proliferation of weapons of mass destruction and their delivery systems remains a growing threat to Europe and the wider world. The European Union will strongly support the expanding membership, universalisation, full implementation and the enforcement of multilateral disarmament, non-proliferation and arms control treaties and regimes. We will use every means at our disposal to assist in resolving the proliferation crisis as we successfully did on the Iranian nuclear programme. More specifically, I would like to mention two major treaties, the Nuclear Non-Proliferation Treaty and the Comprehensive Nuclear Test Ban Treaty, as well as a couple of regional issues.  The European Union and its Member States agree on the importance of upholding and strengthening the authority and integrity of the NPT which has contributed to international peace, security and stability for more than 40 years. We call for the implementation of all obligations and commitments assumed under the Treaty or undertaken during the previous review conferences. The European Union has been and remains a strong supporter of the CTBT and its organisation and is working towards the entry into force of the Treaty. Of course, all 28 Member States have ratified this Treaty, and together with all the Member States in this 20th anniversary year of the Treaty’s opening for signature, the European Union is conducting a number of actions promoting the Treaty and its organisation, based on an action plan adopted at the beginning of the year.  The European Union welcomes the recent UN Security Council Resolution 2310 which urges all states that have either not signed or ratified this Treaty to do so without further delay as it is an important step forward towards the entry into force of the Treaty.  I warmly welcome the act that in June this year Parliament’s Committee on Foreign Affairs (AFET) held an exchange of views on this Treaty, with the participation of the Executive Secretary Mr Zerbo and of course High Representative Mogherini.  Finally, turning to some regional proliferation issues, the European Union has played a key role in the negotiations leading to the nuclear deal with Iran, the Joint Comprehensive Plan of Action, and we have already issued three reports confirming that Iran is sticking to its nuclear commitments. High Representative Mogherini, as coordinator of the Joint Commission, is playing a key role in the implementation of the deal. The EU condemns in the strongest possible terms all the nuclear and ballistic tests conducted by North Korea. Achieving complete, verifiable and irreversible denuclearisation of the Korean peninsula in a peaceful manner is essential for maintaining peace and stability on the Korean peninsula and in North-East Asia at large. Thank you for your attention, and I am looking forward to our debate.

name: Andrey KOVATCHEV
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. - Madam President, Commissioner, concepts from my childhood such as 'nuclear asylum' and 'nuclear explosion training', which I thought belonged to the past, are unfortunately returning. It is insane, suicidal and barbaric to use nuclear weapons, whether only to threaten or to achieve geopolitical goals. I give two examples: a few years ago, Russia deployed missile systems that could carry nuclear warheads in Kaliningrad - very close to or on the very border of the European Union. The statements of leading Russian politicians that Russia has the right to deploy and store nuclear weapons on the territory of Crimea are also worrying. Equally worrying is the new Russian doctrine of 2014, which allows the use of nuclear weapons against countries that do not have them, as well as Russia's decision to terminate the Russian-American agreement on the utilization of plutonium and link it to inadmissible requests. One month ago, North Korea conducted another nuclear test in gross violation of UN resolutions and is thought to be able to mount warheads on its missiles. North Korea must honor its international obligations by returning to the negotiating table and ending its nuclear program immediately. Increasing the security of nuclear weapons positioned in non-nuclear states, such as Turkey, in the immediate vicinity of military action in Syria, must also be our immediate priority. One of the most dangerous scenarios is the fall of nuclear weapons into the hands of terrorist groups or non-state actors. Strengthening the mandate of the International Atomic Energy Agency and the inclusion of non-proliferation clauses in the European Union's treaties with third countries are steps in the right direction.

name: Ana GOMES
text: on behalf of the S & amp; D Group. - Madam President, the resolution, Parliament, can make a difference by a broad consensus on a central issue for global security. There are no excuses and it is not worthwhile to find escapes to try to justify the unjustifiable. Anyone who does not support this resolution will have much to explain to European citizens who care about the future of humanity. The resolution focuses on three points: first, an appeal to ban all nuclear weapons and to constructive participation by the European Union in the international conference proposed by the UN Open Working Group, approved by the General Assembly by a large majority, to negotiate the legally binding instrument for multilateral nuclear disarmament. Second, to assign a mandate to the High Representative with the power to contribute to these same negotiations, in line with the approved global strategy. It was Mrs. Mogherini herself who suggested it here, in this House. A European Parliament resolution could untie the gag that some Member States want to impose on it in this area, which also involves combating one of the most frightening forms of terrorist threat, as Mrs Crețu also underlined. Third, this is the last opportunity we have to pass a resolution on nuclear disarmament before the start of the new round of negotiations at the international level. Failure to do so will be to consciously remain on the sidelines, in the year that celebrates the 20th anniversary of the opening of the signing of the Nuclear Test Ban Treaty. These negotiations, if successful, will reinforce non-proliferation and disarmament objectives and obligations under the Nuclear Non-Proliferation Treaty, to which even the European Union's nuclear states are signatories, helping to create conditions for a world without nuclear weapons. , with a tremendous transformative balance for Humanity at the political, economic and, obviously, global security levels. I am grateful for the collaboration of all colleagues and political groups that contributed to the very substantial text in the resolution that we will vote on tomorrow.

name: Anna FOTYGA
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Madam President, for a long time, Russia was considered a responsible steward of nuclear arsenals. This situation changed rapidly with the annexation of Crimea and militarisation of this peninsula. This step not only undermined the Budapest Memorandum but the whole system of international non-proliferation and the credibility of this system. It was aggravated quite recently by the deployment of Iskander-M nuclear-capable missiles to Kaliningrad and the testing of further missiles. International communities should reconsider their policies vis-à-vis Russia and find an effective way of deterring this country.

name: Urmas PAET
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Madam President, the European security situation has grown increasingly fragile. The global security environment has deteriorated considerably, bringing about different threats. This brings us to an era where more and more states see nuclear weapons as an active deterrent, and we are faced with a situation where, instead of reducing the number of nuclear weapons in the world, we see their re-emergence. In addition to states actively developing their nuclear weapons, for example North Korea and others like Russia, boasting around making statements on the importance of nuclear deterrence, bringing Iskander short-range missiles to Kaliningrad and conducting exercises and overflights flights involving nuclear-capable systems, there is also a threat of terrorism. The fear that terrorists will get a hold on either a nuclear weapon or materials is real, and all countries must be vigilant to make sure that this will not happen. In order to decrease the possibility of a huge nuclear disaster in this world of serious contradictions, we have to reduce the number of nuclear weapons, with the aim of eliminating them altogether. This cannot be done by any nuclear state alone but needs to be a concerted effort. We must come to an understanding that, in order to reduce the amount of nuclear weapons, all nuclear states must do that. There are different possibilities for achieving a world free of nuclear weapons. The ratification and implementation of the international legal instruments regarding nuclear security must be broadened. The CTBT treaty should be ratified by states that have not yet done so. The Non-Proliferation Treaty needs to be further strengthened. To effectively counter nuclear terrorism we need international cooperation, including the sharing of information between states. Also, it is important for the nuclear states to have a dialogue and decide on a legally-binding instrument to prohibit nuclear weapons.

name: Sabine LÖSING
text: on behalf of the GUE / NGL Group. - Madam President! The Nuclear Non-Proliferation Treaty was a consequence of the atomic bombs being dropped on Hiroshima and Nagasaki. The USA, and thus the leading power in NATO today, which is known as the guarantor of peace, is the only state that has used the terrible atomic bombs against civilians. The threat of nuclear weapons is not a legitimate political or military means - it must never be again! But even two decades after the end of the Cold War, thousands of nuclear weapons remain a terrible threat worldwide. This threat can only be mastered by a firm will for peace. A will for peace that is attested by confidence-building measures, according to the conference proposed by the UN working group next year and the negotiations on legally binding measures to abolish all nuclear weapons. It is imperative that all nuclear weapon states and within the framework of NATO strategy rule out first use, the halt of all modernization plans for nuclear weapons and means of delivery and the withdrawal of all US nuclear weapons from European soil. What is needed is a multilateral treaty, signed and ratified by all states, on complete nuclear disarmament, until then no proliferation and a ban on nuclear weapons tests, and the establishment of an effective control and implementation system. Without substantial and sustained progress towards a world free of nuclear weapons, this threat to humanity will remain uncontrollable.

name: Klaus BUCHNER
text: on behalf of the Verts / ALE Group.- Madam President!I've changed my concept.I am one of the authors of the report that will be voted on tomorrow, but your speech, Commissioner, led me to raise a very different issue.In Europe, e.g.B. in Munich, there are still research reactors that work with highly enriched uranium.This uranium is the essential component of atomic bombs.Anyone who has this type of reactor practically has the bomb.Please ensure that all research reactors are finally converted to medium-enriched uranium and, above all, that this also happens outside of the European Union, where the situation is even more dangerous.Any terrorist can use it to build atomic bombs.

name: Laurenţiu REBEGA
text: on behalf of the ENF Group. - The nuclear security agenda means much more than the agreement signed last year with Iran. Although the European Union claims the rights of a decisive victory in relation to the Tehran authorities, we must not lose sight of the overall picture of security, which often indicates that Brussels' concerns remain disproportionate. We forget that the success story of the European Union's relationship with Iran is overshadowed by unconventional nuclear exercises taking place in different parts of the globe, asymmetric and hybrid wars, cyber threats and acts of terrorism. To these are added the inconclusive results of the last summit on nuclear security, which took place in Washington a few months ago, where Iran was one of the biggest absentees. I believe that this agreement is presented in a favorable light to the European Union, which, however, highlights only a momentary success, when, in fact, the situation is incomplete and biased. It has already been 46 years since the ratification of the nuclear non-proliferation treaty, and what was indeed achieved last year remains for the time being only a relative and highly publicized victory.

name: Julie WARD
text: – Madam President, I am very glad to see this resolution being brought for a debate in the European Parliament, which I hope will allow the EU to engage in the important international process that is taking place at the UN today. Over the last few years, civil society activists, academics, diplomats and governments have worked to make clear to the international community that the humanitarian impacts of nuclear weapons are so utterly horrific that they cannot be justified under international law. Together we must work to make that an international consensus, which will make our world safer and more humane. The international community has already worked to ban landmines, chemical and biological weapons, and cluster bombs. Now we must work together for a world free of nuclear weapons.
